headline: Higher Calling for a Philippine Entrepreneur
abstract: MANILA—  Lucio Tan is a hero or a tax-evader, depending on your point of view. But by nearly everyone's reckoning here, the tobacco and beer baron is a leading power broker in the Philippines and probably the country's richest man.

headline: EU Votes Early for Yeltsin's Russia
abstract: BRUSSELS—  In another demonstration of Western support for President Boris N. Yeltsin, European Union foreign ministers on Monday approved a plan for closer cooperation with Russia on trade and security issues.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF ANALOGY FALL AFTER PURCHASES POSTPONED
abstract: Shares of Analogy Inc. fell 34 percent yesterday after an analyst said that the General Motors Corporation, one of its largest clients, had postponed purchases from the software developer indefinitely. John Barr, an analyst at Needham & Company, also said he had lowered his fiscal 1997 and 1998 earnings estimates for Analogy, of Beaverton, Ore. Analogy shares fell $4.50, to $8.75.

headline: Yeltsin, in Another Political Purge, Dismisses 7 Top Generals
abstract: In a political purge, President Boris N. Yeltsin today dismissed seven senior generals with ties to the ousted Defense Minister, Gen. Pavel S. Grachev.         The dismissals were intended to polish Mr. Yeltsin's image as a reformer and  strengthen the authority of Aleksandr I. Lebed, a former election rival of Mr. Yeltsin who was recently named his national security adviser.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: A Compromise Plan to Address Workplace Ergonomics Stays on the Shelf
abstract: In his Manhattan office, Dr. Emil Pascarelli leafed through the files of a day's worth of patients: a computer programmer, a television producer, a systems engineer, a magazine editor, a help-desk worker at a telephone company and a couple of others.         They came to Dr. Pascarelli with severe pain and weakness in the arms and hands. For them, the simple task of gripping a pen or a telephone can be a challenge, making work excruciating or impossible.

headline: For the Corporate Penske, No Fear of Sharp Turns
abstract: CHALLENGING the venerable Indianapolis 500 by staging a rival auto race at your own speedway with some of the world's top drivers may be the height of brashness. But then, Roger S. Penske has made a lucrative business career out of taking high-stakes gambles.         Mr. Penske, an entrepreneur whose racing team has won the Indy 500 a record 10 times over three decades, is one of two dozen wealthy businessmen starting the U.S. 500 today at Michigan International Speedway, shortly after the Indiana classic gets under way. They made their move -- deciding to lease the track from Mr. Penske -- after a dispute with the owner of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway  over qualifying rules.

headline: G.M.'s Monthly Sales Drop While Chrysler's Increase
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced today that its March sales dropped 2.2 percent from levels a year earlier because a long strike interrupted its production. But the Chrysler Corporation reported an 8.1 percent gain for the month.         One reason G.M. car sales declined, according to Ed Lechtzin, a company spokesman, was that it delayed until April the delivery of some cars to fleet buyers in order to conserve its scarce supply of cars for retail buyers during the 17-day strike. The work stoppage involved two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, that led to a gradual closing of most of the company's North American assembly plants and some shortages of cars on dealer lots.

headline: Ruling Curbs Jury's Role On Patents
abstract: In one of the most important patent decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that in a patent infringement suit it was up to judges,  rather than juries, to resolve the crucial issue of what a patent means.         While the decision does not completely oust juries from patent cases, it may  have that effect as a practical matter in many infringement suits. The interpretation of the patent claim -- the precise definition of the scope of the patent over which the patent owner exercises a lawful monopoly -- is often the most important aspect of the case, and once a judge has decided this question, there may be nothing left for the jury to do.

headline: Neither Ridicule Nor Rancor Halts Gorbachev Election Bid
abstract: The last leader of the Soviet Union stepped out of his car on the edge of his boyhood village on Wednesday and looked expectantly at the small group of people gathered.         "So, who is meeting me here?" he asked jovially. He looked closer and frowned as he recognized only Western reporters. "It's mostly foreigners. I want to see  someone I know."

headline: Wife of Suharto Is Dead
abstract: Siti Hartinah Suharto, the wife of President Suharto of Indonesia, died today of a heart attack, a spokesman for the President said. She was 72.         Mrs. Suharto died in the Gatot Subroto military hospital in central Jakarta.  The Government ordered a week of mourning.

headline: Mortgage Rates Dip
abstract: Mortgage rates inched down this week, with 30-year fixed-rate loans at 7.92 percent, compared with 7.95 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. The average interest rate for 15-year fixed-rate loans also fell, to 7.43 percent from 7.48 percent. The average adjustable-rate loan inched down to to 5.74 percent from 5.75 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reckitt & Colman Sells a U.S. Unit
abstract: Reckitt & Colman P.L.C., a British household goods maker, said yesterday that it had sold its United States personal products division to J. W. Childs Associates L.P. for $123 million to concentrate on its main business of household products. Reckitt & Colman, based in London, which makes Lysol disinfectant and Woolite fabric wash, said it would receive $108 million in cash and a loan note, payable in seven and a half years, for the remainder.          The sale includes Wet Ones towelettes, Diaparene baby care products, Binaca  breath spray and Mr. Bubble bubble bath. J. W. Childs is a Massachusetts-based investment management company.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Donna Karan to Offer 10.75 Million Shares
abstract: The New York fashion designer Donna Karan International Inc. plans to offer 10.75 million common shares in an initial public offering, selling more than half the company to new investors.         The upscale clothing designer said today in a filing with the Securities and  Exchange Commission that it planned to put 7.53 million shares up for sale in the United States and Canada and to offer 3.22 million shares to investors in other countries.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FTP SOFTWARE CUTS PRICE FOR FIREFOX COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: FTP Software Inc., which agreed to acquire Firefox Communications Inc. in January, said yesterday that it had reduced the price it would pay to $60 million, 28 percent less than the amount originally negotiated. FTP Software's chief executive, David Zirkle, said that slower growth in the markets served by  Firefox had prompted the companies to lower the price. The shares of both companies, which produce computer software, fell yesterday in Nasdaq trading. The shares of FTP Software, which is based in North Andover, Mass., lost $1.875, to $11.75, while the stock of Firefox, which is based in San Jose, Calif., fell  $2, to $9.25.

headline: Acclaim Takes a Charge as It Refocuses
abstract: Acclaim Entertainment Inc. said today that it would get out of the cartridge  video game business to focus on personal computer games and that it had taken a  related charge of $51.2 million.         Acclaim, a video game software company, said it was taking the charge in its  second quarter, ended Feb. 29.

headline: Europe Jobless Rate Rises
abstract: The European Union said today that its unemployment rate rose to 11 percent in February after being stable in the two previous months. Some 18.3 million people are out of work in the 15-nation bloc.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COX TO ACQUIRE OWNER OF 18 AM AND FM RADIO STATIONS
abstract: Cox Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that its broadcasting unit had agreed to  acquire Newcity Communications Inc. of Bridgeport, Conn., for $250 million. Newcity consists of 18 AM and FM radio stations. After the acquisition is completed, the closely held Cox's radio franchise would operate 37 stations. Cox Enterprises, a media company based in Atlanta, is the majority owner of Cox Communications Inc., a cable-television concern.

headline: Utility Support For Electric Cars
abstract: The General Motors Corporation and the Boston Edison Corporation said today that they had agreed to develop an infrastructure to support electric vehicles in the Northeast and to market the vehicles to utilities and governments in the  region.         The companies will work together to install Delco Electronics chargers in the nine Northeast states: New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and the six New England states.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS;Describing intelligence through a virtual symphony.
abstract: IN a large black room, two stories high, on the ground floor of the Media Lab of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, the composer Tod Machover is working on the model of a brain.         Hanging from the top of a triangular prism of metal struts are two large white pods that appear to have been deposited by an alien being; they will eventually be covered with what appear to be soft plastic urchins. On a PC, hooked up to the Internet, a web of neurons appears, represented by a panel of lights, which flash in different colors as they are touched by the cursor. Nearby, a singer, hitting the right pitch, causes an image of an eye to open on  a monitor, until the screen is suffused in brilliant white light.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Champion Puts Account in Review
abstract: The Champion sportswear division of the Sara Lee Corporation has placed its account in review. With billings estimated at $10 million, the account has been  handled by the Merkley Newman Harty unit of the Omnicom Group in New York for the last year and a half.         Peggy Dyer, senior vice president for marketing at Champion in Winston-Salem, N.C., confirmed a report of the review this week in Adweek. She said Merkley Newman had been invited to participate but declined to identify other contenders. Adweek listed three New York agencies, all already on Sara Lee's roster, as possibilities: Ammirati Puras Lintas, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which handles accounts like Hillshire Farm; Grey Advertising, which handles accounts like Endust, and TBWA Chiat/Day, also owned by Omnicom, which handles accounts like the Wonderbra.

headline: INVESTING IT;The Widest of 401(k) Options: Invest It Yourself
abstract: GIVEN the thousands of flavors that investments come in these days, the situation is hardly unexpected: Many workers chafe at the handful of options that their companies, carefully or not, have selected for their 401(k) retirement plans. "Why is there no bond investment in the mix?" they may ask. "And why not include this delicious foreign equity fund?"         Responding to these kinds of complaints, as well as to Government guidelines, companies have added to their 401(k) menus in recent years, expanding from the three or four funds that used to be standard to one dozen, two dozen or more.   But they have also begun to embrace a radically different option that can forever put to rest the complaints about too little choice, even if it can be risky for many workers. It is a self-managed 401(k) account that lets an employee choose among thousands of stocks, bonds and funds while still being able to invest in the plan's other choices.

headline: Tirana Journal;Dictator Liked Bunkers. My, They Mushroomed!
abstract: There is paranoia. And then there was Enver Hoxha's brand of paranoia.         The brutal, eccentric, isolationist dictator of Albania for more than four decades, Mr. Hoxha sealed off this small southern European nation from the outside world, insisting that Albania faced enemies from every side, on every border.

headline: Peres Backers and Peace Activists Left in Gloom
abstract: A cloud of gloom has settled over Israel's peace advocates, Labor Party professionals and other supporters of Prime Minister Shimon Peres after his unexpected defeat at the hands of Benjamin Netanyahu.         It is not just that an election was lost, though it was particularly deflating to lose by less than 1 percent after being 15 points ahead in the polls less than four months ago. But there is also the disheartening feeling among Peres supporters that after three years of imagining a peace with the Palestinians, a majority of Israelis do not share their dreams.

headline: Age Bias Accord By British Gas
abstract: British Gas has agreed to pay $12 million to hundreds of women who were forced to retire at 60, five years earlier than men, a union said last week.         The women will receive on average of $34,500, according to their union, Unison, which has been fighting with British Gas for a decade. The union is one of the largest in the country and is particularly strong among public employees.

headline: U.S. Says Profits Rose in Quarter
abstract: Profits of manufacturers rose strongly at the beginning of 1996 after a weak  finish in the closing quarter of 1995, the Commerce Department said today.         A quarterly survey of about 7,900 companies showed that profits rose to a seasonally adjusted 5.8 cents a dollar of sales from a revised 5 cents in the fourth quarter last year.

headline: Plight of Kashmir Captives
abstract: Western tourists, including an American, held hostage by separatist guerrillas in Kashmir have begun their 11th month in captivity with no end to the ordeal in sight.         Negotiations between Indian authorities and the militant group that calls itself Al-Faran, which is holding the four hostages, broke down months ago. Officials say the tourists are alive and in good health, but that there is no progress in efforts to free the men.

headline: Economic Scene;Teen-age childbearing: the cost is put at $8.9 billion a year.
abstract: AN ambitious study issued last week by the Robin Hood Foundation in New York  called "Kids Having Kids" will no doubt convince any remaining skeptics that teen-age childbearing is an economic as well as a social disaster.         But the research will disappoint those who assume that anyone going to the trouble to document these costs must have a fix in mind. "We haven't got the slightest idea what to do about teen-age pregnancy," said Douglas Besharov, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute who was an adviser to the  authors of the study.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TAKEOVER IS DENIED AS SYQUEST STOCK PRICE TUMBLES
abstract: The shares of Syquest Technology Inc. plunged yesterday after the company's chief financial officer punctured takeover rumors. Syquest fell $7, to $10.875,  in Nasdaq trading of 13.9 million shares. The shares nearly tripled in the previous five days of trading, but in an interview on Thursday, the chief financial officer, John Luhtala, denied that the company had been approached about a takeover. "We're not engaged in talks to sell the company," he said. Earlier this month, the company hired the investment banker Needham & Company to find a buyer or new financing. Syquest makes computer disk drives with removable cartridges, which greatly expand the amount of data that users can save.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CROWN CASINO AGREES TO BUY MISSISSIPPI BELLE II
abstract: The Crown Casino Corporation signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Mississippi Belle II Inc., a privately held riverboat casino operator, for $40 million. The Mississippi Belle riverboat casino, which is in Clinton, Iowa, has been profitable since its opening in June 1991, Crown said. The riverboat contains 485 slot machines, 20 table games, and on-board dining and entertainment areas. Crown's shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $3.3125.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;10 Japan Banks Had a Bad Year
abstract: Japan's seven trust and three longer-term credit banks reported sharp losses  for the fiscal year today, reflecting huge writeoffs of bad loans.         The 10 institutions lost a total of 1.805 trillion yen, or $16.8 billion. Sumitomo Trust Bank fared worst, with a pretax loss of 331 billion yen -- more than its last five years of profit.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;For Social Security, More Gain and Less Pain
abstract: WILL Social Security be there when my time comes?"        A majority of Americans do not think so. And a recent report from the Social  Security trustees reinforces the fear, warning that the system will not survive past 2029 if program financing isn't brought into long-term balance with obligations.

headline: For Texas Instruments, Some Bragging Rights
abstract: Texas Instruments claimed victory yesterday in a bitter six-year dispute over the invention of the computer on a chip, a crucial component that has fueled the microelectronics era.         The company said the United States Patent Office had recently affirmed that one of its former engineers, Gary W. Boone, was the inventor of the single-chip  microcontroller, a device that is now embedded in millions of electronic products.

headline: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN AND COMMUNIST RIVAL TO BE PAIRED IN RUSSIA RUNOFF
abstract: Registering both their fear of the past and a cry for change, Russian voters  on Sunday gave President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Communist opponent, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, enough support to face each other in a runoff election next month that will decide the future of the country.         According to preliminary results from 60 percent of the electorate and a nationwide survey of voters leaving the polls, Mr. Yeltsin was leading this morning with about 35 percent, followed closely by Mr. Zyuganov with nearly 32 percent.

headline: Rivals Bicker In Monrovia As Cease-Fire Holds, Barely
abstract: Liberian leaders tried to shore up a tenuous truce today even as sporadic sniper fire rang out in Monrovia and young thugs raced through the streets brandishing assault rifles.         With only an estimated 50 Americans remaining in Monrovia, American troops ended their full-scale evacuation effort on Sunday. About 500 Americans and more than 1,100 other foreigners were lifted to safety since violence convulsed the capital nine days ago.

headline: Archer Said To Be in Talks On U.S. Case
abstract: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company has entered into substantive negotiations  with the Justice Department to settle potential criminal charges of price-fixing, people involved in the case said yesterday.         The talks with the Government deal only with the corporation's culpability for wrongdoing, these people said, and would not resolve any cases against individual executives who are being investigated by Federal prosecutors. The company and at least two executives have already been told by the Government that they are likely to be indicted, people with knowledge of the matter said.

headline: Dole '96 Button Not Necessarily Business Attire
abstract: As a longtime supporter of President Clinton, John H. Bryan, the chairman of  the Sara Lee Corporation, is used to having his politics questioned by other chief executives, most of whom are staunch Republicans. "Every now and then, someone will check in and ask if I still back him," Mr. Bryan said last week. "I always profess my loyalty."         Lately -- and surprisingly -- Mr. Bryan has been getting less ribbing.

headline: Media: TELEVISION;Entrepreneurs race big cable companies to get new cable services to viewers.
abstract: HUNDREDS of new cable services are on the drawing boards, from the privately  owned My Pet TV and the Love Channel to Nick at Nite's TV Land and the News Corporation's Fox News Network. The owners of these services have been banking on the arrival of the digital boxes that would let cable operators offer 500 channels.         But the digital boxes have been late to market. "They are coming, but we are  not looking at tens of millions of them out there," said Larry Gerbrandt, a cable programming analyst at Paul Kagan Associates. "Most people think it will be three to five years before there is real critical mass."

headline: U.S. Charges Sexual Harassment At a Mitsubishi Plant in Illinois
abstract: Federal officials accused a Japanese-owned auto maker today of allowing sexual harassment on an "outrageous scale" at an Illinois plant.         The lawsuit contends that as many as 700 women were subjected to groping and  sexual remarks, creating a "hostile and abusive work environment" that went unchecked for years at the Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America plant. The  subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, of Tokyo, was formerly known as Diamond-Star Motors.

headline: EARNING IT;Summertime, and Working in a Home Office Isn't Easy
abstract: VERY year about this time, Elaine Carey has a meeting with her children, Alexander, 12, and Sofia, 13. The subject of the talk is Ms. Carey's home office and the rules the children must follow in the summer so they do not disrupt her  work.        "My husband and I remind the kids that I am working and am not here as their  summer entertainment counselor," she said.

headline: Serb Gangs Rule in Last-Chance Fief of U.N.
abstract: Chez Daddy's nightclub changed owners a few days ago in a business transaction that, as so often happens in the Balkans, dispensed with impediments like money and legal titles.         "A gang of men came in with guns," said a waiter, who did not want to give his name. "They ordered the old guards out and beat the owner until he was unconscious. All those men sitting there with the pistols in their belts are the new staff."

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Gain On Treasuries For 3d Session
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities were higher yesterday despite a lack of new economic data.         While bonds have now posted gains in three consecutive sessions, traders and  analysts say the market has not shifted from its bearish tone.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit at Division Trims Thomson's Loss
abstract: Thomson S.A. said yesterday that its net loss narrowed in 1995, aided by improved results at its Thomson-CSF unit, which posted its first profit in three years.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PENNZOIL IN DEAL TO SELL RANCH TO A TURNER COMPANY
abstract: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Vermejo Park Ranch to Vermejo Park L.L.C., a Georgia company owned by Ted Turner, the media executive. Pennzoil, a maker of oil and lubricants, said it would retain the rights to oil and gas interests on the ranch. A Pennzoil spokesman said the  588,000-acre ranch in northern New Mexico and southern Colorado is a hunting and fishing resort and cattle ranch. Pennzoil, based in Houston, said the sale of the ranch, combined with other recent sales of Houston apartment and commercial  properties, would generate about $103 million in cash. The company will use the  proceeds primarily to reduce debt.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;More Job Cuts Planned By Credit Lyonnais
abstract: Continuing a drive to reduce staff and increase productivity, the troubled French bank Credit Lyonnais said yesterday that it would shed more than 14 percent of its French work force between now and the end of 1998. The 5,000 job  cuts would lower the state-controlled bank's payroll in France to 30,000. The bank had already said it planned to cut 5 percent of its work force a year in 1996 and 1997.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Show Little Change On Treasuries
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday, retreating from early gains after the Treasury said it would sell some notes and bonds more often.         Bonds rose early in the session after a survey showed that prices paid by manufacturers rose less than expected. The report prompted a wave of short-covering as investors who had bet that bond prices would fall bought securities to limit their losses. In a short sale, an investor sells a borrowed  security hoping to buy it back at a lower price, and thus profit from the difference.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: OVATEK INTERNATIONAL INC., Boynton Beach, Fla., named Gaston Oxman president, effective in July. He will replace Frank J. Cooney.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Retreat on Forecasts Of Improved Planting Weather
abstract: Corn prices fell yesterday after weather forecasts showed improved conditions for planting, though an Agriculture Department economist warned of isolated shortages before the crop arrives.         In other activity, cattle prices rose while heating oil fell.

headline: Enhancing Leadership
abstract: To the Editor:         "Away at Management Camp and Feeling Alone" (Earning It, April 28), discussed a one-week leadership course conducted by my organization, the Center for Creative Leadership, but said we had not studied the week's long-term effect on  participants.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Michael Burns, executive vice president and core group director overseeing the General Mills Inc. account at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was promoted to the new position of vice chairman.

headline: Higher Calling for a Philippine Entrepreneur
abstract: MANILA—  Lucio Tan is a hero or a tax-evader, depending on your point of view. But by nearly everyone's reckoning here, the tobacco and beer baron is a leading power broker in the Philippines and probably the country's richest man.

headline: EU Votes Early for Yeltsin's Russia
abstract: BRUSSELS—  In another demonstration of Western support for President Boris N. Yeltsin, European Union foreign ministers on Monday approved a plan for closer cooperation with Russia on trade and security issues.

Lebed, a former election rival of Mr. Yeltsin who was recently named his national security adviser.

They came to Dr. Pascarelli with severe pain and weakness in the arms and hands. For them, the simple task of gripping a pen or a telephone can be a challenge, making work excruciating or impossible.

headline: For the Corporate Penske, No Fear of Sharp Turns
abstract: CHALLENGING the venerable Indianapolis 500 by staging a rival auto race at your own speedway with some of the world's top drivers may be the height of brashness. But then, Roger S. Penske has made a lucrative business career out of taking high-stakes gambles.         Mr. Penske, an entrepreneur whose racing team has won the Indy 500 a record 10 times over three decades, is one of two dozen wealthy businessmen starting the U.S. 500 today at Michigan International Speedway, shortly after the Indiana classic gets under way. They made their move -- deciding to lease the track from Mr. Penske -- after a dispute with the owner of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway  over qualifying rules.

headline: G.M.'s Monthly Sales Drop While Chrysler's Increase
abstract: The General Motors Corporation announced today that its March sales dropped 2.2 percent from levels a year earlier because a long strike interrupted its production. But the Chrysler Corporation reported an 8.1 percent gain for the month.         One reason G.M. car sales declined, according to Ed Lechtzin, a company spokesman, was that it delayed until April the delivery of some cars to fleet buyers in order to conserve its scarce supply of cars for retail buyers during the 17-day strike. The work stoppage involved two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, that led to a gradual closing of most of the company's North American assembly plants and some shortages of cars on dealer lots.

headline: Ruling Curbs Jury's Role On Patents
abstract: In one of the most important patent decisions in years, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that in a patent infringement suit it was up to judges,  rather than juries, to resolve the crucial issue of what a patent means.         While the decision does not completely oust juries from patent cases, it may  have that effect as a practical matter in many infringement suits. The interpretation of the patent claim -- the precise definition of the scope of the patent over which the patent owner exercises a lawful monopoly -- is often the most important aspect of the case, and once a judge has decided this question, there may be nothing left for the jury to do.

headline: Neither Ridicule Nor Rancor Halts Gorbachev Election Bid
abstract: The last leader of the Soviet Union stepped out of his car on the edge of his boyhood village on Wednesday and looked expectantly at the small group of people gathered.         "So, who is meeting me here?" he asked jovially. He looked closer and frowned as he recognized only Western reporters. "It's mostly foreigners. I want to see  someone I know."

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Pepsico's First-Quarter Net Rose 23%, to $394 Million
abstract: Pepsico Inc. reported yesterday that it had strong first-quarter volume growth in its snack-food, soft-drink and restaurant businesses in a performance  that analysts said presaged a return to the company's traditional double-digit increases in annual earnings.         The company, which was struggling to turn around its fast-food unit at the end of last year, registered a 23 percent jump in first-quarter net income, to $394 million, or 49 cents a share, from $321 million, or 40 cents a share, in the comparable quarter last year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FORMER S.E.C. CHAIRMAN TO HEAD BENNETT FUNDING
abstract: Richard C. Breeden, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was appointed yesterday to take over the financially troubled Bennett Funding Group, which stands accused of swindling investors out of millions of dollars. Mr. Breeden was appointed S.E.C. chairman by President George Bush; he served from 1989 until 1993. The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Bennett Funding, based in Syracuse, and its subsidiaries of selling earlier this decade $570 million of fraudulent securities to investors in what it says might be the largest pyramid scheme in history. Bennett Funding has filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Stripped of Themes, Yeltsin Wraps Himself in Flag
abstract: In his embattled bid for re-election, President Boris N. Yeltsin has raised the red flag. Literally.         Bowing to the growing nationalism and nostalgia for Soviet power fueling the  Russian presidential elections, Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree this week restoring the red banner, embossed with a gold star instead of the Communist hammer and sickle, as a national emblem.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SANDOZ OFFERS TO PURCHASE REMAINING STAKE IN HOLDING
abstract: The Swiss drug company Sandoz A.G. said yesterday that it was offering to buy the rest of the majority-owned Systemix Inc. for about $70 million, sending stock of Systemix soaring 69 percent. Sandoz already holds a 71.6 percent stake  in Systemix, which researches gene therapies for cancer, AIDS and genetic diseases. Sandoz is offering $17 a share for Systemix, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif. Systemix's shares jumped beyond that price yesterday, gaining $7.625, to reach $18.625 on the Nasdaq stock market.

headline: EXCEL SHARES CLOSE AT ALMOST TWICE OFFERING PRICE
abstract: The shares of Excel Communications Inc., a long-distance telephone service reseller, closed at almost twice their offering price after their first day of trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Excel's stock closed at $29.375 after 11 million shares were traded. Excel, based in Dallas, sold 10 million shares at $15 to raise $150 million in its initial public offering on Thursday. Investors  snapped up the company's shares because of the prospects for rapid increases in sales and earnings, said Ryan Jacob, director of research at IPO Value Monitor in New York. Excel's revenue soared to $506.7 million last year from $30.8 million in 1993.

headline: General Strike Fails in South Africa
abstract: A general strike, called to fight a constitutional provision, seemed to fizzle today.         With a deadline looming for constitutional negotiators to complete their work, the strike had been called to prevent the insertion in the new charter of language giving employers the right to lock out workers.

headline: Business Travel;President Clinton's proposal to increase the international departure tax raises  some hackles.
abstract: AIRLINES and the travel industry have usually supported taxes earmarked for improvements in aviation or infrastructure. But President Clinton's recent proposal to raise the tax on international departures from $6 a passenger to $16, with the money used to help offset the cost of attending college, has gone  over with the business travel community like the proverbial lead balloon. The Air Transport Association termed the proposed increase "an absolute outrage  to air travelers who already pay a long list of taxes and fees totaling more than $6 billion annually." Carol Hallett, the association president, said the proposal would cost an additional $500 million a year, "and not a dime will be used to fund runways, radar systems, or anything else that benefits aviation safety or overall system capacity." She added that the tax would lead to a new round of bankruptcies and layoffs by aircraft makers.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Mexico Ex-Governor Tied To Cover-Up of Killings
abstract: An investigation by the Mexican Supreme Court released today found that the former Governor and several officials of the state of Guerrero tried to cover up the killing of 17 poor farmers by police last June.         The court also said the former Governor, Ruben Figueroa Alcocer, had violated the peasants' rights by ordering that they be kept from attending an anti-government rally.

headline: Way Out West: Ray Brown and His Lucky Star
abstract: LUCERNE, Switzerland—  Speaking of Dizzy Gillespie, Raybrown — which sounds right pronounced just like that, one walking sostenuto phrase — speculates about his luck: "I don't want to question fate, but I can't help but wonder how much of what happened was me, and how much my lucky star."

headline: U.S. Offers Data to Link Sudan to Plot
abstract: Pressing a divided Security Council for tough sanctions against the Sudan, the Clinton Administration presented evidence for the first time today that it said directly implicated the Sudanese Government in the attempted assassination  of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt by Islamic militants.         The attack by the militants, apparently all Egyptian, took place last June 26 in Ethiopia, which says that the neighboring Sudan has been harboring three fugitive assailants. Ethiopia has demanded action from the United Nations on the matter.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Europe Extends Study Of Ciba-Sandoz Merger
abstract: The European Commission said yesterday that it would extend its investigation into the $36 billion merger of Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G. The merged company, to be called Novartis A.G., would have annual sales of $22 billion and  a market capitalization of about $80 billion.          After a preliminary investigation lasting one month, the commission said in  a statement that it had decided the activities of the two companies were "primarily complementary" and without cause for antitrust concern. But the European Union executive agency also said it needed to carry out a "second stage" investigation lasting four months to examine "a number of specific sectors, particularly for pharmaceuticals, crop protection and animal health."   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ABN-Amro in Venture With Rothschild Group
abstract: The Dutch banking company ABN-Amro Holding N.V. said yesterday that it was merging its equity capital markets activities with those of the Rothschild Group of Britain. The two will cooperate in originating, underwriting and distributing equity transactions, under the name of ABN-Amro Rothschild.          ABN-Amro Rothschild will be responsible for executing all international equity capital market transactions worldwide and for domestic equity capital market transactions. British domestic capital market transactions will be excluded, however, as will the British corporate broking activities of ABN-Amro  Hoare Govett. The joint venture will be run by an executive committee.   (Dow Jones)

headline: An Ad Accuses Companies Of Overcharging for Drugs
abstract: The wealthy Omaha industrialist Phil Sokolof, whose full-page newspaper advertisements in 1988 accused food marketers of poisoning Americans with saturated fats, is at it again. In a fresh round of ads that he said cost him more than $550,000, Mr. Sokolof is accusing Merck & Company of charging too much for cholesterol-lowering medications.         The new advertisement, with the headline "The Gouging of America," appears today in The New York Times on page A16, and is scheduled to appear in about 40  other major newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal, USA Today and The Los Angeles Times, Mr. Sokolof said.

headline: MARKET WATCH;Bond Buyers Love Bad Credit
abstract: Confidence is a wonderful thing. And one way to read the current bond market  is to say that seldom has confidence been greater. Or, to put it another way, seldom has credit risk seemed less scary to investors.         The Treasury bond market has had a rough 1996, in part because of fears that  the economy is too healthy. But within the bond market, things are not as bad as you would think from looking at Treasuries. Corporate bond prices have not fallen as far, and many junk bond prices are rising.

headline: Prison for Ex-Chief Of College Bound
abstract: The former chief executive of College Bound, George Ronkin, was sentenced last week in Federal court to six years in prison for fraudulently overstating the company's earnings in 1991.         College Bound, a company in Boca Raton, Fla., which trained students to take  college entrance exams, declared bankruptcy in 1992 and is now defunct. Mr. Ronkin and his wife, Janet Ronkin, founded the company in their home in 1981.

headline: I.B.M., in Its Dress Shoes, Chases Software Success
abstract: When John M. Thompson, chief of software at I.B.M., wanted to let his hair down at a Florida meeting of the company's new Lotus division earlier this year, he donned a canary yellow Lotus polo shirt. But true to his roots, Mr. Thompson, who is 53, wore his standard I.B.M. blue blazer over it. The clashing attire seemed to symbolize the challenge facing Mr. Thompson, a career I.B.M. executive whom many in the industry consider ill suited for the role that has been thrust upon him: to reverse a tide of expensive and embarrassing software flops over the last 15 years and push the company to the fore of the fastest-growing and most lucrative segment of the computer industry.         Success in software is crucial to I.B.M.'s chairman, Louis V. Gerstner Jr. and his goal of finding new sources of revenue and making the International Business Machines Corporation a major player in the emerging world of network computing. Just how crucial was underscored by I.B.M.'s first-quarter financial  report on April 17. Although the company posted better-than-expected earnings, its stock plunged 9 percent on the day of the earnings announcement because of jitters about future profits.

headline: Kohl Offers Plan for Big Cuts In the German Welfare State
abstract: With Europe in the throes of a widespread debate over its economic future, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced a plan today for long-heralded cuts in Germany's vaunted and well-padded welfare state that threaten social benefits that his compatriots have come to regard as virtually sacrosanct.         The proposals, intended to reduce Germany's budget deficit by some $33 billion, reflected a broader sense in Europe that leaner times lie ahead for nations, led by Germany, that are working to fulfill the economic conditions for a single European currency.

headline: Istanbul Arrests Protesters
abstract: The police arrested hundreds of people today at two demonstrations near the site of a United Nations conference on cities, human rights advocates said.         About 100 people were arrested at one demonstration, held by relatives of people who are missing, said Joanna Weschler, a spokeswoman for Human Rights Watch.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Post Mild Gains
abstract: Treasury prices ended little changed yesterday, displaying resiliency in the  face of an economic report showing unexpected strength and a disappointing auction of new five-year notes.         The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 3/32 , to 876/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 7.03 percent, from 7.04 percent on Tuesday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of Ireland to Buy British Building Society
abstract: The Bank of Ireland agreed yesterday to buy the Bristol and West Building Society for L600 million ($906 million) in cash to create the largest bank in Ireland and establish a British mortgage business. The Bank of Ireland, now the  second-biggest Irish bank after the Allied Irish Bank, said the acquisition would create a company with assets of L29 billion and 650 branches. Bristol and  West is Britain's ninth-largest building society.          Bristol and West becomes the seventh of Britain's 10 largest building societies, which are mortgage institutions owned by their customers, to abandon  the sector either by converting to bank status or being taken over in the last 18 months.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Rig Count Jumps by 23
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide rose by 23 this week, to  772, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 689 rigs operating in the United States a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 474 were exploring for natural gas and 290 for oil.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALLERGAN PLANS TO CUT JOBS AND TAKE EARNINGS CHARGE
abstract: Allergan Inc. said yesterday that it was cutting 450 jobs from its staff of 6,000 to improve profit margins hurt by competition and acquisitions. The cuts will result in charges that will reduce pretax earnings by as much as $75 million, or 81 cents a share. Spun off from Smith Kline Inc. in 1989, Allergan made a series of acquisitions last year and expanded its operations in Asia and  Latin America. But those moves added overhead while managed-care concerns have restrained sales growth. Allergan of Irvine, Calif., said the restructuring charges could be distributed in any or all of the second, third or fourth quarter. In 1995, Allergan profits were $72.7 million.

headline: Hong Kong Is Warned By Beijing On Press
abstract: Long accustomed to their boisterous, muckraking press, Hong Kong's journalists and news organizations are reeling from a series of body punches delivered by a senior Beijing official over the future of press freedom here.         Lu Ping, the Chinese official charged with setting up Hong Kong's new government after China retakes the territory from Britain on July 1, 1997, has issued a procession of comments starkly warning the crown colony's press that there will be limits on what can be published here under Chinese rule.

headline: Stocks Lowerin Tokyo
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of  225 issues was down 193.73 points, or more than eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,041.30. There was no trading on Monday because of a holiday, Greenery Day. On Friday, the Nikkei finished up 4.93.

headline: Cult Is Done With Terrorism, Guru on Trial in Japan Pledges
abstract: Seeking to persuade the Japanese Government not to ban his group, the guru of the Aum Shinrikyo religious cult pledged today that it would not commit terrorist acts.         The Government is proposing to ban the sect, which is charged with the nerve  gas attack on the Tokyo subway system last year in which 11 people were killed and thousands hurt.

headline: World News Briefs;Kidnappers in Germany Escape With $20 Million
abstract: Using a tape-recording of one abductor's voice and a partial license plate number, the police worked today to track down kidnappers who made off with a $20 million ransom after holding a millionaire captive for a month.         The millionaire, Jan Philipp Reemtsma, 43, was released unharmed near Hamburg late Friday, a day after friends dropped off Germany's biggest ransom on a highway near the Dutch border.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PFIZER INC., New York, said it planned to acquire a 15 percent interest in the Catalytica Fine Chemicals unit of Catalytica Inc., Mountain View, Calif., for $15 million. In return, Catalytica Fine Chemicals will do five years of research for Pfizer, the drug maker.

headline: Ex-Employee of Philip Morris Pleads Guilty to Bank Fraud
abstract: Edward J. Reiners, a former employee of the Philip Morris Companies, pleaded  guilty to money-laundering and bank-fraud charges yesterday in a scheme that bilked eight prominent international financial institutions out of more than $350 million for more than two years.         Mr. Reiners, 51, of Somers, N.Y., entered his plea in United States District  Court in Richmond before Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. He faces 30 years in prison and a fine of $1 million on the bank-fraud conviction, and 20 years and fines of more than $295 million for conviction on the money-laundering charge. A sentencing hearing was scheduled on Oct. 21.

headline: Violence by Rwandans Is Reported in Zaire
abstract: Rwandan Hutu refugees armed with assault rifles and machetes hunted down hundreds of Tutsi who had sought refuge in a church in Zaire and killed at least 12 of them, a United Nations official said today.         About 130 other Zairian Tutsi who had been hiding in the church were missing, and by late Wednesday at least 600 others had fled the armed mobs to Kichanga, near the border with Rwanda, said Paul Stromberg, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.

headline: Phillips and Conoco End Talks About Merging Operations
abstract: Conoco Inc. and the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that they had been unable to reach a final agreement to merge their refining and marketing businesses and had broken off talks.   Executives familiar with the discussions said the companies could not agree on the value of the businesses to be merged -- in particular, the value of the refineries -- and on how much cash each company was to have received in the deal.

headline: World News Briefs;Turkish Leader Escapes An Attempt to Kill Him
abstract: A man reportedly upset at Turkey's military cooperation with Israel pointed a gun at President Suleyman Demirel today, but bodyguards tackled him and the Turkish leader was unharmed. The gun went off in the scuffle and two people were hurt.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Prime Rate Is Raised To 20.5% in South Africa
abstract: South African banks raised their prime interest rate yesterday for the second time in three weeks. Standard Bank of South Africa Ltd., First National Bank of  Southern Africa Ltd. and Nedcor Bank Ltd. all raised their prime lending rates to 20.5 percent from 19.5 percent.          Banks raised lending rates to protect their margins as foreign investment capital fled South Africa, draining liquidity from the domestic money market. Foreigners have sold rand-denominated assets in recent months as political upheaval undermined confidence in South Africa.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Disney Reorganizes ABC Radio Division
abstract: The Walt Disney Company has reorganized the management structure of Capital Cities/ABC's radio division.

headline: Question Mark In Israel Ballot: 'The Russians'
abstract: The other day, Natan Sharansky, the former Soviet dissident, sat in a small classroom at Hebrew University in Jerusalem and listened to a dozen Russian physicists, chemists and engineers vent their dissatisfaction with their new lives as immigrants.         Lev D. Bergelson, a biochemist, said the principal complaint was that Israel  had been saturated with scientists -- 10,000 qualified Russian immigrants trained as academics and researchers -- but about 70 percent of them were working as truck drivers, bricklayers and in other jobs outside their fields.

headline: Labor Won't Try to Undo Thatcherism, Chief Says
abstract: The leader of the opposition Labor Party said today that once in power his party would not try to roll back changes wrought by Prime Ministers Margaret Thatcher and John Major in many British institutions, from state-run industries  now privatized to once-powerful unions now curbed.         "I believe passionately that our government will fail if it sees its task as  dismantling Thatcherism," said the Labor leader, Tony Blair. "We can't just switch the clock back to where we were or we will fail. Our task is to build and create those things that Thatcherism didn't deal with."

headline: Chairman Leaving RJR, Tumult Intact
abstract: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that Charles Harper was retiring as chairman after leading the cigarette and food company through three  turbulent years.         Steven Goldstone, 50, who replaced Mr. Harper as chief executive of the company in December, will succeed him as chairman as well, the company said.     RJR hired Mr. Harper, the former chief executive of Conagra Inc., in 1993 in the hope that he would be able to help RJR deal with its problems, which include a heavy debt burden. RJR, which is based in New York, makes Camel cigarettes, Oreo cookies and other food and tobacco products.

headline: DIARY
abstract: POLITICS

headline: Nissan Recalls A Million Cars
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company is recalling 1.12 million cars in Japan and the United States to fix faulty engine and seat belt parts that could result in fires. Nissan said the recall was the largest ever in Japan.         Of the vehicles recalled, only about 70,000 were sold in the United States, all Infinitis. Nissan said the Infinitis had the faulty seat belt component.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;History Channel Cancels Plan For Series on U.S. Companies
abstract: Abashed by criticism of their plan to produce a series of television profiles of American corporations with those companies, executives of the History Channel decided yesterday to scuttle the project.         The History Channel, one of the fastest-growing new cable channels, had envisioned that the series, "The Spirit of Enterprise," would take an inside look at major American companies by using corporate archives and cooperation. The companies would have underwritten production costs and bought advertising time, and each company would have been given editorial control over the content  of its profile.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Smaller Stocks Rise, As Dow Average Falls 16.26 Smaller issues took the leadership role in a mixed stock market. The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 1,138.70, establishing its third new record of the week. And the American Stock Exchange market value index climbed 2.80 points, to 585.88, marking its fourth consecutive record and its 18th high this  year.

headline: White House Supports Payment To 281 Vietnamese Commandos
abstract: The White House said today that it would support legislation to give $11 million in back pay to 281 Vietnamese who served as secret agents for the United States during the Vietnam war and were later written off as dead.         The Vietnamese worked for the Central Intelligence Agency and the United States military in a doomed effort to infiltrate North Vietnam between 1961 and  1969. They were dropped behind enemy lines by parachute, or secretly swam ashore after being taken north in speedboats.

headline: A Safer Smoke Or Just Another Smokescreen?;Reynold Courts Support for a New Product
abstract: Once a company designs an innovative product, figures out how to make it profitably and determines consumers are anxious to try it, it can count on smooth sailing toward a big payoff, right? Not for the increasingly reviled tobacco industry.         After decades of fiercely contesting the scientific and public consensus that its products are dangerous, the $45 billion tobacco industry is saddled with the business world's biggest credibility gap. But the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company is nonetheless trying to overcome the skepticism of antismoking activists and win their support for a nearly smokeless cigarette called Eclipse, its biggest effort to introduce a safer product since a $300 million marketing debacle in the late 1980's.

headline: Corning to Spin Off Labs and Drug Unit
abstract: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its laboratory-testing and pharmaceutical-services businesses to shareholders, creating two additional, independent companies.         The spinoff represents an end to 14 years of diversification by Corning, whose roots are in glass and related products. It started the diversification in 1982 by acquiring Metpath clinical laboratories. Metpath, which provides services like blood screening for doctors and hospitals, has grown to $1.6 billion in annual sales from $100 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Shells Seafood Restaurants Inc., Tampa, Fla., to the West Group, Tampa, to handle advertising for the restaurant chain, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: Dekalb Sues Rivals Over Patented Seeds
abstract: The Dekalb Genetics Corporation is suing three rival seed companies, contending they infringed its patent rights to genetically altered seeds.         The company said on Tuesday that it had filed its lawsuit in Federal court in Rockford, Ill., against the Mycogen Corporation, the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc.

headline: As Israelis Prepare to Vote, The World Watches Closely
abstract: As Israelis prepare to make one of the most important choices in their history, they are finding that a lot of the world is staring over their shoulder.         People with long memories cannot remember when an Israeli race has been scrutinized from abroad as closely as Wednesday's is, or when the world has shown as keen an interest in the outcome.

headline: 2 Mortgage Rates Inch Up
abstract: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose to 7.78 percent this week from 7.69 percent the previous week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Rates on 15-year mortgages rose to 7.29 percent from 7.19 percent.  Rates on one-year adjustable loans were unchanged at 5.62 percent, after rising  for six consecutive weeks. A year ago, 30-year loans averaged 8.41 percent; 15-year loans, 7.99 percent, and one-year adjustable loans stood at 6.41 percent.

headline: Iraq Yields on Opening Suspected Arms Sites
abstract: Iraq has agreed to grant United Nations weapons inspectors immediate access to sites suspected of housing banned weapons material, Rolf Ekeus, the chief United Nations inspector, said today at a news conference at the Iraqi Foreign Ministry.         The dismantling of Iraqi programs for producing long-range missiles and chemical, biological and nuclear weapons was required by the United Nations Security Council under resolutions that ended the Persian Gulf war in 1991.

headline: NGC and Chevron Reach Accord on Gas
abstract: The NGC Corporation and the Chevron Corporation said today that they had signed a final agreement that would make NGC the largest natural gas and gas liquids wholesaler in North America.         The agreement to merge natural gas operations, first announced in January, calls for NGC to pay $300 million in cash and notes and to issue Chevron 38.6 million new common shares and 7.8 million preferred shares. Based on NGC's closing share price of $15.375 on Wednesday, the shares would be valued at $713.4 million.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Surge After a Report Showing Low U.S. Inventories
abstract: Crude oil prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a report showed that United States inventories fell to 19-year lows last week, heightening concern that rising demand around the world would continue to keep supplies tight.         On other markets, corn prices fell while copper rose.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japanese Bank In Bond Inquiry
abstract: American banking authorities are investigating a United States subsidiary of  the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan for misreporting bond trades, the bank said today.         No money was lost in the transactions by LTCB Trust, the bank's New York-based subsidiary, but the bank did not disclose the value of the deals.

headline: An After-School Job That's Not Kids' Stuff;Wanted: Web Designers and Programmers; $25/hr.; Need Parents' Consent
abstract: When the school day ends at 2:15 P.M., Jascha Franklin-Hodge ambles out of the red-brick edifice of Brookline High School and makes the uphill trek on Tappan Street, heading for work. In another time, his after-school job probably  would have been delivering newspapers or pumping gas.         But the 17-year-old junior in high school works at a local Internet access company, Software Tool and Die Inc., doing programming and maintenance for $8 an hour and unlimited Internet time. At school, Mr. Franklin-Hodge has learned French, but he has taught himself the vernaculars of computing like Basic, C, Perl and Java. He speaks of computer languages with the familiarity of a carpenter discussing his hammer and saw. "They're like a box of tools," he said, "and you have to choose the tool that is most effective for the job at hand."

headline: New Netscape Software Flaw Is Discovered
abstract: Computer science researchers at Princeton University said yesterday that they had discovered a new and potentially serious flaw in the Netscape Communications Corporation's Navigator software, the leading program used to browse the World Wide Web of the Internet.         The flaw, which was found in recent versions of the Netscape software that support Sun Microsystems' Java programming language, could allow people to write destructive or malicious programs and potentially destroy or steal data or otherwise tamper with a computer that was connected to the Internet and used the Navigator program.

headline: 7 Suspects Accused Of Smuggling Guns Into California : 'Sting' Case Further Tests U.S.-China Relations
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Adding to already serious strains in relations with China, U.S. agents have arrested seven people allegedly linked to arms companies run by the Chinese government, charging that they smuggled 2,000 AK-47 assault rifles into the United States.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung Rules Out Buying Part of Fokker
abstract: The Samsung Aerospace Industries Company, a unit of the Samsung Group of South Korea, said yesterday that it had ruled out buying part of the bankrupt Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. A Samsung spokesman said the company would continue to negotiate with Fokker on the acquisition of its engineering technology in 100-seat planes.          Samsung is leading a $2 billion project by South Korea and China to design and build a 100-seat airplane. Samsung had negotiated with Fokker on a possible takeover before the Dutch company filed for bankruptcy on March 15. In  January, Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, which had owned a majority share of the Dutch company, cut off its financial support.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Bosnia Hunting Enemies Down, Diplomats Say
abstract: The Muslim-led Bosnian Government has dispatched small Iranian-trained commando units to kill or capture enemies it has branded as war criminals, senior Croatian officials and Western diplomats say.         The existence of these units came to light this month after five Bosnian Muslims, now in prison in Croatia, were arrested and accused of trying to assassinate a renegade Muslim leader, Fikret Abdic, who is in exile in Croatia.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: No Headline
INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Scottish Power Appears To Win a Bidding War
abstract: Scottish Power P.L.C. apparently won its battle yesterday to acquire another  British utility, Southern Water P.L.C., with an improved bid of L1.677 billion -- about $2.6 billion -- that the rival bidder, Southern Electric P.L.C., said it would not match.  Southern Electric said it would allow its L1.6 billion offer to lapse on July 4.         The higher offer by Scottish Power represented a 7.5 percent increase over its earlier bid.   (AP)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Mexico Awards TV Concession
abstract: A unit of Grupo Televisa S.A. said today that it had won a Government concession to provide direct-to-home television.         The concession, offered by the Ministry of Communications and Transportation, allows Televisa and its partners, the News Corporation of Australia, Globo of Brazil and Tele-Communications Inc. of Englewood, Colo., to move ahead with plans to provide such service across Latin America. Direct-to-home television is transmitted to subscribers via a signal, which is received and decoded at users' homes for a fee.

headline: 2 Communists, The First Ever, Join Cabinet In New Delhi
abstract: India's President today inducted the first Communist ministers to serve in the Government since independence nearly 50 years ago.         The President, Shankar Dayal Sharma, swore in the two men as part of an expansion of the month-old Government, which is led by Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda.

headline: World News Briefs;  Pension Dispute Silences Song of Gondoliers
abstract: Venice's gondoliers, who usually serenade their customers as they steer them  through the city's romantic canals, stopped singing today because of a dispute over pensions.         For many visitors to Venice, a ride in a gondola is not complete without the  soft serenading of the gondolier.

headline: YELTSIN CHOOSES A DEFEATED RIVAL FOR SECURITY POST
abstract: In a bold stroke to consolidate support before next month's runoff election,  President Boris N. Yeltsin dismissed his unpopular Defense Minister today and appointed Aleksandr I. Lebed, a retired general who finished a strong third in Sunday's first round, as his top national security adviser.         Mr. Yeltsin's move tightened his grip on first place by giving him a claim to the 15 percent of the electorate who supported the gruff-talking Mr. Lebed in the first round of presidential balloting.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spanish Airline Finally Turns a Profit
abstract: Spain's state airline, Iberia, said yesterday that it had an operating profit of 2.9 billion pesetas ($22.55 million) in the first four months of the year, the first profitable showing in this period since 1989. Juan Saez, president of  Iberia, forecast the company would have net income of 20 billion pesetas this year, after a loss of 44.9 billion pesetas in 1995.          In addition, a Spanish newspaper reported that British Airways was interested in buying a 15 percent stake in the Spanish carrier for $100 million. Neither Iberia nor British Airways would comment on the report, published by the Barcelona daily La Vanguardia. It said the acquisition would be the first step to a three-way strategic alliance of Iberia, British Airways and  American Airlines.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;Divorce: Can You Get It for Me Wholesale?
abstract: Q. Is it possible to find a lawyer willing to negotiate a flat-fee divorce?

headline: COMPANY NEWS;READING & BATES SPURNED IN TRANSOCEAN BID
abstract: The Reading & Bates Corporation of Houston said yesterday that it had made an offer to acquire Transocean A.S., the Norwegian offshore-drilling concern, for $1.51 billion in stock. But Transocean rejected the offer in favor of an offer made a week ago by Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. for about $1.43 billion. Reading & Bates, a drilling company, said it had offered 1.245 shares of its own stock for each Transocean share. Reading & Bates said it believed its offer was more economically favorable for Transocean's shareholders and a better strategic fit  between the two companies. But Transocean said that after talks with both Reading & Bates and Sonat, it had decided that the Sonat deal would be the best  solution for the company.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes Relaxing Rules on Trading
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed relaxing restrictions on trading in stocks and bonds before companies make new issues of the securities available to the public.         The proposed rules, which will be open to public comment for 60 days, also seek to reduce underwriting costs associated with these offerings, which are known as secondary offerings.

headline: Drug Scandal Taints Panama's Reform Chief
abstract: Less than seven years ago, American troops invaded Panama and ousted Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and the drug-dealing army that he commanded. Now, with a friendly Government in power and the hand-over of the Panama Canal looming, the United States finds itself again facing a familiar quandary here.    Since taking office in 1994, President Ernesto Perez Balladares has repeatedly pledged to crack down on drug trafficking here, and even followed through with some actions against Colombian cocaine cartels.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pirelli Chief Retiring After Years at the Helm
abstract: Pirelli S.p.A. said yesterday that its 70-year-old chairman, Leopoldo Pirelli, would retire from the company. The Italian tire and cable concern was founded by Mr. Pirelli's grandfather, Giovanni Battista Pirelli, in 1872. After  spending almost a half-century at the helm of Italy's 10th-largest industrial company, Mr. Pirelli will be replaced by the chief executive, Marco Tronchetti Provera, 48. Mr. Pirelli's son, Alberto, was named deputy chairman.          As part of the announcement yesterday, Pirelli reinstated the payment of its dividend for the first time in four years, signaling the company's return to profitability after losses in 1991, 1992 and 1993. Pirelli will pay 50 lire an ordinary share and 210 lire for a savings share.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: South Africa Losing Battle to House Homeless
abstract: A year ago, when Maureen Mkhize was brought to this field north of Johannesburg and given a spot for her shack, she was told she would have real housing within six months. Since then, hundreds of families have joined her -- brought here by the truckload from sordid urban squatter settlements, the flimsy bits of their old shacks dumped beside them so they can rebuild.         As far as the eye can see in a vacant section of this black township, small white stones mark off thousands of future plots. There are tractors busy making  dirt roads in a grid pattern, and portable toilets and barrels of drinking water are set up at regular intervals.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Set to Issue New 30-Year Bonds
abstract: Mexico said today that it was issuing up to $2.5 billion of new bonds that it would swap for United States-backed Brady bonds in a sign that the country's status had improved in financial markets.         The news immediately sent Mexican bond prices and the peso higher as investors scrambled to get in position to buy the new securities.

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 22,322.40, up 87.02 points, or 0.39 percent. On Monday, the Nikkei slid 44.01 points.

headline: Serbs Turn Over Files On Captive Suspects
abstract: Bosnian Serb officials handed over files on 4 Muslims and 12 Croats they suspect of war crimes but refuse to release the prisoners, officials said today.         Threatening to withhold money for reconstruction in Bosnia, Carl Bildt, the civilian administrator overseeing the peace accord, had demanded the prisoners' release by midnight Friday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DONNA KARAN INTERNATIONAL INCREASES OFFERING PRICE
abstract: Donna Karan International Inc. priced its initial public offering yesterday at $24 a share to raise $258 million for the New York fashion design company. The concern sold 10.75 million shares, a 50 percent stake, with about half of the proceeds going to original investors. The company, valued at $513.6 million, raised its price range to $23 to $25 a share from $20 to $23. Some $58 million of the funds raised are expected to go to Ms. Karan, her husband and her children; another $58 million would go to the Takihyo Group, which is the company's second- biggest owner, and an additional $90 million would go to pay debt. The rest will be used for general corporate purposes.

headline: World News Briefs;Official of Khmer Rouge Says Pol Pot Is Alive
abstract: A Khmer Rouge official based at the guerrillas' stronghold in Phnom Malai, Cambodia, today denied reports that the group's leader, Pol Pot, is dead.          "The report about Pol Pot's death is not true," the guerrilla official, who  identified himself as Mit Chien, told reporters. "We've got no idea how this rumor spread."

headline: World News Briefs;Figure Linked to Scandal Is Found Dead in Brazil
abstract: A central figure in the downfall of the former Brazilian President, Fernando  Collor de Mello, was found killed this morning in northeastern Brazil, the police said.         A police spokesman said the victim, Paulo Cesar Farias, 50, who was believed  to have organized the influence-peddling scheme that undermined Mr. Collor, was  found shot to death alongside a 28-year-old female friend in a beach house just  outside Maceio, the capital of Alagoas state.

headline: Oh, Sorry: Tabloids Lose the Soccer War
abstract: LONDON—  Remember when England's soccer stars were being passed off as drunken louts, a harmless embarrassment, more likely to be dribbling down the fronts of their shirts than toward goal?

headline: It's Indians vs. Loggers in Nicaragua
abstract: On the official map of Nicaragua, the lands where the Sumo Indians dwell show up as a solid swath of rain forest interrupted by a few dots that seem to signal tentative human forays through the jungle.         In the minds of the Sumos, the same territory is set off by conspicuous landmarks and vivid boundaries traced by ancestors who fished the streams and hunted armadillos in the mahogany stands.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CASCADE COMMUNICATIONS PLANS TO BUY ARRIS NETWORKS
abstract: The Cascade Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Arris Networks Inc., a provider of technology for communications companies, for $145.3 million  in common stock. Cascade said the purchase would extend its product offerings. The company, based in Westford, Mass., mainly provides switching systems used to distribute data at high speeds over telephone networks. Arris, a private company also based in Westford, would expand Cascade's product line to allow users to gain access to high-speed networks from remote locations. Cascade's shares gained $1.50, to $86.50, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition is expected to be completed in May.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SARA LEE AGREES TO ACQUIRE LOVABLE ITALIANA
abstract: The Sara Lee Corporation, based in Chicago, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Lovable Italiana S.p.A., an Italian maker of intimate apparel with annual sales of $115 million. The company did not disclose financial details of the deal. "The acquisition of Lovable Italiana is consistent with Sara Lee's plans to build its portfolio of intimate apparel brands, which currently includes Dim, Playtex, Bali and Wonderbra," said Donald Franceschini, executive vice president of personal-products businesses for Sara Lee. Sara Lee's products include Hanes, L'eggs, Bali, Champion and Playtex.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ACE SETS RATIO FOR PURCHASE OF TEMPEST REINSURANCE
abstract: Ace Ltd. said yesterday that it had set the ratio governing the stock swap included its agreement to acquire the Tempest Reinsurance Company. Ace will pay  Tempest holders 3.2091 shares for each share of the closely held reinsurance concern, or a total of about 13.3 million shares. The exchange ratio is based on an average closing price of Ace stock of more than $45 a share. Ace shares fell  25 cents yesterday, to $47.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tempest agreed to be acquired by Ace last week for $976 million. Ace's offer beat a bid from IPC Holdings Ltd., a reinsurance concern that had offered $943 million. All the  companies are based in Bermuda.

headline: International Briefs:;News Corporation Offers Shares for British Unit
abstract: Shares in News International P.L.C., the British newspaper publisher, soared  yesterday after its stockholders were offered preferred shares in its parent company, the News Corporation, in exchange for their 9 percent stake. The News Corporation, headed by Rupert Murdoch, already owns all the ordinary stock of News International and 82 percent of the publicly traded special dividend shares of the subsidiary. After the exchange, News Corporation will own all the shares  in News International and the unit will cease to trade. The swap, which offers 1.33 preferred News Corporation shares for each News International special dividend share, values News International shares at 410 pence each. The shares closed up 79 pence yesterday, at 387.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saint-Gobain to Buy Poliet in Phased Deal
abstract: A French glass maker, Saint-Gobain, said yesterday that it planned to buy the building materials company Poliet for as much as 15 billion francs ($2.9 billion) over the next three years under a deal with Poliet's main shareholder,  Groupe Paribas. Under the agreement Saint-Gobain will buy 4.7 percent of Poliet, which has 20,000 employees, and take management control of the company in the first phase. It also has options to acquire the rest of the 56.6 percent held by Paribas in 1997 and 1998, according to a joint statement.          The statement did not price the acquisition, but Saint-Gobain's chairman, Jean-Louis Beffa, said it would cost around 15 billion francs if minority shareholders also sold.   (Reuters)

headline: Orange County Creditors Said To Accept Plan
abstract: The largest municipal bankruptcy in United States history neared a conclusion today with the announcement that the creditors of Orange County, Calif., appeared to have accepted a recovery plan.         Lawyers involved in the lengthy negotiations said that an informal tally of ballots filed by all the county's creditors, from bondholders to suppliers of office products, showed that they had approved the plan. That makes it likely, the lawyers said, that the Federal bankruptcy court would accept the plan at a hearing scheduled for May 15. The final count of the ballots will be ready on Monday or Tuesday, the lawyers said.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: JETFORM INC., Ottawa, said it would buy back Moore Corp.'s option to purchase a  controlling stake in the company in a transaction valued at $33.75 million. The  software company will issue about 1.8 million common shares to Moore, valued at  $18.75 each, in exchange for Moore's option to buy 7.7 million JetForm shares by 1999.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TIGER REAL ESTATE TO BUY KAHLER FOR $222 MILLION
abstract: Tiger Real Estate Fund L.P. said yesterday that it would buy the Kahler Realty Corporation for about $222 million. Kahler, based in Rochester, Minn., said the deal consisted of $77 million in cash and the assumption of $145 million in debt. The bid values Kahler at $17 a share, and the company's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $16.25, in Nasdaq trading. Kahler owns or manages 23 hotels, primarily in Minnesota, Utah, Idaho, Montana and Arizona. The company earned $3 million on revenues of $139.9 million in 1995. Tiger, a private New York-based fund, said its portfolio was valued at about $1.5 billion.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Advertising Federation Attemps to Raise Its Profile
abstract: The American Advertising Federation is seeking to raise its profile with measures that emulate those taken by its marketer members when they want to woo  consumers: a new slogan, a new logo and an advertising campaign.         The federation, which was formed in 1967, represents agencies and the media as well as marketers. Its members also include 220 local advertising associations across the country and 200 college chapters.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.      Monday None

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Law Near to Require Children's Programming A rule calling for television stations to broadcast three hours a week of educational programs for children became a virtual certainty as James Quello, one of the Federal Communications Commission members who had been blocking the legislation, said he would drop his opposition. Mr. Quello agreed to a compromise under which an absolute minimum of three hours might not be required, if stations could demonstrate that they had performed a public service for children that was roughly equivalent. [11.] Industrial Production Rises Again Output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent last month, a bigger increase than analysts had expected. The jump in production was the second straight, and businesses also showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that could mean even greater output and  more jobs. [Page 33.]

headline: O.J. Simpson at Oxford: Some Aye Votes by Students, Some Nay
abstract: It was presented as an effort at public rehabilitation, an attempt to restore some of the old luster to his tarnished image. And when O.J. Simpson came to argue his case before the venerable Oxford Union tonight, he found that as poor  as his status is at home after his double murder trial last year, he can still impress an audience abroad.         It was an incongruous sight: Mr. Simpson, who to the British embodies a particularly American mixture of celebrity and notoriety, appearing before a centuries-old institution steeped in tradition and bound by pre-television rules of discourse.

headline: S.E.C. Proposes N.A.S.D. Censure to Settle Rules Inquiry
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has proposed that the National Association of Securities Dealers agree to be censured to settle administrative  charges that it did not adequately enforce its rules at large brokerage firms, securities industry regulators said today.         Under the proposed settlement, sent to the N.A.S.D. last week, the self-policing industry body would not admit or deny wrongdoing and would agree not to commit future securities-law violations, said the three regulators, speaking on condition they not be identified.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRISTOL-MYERS IN ANOTHER BIOTECHNOLOGY INVESTMENT
