abstract: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it planned to make a $10 million investment in the Somatix Therapy Corporation, a biotechnology company,  bringing its total investment in the company to $20 million. In exchange, Bristol-Myers, the pharmaceutical concern, has first rights to collaborate with  Somatix on any cancer products it develops. Somatix, which is based in Alameda,  Calif., is developing gene-therapy products to treat cancer and Parkinson's disease. Bristol-Myers, which is based in New York, made an initial investment of $10 million in Somatix last August. Somatix's stock fell 50 cents yesterday,  to close at $7.625 a share on the Nasdaq stock market.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Nutmeg Mills, Tampa, Fla., a unit of the VF Corp. that markets licensed sports apparel, to Sass & Associates in Annapolis, Md., to handle advertising for the Lee Sport brand and to introduce Lee Sport Genuine Casualwear. The billings were estimated at $9 million to $11 million. The Lee Sport brand had been handled for the last year by the lead VF agency, Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. Sass also handles a line of Nascar apparel for Nutmeg under the Nutmeg Racing brand.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Nissan Posts $814 Million Loss for Year
abstract: The Nissan Motor Company reported today that its group net loss narrowed in the latest fiscal year, and the company and analysts said they expected a return to profitability this year as conditions improved at troubled foreign operations.         Results for the parent company alone, which reflect operations in Japan, recovered strongly in the latest fiscal year. But losses in Mexico and Europe pulled down group results, which reflect all the company's operations.

headline: Liberians Keep on Fighting But Avoid the U.S. Embassy
abstract: Rival militias moved their battles away from the United States Embassy and into the neighborhood of Liberia's main faction leader today, littering the streets with bodies and provoking a strong showing of American military force.         The spread of fighting came one day after marines guarding the United States  Embassy here shot and killed three Liberians who fired weapons toward the compound.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Electronic Arts Buys South Africa Distributor
abstract: Electronic Arts Inc., the biggest publisher of video game software, said yesterday that it had bought Vision Software Ltd., a South African software distributor, to expand its reach in Africa. Vision Software, based in Johannesburg, is building import operations in Kenya and four central African countries. Africa "represents a significant opportunity," said David Gardner, managing director of Electronic Arts, based in San Mateo, Calif. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Data East USA Inc., San Jose, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, as the first agency to handle advertising for the manufacturer of sports video games. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $7 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MAXXIM MEDICAL AGREES TO BUY STERILE CONCEPTS
abstract: Maxxim Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sterile Concepts Holdings for about $115 million in cash and the assumption of $32 million in debt. The deal would create the second-largest surgical kit and tray distributor behind Baxter International Inc. Maxxim, which made previous attempts to buy Sterile Concepts, agreed to pay $20 for each share. Shares of Sterile Concepts,  which is based in Richmond, fell $1.875, to $19.75, on the New York Stock Exchange, and Maxxim, based in Sugar Land, Tex., rose 75 cents, to $18.625. Maxxim's first offer, made in February, was $16 a share.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Putting Indexing Into Action, in Small Ways
abstract: The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index has been tough to beat in the last few  years. Taking note, investors have been pouring money at a rapid clip into mutual funds that buy the stocks in the index, seeking to match its performance.         There are, however, a few drawbacks to indexing, said Sheldon Jacobs, editor  of The No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. For one, because they aim to be fully invested, meaning that they don't keep significant cash holdings, index funds tend to be volatile. Their managers cannot retreat to cash even if they see tough times ahead.

headline: I.B.M. and Hughes Plan Alliance for Chip That Uses New Material
abstract: A silicon chip that uses a new semiconductor material is edging closer to market as I.B.M. and the Hughes Electronics Corporation plan to announce a collaborative effort today to create high-speed communications products based on the technology.         These chips, which combine the materials silicon and germanium, will not result in more powerful computers, at least initially. Instead, officials of I.B.M. and Hughes Electronics, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said they believed that the first use of the chips would be in extremely high-frequency analog, rather than digital, applications. One likely early product is a small radar system that could be installed in cars and trucks to help avoid collisions. It is expected to add less than $1,000 to the cost of a vehicle.

headline: Palestinians Meet to Rethink Calls for Israel's Destruction
abstract: The Palestine National Council, the Palestinian parliament-in-exile whose roster of members reads like a who's who of Israel's old enemies, convened today in Gaza to hear Yasir Arafat say that the time had come to formally take Israel's destruction off the Palestinian agenda.         Participants here said Mr. Arafat faces some hard bargaining over the next three days. His mission is to convince the members, many of them hard-core radicals, to make a conciliatory gesture toward Israel at a time when Israeli attacks have killed scores of civilians in Lebanon and while Gaza is in its seventh week of harsh Israeli restrictions imposed after a series of suicide bombings in Israel.

headline: Federal Reserve Turns Aside Criticism in G.A.O. Report
abstract: The Federal Reserve Board dismissed most of the criticisms of its management  today that had been included in a recent report to Congress, and said that it ran itself as efficiently as any company or Government agency.         The Fed was responding to a draft report from the General Accounting Office,  the Congressional auditing agency, released last month by two Democratic Senators. The report said that the central bank had been lax in controlling its  costs and questioned whether the Fed was adequately preparing itself for changes in the financial world. The report did not address the Fed's conduct of monetary policy.

headline: P.L.O. ENDS CALL FOR DESTRUCTION OF JEWISH STATE
abstract: Bowing to the insistent demands of Yasir Arafat, the main assembly of the Palestine Liberation Organization voted today to revoke the clauses in its 32-year-old charter that called for an armed struggle to destroy the Jewish state.         The vote came behind closed doors after two days of impassioned speeches at the first meeting of the Palestine National Council, the old Palestinian parliament-in-exile, inside Palestinian lands since Mr. Arafat began peace talks with Israel and gained control over portions of the West Bank and Gaza.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL UNIT ANNOUNCES THAT IT HAS CUT 585 JOBS
abstract: Mobil Exploration and Producing U.S. Inc., a Dallas-based unit of the Mobil Corporation, said yesterday that it had cut 585 jobs in a reorganization announced in January, which also resulted in the loss of 30 more jobs at Mobil Drilling. Mobil said about 500 employees had left the Dallas-based company voluntarily under an incentive plan. Mobil's major exploration and producing units are in Bakersfield, Calif.; Dallas; Houston; Midland, Tex., and New Orleans.

headline: Minntech Advisory Sends Shares Down
abstract: The Minntech Corporation has advised its customers to stop using its Biocor oxygenator because of unexplained incidents of large pressure drops.         Oxygenators are used during open-heart surgery to remove carbon dioxide from  the blood and reinfuse it with oxygen.

headline: SPENDING IT;Low Fares, Sure, but What if Your Flight Is Canceled?
abstract: PASSENGERS on the nation's low-cost airlines save an estimated $6.3 billion a year in air fares, but for many travelers, money is not the only object. Since the Valujet crash last month, travelers have been more concerned about the safety records of some of these carriers. And while these airlines may get you from point A to point B at less expense than their full-service rivals, they generally do not provide the little extras that can make air travel easier and more pleasant.         Southwest Airlines, for example, which has a pristine safety record as the king of the low-fare carriers, flies from Baltimore to Orlando, Fla., for $159,  about a third less than USAir. But if you are then connecting with, say, a Delta Air Lines flight to Nassau, the Bahamas, you'll carry your own bags through the  terminal because Southwest does not transfer luggage.

headline: South Africa Murders Soar
abstract: An average of 52 people are murdered each day in South Africa, making the murder rate nearly 10 times that of the United States, according to police figures released today.         The South African Police Services said 18,983 murders were committed last year, or 87.5 murders per 100,000 people. The figures exclude the former "independent" homelands set up under apartheid, where crime rates were believed  to be similar.

headline: Bear, Stearns Computer
abstract: Bear, Stearns & Company, the nation's sixth-largest securities firm, is buying a Cray Research Inc. supercomputer that would operate 30 to 45 times as fast as the firm's current computers.

headline: Israeli Soldier Kills Gaza Palestinian
abstract: An Israeli soldier shot and killed a Palestinian who ran toward an Israeli Army outpost in the Gaza Strip today, a military spokeswoman said.         "A soldier shouted for him to stop, and when the Palestinian didn't, he fired several shots in the air," an army spokeswoman said. "When he kept on running, he fired toward him and hit him. The Palestinian died of his wounds."

headline: MARKET WATCH;No Hype Here, Or So He Says
abstract: As an entrepreneur, Robert Kopstein has accomplished things that most of us can only dream about. For a few minutes last month, he was a paper billionaire,  with stock that the market valued at $1.2 billion. And he became rich by thumbing his nose at Wall Street, which said stock in his company could not be sold at a fifteenth of that price.         Mr. Kopstein is the 46-year-old chairman, chief executive and, until recently, sole stockholder of the Optical Cable Corporation of Roanoke, Va., which makes fiber optic cable. While it is not a large player in the business, its sales have risen from $12.8 million in 1990 to $38.6 million over the most recent 12 months. And it is profitable, having earned 58 cents a share in fiscal 1995.

headline: Unemployment Off in Germany
abstract: Germany's Federal Labor Office reported today that unemployment fell in April for the first time in nine months.         The jobless report showed that seasonally adjusted joblessness fell by 62,000, to 3.934 million, a bigger drop than most analysts had expected.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;At Japanese Banks, Looks Are Deceiving
abstract: For Japan's banks, 1995 was the year of the $150 billion reckoning.         When the nation's banks announce their 1995 results on Friday and Monday, the aggregate losses -- about $30 billion -- will probably represent the largest amount of red ink ever to flow at one time from any banking industry in the world. By setting aside reserves of $150 billion against unrecoverable debt, Japan's banks are finally admitting in public that they must atone for the financial excesses of the 1980's.

headline: Business Group Sees Strong Job Creation
abstract: Contending that public anxiety about job insecurity has been exaggerated, a major business organization argued yesterday in a new report that the economy was creating millions of higher-paying jobs and this "occupational upgrading" should in time ameliorate the fear over layoffs.         The report from the Committee for Economic Development, a research group financed mostly by major corporations, comes on the heels of a similar report by the National Association of Manufacturers. Together they constitute an endorsement by big business of the Clinton Administration's position, set forth  in its own white paper last week. They also represent an unusual appeal to Republicans, usually closely allied with business, to resist attacks on the Administration that focus on the anxiety about corporate layoffs.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO TO PURCHASE CARLISLE FOR $121 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Tyco International Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy Carlisle Plastics Inc., a maker of specialty packaging materials and garment hangers, for stock valued at  $121 million. Tyco, a maker of packaging materials and disposable medical products in Exeter, N.H., said it plans to exchange 0.172185 of a Tyco share for each of Carlisle's 17.9 million shares. Carlisle shares jumped $1.75 yesterday,  to $6.625, and Tyco's rose 25 cents, to $39.375. Carlisle Plastics, which is based in Phoenix and has annual sales of $400 million, would become part of Tyco's disposable and specialty products business.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McCann to Acquire Torre Renta Lazur
abstract: McCann-Erickson Worldwide said in New York yesterday that it had expanded its health care advertising operations by agreeing in principle to acquire the Torre Renta Lazur Healthcare Group in Parsippany, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.         Joe Torre, 50, the chief executive at Torre Renta, will serve as the head of  McCann's health care division, now called McCann Global Healthcare. Torre Renta, with 130 employees and other offices in La Jolla, Calif., and Freiburg, Germany, will operate as an independent unit of McCann-Erickson, which is owned  by the Interpublic Group of Companies. Torre Renta will work with McCann's existing health care units, which are in 11 countries.

headline: Bill Collector Files for U.S. Bankruptcy
abstract: Credit Exchange Inc., a credit-rating and collections agency that has long been a thorn in the side of slow-paying retailers and apparel manufacturers, has filed for bankruptcy protection.         The agency owed the Internal Revenue Service $465,000, according to its filing on Tuesday for protection under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.

headline: U.S. Industrial Production and Business Inventories Rise
abstract: American industries increased production for a second consecutive month in May and businesses showed signs of rebuilding depleted inventories, a move that  could mean even greater output and more jobs.         "The economy clearly has rebounded from its weakness last year," said Gary Thayer, an economist with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MAIC HOLDINGS INC., Birmingham, Ala., an insurance company, agreed to buy Momed  Holding Co., St. Louis, a liability insurer, for $18.7 million. MAIC plans to exchange either 0.779 share of its common stock or $25.32 in cash for each Momed share.

headline: U.S. WILL OPPOSE MOVE TO RE-ELECT TOP U.N. OFFICIAL
abstract: The Clinton Administration has decided not to support Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as United Nations Secretary General and has informed him that  Washington will use its veto, if necessary, to prevent his re-election, senior American officials said today.         The United States, which considers Mr. Boutros-Ghali an obstacle to reform at the international organization, has begun the process of informing other countries, including other Security Council members, the officials said, describing the decision as irrevocable.

headline: Rig Count Rises by 10
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide rose by 10 last week, to  757, Baker Hughes Inc. said. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : New Rules on Hot Tubs
abstract: Legislators in several states are planning to tighten rules governing hot tubs after a 16-year-old high school student was pinned to the bottom of one during a post-prom party and drowned.

headline: I.B.M. Is Set to Begin Selling Laser Printers Once Again
abstract: I.B.M. is planning to announce tomorrow that it will start selling laser printers designed to be attached to networks of personal computers -- five years after spinning off its printer division for $1.5 billion.         The new printers will compete directly against the Hewlett-Packard Company, the industry leader, which sells an estimated 70 percent of the world's laser printers. Other players are Apple Computer, which makes printers only for Macintosh computers, and the Lexmark International Group, the company created when the International Business Machines Corporation sold its printer business to Wall Street investors in 1991.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;On Slow Day, Bond Prices Rebound a Bit
abstract: The prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, lifted by covering of short positions and by bargain hunting after the sharp selloff on Friday that was prompted by the April employment report. But trading was light, exaggerating the gains, as the market braced for a flood of new securities this week.         The Treasury is selling $73 billion of securities in auctions that will be conducted nearly every day this week. As a result, traders and investors are moving cautiously and large buyers have become scarce.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Telekom Bars Comment on Videotron
abstract: Deutsche Telekom refused yesterday to comment on a report that it was in talks to buy a majority stake in Videotron Holdings P.L.C., a British cable television operator. "The British market is very interesting for us, but we won't comment on these reports," a spokesman, Ulrich Lissek said.

headline: Two Roads to China: Nice, and Not So Nice
abstract: AFTER this month, in an extraordinary example of corporate diplomacy, the Boeing Company will airlift its entire board to China. Ostensibly, the directors will simply be holding their regular bimonthly meeting there, while touring sites like the vast construction hangars in Xian where, with Boeing's help, tens of thousands of workers are trying to transform China into a world-class aerospace power.         But the real purpose of the China tour is to deepen Boeing's ties to a small  clutch of Chinese leaders who are by turns the aircraft maker's best customers and worst torturers. Just as oil companies have paved the way for Middle Eastern kings and emirs in America, Boeing is working harder than ever to impress the Chinese, intervening to defuse the cycle of recriminations between Beijing and Washington that has already begun to poison Boeing's hold on China's civilian aerospace market.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BARNES & NOBLE TO BUY STAKE IN CANADIAN CHAIN
abstract: The bookseller Barnes & Noble Inc. plans to buy a 20 percent stake in Chapters Inc., Canada's largest bookstore chain, its majority shareholder, Canadian General Capital Ltd., said yesterday. Financial details of the deal were unavailable. The deal did not include a management role for Barnes & Noble, which is based in New York and which operates more than 1,000 bookstores. Chapters has 375 stores.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SONAT DRILLING SWEETENS OFFER FOR TRANSOCEAN
abstract: Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. has virtually locked up an acquisition of Transocean A.S. of Norway by raising its bid and winning support from Transocean's largest shareholder, the Tiger Management Corporation, analysts said yesterday. Sonat, a Houston-based drilling company, increased its offer to  0.53 share of its stock, for each share of Transocean. At Sonat's current stock  price, the offer is worth about $27.83 for each Transocean share. The previous offer had been valued about $27.08 a share in cash and stock. Based on yesterday's closing stock prices, the revised Sonat offer values Transocean at $1.43 billion. A rival offer, from the Reading & Bates Corporation, another Houston-based drilling company, values Transocean at $1.49 billion. A spokesman  for Reading & Bates could not be reached for comment.

headline: World News Briefs;Bomb Rips Pakistan Bus; 9 Die and 38 Are Hurt
abstract: A bomb hidden under a seat tore through a passenger bus today, killing 9 people and wounding 38 in Punjab province, witnesses and state-run news organizations said.  No one made any immediate claim of responsibility         Last month a bomb destroyed a crowded bus, killing 43 people.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN COMPANY TO ACQUIRE SHERIDAN SYSTEMS FROM AM
abstract: AM International Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell the assets of its Sheridan Systems division to Heidelberger Druckmaschinen  A.G. of Heidelberg, Germany, for about $56 million in cash. Sheridan Systems, a  supplier of systems and components to both the printing and newspaper publishing industries, had revenues of $182 million in 1995. It has about 700 employees worldwide. The sale does not include AM's AM Multigraphics division, which has operations in North America and Japan. AM International, based in Rosemont, Ill., said it intended to use the proceeds from the sale to reduce liabilities and provide working capital.

headline: Oil, Prices and Politics;Volatile Blend Fuels a Labor Battle at Shut Refinery
abstract: For some 70 years, the huge oil refinery here pumped out gasoline as dependably as the Delaware River, over which it loomed, sent its waters south to the Atlantic.         But since Feb. 1, only the river has been running. On that day, the refinery's owner, the Tosco Corporation of Stamford, Conn., turned off the spigot. It is not clear when, if ever, it will be turned on again.

headline: Turkey Approves a Second Graft Inquiry Into Ex-Premier's Actions
abstract: Parliament approved a second investigation today into corruption allegations  against a former Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, increasing pressure on Turkey's fragile coalition Government.         If ordered to stand trial, Mrs. Ciller would be barred from a power-sharing pact that calls for her to regain the premiership. She has denied any wrongdoing and has said she would instead pull her True Path Party from the coalition and press for elections.

headline: Upheaval in India
abstract: As India begins settling down after a political roller-coaster ride that produced two Governments in two weeks, many in this nation of 930 million people wonder whether they have entered a new era of recurring political upheavals.         After two months of political clamor -- first an inconclusive election, then  a scramble for power among more than 20 parties that won parliamentary seats --  India at last has a Government that seems likely to last for at least a few months.

headline: Vietnam to Retain 3 Aged Leaders, for Now
abstract: After weeks of backstage wrangling, Vietnam's Communist Party has decided to  keep its aged troika of top leaders in place, but to lighten their responsibilities and shorten their terms, a senior Central Committee member said today.         The pivotal Communist Party Congress opened here today with no indications of major policy changes as it gropes toward a formula for a more open, market-oriented economy.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Japanese Explain Error In Downing of U.S. Plane
abstract: The Japanese Navy blamed the chief weapons officer aboard a destroyer today for the shooting down of an American plane during maneuvers in the mid-Pacific this month.         "The cause of the accident was that the chief weapons officer of the Yugiri made the wrong assumption," said Rear Adm. Kataru Hasegawa, the navy's chief inspector. The incident occurred on June 4 during maneuvers in the mid-Pacific.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Liberia Peacekeepers Fan Out in Capital
abstract: Fighters loyal to faction leaders have withdrawn from the center of Monrovia, the Liberian capital, and peacekeeping forces began fanning out today to more outlying districts.         Witnesses said soldiers of the West African peacekeeping force moved into the eastern Sinkor district for the first time since the renewed fighting in the country's civil war began there on April 6.

headline: World News Briefs;Burmese Rulers Ban Speeches by Dissident
abstract: The Burmese military has prohibited the country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, from holding her weekly speech to supporters outside her home, opposition officials said today.         The officials, who insisted on anonymity, said the authorities had contacted  Aung Shwe, chairman of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy, and told him the meetings would be banned beginning Saturday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. to Honor Trade Ruling Against It on Foreign Fuel
abstract: The Clinton Administration agreed today to honor a ruling against the United  States by the World Trade Organization, saying it would change the way it applies environmental regulations to imported gasoline.         The Administration was responding to a finding by the trade group earlier this year that American environmental laws unfairly discriminated against gasoline imported from Venezuela and Brazil.

headline: Le Mai, 56, Dies; Vietnam's Voice in Relations With the U.S.
abstract: Le Mai, Vietnam's Deputy Foreign Minister, who for many years was his country's voice in its edgy postwar relationship with the United States, died of a heart attack on Wednesday, the Foreign Ministry said today. He was 56.         A junior member of the Paris negotiating team that secured America's withdrawal from Vietnam in 1973 and a chief architect of Hanoi's more recent campaign for diplomatic relations with Washington, Mr. Mai was fond of reminding Americans that "Vietnam is a country, not only a war."

headline: Owens-Corning Sues 3 Asbestos Test Labs
abstract: Owens-Corning Fiberglas, the big building-products manufacturer that has been chafing from decades of asbestos litigation, has sued three medical-testing laboratories, contending that they falsified tens of thousands of test results supporting claims against the company.         The lawsuit, filed on Wednesday in United States District Court in New Orleans, cited what Owens-Corning said were 1,431 fraudulent reports indicating non-malignant asbestos-related respiratory illnesses. But the company also said it was seeking to remove as many as 40,000 cases from its backlog of asbestos claims.

headline: Iran's Party of God Puts Deep Roots in Lebanon
abstract: Through more than a decade of confrontation with Israel, the Iranian-backed Party of God has waged war against both soldiers and civilians in a relentless campaign to drive Israeli occupiers out of southern Lebanon.

headline: U.S.-China Talks: A Big Agenda, Little Progress
abstract: A much anticipated meeting between senior Chinese and United States officials to discuss disputes over the spread of nuclear weapons, trade, Taiwan, human rights and the piracy of American software and music produced little today except atmospherics and promises to continue to discuss differences.         American officials said the meeting, between the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher, produced a candid and sometimes sharp exchange of views on the range of problems. But they provided few details of significant progress on the central issues of China's nuclear-related equipment sales to Pakistan and the Chinese piracy of software,  music and videos, which has the Americans drawing up retaliatory sanctions that  could affect up to $2 billion in Chinese imports.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Greenwich Air Reduces Offer
abstract: Greenwich Air Services Inc. said today that it had reduced the amount it would pay for its planned acquisition of Aviall Inc.'s engine service division to about $250 million.         Greenwich Air said in February that it would buy the division for as much as  $280 million. The sale remains contingent on Greenwich Air's obtaining financing.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Group Wins Singapore Rail Pact
abstract: ABB Daimler-Benz Transportation and its partners won a $202.1 million contract yesterday to build Singapore's first light-rail commuter line, opening  the door to a possible $850 million of further business.          The ABB group, including Keppel Integrated Engineering Ltd., also known as KIE, beat out around 10 other bids by consortiums of Singapore and foreign companies to build the Light Rail Transit system.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Provident Agrees to Acquire Paul Revere for $1.2 Billion
abstract: The Provident Companies, the No. 2 seller of individual disability insurance  policies, agreed yesterday to buy the No. 1 insurer in the field in a deal that  would give it more than one-third of the market.         The $1.2 billion deal would eliminate about 600 jobs, give a big Swiss insurer a toehold in this niche and may presage a big write-off on money-losing  policies sold by the insurer that is being acquired, the Paul Revere Company.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A White House Gaffe Puts Clinton in China's Corner
abstract: As the Clinton Administration heads into the last week of a showdown with China over its failure to live up to a major trade agreement, an oversight by the White House is putting President Clinton in the politically delicate position of having to assert that China is opening markets and lowering its barriers to American companies.         The assurance would come in the form of a certification that is ordinarily part of routine renewal of the basic trade agreement that underlies all American trade ties with China.

headline: GTE Gets Contract From the Big Board
abstract: The GTE Corporation said today that it had a contract to provide a wireless-data system and communications services on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange.         A GTE spokesman would not say how much the deal was worth but said it was "a  significant portion" of the exchange's $125 million program to invest in technology.

headline: China Cautions U.S. and Japan on Security Pact
abstract: For the first time since the end of the cold war, the Chinese Government expressed public concern today that the United States-Japan security alliance that served to contain the former Soviet Union might now shift its focus toward  China.         Speaking here one day after President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan reaffirmed the 45-year-old security arrangement in Tokyo, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Shen Guofang, cautioned both parties to limit its scope.

headline: Yahoo Gets Big Welcome On Wall Street
abstract: Yahoo Inc., named to celebrate the rowdy culture of the Internet, found a warm welcome on staid Wall Street yesterday. Investors, undaunted by Yahoo's lack of profits and formidable array of competitors, gave the young company a first-day market valuation of nearly $1 billion.         Underwriters, led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, set an offering price of $13 Thursday night on 2.6 million new shares, but the stock opened yesterday at $24.50 as demand outstripped supply. The shares rose quickly in very heavy trading to reach $43 before settling back to $33 at the end of the day.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHOENIX NETWORK INC., San Francisco, a provider of long-distance telecommunications management services, agreed to acquire Americonnect Inc., of  Park, Kan., which buys and resells long-distance services, in a stock swap valued about $14.2 million.

headline: The Great Mystery of Internet Profits
abstract: Luring talent has not been a problem for Mike Slade, president of the Starwave Corporation. The recruits to this startup company in suburban Seattle include refugees from well-paid jobs as editors, writers and advertising executives in New York and as software engineers in Silicon Valley. They have come to be pioneers in the new medium of publishing on the Internet's World Wide Web, to build a business and, if successful, to become rich.         "There's a gold-rush mentality in this field," Mr. Slade observed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MINNESOTA MINING AND MANUFACTURING CO., St. Paul, set June 28 as the date for the spinoff of its data storage and imaging systems businesses, Imation Corp. Investors will receive 1 Imation share for every 10 shares of 3M stock held.

headline: Kuala Lumpur Journal;Malaysia Looks Down on World From 1,483 Feet
abstract: In the afternoons, their twin pinnacles are lost in the monsoon rain clouds.  At night they twinkle like parallel columns of stars. Malaysia officially became home recently not only to the tallest but even to the two tallest buildings in the world, the side-by-side Petronas Towers.         For the first time in more than a century, the United States is not home to the world's tallest building.  Perhaps it had to happen. And where else should the title go but to Asia, where national economies are growing faster than anywhere else in the world?

headline: Not All Aboard: A Big Rail Merger and Its Critics;Sidetracked Since '13, Plan Still Raises Antitrust Fears
abstract: Talk about your rocky romances. Born as rivals seeking to build the biggest stretch of the first transcontinental railroad in the late 1860's, the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific railroads came close to marriage by the turn of the century only to have their union scotched in 1913 by a disapproving Supreme Court.         Now, the two railroads are once again hoping to get hitched in a $5.4 billion deal that would create a 37,000-mile rail network linking 25 states, Mexico and  Canada. And, once again, the road to the altar is proving rocky.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FORD SELLS SHARES OF CONSUMER FINANCE UNIT
abstract: The Associates First Capital Corporation sold 67 million shares yesterday at  $29 each to raise $1.94 billion in the nation's third-largest initial public offering. Associates, the consumer finance unit of the Ford Motor Company, initially sought $25 to $28 for the shares, but raised the price range because of investor demand. A group of underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company priced the stock yesterday after the close of trading. Associates, based in Irving, Tex., is the largest publicly owned finance company in the United States.

headline: Mitsubishi Overture In Harassment Case
abstract: Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America wants to settle what could become the biggest Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, the company's chairman said, indicating that Mitsubishi was softening its hard line in the case.         Business Day, page D1.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Seagram Profits Drop on Lower Results at MCA and Liquor Unit
abstract: The Seagram Company said today that its earnings dropped to $23 million in the first quarter from a year earlier, when it recorded a huge gain from the sale of stock in E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.         But Seagram's earnings based on cash flow rose nearly 50 percent on new profits from the Dole juice business and Seagram's 80 percent stake in MCA Inc., both of which were acquired in the last year. Wine and liquor sales, however, were weaker.

headline: New Leader at Helm of the Microsoft Network
abstract: Russell Siegelman, who guided the Microsoft Network, or MSN, on-line service  from its inception to a subscriber base of more than a million users, said on Friday that he was stepping down to pursue other interests within the Microsoft  Corporation.         Mr. Siegelman will be succeeded by Laura Jennings, who was named vice president of the Microsoft Network on Friday. Ms. Jennings, who joined MSN as executive producer last fall, previously was in charge of developing software that enabled groups of workers to collaborate.

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Lawmaker Arrives In North Korea for Talks
abstract: An American Congressman arrived in North Korea today to try to persuade officials to accept proposed four-nation peace talks.         Representative Bill Richardson, Democrat of New Mexico, accompanied by State  and Defense Department officials, arrived in the North Korean capital, Pyongyang, the official Korean Central News Agency said.

headline: Chief of Prudential Mutual Fund Unit Resigns Unexpectedly
abstract: The chief executive of Prudential Mutual Fund Management Inc., the mutual fund arm of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, has unexpectedly resigned, leading some fund industry analysts to question whether Prudential is  readying itself to begin selling its funds directly to consumers in addition to  offering them through its stock brokers and insurance agents.         Richard A. Redeker, who joined Prudential as head of its mutual funds unit in September 1993, announced his resignation in an inter-office memo dated May 29.  Mr. Redeker is the second senior executive in a month to leave Prudential mutual funds, which is the country's 16th largest mutual fund company, with $44.7 billion in fund assets.

headline: Judge Backs Settlement in Archer Lawsuit
abstract: A Federal judge gave preliminary approval today to a $45 million settlement of a civil lawsuit accusing the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company and its competitors of fixing prices for an animal feed supplement that speeds muscle growth.         Federal District Judge Milton Shadur said the proposed settlement of the class-action suit was fair and adequate.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHWOODS PROPERTIES IN DEAL FOR CROCKER REALTY
abstract: Highwoods Properties Inc. has agreed to buy Crocker Realty Trust Inc. in a $537.5 million deal that will significantly expand Highwoods's holdings in the Southeast. Highwoods will acquire all of the stock in Crocker, a real estate investment trust in Boca Raton, Fla., for $11.02 a share, or about $297.5 million, and will assume about $240 million of debt. Highwoods, which is based in Raleigh, N.C., will gain a portfolio that includes 70 suburban office buildings totaling 5.7 million square feet in seven Southeastern states. Highwoods's shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $30.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Crocker shares rose $1.125, to $11.125, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: Burmese Foe Of Military Says Backers Are Arrested
abstract: At least 80 supporters of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, have been detained by authorities in advance of a major meeting of her opposition party planned for this weekend, one of her assistants said today.         The assistant, who insisted on not being identified, said by telephone from Yangon, the capital of the former Burma, that new reports of arrests were continuing to arrive and that "our information may not be complete."

headline: When It Comes to Health, Remember the Children
abstract: To the Editor:         "A Double Standard in Health Coverage" (March 17) was on the mark, but it did not discuss how the differences in health coverage between company executives and rank-and-file workers affect the nation's children.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: High Court Strikes Down Restriction on Liquor Ads The Supreme Court struck down a Rhode Island ban on advertising liquor prices. The ruling casts doubt on the Clinton Administration's proposed curbs on cigarette promotions intended to thwart sales to minors.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;British Utility Parrying a Bid by Southern
abstract: National Power P.L.C. sought today to fend off a hostile takeover bid from the Southern Company of Atlanta by agreeing to buy a British utility for L2.5 billion, or $3.78 billion.         The acquisition of the utility, Southern Electric, could make National Power  too big to swallow. Southern already owns a British utility, South Western Electricity, and Government regulators might balk at the American company's proposed merger with National Power.

headline: Lockheed Will Shut A California Plant
abstract: The Lockheed Martin Corporation will close its plant in Ontario, Calif., within two years, dismissing 500 employees, the company said today.         Lockheed, the world's largest aerospace company, will transfer the remaining  1,000 workers at the Ontario plant to a factory in Palmdale, Calif., about 50 miles away.

headline: Algerian President Promises Elections Early Next Year
abstract: Algeria's President promised today to hold new legislative elections next year, but did not say whether the country's outlawed Islamic opposition would be allowed to take part.         An Islamic insurgency began in Algeria in January 1992, when the military-backed Government canceled legislative elections the Islamic Salvation  Front was expected to win.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week.      Monday

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Rise on Signs That Iraq Isn't Close to Accord With U.N.
abstract: Crude oil prices rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs  that Iraq and the United Nations were far apart on an agreement to allow limited sales of oil.

headline: In Mongolia Vote, Poverty Is the Issue
abstract: The voting district that Hashbat Hulan hopes to represent in this vast land of mountain ranges and sprawling Asian steppes is on the eastern edge of town, where people live in crumbling Soviet-style apartment blocks or in tentlike yurts.         To explain why she is running as an opposition candidate for a seat in Mongolia's Great Hural, or Parliament, on June 30, Ms. Hulan pointed to a recent survey showing that in 43 percent of the households in her district not a single person has a stable source of income.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CLOROX BUYS LESTOIL FROM UNIT OF PROCTER
abstract: The Clorox Company purchased the Lestoil brand heavy-duty cleaner yesterday from the Noxell Corporation, a unit of the Procter & Gamble Company, for cash. Specific financial terms were not disclosed. Clorox said it expected the brand to have "a slightly positive impact" on earnings in the fiscal year beginning on July 1. The acquisition includes Procter & Gamble's global trademark rights to Lestoil and finished product inventories but no manufacturing facilities. Procter & Gamble said the sale was part of a corporate program announced last June to divest itself of certain nonstrategic brands.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HERMAN'S SPORTING GOODS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., which operates 117 stores in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had again filed for bankruptcy. The filing of the voluntary Chapter 11 petition in the United States Bankruptcy Court in Trenton was the second time the retailer, based in Carteret, N.J., had applied for protection from its creditors. It previously filed in 1993. As of March 30, Herman's had $127.8 million in assets and $160.5 million in liabilities, according to the filing. Among the top unsecured creditors the company listed were Reebok International, Rollerblade Inc., Authentic Fitness, Russell, Nike and Prince Sports Group. All of the company's stores will remain open for business, Herman's said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BIO-TECHNOLOGY GENERAL SHARES FALL ON COURT RULING
abstract: Shares of the Bio-Technology General Corporation fell nearly 14 percent yesterday after it said on Monday that a Federal appeals court had upheld an injunction awarded to Genentech Inc., a unit of Roche Holding, preventing Bio-Technology from selling its human growth hormone, Bio-Tropin, in the United  States. The court ruled that there was some merit in Genetech's patent-infringement suit, which will now continue at Federal District Court in New York. Bio-Technology shares fell 93.75 cents, to $5.8125. The company sells  Bio-Tropin in several markets overseas and the drug accounts for about 90 percent of Bio-Technology General's annual sales. The drug's American market is  estimated at $300 million to $400 million a year.

headline: Sony Cuts Machine's Price
abstract: The Sony Corporation has cut the price of its Playstation video-game machine  to $199, making the price $50 less than comparable machines from rivals like Sega Enterprises and Nintendo. The move is intended to help Sony sell an avalanche of its game machines before next-generation products from its rivals take off. On Wednesday, Nintendo displayed its Nintendo 64 game player, which it plans to sell in the United States starting Sept. 30. The Playstation previously cost $299.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Australia Investigates Diplomatic Sex Scandal
abstract: Australia launched an official inquiry today into allegations that its diplomats were involved in child-sex rings in Asia, but the opposition said the  closed-door investigation needed to be made public.         The inquiry will also look into accusations of cover-ups and set up procedures for exposing pedophiles in the future, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer told Parliament.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;J Sky B Satellite Planned for Japan
abstract: The Softbank Corporation and the News Corporation said yesterday that the focus of their recently announced joint venture would be digital satellite broadcasting in Japan.  Softbank's president, Masayoshi Son, said that the venture would probably be called J Sky B, the name for a 100-channel digital satellite project recently announced by the News Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch.          The two plan to begin the venture within two years and will face competition from two other digital satellite services aiming at the Japanese market. Softbank and News Corporation announced a joint venture last week to buy a 20 percent stake in the TV Asahi broadcasting network for 41.75 billion yen ($387 million). (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: China Wants U.S. to Continue Trade Talks
abstract: Beijing issued a stern warning to the United States today to come to the trade negotiating table, saying a looming trade war over copyright piracy threatened the American position in China's huge markets.         The official China Daily Business Weekly quoted trade officials and experts as saying that Washington had failed to produce any evidence for its claims of widespread theft of intellectual property in China.

headline: A Gathering By Burmese Defies Junta
abstract: Defying Burmese Government threats of harsh punishment, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of a pro-democracy campaign, addressed more than 5,000 supporters who gathered in front of her house today.         The gathering lasted an hour, and there was no interference from the authorities.

headline: Montgomery Ward May Consider Selling Its Retail Stores
abstract: The Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation is seeking to raise cash and may consider the sale of its retail stores, people close to the company said yesterday.         Montgomery Ward, which was acquired through a $3.8 billion leveraged buyout by the General Electric Company's finance unit and company management in 1988, has 387 retail stores in 43 states that sell low-priced clothing and housewares, as well as the Signature Group, a direct marketing unit.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain Cuts Interest Rate In Bid to Spur Economy
abstract: The Bank of Spain cut its key money market rate by a quarter percentage point yesterday to 7.25 percent, hoping to stimulate the economy after a recent downward revision of 1996 growth forecasts. The rate cut, the fifth this year, brings the key money market rate down from 9 percent in January.          The Government last week revised its growth forecast for 1996 down to 2.3 percent from 2.8 percent. It also announced spending cuts of 200 billion pesetas ($1.6 billion), the brunt of which will fall on public works, transport and the environment.   (Reuters)

headline: U.S. Pullout Not Popular With Some In Okinawa
abstract: When the United States began returning a military base that includes the famous Sugar Loaf battle site of World War II, the Okinawan authorities promised that it would be quickly developed.         That was 19 years ago, and the spot is still a vast vacant lot -- 475 acres of mud and grass and hillocks, surrounded by modern steel and glass office buildings of Naha, the Okinawan capital. It is prime real estate, but full development may still be a decade away.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. Chooses Thailand As Site for Big Asian Plant General Motors plans to announce today that it has chosen Thailand over the Philippines as the site for a huge new Southeast Asian assembly plant.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT/Page 4/ You'd never know Donna Karan, the dressmaker, was in its Government-mandated quiet period from the way its chief executive goes on -- and on. By Jennifer Steinhauer.

headline: Market Place;Valujet's fate is hard to predict, but many see revival by year-end.
abstract: HISTORY has shown that predicting an airline's future can be tricky. Some analysts recommended the stock of Continental and America West a few days before they filed for bankruptcy protection. Predictions a few years ago of the imminent demise of Trans World Airlines have been replaced by recent talk of a turnaround.         And so the question of Valujet's future has prompted predictable hedging from industry experts after the crash of a Valujet plane 12 days ago near Miami. Still, most analysts said Valujet would most likely survive and recover from the crash by the end of the year unless the airline was found to be criminally negligent. Valujet is unlikely, however, to regain its reputation anytime soon as a rapidly growing company with unusually high profit margins for the airline  industry.

headline: India Sends In Troops to Make Sure Kashmiris Cast Votes
abstract: Indian troops moved into villages and urban neighborhoods across the Vale of  Kashmir at dawn today, rousing Muslims from their beds to vote in the first election to be held in the only Indian state with a Muslim majority since a Muslim separatist rebellion began in 1989.         By holding voting for the six seats in Parliament allotted to Kashmir, the Indian Government aimed to show that a large fighting force has beaten back the  insurgency.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Municipal Bond Funds May Be Perking Up
abstract: THE year did not start out well for municipal bond funds. A roller-coaster ride in interest rates -- especially the sudden rate surge in mid-February -- whipsawed them far more than corporate bond funds.         But in the months ahead, municipal bond funds may begin to provide investors  fewer bumps and better returns, many bond analysts say. "Looking out for the next six months, I think it's a pretty decent environment for municipal bonds,"  said Thomas Kenny, director of the municipal bond department at the Franklin/Templeton fund group.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL NUTRITION ISSUES A WARNING AND ITS STOCK FALLS
abstract: The stock of the General Nutrition Companies dropped 24 percent yesterday after the company, the nation's largest vitamin and sports nutrition store chain, warned late on Tuesday of disappointing second-quarter earnings. The stock fell $4.50, to $14, on the Nasdaq market, where it was the most active issue with 36.6 million shares traded. General Nutrition said it expected per-share earnings of 19 cents, below the 21 cents forecast by Wall Street analysts. The Pittsburgh-based company said its third- and fourth-quarter earnings were expected to improve, but still fall short of analysts' estimates.

headline: Fighting Reported at Start of Chechen Truce
abstract: Russian and Chechen fighters accused each other of violating a cease-fire today just hours after it had begun, and the Russian commander in the separatist republic warned that his troops might be forced to "decisively destroy" rebel forces.         President Boris N. Yeltsin negotiated the truce this week with the rebel leader, Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev, in the hope of convincing voters that he was winding down the unpopular war before Russia's presidential election on June 16.

headline: Market Place;Good days for the American steel business, as the orders stream in.
abstract: THIS is a good time to be in the steel business, even if that is not obvious  from first-quarter earnings -- which are down, in some cases sharply, from last  year's levels.         But those results are history, the product of soft prices late last year as well as problems resulting from strikes, weather and production problems at plants that have been running practically flat out since 1992.

headline: Arbitrators Seek Inquiry Into Prudential Unit's Practices
abstract: Prudential Securities' problems from its disastrous foray into limited partnership sales in the 1980's are not over yet.         In a highly unusual move, an arbitration panel of the New York Stock Exchange has asked the enforcement division of the exchange to investigate two firm practices that have been widely criticized by former Prudential brokers.

headline: MARKETS CLOSED
abstract: All financial and commodity markets and banks in the United States are closed today in observance of Memorial Day. A number of European markets, including those in Germany and Britain, are also closed for local holidays.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHILIP MORRIS TO INVEST MORE IN U.S. TOBACCO UNIT
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that it would double capital spending on its United States tobacco unit in particular this year to increase production of cigarettes for sale in the United States and abroad. The company would not disclose how much capital spending for its United States tobacco production was last year. Its total capital expenditures for the year were $1.62 billion.

headline: EARNING IT;Slow Gains for Women Who Would Be Partners
abstract: ANN ZIEGLER was tired of waiting. After more than eight years as a lawyer, her firm still had not made her a partner. So she quit and joined the legal department of the Sara Lee Corporation, where she was promoted within two years.         Although her firm, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom of New York, says she might eventually have made partner, Ms. Ziegler said she didn't regret leaving.

headline: A Revamp of 1556 Edict : France Reforms Auction System
abstract: PARIS—  Within two years, the Paris auction market will have changed beyond recognition.A government official announced last fall that France was, in effect, ready to drop the century-old rule that reserves the right to hold auctions on French territory as the exclusive monopoly of judiciary officers called commissaires-priseurs.

headline: World News Briefs;Burmese Activists Plan To Meet Despite Arrests
abstract: The country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said today that she would go ahead with a planned party congress this weekend despite the arrests of nearly 200 opposition politicians by the Burmese Government.         By today, the military had detained 191 people who planned to attend the three-day conference, which begins on Sunday, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi said.

headline: Ford Selling Rail Business To Unit of First Union Bank
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, which said last fall that it intended to get rid of its nonautomotive finance operations, took a step in that direction yesterday, announcing that it had agreed to sell its rail-services business to a unit of the First Union Corporation for about $900 million.         The rail-services business is part of USL Capital, an operation Ford purchased in 1987 for $512 million. The company, then publicly owned, was known as U.S. Leasing.

headline: Croat Journalists on Trial
abstract: Two independent journalists went on trial today accused of defaming President Franjo Tudjman in a case that has helped sour Croatia's relations with Western Europe.          Viktor Ivancic and Marinko Culic, editor and lead writer of the satirical weekly Feral Tribune, were indicted under the criminal code that outlaws defamation of state leadership. They face up to three years in jail if convicted.

headline: Blue Cross Lawsuit Filed Against Missouri
abstract: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri, the state's largest health insurer, is taking the state to court over its bid to collect hundreds of millions of dollars from the company.         In a suit filed this week in Cole County, the company charges misconduct by the state's Insurance Department and asks a circuit judge to order regulators to relent.

headline: Rise in Output Doesn't Move Bonds Much
abstract: The prices of Treasury securities were virtually unchanged yesterday, with the market showing little reaction to a report that industrial production surged in April.         The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 1/32, to 89 13/32, leaving its yield at 6.83 percent, unchanged from Tuesday.

headline: Ecuador Vote Narrows Race To Privatizer And Populist
abstract: In the first round of presidential elections Ecuadoreans voted today for two  men with sharply different visions for Ecuador, a country that has become a reluctant convert to free-market reforms. They are Jaime Nebot, a Social Christian who would forge ahead with plans to privatize key sectors of the economy, and Abdala Bucaram, a populist who would retain some of the state's biggest holdings and who opposes reform of the bloated social security system.         While final results from today's ballot are not expected until Wednesday, preliminary exit polls showed Mr. Nebot taking 29.8 percent of the vote and Mr.  Bucaram with 25.6 percent. Because Mr. Nebot, the expected front-runner, did not win an absolute majority in the race of nine candidates, the two men will face each other at the polls again in July.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;T.W.A. PLANS TO RAISE $183 MILLION IN A STOCK OFFERING
abstract: Trans World Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it planned to raise about $183  million by offering investors eight million common shares. In a filing with the  Securities and Exchange Commission, the carrier, which is based in St. Louis, said the proceeds from the offering would be put toward general purposes, including capital expenditures and working capital. Paine Webber Inc., Alex. Brown & Sons Inc. and the BT Securities Corporation are managing the offering, which could include another 1.2 million shares to cover additional demand. T.W.A. expects to have about 45 million shares outstanding after the offering. Shares of T.W.A. fell $1.875 yesterday, to $19.125, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUPS PURCHASE BIG STAKE IN MAGIC CINEMAS
abstract: William E. Simon & Sons and the CIT Group/Equity Investments Inc. have bought an equity stake in Magic Cinemas L.L.C., a closely held operator of movie theaters. The investors paid between $6 million and $10 million for the stake, said Jeffrey Davidson, chief executive of Magic, based in Livingston, N.J. Magic expects to open about 150 screens in the next three years. Currently, it operates 37 screens. The company, formerly known as Movie Entertainment Inc., plans to expand into eastern Pennsylvania and southern Connecticut. Simon, a private investment company, was founded by William E. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary. CIT Group/Equity Investments Inc. is a subsidiary of the CIT Group Holdings Inc. of Livingston, N.J.

headline: In San Francisco, Print Books Are Still in Style
abstract: Perhaps Kenneth E. Dowlin, San Francisco's head librarian, can be forgiven for being a little prickly.         The author of the 1984 book "The Electronic Library," Mr. Dowlin often finds  it necessary to sidestep barbs thrown his way by those who fear that computers and the Internet could make the typeset volume obsolete. "At one point there was a rumor going around that I was going to throw away all the books," he said.

headline: In a Swirling Storm, the Fed Governors Stay Calm
abstract: By 9:15 this morning, when the Federal Reserve Governor Lawrence B. Lindsey arrived at his office, the bond market had already rendered its judgment on the  news, released 45 minutes earlier, that employment growth in May was stronger than expected: It sent long-term interest rates sharply higher in the expectation that the Fed would soon tighten monetary policy to cool down an economy at risk of overheating.         By the end of the day, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was down 112/32 , its biggest decline in two months, driving the yield up to 7.02 percent from 6.89 percent on Thursday. The stock market initially plunged, falling nearly 87  points, then recovered, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at 5697.11, up 29.92.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;West Publishing Purchase By Thomson Is Approved
abstract: The Justice Department gave conditional approval yesterday to the Thomson Corporation's $3.4 billion purchase of the West Publishing Company, but it insisted that Thomson sell 58 legal publications valued at about $275 million and license certain services to competitors.         Without the divestitures, the Justice Department's antitrust division said, the acquisition would have stifled competition in several states for the lucrative business of on-line legal research.

headline: Microsoft Buys Game Company
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had acquired Exos Inc., a maker  of personal computer video game control devices that enable users to feel effects like race-car crashes, flight turbulence and gun recoils more realistically.          Financial terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Northwest Announces Air China Agreement
abstract: The Northwest Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to an alliance with Air China to steer passengers to each other's flights. In December, the United States and China agreed to allow their countries' airlines  to promote flights together. Northwest said its Air China venture was the first  alliance between major United States and Chinese airlines.          The deal includes code-sharing, which will allow the airlines to attach their two-letter codes to each other's flights in travel agents' computers and then advertise and sell those flights as their own. Northwest currently operates flights from Los Angeles to Beijing and Shanghai. It plans to begin nonstop Detroit-Beijing service on May 1.   AP

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: MAN IN THE NEWS;The 'American' Premier: Benjamin Netanyahu
abstract: A conversation with Israelis about Benjamin Netanyahu inevitably comes around to how "American" he is.         Some say it with admiration, some with disdain, but they talk of his American accent, his American education, his Kennedy-style clan and the American name he  once tried -- Ben Nitay.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;North and South Korea At Odds on DMZ Patrols
abstract: South Korea put its military on a heightened state of alert today after North Korea announced it would "give up its duty" of jointly controlling the demilitarized zone separating the two nations.         In a statement explaining its security measures, the Defense Ministry characterized the North's move as "an almost complete abrogation of the armistice, and different from its previous moves to discredit it."

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Slip on Housing Data, Then Recover
abstract: After faltering in the wake of a strong housing report yesterday, Treasury bonds rallied from session lows to end mixed. Contributing to the rebound was the Government's sale of five-year notes, which was surprisingly robust despite  recent comments by Fed officials that have suggested an upsurge in inflation.         The price of the 30-year issue rose 7/32 , to 8813/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, dropped to 6.92 percent, from 6.94 percent on Wednesday.

headline: Airman Guilty in Okinawa
abstract: A United States Air Force enlisted man was found guilty today of having sex with a 14-year-old American girl at an air base on Okinawa.         Senior Airman Anthony T. Williams, 24, was also convicted by a court martial  of committing indecent acts with a minor and adultery, base officials said. He was sentenced to 20 months in prison, given a reduction in rank and will receive a bad-conduct discharge.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;No Merger Expected For Lucas and Varity
abstract: Lucas Industries of Britain said yesterday that it did not expect the Varity  Corporation to bid for its stock, indicating that the companies have been discussing a venture limited to their brakes businesses.          The two auto parts makers said on Monday that they were discussing a "strategic combination." In a one-sentence statement yesterday to Britain's takeover panel, Lucas said the talks would probably not lead to a bid for its stock. Varity, based in Buffalo, has been streamlining to concentrate on anti-lock brakes.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Stocks Down in Tokyo
abstract: Shares traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues  was down 135.35 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,464.73. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 39.69 points.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MERCK-MEDCO MANAGED CARE TO BUY SYSTEMED
abstract: Merck-Medco Managed Care Inc., a unit of Merck & Company, said yesterday that it would acquire Systemed Inc. for about $67 million, or $3 a share. Systemed, based in Torrance, Calif., manages pharmacy benefit programs for employers, insurers and government agencies. The company also operates a mail-order pharmacy in Des Moines and a claims-processing business in Cleveland. Systemed had sales of $152 million and net income of $4.3 million last year. Systemed shares fell 31.25 cents, to $2.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Merck-Medco is based in  Whitehouse Station, N.J.

headline: Apple Chief Is Seen Retreating From Price Cuts
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. may be preparing to extract itself from the computer industry price wars.         Apple's new chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, is planning to return the embattled computer maker to a strategy of setting itself apart from the rest of the personal computer industry by trying to develop machines so reliable and sought after that customers willingly pay premium prices, according to employees who have attended meetings with him. For the last three years, Apple had adopted a strategy of competing directly in price with makers of personal computers based on Intel chips and Microsoft operating systems, which dominate the market.

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are 6% Higher on Nasdaq
abstract: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose nearly 6 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.         For the month ended June 15, uncovered short positions totaled 1.08 billion shares in 5,378 stocks. That compares with 1.02 billion uncovered short positions in 5,328 stocks in the month ended May 15, the first time short-selling on Nasdaq surpassed the billion-share level.

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE ORTHODOX;Orthodox Welcome New Powers, And See Big Effects on Daily Life
abstract: Although it was not a Jewish holiday, the streets of this ardently Orthodox suburb of Tel Aviv had an uncommonly festive air today, with the talk at the bustling shops and restaurants all about the new power the Orthodox have snatched in Israel.         In Steisel's Restaurant, Hasidic men, seated in front of plates heaped with stuffed green peppers and potato pudding, took deep puffs of filtered cigarettes and chuckled as they passed their time with predictions of an Israel led by Benjamin Netanyahu and a Parliament with a record 25 deputies from religious parties.

headline: Arafat's Powers of Survival Being Put to the Test
abstract: Only a few weeks ago, Yasir Arafat was riding high, the elected ruler of a state that seemed about to be born.         With the election in Israel of the Likud candidate, Benjamin Netanyahu, who vowed not to give in to many of the Palestinians' most cherished demands, his world seemed to crumble.

headline: Mexico Is Near To Granting Expatriates Voting Rights
abstract: In a surprise development, the country's main political parties have agreed in recent negotiations over voting reforms to grant Mexican citizens living outside Mexico the right to cast ballots in presidential elections.         As a result, the Mexican Congress seems nearly certain to approve a constitutional amendment giving voting rights to the seven million migrant workers and other Mexican expatriates living in the United States when it votes  on a package of electoral reforms this summer, lawmakers and party leaders said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MRS. SMITH'S TO BE SOLD TO FLOWERS, NOT CONAGRA
abstract: The J. M. Smucker Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mrs.  Smith's frozen pie business to Flowers Industries instead of to Conagra Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. Smucker said the sale would result in a charge of 4 cents a share against its 1996 results. Smucker had tentatively agreed in February to sell Mrs. Smith's, which it acquired from the Kellogg Company in 1994, to Conagra. The sale of Mrs. Smith's, which generates $110 million in annual sales, is expected to close at the end of May, Smucker said. Flowers, which is based in Thomasville, Ga., makes food products for retail and  food-service customers.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Quarterly Net Is Up 20% At Times Co.
abstract: rose nearly 20 percent, slightly exceeding the expectations of most Wall Street  analysts.         The main reason for the higher-than-expected profits, analysts said, was the  ability of the company's newspapers to increase advertising rates and circulation charges over the last year without losing large numbers of advertisers or readers.

headline: West African Surprise: Suddenly, Peace Takes Root in Sierra Leone
abstract: Six months ago, while neighboring Liberia seemed well on its way to ending its catastrophic civil war, Sierra Leone stood out in the minds of many in this  region as the most hopeless case in West Africa.         Army officers who had seized power ruled over the capital, Freetown, enriching themselves in the clandestine diamond trade. South African mercenaries bloodily prosecuted a seemingly unwinnable bush war against one of the continent's most vicious guerrilla movements.

headline: Britain's Daunting Prospect: Killing 15,000 Cows a Week
abstract: In the last two weeks, the British mad cow scare has humiliated the Government, agonized the $6.5 billon beef industry and turned carnivores into vegetarians.         The latest twist, in the form of a proposed remedy, is a logistical nightmare: how to kill at least 15,000 "older" cows a week for five or six years and destroy their carcasses.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: MAIN STREET BANKGROUP INC., Martinsville, Va., a bank holding company, agreed to acquire Hanover Bank, of Mechanicsville, Va., for $24.6 million. Main Street will pay Hanover's stockholders $15.25 for each share held.

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;The Lessons From Dad's Counter
abstract: MY father, like his father before him, owned a small, retail store. Syd's Camera Shop was in White Plains, N.Y., on Main Street -- the proverbial, provincial, home-town thoroughfare where Dad did business in cozy proximity to the 18-karat chic of Bramley's Jewelers and the even-then anachronistic charms of Murray's Army and Navy.        Ours was a family business. My mother, who always did the books, advanced her career by attending a training school at Kodak. She returned with a diploma and  an unshakable faith in Kodak's products. My brother and I also worked in the store, following an employment code that was certainly genetic, though, truth to tell, my brother preferred to hang around the neighborhood gas station. He eventually grew up to become a psychologist.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Banker Dies After Losses in Bonds
abstract: The Yasuda Trust and Banking Corporation's managing director in Hong Kong fell to his death this week, shortly before the bank reported losses in bond trades totaling 37 million yen (about $370,000). Masayoshi Kashiwagi, acting director of Yasuda Trust Asia Pacific Ltd. died on Tuesday, said Masashi Doi, a  general manager in Yasuda's head office in Tokyo. Mr. Doi would not confirm news reports that Mr. Kashiwagi had committed suicide at his high-rise home in Hong Kong. "Hong Kong police are still investigating why he died," he said.          Yasuda said in a statement that a series of bond trades in January and February resulted in a loss of 17 million yen. It did not give any specifics about the trades.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Export Boom In Services Cuts Growth in U.S. Trade Deficit
abstract: Erasing about half of a huge January increase, the nation's trade deficit shrank to $8.2 billion in February as sales of American services abroad rose to  records, the Commerce Department reported today.         Exports over all climbed 2 percent to the second-highest total on record while imports fell five-tenths of 1 percent. It was the first time since November that the deficit had narrowed.

headline: Whispers of a Successor Echo in the IMF's Halls
abstract: PARIS—  When Michel Camdessus opens the annual spring meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank next week in Washington, the hidden item on the agenda, and perhaps the hottest, will be — Michel Camdessus.

headline: S.E.C. Disciplines Company Over Accounting
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered the Sulcus Computer Corporation today to refrain from using improper accounting methods that it used in the past, the commission contends, to create phony profits. An S.E.C. official warned that the commission was keeping a close watch on merger accounting.         The cease-and-desist order also applies to Jeffrey Ratner, Sulcus's chairman  and former chief executive, and John Picardi, a former chief financial officer of the Sulcus Hospitality Group.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CALVIN KLEIN SUES PRICE COSTCO OVER JEANS SALES
abstract: The Calvin Klein Inc. jeanswear company said yesterday that it had sued Price Costco Inc., contending that the warehouse retailer has been selling counterfeit goods under the Calvin Klein trademark. Calvin Klein said that a private investigation had found that Price Costco was selling bogus goods, as well as flawed and damaged goods, as Calvin Klein Jeans. Calvin Klein, of New York, has  asked the court to prohibit Price Costco, based in Issaquah, Wash., from selling any Calvin Klein trademarked jeans and jeans-related items.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.T.C. Plans to Simplify Rules on Doctor Networks With big mergers changing the face of the health care industry, the Federal Trade Commission plans to make it easier for doctors to band together, coordinate prices and form networks to compete with insurance companies and health maintenance organizations. Doctors contend that such networks might encourage competition by providing alternatives to H.M.O.'s. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. TO AID ISRAEL WITH TECHNOLOGY AGAINST ATTACKS
abstract: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would help Israel develop  a weapons-defense system to shield the country both from ballistic missiles and  from the types of small rockets that Lebanese guerrillas have rained down on northern Israel in recent weeks.         Under the agreement reached by Prime Minister Shimon Peres and Defense Secretary William J. Perry, Israel would be provided with nearly instantaneous information from American satellites if any of its neighbors launched ballistic  missiles. Israeli leaders have long sought such an early-warning system.

headline: Edward P. Bullard 4th, Development Organization Leader, 61
abstract: Edward P. Bullard 4th, the former president of TechnoServe, a non-profit international development organization, died on Thursday in his home in Wilton,  Conn. He was 61.         The cause was prostate cancer, said his wife, Carol.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Family Ties That Bind Growth
abstract: Take a cab here or a local flight, stay in a hotel, smoke a clove cigarette,  watch a private television station, make a cellular phone call, buy a Mercedes or a Kawasaki motorcycle, put sugar in your coffee -- in each case, some of the  money lands in a business controlled or owned, in whole or in part, by a relative of President Suharto, Indonesia's longtime strongman. And beyond the first family, Mr. Suharto's closest friends control vast business empires, including monopolies and exclusive concessions conferred by the grace of the President.         Some things never seem to change in Indonesia, where nepotism, favoritism and corruption have long been ubiquitous. Small and medium-sized businesses pay licensing fees off the books. Judges are paid to settle cases. Sweetheart deals  are struck between foreign investors and local interests. Indonesia is, in the view of Transparency International, a Berlin-based watchdog organization, the most corrupt country on earth.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: REVCO D.S. INC., the drugstore chain based in Twinsburg, Ohio, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to three million of its shares.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;For the Chiefs, A Gain of 30%
abstract: The new moneybags? Check out how well the mutual fund chiefs did in 1995.         The median combined salary and bonus of the heads of mutual fund groups jumped to $1.2 million last year, roughly 30 percent above the $926,000 of 1994. In some cases, stock options, restricted stock and other incentives pushed those figures even higher, according to an annual study on the compensation of fund executives by Fund Action, an industry newsletter in New York.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Renewed Interest by Industry Pushes Copper Prices Higher
abstract: Copper prices recovered somewhat yesterday as a five-day slide in prices renewed demand from manufacturers.         On other markets, corn prices surged as forecasts for more wet, cool weather  in the eastern Corn Belt raised concern that farmers were running out of time to plant their crops. Crude oil prices also rose.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Retreat On Treasuries Before Report
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities slipped yesterday as market participants awaited today's report on employment in March.         The market shrugged off a report showing a drop in February housing completions that was sharper than expected. The Commerce Department said yesterday that the number of housing units on which construction was completed fell 6.5 percent in February from January.,

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
