abstract: CENTURA BANKS INC., Rocky Mount, N.C., has agreed to acquire First South Bank, Burlington, N.C., in a stock swap valued at about $36.6 million.

headline: Hicks Muse Hires Smith Barney Man
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas investment firm that specializes in  leveraged buyouts, hired Michael Levitt today as a managing director and principal.         Mr. Levitt, 37, was managing director and deputy head of investment banking at Smith Barney Inc. from 1993 until February, when he resigned.

headline: A Rare School Blooms in Chad's Unlikely Soil
abstract: For a few months now villagers have been getting used to a collection of new sounds to compete with the persistent whistle of the morning wind through the thorn trees and the gargling noise of camels as they meander among the dunes that border this lonely desert settlement.   To the ordinary drills of daily life, virtually unchanged in a century here, have been added the drills of the classroom. With scores of plastic sandals filling the entrance of a one-room schoolhouse strung together with hemp and reeds, Achta Abakar starts her pupils off every day with a lesson in phonetics.

headline: Japanese Look at the Possibility of a Military Role in Asia
abstract: For half a century, one of the great taboos of public life here has been any  discussion of a Japanese military role beyond Japan's shores.         Now the taboo has given way to an open debate, even prompting some calls for  a revision of the "peace Constitution" that the United States imposed after World War II. Just as important, for the first time the Government is examining  what it would be willing to do if a war broke out elsewhere in Asia, particularly in Korea.

headline: Peru Suspect Held in New York
abstract: A 46-year-old Peruvian man held inside a Federal jail in Manhattan has been charged with participating in the Shining Path insurgency in Peru, including a guerrilla ambush five years ago that killed six police officers.         Law enforcement officials who disclosed the charges yesterday said the man, Julian Salazar Calero, was arrested on a warrant issued by the Government of Peru on charges that he was involved in the 1991 attack.

headline: 3 Muslims In Bosnia Die Going Home
abstract: Three Muslim refugees were killed today and dozens were wounded in several angry confrontations with mobs of Serbs. The Muslims were trying to return to homes they had not seen since the war.         It was the first time since the war ended that anyone had been killed in showdowns between Muslims seeking to go home and former Bosnian Serb enemies who do not want them to return.

headline: For Lebanese Shiites, A Day to Recall Martyrs
abstract: There was human blood, and there were Katyusha rockets, both meant as gestures of devotion to a grandson of the Prophet Mohammed who was slain 14 centuries ago.         On this Shiite Muslim day of mourning, the streets of this market town turned red as men by the hundreds beat their own razor-slashed foreheads with palms, sticks and even swords in a macabre parade.

headline: Clinton Arms Policy Questioned in House
abstract: The House Oversight Committee voted today to spend nearly $1 million to investigate President Clinton's decision to ignore Iran's shipments of arms to Bosnia.         The committee approved the $995,000 on a straight party line vote of seven Republicans to five Democrats, with Democrats charging that the investigation was motivated by election-year politics.

headline: Retail Sales Up 0.8% in May But Were Below Expectations
abstract: Retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in May, the third advance in four months, the Government reported today, partly because of an increase in auto sales.         Some analysts doubt the pace can be sustained.

headline: India's 'Avenging Angel': Candidate of Low Castes
abstract: No candidate in India's current election has stirred more passion than Phoolan Devi, a onetime desperado and jailbird. Her passage from violent banditry in the rugged country of central India to would-be legislator for a lower-caste party -- "from trigger-puller to crowd-puller," as one Indian newspaper put it -- has angered about as many Indians as it has pleased.         In three weeks of campaigning for Parliament that will end with the voting here on Tuesday, the one constant of Ms. Devi's life -- the extreme passion for  and against her -- has not changed.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ford Workers in Mexico Accept Raise of 26%
abstract: The Ford Motor Company's workers at the Cuautitlan plant on the outskirts of  Mexico City have accepted a 26 percent wage increase, averting a strike that was scheduled yesterday, Mexico's Labor Ministry said. The increase, which takes effect immediately, benefits 3,300 union workers.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: U.S. Seeking to Strengthen Nuclear Agency
abstract: After the Persian Gulf war, when international inspectors got a better opportunity to look around a defeated Iraq, they discovered that President Saddam Hussein had secretly been developing nuclear weapons.         To deter such an ominous possibility from threatening the world again, Washington wants to strengthen the powers of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which is responsible for guarding against the diversion of nuclear material to bomb-making.

headline: Business Travel;The Atlanta airport is being all spruced up for this summer's Olympics, and beyond.
abstract: HARTSFIELD INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT in Atlanta and Delta Air Lines, its biggest  tenant, are spending millions on improvements before the Summer Olympics -- changes that will also make life easier for travelers long after the Olympics have gone.         Delta, the official carrier of the games, is investing $45 million in new ticket counters and furnishings, more baggage-claim equipment, a separate underground pedestrian mall linking concourses C and B, and moving Atlantic Southeast Airlines, its regional carrier, closer to Delta's domestic concourse.

headline: Bulgaria May Close Plants
abstract: Faced with the worst economic crisis since the collapse of Communism, the Bulgarian Government is debating a plan to close 65 state-run companies employing 29,000 workers.         Prime Minister Zhan Videnov said it was necessary to close the plants, which  account for 29 percent of the nation's budget deficit, to ward off "grave financial destabilization."

headline: MEDIA: PRESS;British newspapers are engaging in an exhaustive run of insider chatter.
abstract: By American standards, British newspaper journalism is a small and insular world that sometimes seems populated by surprisingly few people -- mostly the journalists, their friends and their enemies. They constitute a minuscule but powerful village that helps make up what Londoners call "the chattering classes," and many issues are devoted each week to their lives and opinions.         The newspapers encourage these cozy self-referential habits by letting their  reporters develop their own small cults of personality. Each week, in both the tabloids and the broadsheets, celebrity writers lavishly describe the minutiae of their lives. Political columns are illustrated by photographs and pithy descriptions of columnists, as in "Simon Heffer: the Pundit the Politicians Dread," who appears in The Daily Mail of London. Newspapers regularly print the  names of profile writers in larger type than the names of those profiled.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;INVESTING WITH: Robert W. Bissell
abstract: WHEN stock investors look for safety, they flock to companies that are paying high dividends. For whatever the ups and downs of the stock market, these holdings produce a steady stream of income. The comparable investment in mutual funds is the equity-income category. Its funds invest in just such high-yielding stocks. With volatility increasing and talk persistent about how long it has been since a 10 percent decline in the broad stock market, these funds make sense for the conservative.         Among the strong performers in the category is the Stagecoach Diversified Income Fund, which was in the top 25 percent in the first two months of 1996. Robert W. Bissell, 48, chief equity investment officer for Wells Fargo Bank in Los Angeles, has been manager of the fund, now at more than $100 million in assets, since its inception in November 1992. He manages $1.5 billion, including private accounts, in the same style.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Porsche Ads Win At Kelly Awards
abstract: Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco took top honors, winning three awards including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 15th annual M.P.A. Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.         At a ceremony last night in Chicago, which honored campaigns that appeared in magazines during 1995, Goodby, Silverstein, a unit of the Omnicom Group, won the $100,000 prize for a campaign for the Porsche Cars North America unit of Volkswagen A.G., featuring ads that carried such headlines as "Kills bugs fast."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank of Scotland Has Higher Profit
abstract: The Bank of Scotland said yesterday that its pretax profit rose a higher-than-expected 21 percent in the year that ended on Feb. 29. Profit before taxes rose to L545 million ($828.4 million), from L449.7 million the previous year.          The Bank of Scotland, the smallest of Britain's eight major banks, said that the Bank of Western Australia, which it bought in November, contributed L19.7 million of profit. The bank also said net interest income rose 11 percent, to L997.7 million.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Imation Account To Ketchum Unit
abstract: Imation, the imaging systems and data storage company that will be spun off in July from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, has chosen the Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh unit of Ketchum Communications as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at $14 million.          Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh was selected after a six-week review that also included three other finalists: Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt; Colle & McVoy in Minneapolis, and Grey Advertising in New York, which handles the bulk of the 3M worldwide corporate and consumer account. Imation, which will be based in Oakdale, Minn., will be promoted in a worldwide print campaign scheduled to begin in June.

headline: Lows Creek Journal;Eureka, Hardly, but for Africans, Specks of Hope
abstract: Outside their mine, the men had been chatting as they ate a lunch of cornmeal porridge cooked on a nearby fire. But now it was time to examine the morning's samples, and there was total silence.         Some of the men, like Boy Masilela, had been working the slopes here for months and had seen very little gold yet. Mr. Masilela, who has a wife and three children, had earned less than $60 since December.

headline: 110 Prisoners Are Freed in Exchange in Caucasus
abstract: Foreign Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia said 110 people were freed today under a prisoner exchange between Azerbaijan and Armenia as part of a Russian diplomatic effort to end the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh.         "This is a serious start to settling the Karabakh conflict," Mr. Primakov told reporters after flying into Baku with 67 of the freed prisoners from Armenia.

headline: Gun-Running in the Balkans: C.I.A. and Diplomats Collide
abstract: Two summers ago, the C.I.A. station chief in Croatia thought he had uncovered a terrible secret: the United States Ambassador was involved in a rogue operation to smuggle Iranian weapons to Bosnia's Muslims, defying a worldwide arms embargo.         The station chief spent hours at his computer terminal, tapping out coded messages to Washington, bluntly describing his suspicions about the Ambassador, Peter W. Galbraith. The Ambassador never knew of the messages until  a few weeks ago, when he spent 10 hours reading a foot-high stack of secret papers in a sealed C.I.A. vault. Mr. Galbraith, who had been given the papers to prepare to testify before Congress about Bosnia, told a colleague that it was "the most chilling day" of his life in government. He concluded that the station chief had been spying on him -- and doing a poor job. The idea that he was spearheading a smuggling operation was "typical of the phenomenal amount of misreporting" by the station chief, said an Administration official in tune with the Ambassador's views.

headline: 20% of World's People Live on Dollar a Day
abstract: More than one-fifth of the world's population lives on less than one dollar a day, according to a World Bank report on poverty released today.         "Although the overall incidence of poverty is declining, the number of people living on less than one dollar a day continues to increase," the report said. It said that number rose to 1.31 billion people in 1993 from 1.23 billion in 1987.

headline: I.S.D.N. Touted As a Contender
abstract: A Silicon Valley start-up company plans to introduce a small computerized system today intended to deliver on the promise of digital telephone system known as Integrated Digital Service Network, or I.S.D.N. for voice calls.         Proclaimed the telephone service of the future until the emergence of the Internet, I.S.D.N. has languished as an oddity. Now Jetstream Communications, of San Jose, Calif., hopes to tap into a growing market of independent business people and corporate workers who do not have a personal secretary.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Astra Reports 11% Profit Gain
abstract: The drug maker Astra A.B., Sweden's largest publicly traded company, reported yesterday that it had an 11 percent pretax profit gain in the first quarter and  said it would not postpone plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in two weeks. Astra's profits were lifted by strong United States sales of Prilosec, an ulcer medication. Astra earned 3.44 billion kronor ($506 million) in the three months that ended on March 31. A year earlier the company  earned 3.11 billion kronor. Sales were 9.34 billion kronor, up from 8.65 billion.          Allegations of sexual harassment against the company's United States arm, Astra USA Inc., had caused fears in Swedish markets that the company might delay its New York Stock Exchange listing.   (AP)

headline: Court Reverses Convictions Of 4 Real Estate Executives
abstract: An appeals court today reversed the convictions of four former executives of  the General Development Corporation. They were jailed for two years after being  convicted of cheating home buyers out of $117 million.         The ruling by the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta came a year after  the Federal panel ordered the four freed pending the appeal.

headline: Lower Castes Hold the Key As India Gets Ready to Vote
abstract: As the setting sun spread a golden hue over the wheatfields that embrace his  ancestral village, Ram Ujagar Yadav sat in a grove of eucalyptus trees and mused aloud about the votes that he and tens of millions of other poor, lower-caste Indians will cast in the general election next month.         For now, Mr. Yadav said the other day, he will await the emergence of what many around here know as the "fiza," a sort of buzz that develops before the election. Many of India's 600 million villagers rely on it to reach a political  consensus on who suits their interests best.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Sugar Producer Gets $550 Million Offer
abstract: The French food concern Eridania Beghin-Say S.A. said yesterday that it had offered 2.85 billion francs (about $550 million) to acquire the sugar producer Compagnie Francaise de Sucrerie from Compagnie de Navigation Mixte S.A. Navigation Mixte, which is wholly owned by the French holding company Groupe Paribas, has accepted the offer and said final details would be decided in the coming weeks.          The sale is the latest move by Paribas to concentrate on its financial and banking activities and to pay down debt accumulated from its takeover of Navigation Mixte.   (Dow Jones)

headline: South Africans' Everest Climb Ends in Death and Mystery
abstract: South Africans have been glued to radios for three days listening to a distant drama of national triumph crumble into an inexplicable tragedy. At dawn  on Saturday, they heard that the South African flag had been planted atop Mount  Everest for the first time -- a successful end to a much-publicized trek. But the last member of the shattered team, which straggled one by one to the top, has now been missing for 48 hours after trying to descend in the dark and is presumed dead.         Reports have become sketchier as the Nepalese Government, for reasons that are unclear, cut off the live radio reports from the Everest base camp, but the  trek seems to have ended in the every-man-for-himself selfishness that has characterized the whole effort and turned a national victory into something of a national embarrassment.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Bank in Japan To Replace Failed One
abstract: Japanese banks disclosed plans yesterday to set up a new bank to take over the assets of the Taiheiyo Bank, a regional bank that failed in March because of bad loans. The Sakura Bank of Tokyo said that it and other major banks would finance the new bank.          The new Wakashio Bank will be capitalized at 40 billion yen ($370 million),  all of which will be provided by Sakura. In addition, the Sanwa, Fuji and Tokai  banks will extend subordinate loans of more than 90 billion yen ($833 million).   (Reuters)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Print Edition For Journal On Internet
abstract: Slate, the Microsoft Corporation's new political and cultural magazine published on the Internet's World Wide Web, has been widely anticipated as an attempt to define a new medium.         But even as Microsoft was scrambling yesterday to meet technical problems and unexpectedly heavy demand for its new electronic journal, the company also described plans to publish it on paper as a conventional magazine.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BHC COMMUNICATIONS INC., New York, a unit of Chris-Craft Industries, named William Siegel president and chief operating officer, succeeding his father, Herbert Siegel, who will continue as chairman and chief executive.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Finish Lower In Wake of Economic Data
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities traded in a narrow range yesterday before finishing moderately lower, as mixed readings of three separate economic reports kept investors off balance.         The price of the 30-year bond dropped 9/32 of a percentage point, to 87 16/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.01 percent, up from 6.98 percent on Friday. The yield was the highest for the long bond since May 9, when it was 7.02 percent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Mobile Media Selects Jordan, McGrath
abstract: Mobile Media Communications Inc. in Ridgefield Park, N.J., which provides paging and personal communications systems like voice mail, has named Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York to handle its account, which had been at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York for a year. Billings were estimated at $10 million.          Jordan, McGrath was awarded the account last week after a three-month review that also included Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York and the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of the Omnicom Group in New York.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHICAGO DOCK MERGER WITH NEWSWEB UNDER STUDY
abstract: Fred Eychaner, who controls the Newsweb Corporation and is the holder of a 9.22 percent stake in Chicago Dock and Canal Trust, a real estate investment trust, will consider a possible merger of the two companies, according to a filing yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Chicago Dock signed an agreement on Thursday to provide confidential information on its operations to Newsweb. Chicago Dock's main asset is the Cityfront Center development in downtown Chicago. The company's stock slipped 12.5 cents, to $14.75, in Nasdaq trading. The Chicago-based Newsweb owns a television station and printing company.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WIRELESS ONE IN AGREEMENT TO ACQUIRE TRUVISION
abstract: Wireless One Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Truvision Wireless Inc. in a stock swap valued at $45 million. Wireless One, an operator of wireless pay-television systems, will exchange 3.4 million shares for all of  Truvision's shares. Truvision, based in Jackson, Miss., operates four wireless pay-television systems in and around Mississippi. Wireless One, which operates 14 systems, will have about 34,000 subscribers when the deal is completed.

headline: North Korea Is Paid for Help on War Dead
abstract: The United States paid $2 million to North Korea today for its past help in recovering remains of American soldiers killed in the Korean War.         The payment was conveyed to North Korea by the United Nations Command in South Korea. North Korea is suffering from food shortages, and its relations with South Korea are tense because North Korean soldiers made an incursion into  the demilitarized zone last week.

headline: Albania's Reformer Turns Autocrat
abstract: When an unknown apparatchik with a big medical reputation emerged as a key negotiator in the downfall of Europe's strictest Communist government, Washington believed that it had found its man in the volatile southern Balkans.         He knew how to talk about democracy and how to expound on the merits of a market economy. He was eager to make his ragged country a doormat for American military interests.

headline: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
abstract: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.      To the Editor:

headline: Fiat's Crown Prince Takes Aim at Old Guard
abstract: PONTEDERA, Italy—  Distancing himself from his powerful family and his country's business establishment, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, the designated future chairman of the Fiat group, has called for a shake-up of Italy's clubby corporate business practices.

headline: Hebron Arabs Fight Troops
abstract: Stone-throwing Arabs clashed with Israeli troops in the occupied West Bank town of Hebron today.         Palestinian witnesses said Arab youths, angry after Israeli soldiers lined up a number of plainclothes policemen of the Palestine Authority against a wall and searched their vehicle, attacked troops with stones.

headline: Cellular Spinoff Finds Success Overseas
abstract: Sam Ginn was startled when the telephone rang in his sprawling corner office  here at 5:30 A.M. on April 1. The caller was his former deputy, Philip J. Quigley, now the chairman of the Pacific Telesis Group. And the message was stunning: Pacific Telesis had just announced that it would sell itself to SBC Communications in the first marriage of two regional Bell telephone companies.         Mr. Ginn is understandably sensitive about the $17 billion deal. Some of his  telephone industry colleagues believe that Mr. Ginn, who preceded Mr. Quigley as chairman of Pacific Telesis, deprived the company of its future by spinning off  its lucrative cellular properties in 1994. Lacking a presence in the fastest-growing part of the business and yoked to the unforgiving California market, Pacific Telesis may have had little choice but to sell out to the more robust SBC.

headline: In New Challenge to Peace Plan, Bosnia May Pull Out of Election
abstract: In a new challenge to the American-brokered peace in the former Yugoslavia, the Bosnian Government threatened today to withdraw from elections unless voting rules were drastically changed and NATO arrested the most prominent Serbian war  criminals.         The elections, scheduled for Sept. 14, are intended to underpin a stable democracy here and allow the withdrawal of 60,000 NATO peacekeeping troops. But  in an interview today, Ejup Ganic, the Vice President of the Muslim-led Government, said the elections would not be held unless Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic, Bosnian Serb leaders indicted for genocide, were removed from power. He also insisted that voting rules be changed to prevent Serbs from gaining electoral control over Muslim towns and villages they seized in the war.

headline: Planet Wall Street Embraces Planet Hollywood
abstract: Does 75 times earnings sound like too much to pay for a restaurant company?         Not to Wall Street, at least not if the company is Planet Hollywood.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Kept In Check
abstract: Signs of economic strength and concerns over inflation and supply combined to restrain Treasury prices yesterday.         By the New York market close the 30-year Treasury bond was down 1/32 , to 8613/32 to yield 7.10 percent -- unchanged for a third day.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AMERICAN SKANDIA LIFE ASSURANCE CO., Shelton, Conn., named Lawrence Kudlow chief economist.

headline: Pharmacia Settles A Trademark Case
abstract: Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories has agreed to pay royalties to Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. for the use of the suffix "pro" in its Prempro female hormone replacement therapy.         Pharmacia & Upjohn's agreement to license the suffix to Wyeth-Ayerst settles  a lawsuit contending that the Philadelphia-based drug company infringed the trademark on Pharmacia & Upjohn's Provera product.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pilkington Reports 47% Jump in Profit
abstract: Pilkington P.L.C., a British glass and building materials maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 47 percent in the year that ended on March 31 before a reorganization charge. The profit was L212 million ($326.5 million)  before the previously announced charge of L155 million. A year earlier, pretax profit was L144 million before charges.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KIMBERLY-CLARK MOVES TO SATISFY ANTITRUST CONCERNS
abstract: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to license its Scotties facial tissue brand in the United States and to sell a tissue mill  in New York to Irving Tissue Inc. The sale is intended to satisfy antitrust issues related to Kimberly-Clark's $9.4 billion acquisition of the Scott Paper Company. Terms were not disclosed. Dallas-based Kimberly-Clark, which was required by the Justice Department to license the Scotties brand and to sell up to two tissue mills by Sunday, said it had asked the department to extend the deadline to July 12 and to accept the sale of the mill in Fort Edward as satisfying its requirement. Irving Tissue is part of the Irving family of businesses, which is based in St. John, New Brunswick.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Wife of Jailed Nigerian Opposition Leader Is Slain
abstract: A wife of the wealthy Nigerian businessman who is widely believed to have won a 1993 presidential election was shot and killed today.         The wife, Kudirat Abiola, a 44-year-old businesswoman, was shot, as was her driver, as they rode along a street in Lagos. Three men in a car attacked her car, witnesses said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A new campaign by British Airways generates some critical comments from consumers.
abstract: WITH a plain-vanilla tag line like "The World's Favorite Airline," it seems reasonable to assume that British Airways will not go out of its way to create turbulence with its marketing.         But the airline has accomplished just that with its current $15 million ad campaign, which after several months has earned the airline dozens of critical letters from consumers. And that's fine with British Airways marketing executives and their agency, M & C Saatchi, who say the criticism is the inevitable consequence of getting the attention of ad-saturated consumers.

headline: March Fed Meeting Unanimous for Steady Rates
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously at their March 26 meeting to  keep the overnight bank lending rate unchanged, according to the minutes of the  session, released today.         The 10-to-0 vote by the Federal Open Market Committee's left the target for the Federal funds rate at 5.25 percent. The committee left the rate unchanged again at its latest meeting on Tuesday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fallon McElligott's New York Office
abstract: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis said yesterday that it would expand to New York by forming a creative team to be based there headed by two creative group directors.         Bill Schwab, 41, an art director, and Joe Lovering, 37, a copywriter, will head a creative team that will have six members. Though they will be in the office of the agency's New York affiliate, Fallon McElligott Berlin, they will work for Fallon McElligott. Mr. Schwab and Mr. Lovering have helped produce campaigns for Fallon McElligott clients like BMW of North America, for the Z3 Roadster, and the McDonald's Corporation, for a new sandwich, Arches Deluxe, that will be introduced in May.

headline: Mitsubishi Motors Plans Rescue of Embattled U.S. Unit
abstract: The American manufacturing subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, already the target of a potentially huge Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, is also facing serious financial problems that will force a reorganization and a huge capital infusion, the parent company announced today.         Mitsubishi said it would take a one-time charge against earnings to reflect the lower value of the American subsidiary, Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, which has lost money almost every year of its existence and is mired in debt. The charge, for the year that ended on March 31, is 32.6 billion yen, or about $300 million.

headline: Disney Says His Resignation Bars Bonuses to Katzenberg
abstract: The Walt Disney Company fired back against Jeffrey Katzenberg today, contending that the former studio chief was well aware of the financial consequences of leaving the company and should not receive millions of dollars in damages.         Mr. Katzenberg, who quit Disney in 1994 in a dispute with Disney's chairman,  Michael D. Eisner, filed a $250 million breach of contract lawsuit last month, accusing Disney of failing to pay him enough for blockbusters like "The Lion King" and "Beauty and the Beast."

headline: Doctor Quoted as Criticizing Arafat Is Freed
abstract: A Palestinian human rights advocate detained after he was quoted as criticizing Yasir Arafat's self-rule administration was released today, his brother said.         Eyad R. Sarraj, a psychiatrist and the leader of the Palestinian Independent  Commission for Citizens' Rights, was detained on May 18. He had been quoted by a columnist for The New York Times, Anthony Lewis, on the May 6 Op-Ed page as saying that the Palestinian Authority was "corrupt, dictatorial and oppressive."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Westdeutsche Bank Says Profits Increased
abstract: Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, Germany's third-largest bank, said yesterday that its operating profit after risk provisions rose 58.7 percent in the first quarter. Operating profit rose to 400 million marks ($263 million), from 252 million marks in the first quarter of 1995, Friedel Neuber, the bank's  chief executive, said.          The company also said its net income rose 21.5 percent in 1995 as trading income soared. Profit rose to 520 million marks, from 428 million in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Afghan Toll In Flooding Put Over 100
abstract: Heavy flooding has killed more than 100 people across Afghanistan, relief workers said today as a Red Cross official warned of an ecological disaster in the war-devastated country.         At least seven provinces, covering more than a quarter of Afghanistan, have been affected by floods brought on by melting snow and heavy rains, aid workers  said. They said they had received reports of some 100 deaths but the toll was likely to be much higher. About 3,000 homes were destroyed or badly damaged and  thousands of cattle and other livestock killed.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sega Buying Maker Of Slot Machines
abstract: Sega Enterprises of Japan said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Games Network Ltd., the largest maker of slot machines in Britain, to expand its range of entertainment products in Europe. Sega did not disclose the price it paid. Games Network is a privately owned holding company based in Cardiff, Wales. It consists of JPM International Ltd., Ace Coin Equipment Ltd. and Crystal Leisure  Ltd. of Britain and Negocio Internacional de Technologia S.A. of Spain. Games Network generated sales of about $64 million in the fiscal year that ended in September 1995.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Big New Loss Makes Japan Look Inward
abstract: In the last several years, at least five Japanese companies have suffered huge losses from trading complex financial instruments, the most recent being the Sumitomo Corporation, which disclosed last week that a single copper trader  had cost it $1.8 billion.         The stunning loss inevitably raised concern as to what other potential time bombs might be lying around on the balance sheets of Japanese companies. And amid the gleaming office towers here in Tokyo, many people are asking: Why Japan?

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP., New York, said that Frank N. Newman, its president and chief executive, would become chairman, succeeding Charles S. Sanford Jr., who is to retire by mid-1996.

headline: Troops Patrol Belfast Again, Raising the Tension
abstract: After nearly 22 months of peace, with only a routine presence of security forces on the streets of Belfast, the British soldiers are patrolling again, drawing beads with their automatic rifles on rooftops and down alleys where guerrillas of the Irish Republican Army, or Protestant paramilitaries, may be hiding.         The Royal Ulster Constabulary, or police force, has restored dozens of checkpoints around the city in recent days, blocking streets with its armored Land-Rovers to check cars for bombs and bombers, weapons and guerrillas, slowing traffic and turning the 20-minute run to the airport into an hour.

headline: Tiff Over Intellectual Property;Should Columbia Own Fruit of Economist's Labor?
abstract: Did Columbia University convince Geoffrey H. Moore, a world-renowned pioneer  in business cycle forecasting, to sign over the rights to his life's work, then  callously evict him from his office? Or did the university walk the last mile with Dr. Moore, an 82-year-old economist, absorbing his deficits for a decade and arranging for a wealthy alumnus to underwrite his money-losing research center before cutting off his paycheck?         Just who has the better claim to the high moral ground in this embarrassingly public dispute between the Ivy League university and an icon of economics remains murky.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ivory Coast Bars Ship With 4,000 Liberians
abstract: Ivory Coast officials ordered a ship carrying 4,000 Liberian refugees back to open waters today despite concerns that the ship might not be seaworthy, a spokeswoman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said.         She added that Ivory Coast officials forced most of the women and children who had been taken from the ship for medical care and food to get back on board. Government officials in the Ivory Coast, which officials of aid organizations say has been flooded with 350,000 Liberian refugees, have repeatedly declined to comment on the decision regarding the ship.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING RECEIVES A JETLINER ORDER VALUED AT $1.6 BILLION
abstract: The Boeing Company has received a $1.6 billion order for 23 jetliners from the airline Garuda Indonesia, which is owned by the state. Boeing said the airline had ordered six 777's and 17 737's. Delivery is expected to begin in 1997 and continue through 2002. With the Indonesian contract, Boeing's backlog of 777 orders totals 249 planes, while the backlog of 737 orders is about 526 planes. As of May 31, the company, which is based in Seattle, had a backlog totaling 1,115 planes. Garuda Indonesia also has an option to buy six Boeing 747's. Shares of Boeing rose $1.375, to $90.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Andreas Papandreou Dies at 77; Fiery, Ambiguous Premier DominatedGreek Politics
abstract: Andreas Papandreou, the former Prime Minister of Greece and a maverick who towered over Greek political life for more than two decades, died early today at his home in Athens. He was 77.         The cause was a heart attack, his doctors said in a statement. Mr. Papandreou had open-heart surgery in 1988, though that did not keep him from winning an election in 1993.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;New Arena, Old Strategy for a Money Manager
abstract: LAURA J. SLOATE'S corner office in midtown Manhattan has all the signs of a successful money manager. Piles of annual and 10-K reports swamp her desk. A computer spits out stock quotations at a rate of 240 words a minute. Several Eisenstaedt prints, including two of her favorite conductor, Leonard Bernstein, adorn the walls.         The only hint that this high-powered investment adviser is unlike her Wall Street peers is the unobtrusive aluminum dog dish behind her desk.

headline: U.S. Defeated In Its Appeal Of Trade Case
abstract: The United States lost its final appeal today in the first major case brought before the newly created World Trade Organization. A three-judge panel ruled that regulations issued under the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners.         The practical effect of the ruling is that the Environmental Protection Agency will almost certainly be forced to rewrite some of the rules concerning the environmental standards for imported gasoline or face trade sanctions from the countries that filed the complaint, Venezuela and Brazil. Imported gasoline  accounts for only about 5 percent of gasoline sold in the United States, but about 20 percent of gas sold in the New York area.

headline: Shanghai Journal;It's a Lucky Day in May, and Here Come the Brides
abstract: Upstairs at the Hujiang Beauty Salon, as hairdressers fussed over eight women seated regally before the mirrors and bright lights, two dozen other women waited anxiously on a long puffy sofa, in a various stages of preparation for the big day.         Every one a bride or a bridesmaid, many looked like princesses-in-the-making. Turban-towels floated on the heads of some, and cheesecloth adorned the faces of others, with holes cut out at the eyes, dark with mascara, and at the mouth, shiny red with lipstick.

headline: Russian Liberal Keeps Lines to Yeltsin Open
abstract: With the doors of political opportunity creaking shut, the liberal also-ran,  Grigory A. Yavlinsky, has jammed his foot across the threshold, struggling to hold them ajar just a little longer.         Mr. Yavlinsky, the most unreservedly democratic candidate in the presidential race, came in a weak fourth in the first round of voting, losing his leverage and much of his popularity to the more conservative Aleksandr I. Lebed.

headline: Real Estate;In Edgewater, N.J., luxury apartment construction is reviving on the Hudson shoreline.
abstract: By August, work will begin on transforming a patch of the Hudson River shoreline here into a luxury apartment enclave, ending an eight-year dry spell in new residential construction.        The $40 million project, the River Club, will also be the first rental to rise amid the condominium and cooperative developments that dot the 3.5-mile-long old industrial waterfront of this Bergen County borough at the base of the Palisade cliffs, south of the George Washington Bridge. Plans call for 266 one- and two-bedroom apartments in seven brick-and-stucco buildings of three stories. The buildings will be clustered into two groups, framing a courtyard and open space.

headline: Arabs at Cairo Talks Seek Unity on Mideast Issues
abstract: It was nearly three decades ago that Arab leaders meeting in Khartoum, the Sudan, after the 1967 war with Israel took a stand known as the three no's -- "no recognition, no negotiation, no peace."         Such starkness seems like ancient history now. As their successors gather en  masse today for the first time in six years, it is what Arabs see as three no's  from Israel's new leader that has inspired the Arabs to try again to speak with  one voice.

headline: Shimonoseki Journal;Japan's Whalers Start to Take On a Hunted Look
abstract: Sitting uneasily in the ship's mess, the afternoon sunlight filtering through a porthole and dappling his curly brown hair, Yasuhisa Abe acknowledged that he  has chosen an unlikely occupation for the 21st century.         "People say I'm kidding when I tell them that I'm a whaler," he said. "They don't know that Japan is still whaling, for research."

headline: Clinton Urges Broad Global Role for Japan
abstract: Bringing a state visit to an end, President Clinton today urged Japan to forge an alliance with the United States for the next century, with a growing commitment to free trade and to an expanding international leadership role that  "flows from its place as a great nation."         In an address to Parliament this morning, Mr. Clinton also said the American  people "profoundly regret" the rape of a Okinawan schoolgirl by three American servicemen last September, an attack that shook the security alliance by provoking an anti-American backlash.

headline: Once Again, No Safety In Lebanon
abstract: Before Israeli rockets fell on Beirut today, reproducing the familiar black smoke spirals and sirens of 14 years ago, Mohammed Nasur stood in the deserted streets of his neighborhood in the southern suburbs and peered into the overcast sky.         "Listen, there they are -- those are the Israeli planes," said Mr. Nasur, 75, who left his village in the south of Lebanon a decade ago to flee Israeli occupiers for the relative safety of Beirut.

headline: P.& G. to Acquire a Baby Products Unit of Scott
abstract: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell the Scott Paper Company's baby wipes business to the Procter & Gamble Company for $220 million.         The sale was needed to satisfy the Justice Department's requirements.  The department had allowed Kimberly-Clark to buy Scott Paper for $9.4 billion in December only if it sold the baby wipes business, its Scotties tissues business, a baby wipes factory and two tissue mills.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Up As Inflation Stays Benign
abstract: Treasury prices surged yesterday after a report on consumer prices showed inflation continuing to be benign.         The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32 , to 8914/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.83 percent, from 6.89 percent on Monday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Barry's Jewelers, Monrovia, Calif., to Bates Southwest, Houston, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Ann Taylor To Buy Rest of Joint Venture
abstract: In an effort to salvage its ailing principal supplier, Ann Taylor Stores said yesterday that it would buy 100 percent of a joint venture it now shares with Cygne Design Inc., as well as another unit of that company.         The retailer will buy Cygne's 60 percent interest in the venture, known as CAT, which provided Ann Taylor with about 38 percent of its merchandise last year, and Cygne's Ann Taylor Woven division, a merchandise sourcing unit.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TCI Reaches Deal With Fox To Carry All-News Channel
abstract: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, completed a deal yesterday to carry Fox's planned 24-hour news cable channel in 10 million homes when the channel starts up this fall.         The deal, in which TCI was granted an option to acquire a 20 percent stake in the channel, gives Rupert Murdoch's incipient Fox news service a base from which to challenge both the entrenched Cable News Network, a unit of the Turner  Broadcasting System, and the other impending challenger in the cable news arena, MSNBC, which is owned by NBC and the Microsoft Corporation.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Net Fell 1% At Eli Lilly In Quarter
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company showed modest growth in the first quarter, despite strong sales of the antidepressant Prozac.         While earnings over all fell 1 percent, the comparison with the quarter a year earlier reflected earnings in the 1995 quarter of $18.4 million, or 3 cents a share, from its medical device and diagnostics businesses, which it has since sold.

headline: Utility in Settlement With Chase Group
abstract: The Bonneville Power Administration said today that it had reached a $115 million settlement of a lawsuit filed by the Chase Manhattan Bank over the agency's decision last year to cancel its 20-year contract to buy electricity from a half-built power plant in Frederickson, Wash.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Dismisses Head Of Jet Engine Maker
abstract: The French Government has dismissed Bernard Dufour, the chairman of the jet engine maker that it owns, Snecma, after it grew increasingly irritated with his calls to recapitalize the company and the slow pace at which he was selling noncore assets. The surprise move yesterday, just a year and a half after Mr. Dufour was brought in to run Snecma, which makes civil and military engines, came as the chairman was helping prepare the company for sale to the public. Mr. Dufour had repeatedly called on the state to put 6 billion francs into the company, before selling it to the public.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Exxon Wins $250 Million From Lloyd's for Alaska Oil Spill
abstract: The Exxon Corporation won $250 million yesterday from Lloyd's of London underwriting syndicates and other insurers that sold policies to protect the oil company from liabilities like those incurred after the Exxon Valdez oil spill.         A Texas state court jury voted 11 to 1 that the insurance underwriters should honor a policy that covered Exxon as the owner of some 11 million gallons of oil spilled into Prince William Sound, Alaska, in 1989.

headline: Varity and Lucas in Talks To Combine Some Businesses
abstract: The Varity Corporation and Lucas Industries, responding to demands from auto  makers for more efficient suppliers, said they might combine some of their businesses.         A combination between the companies could help the Buffalo-based Varity expand in the worldwide anti-lock-brake market. It could also help Lucas, which  is based in Britain, to strengthen its foothold in the American auto-parts market.

headline: Human Remains Found in Prison Oven After Riot
abstract: Law enforcement officials said today that they had found human skulls, thigh  bones and other body parts in the ovens of a maximum-security prison where seven inmates disappeared in a weeklong, nationwide revolt that ended on Sunday.         Investigators made the discovery at the Sierra Chica prison in Azul, located  in the south of Buenos Aires province, where 1,000 inmates mutinied last week, setting off similar revolts in 20 prisons across the country involving more than 10,000 inmates.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                 May 17    May 10    May 19                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.8       7.8       7.7 Distillate production, daily                  3.3       3.2       2.9 Gasoline stocks                             204.9     203.0     208.2 Distillate stocks                            90.4      90.6     113.9 Crude imports, daily                          7.8       8.6       8.0 Product imports, daily                        1.7       2.5       1.8 Crude stocks                                295.2     299.7     330.0 Crude production, daily                       6.4       6.4       6.6 Refinery utilization (%)                     92.2      92.2      94.0

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COOPER CAMERON IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR INGRAM CACTUS
abstract: The Cooper Cameron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the assets of the  closely held Ingram Cactus Company in a $100 million deal requiring Cooper Cameron to assume certain liabilities. Ingram Cactus manufactures and sells equipment used primarily for onshore oil and gas production operations. In 1995, Ingram Cactus generated revenue of about $105 million. Cooper Cameron, a Houston-based maker of oil and gas pressure control equipment, lost $500.1 million, or $19.87 a share, on 1995 revenue of $1.14 billion. The latest results included a $441 million write-off of good will. Cooper Cameron shares rose $3 yesterday, to $45, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WORLD COLOR PRESS TO PURCHASE RINGIER AMERICA
abstract: World Color Press Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Ringier America for $415 million in cash and debt, moving it into the business of printing soft-cover books and bolstering its magazine and catalogue operations. The nation's No. 3 printer and a unit of Printing Holdings L.P. will acquire Ringier's six printing and production facilities and its prepress facility. Ringier, based in Chicago,  is owned by the Swiss publishing company Ringier A.G. As part of the transaction, World Color will assume about $285 million in debt.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SCITEX REJECTS $856 MILLION BID BY INVESTOR
abstract: The Scitex Corporation has rejected a bid of $20 a share in cash from the investor Davidi Gilo, who expressed his disappointment yesterday. The proposal by Mr. Gilo, who owns 3 percent of Scitex, valued the company at $856 million. Shares of Scitex, the maker of computer imaging systems used in printing and graphic arts, fell 25 cents, to $17.625, in Nasdaq trading. The Scitex board said it would seek to increase the value of the company's stock by working with its financial adviser, Alex. Brown & Sons. Mr. Gilo said that he and his advisers would "examine all alternatives." Mr. Gilo is chairman of DSP Communications Inc., a chip maker, but the company has said it has no connection with the bid.

headline: Securities Regulation Bill Is Cleared by the Senate
abstract: Legislation reducing overlapping state and Federal regulation of the mutual fund and securities industries has cleared the Senate.         The bill, adopted without debate by voice vote late Thursday night, would eliminate much of the ability of states to regulate the booming mutual fund industry and large securities offerings, leaving that responsibility with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Is the Black-and-White Printer a Goner?
abstract: Though sales of home computers are beginning to slow, that does not seem to affect the low-priced color printers that connect with them.         Sales of color printers to users of home computers are continuing to surge, making this one of the hottest product categories in computing. Last year alone, color ink-jet printers accounted for $3 billion in revenues to manufacturers and retailers, according to The Hard Copy Observer, a printer-industry newsletter. More than 10 million color printers priced at less than $500 were sold, up from  3.8 million units in 1994.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: AMERICAN BANKNOTE CORP., New York, a printer of stock and bond certificates and  other products, has acquired a 55 percent stake in Leigh-Mardon Security Group,  an Australian securities printer, from Amcor Ltd. The total valuation of Leigh-Mardon is $80 million.

headline: IOMEGA STOCK UP AFTER REPORT OF POSSIBLE I.B.M. DEAL
abstract: The stock of the Iomega Corporation, a maker of computer storage devices, jumped $4.766, to $59.517, yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Traders said the increase was caused by coverage of short positions and a report that the company's Zip tape drive might be used in I.B.M.'s upgrade of its Aptiva personal computers. Cliff Josephy, an analyst with H. D. Brous & Company, said Iomega's stock rose after a report in the trade magazine Computer Retail Week that I.B.M. might use the Zip drive in new Aptivas. Spokesmen for Iomega, which  is based in Roy, Utah, and for I.B.M. declined to comment. One trader said short-covering, when traders buy back borrowed shares that they had sold in   hopes of a drop in the price, also contributed to the move in the stock, which traded last week at about $46.

headline: Anne Klein to Close Designer Collection Unit
abstract: Anne Klein & Company, one of the first American design houses run by a woman  to achieve world-class respectability, said yesterday that it would terminate its designer collection division.         The collection, which had suffered through several seasons of savage reviews  and poor sales, had not been profitable since 1989, Frank R. Mori, president of  Takihyo Inc., Anne Klein's parent company, said in a telephone interview yesterday. It accounted for about 10 percent of the company's annual sales, which Takihyo estimated at between $100 million and $200 million. Anne Klein's lower-end lines -- Anne Klein II, A Line Anne Klein and Anne Klein Studio -- will remain in stores.

headline: World News Briefs;Chess Match Moved From Iraq to Russia
abstract: The world chess federation has dropped its plans to stage its championship in Iraq and will hold the match in southern Russia, the federation's president, Kirsan Ilyumzhinov, said today.         The federation met a storm of protest after it announced that Baghdad would be the site for a championship match between Gata Kamsky and Anatoly Karpov. The United States denounced the proposal and refused to grant a visa to Mr. Kamsky,  a Russian emigre seeking American citizenship. Mr. Karpov is a Russian.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WITCO CORP., Greenwich, Conn., acquired parts of Ferro Corp.'s plastic lubricants business and sold its oil additives division to Ferro.

headline: Liberia War: Nation Adrift
abstract: When an aging cargo vessel crammed with up to 4,000 Liberian refugees limped  past this city sometime Friday night on its uncertain route toward neighboring Ghana, much of the history of Liberia's catastrophic six-year civil war traveled with it.         The Nigerian owners of the ship, the Bulk Challenge, charged $75 and more for passage aboard the overcrowded ship to people desperate to flee a month of intense fighting in the Liberian capital, Monrovia. In doing so, the Nigerians seemed to be emulating the approach of their own nation, whose intervention in 1990 was meant to stop the raging civil war but which many Liberians feel has sucked their country dry instead.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Euro Disney Says Loss Narrowed in Winter
abstract: Euro Disney said yesterday that it had cut its losses during the slow winter  season as higher attendance at its Disneyland Paris theme park and hotels more than offset an increase in debt charges. The company, a French theme park operator that is 39 percent owned by the Walt Disney Company, said its loss for  the six months that ended on March 31 had fallen to 169 million French francs ($33 million) from 241 million francs in the period a year earlier.          Euro Disney reported a 13 percent rise in revenues to 1.90 billion francs ($373 million) during the fall and winter season despite bomb attacks in Paris last fall, a public transport strike in December, weak consumer spending in France and the franc's strength against other currencies.   (Reuters)

headline: Ex-Official of Bankers Trust Charged With Securities Fraud
abstract: A compliance officer, whose job was to guard against insider trading by employees of the Bankers Trust Securities Company, illegally traded shares of at least nine companies in 1994, Federal prosecutors said yesterday, after charging him with securities fraud.         Postal inspectors arrested Nir Kantor, 39, outside his home in Riverdale, the Bronx, and charged that he and a cousin used inside information to make $54,000 by buying shares of Caesars World, the casino operator that was acquired by the ITT Corporation in December 1994.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mobil Takeover Bid For Ampolex Stalls
abstract: Ampolex Ltd. won a court order yesterday stalling the Mobil Oil Corporation's hostile attempt to buy the Australian oil company. The decision stops Mobil from sending out takeover documents to Ampolex shareholders and could delay the oil company's effort for at least two weeks. It must either revise its documents or  appeal the court's decision.          Mobil began its $1.17 billion hostile bid for Ampolex on Feb. 14, and Ampolex has rejected the offer as inadequate. The federal judge found Mobil's original documents lacked information about Mobil's intentions for Ampolex. The  judge said Mobil had been giving consideration to the early sale of all Ampolex's United States assets.   (AP)

headline: Wireless Systems Put Out Their Antennas
abstract: The race is on for the high ground: buildings, trees, water towers, church steeples, any place with a clear view and a sturdy spot to anchor an antenna.         In recent auctions, 107 companies spent a combined $18 billion on licenses to offer new wireless systems, called personal communications services, or P.C.S. Already, some of these services, using licenses auctioned last year, are operating, carrying not only telephone conversations but data and paging signals.

headline: Russia's New-Look May Day: Marching Is Out, Politicking Is In
abstract: The Soviet anthem blared through the loudspeakers. And the old Soviet flag was raised high, as the presidential candidate Gennadi A. Zyuganov sought to use Russia's May Day celebration to tap a wellspring of nostalgia for the Communist  cause.         But Mr. Zyuganov was not the only candidate who took to the streets today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Three Marketers Name Agencies
abstract: Three consumer marketers have named agencies already on their rosters to help market new products.         The Best Foods division of CPC International in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., named BBDO New York to introduce a line of salad dressings under the Hellmann's name in the East and Best Foods name in the West. The billings were not disclosed, but Advertising Age estimated that $31 million would be spent on advertising and promotions. BBDO New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group that already handles the  Hellmann's and Best Foods brands of mayonnaise, was awarded the assignment without a review.

headline: India's Prime Minister Wages Uphill Campaign
abstract: When Prime Minister P.V. Narasimha Rao opened his campaign to win the support of India's 590 million eligible voters, he began with what many political consultants might consider a gaffe: He apologized for not being somebody else.         "I am not Rajiv Gandhi," Mr. Rao said. "But I am Rajiv's successor, and I am  trying to follow his path. If you could give him so much support, don't I deserve the same?" Mr. Gandhi was assassinated by a suicide bomber just before the last general election, in 1991. Mr. Rao succeeded him as leader of the Congress Party.

headline: Thrill of the Hunt Is Key to an Auction of Old Masters
abstract: LONDON—  There is a hidden hunter in every art lover and the best opportunities for those dying to buy a gem that no one else paid attention to are still to be found in lightweight auctions halfway through the season.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH HOLDERS REJECT SPINOFF OF SPORTS CHAINS
abstract: The shareholders of the Woolworth Corporation defeated a proposal yesterday to spin off the company's athletic-store division, which includes the Foot Locker and Champs stores. Woolworth said about 85 percent of the votes cast at its annual meeting were against the proposal, made by Greenway Partners L.P., a  New York investment firm. The defeat was expected, as Woolworth management had urged shareholders to reject the plan, saying its current strategy to revive the company was working. Roger N. Farah, the chairman and chief executive, has said he plans to expand the company's successful businesses and to sell others.

headline: MCI and BellSouth Agree to Link Networks
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation said today that they had agreed to link their local telephone networks in five states. It is the first such multistate agreement between MCI and a regional Bell phone company.         Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Ziff-Davis Adds Units
abstract: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company has acquired two related publishing companies that specialize in video-game magazines. Terms were not disclosed. Ziff-Davis, a publisher of computer-related magazines and journals owned by the  Softbank Corporation, said it had bought Sendai Publishing Group and Decker Publications from their founder, Steve Harris. Electronic Gaming Monthly is the flagship publication of the companies, which are both in Lombard, Ill. Sendai also publishes Computer Game Review and Internet Underground.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Increase in Compaq's Earnings a Surprise
abstract: After warning Wall Street that its profits would be weak in the first quarter, the Compaq Computer Corporation reported a surprising 8 percent increase in earnings yesterday, belying worries that the personal computer market was weakening.         The news bolstered technology shares, sending Compaq's stock up 7 percent. But the stock was still trading below its level before March 1, when Compaq warned that price reductions forced on the company by heavy competition in the United States would reduce earnings.

headline: Chechen Rebels Cite Some Progress in Talks
abstract: Peace talks aimed at ending the war in Chechnya adjourned today without a signed accord, but a rebel spokesman said the two sides had agreed on a Russian  troop withdrawal by the end of August.         The talks were scheduled to resume on Monday.

headline: Opening Day for Biggest Bank in the World
abstract: After two Japanese banks said a year ago that they would officially merge today, to become the world's biggest bank, the financial community waited excitedly for details.         For months there was not a peep from either the savvy, worldly Bank of Tokyo  or the aristocratic Mitsubishi Bank, until an announcement in November: a team of bankers from both sides had finally agreed on the uniforms that women employees would wear.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MULTICARE TO ACQUIRE PROVIDER OF HEALTH CARE SERVICES
abstract: The Multicare Companies agreed yesterday to acquire ADS Group, the largest provider of long-term health care services in Massachusetts, in a deal valued at about $100 million, including assumption of debt. Multicare, which owns and manages long-term-care facilities, plans to pay $62.6 million, assume or repay about $27 million in debt and issue 531,507 shares of its common stock to acquire ADS, which is based in Newton, Mass. The stock of Multicare, based in Hackensack, N.J., fell 12.5 cents, to $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Privately held ADS owns, operates or manages 23 long-term-care facilities and provides consulting services. It also manages 21 hospital-based units, most of them in Massachusetts, and five assisted-living facilities.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AUCTION HOUSE SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK MORE OF ITS SHARES
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings Inc., the New York auction house, has raised the number of common shares it plans to buy back to four million, from one million, the company said yesterday. Sotheby's attributed the increase to its positive outlook for the international art auction market and its strong financial performance. The buyback represents 10.3 percent of outstanding class A common shares and 7.1 percent of the total outstanding class A and class B common shares. Based on Tuesday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange, the buyback would cost $56 million. The shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $14.125.

headline: Drink-Label Suit Settled
abstract: Heublein Inc. said yesterday that it had settled a lawsuit against E.& J. Gallo Winery over the labeling on Gallo's Bartles & Jaymes' margarita-flavored coolers -- which do not contain tequila.         Heublein, which is based in Hartford and is a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., imports Jose Cuervo tequila from Mexico and sells a pre-mixed drink called Jose Cuervo Authentic Margarita. Tequila is the primary alcohol ingredient in a margarita.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALCO STANDARD TO SPLIT INTO TWO COMPANIES
abstract: The board of the Alco Standard Corporation approved a plan yesterday to split into two publicly traded companies: one to sell and lease office equipment and the other to distribute paper products. The company, based in Wayne, Pa., also said its second-quarter earnings rose 45 percent. Since early February, Alco has been considering a plan to split its Ikon Office Solutions unit and its Unisource paper products division. Alco shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $54.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: For Kohl, British Beef Is Edible, but Not Worth a Political Stew
abstract: The German Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, wouldn't touch the British beef controversy with a 10-foot pole, but he didn't mind digging in with a fork and knife today.         While he dined, European agriculture ministers were gathering in Luxembourg to reconsider the ban on exporting the British beef.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Hearing Alarm Bells In Those Cold Calls
abstract: INVESTORS, brokers, readers: listen up.  There are impostors among us. Would-be brokers, unlicensed and dangerously devoid of knowledge, are often cold-calling prospective clients, opening accounts and, in some cases, executing trades. The National Association of Securities Dealers, the industry watchdog, has been unable to stop these abuses of its own rules, despite some effort.        Brokers -- or, more appropriately, "registered representatives" -- are required to pass the N.A.S.D. Series 7 and 63 examinations. The first of these is a difficult, 250-question, six-hour test that many first- and second-time takers fail. It is not uncommon for some people to study for it full time for a  month or so. The best firms offer in-house classroom training to prepare their new hires for the test. But other firms don't. In fact, some firms actually want, and help, their own new hires to fail.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The X Games: Going to extremes in an effort to tap a growing segment of sports
abstract: HERE's "Generation X" and "The X-Files," "Madame X" and X marks the spot. Now, ESPN Inc. hopes to add one more name to that list: the X Games.         The second annual installment of the event, which will run from Monday through June 30 on the ESPN, ESPN2 and ESPN International cable television networks, is, to paraphrase an advertising slogan, not your father's Olympics. Rather, the 35 1/2 hours of contests are intended as a showcase for the new so-called extreme sports -- "sheer unadulterated athletic lunacy," as they are billed in the X Games promotional campaign by Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. -- like sky surfing, skateboarding, sport climbing and even bungee jumping.

headline: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE INDUSTRY;Managed Care Empires in the Making
abstract: Leonard Abramson decided about a year ago that U.S. Healthcare Inc., his enormously successful health maintenance organization, needed a new strategy to  keep its profits up. A flock of competing H.M.O.'s, led by Oxford Health Systems, was vying for customers on his home turf, in Philadelphia and New Jersey. Even more threatening, hospitals and doctors were melding into groups big enough to resist when the H.M.O.'s try to squeeze their fees.         Mr. Abramson, the founder and chief executive of U.S. Healthcare, turned over daily operations to his lieutenants and set out to find a strategic partner. He  ended up selling his managed care company to the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, he said yesterday, to get the "mass we needed, the power to negotiate with the physicians, the hospitals, the drug companies" and force down their charges.

headline: Mediation Expected In CBS-Guild Split
abstract: A mediator is scheduled to meet Monday with the Writers Guild of America and  CBS in an attempt to resolve an impasse that has left about 350 newswriters, graphic artists and others without a contract for almost a week, Variety reported today.         Meanwhile, a new deadline was set for midnight Tuesday. Employees of the network in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington already have authorized a strike should discussions fail, although both sides continued to talk after the pact expired March 31.

headline: Caremark and Medpartners Seen Merging
abstract: Caremark International and Medpartners/Mullikin have agreed to a $2.5 billion merger that would create the nation's largest management company for physician practices, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.         The transaction, which is expected to be announced today in New York, would be a tax-free stock swap. The deal would be part of a consolidation that continues to sweep through the health industry, as providers are increasingly coming under pressure to cut costs.

headline: Dull Israeli Election Masks a Race Against Terror
abstract: Compared with the election campaigns in Russia or India, Israel's might appear a dull affair. Dull, that is, if the campaign is defined only by the tame speeches and glossy television spots.         The real race, as every Israeli knows, is being waged in Israeli buses, in south Lebanon, in the West Bank, in Hebron -- wherever terrorists have struck and could strike again, challenging the hopes of the developing peace.

headline: Philip Morris Sharply Cuts Prices on Post and Nabisco Cereals
abstract: In a bid to take market share from its larger competitors, the Post cereals division of the Kraft Foods unit of the Philip Morris Companies announced an immediate 20 percent reduction yesterday in the retail prices of its Post and Nabisco breakfast cereals.         The price cuts range from 90 cents for a 24-ounce box of Post Grape-Nuts to $1.14 for a 20-ounce box of Post Premium Raisin Bran.

headline: Consumer Confidence Fades a Bit, but Home Resales Rise
abstract: Although consumer confidence waned a bit in May, many professional forecasters remain upbeat about the economy, seeing no recession at least through next year.         And despite rising mortgage rates, sales of previously owned homes rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April to the second-highest level on record, a real  estate trade group reported.

headline: Peres Speech Invokes 'Israeli Dream'
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres, who failed to sweep up enough of his nation in his vision of peace, delivered a political testament today, saying Israel should honor an agreement with the Palestinians and reach accords with Syria and Lebanon.         In his first public appearance since he lost last Wednesday's election to Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Peres, looking subdued but composed, was given three emotional standing ovations as he addressed an honorary doctorate ceremony at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Steve Albertini, executive vice president at Earle Palmer Brown, Philadelphia, was promoted to general manager, assuming responsibilities held by J. Scott Franks, president and general manager, who will leave after two months to join Tierney & Partners, Philadelphia, a unit of True North Communications, in the new post of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Fred Zuckerman was named to the new position of executive vice president and media services director at Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He had been senior vice president and media director at Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, New  York.

headline: Japan's Vaunted Bureaucrats, the Real Power Behind the Throne, AreUnder Siege
abstract: When former Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama took office two years ago, his aides begged Japan's senior bureaucrat, a man who had served seven Prime Ministers, to stay on for fear that the Government would descend into chaos without him.         Japan's Prime Minister heads the Government, of course, but some say that to  encounter real power one must talk to the bureaucrats who effectively write the  laws and really run the country.

headline: Energy Dept. Sees Lower Prices at the Pump
abstract: Gasoline prices could drop as much as 10 cents a gallon this summer, the Energy Department said today.         The decline could be "even more in California," Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary said in releasing a study ordered by President Clinton on April 29.

headline: ACCORD REACHED BY IRAQ AND U.N. FOR OIL EXPORTS
abstract: Iraq and the United Nations signed an agreement today allowing the Iraqis to  sell oil for the first time since their 1990 invasion of Kuwait in order to pay  for the urgent needs of a civilian population suffering from six years of tight  international sanctions.         The agreement permits Iraq to sell up to $1 billion worth of oil every 90 days, under tight United Nations supervision, with most of the money to buy food and medicine.

headline: World News Briefs;Threats by Guerrillas Put Colombia on Alert
abstract: The Colombian army and police went on maximum alert today after leftist guerrillas called for a nationwide strike under the threat of violence.         A police official said soldiers and police officers had gone on alert throughout the country after the guerrillas called on public and private officials not to go to work Monday or Tuesday.

headline: Bond Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill being auctioned Thursday.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.00 percent and a six-month bill was 5.11  percent. In when-issued trading the 52-week bill was offered at a price to yield 5.25 percent.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMINA PRODUCTION TO BE CUT 350,000 METRIC TONS
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would cut its annual alumina production by 350,000 metric tons, or about 3.3 percent, because of weaker demand for the material, which is used to make aluminum. Alcoa is the world's largest maker of alumina through Alcoa World Alumina and Chemicals, its  60 percent owned joint venture with WMC Ltd. of Australia. Alcoa World Alumina produced 10.6 million metric tons of alumina last year at refineries in Australia, Brazil, Suriname, Jamaica and the United States. Alcoa will immediately begin curtailing alumina production worldwide to bring it "into balance with market demand," said Al Posti, a spokesman for the Pittsburgh-based company. Alumina is a white powdery material that is refined from the mineral bauxite and used to make aluminum.

headline: Defense Secretary Says U.S. Troops May Have to Remain in Bosnia WellInto Next Year
abstract: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that American ground troops may have to remain in Bosnia beyond their original December pullout date and well into next year to prevent the shaky peace in Bosnia from disintegrating again into civil war.         Mr. Perry said that if NATO decided to keep its peacekeeping force in Bosnia, "it would be my recommendation that the United States participate in that decision, and participate in any force that is so designated."

headline: Jobless Claims Fall By 25,000 in Week
abstract: The number of Americans filing first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 25,000 last week as workers affected by the strike at the General Motors Corporation returned to their jobs.         But the Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance still totaled a seasonally adjusted 408,000, much higher than the 367,000 level that many analysts had expected.

headline: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE REGION;In New York, Aetna Will Be Understudy
abstract: Even though the Aetna Life and Casualty Company is buying U.S. Healthcare Inc., the impact in the New York metropolitan region will probably make it seem  as if the opposite has occurred. The U.S. Healthcare network -- it is both far larger and more successful, with about four times as many managed care patients  as Aetna in New York State, for example -- is expected to provide the imprint for how the two companies march forward together.         "It makes U.S. Healthcare even more of what they were -- a strong competitor  in the market," said Jim Tallon, president of United Hospital Fund, a nonprofit  philanthropic and medical research organization based in New York City.

headline: DE KLERK'S PARTY QUITS GOVERNMENT
abstract: The day after South Africa adopted a Constitution that he called flawed, Deputy President F. W. de Klerk announced that his National Party would pull out of President Nelson Mandela's coalition Government.         Mr. de Klerk, who has clearly chafed in his role as deputy over the last two  years, said that South Africa's first non-racial democracy was already strong enough for a robust opposition party and that he intended to lead it.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOYD GAMING TO ACQUIRE PAR-A-DICE GAMING
abstract: The Boyd Gaming Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Par-a-Dice Gaming Corporation for $163 million in cash and the assumption of $12 million of debt.  Par-A-Dice owns the Par-A-Dice riverboat casino in East Peoria, Ill. Boyd Gaming said it valued the riverboat and land-based assets and operation at $155 million. Boyd is also acquiring an adjacent 204-room hotel and a vacant potential gaming site in Missouri, which the company valued at $20 million. Shares of Boyd Gaming, based in Las Vegas, Nev., rose 50 cents, to $14.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Warwick Baker Gets Used-Car Account
abstract: Driver's Mart Worldwide Inc. in Grand Rapids, Mich., a new company that plans to open a national chain of used-car stores this year, said yesterday that it had named Warwick Baker O'Neill in New York to handle its account, which will include advertising, direct marketing, point-of-sale materials and event marketing.

headline: Thousands Flee Fighting in the Liberian Capital
