abstract: Thousands of residents fled homes in Monrovia, the capital, for a second day  today as fighting continued between Government soldiers and rebels loyal to a besieged militia leader.         The battles, the worst in the capital in more than three years, started on Saturday after Government troops tried to drive the faction leader, Roosevelt Johnson, from his home in the normally quiet eastern suburb of Sinkor.

headline: Canada and Mexico Join to Oppose U.S. Law on Cuba
abstract: In a united and increasingly defiant stance against their common ally, Canada and Mexico are stepping up their opposition to what they consider an unlawful United States effort to penalize foreign companies that trade with Cuba.         During meetings here and in other Canadian cities this week Jean Chretien, Canada's Prime Minister, and Ernesto Zedillo, Mexico's President, strongly criticized the United States for its attempts to impose the Helms-Burton Act. The American law requires foreign companies to report any property they have in  Cuba that was confiscated from American owners by the Communist Government of President Fidel Castro. It also opens the way for those companies to be sued in  American courts for compensation.

headline: Good Cigars, but a Lot of Smoke
abstract: THE Culbro Corporation has long been a quiet company.         Its premium cigars, led by the popular Garcia y Vega and Macanudo brands, are puffed at Wall Street gatherings, and it is a big landowner in popular Wall Street getaways like rural Connecticut and Florida. But with a stock market value of less than $300 million, and with half of its shares in insiders' hands, it has never attracted much attention, despite ties to a fabled tobacco dynasty and a board studded with business celebrities.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Netscape Exceeds Wall Street Expectations
abstract: Driven by the rapid deployment of private corporate intranets and the continued expansion of the global Internet, the Netscape Communications Corporation reported first-quarter earnings today that were double Wall Street's expectations, as well as a tenfold increase in revenue.         Although the company is best known for its Netscape Navigator program for browsing the World Wide Web, which is available for free, Netscape now sells an  increasingly diverse group of software programs that use Internet technology to  distribute information. While some companies buy Netscape's server software for  managing their own Web sites or for offering on-line catalogues, many more use it for maintaining free-form corporate data bases that are readily accessible to nontechnical users.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: CIT Group Holdings Inc., Livingston, N.J., is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2001 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The medium-term notes are priced at 99.845 to yield 6.737 percent. The issue is rated Aa3 by Moody's Investors Service, A+ by Standard & Poor's and AA- by Duff & Phelps.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bulgarian Car Maker Decides to Close
abstract: Rodacar, Bulgaria's sole car maker, said yesterday that it was closing down because of bureaucratic obstacles and a lack of Government support. Rodacar said it would halt production of its Rover Maestro cars in its factory at the Black Sea port of Varna by the end of May, a move that was seen as a blow to Bulgaria's hopes of attracting sorely needed foreign investment.          Rodacar was started in March 1995 by Rover Group Ltd., a subsidiary of the German auto maker BMW A.G. Rover invested $20 million for a 51 percent stake. The remaining 49 percent is owned by four companies belonging to a private consortium in Bulgaria called Daru Group.   (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Earnings at Nomura Reach 5-Year High
abstract: Japan's largest securities house, the Nomura Securities Company, announced yesterday that it had its biggest annual profit in five years last year, saying  it had been helped by a recovery of Japan's stock market and lower interest rates. Nomura's earnings of 91.49 billion yen ($863 million) for the business year that ended on March 31 were well above the 6.8 billion yen ($64.1 million)  it earned a year earlier, but slightly below analysts' forecasts.  The figures are for parent current profit, which is a pretax profit including gains and losses made on securities investments and other nonoperating activities.   (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Bank Buys Private Banking Units
abstract: The Swiss Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the international private-banking arm of Standard Chartered P.L.C. in an effort to increase its international asset management business. The unit has more than $5 billion in assets. Swiss Bank also said it had bought a private portfolio of international  assets worth $1 billion from the Chase Manhattan Private Bank, a move that would beef up the Swiss bank's United States private-banking business.          While Swiss Bank did not disclose the price of the transactions, a spokesman, Thomas Staffelbach, said the acquisitions would not be the last. "We'll keep expanding our private-banking business because it's the most profitable and very stable," he said.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: SPENDING IT;Thoroughbreds Aren't Just the Sport of Kings
abstract: WHAT do M. C. Hammer, the rap star, and Queen Elizabeth have in common?         Both have owned thoroughbred race horses. In fact, a horse owned by Mr. Hammer finished third in the Kentucky Derby four years ago.

headline: Aide to Yeltsin Calls for Delay In June Election
abstract: Lending disturbing credence to the darkest suspicions of many Russians, President Boris N. Yeltsin's closest confidant called today for a postponement of the presidential election scheduled for June 16.         "People must be given time to calmly think about everything and reach a mature conclusion," said Maj. Gen. Aleksandr V. Korzhakov, Mr. Yeltsin's security chief, in a rare interview with the Interfax news agency. "For this, more time is needed than we have until June 16. There are entire regions of Russia where the civilized expression of people's will is not yet possible."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH CORONA WINS COURT ORDER TO KEEP OFFER SECRET
abstract: The Smith Corona Corporation won a temporary restraining order yesterday that would bar a group from going public with information about an offer it made to buy the company. The lawyers for Smith Corona, which is based in New Canaan, Conn., argued in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., that Cannon T.& C. Ltd. had violated a confidentiality agreement by issuing public statements this week about its rejected bid. Cannon is a private investment concern that made the bid proposal along with Mara Fund Ltd. of New York and a Smith Corona shareholder, Max Resnick. In court yesterday, a lawyer for Cannon said the group had offered $3 a share for 30 million Smith Corona shares but had not secured funds for its offer. The shares of Smith Corona fell 1.25 cents, to  5 cents, yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Nathan's Famous Rehires an Agency
abstract: Nathan's Famous Inc., the restaurant chain, has rehired the Manhattan Marketing Ensemble in New York to handle its account, which had been at Jerry &  Ketchum in New York, a joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and Ketchum Communications, for the last year. Billings were estimated at $1 million.          Richard E. Boudreaux, executive vice president of Nathan's in Westbury, L.I., said that Manhattan Marketing, which had handled the account for four and  a half years before it left for Jerry & Ketchum, was rehired without a formal review.

headline: Still Life, With Tourists;Can Visitors Revive the Economy for Philadelphia?
abstract: The promoters of this city's summer blockbuster art exhibit, which opens May  30, aren't missing a trick. Already, tourists can buy neon-hued, vinyl-covered baseballs plastered with Paul Cezanne's signature, or see the sights on a bus decorated with a 40-foot-long copy of a Cezanne still life of fruit. The exhibit is even being touted in a 20-page special-advertising section in Business Week magazine.         While the showing of 170 paintings by the French master is a major cultural event, its real objectives are economic. Philadelphia has lost tens of thousands of jobs in recent years, and now the nation's fifth-largest city has become the  latest Eastern dowager to embrace tourism as its economic salvation.

headline: Investors Shift To More Risky Mutual Funds
abstract: Cash continues to pour into mutual funds that invest in stocks. But American  investors are steering growing amounts of that new money to the riskiest type of funds, the category known as aggressive growth, perhaps indicating that speculative fever among mutual fund investors is rising again.         According to two groups that track mutual fund cash flows, the move back toward aggressive growth funds, which offer investors the highest potential rewards but come with a greater degree of volatility and risk of loss, reverses  a trend in evidence through the last half of last year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AVON STOCK JUMPS ON EARNINGS AND PRODUCT PLANS
abstract: Executives at Avon Products Inc. announced ambitious new product plans yesterday and said the worst appeared to be over for Avon in economically troubled Mexico. Meeting with analysts at Avon's headquarters in Manhattan, the  executives also said first-quarter earnings would be in line with analysts' estimates, on modestly higher revenue. The company's stock gained $4.50 a share, to $93, an all-time high. Among the new products announced by Avon is its first hair-care line, Avon Techniques. Late this year, the company will come out with a newly formulated skin-care product and a new fragrance, the company said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Big Japan Developer Seized For Blocking Land Auction
abstract: The police arrested a leading Japanese property developer today, once one of  the world's richest men, in a growing investigation into the roots of Japan's debt crisis.         The man arrested, Kichinosuke Sasaki, 63, is president of Togensha, a large real estate borrower that is in default on hundreds of millions of dollars of loans. He and other property developers have become the focus of intense public  anger, and his arrest may increase the prospects for passage of a Government plan to dissolve the nation's ailing mortgage companies, called jusen.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Wheat Move Lower With End of Drought in Kansas
abstract: Wheat plunged yesterday as speculation revived that rain last weekend in Kansas had halted the drought damage that sent prices to record highs this year.         Wheat prices have swung in the last two weeks as traders try to assess the extent of the damage to the winter-wheat crop.

headline: Stocks End Mixed as Dow Drops 33.96 Points
abstract: The stock market turned mixed yesterday after Monday's sharp decline. The Dow Jones industrial average continued to move downward, but advancing issues outnumbered declining ones on the New York Stock Exchange.         On Monday, the Dow tumbled 88.51 points in reaction to Labor Department data  that companies added 140,000 new jobs to their payrolls in March, more than had  been expected. This was the second consecutive month that a robust Labor Department employment report caused a major selloff; on March 8, the average dropped 171 points, the largest percentage decline in four years.

headline: Copenhagen Journal;Biker Wars in the Land of 'The Little Mermaid'
abstract: The hum of business at Copenhagen's smoothly efficient airport was broken by  bursts of automatic weapons fire one afternoon recently. Members of the Hell's Angels motorcycle gang were ambushing a group of rival bikers returning from abroad. They killed one and seriously wounded two others.         In the weeks since then, the rival Bandidos gang has attacked two Hell's Angels clubhouses with rocket-propelled grenades stolen from a Swedish Army base, and a Bandidos leader serving time at a Danish prison was nearly killed when a hand grenade exploded under his bed. The police are awaiting the next blow.

headline: None-Too-Bright Criminals Spoiling Germans' Efficient Image
abstract: Pessimists in Germany, of whom there is no shortage, see evidence of their country's decline everywhere. The economy is at a virtual standstill, unemployment is worse than it has been in 30 years, public employees are threatening to call a national strike, and dynamic political leaders are nowhere to be found.         But one sign of Germany's decline may actually be cause for celebration. Criminals here are getting dumber.

headline: Russia Agrees to Limit Its Forces on Borders
abstract: Russia has agreed to freeze the number of its conventional forces now deployed on its European borders and to meet its obligations under a 1990 arms reduction treaty within three years, United States and European officials said today.         The commitment by Russia, which has been in breach of the Treaty on Conventional Forces in Europe, followed two weeks of talks here aimed at settling problems over the pact that had arisen after the breakup of the Soviet  Union.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Surge in Market Rates Worrisome to Policy Makers Stock and bond prices tumbled as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates  stable. Analysts said the rate surge could endanger the moderate rate of growth  expected this year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REYNOLDS METALS TO CLOSE CAN PLANT IN HOUSTON
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company, the nation's second-largest aluminum company, said yesterday that it would close its Houston aluminum beverage can manufacturing plant within 12 months, affecting about 200 workers. The Houston-based company will take an after-tax restructuring charge of $23 million in the first quarter, mostly to cover costs for the closing, when it reports earnings on Monday. "Regretfully, we must close the Houston plant because of overcapacity in the U.S. can industry and an anticipated slowdown in the average annual growth rate for aluminum cans from 5 percent to 2 percent," said William  Leahey Jr., Reynolds Can division vice president and general manager.

headline: Conoco Talks With Phillips About a Deal
abstract: Conoco Inc. and the Phillips Petroleum Company said yesterday that they were  in talks to combine their gasoline refining and marketing businesses.         A deal would form a company with $13.6 billion in annual revenue. Such a venture would be the first of its kind in the United States, but it would follow a move in February, by the Mobil Corporation and the British Petroleum Company P.L.C., to combine refining and marketing operations in Europe. Mobil and British Petroleum expect their joint effort to save about $500 million in the next three years.

headline: Nigeria and Cameroon Clash Over Peninsula on the Border
abstract: Nigerian and Cameroonian forces fought all weekend and into this morning in the latest outbreak of violence over the small Bakassi peninsula, which lies between the two countries, officials at Nigerian defense headquarters said today.         The officials said long-range artillery, helicopter gunships and gunboats had been used, and diplomats said more than 50 Nigerian soldiers had been killed and a number taken prisoner in the most recent fighting. No information was available on Cameroonian casualties.

headline: Japanese Stocks Up a Bit
abstract: Japanese stocks traded slightly higher here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 18.79 points -- less than one-tenth of 1 percent -- to stand at 22,549.44. On Friday, the Nikkei index gained 93.35 points.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Filling a Void in Accounting
abstract: THE battle over who chooses the people who set accounting standards seems likely to end in some sort of compromise, with Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, prevailing in his effort to have people who represent the "public interest" added to the Financial Accounting Foundation.        The foundation oversees the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the quasi-official group that sets the accounting rules for America's publicly owned companies. Mr. Levitt says the foundation should be changed so that a majority of its members are people "with strong public service backgrounds, who are able  to represent the public interest, free of conflict."

headline: Lebanon Buries 90 Victims of Israeli Attack
abstract: Lebanon held a mass burial today for the victims of an Israeli artillery attack on a United Nations base.         With chants of grief filling the air, 90 wooden coffins were passed by hand above an emotional crowd of mourners near the site of the attack in Qana.

headline: A Boston Bank Merger Gets an Approval
abstract: The Justice Department approved the $2 billion merger of the Bank of Boston and Baybanks today after they agreed to sell 20 branch offices to the U.S. Trust Company.         The sale of the 16 Baybanks and four Bank of Boston branches would resolve concerns that the merger would have reduced competition in banking services for  small and medium-sized businesses, the Justice Department said. The banks also agreed to take no steps to preclude other banks from leasing or buying any branches they decide to close after their merger.

headline: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE REFORMER;A Onetime Scapegoat Savors Taste of Revenge
abstract: Just five months after the Yeltsin Government's foremost proponent of free-market reform was humilated and forced out of office, Anatoly B. Chubais has vanquished his enemies and made a triumphant return.         As a top campaign aide to President Boris N. Yeltsin, it was Mr. Chubais who  explained Mr. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his hard-line aides at a news conference broadcast on a state controlled television network. And for months it has been Mr. Chubais who has instilled a sense of strategy and organization into Mr. Yeltsin's previously rudderless election campaign.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMAX TO SELL MOST OF FABRICATED PRODUCTS OPERATION
abstract: Alumax Inc. agreed yesterday to sell most of its steel and aluminum fabricated products business for $245 million to Euramax International Ltd., a new British company held by venture capital affiliates of Citicorp. Analysts had expected Alumax to shed assets and focus on its core aluminum processing operations after it had rejected a $2.5 billion takeover bid from the Kaiser Aluminum Corporation. Alumax, which is based in Norcross, Ga., plans to sell 30 plants and service centers in the United States and five plants in Europe. The plants manufacture roofing materials, siding and rain gutters. The businesses to be sold have annual sales of $500 million and employ about 2,100.

headline: Consumer Stocks Lift The Dow Over 5,700
abstract: It's the consumer who has turned around the stock market.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italian G.D.P. Data Offer Mixed Picture
abstract: Italy's gross domestic product expanded 2.3 percent in the third quarter compared with the similar period a year earlier, though the country's economy contracted nine-tenths of 1 percent in 1995's final quarter from the third quarter, the state statistical institute, Istat, said yesterday. Italy's G.D.P.  grew by 3 percent for the full year, compared with 2.1 percent in 1994.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Health Plans In New Jersey Face Rivalries
abstract: New Jersey's fiercely competitive health insurance market will soon become even rougher. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey yesterday agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big, diversified Midwestern insurer. The merger will create  the nation's second-biggest holder of Blue Cross and Blue Shield franchises.         The deal will help give New Jersey Blue Cross, which already covers 1.9 million residents, the financial heft to slug it out in the managed-care market with the likes of U.S. Healthcare, Prudential and Oxford Health Plans.

headline: East German Ex-Activists Continue as a Force in West
abstract: When Chancellor Helmut Kohl dropped by to visit the human rights advocate Barbel Bohley in her small Berlin apartment recently, a storm of controversy erupted.         Ms. Bohley helped organize the mass protests that brought down East Germany's Communist Government in 1989, and many of her former comrades felt she was betraying their cause by sipping tea with someone who epitomizes the political establishment as completely as Chancellor Kohl. Left-leaning journals condemned  her with headlines like "Former Dissident Makes Peace With Power."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Seagram Criticized For Possible TV Ads
abstract: The Coalition for the Prevention of Alcohol Problems, a group of 24 public health and consumer organizations, has accused the Seagram Company of planning "to seduce America's children" because Seagram might be ending its decades-long  adherence to a voluntary ban against broadcast advertising among liquor marketers.          The coalition, based in Washington, was responding to reports in Advertising Age and other publications that Seagram had asked at least four cable television networks about the possibility of carrying commercials for Absolut vodka, which  Seagram distributes. The coalition sent letters to Seagram and to a trade organization, the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States, urging Seagram to reconsider any such plans and warning that liquor commercials would spur "invigorated calls for additional governmental restrictions on alcoholic-beverage advertising in all media."

headline: I.R.A. Ally Might Accept Disarmament Terms
abstract: Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, said today that if it was permitted to take part in Northern Ireland peace talks scheduled for next month, it would abide by stipulations for disarmament recommended by an international commission headed by former Senator George J. Mitchell.         Sinn Fein has never agreed to such strict disarmament stipulations as those proposed by the commission in January. British officials here and Irish officials in Dublin welcomed the promise, made in Belfast by Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein.

headline: Austin Center Is Sold
abstract: The Intercontinental Life Corporation sold the Austin Center office-hotel complex today for $62.7 million to the Khimji family of Dallas and Vancouver, British Columbia. The Austin-based insurance company expects the sale to add $15 million, or $2.78 a share, to its first-quarter results. The company will use the proceeds to reduce its bank debt to $29.9 million from $44.9 million. For the first quarter ended March 31, 1995, Intercontinental Life earned $2.6 million, or 51 cents a share.

headline: Need to Cut Costs? Order Out;Outsourcing Saves Money, but Labor Is Frustrated
abstract: The anti-lock brake systems look out of place as they slide by almost silently on conveyor belts at the ITT Industries factory here. From the spotless white floors to the cool, filtered air to the young workers in white hair nets and white plastic laboratory coats, the factory seems more suited to the production of computer components than auto parts.         Far different are the cavernous buildings in Dayton, Ohio, filled with endless rows of clanking, roaring machinery, where the General Motors Corporation makes brakes for nearly all its cars and trucks. A few rusting fans  hang from the exposed support beams, the only relief when temperatures soar above 100 degrees in the summer. The floors are concrete painted black, and the  air smells of oil and sweat. The workers, mostly graying men in their 40's and 50's, wear greasy orange jump suits or blue jeans -- and nobody has a hairnet.

headline: Copper Plunges on Worries Of Possible Big Sales in Japan
abstract: Copper prices tumbled yesterday as a market already nervous about supply was roiled by speculation that a management change at a big Japanese trading company could lead to a selloff of its copper holdings.   Traders said that rumors that Yasuo Hamanaka, the chief copper trader at the Sumitomo Corporation, had resigned sent copper prices plunging. Traders were betting that the company would sell its copper positions, said Wolfgang Becker, a trader at Iceni Commodities Brokerage in Hamburg, Germany.

headline: World News Briefs;Yeltsin Offered Rival A Market Reform Post
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin said today that he had offered to put Grigory A. Yavlinsky, an economist who is Mr. Yeltsin's main liberal challenger, in charge  of Russia's market reforms if he would agree to drop out of the presidential race.         Mr. Yeltsin said that he had proposed the post of Deputy Prime Minister to Mr. Yavlinsky but that Mr. Yavlinsky had wanted more.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nikon's Annual Profit More Than Triples
abstract: The Nikon Corporation announced sharply higher annual profit yesterday that exceeded its own forecasts, and credited strong growth in sales of equipment used to make semiconductors. The camera maker said its unconsolidated pretax profit soared 221 percent, to 18.85 billion Japanese yen, about $177.8 million,  in the year ended March 31, up from 5.88 billion yen the previous year. Nikon's  pretax profit beat company forecasts by 7.7 percent. Sales rose to 259.56 billion yen from 229.19 billion yen.          Sales of equipment used in making semiconductors rose 33 percent, to 157.18  billion yen. Nikon is the world's largest maker of steppers, lithography tools that use sophisticated lenses to trace chip circuitry while making semiconductors. Over all, domestic sales rose 23 percent and made up just less than half of the company's total sales. Exports rose 5.3 percent.   (AP)

headline: World News Briefs;Burundi Issues Appeal For Help to End Killings
abstract: Feuding members of Burundi's Government set aside their differences today to  make their first appeal for foreign help to end ethnic killings in the central African nation.         The appeal came at a six-nation regional conference called to prevent Burundi's two major tribal groups, the Hutu and Tutsi, from plunging into full-scale war.

headline: U.S. Aid for North Korea
abstract: The United States announced today that it had formally decided to provide North Korea with $6.2 million in food aid to ease a shortage caused by floods in 1995.         The aid, announced by the State Department, will include some 3,500 tons of corn and soy blend for children under 5, 6,600 tons of rice and 3,000 tons of cornmeal. It will be distributed through the United Nations World Food Program.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;In Shift, Viacom Is Said to Let Former Executive Join MCA
abstract: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., has dropped his efforts to prevent Frank J. Biondi Jr., whom Mr. Redstone ousted as president and chief executive in January, from taking the top job at rival MCA Inc., according to executives close to the talks. An announcement of Mr. Biondi's appointment is expected today.         Mr. Redstone had been attempting to force business concessions from MCA in exchange for letting Mr. Biondi out of a one-year noncompete contract. It appeared yesterday, however, that Mr. Redstone had agreed to let Mr. Biondi leave without having extracted the concessions.

headline: 2d Briton Is Charged In Computer Spying
abstract: The British police said today that they had charged a 21-year-old computer hacker with trying to gain electronic access to United States military files. The charges come just months after a teen-ager was arrested and accused of intercepting messages from United States agents in North Korea.         In the latest case, Mathew Bevan, an information technology technician, was charged with conspiracy to gain unauthorized access to computers and conspiracy  to cause unauthorized modification to computers, a Scotland Yard spokeswoman said.

headline: BUSINESS BEST SELLERS
abstract: HARD COVER

headline: Judge Says He Erred in Trial Fleming Lost
abstract: A Texas judge who entered a $211.1 million verdict against the Fleming Companies recused himself today from post-trial motions and said he would ask that Fleming, a grocery distributor, be granted a new trial.         Judge Charles C. Cooke of Johnson County wrote to an administrative judge to  apologize for failing to disclose that he once owed money to the controlling shareholder of the company that sued Fleming.

headline: G.O.P. Bill Would Extend Pensions in Small Business
abstract: House Republicans plan to pass legislation on Wednesday that would make it easier for small businesses to offer retirement savings plans for their 36 million workers. And in a break from decades of pension policy, the bill would let owners reap tax benefits for themselves even if their workers do not participate.         The retirement provisions are part of a $7.5 billion bill filled with changes sought by owners of small businesses to simplify tax, pension and other rules that bedevil companies with fewer than 100 workers.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: Chile Will Enter a Big South American Free-Trade Bloc
abstract: In a move that expands free trade in South America, Chile agreed today to join the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur, which includes the continent's largest trading partners, Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.         The inclusion of Chile, the most economically developed country in the region, gives the Mercosur bloc access to a robust economy of 14 million people  and to Chile's Pacific Ocean ports -- vital gateways to commerce with Asia.

headline: Pope Extols Church's Nazi Resistance, but With a Sidestep
abstract: Pope John Paul II today lauded German Catholics who resisted Nazism, but in a departure from his text omitted remarks laying claim to a broad Roman Catholic stand against the Holocaust.         Before 70,000 people at an open-air mass, the Pope spoke of four Catholics who died resisting Nazism, two of whom he has already beatified and two others whom he plans to beatify on Sunday in Berlin. In Catholic practice, beatification is the last step before sainthood.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VOICE CONTROL SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY VOICE PROCESSING
abstract: Voice Control Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Voice Processing Corporation, a developer of speech-recognition computer technology, for more than $40 million. Voice Control said the purchase price included four million of its shares, which fell 12.5 cents, to $10.125, in Nasdaq trading. Shareholders of Voice Processing, based in Cambridge, Mass., will own about 30 percent of the combined company's fully diluted shares after the transaction. Dallas-based Voice Control supplies speech-recognition and speaker-verification technology.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Absence of Buying by Japan Weakens Dollar Against Yen
abstract: The dollar fell against the yen yesterday, hurt by speculation that the Bank  of Japan might soon raise interest rates.         The dollar was also weakened as currency traders took advantage of a national holiday in Japan to sell dollars, believing the Bank of Japan would not intervene to support the dollar against the yen. While Japanese markets were closed yesterday for the holiday, Greenery Day, the Bank of Japan might have left orders with other central banks to buy dollars for yen on its behalf. But such orders did not materialize in the market.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MCCORMICK, SPICE PRODUCER, PLANS PRETAX CHARGE
abstract: McCormick & Company, the spice producer, whose profits have been falling, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $57 million this quarter for restructuring moves that would reduce sales about 5 percent. McCormick, based in Sparks, Md., said it would close a packaging plant in Brooklyn, sell a  dehydrating operation in Cairo, and also sell a number of small noncore businesses. It said that in parts of the United States it would change from a direct sales force to a broker sales force. As a result, sales will be reduced by about 5 percent, it said. McCormick earned $97.5 million, or $1.20 a share, on sales of $1.86 billion in 1995.

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading higher here today, amid expectations that the dollar's rise against the Japanese yen would help profits at Japanese exporting companies. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 357.11 points, or 1.63 percent, at 22,273.71. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 230.61 points, or 1.04 percent.

headline: Telegraph Publisher to Take Paper Private
abstract: Conrad Black, the Canadian newspaper owner, took steps to remove his company  Telegraph P.L.C. from the London stock market with an offer of L280 million ($420 million) for the 36 percent of the company that he does not already control.         The move will bring to an end a stormy relationship between Mr. Black and London's financial institutions that developed during the four years that Telegraph has been traded on the exchange.

headline: Basque Woman Held By the French Police In Attacks in Spain
abstract: The French police have arrested one of Spain's most wanted Basque separatist  guerrilla suspects, French and Spanish Interior Ministry officials said today.         The suspect, Maria Nagore, who has six Spanish arrest orders against her, was detained on Wednesday after a routine check at Charles De Gaulle Airport in Paris disclosed that her Spanish passport was a fake, a French Interior Ministry spokeswoman said.

headline: Treasury Auction And Other Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of bills and notes,  beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. Tomorrow, the Treasury will auction a two-year note, followed by Wednesday's auction of a five-year note.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.11 percent and on the six-month bill, 5.25 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a rate to yield 6.32 percent and a five-year note at 6.71 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NABISCO HOLDINGS CORP., Parsippany, N.J., the maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, plans to raise its quarterly dividend by 12.7 percent to 15.5 cents a  share, payable on July 1 to shareholders of record on June 14.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SCITEX Corp., Herzlia, Israel, a computer imaging systems company, said an Israeli investment group had raised its stake in it to 24.33 percent of the company's outstanding ordinary shares. The group, which includes IDB Development Corp. Ltd., PEC Israel Economic Corp. and Recanati family members, purchased 225,000 shares at $18.38 to $19.12 a share.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Issues Strong Warning To China About Copyrights
abstract: The Clinton Administration has delivered a sharp warning in private to Chinese leaders that China's failure to comply with a 1995 agreement on copyright piracy of American products is undercutting the Administration's credibility in Congress and will force tariff sanctions on up to $2 billion in Chinese imports sometime next month, Westerners who were briefed by the Administration said.         The ultimatum was delivered by Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States  trade representative, who held two days of talks here last week and then left Beijing without public comment.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MERRILL LYNCH TO BUY LENDER'S SERVICE FROM PRUDENTIAL
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Lender's Service Inc., a provider of appraisal, title and closing services to the mortgage and real estate industry. Terms were not disclosed. Merrill Lynch will  acquire Lender's Service from the Residential Services Corporation of America, a unit of the Newark-based Prudential Insurance Company of America. Pittsburgh-based Lender's Service, which employs about 450 people, will become part of Merrill Lynch's Private Client Group.

headline: SPENDING IT;Only a Will Can Insure That Thy Will Be Done
abstract: ABRAHAM LINCOLN died without one.         So did Presidents Andrew Johnson, Ulysses S. Grant and James A. Garfield.

headline: Glass-Steagall Overhaul Is Abandoned
abstract: Short of time and facing mounting opposition, the chairman of the House Banking Committee today abandoned an ambitious election-year effort to overhaul the financial-services industry.   The chairman, Representative Jim Leach, said he would instead content himself with providing banks with modest regulatory relief while asking the Federal Reserve to let the very biggest banks underwrite larger, but still severely limited, volumes of corporate securities.

headline: U.S. Calls Off Risky Daylight Rescue Flights in Liberia
abstract: As fighting by rival militia groups raged on in Monrovia, the Liberian capital, United States officials today called off daytime evacuations of foreigners for fear that rescue helicopters based here would come under attack.          Hundreds of Americans and other foreigners are still trapped in Liberia by the uncontrolled fighting, American military officials said. With no functioning airport there, evacuations have been made by helicopters that can carry only 25  passengers at a time.

headline: Furloughed Delta Pilots Now All Rehired
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that it had recalled the last 199 of its furloughed pilots, reflecting the airline's growth.         The pilots are being rehired to work on Delta's low-cost service intended to  compete with no-frills carriers like Southwest Airlines and Valujet. The service is scheduled to begin this fall. Delta also needs pilots to fill openings created by the departure of senior pilots who take advantage of an early retirement option under a contract signed with the pilots' union on April  23.

headline: South Africans Revisit Apartheid's Horrors
abstract: Nohle Mohapi's husband had been in detention -- she didn't know where -- when someone came to her workplace to deliver two letters he smuggled from jail. They were written on toilet paper and said "the situation was bad" but that her politically active young husband, Mapetla, was all right. The letters said she must take care of the children until they would all be together again.         It was only a few days later, in 1976, that the police told Mrs. Mohapi that  her husband had hanged himself in his cell with a pair of blue jeans.

headline: Japanese Markets Closed
abstract: Japanese stock markets were closed today in observance of Children's Day. In  a holiday-shortened week last week, the Nikkei index of 225 issues lost a total  of 572.65 points, to 21,662.38.

headline: When 2 Speakers Are Not Enough
abstract: The idea of bringing the spectacle of cinema into the living room has transformed the consumer electronics industry. High fidelity, as a marketing concept, has substantially given way to home theater. And the magnitude of that  shift, several industry managers agree, can be read in the dominating influence  of home theater on loudspeaker sales.         "About a year ago, I called around to our dealers asking what percentage of loudspeakers go out for home theater setup," said Steve Ravinski, marketing manager for KH America, a speaker distributor that is a subsidiary of Gold Peak  Industries. "The answer was 95 percent." For the industry as a whole, the estimate is 40 percent.

headline: In Europe, an Ex-Ambassador's New Empires
abstract: Ronald S. Lauder is not the first American diplomat to turn a political assignment into a subsequent business opportunity. But few people have done it on as grand a scale.         Eight years after he completed a stint as United States Ambassador to Austria, Mr. Lauder has used his knowledge of Central and Eastern Europe to cobble together two business empires -- one in television and one in telecommunications.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COLLINS & AIKMAN TO SPIN OFF WALLCOVERING UNIT
abstract: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off its Imperial Wallcoverings Inc. subsidiary to shareholders. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., said the spinoff, which should be completed within four months, would let it focus on its automotive products business. The company said Imperial, a publicly traded company before it was acquired by Collins & Aikman in 1971, had revenue of $205.3 million for the latest fiscal year. Shares of Collins & Aikman, which also makes residential upholstery fabrics and contract carpets, rose 25 cents, to $6.375 yesterday.

headline: U.S. Defends Its Silence on Teheran's Arms Smuggling to Bosnia
abstract: The Clinton Administration today defended its 1994 decision not to block Iranian arms shipments to Bosnia but failed to shed light on how the decision was made or why Congress was not formally informed.         At a hearing of the House International Relations Committee, Peter Tarnoff, the Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said he knew little about the President's decision to do nothing to stop the flow of arms to Bosnia by way of Croatia, despite an arms embargo. Much of what he did know was classified, he said.

headline: The Bonds: Some Issues Not Settled By Treasury
abstract: The Treasury's proposal to issue inflation-index bonds raises a number of issues, some of which have not yet been resolved.         The maturity of the bonds.

headline: Blue Cross Warns Ohio Plan Not to Sell to Columbia
abstract: The national Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association said yesterday that it would terminate the licenses of Ohio Blue Cross and Blue Shield if the Ohio plan proceeded with a $299.5 million agreement to sell its main lines of business to  the Columbia-HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's biggest investor-owned hospital chain.         Analysts called it a warning to Blue Cross plans across the country not to try to auction themselves off to hospital chains or other well-heeled bidders outside the Blue Cross system.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Aerospatiale and Dassault Close to Merger Agreement
abstract: Two French arms industry giants, the Government-owned Aerospatiale and the privately held Dassault Aviation, are close to a merger, Defense Minister Charles Millon said today.         A merger would create a company with $12 billion in annual sales. Mr. Millon  said the final terms of the merger would be announced in a few days. But French  reports said that 27 percent of the merged company would be owned by Serge Dassault, who owned 49.9 percent of the company that was founded by his father.

headline: Scaring Up New Business With a Twist
abstract: At a time when the entertainment world seems maddeningly complex, consider the refreshingly simple way the Six Flags theme park here will amuse customers this summer: they will be strapped in a car, shot 415 feet in the air, then dropped along a track at 100 miles an hour.         At Universal Studios, near Hollywood, people will have the pleasure of being  attacked and nearly devoured by a five-story Tyrannosaurus rex. At Sea World, a  park near San Diego that is owned by Anheuser-Busch, visitors this summer will be able to pet killer whales.

headline: F.D.A. Approves a Biogen Drug for Treating Multiple Sclerosis
abstract: Biogen Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing Avonex, its genetically engineered drug for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Avonex will be available by prescription beginning Monday.         Avonex is the first drug shown in clinical trials to actually slow the progression of relapsing multiple sclerosis, a degenerative nerve disease that frequently disables sufferers. Betaseron, a similar drug manufactured by the Chiron Corporation and marketed by the Berlex Laboratories division of Schering  A.G., has been shown only to reduce the frequency and severity of multiple sclerosis attacks. Betaseron also requires more frequent dosing and has more side effects than Avonex, setting the stage for a major marketing battle between Biogen and Berlex, analysts said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HOMETOWN BUFFET AGREES TO ACQUIRE BUFFETS FOR STOCK
abstract: Hometown Buffet Inc. of San Diego will acquire Buffets Inc. for stock worth more than $175 million, plus other considerations, the restaurant companies said. The combined company will operate 252 Old Country Buffet Restaurants, 93 Home Town Buffets and 2 Roadhouse Grills in 32 states with annual sales around $661 million. Under the agreement, Hometown shareholders will receive 1.17 Buffets common shares for each Hometown share held. Buffets, based in Eden Prairie, Minn., will also assume $41.5 million in Hometown debt securities convertible into common stock. Hometown shares fell $1.125, to $14, in Nasdaq trading; Buffets shares fell 12.5 cents, to $12.375.

headline: The U.S. Deficit Fell in March
abstract: The United States budget deficit fell to $47.28 billion in March from $50.54  billion in March 1995, the Treasury Department said today.         Halfway through the 1996 fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, the Government's perennial spending deficit has been improving, in part because Congress and the Clinton Administration remained deadlocked over a budget plan.

headline: U.S. and North Korea Agree On Joint Search for Missing
abstract: The United States and North Korea announced today that later this year they expect to begin their first joint effort to search for the remains of thousands  of Americans soldiers missing from the Korean War.         The announcement, which could signal a broad improvement in ties between the  two countries, means that Pentagon investigators could soon be wandering the North Korean countryside, searching for evidence of the burial sites of Americans missing since the war ended in 1953.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Revamping At True North
abstract: True North Communications Inc., which owns agencies including Foote, Cone & Belding, announced yesterday another revamping of top management that included two executives being stripped of their responsibilities, two promotions and a formation of a committee to focus on resolving a fractious dispute with Publicis S.A. over a joint-venture European agency network.         Jack Balousek, who only three months ago was named chairman and chief executive of TN Technologies, the digital and interactive marketing services unit of True North, will be replaced in those roles by Gregory W. Blaine, 47, executive vice president and global operating systems director. Mr. Balousek, 52, will continue at True North, but has not yet been assigned new duties.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Regulator Orders Cuts In British Gas's Rates
abstract: British regulators said yesterday that British Gas P.L.C. would have to cut prices by 10 percent next year. The company vowed to fight the proposal and said it would appeal to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. Shares of British Gas  were down more than 11 percent in London and the price of an American depository receipt, representing one share, fell $4.125 in New York, to $30.625.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FORD SWEETENS TAURUS DEAL TO FIGHT CHALLENGE
abstract: Moving to protect the Taurus's title as the "best-selling car in America" from a challenge by the Honda Accord, the Ford Motor Company sweetened financing terms yesterday for the vehicle. Ford cut the financing costs for the Taurus and the Contour, offering loans with an interest rate of 2.9 percent instead of 4.8  percent. The average lease payment on a Taurus will drop to about $240 a month from about $270. The Taurus, which has held the top United States sales position for the last three years, has had sales of 91,828 cars this year -- just 486 more than the Accord. Ford also said it was introducing a new base model for its redesigned Escort, which goes on sale May 23. The new model will start at $11,430, about $500 less than the old base model.

headline: Nanjing Journal;China's Campus Model for the 90's: Earnest Patriot
abstract: His manner was friendly, but his words had a hard, metallic edge to them.         "Pardon me for speaking so bluntly," said Liu Junhai, a junior at Nanjing University, pausing on a walk across the leafy campus to respond to a visitor's  questions about student attitudes.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ORACLE AND SUN MICROSYSTEMS TO COOPERATE
abstract: The chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, Lawrence J. Ellison, said yesterday that his company and Sun Microsystems Inc. would cooperate on basic design ideas for the software that runs less expensive computers. The companies  have been talking about computers that could access the Internet and other data  networks but with less processing and memory power than PC's. "We're going to compete, but we're also going to cooperate because the industry is in desperate need of an alternative to the Microsoft monopoly," Mr. Ellison said. Both companies are designing software to perform the basic functions of such machines, which Oracle calls a network computer, or NC. A Sun spokeswoman said she could not confirm the arrangement.

headline: British Officials Harden Stand On Talks With I.R.A. Allies
abstract: Stiffening their position after the bombing in downtown Manchester on Saturday, Government officials said today that it would be much more difficult for Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., to be admitted to the nascent peace talks on Northern Ireland.         At the same time, Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, tried to deal with the negative fallout from the blast. He said it would be "sheer folly" for the British to isolate the republicans who are opposed to British rule and to exclude them from talks on the future of the province.

headline: Israelis Suffer First Casualties in Lebanon Since Truce
abstract: Hezbollah guerrillas and Israeli forces exchanged fire in southern Lebanon today, causing the first Israeli casualties since the United States brokered an  end to a major Israeli military operation inside Lebanon two weeks ago.         The fighting today, in which at least five Israel soldiers were wounded, did  not violate that truce. The American deal, negotiated by Secretary of State Warren Christopher in a week of intensive shuttling between Jerusalem and Damascus, declared only that neither side would fire on the other's civilians.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mexico Adds to Aid On Bad Bank Loans
abstract: In the largest Government-assisted Mexican bank rescue to date, Grupo Financiero Serfin has sold $2.7 billion in bad loans to a bank bailout fund in exchange for a promise to raise $1.35 billion in fresh capital.         The deal, which was reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, is considered unusual because J. P. Morgan & Company has committed to temporarily invest as much as $350 million in Serfin to help the Mexican bank's owners complete the restructuring.

headline: New York Festivals Names 5 Winners
abstract: The New York Festivals has named five grand Best of Show winners at the 38th annual international print and radio competition.   In print, there were four winners: the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, for the best consumer campaign, for Altoids Mints, which are marketed by a unit of the Philip Morris Companies; Euro RSCG Ball Partnership in Singapore, a unit of Euro RSCG, for the best newspaper advertising, for the Samaritans, a society dedicated to the prevention of suicide; Lewis Moberly in London, for the best design for a package, for Boots Childrens' Batteries, marketed by the Boots Company P.L.C., and Wunderman Cato Johnson in Eschborn, Germany, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., for the best direct mail, for Andersen Consulting.

headline: 2 Small Competitors in New Giant's Path
abstract: Two huge holes can be found on a map of the 13-state region from Maine to Virginia that will be dominated by the proposed merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. One is virtually all of Connecticut, which is served by the 118-year-old  Southern New England Telephone Company; the other is a swatch of western New York around Rochester served by the Frontier Corporation.         In light of yesterday's merger announcement, can these two relative dwarfs continue to provide competitive service when they will likely be surrounded by a telecommunications giant with more than $27 billion in annual sales?

headline: In Time for Campaign '96, A New Political Web Site
abstract: If advertisers balked at supporting two huge political sites on the World Wide Web, will they be more receptive to one big site?         That's the gamble three of America's biggest media companies are taking with  Politics Now, a deep-dish digital buffet of campaign news, chat and games.

headline: Apple Licenses Macintosh System to I.B.M.
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had licensed its Macintosh operating system to the International Business Machines Corporation in an effort to prop up its shrinking market share.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Venezuela to Lift Currency Controls
abstract: President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela will announce the lifting of all foreign-exchange controls during a national address scheduled for Monday evening, Government officials said yesterday. The Government will adopt a unified exchange rate to be set by the market, said Teodoro Petkoff, Venezuela's Planning Minister. The rate is expected to be between the fixed rate of 290 bolivars to the dollar and the market rate of 470. "It will probably be nearer the latter," Mr. Petkoff said.          The country's international reserves are sufficient to cover the initial demand for dollars, Mr. Petkoff said. The central bank will also be expected to  protect the bolivar, presumably through higher interest rates. Venezuela imposed exchange controls in June 1994 to arrest a fall in international reserves and avert a collapse of the bolivar.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DATAPOINT CORP. San Antonio, will sell its European unit that creates computer software and hardware for car dealerships to Kalamazoo Computer Group P.L.C. for $33 million.

headline: DIARY: THE AUTO INDUSTRY;Looking Back, and Ahead, at General Motors
abstract: General Motors is like a lumbering ocean liner -- it doesn't exactly turn on  a dime, or even a $100 gold piece. Still, a changing G.M. was clearly visible last week. It was out with the old, in with the new, and a touch of luxury for dessert. Out went that North Tarrytown, N.Y., plant (above), which had been on the brink of closing, it seemed, for years, and really did so on Friday. It was  a plant that nearly spanned a century, making steam-powered cars starting in 1900 and Chevrolets since 1915, and it just turned out its last of those odd late-century creations, mini-vans. Also last week came a peek at the new G.M., as word leaked out about a radical plan to streamline a vast mix of offices and  labs, putting engineers under one roof. G.M. wastes billions of dollars designing parts for all its many models, and the goal is to get parts designers  working together. Finally, its flight of fancy: G.M., which owns half of Saab, got an option to buy the other half.

headline: Appeals Court Halts Takeover
abstract: Regulators who allowed MAC, the nation's largest automated teller machine network, to grow should have given opponents a chance to fight, an appeals court panel ruled today.         In a 2-to-1 decision, a panel of judges from the United States Court of Appeals vacated a Federal Reserve Board order allowing Electronic Payment Services, the joint banking venture that owns the MAC network, to buy a smaller  rival, the Money Center network, from the National City Corporation -- without a hearing.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Another Outsider At Ogilvy & Mather
abstract: The Ogilvy & Mather Direct unit of WPP Group in New York has hired its third  executive from outside the agency since February, when Wendy Riches joined as chairwoman and chief executive.         Bruce Lee, 45, becomes executive creative director, assuming responsibilities from Stanley Winston, 65, vice chairman and executive creative director, who becomes a consultant. Mr. Lee had been an executive vice president and creative  director at the Wunderman Cato Johnson unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. At Wunderman, in a development related to Mr. Lee's departure, Charles Webre,   33, who had also been an executive vice president and creative director, was promoted to the new position of chief creative officer.

headline: Rig Count Drops by 10
abstract: The number of oil and gas rigs operating nationwide dropped by 10 this week,  to 765, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. There were 677 rigs operating in the United States a year ago. Of the rigs running this week, 472 were exploring for  natural gas and 288 for oil; 5 rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count  represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

headline: War Crimes Suspect Succumbs to Cancer
abstract: A Bosnian Serb army general, Djordje Djukic, who was released by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague last month for ill health, died here on Saturday.         The Hague tribunal last month ordered the 62-year-old general's immediate release because he was dying of cancer, but said war crimes charges against him  should remain in place.

headline: World News Briefs;Afghans Get New Leader During Rebel Assault
abstract: Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, a former rebel leader, was sworn in as Prime Minister today during the deadliest rebel assault on the Afghan capital this year, a relentless barrage that killed at least 30 people.         Although many hoped the ceremony would symbolize a renewed peace effort, the  day was marred by rocket attacks from the Taliban militia.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Coca-Cola Enterprises Adds to Europe Stake
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., continuing to increase its share of the European  market, said today that it would buy the British bottling operations co-owned by the Coca-Cola Company and Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. for about $1.9 billion.         Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is owned 44 percent by Coca-Cola and is the world's largest bottler of that company's drinks, bought Coca-Cola's French and  Belgian bottling operations for $915 million in May and has a three-year-old business in the Netherlands. Those operations plus the British bottling company, the nation's largest with a 23 percent market share, will account for 28 percent of Coca-Cola Enterprises' overall volume. "In those four, there are economies of scale," said Roy Burry, an analyst at Oppenheimer & Company. "You can raise their profit margins substantially."

headline: Approval Given For Cancer Test
abstract: The Cytyc Corporation said this week that the Food and Drug Administration had cleared its Thinprep 2000 system for cervical cancer screening.         The company, based here, said the new test should reduce the number of errors that occur with traditional Pap smear tests. Some 50 million Pap smears, the

headline: Stocks Are Mixed as Dow Posts a Slight Gain
abstract: Stocks were mixed yesterday as a rally in bonds failed to shake investor concern that profits would fall short of expectations later this year.         The Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.33 points, to 5,652.78, ending five straight days of losses. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell  0.69 point, to 665.16, while the Nasdaq composite index slipped 5.54 points, to  1,207.64.

headline: Mexico's May Day March Shows Worker Anger at Official Unions
abstract: Dissident labor unions staged a huge but peaceful May Day march through downtown Mexico City today, in a show of workers' growing rejection of the official labor movement.         For the second year in a row, Fidel Velazquez Sanchez, the 96-year-old leader of the major Government-allied labor confederation, called off the traditional May Day march, attempting to ban all public demonstrations by laborers. Confederation officials said they canceled the march because they feared street  clashes between pro-Government and anti-Government marchers.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BARRETT RESOURCES CORP., Denver, an oil and gas exploration concern, plans to acquire natural gas, oil reserves and pipeline assets in Colorado's Piceance Basin for about $38.5 million in stock. The name of the party selling the assets was not disclosed.

headline: A Bomb in Buenos Aires
abstract: Explosives experts found a bomb today outside a naval hospital where a former military doctor in Argentina's so-called dirty war remained in critical condition after being riddled with bullets in an attack by a leftist guerrilla group last week.         The doctor, Jorge Berges, was sentenced in 1986 to six and a half years in prison for torturing pregnant prisoners and selling their babies for adoption in the 1970's, but was later freed under an amnesty.

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Warns Americans Living in Saudi Arabia
abstract: The State Department, concerned about the threat of another attack on American institutions in Saudi Arabia, issued a warning today to Americans throughout the kingdom.         The statement, issued here and in Riyadh, said the American Embassy there has received an anonymous telephone call threatening retaliation if four Saudis charged in a bombing six months ago are punished.

headline: War Crimes Aides Say Bodies in Graves May Have Been Moved
abstract: Many of the hundreds of bodies thought to be buried in two mass graves in this area may have been removed recently, officials close to the International War Crimes Tribunal said today after a preliminary examination of the sites.         The investigators, in their first survey of the area, said the digging was probably done within the last several weeks, according to the officials, who asked to remain anonymous. The extent of the digging indicated that some remains could have been removed, they said.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Climbs Near 110 Yen As Japan Rate-Rise Fears Ebb
abstract: The dollar rose to within a whisker of 110 yen yesterday, reaching its highest level in almost 29 months, as concerns about an increase in Japanese interest rates faded.         The yen fell against the dollar and other leading currencies after Japan said that its unemployment rate rose to a record 3.5 percent in May. The labor report reinforced the view that Japan's economic recovery was still too fragile  to withstand an increase in interest rates. Higher rates in Japan would make some investments there more attractive, helping the yen.

headline: Raytheon to Buy Chrysler Military Units
abstract: The Raytheon Company agreed to buy most of the Chrysler Corporation's military electronics and aircraft-upgrading business in a deal worth about $475  million, the companies said today. The transaction continues the consolidation of the nation's military businesses in the face of stagnant spending.         The deal would bring Raytheon's E-Systems Inc., which for decades has remodeled Air Force One, together with the Chrysler unit that set up the President's red phone, used for top-secret conversations.

headline: Williams Holdings Deal
abstract: Williams Holdings P.L.C. said today that it had acquired Nighthawk Systems Inc., a maker of carbon monoxide detectors, for $19.6 million in cash and debt.  Nighthawk, based in Colorado Springs, had sales last year of $32 million.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Texas Drought Sends Cotton Up As Wheat and Copper Decline
abstract: Cotton futures prices rose yesterday on concerns that a drought in West Texas, where almost 20 percent of the American crop is grown, could cut production.         Rainfall in the Texas highlands surrounding Lubbock has been less than two inches since October, according to the Weather Services Corporation, compared with more than seven inches normally.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHERN TELECOM PLANNING TO TAKE OVER MICOM
abstract: Northern Telecom Ltd. said yesterday that it planned a $137.4 million takeover of the Micom Communications Corporation, a maker of computer-networking devices based in Simi Valley, Calif. Northern Telecom, a Toronto-based provider  of telecommunications equipment and services, offered $12 for each Micom share,  below the stock's closing price on Friday. Micom's stock fell $2.25, to $11.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Nortel's stock was up $1.625, to $52.375.

headline: World News Briefs;Cameroon Holds Suspects In Rwanda Mass Killings
abstract: Cameroon has arrested 11 people accused of having been ringleaders in the mass killings in Rwanda in 1994, including the former director of a radio station that urged on the killers, Foreign Minister Anastase Gasana of Rwanda said today.         The arrests were made on Wednesday under arrest warrants issued by Rwanda, the Foreign Minister said. He said that all 11 men were being held in the central prison in Cameroon's capital, Yaounde, where they were identified by a Rwandan official.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canal Plus May End Bertelsmann TV Link
abstract: Canal Plus S.A. of France, Europe's biggest pay-television company, is talking with Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany on whether to end a two-year-old joint  accord to develop digital pay-TV in Europe. Executives at Canal Plus and its main shareholder, Havas S.A., said they were reconsidering the link in the wake  of Bertelsmann's alliance with Compagnie Luxembourgeoise de Telediffusion -- a Canal Plus rival.          Canal Plus said that while it had not decided to terminate the Bertelsmann accord, "it would be a logical consequence, since Bertelsmann has de facto broken the agreement by negotiating with CLT without us," said Sylvie Ruggieri,  a spokeswoman for the French company.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Correction
abstract: A chart with an article in Money and Business yesterday about companies' accounting practices misstated the titles of Sally Kasaks of Ann Taylor Stores.  Ms. Kasaks is chairwoman and chief executive, not the former chief executive.

headline: FOAMEX INTERNATIONAL TO SELL ITS PERFECT FIT UNIT
abstract: Foamex International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Perfect Fit Industries unit to an investment group and Perfect Fit management for $50 million. Foamex, a chemical company based in Linwood, Pa., said it planned to take a $38 million charge in the second quarter and restate its loss in the 1995 fiscal year to $1.73 a share from the previously reported $2.01. Perfect Fit, a maker of home furnishings, had sales of $98.5 million in 1995.

headline: Is North Korea Turning to Counterfeiting?
abstract: With North Korea so poor that people are going hungry, some experts are worried that the Government there may be turning to a novel approach to raising  hard currency: peddling counterfeit American money.         The evidence is far from conclusive, and North Korea denies that it is moonlighting as a counterfeiter. But the accusations have been boosted by the indictment last week in Thailand of a Japanese man who has close ties to the North Korean Government on charges of passing fake $100 bills.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Conagra Units Divide Assignments
abstract: The Armour Swift-Eckrich and Butterball Companies, which are owned by Conagra Inc., have divided their meat-products accounts between two agencies on the Conagra roster, Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis and Grey Advertising in New  York. The accounts, with combined billings estimated at $29 million to $32 million, had been handled by Puskar Gibbon Chapin in Dallas for the last three and a half years.          Campbell Mithun, which is owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies, will handle the Eckrich, Armour, Swift and Swift Premium Brown 'N Serve brands, with combined billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million. Campbell Mithun already handles brands like Healthy Choice for Conagra.

headline: A Top Economist Switches His View on Productivity
abstract: In the endless debate over whether companies in the huge service sector are becoming more efficient and productive, Stephen S. Roach is famous as the economist who says, flatly, they are. No skeptic can challenge that proposition  without facing down Mr. Roach. He has preached his case on talk shows, before Congress, in academia and on Wall Street. But now he is changing his mind.         "I must confess that I am having second thoughts as to whether we have reached the promised land," Mr. Roach said, in the opening paragraph of a circular that will be faxed tomorrow to the media and to hundreds of clients of  Morgan Stanley & Company, where he is chief economist. "These doubts have caused me to rethink many of the glorious conclusions that I have long argued would be  part of the sacred productivity-led recovery."

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Sends Troops To Aid Tornado Victims
abstract: The army sent medical teams and soldiers to northern Bangladesh today to help tens of thousands of people injured by a tornado and to search for 500 others who are still missing.         Authorities said 508 people were killed and 33,000 injured by the tornado, which swept through 80 villages in the northern plains on Monday.

headline: CHRISTOPHER GETS SNUB FROM ASSAD IN MIDEAST TALKS
abstract: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria abruptly canceled a meeting this afternoon  with Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who had flown to Damascus especially to meet him. Mr. Assad's stated reason was that the Americans had arrived 20 minutes later than expected and that he had a state dinner planned for the Pakistani Prime Minister, American officials said.         Mr. Christopher was told he could return on Wednesday to renew his appeal for Mr. Assad's help in ending the fighting along the border of Israel and Lebanon,  where rockets and bombs fell in a 13th day of devastation.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;ABC's All-News Cable Channel Is Shelved
abstract: In a decision that marked a full-blown retreat for the leading network news division, ABC announced yesterday that it was indefinitely postponing its plans  to begin a 24-hour all-news cable channel.         The decision, which ABC executives attributed to the excessive cost of distributing the channel and Rupert Murdoch's willingness to pay enormous distribution fees for his own all-news channel, is the first sign that three broadcast networks may have oversold their ambitious plans to start cable news channels to compete with the Turner Broadcasting System's Cable News Network.

headline: DLB Oil and Gas Purchase
abstract: DLB Oil and Gas Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire most of the Amerada Hess Corporation's Oklahoma oil- and gas-producing properties for about  $35 million. The purchase includes ownership in 44 fields, nine of which DLB plans to operate, and 1,196 wells. Proven reserves total about 7.22 million barrels of oil.

headline: Excel Chairman to Join Billionaires' Club
abstract: Kenny Troutt, the chairman of Excel Communications Inc., is close to becoming the latest Texas billionaire.         Excel, a Dallas-based reseller of long-distance services, disclosed today that its coming initial public offering calls for the sale of 10 million shares at $13 to $15 each.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Higher As Economic Data Are Due
abstract: Treasury securities rose yesterday, in trading that began quietly but gained  momentum near the market close while prices were increasing.         Bond prices had risen sharply on Friday after a report on producer prices showed that inflation in April was weaker than expected. As a result, some market participants sought yesterday to consolidate their positions ahead of today's report on consumer prices for April.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mixed Data Spur Some Hope in Germany
abstract: Germany's gross domestic product fell by half a percentage point in the first quarter of 1996, its worst performance in three years, the Federal Statistics Office said today.         But industrial production rose strongly in April, the Economics Ministry said, reflecting a belief among economists and the Government that recovery was  in sight despite two successive weak quarters.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fortis Considers a Bid For German Insurer
abstract: The insurance and financial services company Fortis A.G. is weighing a bid for the German insurer Vereinte Versicherung A.G., but it is not in talks yet with its owners, Fortis's chief executive, Maurice Lippens, said yesterday. "We  are studying it," Mr. Lippens said at a news conference after Fortis reported that net profit had risen 15 percent last year.         Mr. Lippens said Fortis had been approached by investment banks working for Allianz A.G., the owner of Vereinte, but not by Allianz itself.  A recent report in Der Spiegel, the German news magazine, that Fortis could pay up to 3.5 billion marks ($2.33 billion) for Vereinte was premature, he said. He declined to comment on a possible price.   Reuters

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico's Economy Shrinks, But Not as Fast as Before
abstract: The badly bruised Mexican economy continues to show mixed signals with a steady recovery belying a nagging underlying weakness.         Most private economists who follow Mexico were pleasantly surprised when the  Government released official figures today showing that the economy contracted by just one percentage point in the first quarter of 1996, compared with the period a year earlier.

headline: Soap and Substance for Arabic TV
abstract: Abdelwahab had it all. Almost. A poor shopkeeper who became one of Egypt's richest men, he lived in a grand apartment in posh Zamalek that was filled with  gilded furniture. He had a Mercedes, an adoring wife and four daughters. But the son whom he educated at Egypt's most expensive university was giving him no end  of trouble.         For a month, before a mesmerized television audience across the Arabic-speaking world, Abdelwahab Jr. fell in with company no upstanding Egyptian would tolerate. First he became an Islamic militant. Then he was pursued and caught by an American seductress.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wieden & Kennedy, Take a Bow
abstract: For the second time since 1992, Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., has been  named the National Agency of the Year by the trade publication Adweek.         Adweek, in its special annual Agency Report Card issue this week, praises Wieden & Kennedy's work for clients that market "three of the world's most powerful brands": the Coca-Cola Company, the Microsoft Corporation and Nike Inc.

headline: Francois Genoud, Nazi Sympathizer, 81
abstract: Francois Genoud, a Nazi sympathizer who became a banker for Arab militants and defender of terrorists, committed suicide by poison on Thursday with the help of a Swiss pro-euthanasia group, a family spokesman said. He was 81.         Mr. Genoud, who made a fortune from publishing the diaries of Josef Goebbels, the Nazi propaganda chief, helped set up the Arab commercial bank in Geneva in 1958. The bank was active in lending money to Arab nationalist groups and held the fighting fund of the Algerian independence movement.

headline: Croat Handed Over to War Tribunal
abstract: A Bosnian Croat who was commander of a prison camp was handed over to the Balkan war crimes tribunal today.         The man, Zdravko Mucic, is charged with responsibility for at least 14 murders, seven cases of torture and two rapes committed against Bosnian Serbs in 1992 by guards at the Celebici prison camp in central Bosnia. Three Bosnian Muslims also have been indicted in connection with the treatment of prisoners there.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ampolex of Australia Accepts Bid by Mobil
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that Ampolex Ltd. had accepted Mobil's increased offer of $1.78 billion (Australian), or $1.4 billion (United States),  to buy Ampolex. For months, Ampolex, an oil company, had been rejecting Mobil's  overtures, but it agreed to the latest bid, which represents a 20 percent increase. Ampolex said it would not seek other bids and would urge shareholders  to sell to Mobil.

headline: Tandem Computers to Create Machines With Microsoft
abstract: Tandem Computers Inc. and the Microsoft Corporation said today that they had  set up an alliance to create machines that will be made by Tandem and will run the Microsoft Windows NT operating system. The first of the systems is to be available this summer.         Though the companies will not formally announce the deal until Tuesday, the agreement was broadly anticipated. The shares of Tandem closed today at $14.125, up $1.125, while Microsoft shares closed at $111.75, up 87.5 cents, both in Nasdaq trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALUMAX SELLS MEXICAN MINING STAKE TO PARTNER
abstract: Alumax Inc., based in Norcross, Ga., agreed yesterday to sell its Mexican mining interests to its partner, Industrias Penoles S.A., for $160 million. Alumax, the No. 3 United States aluminum producer, said the mines primarily produce silver, gold, lead and zinc. The stake in the Mexican mines was transferred to Alumax when the company was spun off from Amax Inc. in November 1993 at the same time Amax merged with the Cyprus Minerals Company. Industrias Penoles is Mexico's biggest silver-mining company.

headline: Antitrust Suit Goes Against Big H.M.O.
abstract: U.S. Healthcare was ordered by a Federal jury yesterday to pay $1.2 million in damages to a smaller company that had accused the big health maintenance organization of violating antitrust laws by forcing retail pharmacies to buy employee coverage from it.         The jury, in its verdict in a civil lawsuit in Philadelphia, found that U.S.  Healthcare and three senior executives were liable under Federal antitrust and racketeering laws and a Pennsylvania law on contracts. The suit was brought by Brokerage Concepts Inc., a privately held insurance broker that also runs self-insured health plans.

headline: Gerry Adams, Ulster Pivot, Sees 'Best Bet' for Peace
abstract: Gerry Adams sat in a patch of sunlight in the tiny front yard of Connolly House, headquarters of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. The white stucco building on Andersonstown Road is caged by a double barrier of metal fence as a defense against attack, but on a recent relaxed Saturday afternoon the doors were left open so the breeze could blow in and "the lads" could wander in and out.         "How youse doin'?" Mr. Adams asked each of them, lapsing into the West Belfast accent he uses on his native streets, as solicitous as a ward heeler in  Chicago at election time.

headline: Yugoslav-Macedonia Ties
abstract: Yugoslavia established diplomatic ties today with its southern neighbor Macedonia, a long-awaited move that requires it to give up any territorial claim on the former Yugoslav republic.
