Yugoslavia, which consists of only Serbia and Montenegro, also agreed to exchange ambassadors in the accord signed by its Foreign Minister, Milan Milutinovic, and his Macedonian counterpart, Ljubomir Frckovski.

headline: Crash Prompts Pentagon To Install Safety Devices
abstract: The Secretary of Defense has ordered that new recording devices and safety equipment be installed on military aircraft that carry passengers, after investigators found no sign so far that major components failed on the plane that crashed in Croatia on April 3, killing Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others, a senior Air Force official said today.         The official said the crash, which killed all on board, occurred in weather good enough for a landing at the field and not at all unusual for the area. "The weather reported at the time was above minimums for this approach," said the official, who spoke at a Pentagon briefing on condition of anonymity.

headline: Ex-General's Voters Crucial to Yeltsin
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin had a big problem in Tula before he latched onto Aleksandr I. Lebed. People in that central Russian city -- even those who voted  for him -- dislike Mr. Yeltsin intensely, according to focus groups meeting there on Wednesday, the day after Mr. Lebed, the outspoken former general who came in a strong third in last week's presidential election, was named to the Cabinet.         They do not like Mr. Yeltsin's program and they are even more confused about  who should lead Russia into the next century than most of their fellow citizens, as last Sunday's vote suggests: Mr. Yeltsin received 31 percent of the local votes; Mr. Lebed, who represents Tula in parliament, received 29 percent and the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, got 25 percent.

headline: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: Russia;Where Pushkin Still Lives
abstract: Culturally haughty visitors who are sick of their own low standards love to sneer about the declining state of Russian literature -- and literacy. Yes, Sidney Sheldon and Stephen King are far more popular here than Pushkin or Dostoyevsky.          But books are sold by the wagonload on half this city's streets. They are affordable, plentiful and often very good. They are also sold, with increasing success, in the type of small, personal independent bookstores that in America are going the way of the dime novel.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP., New York, named Lee Fensterstock president and chief operating officer at its Gruntal & Co. securities brokerage subsidiary. Henry Gottmann was named executive vice president of retail and marketing. Stephen DiTursi was named executive vice president, capital markets, and Joanne Marren was named executive vice president and general counsel.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TOWER AUTOMOTIVE TO ACQUIRE A MASCOTECH UNIT
abstract: Tower Automotive Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire Mascotech Inc.'s Stamping Technologies Inc. unit for about $80 million, the companies said yesterday. Mascotech expects to receive about $55 million in cash and the remainder in stock and notes. The Mascotech unit, which is based in Rochester Hills, Mich., has annual sales of about $190 million. Tower Automotive, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., makes engineered metal stampings and assemblies for light vehicle manufacturers in North America. Mascotech is an affiliate of the Masco Corporation of Taylor, Mich.

headline: Hindu Party's Rising Election Hopes Trouble Many IndianTraditionalists
abstract: Like many Indian politicians, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, the man opinion polls say is favored for Prime Minister by more Indians than any other contender, runs chronically late for election rallies. So when he greeted a crowd that had waited three hours here in 105-degree heat, Mr. Vajpayee had a practiced excuse.         "If I were Prime Minister I would have a proper jet, not a turboprop," he said. The remark set off chants from loyalists of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the Hindu nationalist group that opinion polls have predicted will take the largest number of seats in the general election that ends with a third round of  voting on Tuesday.

headline: G.E. Unit Teams With Netscape in Business Services Venture
abstract: Hoping to make computer transactions a common way for companies to conduct business with one another, two leading Internet players, GE Information Services and Netscape Communications, said yesterday that they had formed a new software  company.         The new joint venture, Actra Business Systems, will focus on creating industry-standard, Internet-based applications that will allow businesses to exchange purchasing and supply forms, messages, orders and payments and electronic catalogues. Company officials said they hoped to deliver their first  new products within a year.

headline: Government Dexterity Eases Misery for Iraqis
abstract: All of a sudden, Bala Abdullah Khalil, a mother of seven, can afford to heap  rice on her children's plates in quantities she could not conceive of a few months ago.         Even meat and eggs are no longer out of the question; the Iraqi dinar is worth nearly five times what it was when the year began. And like the dinar itself, Mrs. Khalil's spirits have been buoyed by expectations that life in Iraq, a grim struggle after more than five years of United Nations sanctions, may soon get a little bit better.

headline: Advertising;Advertising agencies make a pitch to politicians and consultants, urging them to clean up their act.
abstract: IN an innovative initiative to reduce the personal attack and invective in political advertising, the nation's advertising agencies will urge broadcast and print media to assume watchdog duties during this year's election campaign season.         The initiative -- and one agency's effort to encourage voters to boycott candidates running attack ads -- was announced as the 78th annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies concluded Friday at the Renaissance Esmeralda Resort in this Southern California desert town. Both efforts are motivated by growing fear among agency executives that the product advertising they create for marketers is increasingly damaged by the growing public disdain  for negative political advertising -- even though most political advertising is  produced by political consultants rather than by Madison Avenue.

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN AMERICA;In Reactions, Jewish Groups Echo the Split Of the Results
abstract: Rabbi Avi Weiss, leader of the Coalition for Jewish Concerns and of the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale in the Bronx and a hawk on the issue of how to insure Israel's security, said yesterday that he was "absolutely ecstatic" over  the results of the Israeli election.         "It's only a Likud Government that will be able to secure this peace," Rabbi  Weiss said, anticipating a tougher negotiating approach.  But he said it is just as important that Likud's leader, Benjamin Netanyahu, reach out to those who opposed him and say, "I am the Prime Minister of all the people of Israel."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CASTLE HARLAN IN DEAL TO MERGE 2 MAKERS OF CLASS RINGS
abstract: Castle Harlan Inc., a New York-based commercial bank, agreed yesterday to acquire the class ring businesses of the Town and Country Corporation and CJC Holdings Inc. for about $180 million. The combined businesses, which include the Balfour and Art Carved lines, had combined revenue of about $155 million in 1995 and would be the second-largest United States maker of class rings. Town and Country, based in Chelsea, Mass., will have a minority equity interest in a new holding company to be called Class Rings Inc. Jostens Inc. has about a 45 percent share of the class ring market. Town and Country and CJC each have about 20 percent.

headline: U.S. Extends Deadline for Bosnia Pullout
abstract: The Defense Department said today that American and other peacekeeping troops would remain in Bosnia for at least a month after the original pullout deadline  of Dec. 20 -- a deadline once described by the Clinton Administration as absolutely unextendable.         The Pentagon's chief spokesman, Kenneth Bacon, said commanders of the American-led NATO peacekeeping troops wanted a significant number of American and other peacekeepers to remain in Bosnia right up to Dec. 20, the anniversary  of the arrival of the first peacekeepers.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Drops on Stockpile Rise; Gasoline Falls and Wheat Is Up
abstract: Copper prices tumbled yesterday as an unexpected rise in stockpiles indicated slowing demand from China and Europe, two major sources of global demand.         On other markets, gasoline prices fell while wheat rose.

headline: Colombian President May Be Cleared of Charges
abstract: Dismissing evidence in 3,200 files from Colombia's chief prosecutor, the chairman of the congressional committee investigating whether President Ernesto  Samper financed his electoral campaign with $6.1 million from Cali drug dealers  will reportedly recommend dropping all charges.         In a 66-page resolution, excerpts of which were reprinted today by the daily  El Tiempo, the chairman of the Accusations Committee, Heyne Mogollon, said that  since the money had been used to finance Mr. Samper's presidential campaign, there was no proof that his personal wealth had increased as a result of the donation.

headline: Innovations on Internet Deliver News and the Mail
abstract: Two companies plan to introduce technologies on Monday that demonstrate how rapidly the Internet is evolving and transforming the uses of traditional broadcasting and telecommunications services.         Jfax Communications Inc., a New York-based start-up company, plans to introduce a service that allows Internet users to receive fax and voice-mail messages at their electronic mail address anywhere in the world.

headline: Internet Monitors Can Aim at Workers
abstract: A software program intended to help network administrators spot anyone using  Internet resources to an unusual degree can also be used to monitor an employee's cyberspace activities.         Optimal Networks of Mountain View, Calif., plans to release a test version of its monitoring software that will track every World Wide Web site, news group or file-transfer location an employee visits, and record the size of each file downloaded. "We're giving employers something like an itemized phone bill," John Graham-Cumming of Optimal said. "The spinoff is that they can see what the employees are doing."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ASHANTI GOLDFIELDS TO ACQUIRE TORONTO MINING COMPANY
abstract: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, a gold mining concern in Ghana, agreed yesterday to buy the International Gold Resources Corporation of Toronto for about $100 million. International Gold is a gold mining company whose main asset is the right to acquire a 45 percent operating interest in the proposed Bibiani  mine in Ghana. Ashanti said its principal mining operation is near Obuasi, about 110 miles northwest of Accra, Ghana's capital. The site's gold reserves were about 20 million ounces at the end of 1995, Ashanti said.

headline: Real Estate;A warehouse nearly destroyed by fire is rising again as a luxury apartment building in TriBeCa.
abstract: NEARLY destroyed by fire in 1992, a six-story warehouse in TriBeCa sat charred and vacant for a year and a half. Now it and a smaller adjacent warehouse are being reborn as a luxury condominium.         When the conversion is completed this summer the warehouses at 31-33 and 35-37 North Moore Street will have 23 large residences, averaging 3,000 square feet and priced from $450,000 to nearly $2 million. But instead of the open lofts common to the area, most will have more traditional apartment layouts.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: World News Briefs;Taiwan Postpones War Games Off China
abstract: Under pressure from Washington and domestic critics, Taiwan said today that it would postpone for at least three months a live-fire military exercise on Matsu Island, the heavily fortified Taiwanese base that lies less than two miles off mainland China.         Beijing also cautioned Taiwan's leaders against re-igniting military tensions. China mounted three sets of threatening military exercises in the weeks before Taiwan's presidential election last month in hopes of diminishing support for President Lee Teng-hui. But voters instead gave the 73-year-old Taiwanese leader a strong mandate to negotiate with China over Taiwan's political status.

headline: World News Briefs;Belgian Colonel on Trial In Deaths of 10 Soldiers
abstract: A former commander of United Nations troops in Rwanda was court-martialed today, accused of negligence in the killings of 10 peacekeepers by Rwandan soldiers in 1994.         The commander, Col. Luc Marchal of Belgium, denies he placed the lightly armed peacekeepers in excessive danger when he ordered them to escort Prime Minister Agathe Uwilingiyimana, as violence swept Rwanda's capital Kigali in the early hours of April 7, 1994.

headline: 2 Take Top Honors At the Addy Awards
abstract: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., won the Best of Show awards last week at the 29th annual American Advertising Awards, sponsored by the American Advertising Federation in Washington.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
abstract: Frank Lalli, managing editor of Money magazine, New York, was named president of the American Society of Magazine Editors, New York, succeeding Ellen Levine, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, New York.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;High School Student Wins Ad Contest
abstract: An 18-year-old at a high school in Long Island City, Queens, has won a contest to create a 30-second public service announcement that will be offered to local television broadcast stations and cable channels.          The commercial was created by Evelyn Quesada, a senior at the Newcomer School, with the help of Macguffin Films Ltd. in New York, which co-sponsored the contest with the New York City Board of Education. Her spot, titled "A Newfound Home (A True Story)," was selected from more than 200 entries in the contest, which asked students to create commercials around the theme "My New York: I Live Here and I Love It." Her school won a $1,500 scholarship for art supplies and videomaking.

headline: Dow Surges to a 45.52 Gain, Easing Big Losses for Week
abstract: Stocks broke out of a weeklong slump to end sharply higher yesterday, as a rally in the bond market eased worries about higher interest rates.         The Dow Jones industrial average rose 45.52 points, to 5,532.59, and would have gained about 62 points if not for a big drop in one of its components, I.B.M.

headline: Cisco Agrees to Acquire Stratacom In a Stock Swap Worth $4 Billion
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Stratacom Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $4 billion. The deal will create a networking giant whose technologies and customer base will spread across many diverse market segments.         Although Cisco and Stratacom, which are based near each other in San Jose, Calif., are both networking companies, their product lines do not overlap and they have not been competitors. Cisco is best known for routers, a key piece of  hardware used in creating private local area networks, or LAN's, within corporations, while Stratacom makes switching equipment used to send computer data, voice and video between offices. The equipment is primarily sold to long-distance carriers, which use it to provide data transmission services.

headline: Bank Lobbying Blocks a Bill On S.& L.'s
abstract: After months of maneuvering, the nation's big commercial banks succeeded this week in blocking legislation -- supported by both the Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership -- that would have forced them to pay a big share of the cleanup bill from the savings and loan crisis.         In a display of raw lobbying power, the American Bankers Association and individual banks from around the country won support from a handful of key Democratic and Republican House members who defied their parties to derail the measure, which would have cost banks $12 billion over two decades.

headline: Jordan's King Says Election Won't Derail Peace Effort
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan said today that Arab alarm over the change of government in Israel had been overwrought and he expressed confidence that Benjamin Netanyahu's election would not undermine the quest for peace in the Middle East.         The King sounded far more upbeat than other Arab officials who have spoken out since the election on Wednesday, and his remarks appeared to reflect the deep commitment he has shown to partnership with Israel since the two countries  signed a peace accord two years ago.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WOOLWORTH TO SELL CHAIN OF LADY PLUS STORES
abstract: The Woolworth Corporation said it will sell the Lady Plus chain of women's large-size clothing stores to Popken Classics G.m.b.H. and Company as part of a  plan to streamline its operations. Terms of the sale, expected to be completed by Aug. 1, were not disclosed. The 34-store chain is run by Woolworth's Retail Company of Germany subsidiary. Woolworth plans to focus on general merchandise stores in Germany. New York-based Woolworth is a general merchandise retailer, operating more than 8,200 stores worldwide including Foot Locker, Northern Reflections, After Thoughts and Champs Sports. Woolworth stock rose 25 cents to  close at $22.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ABB Posts 19% Rise In First-Quarter Profit
abstract: Asea Brown Boveri said yesterday that its profit rose 19 percent in the first quarter, to $219 million, compared with $184 million in the first quarter of 1995. ABB, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company whose products include industrial robots and power stations, said it expected cost-cutting and "good growth" in emerging markets to continue to have a positive impact on earnings this year, even as overall order growth slows.         First-quarter sales rose 7 percent from a year earlier, to $7.44 billion from $6.93 billion. Excluding the transportation activities for both years, sales rose 14 percent, ABB said. ABB last year formed a rail joint venture with Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany, a move that led to a $250 million one-time gain.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: New Blood for the Big Three's Plants
abstract: JUST over a year ago, Tammy M. Nedzweckas quit her $10,000-a-year job as a restaurant cook and started working the night shift at a Ford Motor Company plant here, earning $31,000 a year. Every minute and 15 seconds, she twists an air-conditioning valve cap on a Bronco or a pickup, slams the hood shut and clambers up behind the wheel to drive the truck around the corner. Then she hurries back on foot to tighten the next cap.         Almost overnight, Ms. Nedzweckas (pronounced nez-WES-cus) escaped the clutch  of poverty-level wages and grabbed a piece of the American Dream: a better life  for her two children. "I can afford to have my own house -- I can afford to have a reliable car," she exults. When her daughter was born last year, she collected five months of paid maternity leave.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hoechst Earnings Flat Before Special Gains
abstract: Hoechst A.G., the German chemical company, said yesterday that its profit would have been flat in the first quarter if not for extraordinary gains from sales of assets. Those gains pushed pretax profit up 27 percent. Hoechst earned  1.25 billion marks ($822 million) before taxes, up from 984 million marks a year earlier. Sales were unchanged at 13 billion marks ($8.55 billion).   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUNGARD TO BUY A UNIT OF NATIONAL COMPUTER
abstract: Sungard Data Systems Inc., a computer services company, has a definitive agreement to buy the Financial Systems business of National Computer Systems Inc. for $95 million in cash, the companies said yesterday. Financial Systems provides software and services for bank asset management. It had revenues of $58.1 million for the year ended Jan. 31. The Minneapolis-based National Computer provides trust accounting and corporate trust systems to banks and other financial institutions. It has about 350 employees. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Sungard rose $1.25, to $37.75, and shares of National Computer rose $1.25, to $24.25.

headline: Computer Theft
abstract: To the Editor:         "Leaping Laptops! As Computers Shrink, Thefts Grow" (Spending It, March 24) illustrated the well-known phenomenon that burglars and thieves go where the money is.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Disney Talking To McDonald's About Alliance For Promotions
abstract: The Walt Disney Company and the McDonald's Corporation, two of the defining forces in American culture, are negotiating exclusive arrangements to cross-promote their products well into the next century, a Disney executive said today.         Speaking on condition of anonymity, the executive confirmed a trade report today that the two companies were working on a 10-year deal that would allow McDonald's to run as many as 17 promotions a year linked to Disney films, characters and theme parks.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Jump In Light Day
abstract: Treasury prices rose sharply yesterday, but light trading exaggerated the gains.         With a lack of fresh economic data, the impetus for buying yesterday came from the Treasury's announcement outlining next week's auctions of new two-year  and five-year notes. The size of the auctions will be much smaller than what many traders had been expecting, and the announcement helped ease concerns about the market's ability to absorb new supply.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir Reports Its Deficit Narrowed From '95 Quarter
abstract: USAir Group Inc. reported today that its first-quarter loss was considerably  smaller than in the comparable 1995 quarter, even though a harsh winter reduced  airline travel and revenue in January and February.         The airline said it lost $32.3 million in the latest quarter, compared with a loss of $117.5 million a year earlier. On a per-share basis the net loss to common shareholders was cut more than half, to 86 cents, from $1.91 a year earlier. The per-share loss in the latest quarter included a $22.3 million allowance for preferred stock dividends, which it said in January that it would  not pay this quarter.

headline: Surge in Jobs Stirs Fears of an Increase In Interest Rates : Don't Brake Economy, Clinton Tells Central Bank
abstract: NEW YORK—  The U.S. economy created double the number of jobs in May that was forecast, prompting President Bill Clinton to appeal to the Federal Reserve Board not to raise interest rates and kill the nation's economic expansion in an election year.

headline: A.A.R.P. Will License Its Name To Managed Health Care Plans
abstract: In a move that could prompt millions of older Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health maintenance organizations across the country later this year.         The 33-million-member association, best known as a lobbying group for the elderly, is already a big player in the insurance business, endorsing selected auto and homeowners policies, and insurance that pays medical bills not covered  by Medicare. In return, it receives substantial revenue from royalties and related income -- $146 million in 1994, which provided 38 percent of its budget.

headline: Smart Phone' Makers Seek Cheaper and Easier Way to Reach the Internet
abstract: Despite the considerable attention being paid to the development of the network computer, the gateway to the Internet may not be a $500 PC but a $250 telephone -- or both.         In recent months, several of the nation's telephone manufacturers have announced plans to market sophisticated screen phones that will let consumers perform a variety of sales transactions like banking or bill-paying, receive documents over the Internet and grab bits of information from Web sites or other information services.

headline: Cablevision Acquisitions
abstract: Cablevision Systems has agreed to acquire cable television holdings from Warburg Pincus Investors L.P. for $183 million. Cablevision is buying the interests it does not already own in A-R Cable Services Inc., which operates in  New York, Massachusetts, Arkansas, Missouri and Rockford, Ill.; in A-R Cable Partners, which operates in Massachusetts; in Cablevision of Newark, and in Cablevision of Framingham Holdings, in Massachusetts.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon's Earnings Soared In First-Quarter Rebound
abstract: Salomon Inc., recovering from a difficult 1995, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings more than tripled, to $276 million, from $81 million in the first quarter of last year, thanks to robust securities trading and investment banking revenues.         Salomon, the parent of one of the largest United States securities firms, Salomon Brothers, and of Phibro, a commodity trading company, reported earnings  of $2.44 a share, far exceeding both analysts' expectations for about $1 a share, as well as the 59 cents a share it reported for last year's first quarter. In the fourth quarter of 1995, Salomon reported net income of $168 million, or $1.32 a share.

headline: Peres and Arafat, After Talks, Agree to Revive Peace Efforts
abstract: Under the shadow of the fighting in Lebanon, Prime Minister Shimon Peres and  the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat agreed today to revive their peace efforts,  which had been suspended after a spate of suicide bombings in Israel by Palestinian militants.         The two leaders, in their first meeting since the bombings, held talks at the Erez checkpoint on the northern edge of the Gaza Strip. They emerged after two hours to announce that they would move forward with the agreements on Palestinian self-rule signed by Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in 1993 and last September.

headline: New Corestates President Plans to Resign
abstract: The Corestates Financial Corporation said yesterday that Samuel A. McCullough, who became its president yesterday, would step down on June 30th, after less than two months on the job. Mr. McCullough had been the chairman of the Meridian Bancorp of Reading, Pa., which Philadelphia-based Corestates agreed to buy in October for $3.1 billion, a deal that was closed yesterday.         The merger agreement specified that Mr. McCullough would take the No. 2 spot  at Corestates, but Mr. McCullough, 57, said yesterday that he chose to vacate the presidency in favor of a one-year consulting contract because he could not reach a satisfactory division of duties with Terrence A. Larsen, the chairman of Corestates.

headline: Rockwell Agrees to Pay Fine Of $6.5 Million in Explosion
abstract: The Rockwell International Corporation agreed today to pay a $6.5 million fine in connection with an explosion that killed two men at its rocket engine subsidiary.         As part of the settlement, which must be approved by a Federal judge, the company pleaded guilty to three counts of improper storage and disposal of a hazardous material.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JOINT VENTURE FOR MALAYSIAN PETROCHEMICAL COMPLEX
abstract: The Union Carbide Corporation of Danbury, Conn., and Petronas, Malaysia's state-owned oil company, said yesterday that they would form a joint venture to  build a Malaysian petrochemical complex to supply Southeast Asia, the world's fastest-growing market for petrochemicals. The companies did not say how much the project would cost. The joint venture is expected to be held equally by the  two partners. The partners plan to build an ethylene and propylene plant that will make 600,000 metric tons a year. A second plant will be built to make at least 500,000 metric tons a year of ethylene glycol, an ingredient used in polyester fibers and automotive antifreeze.

headline: Rockefeller Center Plan
abstract: A Federal Bankruptcy Court gave final approval yesterday to the Chapter 11 reorganization plan of the two partnerships that own the Rockefeller Center complex. The approval clears the way for the two partnerships, which are controlled by the Mitsubishi Estate Company, to transfer ownership to Rockefeller Center Properties Inc., which is its largest creditor. In turn, an investment group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company is set to acquire the complex by paying about $306 million, or $8 a share, to buy out shareholders of Rockefeller Center Properties, which holds a $1.3 billion mortgage.

headline: Warnaco Chief: $10 Million Pay
abstract: Linda Wachner, the top executive of the Warnaco Group, the apparel maker, was paid about $10 million last year in cash and stock. And she was given stock options that could be worth an additional $10.3 million, assuming the stock appreciates 5 percent annually over the next nine years, the company said yesterday.         Warnaco, which is based in New York, said it had paid Ms. Wachner a salary of $2.4 million, a bonus of $1.3 million, other annual compensation of $361,805, a  restricted stock award the company valued at $6 million and on top of that, options to buy one million shares of Warnaco stock.

headline: Indiana Approves A Floating Casino
abstract: Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts Inc. said yesterday that it had won approval  from Indiana authorities to operate a floating casino on Lake Michigan.         The 290-foot boat, to be anchored at Buffington Harbor, Ind., near Chicago, will be the first casino operated by Donald J. Trump outside of Atlantic City.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Rise On Treasury Securities
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, bolstered by reports that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation.         One report, on leading economic indicators, showed a gain that was stronger than expected. But the market viewed the improvements as recoveries from sharp weather-related setbacks and not indicative of a trend that could keep the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates in the coming months. Bond prices were also supported by a weekly survey of retail sales that showed weakness and by a firm dollar.

headline: U.S. Helps to Start Negotiations To End the Fighting in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli planes and artillery hammered Lebanon for the fifth day today, but Israeli and American officials said intensive contacts had begun in an effort to end the fighting, possibly by week's end.         A White House spokesman said Secretary of State Warren Christopher, en route  to East Asia, opened a round of extensive talks today with Syrian, Lebanese and  Israeli officials. At the same time, Israeli radio reported that the Iranian Foreign Minister would visit Syria and Lebanon within the next two days.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Nickelodeon Programming Planned for Latin America
abstract: Nickelodeon, the top-rated basic cable network in the United States, announced yesterday that it will expand into Latin America this fall, making its children's programming available in both Spanish and Portuguese.         The 24-hour Latin American Nickelodeon channel, to be based in Miami, will transmit its programs using both cable and satellite, according to a statement.

headline: Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, A Vatican II Leader, Dies at 91
abstract: Leo Joseph Cardinal Suenens, whose public and behind-the-scenes leadership at the Second Vatican Council made him a major architect of 20th-century Roman Catholicism, died yesterday in Brussels. He was 91.         Active to his last day, the retired Archbishop of Mechelen-Brussels and Primate of Belgium was planning to attend a symposium in his honor at John Carroll University in Cleveland at the end of this month.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP TO BUY BANK UNIT OF COLE TAYLOR
abstract: Cole Taylor Financial Group Inc., a financial holding company based in Wheeling, Ill., a Chicago suburb, has agreed to split off its Cole Taylor Bank subsidiary to an investment group headed by the company's chairman, Jeffrey W. Taylor. Under the agreement, the holding company will get 4 million to 4.5 million shares of Cole Taylor Financial stock from the investor group. Besides the stock, the holding company will receive cash and receivables ranging from about $82 million to about $98 million.

headline: A Bit Late, Official Quits Post in Ottawa To Protest Tax
abstract: In a setback for Canada's two-and-a-half-year-old Liberal Government, the Deputy Prime Minister resigned today over its failure to abolish a detested 7 percent tax imposed by the previous, Conservative administration.         Repealing the levy, the goods and services tax, was a Liberal commitment during the election campaign in the fall of 1993, but has proved impossible to carry out because the Government critically needs the $18 billion the tax generates each year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CALIFORNIA FINANCIAL REJECTS FIRST NATIONWIDE OFFER
abstract: The California Financial Holding Company said yesterday that it had rejected  a $24-a-share takeover offer from First Nationwide Bank in December. California  Financial, which operates Stockton Savings Bank, said its board had responded that "it is the longstanding policy of the company to remain independent." California Financial, based in Stockton, Calif., said it issued the statement in response to a Business Week article about First Nationwide's interest. California Financial's stock rose 50 cents to close at $21.50.

headline: SPENDING IT;Accounts That Give Piggy Banks a Run for the Money
abstract: WHEN Alana Miller was 11, she decided that if she wanted to go to college, she had to start saving her baby-sitting money and weekly allowance.         A neighbor in Massillon, Ohio, told her that a Key Bank branch in nearby Canton had a program geared for children. Youngsters who opened and maintained an account could earn model dinosaurs and recognition in a national newsletter mailed to other "Dinosavers."

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Settle Higher Despite Speculation on Iraq Deal
abstract: Crude oil prices settled higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, after plunging early in the day, as traders bet that stockpiles are so low that even a limited oil sale by Iraq would be absorbed by the world market.         On other markets, corn prices also rebounded from an early dip, and coffee rose.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Loss in '95 Was Double That of '94
abstract: Eurotunnel, the British-French company that operates the tunnel under the English Channel, reported yesterday that its losses had more than doubled in 1995. The performance was worse than experts had predicted. Eurotunnel's British co-chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, said business was picking up for the company,  which went into default on bank interest payments last year.          The loss soared to L925 million, ($1.44 billion), in 1995, from L387 million in 1994. The widened loss came even as revenue surged to L299 million ($464 million), from L30.6 million. Sir Alastair predicted that the operating results  of the tunnel, which are now covering daily operational costs, should help it in negotiations with bankers.   (AP)

headline: Rivals of American and British Air Quickly Assail New Alliance asAnticompetitive
abstract: American Airlines and British Airways formally announced their plans yesterday for a broad marketing alliance, setting off sharp criticism from competitors and raising questions about the likelihood of their partnership winning approval from Government regulators in both countries. In addition, their announcement left unanswered the question of what would become of British Airways' current marketing link with USAir, which would be eclipsed by the new alliance with American.

headline: Rebuffed, Western Resources Tries Again
abstract: Western Resources Inc. sweetened its bid for the Kansas City Power and Light  Company by about 11 percent yesterday in an attempt to force Kansas City Power's board to reconsider its agreement to merge with Utilicorp United Inc.         Some analysts said the move could force the board of Kansas City Power to begin talks with Western Resources -- a large utility based in Topeka, Kan., whose first bid in April was quickly rejected.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES FALL AFTER OAK TECHNOLOGY ISSUES A WARNING
abstract: The shares of Oak Technology Inc. fell 24 percent yesterday after the company, a multimedia computer chip maker, said late on Wednesday that it expected fourth-quarter results to be significantly lower than expected. The shares fell $4, to $12.50, in Nasdaq trading of 9.6 million shares. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it expected a loss of 4 cents to 8 cents a share on revenues of $20 million to $25 million in the quarter ending on June 30. In last year's fourth quarter, the company earned $9.3 million, or 47 cents  a share, on revenues of $42.5 million. Oak Technology said shipments of its CD-ROM controller chip were unexpectedly low.

headline: Books on Tape Inc. Carves Out Quiet Niche Among Big Publishing Houses
abstract: In 1975, when a former Olympic rower named Duvall Y. Hecht founded Books on Tape Inc., his plan to market audiocassettes containing complete spoken-word versions of printed books was considered foolhardy, even eccentric.         By the mid-1980's, when publishers like Random House, a unit of Advance Publications, and Simon & Schuster began pushing "audio books," or condensed versions of best sellers and self-help books, the most important part of Mr. Hecht's business strategy -- offering unabridged recordings of a wide variety of books -- was rejected by these publishing giants as impractical.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iraq and U.N. Meet On Issue of Oil Sales
abstract: Iraqi and United Nations negotiators met for two hours today at the start of  the third round of talks to determine whether Baghdad will be allowed to sell oil to buy food and medicine.         As the talks began, the Iraqi negotiator, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, said that the "gap was not that large" and that the differences between the two sides had been "exaggerated."

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Nasdaq Weighs Tighter Rules For Listing Small Stocks
abstract: The Nasdaq stock market, under fire for trading some low-quality companies, said yesterday that it would "undertake a thorough review" of how its listing standards for small stocks should be tightened.         Joseph R. Hardiman, the president of the National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent organization of the Nasdaq market, ordered the review, focusing in particular on the standards needed for a company to retain a listing on the market, a Nasdaq spokesman said.

headline: Mortgage Rates Fall
abstract: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.95 percent this week, down from 8.05 percent last week, according to a national survey issued today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.75 percent, down from 5.8 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.48 percent this week, down from 7.56 percent a week earlier.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
abstract: Barbara Carr, president of Carr & Associates, New York, and Lee Nadler of the Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation, New York, were awarded the Crystal Prism Award by the Advertising Club of New York, which also awarded the  American Advertising Federation Silver Medal to Burt Manning, chairman and chief executive of J. Walter Thompson Co., New York, a unit of the WPP Group.

headline: SPENDING IT;Compensation and the I.R.S.: It's Not the 'Good' Old Days
abstract: For those who grumble about high taxes and hark back to "the good old days,"  remember: it used to be worse, at least for the very rich. In fact, 55 years ago, the top marginal rate was 81 percent, nearly double today's top effective tax rate of 39.6 percent at the Federal level.          Because of a query from President Franklin D. Roosevelt, we know a great deal about the top taxpayers back then. In 1943, he asked the Internal Revenue Service to find out how many people earned more than $67,000. The I.R.S. reported that 2,090 people fit the bill in 1941 and put together a list.

headline: In a Sign of Changing Times, Shanghai Shelters Battered Women
abstract: In a country where family problems have traditionally remained behind closed  doors, wife-beating has often been endured without relief or outside interference.         But untold side effects from China's deep economic and social change are bubbling up everywhere. The upside is Shanghai has opened its first shelter for  battered women; the downside is that there appears to be a growing need for such a place.

headline: World News Briefs;Chinese Province Bans Tests for Sex of Fetus
abstract: Fujian province has banned medical tests specifically to identify the sex of  unborn babies after surveys have indicated that large numbers of females are being aborted, the Xinhua news agency reported today.          The agency said that the new law would deny official permission to give birth for five years to women who have aborted a fetus after a sex identification test. China's population control policy, which leaders in Beijing have had difficulty enforcing, allows couples to have only one child.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nigerians Protest Death Of Top Dissident's Wife
abstract: Thousands of university students marched today through a western Nigerian city to protest the fatal shooting of a wife of Moshood K. Abiola, the jailed opposition leader.         The police broke up the demonstration, which began at the University of Ibadan in the city of the same name about 70 miles north of Lagos. Students met  at the university gates and marched to the main marketplace, where merchants joined them.

headline: Media: PRESS;In Canada, concerns about consolidation.
abstract: IN his 1993 memoir "A Life in Progress," the publisher Conrad M. Black describes his efforts to clean up a local lake when he was the co-proprietor of  his first weekly newspaper east of Montreal.         "Like Orson Welles in 'Citizen Kane' saying, 'People will think what I tell them to think,' " he wrote, "I launched a violent campaign against the 'mismanagers of the dying lake.' " The lake was cleaned up.

headline: Correction
abstract: An article last Sunday about problems in celebrity foundations referred incorrectly to the American Institute of Philanthropy. It evaluates nonprofit organizations' financial management; it is not a trade group.

headline: Corrections
abstract: A chart last Sunday with an article about tax-law enforcement misstated the source of a list of the 10 American taxpayers with the highest salaries in 1941. It was the National Archives, not the Internal Revenue Service. Another chart, describing the Federal income tax form for 1913, misstated the tax treatment of  home mortgage interest that year. Home mortgage interest, though not identified  specifically on the form, was deductible, as were all types of loan interest at  the time.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hitachi Plans to Spend $112 Million on Plant
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. said yesterday that it would invest 12 billion yen, or about $112 million, to build a silicon wafer plant in Japan. The plant will make epitaxial wafers, used to make more powerful semiconductors, Hitachi said. The plant, expected to begin full production in 1999, will be in the Ibaraki prefecture north of Tokyo.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Talks With Varity On Track, Lucas Says
abstract: Lucas Industries said yesterday that its negotiations aimed at a merger with  the Varity Corporation of Buffalo were proceeding well, though an announcement might not come until early June at the earliest. The two makers of auto parts are discussing a $4.6 billion stock swap, analysts say. They confirmed on May 6  that they were discussing a "strategic combination" of their businesses, although Lucas later ruled out a cash bid from Varity.          A merger of the brake businesses would give the companies global reach. Varity's Kelsey-Hayes brake business is among the largest in North America. Lucas is the world's largest maker of diesel-fuel injection systems and disk brakes.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcy Seems Near For German Shipbuilder
abstract: The financially troubled German shipbuilder Bremer Vulkan Verbund A.G. said yesterday that it had been unable to negotiate a settlement with its creditors on a rescue plan. There now appears to be no way to save the company from bankruptcy. A judge said he would decide soon whether to begin bankruptcy proceedings.          The company lost about 1 billion marks ($684 million) in 1995 and declared itself insolvent in February. It was placed under court protection, and a court-appointed administrator tried unsuccessfully to mediate a solution with creditors. If the company is declared bankrupt by the court, its creditors will  probably retrieve only 2 percent to 5 percent of their investments.   (AP)

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stock prices were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 204.88 points, or 0.95 percent, at 21,865.35. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 33.96 points.

headline: Hilton Is Said To Be Near Deal for Bally
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation is close to an agreement to acquire the Bally Entertainment Corporation in a stock-swap deal that would value Bally at $28 a share, according to a person familiar with the talks.         Under the proposal, Bally shareholders would receive stock in Hilton, which is also expected to assume about $1 billion of Bally's debt. The deal, which was still under discussion last night, would be worth more than $2.5 billion.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER TWO BIDS, EFFORT TO BUY SCITEX IS WITHDRAWN
abstract: Davidi Gilo, a high-technology entrepreneur who made a $1 billion offer for the Scitex Corporation, said yesterday that he had withdrawn the bid because directors of the company, an Israeli maker of computer-imaging systems, refused  to negotiate. Mr. Gilo, the chairman of DSP Communications Inc., a chip maker, offered in March to buy Scitex for $20 a share, or $856 million. He raised the bid in April to $25 a share. Mr. Gilo said that board members of Scitex had bought more than one million Scitex shares since his offer in an effort to "thwart our proposal." He said he remained open to discussions. Scitex officials were not immediately available for comment. Scitex shares fell 50 cents, to $17.375, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: T. Rowe Price Closes Fund to New Investors
abstract: T. Rowe Price Associates Inc. is taking steps to prevent new investors from buying shares of one of the company's most popular mutual funds because it is getting too big.         The company, which is based in Baltimore, said it planned to close its $4.1 billion New Horizons Fund to new investors on June 18 for an indefinite period.  The fund plans to continue to accept investments from existing holders.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ROCHE TO BUY P.& G.'S SHARE OF JOINT VENTURE
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that Roche Holding of Switzerland would buy its half of the their United States joint pharmaceutical venture. The  deal would give Roche worldwide rights to the pain reliever Aleve and to Femstat 3, a vaginal yeast-infection treatment, both of which P.& G. marketed in the joint venture and would continue to sell in the United States for up to a year.  While the terms of the sale were not disclosed, P.& G. said it would record an after-tax gain of $120 million from the transaction in the fourth quarter. The company, based in Cincinnati, entered into the joint venture in 1988 with Syntex Laboratories, which Roche bought in 1994. Shares of P.& G. fell $2.25 yesterday, to $91.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;It's Time to Set the Table
abstract: DESPITE public pronouncements to the contrary, the Clinton Administration could be forced to limit or halt United States grain exports this year or next.         Let's look at the forecasts: Sparks Commodities, one of the most influential  crop-forecasting firms, has projected that United States corn stocks will fall to their lowest levels in 60 years. Feedstuffs magazine has speculated that the  United States may even run out of corn in September, a possibility that it called horrific. Analysts envision a grain export embargo if only 300 million bushels of corn stocks, instead of the usual billion or more, are left before the next crop is harvested in the fall. If those stocks fall below this level and the Government does not restrict exports, livestock may starve.

headline: Yeltsin's Good Week: He's Back in Race
abstract: It has been a long time since President Boris N. Yeltsin has had a week this  good. He started it last Sunday by announcing a peace plan for Chechnya and he ended it late this afternoon, telling 2,000 core supporters, "We will win in June so that Russia can never be called an evil empire again."         In between, he set off with a fistful of promises to Communist-dominated southern Russia and watched with delight as his once anemic ratings in opinion polls edged within striking distance of his main opponent in the presidential race, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist leader.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MCI AND INTEL TEAM UP TO SELL WEB PRODUCTS
abstract: The MCI Communications Corporation and the Intel Corporation teamed up yesterday to sell a combination of products and services that are aimed at helping businesses publish information on the World Wide Web. MCI planned to market the product, called NetworkMCI Webmaker, to small and medium-sized businesses. At a starting price of about $10,000, businesses could purchase preconfigured computers, based on Intel's Pentium Pro chip, and software to establish a secure Internet presence. MCI and Intel hope to save companies the trouble of assembling various communications links, computers and other products themselves.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC ENVIRONMENTAL TO SELL A MAJORITY STAKE
abstract: Republic Environmental Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a majority stake to the Alliance Holding Corporation, which is to contribute its Century Surety Group in exchange for 7.5 million new Republic common shares and  options to buy 2.1 million more. Republic's chief executive, Michael G. DeGroote, and H. Wayne Huizenga will each invest $5.25 million, receiving one million newly issued common shares apiece and options to buy up to three million more. Republic, a waste cleanup company in Blue Bell, Pa., said it would move its headquarters to Cleveland, where Century is based. Alliance Holding is  controlled by a group that includes Joseph E. LoConti, a director of Republic. Mr. Huizenga, chief executive of Republic Industries, does not currently have a  stake in Republic Environmental, which was spun off by Republic Industries last  year. Republic Environmental shares rose $5.375 yesterday, to $10, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: World News Briefs;Chechnya Opens Inquiry Into Copter Attack
abstract: Prosecutors in the Kremlin-installed Chechen government began an investigation today into a helicopter attack on the outdoor market of a major Chechen town.         Helicopters fired rockets into Urus-Martan on Tuesday, killing 5 people and wounding 21, Government officials said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NEW WORLD COMMUNICATIONS TO SELL 2 STATIONS
abstract: NBC agreed yesterday to acquire two television stations, in San Diego and in  Birmingham, Ala., from New World Communications Group Inc. for $425 million. NBC, which is owned by the General Electric Company, will buy KNSD in San Diego  and WVTM in Birmingham, both of which are NBC network affiliates. In addition to the $425 million, NBC will provide an undisclosed amount of working capital. After the sale, New World, which is based in Atlanta, will operate 10 television stations, all of which will be affiliated with the News Corporation's Fox network. New World expects pretax earnings of about $225 million from the sale. Its shares rose 68.75 cents yesterday, to $17.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: U.S. Report Says Bosnia Peace Is Fragile
abstract: A draft intelligence report circulating in the Government warns that the chances are poor that Bosnia will hold together as the multi-ethnic, unified state called for in the Dayton peace agreement, senior American officials say.         The National Intelligence Estimate -- a classified effort to pull together a  consensus view of the American intelligence agencies -- questions the public position of the Administration that the civilian effort in Bosnia and Herzegovina is on schedule and going well.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Trade Surplus Off 25% in Latest Year
abstract: Japan's trade surplus tumbled by nearly a quarter in the last year, the Government said yesterday, providing further evidence that Japan's export-driven economy is undergoing a change. The Finance Ministry said the surplus in the current account fell 23.8 percent, to 9.46 trillion yen ($90 billion) in the year that ended on March 31, down for the third consecutive year.          The figure, a measure of trade in both goods and services, was below the official forecast of a 10 trillion yen ($95.2 billion) surplus. The Government has predicted that the surplus will be 9.7 trillion yen ($92.3 billion) this fiscal year.   (Reuters)

headline: Thorn EMI Says Profit Climbed 27% in Year
abstract: Thorn EMI P.L.C., the British music recording and consumer-rentals company that is set to break up in August, said yesterday that its pretax profit in the year ended March 31 rose 27 percent, largely on gains from its EMI Music recording unit. Pretax profit at the London-based company, which owns the Virgin and Capitol record labels, jumped to $:539.1 million ($827.5 million) before one-time items, compared with $:423.6 million a year earlier.

headline: World News Briefs;Slovakia Leader Vetoes Measure to Ban Rallies
abstract: Under pressure from the United States and the European Union, Slovakia's President vetoed legislation today that critics say would limit free speech and  public assemblies.         The legislation, approved by Parliament two weeks ago, bans rallies deemed to subvert the country's constitutional system, territorial integrity or defenses.

headline: Signs Emerge Of China Deal On Sanctions
abstract: China invited United States trade officials today to fly to Beijing immediately as new signs emerged that a last-minute Government crackdown on factories pirating American software, music and videos might persuade Washington not to impose $2 billion in sanctions on Chinese imports.         The acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said she  planned to leave for Beijing on Thursday. Still, she met this afternoon with China's Ambassador to Washington, Li Daoyu, telling him that "while plenty of progress has been made, it is insufficient," according to American officials familiar with the discussion.

headline: Spanish Leader Wins Support Needed for Majority
abstract: The conservative Popular Party announced a long-sought agreement tonight with a coalition of Catalan nationalists, paving the way for the party's leader, Jose Maria Aznar, to become Spain's next Prime Minister.         In last month's general elections, the Popular Party fell 20 seats short of a majority in Parliament.

headline: Glitz Isn't Everything, as a U.K. Film Studio Boss Can Verify
abstract: SHEPPERTON, England—  Running a movie studio just ain't what it used to be.

headline: U.S. MILITARY ROLE IN EAST ASIA GETS SUPPORT IN TOKYO
abstract: Defying anti-American sentiment fanned by the rape of an Okinawa girl by American servicemen last fall, President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan today reaffirmed the United States' military presence in the  Far East as "essential for preserving peace and stability" in the region.         In a joint declaration signed by Mr. Clinton and Mr. Hashimoto at a midday ceremony, the two leaders proclaimed that the security relationship between America and Japan "remains the cornerstone for achieving common security objectives and maintaining a stable and prosperous environment" in Asia.

headline: World News Briefs;Zulu Princess Found Stabbed to Death
abstract: A Zulu princess believed to have been abducted during an attack on a royal residence this week has been found stabbed to death, the police said today.         The body of the princess, No- nhlanhla Zulu, 35, was discovered Friday on a soccer field in a workers' residential compound controlled by the Zulu nationalist Inkatha Freedom Party, a police spokesman said.

headline: Liberian Ship Visits Ghana After Mutiny By Refugees
abstract: After reports that desperate refugees fleeing Liberia's civil war aboard a freighter that had been refused entry to several West African countries had rioted and overwhelmed the ship's captain, Ghanaian officials agreed today to allow the ship to dock.         The uprising, apparently by passengers trying to force the captain to land, occurred off the Ghanaian coast near the town of Axim. There, the Norwegian freighter, the Bulk Challenge, had been moored for more than 24 hours awaiting approval from a West African government to unload its 3,500 or more refugees.

headline: Contract Is Expiring for 350 at CBS News
abstract: The first labor negotiation at CBS News since the Westinghouse Electric Company bought CBS Inc. earlier this year reaches a pivotal moment tonight at midnight, when the company's contract with the Writers Guild of America at CBS's three biggest television and radio stations expires. The union's members have voted to authorize a strike.         The contract covers about 350 people at WCBS in New York, KCBS in Los Angeles, WBBM in Chicago, as well as the CBS all-news radio stations in each city and the CBS radio network and a 12-member Washington news bureau. The employees are news writers, editors, some producers, graphic artists, desk assistants and promotion writers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PARSONS NAMES A NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: The Parsons Corporation named James F. McNulty as chief executive, succeeding Leonard J. Pieroni, 57, who died last week in the plance crash in Croatia with Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown. Mr. McNulty, who is 53, will also become a director. He joined the corporation in 1988 and has held several senior-level positions, most recently as president of Parsons Infrastructure & Technology Group Inc., one of four global business units of the company, an engineering and construction group based in Pasadena, Calif.

headline: Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Against Moody's Service
abstract: Moody's Investors Service, the bond-rating agency, received some good news yesterday when a Federal judge threw out a lawsuit over its unsolicited rating of bonds that a Colorado school district sold in 1993.         But the decision in the Federal District Court in Denver did not address the  school district's recent contention that Moody's violated Federal antitrust laws. The Justice Department's antitrust division is investigating whether Moody's, in effect, threatened bond issuers with unwanted ratings to insure the  issuers hired the agency.

headline: Tough or Lenient? It's a Question of Risk
abstract: WHERE companies stand on how the Government should deal with China -- whether to impose sanctions for pirating software and music, whether to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status -- is usually a direct function of how much they have at risk.         On sanctions, those urging the most conciliatory approach have the most to lose if China lashes out because of American pressure. Among them are the National Retail Federation. Its members -- Sears, Kmart and Toys "R" Us among them -- went to Washington last week to denounce the 100 percent tariffs that will be slapped on a range of made-in-China clothing if sanctions are invoked later this month. The federation has denounced the sanctions as "illegal" and "disastrous for consumers."

headline: G.E. Seen in Talks To Purchase Space In Rockefeller Center
abstract: The General Electric Corporation is in talks with an investment group led by  Goldman, Sachs & Company to buy the 1.3 million square feet of space that G.E. leases in Rockefeller Center, people familiar with the discussions said yesterday.         If G.E. paid the average rate for midtown Manhattan real estate, which according to National Real Estate Index is $234 per square foot, the purchase would have an indicated value of $305 million.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Sooner Than Expected, Germans Cut Key Rates
abstract: The central bank of Germany, faced with a stagnant national economy, unexpectedly cut official interest rates half a percentage point yesterday.         The move is expected to help the German economy, which appears to have contracted for a second consecutive quarter. And because Germany has Europe's largest economy, a rebound there could be expected to flow into neighboring countries.

headline: Economics Lesson In a Border Town;Why That Asian TV Has A 'Made in Mexico' Label
abstract: The towering blue sign that lights up the night at Samsung Group's sprawling  new industrial complex seems out of place in this gray and grubby border town.         But in the months since it was erected, the 70-foot steel structure has become an unofficial landmark, at once a beacon for poor and restless Mexicans looking for work and a symbol of the free-trade forces that are siphoning manufacturing jobs from the United States.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Jobless Rate Took Big April Jump
abstract: Japan's jobless rate made it biggest one-month jump in four decades in April, the Government said yesterday. The increase of three-tenths of a percentage point, to 3.4 percent. was the biggest since 1959. Japan's unemployment rate would be significantly higher if calculated by United States or European methods, falling somewhere between 5 and 8 percent, economists say. Anyone who has worked an hour or more in the last week of a given month is counted as fully employed in Japan.   (AP)

headline: G.M. Locomotive Order
abstract: The General Motors Corporation said today that its Electro-Motive division had received an order to supply up to 250 freight-hauling locomotives to English Welsh & Scottish Railway Ltd. Financial terms were not disclosed. The G.M. unit  will provide 3,000-horsepower locomotives under the agreement, which requires delivery of 25 to 100 locomotives a year. An Electro-Motive spokesman said initial deliveries would likely begin in 1998. English Welsh & Scottish Railway  is owned by the Wisconsin Central Transportation Corporoation of Rosemont, Ill., and American and New Zealand investors.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;American Portable Selects Korey Kay
abstract: American Portable Telecom in Chicago, a wireless communications company owned by Telephone and Data Systems Inc., said yesterday that it had selected Korey Kay & Partners in New York as the first agency to handle its brand and retail advertising account. The billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.           Doug Rothrock, a spokesman for American Portable, said that Korey Kay was awarded the account after a two-month review that also included two other finalists: Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., and Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago. American Portable is licensed to offer its wireless services in several markets, including Houston, Minneapolis and Pittsburgh.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: U.S. Strains With China: 1 Exception
abstract: Despite their strained relations, the United States and China have embarked on a program of environmental cooperation to address problems like rapid urbanization, pollution from energy consumption and the changing agricultural patterns of an increasingly prosperous population.         White House officials said a three-day meeting of senior agency officials from both nations at the White House last week was especially noteworthy because it occurred at a time when Chinese-American relations have been strained by differences over Taiwan and other trade and security issues.

headline: DIARY
abstract: CHINA RELATIONS

headline: World News Briefs;U.N.-Iraq Talks On Oil Deal Stalled
abstract: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations on a plan for Baghdad to sell oil to pay for urgent civilian needs remained suspended today as negotiators waited  for President Saddam Hussein to either accept or reject a deal.         Diplomats said they hoped that an agreement, the details of which were worked out here in recent weeks, could be announced early next week. But there have been conflicting accounts of whether the secretive talks have satisfied Baghdad's concerns.

headline: Amex's Profits Rise to Record
abstract: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that its first-quarter profits tripled to a record $3.9 million, fueled by higher stock trading volume and demand for market data.         The total is up from $1.3 million in the first quarter of 1995, as revenue rose to $42.5 million from $36.1 million. Amex, the nation's No. 3 stock exchange, makes money by selling subscribers market data on the 773 companies that list on the exchange.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INSIGNIA FINANCIAL AGREES TO MAKE 3 ACQUISITIONS
abstract: Insignia Financial Group said yesterday that it had reached preliminary agreements to make three new acquisitions of real estate asset and service companies for a total price of $250 million. Insignia Financial said it did not  have the money yet for all three acquisitions, which could contribute $50 million a year in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Insignia Financial provides property or asset management services for more than 2,400 properties. Its stock rose $1 a share, to $22.25.

headline: Drogheda Journal;New Curse, They Say, From the Land of Cromwell
abstract: Since 1649, when Oliver Cromwell and his Roundheads massacred more than 1,000 Irishmen, there has been a suspicion of English actions here in this hilly town  on the River Boyne, three miles from the Irish Sea.         In recent years, the suspicion has grown to resentment, stirred by fears among the town's 25,000 people that England is endangering their health by flushing nuclear waste into the sea that laps up on the nearby shore.

headline: Real Estate;A generic drug maker spends $5 million on renovation of a 100-year-old plant in  Philadelphia.
abstract: AFTER the Global Pharmaceutical Corporation, a publicly held producer of generic drugs, acquired Richlyn Laboratories Inc., it considered moving into a new plant, but given the Federal regulatory hurdles to getting a new plant certified, it chose instead a $5 million renovation of Richlyn's century-old manufacturing plant here.         That effort is now nearing completion. For city officials, Global's decision  was an unexpected aid to their effort to hold industrial jobs. "Certainly we've  lost a lot of pharmaceutical jobs in the city; they've grown in the suburbs," said Stephen Mullin, the city's commerce director. The city has been able to retain some companies that package foods and pharmaceuticals requiring Federal approvals, but few large employers have moved into Philadelphia.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PARK-OHIO IS SELLING ITS BENNETT INDUSTRIES UNIT
abstract: Park-Ohio Industries of Cleveland said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Bennett Industries unit to Nampac, an American division of Southcorp Holdings Ltd. of Australia, for about $50 million. Bennett makes plastic containers used by paint, chemical and food companies. The company had revenue of more than $80 million last year, while Park-Ohio, a diversified maker of industrial products, had 1995 revenue of $371 million.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Partners Vote For Changes At Goldman
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Company took action yesterday to strengthen its capital base and to limit the liability of the firm's partners.         Goldman said it would retain for a longer period the capital of partners who  leave the firm. The firm also said it would become a limited liability partnership on Nov. 30, the end of its financial year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;After 37 Years, A Pennzoil Review
abstract: The Pennzoil Products Company, the maker of motor oils, said yesterday that it had begun a review of its account after 37 years at Lois/EJL Advertising in Houston. Billings were estimated at $40 million.          Tom Floyd, chief marketing officer at Pennzoil in Houston, confirmed reports of the review this week in trade publications. Richard Westman, chairman and chief executive at Lois/EJL, a unit of Lois/ U.S.A., said the agency would participate in the review. Gregg Dearth, president of the Dearth Company in Atlanta, which is managing the review, said 10 unidentified other agencies were  also asked to participate. A decision is expected by early fall.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Burmese Leaders Expand Moves Against Dissident
abstract: The Burmese military has mounted a new offensive against the country's leading democracy advocate, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, using 30-foot-tall billboards  that denounce her as a stooge of foreign countries.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: Southwest in Accord on Corporate Fares
abstract: A consortium that represents 25 companies, including Chrysler and Procter & Gamble, has won a commitment from Southwest Airlines to offer simplified fares,  based on flight distance, to their employees for business travel.         Southwest's support represents a minor victory in the fight to change the Byzantine fare system, in which corporations, airlines and travel agents negotiate separate deals with one another. This fare structure often results in volume discounts for large companies that plan trips in advance through travel agencies. But fares change often, and business travelers generally pay a  premium for last-minute arrangements.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hong Kong Group Buys Hilton Hotel in London
abstract: Ladbroke Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to sell the Langham Hilton Hotel in London to a unit of Great Eagle Holdings Ltd. of Hong Kong for L100 million, or  about $151 million. Ladbroke, a London-based hotel and leisure company, said the sale price was slightly below the book value of the hotel, which recorded an operating profit of L7.5 million ($11.3 million) last year.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: MONDAY

headline: Voluntary Rules Are Proposed For the Privacy of Internet Users
abstract: The on-line and direct marketing industries today proposed voluntary guidelines intended to protect Internet users against unauthorized collection of personal information.         But the proposal, made at a Federal Trade Commission hearing on personal privacy in the information age, drew fire from civil liberties groups and others concerned over privacy issues. They argued that self-policing by the industry would not restrain on-line abuses that they said already range from surreptitious monitoring of activities on the Internet to the illegal sale of personal credit histories over the Internet.

headline: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS;A Big Day for Mergers in the United States
abstract: Only one day into the second quarter and the mergers business is already on a tear.         United States companies announced about $28 billion worth of mergers yesterday, more than 10 percent of the amount announced in the entire first quarter. Bolstered by rising stock markets and low interest rates, the torrid pace indicates 1996 may exceed the record $866 billion of mergers last year.

headline: Levi Strauss Offers to Pay A Dividend To Workers
abstract: Levi Strauss Associates, the world's largest apparel company, announced yesterday that it would pay an unusual one-time dividend to all its employees, totaling as much as $750 million in six years.         Levi Strauss, famous for its riveted blue jeans, completed a big stock buyback in February, purchasing roughly 30 percent of its shares for $4.3 billion. To complete that transaction, it took on $3.2 billion of debt The bonus that was announced yesterday is based on the amount of time the company believes it will take to repay that debt.

headline: To Err Is Human
abstract: We are, after all, only human. So from time to time we do stupid things. That can be pretty harmless at home, but what if you're at work? Maybe you almost operated on the left leg instead of the injured right one. Or, during an audit,  you carried the 1, when it should have been a 2. Or you just said something so inappropriate that your business meeting came to a silent halt. Send your story  to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New  York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished  in any medium.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cable and Wireless Posts One-Time Charge
abstract: Cable and Wireless P.L.C. said yesterday that it would post a one-time expense of L120 million, or about $181.2 million, primarily related to its operations in Central and Eastern Europe. The British telecommunications operator said the expense would not have any impact on the company's cash position. The company said the charge would be more than offset by a one-time earnings gain from the sale for L199 million of the company's stake in Mannesmann Mobilfunk, a German cellular-telephone network operator.

headline: USA Waste to Merge With Sanifill in $1.3 Billion Deal
abstract: USA Waste Services Inc., the third-largest solid-waste removal company in the nation, said today that it had agreed to merge with Sanifill Inc., a big waste hauling and disposal concern, in a deal worth about $1.3 billion.    USA Waste, which is based in Dallas, said it would offer shareholders of Sanifill, which is based in Houston, 1.7 shares of USA Waste for each common share of Sanifill, worth a total of about $1.3 billion, and also assume about $400 million in debt.          In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of USA Waste rose $1, to $28.875, and shares of Sanifill fell 37.5 cents, to $47.50.

headline: Metallgesellschaft Reports Talks With Ex-Chief Fail
abstract: Metallgesellschaft A.G. said today that it had held talks on a settlement with a former chief executive who was ousted after a unit racked up $1.3 billion in trading losses.

headline: Resorting Priorities And Doing It in Bulk;Winners and Losers as Postal Service Changes the Rules for Business Mail
abstract: D-Day is looming for the Postal Service and its bulk-mail customers.         On Monday, new regulations go into effect that are supposed to speed the delivery of bulk mail and other business correspondence. The rules give companies a bigger role in the service's streamlining efforts, laying out new guidelines for everything from presorting mail and checking addresses to limiting catalogues to certain sizes and weights.

headline: Environment Yielding to Other Worries, U.N. Talks Suggest
abstract: Four years after the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro propelled the environment to the top of the world agenda, the movement seems to have reached an impasse here at the United Nations, where a commission set up to monitor progress since  Rio ended two weeks of talks today.         The Commission on Sustainable Development -- dedicated to the notion that nations can continue expanding their economies without destroying their environment -- heard success stories as it prepared for a major review next year of how far the world has come since the 1992 Earth Summit, formally called the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.

headline: April Spending By Consumers Barely Rose
abstract: Consumer spending barely edged up in April despite a relatively strong increase in personal incomes, the Commerce Department said today.         The department also reported that the nation's savings rate dropped to a two-year low in April.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO SOLICITS BUYERS FOR NATURAL GAS UNIT
abstract: Tenneco Inc. is seeking at least $4 billion for its natural gas unit, Dana G. Mead, the company's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday in an interview. Tenneco, based in Greenwich, Conn., wants to sell or spin off Tenneco Energy to shareholders. The company has reviewed offers and is preparing presentations for at least three finalist bidders, Mr. Mead said. The company expects to sell Tenneco Energy and spin off Newport News Shipbuilding by the end of 1996, he said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kikkoman Selects Foote, Cone Office
abstract: Kikkoman International in San Francisco said yesterday that it had named the  San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle its consumer soy sauce account, which had been handled for more than a decade by the Saatchi & Saatchi  Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $6 million.          Foote, Cone, a unit of True North Communications, was awarded the account after a two-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and another finalist, the J. Walter Thompson San Francisco unit of the WPP Group; Saatchi &  Saatchi declined to participate in the review. The food service and industrial parts of the account continue to be handled by Ketchum Communications in San Francisco.

headline: Border Issue Raises Fear On U.S. Role In Panama
abstract: From its headquarters here, the United States military's Southern Command has said over and over that for more than two years no American troops have been sent to the Panamanian province of Darien, which is swarming with drug traffickers and guerrillas.         Nevertheless, Panama and Colombia are acting as if there is an American plot  afoot to fill the vacuum along their border.

headline: A U.S. Firm Is Said to Deal With a Serb Tied to Crimes
abstract: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, may not have many friends left in  the outside world, but he apparently has a few in the American accounting firm of KPMG Peat Marwick.         Bosnian Serb leaders say a subsidiary of the firm signed a "mutual cooperation" contract this month in Pale, the Serbian stronghold, with Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted on war-crimes charges.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chinese Fair Showcases An Old Taboo: Lingerie
