abstract: Beneath China," an international exhibition that opened here last week with  a name suggesting archeology or history, was actually a showcase for underwear.          Until recently, advertising of lingerie was banned in China. But items once considered decadent or risque are now eagerly welcomed, and the first lingerie trade fair in modern times offered a full display of current styles.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DELPHI PLANS TO SELL 3 PLANTS AND SHUT ONE
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's parts subsidiary, Delphi Automotive Systems, said yesterday that it would sell three North American plants and close a fourth in an effort to become more profitable. Delphi plans to sell its electrical and  lighting plants in Livonia, Mich.; and Oshawa and Windsor, Ontario, and close a  generator plant in Albany, Ga., that employs about 500 workers. They will be offered transfers to another plant in Flint, Mich., that will take over the Albany plant's work, Delphi said. Delphi also said it would seek a partner for a plant in Flint. The company has said that it plans to increase its business outside North America, and with customers other than General Motors. On Tuesday, Delphi Packard Electric Systems said it would build a $17 million plant and service center in Guangzhou, China, to make automotive electronics for export to Europe and for Chinese car makers.

headline: World News Briefs;Latvia-Estonia Dispute On Sea Border Is Defused
abstract: The Baltic states of Latvia and Estonia said today that they had reached a short-term agreement to defuse an increasingly bitter dispute over their sea border.         The two countries have been arguing for several years over where to mark their sea border in the Gulf of Riga, in a dispute over access to rich fishing grounds.

headline: A Haitian Set for Deportation Is Instead Set Free by the U.S.
abstract: Back home in Haiti, Emmanuel Constant is his country's most wanted man, accused of supervising murders, rapes and torture of supporters of democracy.         But in a move that has dismayed human rights groups and the Haitian Government, the United States has freed the paramilitary leader and former Central Intelligence Agency informant from a Maryland jail where he had been held, pending deportation, for the last year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SETTLEMENT ACCEPTED ON LOUISIANA-PACIFIC HOME SIDING
abstract: A Federal judge accepted the settlement yesterday of a class-action lawsuit that had accused the Louisiana-Pacific Corporation of producing defective siding for homes. After chastising lawyers last week for a proposal he said inadequately compensated homeowners, Judge Robert Jones of the Federal District  Court in Portland, Ore., approved a modified deal. Louisiana-Pacific agreed to pay $275 million, and has an option to add $50 million more to the fund in each of years six and seven of the settlement. The company agreed to pay administrative costs and arbitrators' awards from funds outside the settlement pool. The siding in question, known as Inner Seal, resembles cedar, but it can soak up moisture, resulting in swelling and cracking. It was installed on an estimated 800,000 homes nationwide. Louisiana-Pacific has maintained that up to  90 percent of the problems with the siding can be traced to improper installation and maintenance.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;News Corporation Plans Digital TV for Japan
abstract: Rupert Murdoch, the media entrepreneur, announced plans yesterday to start a  100-channel digital broadcasting system in Japan within two years. Mr. Murdoch said his company, the News Corporation, would produce and supply only a handful  of the channels, leaving most for Japanese programmers.          Only 3 million households in Japan receive cable television, compared with about 60 million in the United States. Also, 7.4 million Japanese households receive two satellite channels offered by the public broadcaster NHK. Digital technology lets a satellite transmit many channels, with better picture quality  than conventional analog TV.   (AP)

headline: Yeltsin's Uncertain Health Leaves a Question in the Minds of RussianVoters
abstract: In his frenetic pursuit of re-election, Boris N. Yeltsin plans 16 campaign trips this month. In April the 65-year-old Russian President's punishing schedule sent him from Moscow to Norway and then across the Asian continent to China. In between, he presided over a hectic summit meeting held for the leaders of the world's richest nations.         "I do not have any time to remember my illnesses," Mr. Yeltsin wrote this week in response to a series of personal questions submitted by voters. "I work  from 5 in the morning until late each night."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UTILITIES WOULD RAISE DIVIDEND AFTER MERGER
abstract: The Kansas City Power and Light Company and Utilicorp United Inc. said yesterday that they would pay a higher dividend if they merged, but the amount of the proposed payout fell short of a promise from Western Resources Inc., a hostile suitor for Kansas City Power. The projected dividend of $1.85 a share would be 18.6 percent higher than Kansas City Power's current dividend and 15.2  percent greater than Utilicorp's payout. But Western Resources has said it would pay shareholders $1.98 a share if its bid of $28 a share to buy Kansas City Power is completed. Kansas City Power's merger with Utilicorp was valued at $26.77 a share when the deal was announced in January. Shareholders of Kansas City Power and Utilicorp are to vote on the merger on May 22. Both companies are based in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Intel Plans PC Video-Phone Technology
abstract: After years of false starts by AT&T and others, the Intel Corporation hopes to bring video-phone technology to the masses.         The company plans to announce at a meeting with analysts in New York today that starting later this year, most new home personal computers will be capable  of making and receiving video-phone calls over standard telephone lines.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Greek Coast Guard Fires On Turkish Fishing Boat
abstract: A Greek coast guard patrol boat fired on a Turkish fishing boat today, trying to stop it after the Turkish boat smuggled illegal migrants onto a Greek islet,  officials said.         Turkey protested to Greece, contending that the Greek vessel had entered Turkish waters, fired on a Turkish boat and wounded a Turkish citizen, the Anatolia news agency reported.

headline: Fidelity Considers Closing Magellan Fund
abstract: An executive at Fidelity Investments said the mutual-fund company would continue to examine the possibility of closing the Magellan fund, the $55 billion fund that is the country's largest, to new investors.         "We have no current plans to close the fund, and it's something we always look at," J. Gary Burkhead, president of Fidelity Management and Research, said. He spoke at a conference sponsored by Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;RJR Nabisco Improved in First Quarter
abstract: Lifted by better-than-expected sales in its premium cigarette brands and by worldwide volume and sales growth in its tobacco and food businesses, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported improved first-quarter results yesterday,  a week after it had beaten back a proxy challenge by the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn.         Earnings rose 12 percent, to 57 cents a share, from 51 cents a share in the comparable period last year. Earnings were about 2 cents a share above the estimates of securities analysts, and the company said its earnings would have been 59 cents a share, had it not been for the proxy battle.

headline: With Sumitomo Loss, U.S. Widens Commodities Inquiry
abstract: Broadening an inquiry into $1.8 billion in copper-trading losses run up at the Sumitomo Corporation of Japan, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission of the United States is investigating ties between Sumitomo and the Global Minerals and Metals Corporation, a small New York company that has conducted extensive trading with the Japanese industrial conglomerate.         The expanded investigation comes as authorities in Tokyo, Washington and London try to determine who might have helped Yasuo Hamanaka, Sumitomo's chief copper trader, in the schemes that resulted in huge, undisclosed losses over the last 10 years. The authorities already know of one copper trader who said he had been asked to confirm fictitious trades by Mr. Hamanaka in 1991.

headline: Sales of New Homes Fell 7.6% in March
abstract: Rising interest rates bit substantially into sales of new homes in March, driving them down by 7.6 percent, to an annual rate of 672,000, the slowest since last May, the Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported today.         As a result, the already-lofty inventories of unsold houses climbed to the highest point since 1980.

headline: ITT Will Expand 2 Caesars World Casinos
abstract: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it would expand its Caesars World casinos in Atlantic City and Las Vegas, Nev., in a move that adds new construction to an expansion strategy dominated by acquisitions.         In Atlantic City, ITT plans to build a 20-story hotel tower and to increase its Caesars Atlantic City casino by almost 43 percent, to 100,000 square feet, according to documents filed with the New Jersey Casino Control Commission.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt Federal Farm Credit Banks is selling $50 million of medium-term notes due in 1999 through Nationsbanc Capital Markets. The notes are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.500 percent semiannually and are priced at par.

headline: Two End Fokker Talks
abstract: The Samsung Group of South Korea and Saab of Sweden, a unit of Investor A.B., dropped out of the running today as potential saviors for the bankrupt Dutch plane maker Fokker N.V., leaving only a Russian consortium as a faint glimmer of hope. "Samsung of Korea and Sweden's Saab have consulted each other but could not come to agreement," Fokker said. "Both parties have therefore decided not to make a bid." Fokker went bankrupt on March 15 after weeks of struggle following a decision in January by its majority owner, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, to cut off financial support. Last week, the Dutch Minister of Economic Affairs, Hans Wijers, said Fokker's administrators were talking to Samsung Aerospace, Saab Aircraft and Tupolev and Yakovlev of Russia.

headline: I.B.M. Jumps and Dow Follows, Adding 33.96
abstract: The stock market's upward momentum continued yesterday, led by a rally in I.B.M.         Shares of I.B.M. surged 7 1/4, or 6.6 percent, to 117 5/8, and accounted for  nearly two-thirds of the increase in the Dow Jones industrial average. The gain  was spurred by improved earnings forecasts and positive comments on the stock from Lehman Brothers.

headline: Taking In the Sites;Dining Out in Manhattan: How to See and Be Seen
abstract: Train a camcorder on just about anything, feed the contents into a Web server and shovel the results onto a site on the World Wide Web. Computer literates in  droves have decided that this is a cool idea and have acted on the impulse. So now there are thousands of sites displaying video images that range from street  corners to sunsets, from fishbowls to toilet bowls.         Mostly these Webcam sites, as they are known, look primitive. Even on the best sites, the pictures, which are often grainy, are updated only every minute  or two. And while the Webcams focused on street scenes and other public gathering spots do seem to occupy an uncertain status as a new medium, they perhaps raise an ethical question: Is this the cinema verite of cyberspace or is it private surveillance?

headline: Two Missions in Africa, but a Common Complaint
abstract: In the space of two months, two foreign military interventions, one American, the other French, have been mounted to extract Westerners from violence that has all but destroyed two African capitals.         In Monrovia, Liberia, United States forces swooped onto the grounds of the seaside American Embassy complex early in April, defending an area extending no  further than the mission's high white walls.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Belfast Protestants Riot At a Blocked Parade
abstract: Protestant marchers hurled firebombs and bottles today after the police blocked a parade from entering a Roman Catholic area. At least five people were  injured.         The violence broke out during a daylong standoff that was a tense start to Northern Ireland's traditional season of sectarian marches.

headline: E.D.S. Regains Independence From G.M.
abstract: Electronic Data Systems, which was sold by Ross Perot to the General Motors Corporation for $2.5 billion in 1984, finally won its independence back from G.M. today.         General Motors reported that with a shareholder vote running 60 to 1 in favor, a majority had officially approved the split.

headline: DEATH IN LEBANON;The Peacekeepers With No Peace to Keep
abstract: Scattered across the rolling, rocky hills of southern Lebanon is a network of 169 checkpoints and observation posts and some two dozen bases -- like the one that was shelled by Israeli troops yesterday -- manned by soldiers from nine countries wearing the distinctive blue berets of United Nations peacekeepers.         But there is no peace there to keep.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HUGE INVESTMENT PLANNED FOR TRANSMISSION DIVISION
abstract: The General MotorsCorporation will invest $275 million in its Allison Transmission division in Indianapolis to modernize its plant and add a new automatic transmission line. The investment will enable Allison to produce transmissions for large-sized pickups. Production will begin in 1999. Allison has traditionally concentrated on automatic transmissions for large heavy-duty trucks, buses and off-highway vehicles. Modernization work at the Indianapolis plant is expected to be completed in 1998.

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Canceling Visas Of Bogota Officials
abstract: The United States has decided to cancel the visas of some high-ranking Colombian officials under investigation by the justice authorities here for suspected ties to drug traffickers.         Two senior Colombian officials, Attorney General Orlando Vazquez and Comptroller General David Terbay, have acknowledged that their visas were withdrawn. Mr. Vazquez said his visa was revoked weeks before his arrest this month on charges of illicit enrichment. Mr. Terbay, who is under a Supreme Court investigation here, has said his was revoked as well.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hewlett-Packard Narrows Review
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company has narrowed to four finalists its review for the account of its printers and scanners and other peripherals sold in the United States. The account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $45 million, had  been handled for the last eight years by the San Francisco office of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.         Separately, Hewlett-Packard selected the London office of Publicis S.A. to handle advertising for its personal information products group in Europe, including personal computers, which had been handled by the London office of Saatchi & Saatchi. Those billings were estimated at $30 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN SPORTING GOODS TO ACQUIRE AVIA BRAND
abstract: Reebok International Ltd. signed a letter of intent yesterday that calls for  the American Sporting Goods Corporation to buy nearly all the operating assets and business of Reebok's Avia Group International Inc. The purchase price was not disclosed. Reebok, based in Stoughton, Mass., said in January that it intended to sell Avia to focus on its Reebok and Rockport brands. The deal is expected to close by the end of May. American Sporting Goods, based in Irvine, Calif., owns the Turntec and Nevados brands and holds the United States license  for Ocean Pacific footwear.

headline: Israel's Losingest Hero
abstract: Shimon Peres should rank as a great figure in Israeli history. But, if the current vote unwinds as many expect today, in his fourth defeat for Prime Minister, he may be remembered as the man who could not win.         Article, page A10.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAYES MICROCOMPUTER EMERGES FROM BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from Federal Bankruptcy Court in Atlanta to emerge from Chapter 11 protection, with somewhat different financing than anticipated. The company told a bankruptcy judge on Monday that the financing initially arranged from an equity investor, the Northern Telecom Ltd. unit of BCE Inc., fell through in early April. Northern Telecom had planned to team with Acma Ltd. of Singapore to buy a 49 percent stake in Hayes for $35 million. Instead, the Atlanta-based Hayes arranged for two Hong Kong concerns -- Kaifa Holdings Ltd. and Rolling Profits Holdings Ltd., a unit of Wongs Ltd. -- to split a 16.3 percent stake for $5.8 million each. Quek Sim Pin, the Acma chairman, also agreed to acquire a 12.3 percent stake for $8.8 million, through companies he controls. Acma had already agreed to pay $17.5 million for a 24.5 percent stake.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Samsung Is Cutting Back Output of Computer Chips
abstract: The Samsung Electronics Company, the world's largest producer of computer memory chips, said today that it would shut its factories for two days a month for the rest of the year to cut production in the face of a sharp oversupply that has sent prices plunging.         The move by the South Korean company, which until now has been saying it would go full speed ahead and ride out the downturn in the industry, attests to  the severity of the drop in prices of dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, the main type of chip used to store information in computers.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Martha Stewart Is Said to Seek a Break With Time Warner
abstract: Martha Stewart, the doyenne of domesticity, is attempting to end her partnership with Time Warner Inc., according to several people close to both parties.         They said Ms. Stewart had clashed with several top corporate executives, especially the president, Don Logan. They said those relations had frayed in part because Ms. Stewart felt that Time Warner would not give her sufficient support to expand the businesses tied to her increasingly visible brand name. Executives close to Ms. Stewart asserted that her entrepreneurial spirit was ill suited to Time's corporate hierarchy.

headline: Market Place;Lexmark makes money but does not excite investors.
abstract: WITH a robust market for new technology stocks, it is easy to forget that there have been some initial public offerings that have stalled -- even offerings from technology companies with actual profits. That is the case with Lexmark International Group, a maker of laser and inkjet printers for computers. Since going public at $20 a share in November, Lexmark shares have traded as low as $15.50 and as high as $23.25. Yesterday, the shares fell 12.5 cents, to $21.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supreme Court Upholds Credit-Card Late Fees In a major victory for banks with interstate credit-card operations, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously that a bank could charge any late-payment fee permitted  by its home state, regardless of the state law where a cardholder lives. The court upheld a ruling by California's highest court concerning Citibank.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE ISSUES;Plane Crash in Croatia Silenced A Big Player in Capital Debates
abstract: When Ronald H. Brown died on a hillside near Dubrovnik, Croatia, on Wednesday, he was in the thick of three battles here that touched the divergent  roles he played in Washington.         The first was a continuing struggle within the Administration -- sometimes still heated three years after it began -- over the degree to which the nation's commercial interests should drive its foreign policy agenda.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombians Must Return 'Antichrist' Scare Money
abstract: The head of Colombia's Roman Catholic Church has ordered priests to forfeit any money they received for performing mass baptisms during a scare this month about the Antichrist.         "Serious harm has been done to the church because of the actions of some priests," the cleric, Archbishop Pedro Rubiano, said in a letter today in the newspaper El Tiempo.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Medeva to Buy Fisons From Big Drug Maker
abstract: The British drug maker Medeva P.L.C. said yesterday that it would acquire Fisons P.L.C.'s former operations in Rochester and licenses to sell various drugs from Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. for $400 million. The sale comes a day after Rhone-Poulenc Rorer's parent, the French chemical and drug company Rhone-Poulenc S.A., said it planned to sell pharmaceutical assets.          Medeva will pay $370 million in cash for the Rochester operations. The company will also acquire the licenses for 10 drugs produced at the Rochester plant. Medeva will pay Rhone-Poulenc $30 million in cash for the right to sell certain respiratory, dermatological and over-the-counter drugs in France.   (AP)

headline: American Topics
abstract: Two Indiana teenagers thought they had devised the perfect scam: signing checks with disappearing ink. But the too-clever teens, who allegedly passed $2,000 in such checks, forgot one detail: the name of one of the two, Jeffrey J. Pyrcioch, was permanently printed at the top of the checks. The vanishing signatures, moreover, can be restored at a police laboratory, authorities say. The suspects, Pyrcioch and Heather M. Green, could face eight years in prison.

headline: Real Estate;A developer has begun its first office building in the U.S. since the late 1980's, in Washington.
abstract: THE Hines Interests, an office developer based in Houston, has started excavations for an office building in the east end of Washington. Hines says it  is the first office development it has begun in the United States since the office market collapsed in the late 1980's.         The 240,000-square-foot building, designed by Robert A. M. Stern of New York, will rise on a site at 600 13th Street N.W. Hines, one of the largest developers of downtown office buildings in the United States, said the 11-story building would be clad in limestone and granite. Occupancy is scheduled for October 1997.

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 8.24 points, or .04 percent, at 21,420.12 .  On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 316.72 points.

headline: Rights Panel For Europe Stirs Anger In Britain
abstract: Seven years ago, the British Board of Film Classification banned Nigel Wingrove's video "Visions of Ecstasy," saying its graphic scenes of Jesus having sex with a Carmelite nun violated Britain's centuries-old law against blasphemy.         What could Mr. Wingrove do? Having exhausted his legal remedies in Britain, he did what more and more of his aggrieved countrymen are doing when they find themselves on the wrong side of a British law. He took his case to the European  Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg, where his lawyers argued in February that Britain's blasphemy statute was arbitrary, anachronistic and illegal under the broader laws of Europe.

headline: U.S. and Hanoi Agree to Give Boat People One Last Chance
abstract: The Clinton Administration and Hanoi have reached an agreement to allow several thousand Vietnamese now living in refugee camps in Southeast Asia to resettle in the United States, provided they first return to Vietnam and apply in writing.         Confronting rioting in camps in Hong Kong by Vietnamese who face forced repatriation to Vietnam, the United States and Hanoi concluded six months of negotiations to give Vietnamese who were in the camps by Oct. 1, 1995 one last hearing on their appeals for asylum.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Clash After Kurds' Arrest Injures 80 in Turkey
abstract: The police arrested 30 leading Kurdish party officials at the end of a party  convention on Sunday night and then battled pro-Kurdish protesters today in a confrontation that left 80 people injured.         The police clashed with supporters of the pro-Kurdish Labor party in downtown Ankara to prevent them from demonstrating against a trial that Kurdish officials say is aimed at shutting down the party, which advocates Kurdish ethnic rights.

headline: Eritrea: African Success Story Being Written
abstract: On the outskirts of this lovely Italianate capital, the Government recently built an unusual steel plant. There is no iron ore nearby. Instead, former rebel soldiers are melting down the Ethiopian tanks once used to crush them and turning them into construction girders.         The plant, called Orota, is the namesake of a military base run by the Eritrean People's Liberation Front where, cut off from international help, rebels made bullets and spare weapons from scrap during the 30-year war against  Ethiopia. The officer who oversaw that shoestring operation is now in charge of  beating battle debris, if not into plowshares, into badly needed construction material.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Softbank Profits Soar On Japanese Demand
abstract: The Softbank Corporation's profit nearly tripled in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, as a surge in Japanese demand for computers, software, network services and computer peripheral devices lifted sales. The company, Japan's largest computer software wholesaler, said yesterday that profit jumped  to 13.8 billion yen ($122.62 million). Sales rose 45 percent, to 140.28 billion  yen.          Computer magazine sales also grew, reflecting the interest in computers. The president of Softbank, Masayoshi Son, predicted solid growth in the Japanese computer market this year.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: Talk of Fed Rate Rise Sends Bonds Over 7% for a Time
abstract: Treasury prices tumbled yesterday after talk of an increase in interest rates coming sooner than expected rattled a market already nervous about a strong economy and inflation.         The selloff briefly pushed the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for mortgages and other consumer rates -- above the psychologically important level of 7 percent. Bond yields move in the opposite direction from their prices.

headline: For a Czech Film Executive, It's All Business
abstract: The sprawling Barrandov Film Studios on the edge of Prague has witnessed much of this country's troubled 20th-century history. Founded in the democratic 1930's, the studios were taken over by the Nazis during World War II. Communist apparatchiks then used them to churn out propaganda films between 1948 and 1989. And when Czech movie makers enjoyed a brief "spring" in the 1960's, Soviet troops soon put an end to that.         True to character, then, Barrandov is once again mirroring political events here, this time the Czech Republic's enthusiastic embrace of capitalism since the 1989 Velvet Revolution. And the group's dynamic 35-year-old chief executive, Vaclav Marhoul, personifies an emerging generation of post-Communist businessmen for whom money is the new creed.

headline: World News Briefs;Editor in Insult Case Is Slain in Cambodia
abstract: Thun Bunly, publisher of The Khmer Ideal, a newspaper, was shot dead today, officials and opposition members said. The publisher had been fighting a 1995 conviction for insulting Cambodia's dual Prime Ministers.         Sam Rainsy, an opposition leader, said the slaying was "a very clear sign of  intimidation."

headline: In Cold War Throwback, Moscow Says London Runs a Spy Ring
abstract: In one of the most contentious spy cases since the collapse of the Soviet Union, Russia has accused Britain of running a spy ring and threatened to expel  as many as nine British diplomats.         The Russian action, and a British threat to retaliate by expelling Russian officials, was a throwback to the cold war and it served to underline the increasingly nationalist refrains of the campaign for the June presidential election, in which President Boris N. Yeltsin and the Communist candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, have sought to make a virtue of standing up to the West.

headline: 6.83% Yield As Prices Rise On Treasuries
abstract: Reports showing a wider United States trade deficit and weaker consumer sentiment eased fears of an overheating economy yesterday and sent Treasury prices sharply higher.         With the exception of the shorter- maturity bills, longer-term Treasury securities surged and recouped the previous day's losses, which came on a surprisingly strong housing report.

headline: Ukraine Yields Warheads
abstract: Ukraine transferred the last of its nuclear warheads to Russia today, President Leonid Kuchma said in a statement. Under an agreement with the United  States and Russia signed in 1994, Ukraine was to receive $1 billion for giving up the weapons and Russia was to sell the nuclear components of the warheads to  the United States and compensate Ukraine, mostly in the form of fuel for its five nuclear power stations. Ukraine is the second former Soviet republic to disarm, after Kazakstan.

headline: Enlisting A Small Publisher
abstract: When popular mystery writer Walter Mosley came calling with a book deal for the Black Classic Press, the owner of the small publishing company did what any  businessman would do under the circumstances. He cried.         W. Paul Coates, a former Black Panther who started the press 18 years ago with a $300 loan and a basement location, has a deep voice that grows husky just at the memory of Mr. Mosley's decision to publish one of his early unpublished manuscripts with the five-person, Baltimore firm.

headline: Trading Halted In Home Link
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended trading in the shares of the Home Link Corporation for 10 business days. The S.E.C. said today that questions had been raised about the accuracy of public information about the company, whose stock price has skyrocketed in the last three weeks.         The trading suspension began today and will end at 11:59 P.M. on June 21, according to a statement issued today by the S.E.C. Home Link shares are traded  over the counter.

headline: Croat Is First to Be Convicted By Balkan War Crimes Panel
abstract: An ethnic Croat who fought for the Bosnian Serb army pleaded guilty today to  crimes against humanity for his part in the massacre of thousands of Muslim men  at a United Nations-designated "safe area" in Bosnia last July.         The soldier, Drazen Erdemovic, is the first person convicted by the Yugoslav  war crimes tribunal since it was set up in 1993. He will be sentenced in July.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: China Gives Airbus Order, In a Slap at Washington China placed a $1.5 billion order for passenger planes from Airbus Industrie, sending a warning signal to Washington that it can turn to Europe if the United  States becomes intractable on human rights and trade. The Chinese ordered 10 short-haul A320 planes from the four-country European consortium, and may buy another 20.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES SELLING A FINANCE UNIT
abstract: Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its recreational-vehicle finance unit, the Fleetwood Credit Corporation, for $157 million to the Associates First Capital Corporation. Fleetwood Enterprises, a recreational vehicle maker based in Riverside, Calif., said Fleetwood Credit had assets of $400 million and serviced a total receivables portfolio of about $1.1  billion. The financing arm contributed $47.8 million in revenue in the fiscal year that ended on April 30, 1995. Associates First, a finance company based in  Dallas, is part of the Ford Motor Company's financial services group.

headline: World News Briefs;In Bid to Restore Order, Algeria Proposes Reforms
abstract: Algeria's President proposed constitutional reforms today, including measures to enforce separation of religion and politics in a country torn by a four-year-old rebellion by Islamic militants.         Under the changes outlined by President Liamine Zeroual, political parties would be prohibited from making explicit displays of religious and ethnic militancy. The proposed reforms also would promote free-market economics, reduce the presidential term, and establish a supreme court and senate.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE SCENE;14 Bodies Are Airlifted To Makeshift Morgue
abstract: The body believed to be that of Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, along with 13 others from the wreckage of the plane that slammed into a rocky hillside here, was transported tonight by helicopter to a makeshift morgue set up at the  airport in Dubrovnik by the United States Army.         Senior military officials involved in the search said final identification would be difficult because of the force of the crash and the ensuing fire that engulfed the plane.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;P.& G. BUYS EAGLE SNACKS TRADEMARK AND BRAND NAME
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had bought the Eagle Snacks trademark and brand name from the Anheuser-Busch Companies. Financial terms were not disclosed. The deal does not include the A&Eagle trademark, which is the Anheuser-Busch corporate symbol. The maker of beer and snacks already sold a number of plants that made Eagle Snacks to Pepsico Inc.'s Frito-Lay Inc.  Procter & Gamble, based in Cincinnati, said it had no immediate plans to use the trademark and brand name.

headline: World News Briefs;Colombian President Suffers Setback in Trial
abstract: President Ernesto Samper suffered a possible setback in his impeachment trial, with an announcement in Congress that he should be judged on political grounds as well as criminal complaints.          The announcement was made late Thursday by Rodrigo Rivera, president of the  House of Representatives, who said, "The trial will have two parts, one criminal and one political."

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ The Whitman Corporation: It's known for chocolates, it sells mufflers, and it's  acting more and more like a Pepsi bottling company. By Barry Rehfeld.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY

headline: Singapore Journal;Good Life Guide: To 5 C's, Like Cash, Add Clout
abstract: Let's grow up!" scolded Singapore's leader, Lee Kuan Yew, lecturing his countrymen on what he called the facts of life in an unfair world.         Even his tailor and his shoemaker give him discounts, he said. Even the pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson hustled to provide an implant for his recent heart operation, eager for the publicity.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Why Our Pensions Aren't Really Portable
abstract: MILLIONS of Americans will never get their money's worth from their pensions  because, in a very crucial way, the nation's pension system is hopelessly backward.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VALUJET TO SLOW ITS GROWTH DURING U.S. REVIEW
abstract: Valujet Airlines plans to slow the growth of its aircraft fleet while Federal regulators review its operations, according to a filing with the Securities and  Exchange Commission. The airline, which is based in Atlanta and markets itself as as a low-fare carrier, said it expected to add 13 or 14 aircraft this year and that it expected, subject to regulatory approval, to return to its plan of adding 18 to 24 aircraft each year thereafter. Valujet said the step was in response to increased scrutiny from the Federal Aviation Administration after a  string of recent problems involving its planes. Valujet stock closed down $3.875 a share yesterday, to $22, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Nordic Track Inc., Chaska, Minn., a unit of the CML Group, to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle advertising for the North American retail stores division, previously handled by Market Resource Inc., Hanover, Mass. Billings were estimated at $5 million. Draft Direct Worldwide, Chicago, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., continues to handle direct marketing.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Westinghouse Deficit Wider; CBS Acquisition Cost Cited
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation today reported a wider first-quarter loss, excluding gains and charges, mainly as a result of costs related to its $5.4 billion acquisition of CBS Inc.         The broadcasting and industrial company said its loss from continuing operations widened to $116 million, from $9 million in the quarter a year earlier. Westinghouse said interest expenses and amortization related to its purchase of CBS in November totaled about $90 million in the quarter.

headline: EARNING IT;Will Tax Break for Schooling Pass a Congressional Test?
abstract: AN estimated one million employees whose companies paid for their continuing  education had an unexpected tax problem in 1995. Because Congress let a tax provision expire at the end of 1994, the educational benefits that employees received last year were treated as taxable income and showed up on their W-2's.         So a worker in the 28 percent tax bracket who received the maximum benefit of $5,250 paid an extra $1,470 in taxes.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHANCELLOR AGREES TO BUY 8 RADIO STATIONS
abstract: The Chancellor Broadcasting Company signed an agreement yesterday to purchase eight Florida radio stations from privately held Omniamerica Group for $178 million in cash and stock. Chancellor, which is based in Dallas, said the deal would consist of one AM and seven FM stations in Orlando, Jacksonville and West  Palm Beach. The purchases would bring to 43 the number of radio stations Chancellor owns in 16 markets. Chancellor shares rose $3.25, to $24.75.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bozell Acquires Garfield-Linn
abstract: Bozell Worldwide Inc., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has acquired Garfield-Linn & Company in Chicago and merged it with its Chicago office. Terms were not disclosed.         Garfield-Linn brings in billings estimated at $15 million and $17 million from clients like St. Pauli Girl beer, Zenith Electronics and Office 1 Superstores. Garfield-Linn's 13 employees will join Bozell Chicago's 205 employees, who handle accounts with billings estimated at $110 million, from clients like Ace Hardware, Midway Airlines and the National Pork Producers Council.

headline: Swiss Diplomat Resists U.S. On Certifying Bosnian Vote
abstract: The Swiss diplomat in charge of determining whether conditions exist for fair elections in Bosnia is resisting intense pressure from the Clinton Administration to announce that the vote should go ahead as scheduled in September, according to Swiss and American diplomats.         The decision by the Swiss Foreign Minister, Flavio Cotti, to maintain independence from the Administration on one of its touchiest foreign policy goals has provoked intense diplomatic activity and some sharp exchanges, the diplomats said. Mr. Cotti is serving as chairman of the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, charged under the Dayton peace accord with  overseeing elections in Bosnia if it determines that they can be free and fair.

headline: Uganda Gets to Vote
abstract: Ugandans voted today for a Parliament for the first time in 16 years in balloting that barred party affiliations. All 814 candidates ran as individuals; a constitution approved in November set a goal of a new nonparty Parliament.         In addition to the 214 deputies to be elected today, seats will be reserved for 39 women, 5 handicapped people, 5 youths, 4 unionized workers and 10 army delegates.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TBC TO BUY OUTSTANDING SHARES OF BIG O TIRES
abstract: The TBC Corporation said yesterday that it had a definitive agreement to acquire all outstanding shares of Big O Tires Inc. for $16.50 a share, or about  $56 million. The companies first said they were negotiating a merger in February. The price could be reduced based on the deal's cost and other expenses, the companies said. Big O Tires, based in Englewood, Colo., has approximately 3.3 million shares outstanding, 1995 sales of $142.1 million and net income of $1.5 million. TBC, a Memphis marketer and distributor of automotive products, reported 1995 sales of $536.1 million and net income of $15.2 million.

headline: No Headline
Target in New York
abstract: Target Stores, the Minneapolis-based discount retail chain, will move into New York State with four stores opening this fall, company officials announced today. The stores, all with 96,000 square feet of floor space, will be in Buffalo, Williamsville, Cheektowaga and Niagara Falls.  Target is a division of  the Dayton Hudson Corporation, which also operates Hudson's, Marshall Fields, Dayton's and Mervyn's department stores. Target has 688 stores in 34 states across the nation and plans to open 70 to 80 more this year.

headline: French Fail To End Unrest Disrupting Central Africa
abstract: BANGUI, Central African Republic, May 25         A French foreign minister in the 1970's used to be fond of saying that Africa was the last remaining place on earth where Paris could change the course of history by deploying a mere 500 soldiers.

headline: NEW FILES PROVE VIETNAM COVER-UP
abstract: Newly declassified Government documents prove that the United States, after sending hundreds of Vietnamese commandos into North Vietnam during the 1960's, deliberately declared them dead, lied to their wives and then buried their story under a shroud of secrecy.         Nearly 200 of those secret agents survived capture, torture and prison and are alive in the United States. They are asking the Government for back pay -- $2,000 a year, without interest, for their prison time -- and help in getting 88 fellow commandos out of Vietnam.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SYKES ENTERPRISES NEARLY DOUBLE ON DAY ONE
abstract: The shares of Sykes Enterprises Inc., a company that provides assistance for  computer users, nearly doubled on their first day of trading. The company, which is based in Tampa, Fla., had sold 3.4 million shares at $18 each, to raise $61.2 million. Yesterday, the shares closed at $35.50 after Nasdaq trading of more than 3.4 million shares. Sykes runs so-called technical call centers, where the  company answers questions from customers on behalf of computer makers and software companies. The company also provides internal computer support services to corporations.

headline: Market Place;A proposed deal by Warnaco raises fair questions of conflict.
abstract: IT'S been six years since the Warnaco Group, needing to raise cash to pay down debt from its 1986 leveraged buyout, sold a division to its management. Yesterday, Warnaco offered to buy back that division, now called the Authentic Fitness Corporation, for a vastly higher price.         The ties between the two companies are far more than historical. The companies share the same chairman and chief executive, Linda J. Wachner. And the Authentic Fitness board committee that will review the offer is run by a former  Warnaco official who resigned from that company's board only yesterday.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France's Renault Stake To Be Cut Below 50%
abstract: The French Government announced plans yesterday to privatize the state-controlled auto maker Renault S.A. in the coming weeks by reducing its stake to about 46 percent from 52 percent. The shares will be sold by direct placement with unnamed investors who will be selected on the basis of bids, the  Finance Ministry said.          The direct placements allow the Government to avoid entering the open market at a time when Renault shares are weak. When the Government first sold shares in Renault, in November 1994, the price was 165 francs each; yesterday Renault shares closed at 149.9 francs ($28.94), off 0.9 franc. At yesterday's price, the Government would reap 2.15 billion francs ($430 million) from the sale.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TOTAL-TEL REJECTS A TAKEOVER OFFER AS INSUFFICIENT
abstract: Total-Tel USA Communications Inc. rejected yesterday an unsolicited takeover  bid of $46 million from Tel-Save Holdings Inc., calling the offer insufficient.  Tel-Save, based in New Hope, Pa., had offered $26 in cash and stock for each of  Total-Tel's 1.8 million outstanding shares. Both companies provide long-distance telephone services to small and medium-sized businesses. Total-Tel, based in Little Falls, N.J., had 1995 revenue of $50 million. Tel-Save had revenue of $194.5 million in the 12 months ended March 31. Total-Tel's shares rose $2 yesterday, to $27, in Nasdaq trading; Tel-Save's shares fell $1.50, to $22.25.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DANAHER EXTENDS ACME-CLEVELAND TENDER OFFER, AGAIN
abstract: The Danaher Corporation said yesterday that it had extended until May 8 its tender offer to acquire the Acme-Cleveland Corporation for $27 a share, or $186  million. It is the second time that Danaher has extended the bid. Danaher, a maker of tools and equipment for the transportation industry, said about 35,000  Acme-Cleveland shares had been tendered as of Wednesday. Last week, Acme-Cleveland agreed to share financial information with Danaher less than a month after it rejected the takeover bid as inadequate. Acme-Cleveland is a maker of communications, motion-control and measurement products.

headline: On Wall St., a Trade Dispute;New York and Cincinnati Battle Over Stock Prices
abstract: It may look as ludicrous as a battle between a rhino and a rabbit, but the fight raging on Wall Street is deadly serious both for the combatants and for American investors.         The giant New York Stock Exchange is using its considerable might to try to close down the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, an obscure little outfit that most Americans have never tried to trade on. The Big Board says it is out to protect  amateur investors from a system that can too easily rip off the unwary. But Cincinnati and its supporters contend the fight is really over the New York exchange's own power and profits, and maybe even over what the stock market of the future will look like. They maintain that small investors have benefited from the competition that Cincinnati and other regional exchanges have stirred up.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;AST Research Loss Increased In First Quarter
abstract: AST Research Inc. said today that its net loss widened sharply in the first quarter, hurt by slower sales, lower prices and excess inventory, and that it planned a restructuring.         As part of the restructuring, the maker of personal computers plans to dismiss 300 workers and take a charge of between $10 million and $15 million in  the second quarter. The plan would split its operations in the Americas, Europe  and Asia into separate divisions.

headline: World News Briefs;Gorbachev Wins Place On Presidential Ballot
abstract: Mikhail S. Gorbachev qualified today to be listed on the ballot for Russia's  presidential election in June.

headline: INVESTING IT;When It Comes to I.P.O.'s, Is Geography Part of Destiny?
abstract: IS there something special in the air in San Diego?         Investors may well ask that question after looking at the performance of the  stocks of 190 new public companies from 20 cities around the country. The stocks of San Diego companies that went public in the year ended on Thursday outpaced those of I.P.O.'s from every other city, with an average gain of 102.7 percent. That is more than two and a half times the 40 percent average for all new offerings in the period.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Supreme Court Is Split On Banning Smut on Cable The Supreme Court ruled that operators of cable television systems may ban indecent programming from certain commercial channels but not from the community-access channels used by local governments and community groups. Shifting majorities on the Court upheld part and struck down other parts of a 1992 Federal law intended to protect children from indecency on cable television.

headline: Business Travel;Tables at Atlanta's top restaurants are filling up as the Olympics near.
abstract: IT'S no secret that corporate Olympic sponsors and other savvy companies -- Coca-Cola, Georgia-Pacific, I.B.M., Jet Set Sports and NBC among them -- have heavily booked some of the best restaurants in Atlanta during the Games to entertain top clients. So, if calling ahead to reserve a table or private room ever counted, it does now with opening ceremonies a mere 10 weeks away.         "We have about 50 percent of our dinners already booked," said Benjamin Yang, operations director of the Buckhead Life Restaurant Group.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Continue Their Rally
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities climbed yesterday, extending their rally from Friday.         Prices rose early in the day, spurred by overnight trading in Europe and bolstered by a firm dollar. The early gains prompted covering by short-sellers,  who speculated with borrowed securities that bond prices would fall. When prices rose at the opening, they were forced to buy securities to minimize losses.

headline: Stocks End Mixed, With Dow Off by 0.37
abstract: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as an afternoon slump in the bond market threw cold water on a rally led by semiconductor issues.         The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 0.37 point, to 5,668.29, after gaining more than 36 points earlier in the day.

headline: World News Briefs;South Korea to Invest $19 Million in North
abstract: South Korea today authorized a $19 million investment package for its impoverished Communist rival, North Korea.         The package is apparently part of an effort by the South to persuade the North to accept the plan for four-party peace talks, including the United States and China, which was proposed on April 16 by President Clinton and South Korea's President, Kim Young Sam.

headline: Woolworth to Shut Jewelry Store Chain
abstract: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it would close its Accessory Lady chain and take a charge against its second-quarter earnings, as the retailer moves to shed some specialty units.         The 109-store Accessory Lady chain, which sells costume jewelry and accessories at mall locations, will be closed by Sept. 30. The chain has 581 employees, some of whom will be moved to other Woolworth stores, a company spokeswoman said.

headline: Cambodian Killers' Careful Records Used Against Them
abstract: Sous Thy played an important role in the mass killings by the Communist Khmer Rouge that for nearly four years turned Cambodia into one of the most terrifying places on earth: He was a clerk.

headline: S.E.C. Charges Fraud in Case of Tiny Stock That Soared
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Comparator Systems and three of its officials yesterday with fraud in connection with the company's financial statements. The commission also contended that the company had not developed a new fingerprint identification system, as it had said, but had instead stolen a  prototype of a system developed by others.         A commission official said that a Federal judge in Los Angeles, Lourdes G. Baird, had issued a temporary restraining order against the company and the officials, and had also ordered a freeze on their assets. A hearing was set for  June 13.

headline: General Magic Is Planning to Introduce New Products for the Internet
abstract: General Magic Inc., which intended to reinvent computing but missed out on the rise of the Internet, plans to introduce several products on Tuesday that will refocus the company on the global computer network.         General Magic, whose investors include the AT&T Corporation, Motorola Inc., Apple Computer Inc., the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation and the Sony Corporation, set out when it was founded in 1990 to develop an operating system  and a telecommunications language.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Sees Profit In 1998 of $4 Billion
abstract: Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that it expected operating profit of 6 billion marks ($4 billion) in 1998, compared with a loss of 5.7 billion marks in 1995. Sales at Germany's largest company are expected to be 132 billion marks in 1998, Daimler said, a 21 percent rise from 1995. The company made the forecasts  in a statement on merging the remaining parts of AEG A.G. with the parent, Daimler.          The company was required to estimate sales and profit to value the two companies. Daimler cautioned that the estimates could prove wrong if "if there are changes in the worldwide business climate and other factors which affect Daimler-Benz activities -- especially the U.S. dollar." Earlier this month, Daimler said it expected to return to profitability in 1996.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A New Phone Merger Creates a Giant in the East The merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, to be announced today, will create the second-largest telephone company in the United States after AT&T -- with $27 billion in sales, 127,600 employees and 36 million customers in 12 states. The impact on consumers is far from certain, since the two companies do not compete  directly. [Page A1.]

headline: Autodesk Broadens Its Product Line
abstract: With a flurry of new products and a new stock-ticker symbol, Autodesk Inc. announced plans yesterday to broaden its business with Internet and animation software.         The company has long dominated the market for personal computer software used by professionals like engineers and architects in their design work. And its flagship product, Autocad, accounted for an estimated 75 percent of the company's $534 million in sales last year.

headline: Uncovered Short Sales Rise On Big Board and the Amex
abstract: Open positions of short sales continued their record-setting pace on the New  York Stock Exchange in the latest reporting period, reaching a record level for  the fourth consecutive month. On the American Stock Exchange, short interest was at its highest level since its record high in October 1994.         The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that short interest rose 4.8 percent, to 2.3 billion shares, involving trades settled last Wednesday for the period ending May 10. This exceeds the previous record set last month, when  short interest was 2.2 billion shares.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE EXECUTIVES;A Dozen Companies Await Word
abstract: Executives at about a dozen companies across the country were missing and presumed dead yesterday after the crash of an airplane that had been carrying a  trade mission led by Ronald H. Brown, the United States Commerce Secretary.         Most of the business leaders were senior managers at engineering and construction companies and had been scheduled to accompany Mr. Brown on his three-day trip to promote American business participation in the reconstruction  of the former Yugoslavia. The plane crashed near Dubrovnik, Croatia.

headline: More Overstatement Found For Inflation in Price Index
abstract: A panel of private economists appointed by Congress to study the Consumer Price Index now says that the index overstates inflation by even more than the one percentage point it initially estimated.         But at the request of the group, its recommendations for improving the accuracy of the index, which is used to adjust income-tax brackets and Social Security and other Federal payments each year, will be delayed to Dec. 1 from the original target of June 15, too late to figure in any budget calculations for this year.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ Facing a possible cash crunch, Apple Computer has already lost its dividend and  stretched payments to suppliers. Will that be enough? By Andrea Adelson.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 16 in India
abstract: A car bomb killed at least 16 people in New Delhi today, and a Kashmiri militant group took responsibility.  The bomb caused a fire in a building that contained at least 30 stores and a dancing school.         The Press Trust of India reported that a man claiming to speak for the Jammu  and Kashmir Islamic Front said it and another group, Lashkar-e-Sajjad, had taken "this serious step to thwart the Government's efforts to hold elections" in Kashmir on Thursday.

headline: SPENDING IT;Nanny-Tax Tally of '95: Who Paid, Who Lied?
abstract: LAST Monday, a New York City couple met with their accountant to file their 1995 taxes. They had an income of $100,000, a hefty mortgage and a nanny the Internal Revenue Service knew nothing about. And they kept it that way.         When their accountant came to line 53, which for the first time asks about household employment taxes, the couple lied, without hesitation.

headline: Maastricht Journal;Dutch Want Back the Fossil Napoleon Took Away
abstract: The full story of this quarrel begins in the age of dinosaurs when a giant reptile lost its head. When the head was found in a local quarry more than two centuries ago, it caused a sensation. No one had ever seen the likes of it, a fossil with wicked rows of teeth set in jaws more than three feet long.         Scientists, who named the monster Mosasaurus after the Maas River, which runs through this southern Dutch city, said this cousin and contemporary of the dinosaurs roamed the seas some 70 million years ago. To this day, every schoolchild in Maastricht goes to the local museum to marvel at the large and enigmatic skull. Or rather, they marvel at a plaster surrogate.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Rebounds on Bond Rally After Falling in Earlier Trading
abstract: The dollar rebounded from early declines yesterday as bond prices rallied after economic reports in the United States eased some concerns on inflation.         "The bond market came up, and people said, 'Fundamentally, there's nothing wrong with the dollar. Let's buy some cheap dollars,' " said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange at the Mellon Bank.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMGEN BUYS THREE MILLION SHARES OF REGENERON
abstract: Amgen Inc. said yesterday that it had bought three million shares of Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. for $48 million, increasing its stake in the biotechnology company to 17.7 percent from 6 percent. The two companies are working together to develop a treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease and a treatment for nerve pain in diabetics. The purchase price also includes warrants to buy an additional 700,000 Regeneron shares at $16 each. Exercise of the warrants, for an additional $11.2 million, would raise Amgen's stake to nearly 20 percent. Shares of Amgen, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., fell 6.25 cents, to $54.50. Regeneron, based in Tarrytown, N.Y., rose 87.5 cents, to $13.625.

headline: The Little Light Light That Could
abstract: Light-emitting diodes play a ubiquitous if humble role in today's electronic  world. They are the little dots of red or pale green light that indicate that the disk drive is spinning, the VCR is recording or a particular line of a multiline phone is in use.         Now, thanks to Shuji Nakamura, the tiny light-emitting chips are set for a vast expansion in usefulness.

headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;A Way to Make Money, and Help Close the Budget Gap
abstract: Q. I've heard you can make money reporting tax violations to the Internal Revenue Service. Is this true?

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;With a new sandwich and a $200 million campaign, McDonald's tries to win back older diners.
abstract: THE McDonald's Corporation, in its biggest marketing effort since it began flipping hamburgers 41 years ago, is betting $200 million -- the greatest gamble ever in the fast-food field -- that older consumers will want meals under the Golden Arches that are sophisticated enough not to bear the word "happy" or the  prefix "Mc" in their names.         At a glitzy news conference yesterday at Radio City Music Hall, McDonald's, the world's No. 1 fast feeder, introduced its initial offering in an ambitious array of menu items aimed at satisfying adult appetites. First off the grill is  the Arch Deluxe, a sandwich on a soft potato-flour roll with ingredients that include a quarter-pound beef patty, American cheese, lettuce, tomato, a "secret  sauce" of mayonnaise and two mustards and an optional slice of bacon.

headline: 'Silver' Starts to Boom in South Korea
abstract: SEOUL—  Many Western families undoubtedly would be pleased to see their elderly parents move into a luxurious retirement village. But for Lee Beom Hong and his wife, moving into La Vie D'Or, a first-class retirement home on the outskirts of Seoul, was tinged with embarrassment.

headline: Britain, Facing Setback in Court, Won't Deport Saudi Dissident
abstract: Facing an embarrassing reversal by the courts, the British Government today dropped its efforts to deport a leading Saudi dissident whose activities here angered the Saudi royal family and raised fears that lucrative British military  sales could be lost.         The Home Office, which is in charge of immigration affairs, called in the dissident, Mohammed al-Massari, for a half-hour conference and informed him that he was "given leave to remain" in the country for four years.

headline: Technology: CONNECTIONS;If life on the Web is postmodern, then maybe Foucault really was a Power Ranger.
abstract: THE bald, mischievous countenance of Michel Foucault no sooner appears on the computer screen than it starts to recede, the left half of his face twisting upward like elastic, the mouth curled into a slightly horrifying grin. A purple  haze begins to envelop the skull of the late French philosopher, which is marked with streaks of yellow. The grin pulls upward even further and the head starts to fade. Then, out of the mist some sort of creature comes into focus. As it pulls forward, the figure reveals itself as a blue-masked fighter, his fist coming out at the viewer in a blur of martial arts expertise. Foucault has morphed into a Power Ranger.         At least that is what happens when one downloads a video from the Web home page of Sherry Turkle, professor of the sociology of science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the author of a recent book, "Life on  the Screen." Ms. Turkle is now on the cover of Wired, and has been proclaimed by the computer veteran, Mitch Kapor, "the leading anthropologist of cyberspace." For more than a decade she has carried out interviews with cyberaddicts, chronicled the effect of computers on our psyches, and constructed theories about the Internet.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MUSICLAND POSTPONES PUBLIC OFFERING FOR UNIT
abstract: The Musicland Stores Corporation postponed the planned initial public offering of its Suncoast Motion Picture Company unit yesterday and said it would take a $35 million pretax restructuring charge in the first quarter. Musicland,  the nation's largest seller of prerecorded music and videos, also said its banks had agreed to provide more financial flexibility in return for an increase of half a percentage point in the interest rate on its debt. The company said it had decided to put off selling a 30 percent stake in Suncoast because it believed that the unit was worth more than the market wanted to pay. Musicland,  which is based in Minneapolis, had said in January that it hoped to sell 3 million of Suncoast's 10 million shares to the public at about $15 a share.

headline: HICKS, MUSE TO SET UP ANOTHER RADIO STATION GROUP
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. announced yesterday that it was committing as  much as $100 million to acquire a group of AM and FM radio stations in rapidly expanding medium-size markets. The move comes less than three months after Hicks, Muse, the leveraged-buyout firm based in Dallas, sold a batch of radio stations in large markets in an initial public offering. Hicks, Muse said the new group, to be named Capstar Broadcasting Inc., would be headed by R. Steven Hicks, who recently announced his resignation as chief executive of SFX Broadcasting Inc. Mr. Hicks, who is 46, is the brother of Thomas O. Hicks, the 50-year-old chairman and chief executive of Hicks, Muse.

headline: New Satellites For Arianespace
abstract: The West European rocket company Arianespace S.A. announced plans today to launch satellites for the United States satellite maker Space Systems/Loral Inc., as well as a simultaneous launching for Israel and Indonesia.         It said it signed an agreement to launch five satellites for Loral before the year 2000 and said its 86th launching, set for mid-May, would carry satellites for Israel and Indonesia into orbit.

headline: Economic Scene;A new rating of economies holds some surprises.
abstract: INDIVIDUALS compete. Corporations compete. But do whole economies compete? Writing in Foreign Affairs magazine two years ago, Paul Krugman of Stanford University labeled the idea "a dangerous obsession" used to rationalize government intervention on behalf of special interests and, more specifically, to justify trade protectionism.         He was not the only mainstream economist to reject the competition metaphor.  And the World Economic Forum, a Swiss-based foundation underwritten by big business that has published an annual "competitiveness report" since 1979, took  the criticism to heart. The organization dropped its association with the Institute for Management and Development in Lausanne, Switzerland, and turned to Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development,  for a make-over. "We wanted to take a second look at the competitiveness debate, as well as to give our members more practical information about investment opportunities," said Lobna Freih, a spokeswoman for the forum.

headline: Tenneco to Sell Its Gas Unit to El Paso Energy
abstract: Tenneco Inc., intent on transforming itself from a stumbling conglomerate into a nimble manufacturer, agreed today to sell its natural gas operations to the El Paso Energy Corporation for $750 million in stock and the assumption of debt and other liabilities.         Tenneco received a healthy price, analysts said, while El Paso Energy won the ability to form a coast-to-coast pipeline network that would make it one of the  nation's largest natural gas companies.

headline: Columbia/HCA to Pay Blue Cross Officials
abstract: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation will pay as much as $19 million to three top officers and an outside legal counsel of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio who engineered the insurer's pending sale to Columbia, Blue Cross disclosed today.         Columbia, which is based here and is the nation's largest hospital operator,  said in March that it would buy most operating units of the Blue Cross plan, a nonprofit mutual insurer, for $299.5 million. Terms of non-competition and consulting agreements were included in a filing with the Ohio Department of Insurance in Columbus.

headline: The Strange Competition With China's News Agency
abstract: When the official New China News Agency announced three months ago that it would start supervising international agencies that sell financial information in China, that decision was widely interpreted as an effort by the Communist Party to protect itself from the swelling pool of information available here.         Like so much in today's China, however, it now seems that the agency's plans  have more to do with its thirst for money and bureaucratic control than anything else. Last week, the New China News Agency detailed its plans for how to control the sale of financial information by the foreign agencies, Reuters and Dow Jones Tele-rate, a unit of Dow Jones & Company.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Texas Lottery Retains GSD & M
abstract: The Texas Lottery Commission in Austin has retained GSD & M in Austin to handle its account for another two years. Billings were estimated at $25 million to $30 million.          GSD & M, which has handled the assignment since 1992, was awarded the account last week after a two-month mandated review that narrowed to GSD & M and one other finalist: the Richards Group in Dallas.

headline: War Crimes Trial Seeks to Define the Balkan Conflict
abstract: Dusan Tadic, a Bosnian Serb and accused war criminal, sat through the first days of his trial this week looking pallid and shifting uneasily in his blue United Nations chair.         Much of the time, Mr. Tadic, a former cafe owner and policeman, simply stared across the courtroom, an ultramodern hall outfitted for this occasion with new computers and furnishings. He took notes as the prosecutor rose to list the charges of killing, rape and torture in the former Yugoslavia that brought Mr. Tadic to The Hague to face this United Nations war crimes tribunal.

headline: Laugh, and the Whole World . . .
abstract: Some of the best jokes come from our experiences at work. And with the advent E-mail, those jokes can spread like lightening, from desk to desk, city to city. Within minutes, Dallas can be laughing at the same joke that double-overed New York. These are the jokes we want to hear. Send your best office jokes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Business Travel;Fare Rises Seen After Shutdown By Valujet
abstract: Valujet's sudden shutdown this week will sharply increase fares along the routes previously flown by the low-cost carrier, according to travel agents and  others who watch air fares closely.         Tom Parsons, editor of Best Fares magazine, predicted yesterday that fares could increase as much as 70 percent in Valujet's former markets, while Blake Fleetwood, owner of Planetarium Travels in New York, predicted those fares would at least double.

headline: World News Briefs;Islamic Group Offers To Freeze Israel Raids
abstract: The military wing of the militant Islamic movement Hamas offered today to freeze attacks on Israelis in exchange for an end to the Israeli and Palestinian crackdown on its members.          There was no immediate response from the newly installed Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, but the statement was met with initial skepticism because the broad-based Islamic movement is believed to lack a central authority that could impose its control on both domestic and expatriate leaders.

headline: CS First Boston Registers Record Earnings
abstract: CS First Boston earned a record $108 million in the first quarter amid rising markets, booming stock and bond sales and a heavy pace of corporate mergers, according to an internal memo sent to employees yesterday.         The results compared with a loss of $2.2 million in the comparable quarter a  year earlier, when the firm took an $80 million restructuring charge. The company, owned by the Swiss banking group CS Holding A.G., is not required to disclose its earnings publicly.

headline: Tudor and S.E.C. In Talks on a Trade
abstract: Paul Tudor Jones, head of the Tudor Investment Corporation of New York, is in talks with the Securities and Exchange Commission over allegations that the firm violated a stock trading rule, the company said Friday.         The S.E.C. says Tudor violated the uptick rule, which says traders cannot sell a borrowed stock when the price of that stock is falling. That rule is supposed to keep short-sellers -- who borrow stocks and sell them in the hopes of buying them back at a lower price -- from manipulating prices by pushing them lower.

headline: Have I Got a Deal for You
abstract: To the Editor:         While cold calls from brokers, both reputable and boiler-room operators, have become a fact of everyday life, some are more creative than others ("A Sign of Bad Brokers: Tap Dancing at the Roach Motel," Investing It, May 5).

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;President Acquires Petry Latino
abstract: Carlos Barba, president of the Petry Latino Hispanic advertising sales division of Petry Television in New York, said yesterday that he had acquired the division through Netspan Inc., a holding company he owns with Marlin Entertainment, a communications company in New York. Terms were not disclosed.          Petry Latino, which has been renamed Netspan Latino, sells commercial time from offices in Miami and New York for broadcast and cable television networks and stations throughout the Caribbean and Latin America. Mr. Barba, 59, and Neal Frank, 38, president and chief executive at Marlin, were named to the additional posts of co-chairmen at Netspan Latino.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Svedala of Sweden Makes Finnish Bid
abstract: Svedala A.B., a Swedish producer of heavy machinery, offered yesterday to buy Tampella Oy, a Finnish maker of metal and forestry goods, in a stock swap worth  1.8 billion kronor ($269 million). Kvaerner A.S., the largest shipbuilder in Europe, is the largest shareholder in Tampella. Neither Tampella nor Kvaerner took a position on the bid yesterday.          The stock swap offer is set at a 38 percent premium to Tampella's closing share price on Tuesday, Svedala said. In Helsinki yesterday, Tampella shares jumped 30 percent, while in Stockholm trading, the shares of Svedala fell 2.3 percent.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Tread Carefully With China, Business Leaders Urge U.S.
abstract: Chief executives in major industries, meeting here with Government officials  today, expressed concern that the Administration's looming showdown with China over piracy of American music, movies and software could set off a wider trade conflict and endanger their ability to compete in the vast Chinese market.         Some members of the Business Council, an organization of chief executives from 100 of the country's largest companies, warned the Administration that it should not allow differences with Beijing over specific issues, including piracy, human rights and the spread of nuclear technology, to poison the broader political and economic relationships between the United States and China.

headline: The Peacock Preens Again
abstract: AT the Capital Cities/ABC annual management meeting in February, in what amounted to his farewell address after the company merged with Walt Disney, Tom  Murphy, the chairman of Cap Cities, had a message for his troops:         "How can you let those engineers beat us?" Mr. Murphy asked. "Those guys make M.R.I. machines."

headline: London Bombs Were Huge, Police Say
abstract: Two bombs that partly detonated beneath the Hammersmith Bridge together contained one of the largest amounts of explosive material planted in Britain by the I.R.A., Scotland Yard said today.         The bombs, contained in separate boxes but described by police as "a complete device," exploded under the south end of the bridge on Wednesday night, the third anniversary of a large Irish Republican Army bomb in the heart of London's financial district that killed one person and injured 45 others.

headline: A New Way to Search for Oil, Via Satellite
abstract: Like many a deep-sea fisherman, Richard A. Morneau obsesses about the ones that got away. Take, for example, the whopper off the Angolan coast three years  ago -- a big deep water oilfield that Mr. Morneau, a geophysicist for the Chevron Corporation, still suspects was down there.         But months had elapsed by the time the ship's seismic readings could be processed by a supercomputer back on land, yielding clues on where to probe further for petroleum. And only then were errors discovered in the original navigational data. The company could not relocate that promising fishing hole.

headline: New Israel Premier Accepts Religious Party Terms
abstract: Agreements signed by Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu and his religious party allies in the incoming Israeli government have spelled out the price that the Orthodox Jewish parties exacted for taking part in the new coalition.         The three religious parties won 23 seats in Parliament, and their support is  vital for Mr. Netanyahu, whose own Likud Party won only 32 seats. He needs the support of at least 61 lawmakers in the 120-member legislature, and the religious parties have bargained hard to increase Orthodox control over public and private life in Israel, and to secure generous state financing for their schools and educational programs.

headline: North Korean Soldiers Fire Shots in the DMZ, Seoul Says
abstract: Seven North Korean soldiers entered the tense demilitarized zone between the  two Koreas today and fired shots in the air before retreating when South Korean  troops fired warning shots, the Seoul Government said.         The North Korean soldiers crossed the demarcation line in the middle of the DMZ, technically intruded into South Korea by 20 or 30 yards, according to statements by the South.

headline: A Shareholder-Rights Leader Is Leaving Calpers
abstract: The California Public Employees Retirement System, the largest and most prominent player in the shareholder-rights movement, is about to lose its voice  for a while.         Richard H. Koppes, 49, the general counsel and No. 2 executive at the $99 billion pension fund, said yesterday that he would announce his resignation today, effective July 31. His departure is likely to slow, at least in the short term, the movement's efforts to hold the nation's chief executives accountable for their performance.

headline: Meeting of Burmese Dissidents Is Denounced by Government
abstract: The Burmese military rulers denounced the opposition today for going ahead with its most important meeting since the junta crushed elections in 1990.         The authorities arrested 238 conference delegates and 24 other party members  to try to block the dissident leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and her National League for Democracy, from opening its three-day conference on Sunday. But even  though only 18 delegates have made it, the meeting has proceeded as scheduled.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Ford Will Shift A Leasing Unit To a Subsidiary
abstract: The Ford Motor Company, which said last month that it would sell a vehicle leasing business owned by its U.S.L. Capital arm, announced today that it would  simply shift the business to one of its subsidiaries.         Ford said that the Associates First Capital Corporation, a finance company in which it holds an 80.7 percent stake, would pay U.S.L. about $875 million for the leasing business, known as Fleet Services. Ford said the deal, between the two divisions of its Financial Services Group, had been subject to competitive bidding that included outside companies. A Ford spokeswoman, Mary Joseph, said that Associates bid was the highest and that Salomon Brothers had issued an independent fairness opinion on the deal.

headline: COURT TOSSES OUT AN ASBESTOS DEAL
abstract: A Federal appeals court threw out a landmark $1.3 billion class-action settlement yesterday that would have limited future health claims of hundreds of thousands of workers and their families against 20 major asbestos producers.
