The 1993 proposal had been attacked by public interest groups, who argued that it stripped away the rights of future litigants. But its advocates had promoted the plan as a model that companies that produced asbestos or other toxic materials could follow to protect themselves against the uncertainty surrounding potential claims by those who have not yet developed any signs of illness.

headline: Deal Comes as Atlantic City Is on a Roll
abstract: With its deal to acquire Bally Entertainment, Hilton Hotels is buying a place at the table in Atlantic City, the East Coast's largest gambling center, just as the Boardwalk rolls toward a major expansion of its ambitions.         The city's plans are buoyed by growing revenue and the sense that casino gambling will not be legalized in nearby states.

headline: Knudsen Sets Merger With Washington
abstract: The Morrison Knudsen Corporation said today that it had agreed to merge with  Washington Construction Group Inc. in a deal that would erase its $350 million debt by giving creditors a big stake in the new company.         Washington Construction, a much smaller construction concern based in Highland, Calif., would acquire Morrison Knudsen for about $205.3 million in cash and stock and would assume as much as $50 million in outstanding loans. The deal would create a $2.2 billion company with a much stronger position in the construction and engineering industry.

headline: A Restitution Maze
abstract: To the Editor:

headline: Bet on a Young Author Pays Off in Foreign Sales
abstract: If it is the aspiring writer's dream to publish a book while very young, the  reality is that it happens rarely. Truman Capote was 24, Carson McCullers, 23; Gore Vidal and Brett Easton Ellis both 21, and Joyce Maynard, 20, when their first books appeared in print.         Next spring, G. P. Putnam's Sons, a unit of MCA, which is owned by the Seagram Company, plans to publish "Necessary Madness," a first novel by a writer whose book has easily managed to snag foreign rights, audiocassette and Book-of-the-Month Club sales and who is even younger than the writers mentioned  above. Indeed, when Putnam made its offer on March 30, the author, Jenn Crowell, was three weeks shy of her 18th birthday, and in the midst of completing both her senior year of high school and her first year of college in a special program at Goucher College in Towson, Md.

headline: Britain Asks Europe to Pay Most of Cost of Killing Cows
abstract: In an effort to rebuild its shattered beef industry, Britain pressed its European partners on Monday to finance 80 percent of the cost of destroying some four million cattle during the next five years, but the European Community today seemed set to offer 70 percent.         Britain has proposed the culling -- at a cost estimated at $700 million or more -- as part of a strategy to contain mad cow disease, coax consumers back to British beef and get the European Community to end the ban on British beef exports that it imposed last week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;What do Chevrolet, Conde Nast and Macy's have in common? A customer base of young women.
abstract: FOR decades, the Detroit auto makers marketed to women about as successfully  as Ford sold Edsels or Cadillac sold Cimarrons. All that has changed, however, as the Big Three belatedly recognized how much power women wielded in the purchasing process and how ardently women were being wooed by Japanese car companies.         An example of that seminal shift is an ambitious cross-promotional program linking the Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation with a leading  retailer, the Macy's East unit of Federated Department Stores, and women's magazines owned by the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications.

headline: Famine Threat Drives Thousands of Somalis From Homes
abstract: In the last six weeks, more than 9,000 people have fled from food shortages caused by drought, floods and clan warfare in the Juba River valley, just north  of this devastated port city, United Nations officials and local Somali leaders  say.         For weeks, tattered groups of malnourished people, mostly women and children, have been straggling into Kismayu from the ravaged lands to the north. About 6,000 displaced people now live in makeshift camps around the city.

headline: Mutiny Ends in Central African Republic
abstract: French troops drove mutinous soldiers back to their barracks today in Bangui, the Central African Republic's capital.         Most mutineers ended their revolt quietly on Monday. A few seemed reluctant to leave the streets, but when confronted by French troops they filed into trucks to be taken back to the barracks. France, the former colonial power, intervened at the Government's request.

headline: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet Dies; Paris Advertising Giant Was 89
abstract: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, the grade-school dropout who gave France its first advertising agency, its first radio news programs and its first opinion polls before capping his visionary business career with the startling invention of Le  Drugstore, died on Thursday at his home in Paris.         He was 89 and had been active until a few weeks ago as chairman of Publicis,  the giant advertising agency he founded as a teen-ager in 1926.

headline: Fewer File First Claims for Jobless Benefits
abstract: The number of first-time claims for jobless benefits fell by 12,000 last week to the lowest level in four months, the Labor Department said today. New applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 336,000, down from 348,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, when claims fell by 24,000.         Last week's total is the smallest number of new claims since 316,000 were filed in the week that ended on Jan. 13, when the blizzard along the East Coast  and severe weather elsewhere kept many laid-off workers from visiting unemployment offices.

headline: Urohealth-Galileo Pact
abstract: Urohealth Systems Inc. signed a letter of intent today to enter a joint distribution agreement with the Galileo Electro-Optics Corporation. Urohealth will have exclusive rights to offer Galileo's rigid and flexible endoscopes for  all urological and gynecological applications. Galileo Electro-Optics makes fiber optic and electro-optic components, which transmit, sense or intensify light or images. Urohealth's stock was up 62.5 cents, to $14.75, and Galileo gained $2.50, to $23.625. Both stocks hit new 52-week highs during the day.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DATA DIMENSIONS RISE, AGAIN
abstract: The shares of Data Dimensions Inc. rose yesterday for a second day after the  billionaire investor George Soros and his affiliates bought an 8.08 percent stake in the computer consulting company. Shares of the company, based in Bellevue, Wash., rose $5.625, to $39.25, in Nasdaq trading. The shares are up 40 percent since Monday. Data Dimensions is working on a solution to the so-called  millennium crisis. Many of the world's mainframe computers are not prepared to recognize dates after Dec. 31, 1999.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McCann-Erickson Acquires Ad:vent
abstract: McCann-Erickson North America in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, acquired Ad:vent, an event marketing and promotion agency owned by Adcom Industries Inc. in New York, and merged it with its existing event and promotion agency, Momentum IMC in New York. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.          The combined agency, operating as Momentum IMC, has 40 employees and combined billings estimated at $12 million from clients like AT&T and the General Motors Corporation. L. Anthony Pace, 38, and Mark Driscoll, 45, who have headed Momentum, continue to do so as managing directors, and Mark Dowley, 31, who headed Ad:vent, becomes the third managing director. The three report to James Heekin, president of McCann North America.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER EARNINGS WARNING, HYPERION SHARES TUMBLE
abstract: Shares of the Hyperion Software Corporation plunged yesterday, a day after the company warned of disappointing earnings. The stock tumbled $7.375, or almost 40 percent, to $11.125, in Nasdaq trading of 8.9 million shares. Hyperion, which specializes in financial management software, said late Wednesday that it expected earnings for its third quarter of about 2 cents a share. Among other things, sales were hurt by delays in closings of some sales contracts.

headline: Netanyahu Is Ready to Talk to Syria, but Not to Yield
abstract: Prime Minister-elect Benjamin Netanyahu today issued official policy guidelines confirming that his Government does not intend to cede the Golan Heights to Syria or to allow a Palestinian state, but declaring that he is ready for negotiations with both the Syrians and the Palestinian Authority.         The guidelines were released as Mr. Netanyahu raced against a self-imposed deadline to have a Cabinet and a parliamentary coalition formed in time to present to the new Parliament when it holds its first meeting, on Monday.

headline: Consumers Feel Less Confident, Survey Shows
abstract: Consumers felt markedly less confident about the economy this month, displaying a pessimism that could herald a slowdown in economic growth during the second half of the year, the Conference Board's monthly sampling of households showed today.         The business research group said its overall index of confidence skidded nearly 6 points, to 97.6, the lowest since January, and the second consecutive decline since reaching a six-year high of 104.8 in April. The rating was lower in seven of the nine geographic regions, with New England and the Southwest showing improvement.

headline: Let's Meet, People!
abstract: Narcolepsy Chicken. Never heard of it? It's a game meant to alleviate the boredom of business meetings. Stanley Bing, who writes a pseudonymous humor column for Esquire, says the game involves seeing how close you can come to nodding off without actually doing so. Do you have a similar survival tactic, or any story about business meetings, that bane of workers everywhere? Send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: TAKING IN THE SITES;The ABC's of Buying Foreign Stocks
abstract: Despite the incessant talk of a global economy, individuals who want to invest overseas might find that foreign stock exchanges seem very far away indeed.         While it has always been easy for American investors to act on a hunch that the Boeing Company stock was going to go into the stratosphere, trying to do the same with a company like British Aerospace P.L.C. has proven to be both difficult and expensive. The only affordable options usually were either to buy  foreign companies that list their shares on American exchanges or entrust American mutual funds to do the international stock-picking.

headline: Russia Given a Deal to Repay $40 Billion Debt
abstract: Russia got up to seven years' more breathing space today on repaying more than $40 billion of the accumulated debt it owes to foreign governments, possibly giving another lift to President Boris N. Yeltsin's prospects for re-election this summer.         Russian negotiators went into talks with 18 creditor nations here on Thursday asking for a rescheduling plan that would give them up to 25 years to pay off the credits, seven more years than the creditors' group has ever given before.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHARMACEUTICAL PRODUCT TO BUY BIOSCIENCE
abstract: Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Applied Bioscience International Inc. for stock worth as much as $467 million, creating one of the largest publicly traded pharmaceutical contract research organizations. Shareholders of Applied Bioscience, based in Arlington, Va., will receive between 0.3125 and 0.4054 share of Pharmaceutical Product stock for each share of Applied Bioscience. Based on Thursday's closing prices, the transaction values each Applied Bioscience share at $12.34 to $16.01. Applied Bioscience's shares jumped $2.4375, to $11.5625, while Pharmaceutical Product fell $4.50 a share, to $35, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

headline: Texas Utilities to Acquire Pipeline Owner
abstract: The Texas Utilities Company has agreed to acquire the Enserch Corporation, which owns one of the largest natural-gas pipelines in the nation, in a deal valued at about $1.7 billion, Texas Utilities said yesterday.         The company, based in Dallas, owns two utilities, the Texas Utilities Electric Company and the Southwestern Electric Service Company, which serve about 2.4 million customers in Texas.

headline: The Hague Journal;A Most Artful Forger Now Beguiles the Dutch
abstract: Harry Anderson, an American Army captain, was taken aback that day at the end of World War II when he walked into the deserted country home of Hermann Goring, the Nazi leader. Captain Anderson, an art historian in civilian life, had spotted an unknown painting bearing the signature of the 17th-century Dutch master Johannes Vermeer.         Not long afterward, a Dutchman who had apparently earned a fortune selling the work to Goring was arrested and jailed in Amsterdam. Han van Meegeren, a painter, was charged with treason for selling part of the national patrimony to  the enemy.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: COMPUSERVE INC., Columbus, Ohio, a unit of H & R Block Inc., said Alexander Trevor, vice president and chief technical officer, had resigned.

headline: Equity Offerings That Are Planned for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Adeza Biomedical Corp., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.5  million shares. Prudential Securities.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Poppe Tyson Buys Marshall Jaccoma
abstract: Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt that offers services like advertising and interactive marketing, said yesterday that  it had acquired Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell in New York. Terms were not disclosed.         Bo Mitchell, 45, president and chief executive at Marshall Jaccoma, will become a senior partner at Poppe Tyson, and Daniel S. Marshall, 58, executive vice president and creative director, will become a senior partner for creative. George E. Jacomma, 56, who had retired this year as chairman of Marshall Jaccoma to become a consultant to that agency, becomes a consultant to Poppe Tyson.

headline: Military Unprepared For Force of Attack
abstract: The United States had received a wave of threats against Americans and American installations in Saudi Arabia in recent weeks but failed to prepare adequately for a bomb of the size that killed 19 American military personnel on  Tuesday, Clinton Administration officials said.          The Defense Department said it did all it reasonably could to protect service personnel, including the installation of concrete barriers around military installations. But one official said, "The surprise is not that there was an attack; the surprise is the severity of the attack."

headline: Indian Center-Left Coalition Gains in Bid to Block Hindu Party
abstract: The momentum in India's post-election maneuvering appeared today to be working against the formation of the country's first Hindu nationalist government and in favor of a center-left coalition that would govern with the backing of the Congress Party.         Still reeling from its election debacle, the Congress Party met and re-elected the outgoing Prime Minister, P. V. Narasimha Rao, as leader of its parliamentary group, leaving until later a decision on his more important post as president of the party. A meeting of senior party leaders decided earlier in  the day to offer support to a center-left coalition, but to remain outside any new government.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;U.S.-Backed Pact Puts Japan In New Role in Asian Finance
abstract: Japan has concluded a currency pact with seven neighboring countries in an effort to expand its role in guarding against turmoil in the currency markets in Asia.         Under the arrangements, announced on Thursday, Japan would effectively lend money to the seven central banks against United States Treasury securities and then reverse those deals in what are called repurchase agreements.

headline: Molson Chief Set to Retire
abstract: The Molson Companies, the Canadian brewing giant, said today that its president and chief executive, Marshall Cohen, plans to retire later this year.          Mr. Cohen, 61, will continue in office until his successor is appointed, the  company said in a statement.

headline: Palestinians In Gaza Arrest Rights Activist
abstract: A prominent Palestinian human rights advocate has been arrested in Gaza, after accusing the Palestinian Authority in a newspaper interview of dictatorial rule and of torturing prisoners, his associates said today.         The arrest of Dr. Eyad R. Sarraj, a psychiatrist who heads the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens Rights, was the latest case in what has become a pattern of harassment of human rights workers and journalists in Gaza who have publicly criticized the authority, which is the Palestinian self-rule government, and its security forces.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WEIRTON STEEL MOVES TO TRIM JOBS AND RETIRE DEBT
abstract: The Weirton Steel Corporation will cut 200 management and supervisory jobs and pay up to $100 million to retire long-term debt under a restructuring plan announced yesterday. Richard K. Riederer, the president and chief executive, said additional job cuts had not been ruled out. He said Weirton would lose money this year but would emerge stronger after the restructuring. The company expects to incur a cash cost of $17 million in the second quarter related to the job cuts, and will take a $6 million after-tax charge for retiring the long-term debt. The debt restructuring calls for issuing $125 million in new bonds to pay off up to $100 million in securities maturing in 1998 and 1999.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Payrolls Rose in March; Hopes Dashed for Rate Cut Employers added a hefty 140,000 new jobs to their payrolls in March, providing solid evidence that the economy is in better shape than it appeared a couple of  months ago. The jobless rate was little changed, edging up one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A twist on film product placements: a movie character in a milk ad.
abstract: HOW do you make a phantom more visible? Paramount Pictures hopes a milk mustache helps.         In an overcrowded summer movie season, which officially begins Friday, Paramount is concerned about enticing enough filmgoers to "The Phantom," an action-adventure based on the comic-strip character that opens June 7. "The Phantom" was nowhere to be seen in articles about the summer movies this week in Time and Newsweek magazines.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Drop On Treasuries For a 2d Day
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities dropped for a second straight day yesterday, despite a Government report that housing starts fell 3.9 percent last month. Much like the weak manufacturing report earlier this week, it failed to ease investor concern that the economy might be poised for an inflationary rebound.         The 30-year bond fell 7/32, to a price of 89 24/32 to yield 6.81 percent, up  from 6.79 percent on Tuesday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DUTCH BANK PLANS TO ACQUIRE CNBC BANCORP
abstract: The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding N.V. said yesterday that it would acquire the Chicago-based CNBC Bancorp, the holding company for Columbia National Bank of Chicago. Terms were not disclosed. Columbia National Bank has $850 million in assets and 280 employees. After the takeover, it would become part of the ABN Amro LaSalle banking group, which has total assets of about $15.6 billion.

headline: Israel Lets an Old Foe Enter West Bank
abstract: Israel agreed today to allow a Palestinian guerrilla leader who was once one  of its most wanted enemies to enter Palestinian-ruled areas, officials said.         "Israel approved today the entry of Nayef Hawatmeh, General Secretary of the  Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine," said Jamil al-Tarifi, the head of a Palestinian liaison committee with Israel.

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;NETANYAHU NARROW VICTOR; SETS OUT TO FORM A CABINET AND ASSURE ARAB NEIGHBORS
abstract: Confirmed as the winner in Israel's leadership race by the narrowest of margins, Benjamin Netanyahu turned today to the task of reassuring anxious Arab  neighbors and sifting candidates for a new Cabinet.         After counting absentee ballots through much of the day, the Israeli Election Commission finally declared Mr. Netanyahu the winner over Prime Minister Shimon  Peres by 29,457 votes, 1,501,023 to 1,471,566.

headline: Insignia Financial to Acquire Edward S. Gordon Company
abstract: Insignia Financial Group, the huge property management company in Greenville, S.C., announced yesterday that it would acquire the Edward S. Gordon Company, New York's largest commercial real estate company, for about $74 million.         The acquisition -- two-thirds in cash and one-third in stock -- would give Insignia, already the country's largest manager of multifamily properties, its first real toehold in the commercial office and retail market in the New York metropolitan region. The deal would give the Edward S. Gordon Company, a 25-year-old privately held company whose management has been toying with the idea of going national for five years, a chance to do so.

headline: Japan Girds for Trial of Sect Leader in Nerve-Gas Attack
abstract: With more than 2,000 police officers enforcing rigid security, Japan braced itself this morning for the beginning of what is billed here as the "trial of the century" as Shoko Asahara entered a courtroom to face charges of ordering the nerve gas attack in the Tokyo subway system last year.         Mr. Asahara, the bearded, half-blind sect leader, was escorted from a detention center to the courthouse today in a bus with closed curtains, part of  a six-vehicle convoy that whisked through Tokyo on an expressway that for most of its length had been cleared of traffic. Fifteen helicopters hovered overhead, at least one operated by the police but most used by television stations to broadcast the spectacle live across Japan.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bristol-Myers Unit Assigns Brands
abstract: Mead Johnson & Company in Evansville, Ind., a subsidiary of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company, has assigned brands to the two agencies that it selected in late March to handle its account, with billings estimated at $30 million.          Peter J. Spengler, vice president for marketing services at Bristol-Myers Squibb in New York, said that Wells Rich Greene BDDP in New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, would handle assignments in the United States like the Boost brand of nutrition supplements and Theragran vitamins, as well as responsibilities for all Mead Johnson brands in Europe. Bozell Worldwide in New  York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, was named to handle the Enfamil, Next Step and Prosobee baby formula brands and the Sustacal nutritional drink for adults.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Priest Said to Leave France After Criticism
abstract: Abbe Pierre, an elderly priest regularly voted France's most popular man, has left the country after a dispute over his support for the author of a book which casts doubt on the Holocaust, a magazine reported today.         Abbe Pierre, 83, who sheltered Jews during World War II and founded a chain of homeless shelters, became embroiled in controversy last month when he backed  his friend Roger Garaudy, whose book "The Founding Myths of Israeli Politics," doubts the widely accepted fact that the Nazis killed six million Jews in World  War II.

headline: SPENDING IT;Life at Sea Is Lonelier If You Want Insurance
abstract: AN ill wind is buffeting pleasure boaters this year as they prepare to launch their craft for the spring.         Devastating hurricanes out of the Caribbean in recent years have given insurance companies the jitters -- making boat insurance harder to find and more expensive in the southeastern United States and the Caribbean. Even some boaters who reside in the north are shifting their schedules to avoid troubled waters or deciding to travel without insurance.

headline: Treasury Announces Schedule to Sell Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.         By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.03 percent and a six-month bill was 5.14  percent.

headline: Sri Lanka Reports Gains Against Rebels
abstract: As part of a major campaign against separatist rebels, Sri Lankan Army units  have pushed into two towns deep in rebel territory on the Jaffna Peninsula, military officials and rebel radio said today.         The military stopped short of saying the towns had been captured, indicating  rebel forces may still be in control of the town centers. But the move isolated  Chavakachcheri, the largest city still held by rebels in the peninsula, which has long been a rebel stronghold. Guerrillas of the ethnic Tamil separatists, called the Tamil Tigers, are believed to have withdrawn from Chavakachcheri.

headline: Bomb Kills 9 at Guest House in New Delhi
abstract: A powerful bomb in the heart of New Delhi ripped through a guest house popular among foreign backpackers tonight, killing at least 9 people and wounding 37, the police said.         There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing, the fifth in  the Indian capital since September.

headline: Clinton Reported Close to a Limited Ban on Land Mines
abstract: President Clinton is close to a decision to ban land mines within several years, but he is expected to approve an exemption that could allow the continued use of the weapons in Korea and for mine-disposal training, Administration officials said today.

headline: EUROPEAN TOPICS : Strasbourg Mayor Courts Muslims With a Mosque
abstract: In an oddity of history, the 2,000 priests, pastors and rabbis of Alsace, unlike their counterparts in the rest of France, are appointed and paid by the state. And Strasbourg, the region's largest city, has France's only two state-run theology schools.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BIG FLOWER PRESS TO BUY SCANFORMS IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Big Flower Press Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Scanforms Inc. for about $26.5 million, including debt. Scanforms, a direct-mail company in Bristol, Pa., had about $27 million in revenue for the 12 months that ended on March 31. Big Flower's Webcraft Technologies Inc. produces direct-mail products, promotional games and stamps and lottery tickets. Under the deal, Big Flower will acquire Scanforms in a stock swap that values the company at $5.75 a share. Scanform's shares jumped $1.5625, to $5.125; Big Flower's shares were unchanged at $13.875. New York-based Big Flower publishes advertising circulars  and television listings for newspapers and Sunday comics.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Remy Cointreau Profit Hurt by Cognac Slump
abstract: The French liquor and wine company Remy Cointreau said yesterday that its revenue in the year that ended on March 31 rose 1.2 percent, but the company said it expected to report lower profit for the year. Remy Cointreau attributed  the profit drop to a 13.5 percent decline in cognac sales. In the 1995 fiscal year, the company earned 276 million francs (about $54 million).          Price increases across the board held sales volume down during the year, the company said. The Champagne division posted the largest percentage gain, with sales rising 25.7 percent. Sales of liquor, wine and spirits rose 3.9 percent.   (AP)

headline: Nintendo Capitalism: Zapping The Markets;Fast Electronic Trading Brings Increased Volatility
abstract: It's 7:29 A.M. high above South LaSalle Street and Patrick Beimford, the chief bond strategist of Zurich Kemper Investments, is poised like an orchestra  conductor in front of three electronic screens. He and more than a dozen highly  paid young traders and portfolio managers scan intently.         Then, exactly at 7:30, multicolored electronics flash the Government's eagerly awaited tally of consumer prices and retail sales for April -- favorable figures, as it happens, for the bond market that prompt an almost instant flurry of staccato barks and orders.

headline: Both Sides Question Value of Unification : East-West Gap Looms Ever Wider
abstract: IN November 1989, when peaceful demonstrations in Communist East Germany triggered the opening of the Berlin Wall, the slogan was:"We Are The People."Soon the message of demonstrators changed to "We Are One People," leading to Germany's reunification in October 1990.Today, half a decade after those events, there are no demonstrations.But if there were, the signs would probably read:"We Are Two Peoples."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;National Power Plans A Special Dividend
abstract: National Power P.L.C., a British electricity generating company, announced a  special dividend yesterday of about L1.14 billion, or about $1.71 billion. National Power said investors would get the dividend of $1 a share subject to their approval of a L1.7 billion ($2.55 billion) sale of power plants to the Eastern Group, a regional utility.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: AMNEX INC., New York, a provider of long-distance services, agreed to buy Capital Network Systems of Austin, Tex., which also provides long-distance service, for about $15 million.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Re Says Profit Rose 17.4% Last Year
abstract: The Swiss Reinsurance Company said yesterday that its net income rose 17.4 percent in 1995 as investment income rose, claims payouts fell and a one-time gain helped earnings. Profit of the company rose to 1.095 billion Swiss francs ($887 million), the highest in its history, from 932 million francs a year earlier.          Swiss Re, the world's second-largest reinsurance company behind Munich Re of Germany, said after-tax profit before extraordinary items and payments rose 53 percent, to 1.09 billion francs from 709 million francs. The company said it had a one-time gain of 11 million francs. Swiss Re said it planned to pay a dividend of 22.5 Swiss francs a share, up from 15 a year earlier.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Havana Journal;25 Years an Exile: An Old Black Panther Sums Up
abstract: More than a quarter of a century after he sought political asylum in Cuba, William Lee Brent still seems American to the core. He speaks a Spanish tinged with the Louisiana accent of his boyhood, prefers whisky to rum, and continues to focus his attention on many of the same causes he once espoused as a member of the Black Panther Party.         But Mr. Brent has cast his lot with the Cuban revolution, and even if he wanted to, he could not return to the land of his birth. He arrived here in 1969 after hijacking an airliner bound for New York from San Francisco with 76 people on board, and after all these years he remains a fugitive from American justice.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Mercury goes high tech to sell its first sport utility vehicle.
abstract: THE Ford Motor Company hopes to make a splash er, crash -- with television commercials for the Mountaineer, the first sport utility vehicle to be marketed  under the Mercury nameplate.         In the spots, by the Detroit office of Young & Rubicam Inc., a mountain floating in the sky thunders to earth, landing on a deserted highway. The 1997 Mountaineer rests atop the mountain, moved there through computerized special effects by Digital Domain, the same company that produced visual effects for the movie "Terminator 2."

headline: On Coastal Road in Lebanon, Tempting Fate (and Shells)
abstract: By its 14th day today, the war had a rhythm.         Israel's daily heavy shelling of southern villages and the coastal road at dawn was followed by the expected brief lull. By noon, the road south had become a drag strip of taxis, supply trucks and ambulances racing past two Israeli gunboats sitting quietly on the horizon.

headline: Shares of Ford's Finance Unit Leap 20%
abstract: Shares of the Associates First Capital Corporation jumped about 20 percent yesterday in the first day of trading, making the Ford Motor Company unit the biggest publicly owned consumer finance company.         Associates First's stock, which was priced for an initial public offering at  $29, gained $5.75, closing at $34.75 on the New York Stock Exchange. With 25.4 million shares changing hands, it was the second-most-active issue on American markets.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;MERCK & CO. (MRK,N)
abstract: Merck & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 14 percent, propelled by sales of its cholesterol-lowering drug Zocor and the addition of newer products including Fosamax, a treatment for osteoporosis.         Merck, the nation's biggest drug maker, said net income rose to $863.8 million, or 70 cents a share, from $757.4 million, or 61 cents, in the comparable period a year ago.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: To Encourage Savings, A U.S. Bond Tied to Inflation In an effort to get Americans to save more, the Treasury announced plans to issue a new type of Government bond that would protect average investors from inflation as well as help the Government finance the national debt.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;House Moves to Prevent Use of Journalists as Spies
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency would be prohibited from using journalists as spies under a House proposal passed overwhelmingly today. But the C.I.A. could still use its own agents in the guise of journalists.         In a 417-6 vote, the House approved an amendment to an overall budget for espionage that would prohibit intelligence agencies, including the C.I.A., from  using American media representatives for intelligence-gathering.

headline: G.M. Strike Drags Down Industrial Output
abstract: Weighed down by a 17-day strike at the General Motors Corporation, industrial output slumped five-tenths of 1 percent in March to match the biggest declines since the final stages of the 1990-91 recession, the Federal Reserve reported today.         But excluding the lost output of vehicles and parts, production climbed three-tenths of 1 percent to support the growing consensus that the economic boiler has picked up steam but is no danger of overheating.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION MAKES OFFER FOR COMMERCIAL INTERTECH
abstract: United Dominion Industries said yesterday that it had made an offer of $27 a  share in cash for the Commercial Intertech Corporation, a manufacturing company  in Youngstown, Ohio. Shares of Commercial Intertech fell 25 cents, to $19.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange before the offer was disclosed. United  Dominion, which is based in Charlotte, N.C., said that the total consideration it was offering was about $500 million, including assumption of debt. United Dominion manufactures engineered products for industrial and building markets.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;EQUITABLE COS. (EQ,N)
abstract: The Equitable Companies reported a rise of nearly 28 percent in first-quarter profit yesterday, citing higher income from insurance products and gains at its  investment businesses from a surging stock market.         The financial-services conglomerate earned $83.3 million, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter ended March 31, compared with $65.2 million, or 32 cents a share, in the 1995 quarter.

headline: Accord in Drug Case Set at $351 Million
abstract: A Federal judge approved a $351.3 million settlement of a lawsuit against drug companies accused of conspiring to deny brand-name discounts to independent pharmacists.         Article, page 33.

headline: Enron Joint Venture
abstract: The Enron Corporation said today that it had concluded negotiations on a joint venture to build a $300 million regasification plant in the Jordanian Red  Sea port of Aqaba. Rebecca Mark, chairwoman of the Enron Development Corporation, said that negotiations with its Israeli and Jordanian partners had  ended and that she expected the parties would sign an agreement in the next couple of weeks. The plant would supply Jordan and Israel with liquefied natural gas from Qatar, on the Persian Gulf, beginning in 2001.

headline: FILENET STOCK FALLS ON QUARTERLY LOSS FORECAST
abstract: Shares of the Filenet Corporation fell 21 percent yesterday after the company said late Monday that it would report a loss for its first quarter of about $12  million, or 72 cents a share, because of one-time expenses. The company, a maker of document-imaging software based in Costa Mesa, Calif., also said its quarterly income before the charges -- for merger and reorganization costs and a write-off from the acquisition of International Financial Systems Ltd. in January -- would fall short of Wall Street estimates. Filenet stock fell $12.125, to $45.75 a share, in trading on the Nasdaq.

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: IN THE REGION;Arab Leaders Seem Ready To Search for a New Unity
abstract: Bracing themselves for the return of a Likud Government in Israel, Arab leaders reached out to one another today in contacts that included surprise talks between the Egyptian Foreign Minister and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.         The hasty diplomacy appeared part of a quest for new Arab solidarity in the face of Israeli election results regarded in Arab capitals as disruptive and even alarming.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Azon Supports Illinois Tool's Bid
abstract: Illinois Tool Works of Glenview, Ill., has offered $302.6 million (Australian), or $240 million (United States), for Azon Ltd., trumping a rival offer from Pacific BBA Industries Pty. Ltd.         Directors of Azon, the Australian hardware and industrial products maker, recommended shareholders accept the Illinois Tool offer of $2.47 (Australian) a  share, including a 7-cent special dividend.

headline: Scrap Steel Venture Is Formed in Trinidad
abstract: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. and the LTV Corporation said today that they had agreed to form a $150 million joint venture to make scrap steel in Trinidad for the steel industry.         The Cleveland-based companies each will own 46.5 percent of the venture, to be called Cliffs & Associates Ltd. Lurgi A.G., a unit of Metallgesellschaft A.G., of Germany will own the rest.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Find cyberspace too male-oriented? A cosmetics company hopes to draw its customers on line.
abstract: CLINIQUE, the No. 2 vendor of women's cosmetics in department stores, is going to cyberspace to jazz up its image.         The company, which in March introduced a World Wide Web site (http://www.clinique.com) that offers personalized product consultations, will distribute special Internet starter kits to customers at 1,500 retailers nationwide starting in July.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Language Lapse Cited In Colombia Air Crash
abstract: The air traffic controller who handled the American Airlines plane that crashed in Colombia on Dec. 20 thought that the crew's request for routing made  no sense, but his English was not good enough to tell them, a report released today by the National Transportation Safety Board and Colombian authorities said.         A transcript of the cockpit voice recorder, also released today, indicates that the pilot and co-pilot were confused about the plane's location.

headline: U.S. to Pay for Rights Monitors in Burundi
abstract: The United States will provide $1.3 million for human rights monitors in Rwanda and Burundi, Brian Atwood, the Agency for International Development administrator, said here today.         But he warned other foreign aid donors that it would not help to support Burundi economically unless ethnic conflict here is reduced.

headline: Trevi Fountain Can Be Plucked
abstract: Legend says a coin tossed in the Trevi Fountain will guarantee a return trip  to Rome. Now a prosecutor says plucking the coins from the fountain does not mean a trip to court.         The authorities last week dropped a case against two boys who used nets to scoop coins from the fountain, newspapers reported today. The prosecutor, Giovanni Bombardieri, said the boys had broken no law by fishing out the change  thrown in by tourists.

headline: G.M.'s Rocky Labor Ties: Do Rivals Have It Easier?
abstract: The Ford Motor Company has not suffered a strike in a decade, while the General Motors Corporation has endured eight strikes in the last three years, including a 17-day walkout in March that cost the company $900 million in after-tax profits.         That startling comparison of labor relations was made over and over again here this week as the United Automobile Workers union officially opened negotiations with General Motors, Ford and the Chrysler Corporation. The disparity partly reflects differences in the way that General Motors and Ford handle the union, but is also misleading because G.M. has an inherently more difficult task in its labor relations, auto industry executives, union officials and labor experts said this week.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Because of an editing error, a chart last Sunday with an article about the Nicholas mutual funds misstated a performance figure for Nicholas Limited Edition, a leader among diversified domestic equity funds. Through the first quarter of this year, it gained 15.04 percent, not 9.67.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GREAT LAKES CHEMICAL IN DEAL FOR NOWSCO
abstract: The Great Lakes Chemical Corporation agreed on Sunday to acquire Nowsco Well  Service Ltd. in a deal valued at $502 million. The offer exceeds a competing bid for Nowsco made by the BJ Services Company last month, which Nowsco rejected. Nowsco, based in Calgary, Alberta, provides well services to oil and natural-gas companies. Great Lakes, based in West Lafayette, Ind., offered to buy all 22.5 million outstanding shares of Nowsco, for $30.90 (Canadian) a share. BJ Services, of Houston, offered $27 (Canadian) a share. The shares jumped today past the price offered by Great Lakes, to $31.95 (Canadian), up $2.60 a share. Great Lakes produces specialty chemicals, including flame retardants, water treatments and petroleum additives. It also provides products and services to the oil and gas industry.

headline: Gunmen Kill an Israeli in West Bank
abstract: Gunmen shot at an Israeli family in a West Bank town today, killing the father and wounding the mother, Israeli officials said. Their young son was not  hurt.         The attack was the second on Israelis in eight days. A Jewish couple from the West Bank settlement of Qiryat Arba was shot and killed in Israel on June 9 after they attended a wedding.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRAVELERS/AETNA OFFERING SEEN RAISING $875 MILLION
abstract: The Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation priced its initial public offering yesterday at $25 a share, which would raise $875 million over all. The  company is selling 35 million shares, or 8.8 percent of its 396 million shares outstanding. At the offering price, the company has a total market value of $9.9 billion. Travelers Group Inc. formed the company this year by buying the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit for $4 billion and combining it with its own such business. The shares of Travelers/Aetna begin trading today on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol TAP.

headline: Looted of Art, German Town Now Feels Economically Plundered
abstract: Six years ago, word reached this medieval town in eastern Germany that its fabled stolen treasures, lost since World War II, had been found in Texas. But people were preoccupied then: their land was about to be reunified.         Now, the trial of the people accused of selling the stolen treasure back to Germany is to open in Texas later this year. But this news finds people still preoccupied, not with the excitements of German reunification, but with its legacy: this town may boast royal treasure, but it does not have too many jobs.

headline: Stocks Flat in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading in a narrow range here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 1.91 points, or one-hundredth of 1 percent, at 21,722.17. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 233.92 points, or 1.07 percent.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Republican Tax Cutters Being Heard in Their Party After years when many in Washington focused on deficit reduction, Republican proponents of deep tax cuts are once again getting a serious hearing within their party.

headline: West London Hit by Bomb; No One Hurt
abstract: An explosion rocked an expensive residential district of west London tonight  after a warning call attributed to the Irish Republican Army, police and fire officials said.         The blast blew out windows at an empty house and neighboring buildings in a fashionable street called The Boltons, but no one was hurt, the police said.

headline: U.S. Cites China for Failing to Curb Piracy in Trade
abstract: The Clinton Administration formally designated China today as the most egregious violator of agreements intended to combat the piracy of American products, a step that seemed to lay the groundwork for imposing long-expected sanctions against China in coming weeks.         In a report to Congress, the Administration said it was citing Beijing because of its blatant failure to rein in piracy of American videocassettes, compact disks, computer software and other products, despite an agreement last year to do so.

headline: Fear of a Communist Comeback Has Many in Russia Packing Bags
abstract: At the age of 22, Galina Mardoyan has seen enough turmoil to last a lifetime. By the time she was done with high school, the Soviet Union had collapsed. As an Armenian living in Georgia, she felt despised, so she moved to a resort on the Black Sea, where she hoped to live quietly with her grandmother.         She got there in 1992, just in time to watch thousands of her new neighbors in the once glorious vacation town of Sukhumi butcher one another in a savage civil war. She fled again, this time to Moscow, where she is a college student.

headline: Guilty Plea Offered in Insider Case
abstract: A Manhattan business executive pleaded guilty yesterday to insider trading charges that he made $60,568 from information about pending mergers given to him by his daughter, a former paralegal for the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.         The executive, Richard A. Kleinbaum, pleaded guilty to two counts of securities fraud in Federal District Court in lower Manhattan. He also pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit perjury and to obstruct an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Despite Tensions, Clinton Urges Renewal of China's Trade Status
abstract: Despite a conflict with China over pirated American computer software, movies and music, President Clinton called today for unconditional renewal of preferential trade status for China, saying the step would be "a vote for America's interests" and "not a referendum on all China's policies."         Mr. Clinton's speech began a full-scale Administration lobbying effort to win Congressional approval for the extension of most-favored-nation trade status for China, even though tensions linger over major issues like nuclear proliferation  and human rights abuses as well as trade.

headline: Israel to Investigate Death in Jersualem
abstract: The Israeli police said they were investigating the death of a Mexican priest whose body was discovered today in his room in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the holiest Christian site in Jerusalem.         "He was found lying on the floor, with blood that had issued from his nose,"  said Shmulik Ben Ruby, a police spokesman.

headline: Journalism Education Less Focused On the News
abstract: Journalism school graduates are the lowest-paid college-educated workers joining the labor force. They are also increasingly likely to have been trained  by people with doctorates, but with little or no experience as reporters or editors.         And, perhaps not surprisingly, graduate and undergraduate interest in journalism education is on the wane.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA CONSIDERS ITS OPTIONS FOR A REORGANIZATION
abstract: The Diana Corporation has hired an undisclosed investment banker to help it consider a reorganization that could include the spinoff of operating units, the company said yesterday. Diana said its board would consider alternatives that involve separating units by industry, into independent public companies. Diana makes central office telecommunications equipment and distributes meat products. The company's stock fell $1.75, to $56.25. The stock was worth less than $6 a share a year ago and more than $120 a month ago. The New York Stock Exchange is  reportedly investigating unusual trading in its shares.

headline: U.S. Troops Rescued From Angry Serbs
abstract: French troops extricated about six American troops from an angry Bosnian Serb crowd near Sarajevo today after the Americans tried to confiscate unauthorized weapons, a NATO spokesman said.         American troops, part of the NATO peacekeeping contingent, were in the area of Lukavica, a Sarajevo suburb held by Bosnian Serbs, when they spotted a Serbian man armed with a grenade and an automatic pistol talking to local policemen, said the NATO spokesman, Maj. Simon Haselock. Under the Dayton peace  accord, weapons are forbidden in the so-called zone of separation, which divides the former warring parties.

headline: Market Place;From Donna Karan this year, a second effort to go public.
abstract: HERE she goes again.         The designer Donna Karan said yesterday that she would make an offering in the public markets, three years after her initial attempt was thwarted when she  rejected a valuation that she considered too low.

headline: Serb Village Sees Only the Flowers
abstract: Spring is trying to poke its way into the high mountain valleys here. Its slowly warming air brings the small flowers and young grass now growing through  the remains of human bodies stretching in a line up a hill.         It is mostly the civilian clothing and bones that are left of about 20 men, who were killed last July as they fled Bosnian Serb forces that were overrunning the Muslim town of Srebrenica, seven miles to the southeast. Other bodies dot the surrounding area.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Advance in Thin Trading
abstract: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, helped by end-of-the-quarter buying by portfolio managers.         That buying activity, bolstered by technical factors and thin trading volume, helped push the yield on the long bond below 7 percent for the first time in nearly three weeks.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
abstract: How I.R.A.'s Gather Dust

headline: Markets Closed in Japan
abstract: Financial markets were closed here today in observance of a national holiday, Greenery Day. On Friday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 4.93 points, to 22,235.03.

headline: SFX Adds FM Station
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc. has acquired the radio station WROQ-FM in Greenville-Spartanburg, S.C., for $14 million from ABS Greenville Partners L.P.  The acquisition gives the broadcaster, based in New York, its third FM station in the Greenville-Spartanburg market, where the company will have 32 percent of  listeners.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIAMOND FIELDS REPORTS BIGGER NICKEL DEPOSIT
abstract: Diamond Fields Resources Inc., which has agreed to be acquired by Inco Ltd. for $3.2 billion, said yesterday that recent drilling results at its Voisey's nickel find had showed that the lode was larger than previously thought. The company's chief financial officer, Ed Mercaldo, said the latest exploration suggested a part of the Voisey's Bay property known as Eastern Deeps had a surface area three times that of the first deposit discovered there. This "significantly augments the resource potential" of the property, Diamond Fields  said. Diamond Fields owns 75 percent of Voisey's Bay, which is in remote Labrador on Canada's northeast coast, while Inco owns 25 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;First Profit in 5 Years For Minolta Company
abstract: The Minolta Camera Company Ltd. said yesterday that cost-cutting and a rise in sales helped it earn an operating profit in the year that ended on March 31,  its first such profit in five years. Minolta's operating profit of 3.96 billion  yen ($36.75 million) compared with a loss of 736 million yen a year ago. Sales in the information-equipment division, which includes copiers, rose 2.9 percent  on the year, to 126.27 billion yen. Sales of optical equipment, which includes cameras, rose 10.8 percent, to 67.49 billion yen.          Minolta cut costs by shifting to low-cost production sites outside Japan and reducing its work force. The company makes 86 percent of its cameras and 64 percent of its copiers outside Japan. It has cut about 1,400 employees in a three-year cost-reduction plan that began in 1993.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Angered, G.M. Halts Investment in Indonesia
abstract: With American auto makers and the United States Government stepping up pressure on Indonesia to end its policies favoring a local auto maker, a senior  executive of the General Motors Corporation said today that his company had suspended plans for further investments there. "We have put our future investment on hold in that country because we want to get a better understanding of where the Indonesian Government is heading on their policy," said Donald T. Sullivan, the G.M. vice president who oversees the company's Asian and Pacific region operations.

headline: Small Stocks Lift Nasdaq; Dow Declines 16.26 Points
abstract: Smaller issues took the leadership role yesterday in a mixed stock market.         The Nasdaq composite index rose 2.40 points, to 1,138.70, establishing its third new record this week. And the American Stock Exchange market value index climbed 2.80 points, to 585.88, marking its fourth consecutive record and its 18th high this year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MELVILLE SELLS WILSONS APPAREL DIVISION TO MANAGEMENT
abstract: The Melville Corporation said yesterday that it had sold its Wilsons leather  apparel division to an investor group led by Wilsons management. Terms were not  disclosed. The sale was part of Melville's reorganization under which it will split into two companies and sell other businesses to focus on its CVS drugstore chain. Wilsons chairman and chief executive, Joel N. Waller, and its president and chief operating officer, David L. Rogers led the management group that purchased Wilsons. The rest of the group, a Minnesota limited partnership, was led by Lyle Berman and Morris Goldfarb.

headline: Serbs in Bosnia Still Holding 16
abstract: Bosnian Serbs failed to release prisoners today, as they had agreed to do, but Bosnian Croats and Muslims bowed to pressure and freed their captives, officials said.         "We expected them to comply," said Rida Attarashany, a spokesman for Carl Bildt, the chief civilian administrator overseeing the peace accord.

headline: Accord Seen for Oracle, Sun and I.B.M.
abstract: The Oracle Corporation, the International Business Machines Corporation and Sun Microsystems Inc. will announce next Monday that they have agreed to a set of standards for a new class of network computing devices, an executive close to the companies said.         The concept of a sub-$500 network computer has been heavily promoted by Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman and chief executive of Oracle, as a less costly and more user-friendly alternative to personal computers. Such a device would receive its software from the Internet, or over private corporate networks, and would need little internal storage or memory. Such a device could also be made without the Intel Corporation's microprocessors or the Microsoft Corporation's operating system software.

headline: EARNING IT;The Forgotten Offspring of Bankruptcy
abstract: DISCOVERY ZONE was quite the cash machine when Doug Fyffe, an electrician in  Dayton, Ohio, read about the company in a magazine five years ago. A line on the cover announced, "Franchising Surge." Inside was the story of an Illinois man whose franchise on a new indoor-playground business was pulling in $18,000 a week.         "It was the latest, the greatest, the bestest," Mr. Fyffe recalled. So he and his wife, Sherri, invested more than $600,000 in savings and borrowed money to become Discovery Zone franchisees, too.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: FIRST UNION MORTGAGE CORP., Charlotte, N.C., a unit of First Union Corp., named  John M. Church senior vice president and manager of the commercial mortgage servicing unit. Mr. Church is a former senior manager at GE Capital Asset Management Corp.

headline: First-Quarter Growth Put Lower, at 2.2%
abstract: The economy grew at a slower pace than previously estimated in the first quarter, reflecting a lull in export demand, Government figures showed today.

headline: I.B.M. to Sell Storage Technology's Products
abstract: I.B.M. said yesterday that it had agreed to resell under its own name storage systems for mainframe computers made by the Storage Technology Corporation. The  products will begin appearing with the I.B.M. logo in July.         The companies said the deal would expand I.B.M.'s product line while broadening Storage Technology's distribution channel. I.B.M. also said it would  provide Storage Technology financing for research and development, though the terms were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALCOHOL SENSORS TO SELL DEVICES WORTH $360 MILLION
abstract: Alcohol Sensors International Ltd., based in Islandia, L.I., said yesterday that it had reached a deal, worth more than $360 million, for Digital Vehicle Security Systems of Britain to sell its ignition interlock devices in Europe. The devices detect, evaluate and help prevent an intoxicated driver from operating a vehicle. Digital Vehicle plans to buy 1.6 million Sens-o-lock ignition interlock units over five years, starting in November, and sell them in 17 European countries, the company said. Alcohol Sensors' stock closed at $15, up 75 cents a share, after jumping as high as $20 earlier in the day in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Yeltsin Hits Campaign Trail, Telling Voters to Forget Past
abstract: Traveling on his first campaign trip straight to the Communist-dominated heartland of Russia, President Boris N. Yeltsin wandered from pig farms to metal factories today, delivering the same simple, heartfelt message: the past is over, please don't bring it back.         "Do you know how important this election is for Russia?" he asked voters at a town meeting here less that a mile from the site of history's biggest tank battle, where the Red Army broke the Nazi advance. "Do you remember the lines, the lists, the fact that you had no choices? Only democracy can insure the future of our country."

headline: World News Briefs;Police in India Dig For Westerners' Bodies
abstract: The Indian police dug for bodies in a Kashmiri village today, apparently to investigate claims that four Westerners kidnapped by Kashmiri separatists last year had been killed.         But Kulbhushan Jandiyal, spokesman for the state government in Jammu and Kashmir, and the state police in Srinagar denied the police were searching for dead hostages.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HARRAH'S SHARES ARE DOWN ON DISAPPOINTING REVENUE
abstract: The shares of Harrah's Entertainment Inc. fell 11 percent yesterday after the company said second-quarter and 1996 profits would fall below expectations because of disappointing casino revenue. The Memphis-based company's stock fell  $3.50, to $27.625, in trading of 3.1 million shares on the New York Stack Exchange. The company sees second-quarter earnings of about 33 cents to 35 cents a share, about 10 cents a share lower than expected. Harrah's estimate excludes an estimated 6-cents-a-share charge from start-up operations. Wall Street expected Harrah's to earn 43 cents a share, according to a recent survey  of nine analysts by Zacks Investment Research.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Improvisation has been utterly necessary for the marketers of 'State Fair.'
abstract: IN the out-of-town tryout, it's usually the show, and not the advertising, that gets road-tested on the way to Broadway. But during the seven-month tour of "State Fair," the marketing message evolved as much as the Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical that opened last week at the Music Box Theater in Manhattan.         And the producers of the show are still tinkering with the advertising campaign. In its latest marketing plan, the musical, in addition to its $165,000 weekly advertising budget, is spending $475,000 for the month of April to find an audience after mixed reviews forced yet more revisions in the show's advertising.

headline: EUROPE, DOWNSIZED -- A special report.;In Europe, a Wave of Layoffs Stuns White-Collar Workers
abstract: Downsizing is coming to Western Europe's white-collar workers, and fast. It is straining families, communities and politics on a continent on which 11 percent of available workers are already unemployed, double the rate in the United States.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHAMPION ENTERPRISES INC., Auburn Hills, Mich., a manufactured housing company,  said it had acquired Grand Manor Inc., Thomasville, Ga., and that it had a definitive agreement to buy Homes of Legend Inc., Boaz, Ala., at a cost of $33 million for both acquisitions.

headline: Pure Software To Buy Astria In Stock Deal
abstract: Pure Software Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy Atria Software Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $928 million.         The deal would combine two of the leaders in the fast-growing market for software tools that manage the development and testing of software programs.

headline: Business Travel;Airlines are offering discounts of as much as 50 percent for certain destinations this summer.
abstract: THE airlines are having their widest and deepest fare sale of the year, with  the major carriers offering discounts of as much as 50 percent for travel this summer in the United States, Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean. The carriers vow  these will be their lowest fares for summer travel, but that really depends on how many people respond to the sale and how strong summer air travel turn out to be. For now, summer appears to be shaping up well, in part because of interest in the Summer Olympics in Atlanta, which begin 100 days from today.         The current sale offers round-trip fares between New York and Los Angeles of  $378, between Philadelphia and Phoenix of $389 and between Newark and Mexico City of $250. But the sale ends soon -- this Friday for Northwest Airlines, for  example, and next Monday for Continental Airlines.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BANKRUPT BARNEY'S PLANS BONUSES TO KEEP EMPLOYEES
abstract: Barney's Inc., the retailer, proposed an $8.3 million program yesterday that  would use bonuses to keep executives at the company and to guarantee severance packages should employees lose their jobs. Barney's said the bonus plan was needed to combat an "alarming rate of attrition" since the company sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January. Barneys said 52 employees, including 12 so-called key employees, had left the company since the filing. Bankruptcy Judge James Garrity will consider the proposal in a hearing scheduled for next Wednesday in New York. The severance plan would cushion the blow of any firings for 473 Barneys employees. The bonus plan would augment the salaries of  87 top executives by 15 percent to 25 percent. Robert and Gene Pressman, the company's co-chief executives, would not benefit from either plan.

headline: Russian Communists, in Retreat, Talk About an Opposition Role
abstract: Although the leaders of Russia's Communist Party still say they have a chance to win next week's presidential election, they have already begun to portray their candidate, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, as a man who stands to gain as much in defeat as he would in victory.         The Communist challenger has not campaigned since the first round of voting on June 16, and he apparently does not plan to travel before the July 3 runoff.  Communist advisers have taken to talking less about how they would govern and more about how difficult they could make things for President Boris N. Yeltsin in their role as parliamentary obstructionists.

headline: Antananarivo Journal;A Palace Inferno Sears Madagascar's Very Soul
abstract: The British author of a travel guide to this island nation compared the fire  to "Westminster Abbey, the Tower of London and Buckingham Palace being destroyed at once."         Nearly the whole city of Antananarivo stayed up all night crying.

headline: Correction: The Dow Thursday, Minute by Minute
Bangladesh Generals Held
abstract: At last five generals, including the dismissed army chief, have been placed under house arrest in Bangladesh for their involvement in a failed revolt, military sources said today.         They said that in addition to the army chief, Lieut. Gen. Abu Saleh Mohammad  Nasim, who was dismissed by President Abdur Rahman Biswas on Monday, the others  included the commander in the northern district of Bogra and the deputy director of the Bangladesh Rifles.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS JUDGE OVERTURNS VERDICT AGAINST FLEMING
abstract: The Fleming Companies will get a new trial in a case brought by a former customer, David's Supermarkets Inc., after a Texas judge threw out a $211.2 million verdict in which a jury found that Fleming violated a supply contract that limited its markup on goods. Judge C. W. Duncan Jr. ruled that Fleming, a grocery distributor based in Oklahoma City, was entitled to a new trial because  the judge that conducted the case earlier this year failed to disclose that David's majority owner, David Waldrip, had once loaned him about $3,000. "It's a result we thought was warranted," Fleming's general counsel, David Almond, said. An attorney for David's predicted that the company would win the second jury trial.

headline: Peres Hints Israel Will Delay A Full Pullout From Hebron
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres announced today that he intended to "coordinate"  a limited Israeli withdrawal from Hebron with the Palestinian Authority, but set no firm date for pulling out of the last West Bank city to remain under Israeli  occupation.         The announcement was issued after Mr. Peres held a special meeting on Hebron  with his senior security officers, and it suggested that the Prime Minister had  decided to postpone a full withdrawal from Hebron until after the May 29 national election. Even after the so-called full withdrawal, some Israeli troops will remain to protect the Jewish settlements in Hebron.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;America Online Has a New Strategy
abstract: America Online Inc., seeking additional revenue to supplement subscription fees, said yesterday that it would significantly revamp its advertising strategies.         "We asked why Madison Avenue wasn't buying us and our conclusion was we weren't acting like a media company," said Myer Berlow, vice president for interactive advertising. "So we developed procedures that speak to advertisers and agencies."

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 316.72 points, or 1.46 percent, at 21,411.88. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 233.32 points, or 1.09 percent.

headline: Senate Confirms Greenspan 91-7 for a Third Fed Term
abstract: The Senate overwhelmingly confirmed Alan Greenspan to a third term as chairman of the Federal Reserve today, brushing aside arguments from a few Democrats that he had held back economic growth by focusing too narrowly on fighting inflation.         The vote was 91 to 7. The "no" votes came from Democrats representing Midwestern states with strong populist histories of opposition to tight-money policies like those that have distinguished Mr. Greenspan's nearly nine-year tenure at the central bank.

headline: Correction: Retailers' Sales in May
abstract: A chart in Business Day yesterday of the Goldman, Sachs retail composite index appeared with many bars partly obscured. Here is a corrected chart.

headline: China, on Eve of Trade Talks, Holds American as Smuggler
abstract: In a case that American diplomats say they believe is intended to send a political message to the United States, China announced today that authorities in Shanghai had apprehended an American businessman "under strong suspicion" of  importing contraband.         Shanghai police officials would not say what the businessman, William Ping Chen, was accused of bringing into China. Nor would they explain why his case, unlike other smuggling cases, was singled out for a report by the New China News Agency.

headline: Blue Chips Plunge, Dragged Down by I.B.M.
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 70.09 points, or 1.25 percent, yesterday to close at 5,549.93, dragged down by a plunge in I.B.M.'s stock that  accounted for nearly 50 percent of the Dow's decline.         The Dow had risen more than 132 points, or 2.4 percent, in the three previous days of trading. But with I.B.M. falling 10 1/4, to 105 1/4, on volume of 16.3 million shares during yesterday's session, the 30-stock blue-chip indicator was constantly under pressure. The selloff in the Dow was its largest since March 8.

headline: Exxon Is Accused of 'Astonishing Ruse' in Oil-Spill Trial
abstract: In a stinging rebuke to the Exxon Corporation, its chairman and its lawyers,  a Federal judge has held that they had all been part of an "astonishing ruse" to attempt to manipulate the jury that awarded $5 billion in damages to pay the victims of the Exxon Valdez oil spill of 1989.         Judge H. Russel Holland of United States District Court in Anchorage, Alaska, in a decision issued late Tuesday, said Exxon had acted as "Jekyll and Hyde" by "behaving laudably in public and deplorably in private."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KANSAS CITY POWER TO REVIEW WESTERN RESOURCES' BID
abstract: The Kansas City Power and Light Company said yesterday that it would promptly review an unsolicited takeover proposal by Western Resources Inc. worth $1.7 billion. On Sunday, Western Resources offered to acquire all of Kansas City Power's outstanding shares for $28 apiece in a stock swap. In January Kansas City Power agreed to merge with Utilicorp in a $3 billion stock deal that would  create one of the nation's largest electric and gas utilities, with operations in eight states.  Shares of Kansas City Power rose $2.125, to $26, yesterday, while shares of Western Resources fell 25 cents, to $28.875.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consumer Savings Likely From Order to Utilities The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered electric utilities to open their transmission systems to outside energy providers, which could eventually save consumers billions of dollars a year.

headline: A TREATY IN HAND, YELTSIN JOURNEYS TO CHECHEN CITY
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin embarked on his most audacious campaign trip today, traveling to the shattered capital of Chechnya only hours after concluding a peace treaty intended to stop the raging war in the secessionist southern region.         Mr. Yeltsin had never before set foot in the region where as many as 40,000 people have died since he sent federal troops there in December 1994. But he has said many times in the last month that he would visit Chechnya during his presidential campaign, and this was one promise he clearly felt he needed to keep.

headline: BIRTH OF A GIANT: A LEADER'S VISION;Gambles, and Successes, at the Top
abstract: Edward E. Whitacre Jr. is as far from flashy as anyone gets in the communications business: laconic, unflappable and largely uninterested in spinning visions of the future.         But appearances are deceiving. As the chairman and chief executive of SBC Communications, parent of the Southwestern Bell telephone company, Mr. Whitacre  has proved to be one of the shrewdest and toughest executives in the telephone industry.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain Puts Price On Railtrack Shares
abstract: The British Government said yesterday that it would sell the nation's rail track and signaling equipment to the public at a price lower than that it had originally sought. Shares of Railtrack will cost between L3.5 and L3.9, or a total of between L1.75 billion ($2.62 billion) and L1.95 billion. The exact price will not be known until trading starts on the London Stock Exchange on May 20.          The Government had originally sought L2.5 billion, or $3.75 billion, for Railtrack, but lowered the market value after threats by the Labor Party to toughen regulations and take back some of the shares.   (AP)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Liz Claiborne gets set to pitch a curve to the youth market and hopes it will throw a strike.
abstract: LIZ CLAIBORNE wants to throw consumers a curve, but they may well be knocked  for a loop.         The Liz Claiborne Cosmetics division of Liz Claiborne Inc., which has been a  solid if unspectacular performer in the competitive fragrance industry, will begin pursuing the lucrative yet fickle youth market with a line of scents and other products for men and women, to be sold under the brand name Curve. A $5 million advertising and promotional campaign, featuring the first television commercials for any Claiborne fragrance, is imbued with symbols and imagery intended to attract consumers in their 20's.

headline: Suicide Rates Are Rising for the Unpopular, Harassed Police Force inParis
abstract: Parisians do not have warm feelings for their police. Older people remember them as collaborating with the German occupiers. Middle-aged Parisians still resent their rough repression of the 1968 student movement.         To some young people, "les flics" are walking emblems of the state, who are fun to taunt, insult and, when possible, bombard with bottles and stones.

headline: Everybody Loves a Clown
abstract: Can you recall the last time you made a really embarrassing mistake at work?  Sure you can. Your co-workers had a good laugh at your expense, so why not give  the rest of us a chance? We even promise to laugh with you and not at you. Send  your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Four Months Into Its Budget Year, the U.N. Says It Is Broke
abstract: Only four months into its budget year, the United Nations is out of money for daily operating expenses and will have to borrow from cash set aside for peacekeeping, the organization's chief financial officer said today.         "Our regular budget balance tomorrow will be zero," the organization's Under  Secretary General for Administration and Management, Joseph E. Connor, said at a news conference today. He said the United Nations had expected to have $79 million at this point.

headline: Walter Guevara Arze, 84; Rebel Became President of Bolivia
abstract: Walter Guevara Arze, a leader of the Bolivian revolution in 1952, died on Thursday at his home in La Paz, the Bolivian capital. He was 84.         He suffered a heart attack, his son, Ramiro, said.

headline: Mongolia Is Devastated by Fires of Epic Scope
abstract: It was the job of a leathery wildlife ranger named Myagmarsuren to protect the conifer forest that is draped across the low mountains here like a rich green garment. And so on May 14, after he saw the first puffs of white smoke over the ridge from his log cabin, he jumped on his pony and rode all afternoon  to the nearest telegraph operator to sound the forest fire alarm.         By the time he got back, the valley was an inferno.

headline: Sinn Fein Runs Strongly in Vote for Ulster Negotiating Teams
abstract: Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, won unusually strong support in an election Thursday for negotiating teams for full-fledged peace talks in Northern Ireland.         The results, announced today, showed that Sinn Fein won 15.5 per cent of the  vote, its strongest showing in the 12 years it has run candidates in province-wide elections.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DISCOVERY TO ACQUIRE THE NATURE COMPANY
abstract: Discovery Communications Inc., which operates the Discovery Channel on cable  television, plans to buy the Nature Company from CML Group Inc. for $40 million  in cash, the companies said yesterday. The Nature Company, in Berkeley, Calif.,  is a specialty retail chain and mail-order business selling nature-related books, toys and games. The deal includes 114 Nature Company stores and three Scientific Revolution stores. Discovery, a privately held company based in Bethesda, Md., is owned by the Liberty Media Corporation, Cox Communications Inc., Advance/Newhouse Communications and John S. Hendricks, founder, chairman and chief executive of Discovery.

headline: A Former Premier And a Mussolini Also Win in Italy
abstract: Although the biggest victory in Italy's elections was for the political left, there were some other winners.         Ciriaco De Mita, the former Christian Democratic Prime Minister branded a lumbering political dinosaur by his center-right opponents, safely won a seat in Parliament.

headline: Harnessing the Sun And Selling It Abroad;U.S. Solar Industry in Export Boom
abstract: Jolted by the oil embargoes of the 1970's, the Federal Government has been awarding research grants to develop solar power ever since. Twenty years and $1.4 billion in taxpayer money later, solar power is still not much more than a  dim light bulb in the nation's energy constellation.         But the investment is paying off anyway -- in a thriving export business that is proving, as solar proponents insisted all along, that "small is beautiful."

headline: A Stock Sale Is Considered By Hambrecht
abstract: Hambrecht & Quist, which has taken fast-growing technology companies like the Netscape Communications Corporation public, is preparing an initial public offering of its own shares, people familiar with the brokerage firm have said in recent days.         Such an offering, which could still be postponed if market conditions change  or if its underwriters demur, would probably involve the sale of between 15 and 20 percent of Hambrecht's equity. The sale of those shares is likely to raise as much as $80 million, analysts said, assuming a current market value for Hambrecht, which is based in San Francisco, of between $400 million and $500 million.

headline: Paraguay Averts a Military Coup, but the Deal Outrages Many
