abstract: Overnight, the shadow of another coup in Paraguay was swept away, but the relief of the people here is tempered by outrage over the compromise the civilian Government made to escape the threat.         The army commander, Gen. Lino Cesar Oviedo, who had refused a presidential order to resign and taken refuge in an army barracks, agreed to leave his post,  President Juan Carlos Wasmosy announced late Tuesday night in a nationally televised address. But the general's condition for resigning was that he be named Defense Minister.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SCITEX REJECTS A SWEETENED TAKEOVER OFFER
abstract: The Scitex Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected a second proposal  from the investor Davidi Gilo to acquire the company and take it private. Scitex, an Israeli maker of computer imaging systems, said such a move would not be in the best interests of shareholders. The Scitex statement came in response  to a letter dated Sunday in which Mr. Gilo said his investor group would be prepared to acquire Scitex for $25 a share. At that price, Scitex would be worth more than $1 billion. Scitex shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $21, in  Nasdaq trading. Mr. Gilo had offered $20 a share in March.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Stock Soars on Rise In Earnings
abstract: After warning investors last month that its personal computer business had experienced an unexpected downturn, the Digital Equipment Corporation reported a 68 percent increase in earnings yesterday for its fiscal third quarter.         The shares of Digital soared more than 9 percent on the news, though the company only met analysts' earnings forecasts and reported lackluster growth in revenue. The stock closed at $60.625 a share, up $5.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Murdoch May Seek Satellite Deal With TCI
abstract: The chairman of the News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that he  was prepared to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in a joint venture with Tele-Communications Inc. and John C. Malone, its chief executive, to provide satellite television in the United States.         Joining Tele-Communications would allow Mr. Murdoch and the MCI Communications Corporation, with which the News Corporation has a satellite-television joint venture, to compete more quickly with DirecTV, the industry leader with 1.3 subscribers. That is because Tele-Communications, or TCI, is a member of another satellite broadcasting group, Primestar Partners, which has 1.1 million subscribers.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ERICSSON, Stockholm, the telecommunications equipment maker, signed a contract with Omnipoint Corp. of Arlington, Va., a communications technology company, that could be worth up to $350 million in equipment orders over the next five years.

headline: Real Estate;Sony makes a number of moves in Manhattan to put more of its businesses under one roof.
abstract: CALL it the Sony shuffle. The SonyCorporation of America has doubled its space at 555 Madison Avenue, cut almost in half its space at 711 Fifth Avenue, and terminated its lease at 9 West 57th Street.         At 555 Madison Avenue, between 55th and 56th Streets and opposite Sony's 700,000-square-foot corporate headquarters at 550 Madison, the entertainment colossus has leased an additional 90,000 square feet, on floors six through nine.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Lists Chinese Goods For Big Trade Sanctions The Clinton Administration listed $3 billion in Chinese goods that could be subject to the largest trade sanctions in American history if Beijing refuses to close factories that pirate American software and music.

headline: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: Japan;Music All Day Long
abstract: Tower Records, in the funky Shibuya district, is the largest music store in the world -- eight floors of music heaven, where hundreds of young people scour  through 600,000 titles of rock, pop, soul, rap, jazz and Japanese popular songs.          Men and women, side by side, their Gucci bags and knapsacks brushing each other in the aisles, sometimes pause in the middle of the store in front of an FM radio station, called the Tower Street Studio. Or they stand swaying in the aisles as music flows into their ears through headphones set up at floor displays. On one rare occasion, a woman spent the whole day by the CD sampling machine, dancing to "fringe" music.

headline: A New Charter Wins Adoption In South Africa
abstract: South Africa adopted a new Constitution today, officially and peacefully completing the country's transition from centuries of white supremacy to a nonracial democracy.         In the austere parliamentary chamber where many of apartheid's laws were created, the Constitutional Assembly embraced a document that renounces the racism of the past and guarantees all South Africans broad freedoms of speech, movement and political activity.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;F.T.C. CLEARS RAYTHEON PURCHASE OF CHRYSLER UNIT
abstract: The Raytheon Company has settled Federal Trade Commission charges that its $475 million purchase of Chrysler Technologies Holding Inc. would violate antitrust concerns, clearing the way for it to move ahead. Raytheon, the defense and aerospace giant, agreed to erect an "information fire wall" for the remainder of a bidding competition between it and the GTE Corporation for the United States Navy's purchase of a satellite communications system to be used in submarines. Chrysler Technologies, a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, is providing GTE with antenna and terminal controls that are used in a proposed satellite system.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Telekom In Malaysia Purchase
abstract: Deutsche Telekom said yesterday that it would buy a 21 percent stake in Malaysia's biggest mobile phone company, TRI, and was discussing alliances with  companies in Thailand and the Philippines. Herbert Mueller, Deutsche Telekom's Asia Pacific managing director, declined to say which Asian companies Deutsche Telekom was talking to. He said the company was "most likely to concentrate" on  the Philippines and Thailand.          Deutsche Telekom said it planned to pay upward of 646.7 million ringgit ($260 million) for the stake in Technology Resources Industries Bhd., known as TRI. "TRI is the strongest mobile phone operator in the Malaysian market, with a 70 to 75 percent market share," Mr. Mueller said.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Mobil to Buy Big Stake in Kazakh Field
abstract: The Mobil Corporation said today that as expected it had agreed to buy 25 percent of one of the world's biggest oil projects, a $10 billion venture led by the Chevron Corporation in the central Asian republic of Kazakhstan.         Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., said it would acquire the stake from the Kazakh Government, which owned a half share in the venture, for an undisclosed amount.  Chevron retains the other half of the company developing the Tengiz oilfield.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit Rises At SGS-Thomson
abstract: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest independent semiconductor maker, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 64 percent as specialized computer chips kept raising profit margins. The French-Italian company said its profit was $175 million, up from $106.9 million a year earlier. SGS-Thomson's sales rose 32 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $779 million in the  1995 quarter.          Since its creation in 1987 from two weak chip makers, the company has become the world's largest maker of analog semiconductor products, producing specialized chips for industries ranging from telecommunications to automobiles.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: New Trial Opens for Italy's Former Leader
abstract: A new trial of former Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti on charges related to organized crime started today, with the prosecution asking that 91 new witnesses be allowed to testify against him.         The first trial, which began in Palermo, the Sicilian capital, last September, had to be halted because one of the three judges became ill.

headline: Microsoft in an Agreement To Acquire Aha! Software
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Aha! Software Corporation, a private company that makes pen-based programs for portable computers. Terms were not disclosed.         Aha!, based in Mountain View, Calif., is best known for the Inkwriter program. Unlike most pen-based software, Inkwriter does not try to recognize handwriting and convert it into type; instead, it allows users to write and send notes in their own handwriting. But Inkwriter gives users the ability to edit their handwriting, by highlighting words or phrases, and by cutting and pasting  material, as if it were in typeface. Although the acquisition cost of Aha! would be negligible for Microsoft, analysts said the deal underscored the software giant's commitment to pen computing, a market segment thought moribund by many.  Sales of Inkwriter have been limited, at least in part because it first appeared on Sony's Magic Link and Motorola's Envoy personal digital assistants, which have not been big sellers. But the technology is well regarded and can run on Microsoft's operating systems as well.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Store Chief in Japan To Quit in Payoff Case
abstract: The president of Japan's largest department store operator said yesterday that he would resign after company executives were arrested on charges of paying gangster extortionists. The executive, Hiroshi Hidaka of the Takashimaya Company, said he "feels responsibility" over the scandal involving payments to "sokaiya," racketeers who blackmail companies by threatening to disrupt their annual meetings. One former and two current Takashimaya executives were arrested on Saturday for  reportedly paying 80 million yen ($730,000) to sokaiya to insure a peaceful annual meeting in May 1995. Two sokaiya have been arrested. Mr. Hidaka denied that he was aware of the payments, but he acknowledged meeting the mob leader, Isao Nishiura.   (AP)

headline: Time Is Changing The Model S.& L.;Home Savings Pushes Ahead Into Full-Service Banking
abstract: The bright California sun filters through the stained-glass windows, creating a reverential mood in this cavernous edifice. Decorated with elaborate mosaics,  bronze statues and lots of marble, it is a stolid temple of thrift -- one of many erected by Home Savings of America in affluent suburbs like this one, outside Los Angeles, in the years after World War II.         The ornate branches gathered enough of the growing wealth of Southern California to make Home Savings the nation's largest and in many ways most successful savings and loan. But on this spring afternoon, a slender banner dangling over a half-dozen tellers bears a simple announcement: "We now offer home equity, automotive, personal loans and credit lines."

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.A.A. Files Show a Trail Of Valujet Safety Lapses Federal Aviation Administration inspectors found many safety violations at Valujet Airlines in the 18 months before the May 11 crash outside Miami of one of its flights, according to internal F.A.A. documents. The documents, in addition to records at other Federal agencies, portray a rapidly growing airline that was repeatedly found to have shortcomings in safety matters in such areas as record keeping, maintenance, training and cockpit discipline.

headline: Serbs' Leader In Bosnia Is Again Told To Step Down
abstract: As part of an intensifying Western effort to oust the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, the senior civilian official overseeing the peace accord has set a July 1 deadline for his removal from office.         The official, Carl Bildt, said that if Dr. Karadzic did not step down then, Serbia, which has considerable power over the Bosnian Serbs, would face renewed  international economic sanctions.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Foote, Cone In Latin America
abstract: The Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications has been awarded  a large assignment in Latin America. Separately, True North is making an acquisition in Canada.

headline: Gunmen Slay Irish Reporter Who Wrote on Gangs
abstract: Veronica Guerin, 33, one of Ireland's most prominent investigative reporters, was shot dead this afternoon after two men intercepted her car on a road in a Dublin suburb.         Ms. Guerin, who specialized in reporting on criminal gangs, was killed on a main road near the town of Clondalkin, the police said.

headline: SPENDING IT;Where the I.R.S. Aims the Prosecution Ax
abstract: AS you slip your tax return in the mail just ahead of tomorrow night's filing deadline, perhaps a bit nervous that the Internal Revenue Service might decide to make a Federal case out of something amiss on your forms, take a deep breath  and check your return address.         If you happen to live in New Mexico, Idaho or South Dakota, you can relax, more or less. But if you are thinking of playing games with Uncle Sam in Roanoke, Va., Pittsburgh or Tulsa, Okla., you may have something to worry about.

headline: Former U.S. Senator Picked to Head Northern Ireland Peace Talks
abstract: Ireland and Britain today appointed former Senator George J. Mitchell, who headed an international commission on disarmament of paramilitary forces in Northern Ireland, to be the chairman of the broad-based peace talks scheduled to start on Monday in Belfast.         The appointment, announced in London by the Irish Foreign Minister, Dick Spring, and the British Northern Ireland Secretary, Sir Patrick Mayhew, came as  officials and citizens on all sides waited to see whether the Irish Republican Army would restore its cease-fire before the talks start. The I.R.A. ended its 17-month cease-fire on Feb. 9 with a series of bomb attacks in London.

headline: Uganda Leader Looks Set for Election Victory
abstract: President Yoweri Museveni, the former rebel commander who fought his way to power 10 years ago, appeared headed for a landslide victory today in Uganda's first presidential election. But the main opposition candidate said he would not accept the results.         The opposition leader, Paul Ssemogerere, 64, the head of the Democratic Party, asserted that there had been widespread fraud. He accused election officials appointed by President Museveni of intimidating opposition voters in rural areas.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;One Bidder Drops Offer For Finnish Company
abstract: Svedala A.B., a Swedish maker of heavy machinery, withdrew its bid of 1.4 billion markka ($300 million) for Tampella Oy, a Finnish engineering company that specializes in drilling, mining and handling heavy goods. The announcement  comes after Sandvik A.B., a Swedish maker of steel and industrial tools, said it had acquired 48.2 percent of Tampella.          Sandvik bought nine million shares in Tampella yesterday. Of these, seven million were bought from Outokumpu Oy, a Finnish metals and mining company, Sandvik said.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE KINGMAKER;From War Hero to Populist Politician
abstract: The retired general who came in third in Sunday's presidential race, and whose endorsement is now avidly sought by Boris N. Yeltsin, has been caricatured as a strident nationalist determined to rebuild the Russian empire on the ashes of the old Soviet Union.         But judged by his platform and his manner, Aleksandr I. Lebed is more Colin Powell than Vladimir Zhirinovsky. An Afghan war hero whose face bears the scars  of a boxing career, Mr. Lebed is well known in the West for his impolitic prediction that the Soviet Union would be partly recreated.

headline: Hanoi Seeks Western Cash but Not Consequences
abstract: In Da Nang, the favored paint color seems to be electric blue. Here in the city still popularly known as Saigon it is mostly white. On storefronts and billboards all over the country, neat swatches of paint have recently been applied, under Government orders, to blot out the brand names of foreign consumer products.         Even as Vietnam hustles desperately for foreign investment, it has launched a campaign to obliterate one of the most visible indicators of its success. In a two-month-old campaign against what the Government calls "social evils," foreign advertising has been demonized along with prostitution, gambling and illicit drugs.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PHYSICIANS CORPORATION SELLS FLORIDA DOCTORS UNIT
abstract: The Physicians Corporation of America, based in Miami, said yesterday that it had sold Physicians First Inc., a network that includes 125 doctors in 40 medical centers in Florida, to FPA Medical Management Inc. for $23 million. The  agreement includes a long-term full-risk contract with FPA, based in San Diego,  to manage the medical care of the Physicians Corporation members who use the centers, the company said. The network provides medical services to about 90,000 people, mainly enrolled in health maintenance organizations operated by the Physicians Corporation. Physicians said the sale would add about $7.5 million to its second-quarter earnings.

headline: Everest Takes Worst Toll, Refusing to Become Stylish
abstract: Around dusk on Saturday, with two American climbers and five others missing and probably already dead atop Mount Everest, a 35-year-old New Zealander made a satellite telephone call to his pregnant wife from a snowhole just below the summit of the world's highest peak.         His voice weak from frostbite, the climber, Rob Hall, murmured what may have  been his last words before he died. "Hey look, don't worry about me," he said.

headline: U.S. and China Agree on Pact To Fight Piracy
abstract: After a month of intense negotiations, China and the United States reached a  broad agreement today on how to crack down more effectively on the piracy of music, movies and computer software in China, and Washington halted plans to impose $2 billion in trade sanctions.         In three final days of round-the-clock talks, with today's deadline for United States sanctions looming, the Chinese agreed to new measures to ban the reproduction and sale of pirated intellectual property. The Chinese and American negotiators ended their intricate game of brinksmanship when the Chinese relented slightly on two final issues, announcing they had closed down two more  pirate compact disk factories -- bringing the total closed this year to 15 -- and expanded permission for foreign music and movie companies to produce and sell their products inside China.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GUESS TO RAISE $188 MILLION IN PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Guess Inc., the well-known designer of blue jeans and other types of casual apparel, said in a filing yesterday that it planned to raise about $188 million  through an initial public offering. The company plans to sell 9.2 million common shares at $21 to $23 each, according to its filing. Founded by the Marciano brothers in 1981, Guess markets its apparel under the trademarks Guess, Guess U.S.A. and Triangle Design. Guess expects the offering to raise about $188 million after expenses if the stock sells for $22 a share. The company will use  the proceeds to repay notes.

headline: Information Highway Hits the Road
abstract: John Krachenfels, the manager of business development at the Oracle Corporation, was cruising through Silicon Valley not long ago. He was going a "few miles over the speed limit," he acknowledged, and glancing at his electronic mail at the same time, when a California Highway Patrol officer pulled him over.         Spotting the open laptop connected to a cellular modem in the front passenger seat, the officer asked, "Sir, what is the maximum safe speed for computing?"

headline: MARKET WATCH;Inflation Is Dead Forever, They Hope
abstract: There are a lot of ways for a company to increase sales. One is to offer customers a deal so good they will leap at it in droves. Of course, if the deal  is that good, the company may come to regret offering it.         That appears to be what is going on at Sprint, the No. 3 company in the long-distance telephone business. It is offering residential customers a rate of 10 cents a minute during night and weekend hours, forever. That is bringing in new subscribers faster than Wall Street expected, and last week's strong profit report sent Sprint's share price up 5 percent.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NALCO CHEMICAL TO BUY WATER TREATMENT UNIT OF MOLSON
abstract: The Molson Companies said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Water Technologies business to the Nalco Chemical Company for $112 million (Canadian), or about $82 million (United States). Water Technologies provides water treatment services in Canada, the United States, Britain and Italy. The business had sales of $82 million (Canadian) in the fiscal year that just ended. Nalco is a chemical concern based in Naperville, Ill.; Molson, which is based in Toronto, is best known for its brewing business.

headline: World News Briefs;Bulgarian King Returns After a 50-Year Absence
abstract: King Simeon II, who fled a Communist takeover in 1946, returned to Bulgaria today to a festive pealing of Church bells and an enthusiastic welcome from royalists.         Tens of thousands of Bulgarians turned out to welcome the 58-year-old King, who works as a business consultant in Madrid, after a 50-year absence.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Plunges 70.09, Dragged Down by I.B.M. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 70.09 points, or 1.2 percent, to 5,549.93, dragged down by a slide of $10.25, to $105.25, in I.B.M., which reported better-than-expected earnings, but saw narrower profit margins ahead.

headline: World News Briefs;Rioting by Vietnamese Continues in Hong Kong
abstract: Rioting Vietnamese in a detention center in Hong Kong hurled rocks and spears today as the police fought back with tear gas in a second day of rioting by boat people resisting deportation.         The Vietnamese waved banners, shouted slogans and bombarded the police from barracks rooftops after authorities tried to round them up for the latest wave of forced repatriation. Security forces said six officers were injured in the clash.

headline: VW Allows G.M. Lawsuit To Advance
abstract: Volkswagen A.G., the German auto maker, agreed today to receive a United States civil complaint filed by the General Motors Corporation, which has accused VW of industrial espionage and is seeking punitive damages.         Though VW, which denies the espionage charges, agreed to accept the complaint under United States jurisdiction, it said it would seek to have the case transferred to a German court. Under legal traditions in Germany, punitive damages are not awarded in civil cases.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Intuit Takes a One-Time Charge, Causing a Third-Quarter Loss
abstract: Intuit Inc. reported a slight loss for its fiscal third quarter today, mainly because of a one-time charge.         The company also said it would acquire a developer of an Internet-based system that gives consumers personalized insurance information.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ex-Prosecutor in Mexico Assassinated in Tijuana
abstract: A former federal prosecutor was shot to death today as he jogged on a public  running track in Tijuana.         The prosecutor, Jose Arturo Ochoa Palacios, who headed the Attorney General's office in the Baja California until May 1994, was shot four times in the head and abdomen at close range and died where he fell. Investigators said two young  men ran alongside Mr. Ochoa and one fired the shots.

headline: The Media Business: What They're Buying in 9 Countries: France;Television vs. The Bistro
abstract: Few cities in the world offer a richer fare of movies and restaurants than Paris, yet the number of movie-goers has slumped and neighborhood bistros continue to close. The culprit? Television. The French now spend an average of three hours each day watching television -- principally between 7 P.M. and 10:30 P.M. -- compared with about four hours of daily viewing in the United States. Just as TV Guide is one of the United States' top-selling magazines, France's three top-selling magazines are voted to television.          The local movie industry has particular cause for complaint because, while the French still love films, they increasingly watch them on television. In the  last week of April, two of the three top-rated programs were movies. Several evenings a week, the two main channels, the privately owned TF1 and the Government-owned France 2, show movies, Canal-Plus, the pay-TV station, is largely a movie channel. Only crucial soccer games draw higher ratings.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;YOUNG AGREES TO BUY TV STATION FROM DISNEY
abstract: Young Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Los Angeles television station KCAL-TV from the Walt Disney Company for $385 million. The acquisition would more than double the United States television households reached by Young, a broadcaster based in New York, to 9.3 percent from 4.1 percent, and increase its revenue by 40 percent, from $122.5 million last year. Young owns 10 television stations. As part of Disney's $19 billion purchase of Capital Cities /ABC Inc. in February, the company was required by Federal regulators to sell KCAL. It is the only independent TV station in Los Angeles, the nation's No. 2 market after New York. Disney's stock was up $1.50 a share, to $60.75. Young's stock was up $3.375, to $33.125.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;British Firm Names San Francisco Head
abstract: The British agency Leagas Delaney said yesterday that it had hired as the top manager of its new San Francisco office an executive who has been responsible for the important Levi Strauss & Company account at the San Francisco office of  Foote, Cone & Belding.          Jack Rooney, 38, has been senior vice president and worldwide account director on the Levi Strauss account, with billings estimated at $130 million, for almost five years. Effective Monday, he will leave Foote, Cone, a unit of True North Communications, to become the managing director of the San Francisco  office of Leagas Delaney, which is based in London. Mr. Rooney's appointment brings the staff in San Francisco to 10; the office was opened to work on the United States unit of Adidas A.G., a Leagas Delaney client in nearly 50 countries.

headline: Market Place;An unusual security helps people like Eli Broad cash out.
abstract: LI BROAD has become rich twice by anticipating the needs of the Baby Boomers  and trying to meet them. Now he is moving to cash in a substantial part of his profits, on terms that could give him about $194 million tax free.         The securities being sold this week on behalf of Mr. Broad, the chairman of SunAmerica Inc., are part of a trend on Wall Street that uses an unusual type of security to get cash. Just as if he had sold the 3.45 million shares of SunAmerica underlying the transaction, Mr. Broad will get the cash now and will  not suffer if the market value of the shares falls later.

headline: Dmitrovskoye Journal;Mansions Muscling In On the Humble Dachas
abstract: It is the season of wildflowers, cabbages and beets in Russia. Each bright, endless day is a gift bestowed on millions seeking shelter in the countryside from the drab, hopeless streets of the city.         The short summer, cherished beyond reason in this land defined by winter, revolves completely around the summer cottage, or dacha. To the Western mind a Russian dacha may conjure images of wealth: Chekhov, grand houses with gables, rolling fields and picket fences. Dozens of dacha communities have recently emerged to serve the new Russian rich, where houses come with price tags that would make a habitue of the Hamptons blush.

headline: Group Asserts U.S. Workers Are Better Off Than Thought
abstract: Injecting its voice into the debate over economic insecurity, a lobbying group representing the nation's manufacturers issued an analysis today that it said rebutted "the conventional wisdom that wage stagnation and job loss represent reality for American workers."         The National Association of Manufacturers said in its report that there were  valid reasons why workers might feel uneasy about the future, reciting what has  now become a familiar list to employees of almost any company: global competition, the fast pace of technological change, demands on the labor force to continually upgrade its skills and the bigger bite taken out of paychecks by  taxes.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;TBWA Chiat/Day Loses an Executive
abstract: Richard N. Costello, the president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/ Day East in New York, is leaving unexpectedly, effective July 15, to head a new strategic marketing unit of MCA Inc. in Universal City, Calif.         Mr. Costello, 52, has been responsible for the New York, St. Louis and Toronto offices of TBWA Chiat/Day since August, when the Omnicom Group formed the agency by merging Chiat/Day with the North American operations of TBWA International. Mr. Costello's position will not be filled, said William G. Tragos, the chairman and chief executive of TBWA International, adding that he would consult with Bob Kuperman, president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/Day West in Venice, Calif., on North America.

headline: World News Briefs;Marines Land in Liberia To Guard U.S. Embassy
abstract: Marines arrived in Monrovia today to take over security at the American Embassy and dozens more foreigners trapped in factional fighting were flown to safety.         The marines number about 1,500, but only about 200 were expected to be on the ground in the embassy, replacing the American Army paratroopers based in Europe  who have been protecting the building for the last week. The rest of the marine  force will remain offshore.

headline: Bank of New York Plans Larger Bad-Loan Reserve
abstract: In another sign that banks are running into unexpected trouble with their consumer loans, the Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it would put $350 million into its reserves for future losses in its credit card portfolio.         Analysts said the move reflected the rising losses from credit cards as a result of rapidly increasing consumer bankruptcies.

headline: ELECTRIC UTILITIES TO PROVIDE ACCESS FOR COMPETITORS
abstract: In a move that could eventually save American consumers billions of dollars a year in electricity bills, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission ordered electric utilities today to open up their transmission systems to outside energy providers.         The ruling applied only to the distribution of wholesale power and thus did not break the monopoly hold that utilities have over residential customers.

headline: Burmese Dissident Presses Demands, Putting Junta on Defensive
abstract: In the last few days, the military Government of Myanmar has imprisoned hundreds of its opponents, filled the controlled press with threats against them, and gathered tens of thousands of people for pro-Government rallies. But it is on the defensive as it has not been for years.         After a mass gathering of her supporters that the military had tried desperately to suppress, the Burmese pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said today in a telephone interview from her home in Myanmar, formerly known as  Burma, that she planned to move forward with a program of action that is a direct challenge to the ruling junta.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CHASE TO CUT 600 JOBS IN ROCHESTER BECAUSE OF MERGER
abstract: The Chase Manhattan Corporation will cut 600 jobs in Rochester in the next two years because of its merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation, the company said yesterday. Chase now has 2,000 employees in Rochester. The cuts will be in back-office support functions, a spokesman, Ken Herz, said. Officials of Chemical and Chase predicted in March, when the merger was completed, that the combination would result in the loss of 12,000 jobs over all.

headline: Beijing Vows To Punish Unauthorized Arms Exports
abstract: China said today that it would punish any company or individual who it finds  has sold weapons or military equipment to the United States without Government review or approval.         American diplomats sought cooperation from officials here on the case brought last week by the Federal authorities in California against Chinese and Taiwanese citizens accused of selling 2,000 fully automatic AK-47 assault rifles produced  in China's state-run munitions companies to undercover United States law enforcement officers.

headline: Where Old Computer Parts Are Given New Lives
abstract: From the outside, Micro Exchange looks like a modest-sized store selling used computers from $99 (for an I.B.M. with a 386 chip) to $1,600 (for a Dell with a  Pentium 166 chip).         But in the back, and in a larger warehouse in nearby Wayne, the company has dozens of technicians testing, repairing and disassembling computers that range  from almost new to those that reach back to the dawn of the personal computer era.

headline: World News Briefs;At Nervous Chernobyl, Another Accident
abstract: A worker at the Chernobyl nuclear plant disposed of some radioactive material today in a container that was not completely sealed, raising new fears of contamination 10 years after the world's worst commericial nuclear disaster.         Officials had initially reported a small radiation leak at the plant. Later they said that it was a case of improper handling of nuclear waste and that it had been cleaned up without incident.

headline: In Malawi, Pilgrims Throng to an AIDS Potion
abstract: It is midday at Billy Chisupe's compound, five rutted miles off the last paved road, deep in the hot countryside of cow dung huts, cotton, maize and sunflower fields.         In the carefully swept dirt yard there are three huts, one slightly bigger than the rest and surrounded by a veranda kept cool and shady by a grass roof.

headline: Petro-Canada Said to Be Paying $538 Million for Unit of Rival
abstract: Petro-Canada said today that it would buy Amerada Hess Canada Ltd. from the Amerada Hess Corporation for $731 million (Canadian), or $538 million (United States).         Petro-Canada, which is based here, said that at least half the cost of the acquisition would be financed through a stock offering to North American and international investors. The remainder would be paid using bank loans.

headline: National Semiconductor Settles On a New Chief
abstract: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had named Brian L.  Halla chairman, chief executive and president, succeeding Gilbert F. Amelio, who left in February to head Apple Computer Inc.         Mr. Halla, 49, will lead National Semiconductor's office of the president, which also includes Ellen Hancock, Richard Beyer and Kirk Pond. Those three executives had been leading the company since Mr. Amelio's departure.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Apple Plans An Offering Of 6% Notes
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that it would offer $575 million in convertible debt, in what analysts called a positive step by the troubled company to raise cash.         Apple's offering was announced as Treasury prices recovered from an early slide to end slightly higher for the first time in three sessions.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICA ONLINE TO SELL ADVERTISING FOR NETSCAPE SITE
abstract: America Online Inc. said yesterday that it and the Netscape Communications Corporation were forming an unusual arrangement in which America Online sales representatives would also sell advertising space on Netscape's World Wide Web site. Netscape has one of the most popular sites on the Web, allowing visitors to download its Navigator software, which helps users browse the Web. Analysts said they expected the deal to bring in more revenues for America Online.

headline: Stocks Up in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks had small gains early today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of  225 issues was up 78.08 points, at 22,022.61. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 244.77 points.

headline: Where, Oh Where, Have All the Corporate Raiders Gone?
abstract: THEY were the much-feared and often reviled commanders of the takeover wars of the 1980's. Fueled by junk bonds, they raided corporate America seemingly at  will, and made vast fortunes. In their heyday, they hobnobbed with the junk-bond king Michael R. Milken at his annual "Predators' Ball."         But this is the 1990's. Junk bonds and greenmail are out, Mr. Milken is a private citizen after spending two years in jail and paying $1.1 billion in fines and settlements for securities-laws violations, and a restructured corporate America has made itself resistant to the unwanted attentions of wheeler-dealers.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: PACIFIC GATEWAY PROPERTIES INC., San Francisco, an office building developer with 3.9 million shares outstanding, received a proposal to be acquired for $5 a share in cash. The name of the bidder was not disclosed.

headline: INVESTING IT;As Retail Rebounds, Investors Snap Up Loehmann's
abstract: WHEN Loehmann's Inc. went public Tuesday, the scene had all the energy associated with the fabled women's clothing store. Investors snapped up the stock as if they were bargain designer dresses, pushing prices from an anticipated $14 a share to $22.25 at day's end. By the weekend, the stock had risen still more, closing Friday at $27.375. Even the most bullish retail analysts were surprised.         "I think people like their story," said Steven Tuen, a retail analyst at IPO  Value Monitor, an investment newsletter. He likes the Loehmann's story too, so much that he gave the 75-year-old chain a "hot" rating on his firm's scale for new offerings.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Treasury Securities Tumble On Fears of Higher Rates Prices of Treasury securities tumbled, reflecting fears that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates earlier than expected. A former Fed governor, Lyle Gramley, said he expected the Fed to raise the Federal funds rate by a half percentage point at its July policy meeting.

headline: World News Briefs;Safety Lapses Cited In German Airport Fire
abstract: Officials at the airport here where 16 people died in a fire last week have admitted that there were serious lapses in safety procedures before and during the blaze.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Surging Grain Prices Raise Fears of Inflation Corn and wheat prices have climbed to records this month, because of bad weather, dwindling supply and strong demand at home and abroad.

headline: World News Briefs;Burmese Dissident Plans To Ignore Ban on Meeting
abstract: A leading Burmese advocate for democracy, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said in a statement today that she would go ahead with her regular weekend meeting in defiance of a Government ban.         Later the military Government of Myanmar, formerly Burma, announced on the state radio and television that anyone who disturbed public order would be liable to prison terms of 5 to 20 years.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nomura Posts Loss From Write-Down
abstract: The Nomura Securities Company, Japan's largest securities house, announced yesterday that its writedown of marketable securities for the year ended March 31 resulted in a valuation loss of 3.2 billion yen, or $29.5 million. The loss comes to 16 percent of its net income of 20.02 billion yen in the fiscal year ended March 1995.          The losses represent the April-March write-down of marketable securities, carried on an issue-by-issue basis, at the lower of cost or market price. Under the Tokyo Stock Exchange's guidelines, companies must disclose securities  valuation losses when the total exceeds certain percentages of results in the preceding year.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: Liberian Civilian Hostages Are Trapped in Mortar Attack
abstract: Several thousand Liberians held hostage in a barracks here by one of the country's warring militias came under mortar attack today by another faction for the second day. While the fighting continued, a United States evacuation effort  focused on pulling out stranded Americans and other foreigners from isolated hiding places here.         Diplomats said they had no way of verifying the number of people trapped in the camp. At the American Embassy a mile and a half away, loud thuds from the shelling could be heard.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Prices Drop Sharply In Speculation Over Sumitomo
abstract: Copper prices fell sharply in London and New York yesterday on speculation that huge sales by the Sumitomo Corporation could swamp the market.         On other markets, soybeans fell, while coffee prices rose.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PLANS SET TO CUT CASH DIVIDEND AS MUCH AS 71%
abstract: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company plans to slash its annual cash dividend as much as 71 percent as part of its plan to become a fast-growing managed health care company. The dividend reduction, which has been expected by analysts, will occur after the Hartford-based insurer completes its planned $8.9 billion acquisition of U.S. Healthcare Inc. In a document filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission last week, Aetna said it initially expected to pay an annualized dividend of about 80 cents to 83 cents, down from its current $2.76 a share.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COLOR GRAPHICS, Moorestown, N.J., a maker of direct-mail products, signed an agreement to be acquired by Anthony Nardiello, its chief executive, and an investment group headed by Eric L. Blum of Philadelphia.

headline: Competition May Thin Profits In Sport Utilities
abstract: From pint-sized Jeep Wranglers to Chevrolet Suburbans the size of a garage, sport utility vehicles have been the mainstay of profits at Detroit's Big Three  auto makers since the late 1980's. But now a small traffic jam of new models is  emerging in the market, and auto executives predict that the profits, while still enormous, will start to erode.         The Ford Motor Company plans to display its largest offering, the three-bench, nine-passenger Ford Expedition, at its annual meeting in Kansas City, Mo., on Thursday. In the last four months, Toyota has introduced the small RAV 4 sport utility and the Lexus LX 450, Nissan has completely redesigned its Pathfinder and Chrysler has come out with a new Jeep Wrangler.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHPLAN SERVICES IN DEAL FOR HARRINGTON SERVICES
abstract: The Healthplan Services Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Harrington Services Corporation, a closely held health benefits administrator, for about $67 million in cash and stock. The acquisition of Harrington, based in Columbus, Ohio, will give Healthplan Services a presence in the administration of managed care plans for large corporations. Harrington had 1995 revenues of $72 million. Healthplan Services, based in Tampa, Fla., expects to complete the transaction with $32.5 million in cash and 1.347 million shares.

headline: 55-Nation Conference on Fund-Raising for Bosnia Is Split Over theSerbs
abstract: Representatives of 55 countries began a two-day meeting today intended to raise $1.2 billion more in foreign economic aid for Bosnia and Herzegovina this  year. American and European officials disagreed about whether the discredited Bosnian Serb leadership should get any of the money yet.         The Bosnian Serbs, who control 49 percent of the country's territory, refused to attend the conference because the organizers insisted that they sit as part of one delegation representing Bosnia's separate but loosely integrated Muslim-Croatian Federation and the Serbian entity.

headline: THE TELEPHONE COLOSSUS: THE NEGOTIATIONS;NYNEX AND BELL ATLANTIC REACH ACCORD ON MERGER; LINKS 36 MILLION CUSTOMERS
abstract: Ending a prolonged public courtship, the Bell Atlantic and Nynex Corporations agreed yesterday to one of the largest corporate mergers in American history, people involved in the negotiations said.         The two regional telephone companies plan to announce the deal today at a news conference in New York City. Their boards unanimously approved the deal during a weekend of deliberations that followed two years of on-again, off-again talks.

headline: World News Briefs;Member of New Coalition To Lead Italian Senate
abstract: At the opening of Parliament today, Italy's center-left election winners voted their own man into the powerful post of Speaker of the Senate, the upper house, after efforts to strike a deal with the opposition fell through.         Election of the speakers is the first task of the new Parliament, Italy's third in four years, and one of the final obligations to be fulfilled before President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro can formally appoint Romano Prodi, leader of the  center-left Olive Tree alliance, as the Prime Minister-designate.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Expansion Is Solid, Fed Survey Finds The economy picked up at a moderate pace in March and April, a survey by the Federal Reserve found, more evidence that expansion is generally solid again, except in the New York area. Furthermore, price increases were subdued, the central bank said.

headline: China Says It Will Retaliate if U.S. Imposes Trade Sanctions
abstract: China warned today that it planned to retaliate heavily if the United States  imposes $2 billion of trade sanctions on China for failing to reduce the piracy  of computer software, music and movies.         A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Cui Tiankai, said China would respond immediately with a list of its own sanctions, amounting to even more than the American penalty, if Washington proceeds with its threat to impose 100 percent tariffs on a long list of Chinese-made goods.

headline: A Report Tries To Counteract Job-Loss Fears
abstract: The Council of Economic Advisers will report Tuesday that more than two-thirds of the new jobs created in the United States in 1994 and 1995 paid better than the average job, Administration officials said today, and that despite waves of corporate layoffs, the length of time most workers spent unemployed in recent years has actually declined.         Nonetheless, the report, written by Joseph E. Stiglitz, the head of the council, found some evidence that the rate at which jobs have been eliminated has risen slightly, despite strong economic growth. Though the evidence is murky -- and subject to differing interpretations within the Administration -- the statistics suggest that managers and other relatively high-paid white-collar workers who have been the focus of the most publicized layoffs are staying unemployed longer.

headline: World News Briefs;Albanians Sentence Ex-Leaders to Death
abstract: Five top officials of the former Communist Government were found guilty today of crimes against humanity; three were sentenced to die.         The verdict came just two days before parliamentary elections in which the Socialists have been gaining against the governing Democrats, who have been accused of pressuring the courts.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cadbury Schweppes To Buy Candy Maker
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said yesterday that a subsidiary had agreed to buy the British popcorn and candy maker Craven Keiller Ltd. No purchase price was released for the deal. Craven Keiller's products include toffees, popcorn and chocolates under the brand names Keiller, Barker and Dobson and Craven and Butterkist.          In its most recent fiscal year, Craven Keiller's sales were L42 million. Cadbury estimates that the British market for prepackaged popcorn has grown about 10 percent annually in recent years.   (AP)

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: IN WASHINGTON;Jet Crash Casts a Sudden Shadow Over Official Washington
abstract: At 10:30 this morning, President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, walked into the Oval Office with the news: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown's plane was missing in the Balkans and wreckage had been spotted. The rest was a welter of unconfirmed reports.         In that moment, a brilliant spring day turned to ashes. Minutes later, the deputy White House press secretaries, Ginny Terzano and Mary Ellen Glynn, crept  into the office of their boss, Michael D. McCurry, with news service bulletins and spirited him off to the top-secret Situation Room in the basement of the West Wing.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FORD PLANNING TO REDUCE ITS PRODUCTION OF MUSTANGS
abstract: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it would reduce its production of  Mustangs with the start of 1997 model year on Aug. 5, because of lower demand for the sporty car. The move, which would reduce Mustang output to 37 cars an hour on two shifts from 42.5 an hour now, would affect about 290 employees at Ford's Dearborn assembly plant, Ford said. Ford said the affected employees would be relocated to jobs at other Ford factories in the Detroit metropolitan area. Currently, 2,200 people are employed at Ford's 78-year-old Dearborn plant.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO BUY MAKER OF NEUROLOGY DEVICES
abstract: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Cyberonics Inc. for about $72 million, or $7 a share, and invest another $12 million later in newly issued Cyberonics shares for $5.50 each. Cyberonics, based in Webster, Tex., develops devices for the treatment of epilepsy and other neurological disorders. The company's products include a pacemaker-like device designed to reduce the incidence of seizures, which is still in the approval process with Federal regulators. St. Jude, which makes cardiovascular devices, is based in St. Paul.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: GALEY & LORD INC., New York, a manufacturer of cotton fabrics, acquired Dimmit Industries S.A. de C.V. of Mexico, a clothing subsidiary of Farah Inc., El Paso, for $22.5 million.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: Deregulation Of Phones: The Hard Part
abstract: Nobody ever said deregulation would be simple, especially when it comes to knocking down barriers to competition in the communications industry.         On Friday, acting in response to a sweeping telecommunications law signed recently by President Clinton, the Federal Communications Commission plans to issue a 100-page proposal for opening up the $100 billion local telephone business to new rivals.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HEWLETT-PACKARD REALIGNS ITS COMPUTER SALES UNIT
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company realigned its computer sales unit to add a group  focused on individual customers and small offices amid surging demand for small-business products. The group will be headed by Pradeep Jotwani, formerly marketing manager for the Inkjet Products Group. Hewlett-Packard, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., also announced formation of a commercial sales group to serve high-volume retailers. The company had previously announced creation of a group focused on large corporate customers.

headline: ITT and Planet Hollywood to Develop Casinos
abstract: The ITT Corporation hastened the convergence between Hollywood and Las Vegas  yesterday by announcing that its Caesars Palace gambling unit had agreed to develop several big casinos with the Planet Hollywood restaurant chain.         The move is significant not just for ITT, whose casino division has been searching for new ways to grow, but also for the entertainment and gambling industries. The two casinos already planned under the venture, in Las Vegas and Atlantic City, are likely to build links with movie studios and stars, accelerating the nascent effort to lure a new generation into casinos.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: U.S. Equestrian Team, Gladstone, N.J., to Burkhardt & Partners, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled by Classic Communication, Foxboro, Mass. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;High-Tech Accounts For Two Agencies
abstract: Two technology companies have selected San Francisco agencies for their accounts.         The Hewlett-Packard Company named Goodby, Silverstein & Partners to handle advertising in North America for printers, scanners and other computer peripheral equipment. That account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $45 million, had been handled for the last eight years by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in San Francisco, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;I.B.M. Stock Falls Despite Strong Profit
abstract: I.B.M. posted better-than-expected first-quarter operating earnings and raised its dividend for the first time in three years yesterday, but its stock plunged nearly 9 percent after the company's chief financial officer worried analysts and investors about its performance in the months ahead.

headline: Friend of Ex-Cravath Lawyer Guilty of Insider Trading
abstract: An insurance salesman from Las Vegas, Nev., pleaded guilty yesterday to one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud, admitting to insider trading based on information from a former lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm.         Edward W. Eizman, 35, who faces a maximum of five years in prison and a fine  of as much as $264,000, is scheduled to be sentenced on July 26, Mr. Eizman's lawyer, Stuart Abrams, said.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ladbroke Tells of Efforts To Reunite Hilton Units
abstract: The chairman of Ladbroke Group P.L.C., John Jackson, told shareholders yesterday that talks were continuing with the Hilton Hotels Corporation on a "range of ways" of reuniting the international Hilton hotel operations with those in the United States. Ladbroke runs Hilton hotels outside the United States and the Hilton Hotels Corporation, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., operates Hiltons in the United States. Last month, British news reports said Hilton was planning a bid of L3 billion ($4.5 billion) for Ladbroke.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL JENSEN INC., Lincolnshire, Ill., which makes speakers and other audio products, has accepted an offer from Recoton Corp., Lake Mary, Fla., to buy Jensen for $52 million in cash and stock and about $45 million in the assumption of debt.

headline: Move From Viacom to MCA Is Worth Millions to Biondi
abstract: For Frank J. Biondi Jr., being dismissed as chief executive of Viacom Inc. might prove to be one of the most profitable events of his career.         Not only did he get an undisclosed settlement for leaving Viacom, but the Seagram Company, which hired him away to become chief executive of its MCA division, has given him a five-year contract that is valued at $76 million by Graef Crystal, an independent compensation consultant.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Barings Executive Penalized in Britain
abstract: Britain's main markets regulator said today that it had banned the former head of finance at the collapsed merchant bank Barings from working in the financial industry as a manager or director for at least three years and charged him L10,000 ($15,000) in costs.         The Securities and Futures Authority, which began disciplinary action in March against a number of unnamed individuals linked to Barings, said the executive, Geoffrey Broadhurst, had been removed from its registers of directors and managers for at least three years. The authority said Mr. Broadhurst, former head of group finance at the Baring Investment Bank, had not responded to the charges.

headline: Far From Former Yugoslavia, First War Crimes Trial Opens
abstract: The horrors of the smashed and ransacked villages of northern Bosnia were brought into court today as a United Nations tribunal opened the first trial to  deal with war crimes in the former Yugoslavia.         Accused is Dusan Tadic, 40, a Serbian policeman, who is to be be tried on 31  counts, including crimes against humanity, that involve the persecution, killing and torture of Muslims in and around Serbian-run prison camps in 1992.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;UNISYS SHAREHOLDERS REJECT PLAN TO SPLIT COMPANY
abstract: Shareholders of the Unisys Corporation yesterday rejected a plan by a dissident investor to split the company into three. About 68 percent of the shareholders voted against the plan while 30.2 percent voted in favor, Unisys said. The proposal was modeled after the AT&T Corporation's recent split-up and  was intended to staunch the company's losses. The biggest proponent of the splitting plan, Greenway Partners L.P., a New York investment firm. disputed the vote count. Greenway owns about 4 percent of Unisys, which has struggled to  shift its focus to computer management and consulting services from the manufacture of mainframe systems. James Unruh, Unisys's chief executive, said the plan would have failed because the new companies would have been unable to stand on their own.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inmet Sells Stake In Australian Company
abstract: The Inmet Mining Corporation of Toronto said yesterday that it had sold its 5.3 percent stake in MIM Holdings of Australia for about $150 million (Canadian), or $111 million (United States). Inmet sold all of its 75 million MIM Holdings shares and acquired options to buy 25 million MIM shares for $1.3 million (Canadian) to cover options previously written.          Inmet and MIM are both mining companies. Inmet will record an after-tax earnings increase of about $7 million (Canadian) from the transaction.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Bonds Stage Sharp Rally On New Data
abstract: Bonds rallied sharply yesterday, for the first time in a week, following data that suggested the economy was not growing at a fast enough pace to accelerate inflation and prompt an immediate Fed response.         The rally was prompted by Government reports showing a weaker-than-expected rise in retail sales and by an increase in initial jobless claims.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY National City Corp Oxford Inds Inc

headline: Taking In the Sites;Hey, Does Camp Granada Have a Home Page Yet?
abstract: If you couldn't get to the summer camp fairs held in February because you were shoveling snow, you can make up for lost time by researching camps on the World Wide Web.         Camp pages, or directories, are intended to allow users to make basic choices to narrow a search. You can search by state or region; look for sleep-away or day camps, or select coed, girls-only or boys-only programs. Within these categories is an alphabetical list with, at minimum, an address and phone number for each camp. Some camps have home pages, created by the directories for a fee.

headline: War Crimes Prosecutor Vents Frustrations
abstract: The chief prosecutor at the United Nations war crimes tribunal said today that NATO's refusal to order its troops to arrest Bosnian Serb leaders accused of atrocities threatens to undermine the fragile peace in the Balkans.         In his first public expression of frustration, the prosecutor, Richard Goldstone, said in an interview that the arrest of Radovan Karadzic, the indicted Bosnian Serb leader, "seems to me not only in the interests of justice  but in the interests of peace."

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Telecom Says Profit Fell 7.3% in Year
abstract: France Telecom said yesterday that its profit fell 7.3 percent in 1995, hurt  by higher corporate taxes and a drop in extraordinary gains. Net income for the  state-owned monopoly fell to 9.2 billion French francs ($1.84 billion), from 9.9 billion francs in 1994. Revenue rose to 147.8 billion francs from 142.6 billion  francs.          The drop in profit came amid broad changes being forced on France Telecom as it prepares for the 1998 deregulation of the European Union's $150-billion-a-year telecommunications market.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Brighter, But the Cheering Isn't by Leaders
abstract: The Mexican stock exchange hit record highs four days this week, interest rates dropped to their lowest point in seven months, and the once-wobbly peso traded at its strongest level since January.         But because the Mexican economy is still so fragile after last year's peso crisis, even the Government's top officials were reluctant to express much optimism.

headline: USAir Chairman Says Carrier's Solution Will Come From Outside
abstract: USAir's future lies in buying another airline, being acquired itself, or forming some partnership with another carrier, Stephen M. Wolf, the airline's new chairman, has told employees in the last few weeks.         According to people in attendance at meetings with employees, where Mr. Wolf  shared his analysis of USAir's strengths and weaknesses, he said he would prefer to see USAir grow internally, but that would be difficult to achieve in the current industry environment.

headline: SUMMIT IN MOSCOW URGES A-TEST BAN
abstract: Concluding their summit meeting, President Boris N. Yeltsin and the leaders of major industrialized nations called today for a speedy enactment of a nuclear test ban and announced measures to stop the smuggling of nuclear bomb ingredients.         But the session was also noteworthy for its warm embrace of the embattled Mr. Yeltsin, who is running for re-election in June, although President Clinton was  careful not to declare his preference for Mr. Yeltsin openly. [Page 10.]

headline: Wife of Jailed Nigerian Candidate Charged
abstract: The wife of the man who is believed to have won Nigeria's annulled presidential elections in 1993 and who is now in prison, was charged today with  publishing false documents.         Kudirat Abiola, the wife of Mashood K. O. Abiola, was held overnight and questioned by the police about documents claiming that her husband is Nigeria's  rightful President. One of the documents also called for the Nigeria's current leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, to give up power. Mrs. Abiola was released on bail pending a trail set for May 28. If found guilty of all charges she could face up to seven years in prison.

headline: Holy Man Linked to Premier Jailed in Indian Fraud Case
abstract: In a new embarrassment to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao during India's general election, a court today jailed a Hindu holy man, Chandraswamy, who has been Mr. Rao's spiritual adviser, political fixer and close friend for a quarter of a century.         After months of behind-the-scenes maneuvering by the Rao Government to keep Chandraswamy, 47, from joining the parade of Rao Government insiders who have drawn criminal indictments on corruption charges, the court rejected a lawyer's  plea that Chandraswamy be spared prison on the grounds of ill health. Instead, the self-proclaimed millionaire was ordered to Tihar jail in New Delhi for the night pending a court appearance on Saturday to answer charges of fraud.

headline: Chechen Rebels Say Leader Died in Russian Air Attack
abstract: Chechen rebels mourned their fallen leader today and vowed to carry on the fight against Russian forces for independence for Chechnya, the secessionist republic in southern Russia.         After a night of rumors and flatly contradictory reports, a senior rebel commander said today that the Chechen insurgents had confirmed that Dzhokhar M.  Dudayev, the rebel leader, had been killed in a Russian rocket attack.

headline: Russia Seeks to Limit An Arms Control Accord
abstract: The first steps in executing a new international agreement to control trade in conventional weapons have been slowed by Russia, which wants to limit the agreement.         Delegates from 31 countries, including the United States, convened here on Tuesday for what was to have been the first plenary session to form a group to supervise the agreement, define its duties, appoint a secretariat and discuss sources for its budget.

headline: 16 Foreign Law Firms Cleared To Open Offices in China
abstract: China's Justice Ministry approved the opening of offices by 16 international  law firms today, reflecting a brighter climate in Chinese-American business relations now that trade disputes have been put aside.         With foreign companies pouring into China in recent years, the need for business-related legal work has grown tremendously. Yet China has tightly limited the number of law firms allowed to fully operate.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Unions Reject Plan to Revive Airline
abstract: Unions at Alitalia rejected a new rescue plan for the troubled Italian air carrier yesterday and accused management of seeking to break up the state-owned  company and sell it off in pieces. Thursday, Alitalia's managing director, Domenico Cempella, disclosed his package of staff cuts, reduced costs and a capital increase of 3 trillion lire ($1.9 billion).         Alitalia's powerful unions, which have sunk two previous rescue plans, said the latest blueprint would have to be rewritten and demanded a meeting with the airline's directors. They particularly objected to a proposal to create two  new divisions under the wings of an Alitalia holding company.   (Reuters)

headline: For Albanians, in Carts and BMW's, a Hard Road
abstract: For Besa Mani, a 17-year-old high school student who watches American soaps,  drinks Fanta soda and yearns to be a judge, her country is a confusing place.         For nearly three years, she has walked a few hundred dusty yards to school and retraced her steps back home. She is too scared to go anywhere else. Her father and mother venture as far as the garden gate and no farther.

headline: DIARY: SETTING RECORDS;$1.8 Billion! Do I Hear 2?
abstract: What is it -- Olympic fever run amok? There seems to be some bizarre contest  going on to see which trader holds the world record for losing the most money in some complex market. Oh, yes, Nicholas Leeson of Barings lost $1.3 billion on derivatives in Singapore, and Toshihide Iguchi of Daiwa Bank dropped $1.1 billion on Treasury bonds. Rank amateurs, it's now clear. They've been left in the dust by Yasuo Hamanaka of Sumitomo, who over 10 years managed to lose $1.8 billion trading copper. Mr. Hamanaka, it seems, was practically a one-man copper market, buying and selling perhaps 500,000 tons of it a year -- fully 5 percent  of all copper traded worldwide -- not to mention the grab bag of futures and options that any self-respecting mega-trader must dabble in. The trouble was that he seemed to consistently pay too much, betting on higher prices, and he lost big. But the true Olympic feat was keeping Sumitomo in the dark about this  huge hole in its pocket.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: HARSCO CORP., Camp Hill, Pa., said it would merge its Sherwood brass-fittings division into the Taylor-Wharton Gas Equipment division to cut costs and add marketing channels for both businesses. The merged businesses would have more than $300 million a year in revenue.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;The High Cost of a Fine Smoke
abstract: The fall of the Soviet Union and rising American animus toward one of Marxism's last bulwarks are taking a sharp toll on an illicit pleasure: the consumption of Cuban cigars.         Though illegal to import, buy or sell here since President John F.Kennedy imposed a trade embargo on the Castro regime in July 1963, Cuban cigars had always remained relatively plentiful -- until late February. Now, smokers say, a box of Cubans is extremely difficult to find. And with prices doubling and tripling, only an elite few can afford those that are available.

headline: Ex-Radio Talk Show Host Ordered to Return Money
abstract: A Federal judge in New York has ordered Irwin H. (Sonny) Bloch, the former financial talk show host; his wife, Hilda Bloch, and six of his companies to return $3.9 million collected from listeners they persuaded to invest in three radio stations in Florida and Connecticut.         The default judgment was issued Thursday by Judge Allen G. Schwartz of United States District Court and released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which brought the civil case in May 1995. "He failed to answer or otherwise defend himself against the allegations," said Andrew Geist, an S.E.C.  attorney.

headline: Spreading the Economic Word;Black Pulpits, a White Businessman and Buying Power
abstract: Strong in faith but weak in economic leverage, prominent black church leaders are joining hands with a little-known white conservative businessman in a secular alliance to cash in on black spending power.         Five denominations representing more than 15 million members -- nearly half of America's black population -- will use the power of 43,000 pulpits next month to urge their flocks to buy products and services endorsed by the Revelation Corporation of America, the for-profit merchandising creation of John B. Lowery, a Memphis developer.

headline: I.R.A. Says It Set Bombs
abstract: The Irish Republican Army took responsibility today for two large bombs planted under a Thames River bridge.         The claim, telephoned to Ireland's R.T.E. broadcast network in Dublin, followed the arrests of several people in London this morning by police officers investigating recent I.R.A. bombings.

headline: MARKETS RETREAT AS INTEREST RATES CONTINUE TO CLIMB
abstract: Stock and bond prices tumbled today as long-term interest rates continued a swift, sharp ascent that is at odds with the Federal Reserve's policy of keeping rates stable and that analysts said could endanger the moderate rate of growth expected this year.         The latest rise in interest rates was set off by data on Friday that showed the economy creating jobs at a faster-than-expected clip. Although the stock market was closed for Good Friday, long-term rates jumped sharply in the bond market. Today that rise, plus a further increase in interest rates, gave the stock market a bad case of the jitters, put upward pressure on mortgage rates and further complicated the economic outlook in a Presidential election year.

headline: World News Briefs;Saudi Arabia Beheads Four in Bomb Attack
abstract: Despite threats of reprisals by militant Islamic groups, four Saudi nationals were beheaded in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, today for the bombing of a United States-run military installation there last November.

headline: Fed Survey Shows Marked Pickup in the Economy
abstract: A survey by the Federal Reserve pointed today to a marked pickup in the economy during March and April, more evidence that expansion is solid again in most parts of the country.         "Activity advanced at a moderate pace," the Fed's survey found, while price increases remained mostly subdued and there was "only scattered" upward pressure on wages despite a tight job market.

headline: Freeze in U.S. Aid Hampers New Haitian President's Recovery Effort
abstract: The final American combat unit withdrew last week, leaving a reduced United Nations presence here. Now the United States has frozen most of its economic aid to Haiti, which until recently was being hailed as one of the Clinton Administration's shining foreign policy triumphs.         Because of a law sponsored by Senator Bob Dole, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, about half of the $85 million in assistance that the United States had allocated this year will remain blocked until the Haitian Government shows progress in solving a series of killings of public figures here.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Monterey Pasta Co., San Francisco, to Ingalls Moranville Advertising, San Francisco, to handle its account, previously handled by Hyett, Broadbant & Heimbrodt, San Francisco. The billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million. * Big Book Inc., San Francisco, to I-Traffic Inc., New York, as the first Internet media agency of record for the on-line Yellow Pages directory. Billings were estimated at $1 million to $3 million. * Amazon.com Inc., Seattle, to CKS Partners, Portland, Ore., a unit of the CKS Group Inc., as the marketing agency of record for Amazon.com Books, a bookstore  on the Internet. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million. * Microsoft Corp., Redmond, Wash., to Spring, O'Brien & Co., New York, to develop an advertising and marketing program for Microsoft's financial services  group. Billings have not been determined. * Black & Decker, Shelton, Conn., to Nick and Paul, New York, to handle a creative assignment for the household products group that includes advertising,  direct mail and packaging for new products. Billings have not been determined. * Summit Bancorp, Chatham, N.J., a newly formed subsidiary of UJB Financial Corp., Princeton, N.J., and Summit Bancorporation, Chatham, to the Lunar Group,  Whippany, N.J. Billings were not disclosed. * Consumer Health Services, Boulder, Colo., to Media Direct Partners, New York,  to handle the media buying part of the account of 1-800-DOCTORS, a telephone medical service, with billings estimated at $4 million to $6 million. Those duties had been handled by Creative Media, New York, which is being acquired by  the Omnicom Group. * Castrol North America Automotive, Wayne, N.J., a unit of Burmah Castrol P.L.C., to Castor Advertising Corp., New York, as the first agency to handle advertising and promotions aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: A Real Estate Merger
abstract: Two Buffalo-area companies have merged to form the largest independent real estate company in New York state. Stovroff & Herman Realtors Inc. and H. Potter  Realtors Inc. announced Tuesday that they had joined forces to create a company  with combined 1995 sales of $782.3 million and more than 900 sales agents. The new company is called Stovroff & Potter Real Estate Inc. and will cover Erie and Niagara Counties, which have a combined population of about 1.2 million. The merger creates the 35th-largest real estate company in the nation. Its headquarters will be here in Amherst, a suburb of Buffalo.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW JONES & CO. (DJ,N)
abstract: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell nearly 19 percent, a decline greater than analysts had expected, as a result of  higher newsprint costs and expenses for new television operations.         The New York-based publisher of The Wall Street Journal said that its net income fell to $37.6 million, or 39 cents a share, from $46.4 million, or 48 cents, a year earlier. The per-share results were below the average estimate of  43 cents of four analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Doner Gets Account Of U.S. Cellular
abstract: The United States Cellular Corporation in Chicago, the wireless communications unit of Telephone and Data Systems Inc., has named W. B. Doner &  Company to handle its account, which for the last five years had been at McConnaughy Stein Schmidt Brown in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $25 million.         Doner, which is based in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich., was awarded the account on Friday after a three-month review that involvedsix other finalists: Cramer-Krasselt in Chicago; Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, a unit of Havas Advertising; Grant/Jacoby in Chicago; Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago; Korey Kay & Partners in New York, and Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., which is owned by the Omnicom Group.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:      MONDAY

headline: SPENDING IT;Why Those Backyards Are Looking Like Versailles
abstract: THE small fishpond that Dennis Broderick placed in front of his home in Merriam, Kan., in 1992 was more a tribute to the memory of his grandfather than  a gardening statement.         "I always said I wanted to have one," Mr. Broderick said.

headline: Chrysler Curb Being Proposed In California
abstract: A California judge proposed yesterday that the Chrysler Corporation be prohibited from shipping new cars to its 300 dealers in the state for 60 days as a punishment after he found that the auto maker had resold 119 cars and trucks that had been returned under the state's "lemon law."         The Department of Motor Vehicles asked Keith Levy, an administrative judge in Sacramento, to review the economic consequences of the proposal, which some Chrysler dealers say would be devastating to their business.

headline: Cereal That Says 'You've Won' Instead of 'Snap, Crackle, Pop'
abstract: The company that tried to convince us that its rice cereal says "snap, crackle, pop" has now succeeded in putting a voice in some of its breakfast-food boxes.         "Congratulations!" certain boxes of Kellogg's Corn Pops will be announcing over the next few months when a lucky buyer opens one. "You are a winner!"

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TESORO REACHES AN ACCORD WITH DISSIDENT INVESTORS
abstract: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a shareholder group that has tried to remove the company's board  for the last two years. The group, the Committee for New Management, agreed not  to seek control of the l company or support any outside candidates for its board until 1999. Tesoro, an oil company based in San Antonio, will add three directors to its board, increasing membership to nine. Sanford B. Prater, a partner in the company's largest shareholder, Ardsley Advisory Partners, and Dr. Alan Kaufman, a member of the shareholders group, will join the board. Tesoro's  governance committee will select a third member who now has no connection to the company, the shareholders' group or Ardsley.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;A Consolidation By Domino's
abstract: Domino's Pizza Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its regional advertising and spot media-buying accounts at the Detroit office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, effective Aug. 1. The accounts, with billings estimated at $35 million, have been split among four agencies.         Tim McIntyre, a spokesman for Domino's in Ann Arbor, Mich., confirmed reports of the consolidation this week in trade publications. The decision to consolidate at Thompson Detroit, a unit of the WPP Group, came after a monthlong review that also included a Domino's regional roster shop, Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., a unit of the Omnicom Group that has  handled the Midwest and Northeast regional accounts.

headline: In Sweden, a Shy Dynasty Steps Out
abstract: IT is one of the most powerful business families in the world, Sweden's answer to the Rockefellers. Yet outside select circles in Europe, the name Wallenberg is likely to ring bells only for those who have heard the tale of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who disappeared mysteriously in Russia at the end of World War II after rescuing thousands of Jews.         But Raoul was only a distant cousin of the reigning patriarch, Peter Wallenberg, and was never involved in the family business, which began when their great-grandfather, Andre Oscar Wallenberg, opened a bank in Stockholm in 1856. The empire has since expanded to control companies representing some 40 percent of the Swedish stock market.

headline: Fidelity to Buy Bank Back-Office Provider
