abstract: In an aggressive diversification move away from usual mutual fund business, Fidelity Investments agreed yesterday to acquire a Broadway & Seymour Inc. unit  that provides back-office operations to bank trust departments.         The $35 million acquisition, while small for Fidelity, is a radical departure for the mutual fund company, a unit of FMR Corporation. In moving into new lines of business, Fidelity has long adhered to a "build, don't buy" strategy, said Burton J. Greenwald, an industry consultant.

headline: Japanese Stocks Gain
abstract: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 22,146.50, up 41.70 points, or almost two-tenths of 1 percent. On Wednesday, the index gained 287.18 points, or 1.32 percent, to 22,104.80, encouraged by buying in export companies like Sony and Matsushita Electric Industrial.

headline: New Product to Improve Satellite Navigation
abstract: Harnessing military-navigation capabilities of the United States and Russia,  a Silicon Valley company today plans to introduce the first satellite receiver for business use that can utilize the signals of both nations' global-positioning satellite networks.         By combining signals from both networks, the system can tell users, with 10 times the accuracy of the current global-positioning system, where they are.

headline: Dole Wavers On Extending Trade Rights For China
abstract: In the first indication that Washington's dealing with China could become a major campaign-year argument in Congress, Senator Bob Dole appeared to back away today from years of support for extending broad trade privileges to Beijing, saying he had not decided whether to oppose the Clinton Administration's efforts to renew those trade rights this spring.         Mr. Dole has been under sharp pressure from the right wing of his party to abandon the traditional Republican position that the best way to influence China's behavior is to engage it economically. But as recently as a few days ago, when he canceled a major speech on his policy toward China, his advisers insisted that he was still firmly in favor of "most-favored nation" status for China, on which billions of dollars of trade with American companies -- and perhaps the economic futures of Hong Kong and Taiwan -- depend.

headline: Split Between Aristide and His Successor Imperils Haiti's GoverningParty
abstract: For years, they were so close that people here routinely referred to them as  twin brothers. But now that Rene Preval has succeeded Jean-Bertrand Aristide as  President, a sudden eruption of sibling rivalry appears to be eroding their relationship and threatening the unity of their party.         Three months after Mr. Preval was sworn in, the Lavalas movement, under whose banner both men were elected, is splintering, with the dominant group supporting Mr. Preval but others sticking by Mr. Aristide. Allies of the new President accuse Mr. Aristide of seeking to maintain control of "the Lavalas family" as a  base to mount a campaign to return to office four years from now.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Designates China As Worst Copyright Violator Washington designated China as the worst violator of agreements intended to combat the piracy of American videocassettes, compact disks, computer software and other products, a step that seemed to lay the groundwork for sanctions against Beijing.

headline: India's Government Wins Confidence Vote
abstract: India's coalition Government won a vote of confidence in Parliament today, ending a power struggle that had caused a virtual suspension of Government activity since elections last month.         By a voice vote, Parliament endorsed the Government of Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda, a coalition of 13 parties, called the United Front, ranging from Communists to centrists.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;GENENTECH SET TO END DEVELOPMENT OF CANCER DRUG
abstract: Genentech Inc. said yesterday that it would stop developing its drug Actimmune as a treatment for renal cell carcinoma because of clinical data that  showed the drug caused no significant benefit for the condition. Genentech, a San Francisco-based biotechnology company, said patients treated with Actimmune  fared no better than a group that was administered placebos. Renal cell carcinoma is a type of cancer that attacks the kidneys. Genentech said the findings do not change the current recommendations for Actimmune in treating chronic granulomatous disease, an immunodeficiency disorder. Genentech's stock slipped 25 cents, to $52.625, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: VICTIMS -- A Banker and 3 Others on Ill-FatedMission; Lee Jackson, Banking Representative, 37
abstract: Lee Jackson was the United States representative on the board of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development,         He was 37 and was based in London.

headline: Russian Polls: Mostly Wrong, But the Only Game in Town
abstract: With one month left before this anguished nation chooses its next President,  public opinion polls -- which have never come close to predicting Russian voting patterns -- are now among the country's principal obsessions.         The polls have become so popular and influential, in fact, that they threaten seriously to distort the voting behavior they are supposed to predict.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Reports 14% Rise in Sales
abstract: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its sales for the first five months of 1996 had risen about 14 percent, and it forecast a  slight increase in sales and revenues for the balance of 1996.  The German car maker said its worldwide vehicle sales rose to 1.65 million units in the period  from January to May, compared with 1.44 million units in the period a year ago.           At the company's annual general meeting, Volkswagen said it had increased its stake in the Western European vehicle market to 17 percent, from 16.5 percent in the 1995 period. North American sales rose 6.7 percent, to 89,200 vehicles, from 83,600.   (Reuters)

headline: Times Expects Steady 2d-Quarter Earnings
abstract: earnings, excluding a one-time gain on a real estate transaction, to approximate its results in the comparable 1995 quarter. The latest results will include a charge against earnings for employee severance.         In the second quarter of 1995, the Times Company earned 45 cents a share. The company said the expected results for the latest quarter were in line with management's expectations. Wall Street had been forecasting about 49 cents a share in the second quarter, based on the average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.

headline: Magellan Fund Chief Explains Cautious Strategy
abstract: The portfolio manager of Fidelity Magellan, the nation's largest mutual fund, said worries about "considerable speculation in the stock market over all" led him to make a controversial shift last year of nearly one-third of the fund's $56 billion in assets out of stocks and into bonds and cash.         Jeffrey N. Vinik, the Magellan manager, says in the fund's annual report that while he is not bearish on stocks, "I am cautious," and that his move into bonds was based on expectations for the next 12 to 24 months.

headline: Mild Sanctions on the Sudan Approved by U.N. Council
abstract: The Security Council agreed today to impose mild sanctions on the Sudan unless it hands over three men accused of trying to assassinate President Hosni  Mubarak of Egypt last June.         The resolution was approved 13-0, with China and Russia abstaining.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Information Resources takes aim at the ethnic market, and Nielsen.
abstract: INFORMATION RESOURCES INC., the market-research company, is expected to announce today that it will join forces with Univision, the largest Spanish-language television network in the United States, in an attempt to take  the lead in one of the biggest areas of growth in advertising: ethnic marketing.         The ethnic arena will thus become the newest battleground in the never-ending war between Information Resources, which is often known as I.R.I., and the market research unit of the A. C. Nielsen Company for the top of the $1.8 billion market-research hill. "If it becomes a successful operation, this could  put pressure on Nielsen," said James D. Dougherty, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WANG LABORATORIES INC., Billerica, Mass., acquired Dataserv, Minneapolis, a provider of computer installation and consulting services, from BellSouth Corp., for about $30 million in cash.

headline: Market Place;The bets are on Yeltsin, but in any case, a Russian stock rally.
abstract: TWO weeks before Russia's second presidential election, market analysts are betting that the incumbent, Boris N. Yeltsin, will emerge as the winner and complete the nation's transition to market capitalism, sending stock values soaring.         But even if the prize goes to his principal rival, Gennadi A. Zyuganov -- who calls himself a Communist, has criticized President Yeltsin's tough anti-inflation measures, and hinted that he may renationalize some companies --  many of these same analysts feel that in practice he will unable to do much more than temporarily slow the pace of economic change. And that, too, leaves their outlook for the market positive.

headline: Real Peace With Security': Parts of Netanyahu's Speech
abstract: Following are excerpts from a speech by Benjamin Netanyahu, Prime Minister-elect of Israel, to his supporters today, as translated from the Hebrew.          My friends, the state of Israel is going a new way: a way of hope, a way of  unity, a path of security, a path of peace. The first and most important peace that should be made is the peace within Israel, the peace between us.

headline: Bahrain Jails 11 in Protest
abstract: Bahrain has imprisoned 11 people for taking part in anti-government protests, newspapers said today.         Twenty-four people have died since the disturbances began in December 1994. Protesters, most of them Shiite Muslims, have been pressing the Sunni Muslim-led Government for political and economic reforms, including the restoration of parliament, which was disbanded in 1975.

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;Surfing When They Should Be Studying
abstract: FOR most of us, it has become impossible to remain impervious to the ballyhooed information superhighway. Look no farther than a car commercial nowadays to find the letters "http://www," the once arcane but now ubiquitous convention for locales on the World Wide Web.        But as someone involved professionally in the world of information, the hype  is sometimes far more insidious. Teaching college students considering careers in journalism, a field whose practitioners are themselves scurrying not to be left by the wayside, I have been feeling special pressure to conform to the world of multimedia, Web browsers and URL's.

headline: German Court Upholds Laws to Restrict Aliens
abstract: In a ruling condemned by opponents as a defeat for human rights, Germany's highest court today upheld strict regulations intended to restrict the number of foreigners gaining refuge in this country.         One of the regulations bars entry to asylum-seekers who travel through other  countries that are considered safe for refugees before arriving in Germany.

headline: Zimbabwe's Leader Scoffs at Critics of Iron Rule
abstract: Zimbabwe is at a crossroads.         It could go the way of South Africa -- an immensely popular president heading a multi-party democracy with room for dissent and a free press, overseeing an economy in which private enterprise is largely free to produce profits and jobs.

headline: Treasury Has Busy Auction Schedule This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week consists of auctions on the first four days of the week, starting today with the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday the Treasury will auction a 3-year note;  on Wednesday, a 10-year note, and on Thursday, a 36-day cash management bill.         At the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.99 percent, traders said, and the rate on the six-month issue was 5.12 percent. In when-issued trading the 3-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.33 percent and the 10-year note at 6.87 percent.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;REYNOLDS METALS CO. (RLM,N)
abstract: The Reynolds Metals Company said yesterday that its earnings fell sharply in  the first quarter, coming in lower than Wall Street's expectations, as a result  of lower aluminum prices, weaker demand, higher raw-material costs and some operating problems.         The company, a producer of aluminum and other metals that is based in Richmond, said its net income in the quarter totaled $2 million, equal to a loss of 12 cents a share after payment of preferred dividends. That compared with net income of $82 million, or $1.13 a share, in the corresponding period a year  earlier.

headline: First Data Shifts Western Union
abstract: The First Data Corporation plans to move the headquarters of Western Union, its money transfer and messaging unit, to Greenwood Village, Colo., from Paramus, N.J., where 150 jobs will be eliminated.         First Data said the move would create up to 300 new full-time professional, technical and managerial jobs between 1996 and 1998.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Germany Cuts Welfare; Lean Times for Europe? With Europeans voicing widespread anxiety about whether they can remain competitive in the global economy, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced long-heralded cuts in Germany's well-padded welfare state that are intended to reduce Bonn's budget deficit by $33 billion.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Engen of South Africa Selling Stake to Malaysia
abstract: The South African oil company Engen Ltd. announced yesterday that it would sell a 30 percent stake to Petronas, the state-owned oil company of Malaysia, for 1.88 billion rand ($436 million). Engen also plans to raise 605 million rand, or $140 million, through a rights offering to shareholders. It will use the fresh capital for debt repayment and future developments, it said.          Engen will tap Petronas's skills in refining and marketing. Petronas has pledged to assist Engen in expanding marketing in South Africa, sub-Saharan Africa and along the Indian Ocean rim.   (AP)

headline: U.N. Team to Quit Iraq After 5-Day Standoff
abstract: A United Nations official in Baghdad said today that the organization's weapons inspectors had withdrawn from military sites in and around the capital and that they would leave Iraq on Sunday.         The official, Goran Wallen, director of the Baghdad Monitoring and Verification Center, refused to comment on whether the withdrawal meant new action would be taken by the United Nations against Iraq.

headline: Guerrillas Kill 3 Israeli Soldiers
abstract: Guerrillas who evidently sneaked into the West Bank from Jordan ambushed an Israeli patrol today, killing three soldiers and wounding two others, the army said.         A radical Damascus-based group called the Palestinian National Liberation Organization claimed responsibility in a statement issued in Beirut, Lebanon. It said its action was intended to protest the "treacherous" peace agreements between Israel and the Palestinian Authority of Yasir Arafat. It said all but one of the attackers managed to flee.

headline: Communist Candidate Looks For Alliance Against Yeltsin
abstract: With less than two weeks remaining before Russia's presidential election, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the once aloof and defiant Communist Party candidate, set off on his final campaign swing today, apparently ready to compromise with anyone whose name is not Yeltsin.         As opinion polls show his popularity sinking fast, and that of President Boris N. Yeltsin continuing to rise, Mr. Zyuganov has begun reaching out to other presidential candidates with sharply differing world views -- men like the liberal economist Grigory A. Yavlinsky and the ultranationalist leader Vladimir  V. Zhirinovsky.

headline: Swiss Accord Is Reported Near on Holocaust Victims' Funds
abstract: Leaders of Jewish organizations and Swiss banking industry officials are expected to sign an agreement today to search for funds deposited in Switzerland during the frantic days of World War II by those who later died in the Holocaust, officials close to the negotiations said.         The agreement would be a key step toward resolving a continuing debate over whether Swiss banks have been forthright in disclosing the value of unclaimed assets deposited by Holocaust victims.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS PLANS $348 MILLION IN ACQUISITIONS
abstract: The U.S. Office Products Company said yesterday that it had reached agreements to acquire 53 companies for $324 million in stock and $24 million in  cash. U.S. Office Products said that under the agreements, its domestic contract stationer and office furniture divisions would buy 22 companies; those divisions have already completed five other acquisitions that had not been announced previously. U.S. Office Products, which is based in Washington, will also buy 4  businesses that provide commercial maintenance supplies, and its coffee service  division will buy 17 companies. Also, the company's school supply division will buy five companies. The total annual revenue of the businesses being bought is $775 million, U.S. Office Products said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BANKRUPTCY COURT APPROVES LIQUIDATION OF HERMAN'S
abstract: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc., the retailer based in Carteret, N.J., won court approval yesterday to hold liquidation sales in all its stores. Gordon Brothers, a liquidation company based in Boston, plans to handle the sales, which should begin sometime after tomorrow, a company spokesman said. Squeezed by competition in the sporting goods industry, Herman's, which operates 117 stores in the Northeast, filed for bankruptcy protection late last month to provide for "an orderly liquidation of assets."

headline: SPENDING IT;Calling Long Distance, on a PC and the Internet
abstract: JEFFREY LEVINE, a medical student in Guadalajara, Mexico, and Mike Dehn, a wildlife biologist in Whitehorse, Yukon Territory, can both make long-distance calls to the four corners of the world over the Internet, at little expense, using their computers instead of the telephone.         But because they use incompatible software to bypass the conventional long-distance phone companies, they cannot talk to each other. Such is the state of talking over the Internet, an evolving niche in telecommunications that is attracting a growing band of enthusiasts.

headline: Japan and South Korea Pledge Aid to North
abstract: Japan decided today to donate $6 million to North Korea in response to a United Nations appeal to help stave off severe food shortages caused by floods,  Government officials said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AFTER REJECTING BID, CHEYENNE ASSERTS IT IS NOT FOR SALE
abstract: Cheyenne Software Inc. emphasized yesterday that it was not for sale, after publicly rejecting a $1 billion takeover offer from McAfee Associates Inc. on Monday. Earlier, McAfee said it would rally shareholder support to press for the merger, which would create the world's fifth largest software company. Bill Larson, McAfee's president and chief executive, would not say whether McAfee would raise its $27.50 a share offer for Cheyenne, a maker of network management software that is based in Roslyn Heights, L.I. Shares of Cheyenne rose $1.375 yesterday, to $23, on the American Stock Exchange. McAfee, of Santa Clara, Calif., is the leading seller of anti-virus software.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Fuji Bank Chief Steps Down but Denies Reason Is Losses
abstract: The president of the Fuji Bank, one of the nation's largest financial institutions, announced his resignation today, but denied that his decision was  a result of huge loan losses at the company.         Still, the resignation was seen as a way of assuming responsibilty for the bad-debt problems, and it puts pressure on the heads of other Japanese banks to  step down as well.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PAYCHEX PLANS TO BUY NATIONAL BUSINESS SOLUTIONS
abstract: Paychex Inc. said yesterday that it would buy National Business Solutions Inc. for $142.5 million in stock, breaking into the business of administering employee benefits for small and medium-sized companies. Paychex, based in Rochester, plans to issue three million shares to acquire National Business Solutions, based in St. Petersburg, Fla. Closely held National Business administers human resources, employment regulator compliance, workers' compensation coverage, health care and 401(k) programs for 9,000 workers in various businesses. Paychex provides computerized payroll accounting services to more than 230,000 small-to-medium-sized businesses nationwide. Its stock closed  at $47.375, down 37.5 cents.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt

headline: COMPANY NEWS;B.U.M. INTERNATIONAL SEEKING CHAPTER 11 PROTECTION
abstract: B.U.M. International Inc. has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act and will liquidate its 41 retail outlet stores. The maker of casual clothing said it expected to post a loss of $9 million to $16 million  for 1995. The company also said it would report a first-quarter loss from operations of more than $1.7 million. The planned liquidation of the company's retail outlets is part of a restructuring program. B.U.M. said late Thursday that it planned to continue as a licensing and marketing company. The company filed Wednesday in a Los Angeles bankruptcy court.

headline: Court Overturns Damage Award In Downing of Korean Airliner
abstract: A Federal appeals court in Ohio today overturned a judgment that had awarded  about $15 million to the relatives of five people who were killed in the 1983 downing of a Korean Airlines jetliner, and experts said the decision might be applied to about two dozen cases still pending 13 years after the incident.         Lower courts had awarded the money to the relatives for pain and suffering of the victims, and loss of society and grief of the survivors. But the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, ruled that the law that should apply is the Death on the High Seas Act, which does not allow such non-economic damages. Korean Airlines was the defendant in the suits.

headline: Bond Offerings Tentatively Set for Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills.         According to traders, by the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.92 percent and the six-month bill was 5.05 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Peugeot Citroen Says Profits Fell 45%
abstract: The French car maker PSA Peugeot Citroen said yesterday that its profits slumped 45 percent last year as it fell victim to currency shifts, sluggish car  sales in Europe and stiff price competition. It said net income fell to 1.7 billion French francs ($332 million) for 1995 from 3.1 billion the previous year. The figure was slightly worse than forecast.          The company's chairman, Jacques Calvet, said it appeared slightly less likely now that the group would set up production in the United States. Mr. Calvet said last year that he was envisaging producing a special model for the United States market and building at least 60,000 cars annually in the United States.   Reuters

headline: F.C.C. Considers A New Auction
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is considering auctioning airwaves used by a small number of TV broadcasters, F.C.C. officials said today.         That portion of spectrum -- used by about 97 TV broadcasters -- could be auctioned by a new generation of mobile wireless communications devices capable of transmitting voice, data and video services. The F.C.C. is studying whether to auction the lightly used TV channels 60 to 69.

headline: U.S. and Japan Agree on Plan To Cut Back Okinawa Bases
abstract: The United States and Japan agreed today on a far-reaching plan that may sharply reduce the friction caused by the American bases in Okinawa. But the plan also raises new questions about the Japanese-American relationship in the years ahead.         The package of steps announced today, just a day before President Clinton arrives for a state visit, will lead to the return of an air base, two communications centers, a port and other major military properties to their owners on Okinawa, the southern Japanese island. The United States military, which now controls one-fifth of Okinawa, is scheduled to hand back 20 percent of its holdings in the coming years.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OWNER OF SPALDING AND EVENFLO CONSIDERS A SALE
abstract: The Spalding and Evenflo Companies said yesterday that its corporate parent,  the Cisneros Group of Venezuela, planned to "explore options" for selling all or part of the company. Spalding and Evenflo, which is based in Tampa, Fla., also said that it expected its branded sales to total $1 billion in 1996. Cisneros bought the Spalding sporting goods company and the Evenflo infant products business in 1984. Cisneros said it was considering a sale because it wanted to pursue opportunities in the telecommunications industry.

headline: Co-Author of Macintosh Program Quits Apple
abstract: The software engineer who was co-author of the program that gave Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh its distinctive look and feel, and who represented the current company's most direct link to its early innovative tradition, has left the company.         The engineer, Steven Capps, who was one of a core of technical employees with the mandate to chart Apple's technological future, said today that he had resigned on Monday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY MAKES OFFER TO BUY RIVAL
abstract: Vishay Intertechnology Inc. said yesterday that it was seeking to buy a rival electronic components maker, the Kemet Electronics Corporation, in a transaction that could exceed $1 billion. The companies did not disclose financial terms of  the proposal. Vishay, based in Malvern, Pa., said it was ready to buy all of Kemet's shares at a premium above Kemet's current market price. Shares of Kemet, which is based in Simonsonville, S.C., rose $2.125 yesterday, to $19, in Nasdaq trading, while Vishay rose 25 cents, to $21.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The companies compete in the $15-billion-a-year market for capacitors, components used in personal computers and electronic devices.

headline: Maser Journal;The Good Word: Creature Comforts for Catholics
abstract: For centuries, the people who built and decorated Roman Catholic churches paid little attention to comfort. A church was a place of worship and of beauty; it could be ornate or it could be austere, but the sore knees of the faithful were never taken into account.         In 1956, Paolo Lion, then finishing school in the Veneto region in northeastern Italy, came up with an idea so simple and obvious as to be downright revolutionary: the padded kneeler.

headline: EARNING IT;Paid by the Widget, and Proud
abstract: HOUR after hour, scarcely pausing between tasks, Mike Darrah sweeps up shards of broken glass from the repair-shop floor in Olympia, Wash., hoists heavy replacement windshields onto car frames and wrestles them into position, then painstakingly seals the rims. Mr. Darrah, a 24-year-old employee of Safelite Glass, a windshield manufacturing and repair company, cannot afford to stop, because he is working on the piece-rate system.         A grim reminder that sweatshop capitalism is alive, if not well, in America?  A Dickensian vision of where the work force, cowed by corporate downsizing, is heading?

headline: Upbeat Data On Economy Hurt Markets
abstract: Already in a jumpy mood, investors sent stock and bond prices tumbling yesterday after they were spooked by another report that showed the economy is stronger than was expected earlier this year.         The resulting selloff sent long-term interest rates over 7 percent for the first time in a year while the Dow Jones industrial average lost as much as 100 points before closing at 5,498.27, down 76.95 points.

headline: Sears, I.B.M. Near a Deal To Sell Prodigy
abstract: A management team led by the president of the Prodigy Services Company, Edward Bennett, has apparently arranged to buy the troubled on-line service from its co-owners, I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company.         A person familiar with the agreement said I.B.M. and Sears had agreed to accept as little as $100 million for Prodigy, in effect writing off more than $1 billion they had invested in the on-line venture during the last decade.

headline: African Immigrants Refusing to Leave France
abstract: Abdel Kader Wague-Dodo arrived at Charles de Gaulle Airport nine years ago from the Central African Republic with a tourist visa, hoping for work and a better life.         That was still a time when France welcomed, or at least tolerated, immigrants from its former African colonies.

headline: Drug Company Stocks Rise As 3 Post Higher Earnings
abstract: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the Warner-Lambert Company and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. posted higher first-quarter earnings yesterday, helping to touch  off a rally in drug stocks.         The results follow double-digit growth reported earlier this week by three rivals, Pfizer Inc., Merck & Company and Johnson & Johnson. The Standard & Poor's index of drug stocks rose 38.76 points, to 2266.12, leading the S.& P. 500 index higher.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WYNDHAM HOTEL STOCK RISES AS 2.9 MILLION SHARES TRADE
abstract: The shares of the Wyndham Hotel Corporation, an operator of upscale hotels based in Dallas, moved sharply higher yesterday after the company began trading. Late Monday 3.65 million shares of the company were sold for $16 each, up from the originally planned 3.35 million shares at $15 each. The stock ended yesterday at $22.625 on the New York Stock Exchange as 2.9 million shares were traded. The company plans to use proceeds of the offering to repay debt, acquire a hotel and provide working capital.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CIRCUIT CITY PLANS 8 TO 10 CARMAX DEALERSHIPS NEXT YEAR
abstract: Circuit City Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would open 8 to 10 Carmax used-car dealerships next year and that it planned to operate 80 to 90 of the so-called superstores by 2001, up from 5 now. The company, which also operates the Circuit City electronics stores, said it planned to open Carmax dealerships  next year in Miami, Houston and Dallas-Fort Worth. Shares of Circuit City rose 87.5 cents, to $36.25.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BIRMINGHAM STEEL TO RECORD CHARGES IN 3D QUARTER
abstract: The Birmingham Steel Corporation will record charges in the range of $18 million to $21 million for the third quarter, which ended Sunday. In the corresponding quarter a year earlier, the company earned $13.3 million, or 45 cents a share, on revenue of $236.9 million. In a statement, the company said the charges included a write-down of older property, plant and equipment; reworking of a contract with Electronic Data Systems; accumulated start-up costs for the new bar mill in Cuyahoga and the new melt shop in Memphis.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;2-FOR-1 STOCK SPLIT SET AS WELL AS HIGHER DIVIDEND
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company announced a 2-for-1 stock split yesterday as well as a 20 percent increase in its quarterly dividend. The announcement comes just  one day after Hewlett reported that its second-quarter earnings rose a less-than-expected 25 percent on disappointing sales of work stations and disk drives, sending its stock down 7 percent. Shares of the No. 2 computer maker behind I.B.M. rose after yesterday's announcement, climbing $4.125, to $109.375. Hewlett-Packard raised its quarterly dividend to 24 cents from 20 cents a share. The dividend will be paid on July 10 to shareholders of record on June 19.

headline: Dana and U.S. In Settlement
abstract: The Dana Corporation said Friday that it had agreed to pay $10.2 million to settle remaining Federal charges that a former subsidiary overcharged the Pentagon for jet-engine parts.         The auto parts maker agreed to the payment in an out-of-court settlement that resolves a Federal lawsuit filed in November 1992.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Ratings for Newcomers
abstract: Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago, is finding itself in the unusual position of supplying information but warning investors not to rely on it.         At issue is an expansion of the star ratings that Morningstar gives to mutual funds. The ratings, from a low of one to a high of five stars, are based on a combination of historical performance and risk measures. To earn a star rating,  a fund has had to have at least three years of data. The Morningstar analysts figured they needed at least that long to take a fund's pulse.

headline: Buenos Aires Journal;Loony Radio's Not So Crazy. It's Great Therapy.
abstract: Every Saturday at 2 P.M., the activities of the Borda Psychiatric Hospital here come to a halt as fidgety patients gather around portable radios, eagerly awaiting their favorite radio program.         "Good afternoon, you crazy people, Loony Radio is on the air!" the announcer  yells, to the excitement and applause of patients. "Today, we will hear reflections from Garces, the Emperor of Paranoia, and next we'll have a report from our correspondent on Mars!"

headline: Economic Scene;If the U.S. doesn't follow trade rules, why should others?
abstract: IF at first you don't succeed, try, try again. Cray Research, the Minneapolis-based maker of supercomputers, seems to have taken that homily to heart. After failing to convince the National Science Foundation that it could build a better machine to simulate global warming than the NEC Corporation of Japan, Cray is attempting to nullify the foundation's decision through the back  door. Friends of Cray in Congress have slipped a provision into the foundation's proposed budget that would effectively bar completion of the deal with the Japanese.         More is at stake here than the $35 million contract announced last month. "Since the late 1970's, America has been pressuring Japan to play fair on government procurement," said Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan. By changing the rules when it suits American interests, Washington is  risking hard-won progress in opening up the Japanese market.

headline: Stewart Funeral Homes
abstract: Stewart Enterprises Inc. said today that it would buy six funeral homes and a cemetery. Terms of the purchases were not disclosed. Stewart's new cemetery is in Virginia, and the funeral homes are in California, Virginia, Oregon, Puerto Rico and Australia.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES RISE AFTER PROPOSED DEAL
abstract: The shares of Republic Industries rose 13 percent yesterday after the company, controlled by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, offered to buy Auto Nation USA, a national used-car company, in a $250 million stock swap. Republic  shares jumped $4.125, to $35.50, in Nasdaq trading of three million shares. Republic, a provider of waste collection and electronic security services that it based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., made the offer on Friday. Since Mr. Huizenga resigned in November as vice chairman of Viacom Inc. and chairman of its Blockbuster Entertainment Group, he has bought large stakes in Republic and  Auto Nation.

headline: F.D.A. Approves Gilead's Drug for AIDS Patients
abstract: Gilead Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company, said today that it had won final approval from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing a drug for the treatment of an infection that causes blindness in AIDS patients.         Cidofovir, which Gilead plans to sell under the brand name Vistide, received  approval for the treatment of cytomegalovirus retinitis, a viral infection of the retina that threatens the sight of between 15 and 40 percent of AIDS patients. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., said it had immediately begun shipments of Vistide, its first drug to receive regulatory approval.

headline: Bosnian Serbs Are Threatened in Sarajevo
abstract: Undermining the vision of a multi-ethnic Sarajevo espoused by the Bosnian Government, some of the remaining Bosnian Serbs in Sarajevo's suburbs are being  threatened, beaten or expelled from their homes by groups of Muslims the police  say they cannot control.         Though diplomats and human rights workers are divided over whether the effort reflects official policy, there is unanimity on the effect: Moderate Bosnian Serbs hoping for reconciliation with Muslims are being intimidated and urged to  leave.

headline: Bell Atlantic And Nynex Are Said to Be Close to a Deal
abstract: Bell Atlantic and Nynex may consummate their long and highly publicized courtship as early as this weekend, according to executives familiar with the negotiations. But the protracted and public nature of the talks could make a merger more difficult for both Bell companies to sell to investors, regulators and their own employees -- all of whom have had months to find fault with the potential alliance.         A person familiar with the discussions said that the companies had tentatively scheduled board meetings on Saturday to vote on a merger proposal. And in anticipation of a deal, Nynex and Bell Atlantic have retained Abernathy MacGregor Scanlon, a New York public relations firm that specializes in mergers  and acquisitions, to advise them on how to promote the merger as favorable to all concerned.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRITON ENERGY TO SELL CRUSADER TO CLYDE PETROLEUM
abstract: The Triton Energy Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Crusader  Ltd. affiliate to Clyde Petroleum P.L.C. for about $69 million, after Clyde increased its offer for Crusader, an Australian oil and gas company. Triton, an  oil and gas exploration concern based in Dallas with a 49.9 percent stake in Crusader, said it expected a second-quarter gain of about $1.7 million and a third-quarter gain of about $8.6 million, after taxes, on the sale of 53.2 million Crusader shares. Clyde, a British exploration and production company, increased its offer to buy Crusader shares to $1.32 a share from $1.28, Triton said. Clyde has already bought 10 percent of Crusader's shares outstanding.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Psion of Britain In Talks to Buy Amstrad
abstract: The British information technology company Psion P.L.C. and the consumer electronics company Amstrad P.L.C. said yesterday that they were in talks that could result in the acquisition of Amstrad by Psion. They said any offer from Psion, best known for its computerized personal organizer, would be at a price of not less than 200 pence an Amstrad share, payable in Psion shares.          The final price could be increased if Amstrad succeeded in court actions against two hard-disk drive manufacturers it says supplied it with faulty products. One action seeks damages of L200 million. Amstrad's shares closed Monday at 148 pence, giving it a market capitalization of L173 million ($265 million). The shares closed yesterday at 185.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: THERMO ELECTRON CORP., Waltham, Mass., a maker of health and environmental monitoring products, plans to acquire Sensormedics Corp., a privately held medical equipment manufacturer based in Yorba Linda, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MCLOUTH STEEL TO BE BOUGHT BY HAMLIN HOLDINGS
abstract: The McLouth Steel Products Corporation, a struggling steelmaker in bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it had agreed to be purchased by Hamlin Holdings. Terms were not disclosed. Hamlin is an affiliate of Reserve Group of Akron, Ohio, which invests in industrial companies. Hamlin plans to reopen McLouth's operations later this year and plans to modernize the steelmaker's operations. McLouth, which has annual revenue of about $400 million, is currently not making any steel. McLouth, which is employee owned, filed for bankruptcy protection last September after falling steel prices drove costs higher.

headline: U.N. Says North Korea Will Face Famine as Early as This Summer
abstract: Hunger in North Korea is growing more intense as the country's economy continues to deteriorate, so that malnutrition could become widespread in the coming months, some experts say.         In the latest sign of the country's crisis, the World Food Program and the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations warned today that "the food supply is becoming increasingly desperate" in North Korea, and that without emergency food imports, "the consequences are likely to be devastating for large segments of the population."

headline: Keeping Peace Alive And Tensions Dormant;Diverse Far Rockaway Sees Room For Harmony as Jewish Enclave Grows
abstract: It was September 1991, the summer of the violence in Crown Heights. Tensions  between blacks and Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn erupted after a Hasidic driver struck and killed a 7-year-old black child. In retaliation, black youths attacked and killed a Hasidic Jew.         Three weeks later, in Far Rockaway, Queens, another incident sounded disturbing echoes.

headline: Ex-I.B.M. Official Charged in Fraud
abstract: The former president of IBM Argentina was charged today with fraud in connection with a contract to modernize the state-owned Banco Nacion's computer  system.         The executive, Ricardo Martorana, and Banco Nacion's former president, Aldo Dadone, were charged by an Argentine court that had investigated accusations that the International Business Machines Corporation had paid kickbacks to a Government-connected contractor to land the $249 million deal.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;AT&T in a Shift From N. W. Ayer
abstract: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it had moved the creative portion of its 1-800-CALL-ATT account to another roster agency, the BBDO New York unit of the Omnicom Group, from N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York. Billings were estimated at $40 million.          Karyn Vaughn-Fritz, a spokeswoman for AT&T in Basking Ridge, N.J., confirmed reports of the move this week in Advertising Age and Adweek. AT&T has not decided the fate of its remaining accounts at Ayer, she added, which include a corporate branding assignment. AT&T is leaving Ayer because of a conflict with the SBC Communications account at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which agreed to acquire Ayer and parent Adcom Investors Inc.

headline: Pepsico to Run Troubled Argentine Bottler
abstract: Pepsico Inc. said today that it would assume management control of the troubled Argentine soft-drink bottler Buenos Aires Embotelladora S.A., after the company suffered big losses in Brazil.         Charles Beach plans to step down as chief executive of the concern on July 1, and Pepsico plans to assume control, the companies said in a joint statement. Pepsico does not plan to immediately increase its 24 percent stake in the company.

headline: Chief of U.P.S. Will Retire
abstract: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said today that Kent C. Nelson, the chairman and chief executive, would retire at the end of the year.         James Kelly, the executive vice president and chief operating officer, will be nominated as chairman at the November meeting of the company's board, U.P.S. said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SCOTTS TO TAKE CHARGE ON FAILED PROMOTION PLAN
abstract: The Scotts Company said yesterday that it would take a charge of up to $8 million in the next three quarters to help it recover from a failed promotional  plan. The company, which makes lawn- and turf-care products, said excess inventories caused by the plan would hurt sales of high-margin products by up to $60 million in the same period. The failed promotion, which was aimed at retailers instead of consumers, has already led to a first-quarter charge of $2.1 million, the restatement of results for the 1995 fiscal year and the resignation of Theodore Host as chief executive. Scotts shares were down 62.5 cents, at $17.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Tishman in Brazil Venture
abstract: Tishman Speyer Properties L.P. said this week that it would enter a joint venture to construct a $175 million, 36-story office building in Sao Paulo, Brazil. The company, based in New York, signed an agreement with Metodo Engenharia S.A., a Sao Paulo construction company. The building would be the tallest in Brazil, Tishman Speyer said. The project will be financed by Funcef,  a Brazilian pension fund. Construction is to begin late this year. "Our goal is  to leverage our presence in Sao Paulo to build our real estate business, not only in Brazil, but in select markets throughout Latin America," said Jerry I. Speyer, Tishman Speyer's president and chief executive.

headline: Sinclair Buys Radio and TV Stations for $1.2 Billion
abstract: The Sinclair Broadcast Group of Baltimore announced today that it would pay $1.2 billion to acquire River City Broadcasting, a closely held television and radio broadcasting company based in St. Louis.         With the deal, Sinclair, which currently owns six television stations, would  become the nation's seventh-largest television holding company based on the number of stations and households reached, according to Broadcasting and Cable magazine, a trade publication.

headline: U.S. Expels Sudan Envoy Suspected In Bomb Plot
abstract: The United States announced today the expulsion of a Sudanese diplomat whom it accused of supplying inside information to Islamic terrorists who were convicted last year of plotting the destruction of the United Nations and other  New York landmarks after the bombing of the World Trade Center.         The Sudanese Mission was told on Tuesday that its second secretary, Ahmed Yousif Mohamed, had been involved in terrorist and espionage activities and must leave the country within two days, said James P. Rubin, a spokesman for the United States Mission.

headline: Hospital Blast In Pakistan; Political Feud Is Heating Up
abstract: A bomb exploded in Pakistan's only cancer hospital today, killing at least 6  people, wounding more than 30 and adding a grim twist to a personal and political feud that many Pakistanis say could have a profound impact on the country's future.         The bomb detonated in the city of Lahore at the Shaukat Khanum Memorial Cancer Center, opened 16 months ago and dedicated to the memory of the mother of Pakistan's former cricket captain, Imran Khan. Mr. Khan, 43, has said in recent  days that he is on the verge of starting a political movement to topple Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was a fellow student with Mr. Khan at Oxford University 20 years ago.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Tatham, Revamping Alters Name a Bit
abstract: Tatham Euro RSCG in Chicago, which is owned by Havas Advertising, said yesterday it had revamped its top management and changed its name to Euro RSCG Tatham.

headline: Sprint, GTE and Ameritech Show Phone Profit Is Strong
abstract: Three of the nation's biggest phone companies reported strong gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday, as customers demanded more lines to hook up to the Internet, fax machines and home offices.         The Sprint Corporation led the group with a 37.8 percent increase in earnings, its best quarter in a decade. The Ameritech Corporation's earnings rose 14.2 percent, not including a special gain in last year's performance, and the GTE Corporation reported a 13.4 percent increase.

headline: For Journalism Graduates, Opportunities in New Media
abstract: When Addie Butt enrolled in the journalism school at the University of Missouri here two years ago, her goal was to become a newspaper sportswriter. But one of the school's newest courses -- new media, an intensive study of on-line publications -- changed her plans.         Within days of graduation, Ms. Butt will report for a $500-a-week job at Fastball, an on-line publication about major league baseball owned by Cox Communications in Atlanta, a unit of Cox Enterprises.

headline: Pickens Plans To Step Down As Mesa Chief
abstract: It is not the end that T. Boone Pickens wanted. But in the unforgiving investment world he helped create as a master of the takeover era, it may be fitting.         At the request of Richard Rainwater, the Fort Worth financier whom Mr. Pickens brought in to defend his Mesa Inc. from hostile shareholders, Mr. Pickens announced today that he would step down as chairman and chief executive.

headline: As the Cereal War Heats Up, Kellogg Reduces Prices
abstract: The Kellogg Company wheeled out the heavy artillery in the cereal war yesterday, announcing price cuts averaging 19 percent on Frosted Flakes, Raisin  Bran and 14 other cereals, representing two-thirds of its domestic cereal sales.         Kellogg's move came after scanner data from supermarket checkout lines warned the company that its industry-leading market share was eroding rapidly in the face of the across-the-board 20 percent price cuts announced earlier this spring by Post and Nabisco cereals, the subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies that ranks third in the industry after Kellogg and General Mills Inc.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Feud Ended by Accord
abstract: The feuding partners of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., one of the nation's leading institutional brokers of Government securities, have reached a peaceful settlement of a bitter succession battle that erupted at the firm early this year.         The pact calls for the dismissal of litigation that pitted a partnership controlled by B. Gerald Cantor, the 79-year-old founder of Cantor Fitzgerald, and his wife, Iris, against the firm itself and its young president, Howard Lutnick, whom Mr. Cantor had groomed for years as his successor.

headline: INVESTING IT;A Sign of Bad Brokers: Tap Dancing at the Roach Motel
abstract: PICTURE the look on your face if you saw a crowd of big bugs crawling around  on your kitchen floor. That expression -- plus eyeball-rolling exasperation -- crosses the faces of regulators at the very mention of some securities firms: First Jersey; Blinder Robinson; Investors Center; Hibbard Brown; F. N. Wolf; Stratton Oakmont.         All these outfits flogged penny stocks; all had rap sheets as long as your leg; all left customers with huge losses; all but Stratton are out of business,  and a committee of the National Association of Securities Dealers took steps last month to try to deal with that. The association is also going to push for jail terms for rogue brokers, and is likely to adopt new rules later this month  to crack down on cold calls, those unsolicited phone calls from unknown brokers.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Israel Counterattacks Guerrillas in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli helicopters fired rockets today at two Lebanese Army checkpoints in this port city after Israeli jets launched two raids in eastern and southern Lebanon, security sources said.         The officials said the helicopters fired rockets at army checkpoints at the entrance of the city, 48 miles south of Beirut. There was no immediate word on casualties.

headline: Chain Agrees to Revamp Movie Theaters
abstract: United Artists Theatre Circuit Inc. agreed today to make its cinemas more accessible to the handicapped, ending a Federal investigation into accusations that moviegoers with disabilities could not go into some theaters or were segregated to the back rows, the Justice Department said.         The company, a unit of the Oscar I Corporation and one of the country's largest cinema chains, agreed to modify or renovate all of its more than 420 theaters before 2001. The agreement settles a Federal complaint under the Americans with Disabilities Act and a private lawsuit in California.

headline: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equities and Debt Issues
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         American Water Works Co., Voorhees, N.J., 4.2 million shares. Smith Barney.

headline: World News Briefs;Local Court Drops Case Against Polish Ex-Leader
abstract: A provincial court in Gdansk, saying it lacked jurisdiction, dropped proceedings today against Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski over the shooting deaths of 44 protesters by security forces in 1970, when General Jaruzelski was Defense Minister.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REGIONS FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE ALLIED BANKSHARES
abstract: The Regions Financial Corporation, a banking company based in Birmingham, Ala., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Allied Bankshares Inc. in a $136.3 million stock swap. Regions will offer 0.226 share of its common stock for each Allied share, or a total of about 2.9 million shares, in a tax-free pooling of interests. The acquisition, including four others that are pending, would raise Regions' total assets to about $18.8 billion, with $4.6 billion in Georgia. Regions operates 355 banking offices and has assets of $562 million.

headline: About Real Estate;High-Technology Theater for Tourists
abstract: The Plaza Theater on 58th Street just east of Madison Avenue, originally a stable for Cornelius Vanderbilt 2d, is entering the high-technology age.         The 500-seat theater, at 42-44 East 58th Street, has been leased and is being renovated for the opening in mid-October of "Show Me New York," a high-definition television travelogue, created especially for tourists, of life in New York City. The 20-year lease was valued at about $15 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NORTHROP GRUMMAN SELLS SHARES TO REDUCE DEBT
abstract: The Northrop Grumman Corporation said it had sold seven million common shares at $63.25 each, raising $422.75 million. The military contractor, based in Los Angeles, said the proceeds would be used to reduce debt incurred from its $3 billion acquisition of the military and electronics business of Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which it completed March 1. The shares were offered simultaneously to United States and foreign investors. The company said it had set aside another 1.05 million shares for unexpected demand. Northrop shares rose $2.50 yesterday, to $65.75 in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Canada Eases Rules On Broadcast Stakes
abstract: Canada has raised the maximum allowable share a foreigner can hold in a broadcast company.         Under regulations put into effect on Thursday, foreigners can now hold voting shares worth as much as 33 percent of a broadcaster or cable company, up from 20 percent previously.

headline: World News Briefs;Mexico Court Rules Debt Can Be Paid by Paintings
abstract: They may not be pretty, these 19 canvasses spattered with contemptuous descriptions of a wealthy Mexican art dealer. But they are art nonetheless and the dealer must accept them in payment of a debt.         With that ruling, a judge here appears to have finally closed the book on a Kafkaesque 10-year-old legal battle between Serapion Fernandez, the dealer and the artist he once represented, Roger Von Gunten.

headline: Bosnian Men Tell Tale of Survival Deep in Serb Territory
abstract: Five Muslim men and a teen-age boy have arrived in Bosnian Government territory with an amazing story. They say they managed to escape the suspected killings of hundreds of the men in a town that fell to the Serbs nine months ago and that they have just emerged from hiding in the mountains and forests deep within Bosnian Serb territory.         "We just helped each other and we stayed alive," said Adnan Spahic, 20.

headline: Insurance by Phone Is Offered in Britain
abstract: Richard Branson's Virgin Group said today that it would take on British insurers with new low-cost life and health insurance products sold directly by telephone.         For years, the life insurance industry in Britain has been a bastion of commission-seeking middlemen, and the big insurers have only recently started experimenting with direct sales. A highly successful effort by the insurance arm of the Royal Bank of Scotland, Direct Line, sells insurance over the phone, but  has not yet had the impact in life insurance as it has in the auto insurance market.

headline: Technology Issues Fall, With Dow Off 24.75
abstract: Technology shares fell sharply yesterday, leading a nervous market lower, as  investors grew concerned about difficult market conditions for high-technology companies.         The Dow Jones industrial average fell 24.75, to 5,628.03. The blue-chip barometer held a slight gain until midafternoon, then trailed lower along with bonds as a weak report on new housing construction failed to calm worries about inflation and interest rates.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Are Off Sharply As Weather Enables Planting
abstract: Corn prices dropped sharply yesterday as dry weather enabled farmers to continue sowing crops in regions where rain had delayed planting.         On other markets, the price of coffee fell while crude oil prices rose.

headline: Real Estate;The New York Times Company sells a building on Fifth Avenue to real estate investors.
abstract: A CENTURY-OLD, 11-story, 170,000-square-foot office building at 110 Fifth Avenue, at 16th Street, has been sold by The New York Times Company to companies owned by Arnold Goldstein and Mickey Rabina, real estate investors with holdings that include buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues in Manhattan.         The purchase price was not disclosed, but people familiar with the real estate market estimate it at more than $100 a square foot.

headline: 7 French Monks Reported Killed By Islamic Militants in Algeria
abstract: The Armed Islamic Group in Algeria said today that it had killed seven French monks who were kidnapped two months ago from a monastery south of Algiers.         A French Foreign Ministry official said the claim appeared to be credible, and the Government once again urged the few remaining French citizens in Algeria to leave for their own safety.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coke Upgrades Nestea Campaign
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company will try expanding the cola wars to another front with  a marketing blitz for Cool from Nestea, a fast-growing brand of ready-to-drink iced tea aimed at younger consumers.         For the first time, Cool from Nestea "will be a core brand for our bottlers"  along with Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke and Sprite, said Tom Reddin, consumer marketing director for noncarbonated beverages at Coca-Cola USA in Atlanta. Efforts that begin today include a product reformulation, new packaging, availability at fountains and a hip advertising campaign by Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis, which was awarded the brand's account in March.

headline: London Journal;Fickle Dame Fortune: She Smiles, Then Frowns
abstract: Less than 24 hours ago, Karl Crompton, 23, was called "one of Britain's luckiest people," "the country's most eligible bachelor" and "every girl's dream" as he stepped into the limelight to collect $17 million and change -- one of the largest lottery awards ever in this country.         His face graced the front pages of this morning's newspapers and his family's joy was amply broadcast on television all day Tuesday. His 50-year-old mother, Pat, vowed to protect her son from female fortune hunters.

headline: G.E. Nuclear Plant Deal
abstract: The General Electric Company said today that its GE Nuclear Energy unit had received a $1.8 billion contract for a nuclear power plant from the Taiwan Power Company. GE Nuclear will supply the design, equipment and nuclear fuel for the project, at Yenliao, Taiwan, which is the fourth nuclear power plant in that country.

headline: Restlessness Among the Nation's Booksellers
abstract: The nation's instant summer community of literati is thriving with a healthy  population of almost 40,000 conventioneers, but the growth has come with much grumbling from its longtime residents -- traditional publishers who have seen their once insular group transformed to reflect the sweeping changes in the industry.         The giant annual trade show of the American Booksellers Association, which will have its 50th anniversary next year, was crowded like a bookshelf this weekend with visitors and exhibitors hawking shiny, would-be best sellers. But those who make their living in the word trade complain that there are far fewer  people sporting the desirable blue badges of bookstore owners, the base of the industry's traditional customers. Year by year, their ranks have dwindled as competition has intensified between independents and superstores that serve espresso with steep book discounts.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Agencies use zippy Dr. Seuss-style rhymes and comics to sell Ford Escorts and Mercury Tracers.
abstract: THE agencies helping to introduce two redesigned small cars for the Ford Motor Company are borrowing techniques from children's books and comic strips to convince buyers the cars are more than mere "econoboxes."         The cars, the Ford Escort and Mercury Tracer, which officially go on sale today as 1997 models, are intended to compete with the Dodge Neon, Honda Civic and Saturn sedans. The Escort ads, by the J. Walter Thompson Detroit unit of the WPP Group, use Dr. Seuss-style rhymes to play up the features found in the revamped car.

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: Tuesday

headline: Is the U.S. Souring on Free Trade?
abstract: Ian W. Delaney, chairman of the Sherritt International Corporation, a Canadian metals company with mining interests in Cuba, has just been warned by the State Department that he, his wife and his children may never be allowed to  enter the United States again.         At the same time, Congress is rattling sabers in Europe's direction, vowing -- with President Clinton's support -- that Total S.A., the big French oil concern, and other European companies that supply Iran's oil industry may not be able to get American bank loans or export their goods to the United States.

headline: Armed North Korea Troops Again Violate the DMZ
abstract: Heavily armed North Korean troops entered the sensitive buffer zone between North and South Korea tonight for the third day in a row, violating the armistice that ended the Korean War, United States and South Korean officials said.         The actions by the North Koreans have heightened tensions on the heavily fortified border, where the cold war has never thawed. But some American and South Korean officials have said the North, by thumbing its nose at the armistice agreement, appears to be making more of a diplomatic gambit than actually preparing for war.

headline: Tupperware Spinoff Is Set for May 31
abstract: Premark International Inc. said last week that the spinoff of its Tupperware  business would be completed on May 31 with the issuance of common stock to holders of record on May 24.

headline: Mutual Funds Are Cutting Cash Reserves
abstract: As rapidly as cash has flooded into mutual funds that invest in American stocks this year, the fund managers have put the money to work even faster, cutting their cash reserves in an attempt to keep up with a red-hot stock market.         According to data released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, cash reserves in domestic equity funds fell in March to 6.71 percent of total assets, the lowest level since September, when the indicator dipped to 6.68 percent, the lowest in 17 years.

headline: THE ISRAELI VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;NETANYAHU, SET TO LEAD ISRAEL, TO SEEK 'PEACE WITH SECURITY'
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu, the conservative opposition leader who campaigned on charges that Israel's Labor Government neglected the country's security in its search for peace with the Palestinians, stood on the brink of victory today, waiting only for the military vote to be counted before he could formally lay claim to the Prime Minister's job, now held by Shimon Peres.         With all the regular ballots counted, Mr. Netanyahu led by a scant 21,399 votes of the 2,811,161 cast, an edge of 0.7 percent. But 150,000 absentee ballots remained to be counted, most of them from military bases, and past experience indicated that a majority were likely to fall to Mr. Netanyahu. The final tally of the first direct election of an Israeli Prime Minister is expected Friday afternoon.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Auditors of Gemina Balk on 1995 Results
abstract: Auditors said yesterday that they had refused to approve the 1995 operating results of Gemina S.p.A., an Italian holding company, citing a lack of information on Gemina's defunct capital markets group. Gemina's auditors declined to sign off on the accounts until management provided information from  its subsidiaries and computed the value of Gemina Capital Markets.          The auditing fiasco is the latest setback for Gemina, a publishing, paper and textiles company. Gemina has lost 893.2 billion lire ($576 million) in two years. Gemina shares skidded 36 lire, to 631, yesterday on the Italian Stock Exchange.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Profits Double At Chrysler As Sales Rise
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation's earnings doubled in the first quarter, surprising  Wall Street.         The results, reported today, were so strong that Chrysler increased its sales forecast for the industry as a whole by 200,000 vehicles annually.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Sights British Utility
abstract: Deutsche Telekom A.G., the German telecommunications giant, is considering a  takeover of Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain and has made unofficial inquiries, a Deutsche Telekom official said today.         The executive, Joachim Kroeske, said here that his company considered Britain a key market in its plans to broaden its presence in Europe. "In our considerations we do not rule this out," Mr. Kroeske said. "We are involved in sensitive pre-exploratory talks. But there have been no official discussions."

headline: Andreas Papandreou, Greek Leftist Who Admired and Annoyed U.S., Diesat 77
abstract: Andreas Papandreou, the former Prime Minister of Greece and a maverick who towered over Greek political life for more than two decades, died yesterday in Athens. He was 77.         His symptoms "were compatible with a heart attack, which finally caused his death at 2:30 A.M.," his doctors said in a statement.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;At home on the frontier, Marlboro will cross one, as the first cigarette in the  Marketing Hall of Fame.
abstract: MARLBORO, the cigarette that Philip Morris and the Leo Burnett Company transformed from an also-ran brand into the world's best-selling smoke -- and perhaps most valuable trademark -- is becoming the first tobacco product to be named to the Marketing Hall of Fame.         The honor, which is sure to stir debate as attacks against cigarette marketing strategies are intensifying, comes amid ambitious initiatives on two other Philip Morris fronts. For Virginia Slims, Burnett is replacing "You've come a long way, baby" -- the theme used since that brand was introduced in 1968 -- with "It's a woman thing." And Philip Morris is testing a retro-chic brand named Player's Navy Cut, which in print advertisements by Burnett features a stalwart sailor wearing a cap labeled "Hero" who evokes the rugged cowboys urging smokers to "Come to Marlboro Country."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ADCO TECHNOLOGIES CONSIDERING A SALE OR MERGER
abstract: Adco Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Schroder Wertheim & Company to help the company consider its options, including a merger or a sale.  Adco, a maker of sealants, adhesives and other specialty chemicals used in roofing, windows and automobiles, did not provide additional details. Adco, which is based in Michigan Center, Mich., sold two million shares at $7 in an initial public offering in February 1995. The stock closed yesterday at $7.125, down 87.5 cents, on Nasdaq.

headline: India's Have-Nots Swamp the Party System
abstract: This tiny settlement astride a railway line in Bihar state is typical of India's 850,000 villages, except that it is quite a bit poorer than most. Life here has not changed much since Mohandas K. Gandhi walked India's hinterland, proclaiming the most downtrodden of the poor, the so-called untouchables, to be  "the children of God."         As the 590 million voters in the world's largest democracy prepare for a general election that begins on Saturday, the promise Gandhi held out to the poor when he led India's freedom struggle, of a future free from deprivation, seems like a distant dream here now. In Risodh, there is no irrigation, no clinic, no primary school, no paved road, and in years when food is especially scarce villagers still sweep the nearby highway for scatterings of grain from passing trucks.

headline: Gates Acquires Rights To Adams Photo Images
abstract: William H. Gates, the computer software billionaire, has added to his storehouse of images by acquiring the electronic rights to the works of Ansel Adams, the nature photographer and environmentalist.         The licensing deal, which will be announced today, gives Mr. Gates the electronic rights to images of stark mountainous vistas that are icons of the American wilderness. Roughly nine million books, posters and calendars based on Adams photographs have been sold.

headline: Announcement Is Set on Mitsubishi Case
abstract: Mitsubishi Motor Manufacturing of America, the Japanese car maker that the Government has accused of allowing widespread sexual harassment at a plant in Normal, Ill., said today that it would make "a major announcement" about the case on Tuesday in Chicago.         Cynthia G. Pierre, a spokeswoman for the Chicago office of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which is investigating the Mitsubishi case, said late today, "We have not reached a settlement with them."

headline: Technology: CONNECTIONS;Beyond 'The Selfish Gene,' where ideas alter the ways in which we think.
abstract: DEAR reader,         This column may infect you.

headline: San Francisco Radio Deal
abstract: The Evergreen Media Corporation has agreed to buy the San Francisco radio station KYLD-FM from Crescent Communications L.P. for $44 million. Evergreen, which currently owns 34 radio stations, including 2 others in San Francisco, is  operating the station under a special agreement that will remain in effect until the Federal Communications Commission rules on the transaction. Evergreen already owns K-101 and KMEL in San Francisco.

headline: After a String of Dictators, Ugandans Get to Vote Again
abstract: For the first time in 16 years, Ugandans stood in line this morning to vote for a new president, ending a bitter race that became a referendum not only on President Yoweri Museveni's tenure, but also on his vision of a democracy without political parties.         Turnout was heavy as nearly eight million registered voters walked to crude polling stations and waited in line for hours, sometimes in the rain, just for the chance to mark a paper ballot with an indelible pen and push it into a metal lock-box.

headline: Economic Scene;Thinking the unthinkable: Raise the Federal minimum wage.
abstract: THE ritual pre-election debate over the Federal minimum wage has begun, with  Democrats reminding blue-collar workers where their bread is buttered and Republicans countering with tears over the tragedy of pricing inner-city youths  out of the job market.         The Republicans can count on support from mainstream economists, who are trained from birth to disapprove of the use of any form of price regulation -- rent control, farm supports, protective tariffs, whatever -- to redistribute income. But this time around, those who pay attention to nuance will notice a waning sense of conviction.

headline: Selling of Yeltsin Hits Obstacles in Heartland
abstract: The re-election of Boris N. Yeltsin promises to be a hard sell in this downtrodden factory town 200 miles northeast of Moscow.          The two textile plants in Lezhnevo are idle. The recent voting trend here in the Ivanovo region is strongly anti-Yeltsin. Workers and retirees, dispirited and cynical, are more preoccupied with getting by than with politics.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nycomed of Norway Sees '96 Profit Drop
abstract: Shares in Nycomed, a Norwegian pharmaceutical company, dropped more than 20 percent yesterday after the company warned that its profit might fall more than  30 percent in 1996. This year's earnings per share "will be closer" to 1994's 7.55 kroner ($1.16) than 1995's 11.20 kroner, Nycomed said. That is as much as 43 percent below analysts' average expectations of a 13.27 kroner profit, according to a survey by IBES International.          The company attributed the expected drop in profit to a 15 percent decline in prices in the United States for X-ray contrast agents, Nycomed's largest business, in April and May. Nycomed stock fell to a 52-week low, with the class  A shares dropping to 95 kroner from 124.

headline: Stocks Higher in Japan
abstract: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 133.14 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,014.07. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 91.24 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Post Steep Decline As Dry Weather Aids Planting
abstract: Corn prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as dry weather in the Midwest over the weekend allowed farmers to resume planting crops.         Farm work had been delayed from eastern Iowa to Ohio as several weeks of stormy weather left fields too muddy to support heavy machinery.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COGNEX SHARES FALL AS INCOME ESTIMATES ARE CUT
abstract: The shares of the Cognex Corporation fell 16 percent yesterday after analysts reduced their earnings estimates for 1996 and 1997 because of order delays for its semiconductors. The company told analysts on Thursday that it was experiencing order delays in its semiconductor business, a Cognex spokeswoman said. The company's products are used to automate manufacturing operations where vision is required. Shares of Cognex, based in Natick, Mass., fell $4 a share, to $18.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 5.7 million shares.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Valujet Forced to Halt Its Operations Indefinitely The Federal Aviation Administration shut down Valujet indefinitely, saying that  an evaluation begun after the airline's May 11 Everglades crash had turned up "serious deficiencies" in its operations. David R. Hinson, the agency's Administrator, said those included "multiple shortcomings" in its supervision of maintenance contractors.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Greene King to Buy Magic Pub in Britain
abstract: Greene King, a British brewer and pub operator, said yesterday that it would  acquire the Magic Pub Company for L197.5 million ($304.8 million), more than doubling the number of the regional brewer's managed pubs. After the deal, Greene King, the largest brewer in the south of England, will have 462 managed pubs and 677 leased pubs. Magic Pub has 277 pubs, hotels and inns.   (Bloomberg  Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WELLCARE MANAGEMENT RESTATES INCOME FOR TWO YEARS
abstract: Wellcare Management Group Inc. restated yesterday its financial results for 1995 and 1994, following complaints by shareholders who contended that the company's accounting practices were misleading. The move also comes as the Nasdaq stock market is reviewing its decision to drop the company because of its failure to file an annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wellcare, a health maintenance organization, said on Feb. 14 that it had net income of $7.8 million, or $1.25 a share, in 1995. Yesterday, the company restated that figure as $1.67 million, or 27 cents a share. The restatement reflected, in part, $2 million in licensing revenue that was recorded as revenue before it had been received. Wellcare, based in Kingston, N.Y., also restated 1994 results to show net income of $3.4 million, or 56 cents a share, down from  the originally reported figures of $6.2 million, or $1 a share.

headline: Thailand and Malaysia Magnets For Millions of Poorer Asians : Migrant Workers:Problem and Boon
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Illegal labor immigration has become widespread in Malaysia and Thailand, and government officials are now describing the inflow as a threat to national security.

headline: American Topics : Those Reports of Bagel Injuries Have Only a Crumb of Truth
abstract: Dan Rodricks, a columnist for The Baltimore Sun, found the reports hard to believe. Are bagel cuts really the most common injury seen in emergency rooms? Or was this a bit of '90s lore so often repeated that it had taken on a life of its own?

headline: Israeli Politics 101: Even the Premier Must Brawl
abstract: Called Israel's "first American politician" for the media-savvy style that brought him to the prime ministry, Benjamin Netanyahu is learning that the game  at the top is still the tough Israeli brand of politics.         As the first Israeli leader elected directly by the people, Mr. Netanyahu saw himself turning the prime ministry into an American-style chief executive, with  advisory councils and professionals in key ministries. In the original version,  Likud Party politicians were supposed to be relegated to supporting roles.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SANIFILL INC., Houston, an environmental services concern, acquired a number of  small waste-services companies with about $29 million in total annual revenues for $18 million in stock and $22 million in cash and notes.

headline: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Alliance Pharmaceutical Inc., San Diego, 2.5 million shares. Lehman Brothers.

headline: Mortar Found on Iranian Ship In Pickles Bound for Germany
abstract: A powerful mortar and a huge shell have been discovered in a cargo of pickles being shipped from Iran to Germany, and officials said today that they may have  been intended for use by terrorists against Israeli targets in Western Europe.         The container in which the weapon was hidden was unloaded from an Iranian freighter in Antwerp on March 14. The container was meant to continue overland to Munich while the ship, the Iran Kolladooz, traveled on to Hamburg.

headline: Cardinal Duval, 92, Critic of French Army
abstract: Leon-Etienne Cardinal Duval, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Algiers who denounced the torture of Arab nationalists by the French Army in the 1954-1962 war of independence, died today in Algiers. He was 92 and had been retired since 1988.         Pope John Paul II praised Cardinal Duval in a telegram to the current Archbishop, Henri Teissier.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Businesses Turn Less Bearish
