abstract: Japanese industrial leaders are becoming more optimistic about the economy but remain divided on prospects for a durable recovery, according to a quarterly survey released yesterday by the Bank of Japan. The central bank's "tankan" survey of nearly 10,000 companies found that pessimists continued to outnumber optimists, but by a smaller margin than in March.          The survey's main index for major manufacturers, which measures the percentage of companies saying business conditions are improving minus the percentage of those who say conditions are worsening, improved to minus 3 from the reading of minus 12 in March. That means that slightly more than half of the large companies surveyed are still bearish on the economy.   (AP)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PANAMSAT CONSIDERS SALE, MERGER OR ALLIANCE
abstract: The Panamsat Corporation said yesterday that it had hired Morgan Stanley & Company to explore its strategic alternatives, including joint ventures, alliances, mergers or the sale of the company. Panamsat also filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary offering of $350 million of common stock. Grupo Televisa S.A., which owns 40.5 million of Panamsat's 100 million shares, said it had not made a decision about Panamsat, based in Greenwich, Conn., or its other assets and could nott promise transactions would result from its review.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * Bealls Department Stores, Bradenton, Fla., to Crispin & Porter Advertising, Miami, to handle broadcast advertising for the retailer, previously handled by HMS/McFarland & Drier, Miami. Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

headline: New Jitters for Hong Kong;In Economics, as in Politics, China Exerts Control
abstract: It was supposed to be a lift-the-glass rally for the future of Hong Kong business. Beijing's de facto ambassador, Zhou Nan, recently described the paradise that awaits the colony after the Union Jack comes down on June 30, 1997, and the Chinese flag goes up. One after another, tycoons and corporate chieftains raved over his vision.         But then, Raymond Chien, trim and bespectacled, stepped to the podium. An economist by training, the managing director of one of Hong Kong's larger food-and-beverage conglomerates by vocation and an oenophile by avocation, Mr. Chien meandered into the murky world of metaphor to make his point. "A confident wine maker would choose to be minimally interventionist, allowing the wine to make itself," he said. "After all, there is no way for the wine to escape the bottle."

headline: Tribunal Plans To File Warrants
abstract: The head of the United Nations war crimes tribunal for Bosnia was quoted as saying today that arrest warrants for the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and his military chief, Ratko Mladic, would probably be issued in July.          The tribunal president, Judge Antonio Cassese, told the Foreign Minister of  Germany, Klaus Kinkel, in Bonn that the tribunal would hear evidence against the two indicted war crime suspects in The Hague on June 27, a Foreign Ministry statement said today.

headline: 2 Monitoring Groups Call Albania Vote Marred
abstract: Two major electoral monitoring organizations said today that the parliamentary vote in Albania, a former Communist country struggling to transform itself into a democracy, was marred by serious irregularities.         The conclusions by the Vienna-based Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and the Washington-based International Republican Institute officially confirmed what many individual observers reported after Sunday's vote.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;$1.9 BILLION OFFER FROM CONRAIL IS REJECTED
abstract: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had rejected Conrail Inc.'s revised $1.9 billion offer to acquire major portions of the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation's system. Conrail said on Wednesday that it increased by $400 million its previously rejected offer to Union Pacific for Southern Pacific's eastern lines. Conrail sought to buy Southern Pacific lines running from Chicago to Houston; between Houston and New Orleans, and throughout Texas, Louisiana and Arkansas. Philadelphia-based Conrail initially offered $1.5 billion last September for the lines after the proposed merger between Southern  Pacific and Union Pacific was announced. Union Pacific rejected the offer. The merger has run into opposition from Federal agencies and some shippers.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daily Mail Gets Stake In British TV Operation
abstract: The Daily Mail and General Trust P.L.C. of Britain has bought a 20 percent stake in Independent Television News for L20.4 million ($30.9 million). Granada  Group and Carlton Communications said jointly yesterday that they had each sold  10 percent of I.T.N. for L10.2 million, giving I.T.N. a total value of L102.5 million ($155.2 million).          Granada and Carlton were required to reduce their shareholdings under the 1990 Broadcasting Act, which limits holdings in I.T.N. to 20 percent. After the sale, the ownership of I.TN. is expected to be 20 percent Carlton, 20 percent Granada, 20 percent Daily Mail and General Trust, and 18 percent Reuters Holdings. Anglia Television and Scottish Television will each hold 5 percent, and 12 percent will be held by a Carlton-Granada joint venture.   (Reuters)

headline: News Analysis;Bosnia Uproar: Why U.S. Pushes for Early Vote
abstract: The United States and other outside powers that sponsored the Dayton peace accords, as well as those engaged in the four-year war in Bosnia -- Serbia, Croatia and Bosnia itself -- will all meet tomorrow in Florence to assess how the peace plan is faring after its first six months. Peace reigns, so far, on the ground. But hanging over the meeting will be a sharp dispute over whether the necessary conditions exist for elections by Sept. 14, as called for in the accords, and whether the United States, for its own political reasons, is manipulating the process it devised to insure a free and fair vote.

headline: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE FAR EAST;Vladivostok Enjoys Vote But Worries Over Result
abstract: A thick, chill fog muddled the masts and cranes of Golden Horn Bay, but inside the Palace of the Sailor, voters of various political stripes clearly shared a common joy on Sunday at exercising their right to elect a President.         "It won't be like Brezhnev any more, getting stuck with a President for 17 years," said a 21-year-old Russian Navy sailor.

headline: Family Calls Serb a Victim of Mistaken Identity
abstract: Ljubomir Tadic's family videos are fuzzy from use. But he assures visitors that poor quality does not hide veracity, and as he pops one after another into  his recorder, rewinding and re-running them, he says there can be no doubt that  a terrible mistake has been made in The Hague.         On the screen there is a party before the war, his brother Dusan Tadic toasting with Muslim neighbors. Then there is the burial of his father, with Muslims among the pallbearers. Later comes Dusan firmly denying to international war crimes investigators that after the Serbs took over control of Kozarac four  years ago he tortured and killed those Muslims he once knew.

headline: Report Faults C.I.A. on Hiring Of Informers in Guatemala
abstract: The Central Intelligence Agency knowingly hired as paid informers a number of Guatemalan military officers suspected of political assassinations, extrajudicial killings, kidnapping and torture, a Presidential panel reported today.         In a sweeping review providing new details about the agency's deep and longstanding ties to the Guatemalan military, the presidential panel, the Intelligence Oversight Board, went far beyond what was previously known about the agency's relationship with one Guatemalan officer, Col. Julio Roberto Alpirez, who was on the C.I.A.'s payroll from 1988 to 1992.

headline: Compuserve and Planet Hollywood Price Their Public Offerings
abstract: Compuserve Inc. and Planet Hollywood International Inc. priced their initial  public offerings late yesterday, becoming the latest companies to enter the sizzling market for new stocks.         Compuserve's offering was priced at $30 a share to raise $480 million for the on-line service.

headline: Hope, and Pragmatism, for U.N. Cities Conference
abstract: Twenty years ago the United Nations held a conference in Vancouver to talk about a worrying world trend toward urbanization, especially the uncontrolled growth of cities in some of the poorest countries.         That conference, held during the height of the cold war, swiftly descended into ideological bickering between industrialized nations and the third world, backed by the Soviet bloc. It ended with a statement of grandiose demands, almost none of which were fulfilled.

headline: Warning Israel, Arab Chiefs Set Summit Session
abstract: In a firm message directed at Israel's new conservative Government, leaders of Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia announced plans today to convene the first Arab summit meeting in six years and warned against any Israeli retreat from past commitments to peace.         In a joint communique, the leaders declared that neglect by Israel of the quest toward peace with its Arab neighbors "will put Israel in confrontation with the international community, representing a genuine threat of returning the region to the cycle of violence and instability."

headline: Communications Trade Pact Eludes the Big Economies
abstract: Trade ministers from four of the world's major economies said today that they had made some progress toward an agreement to liberalize trade in telecommunications. But the officials, who met over the weekend in the Japanese  port of Kobe, said it was still questionable whether a global accord could be forged by the self-imposed deadline of April 30.         At stake is an effort by 51 nations, under the auspices of the World Trade Organization, to negotiate an agreement that would open domestic telephone and telecommunications markets to foreign companies. Although such an opening could  save consumers billions of dollars, many countries are reluctant to let foreign  companies compete with their national telephone companies.

headline: As China Undercuts Democracy, Hong Kong Scuffles for Passports
abstract: Inexorably, the clock marched toward midnight, and the last chance to apply for a British overseas passport.         Then, a few minutes into this morning, a phalanx of blue-uniformed police pushed a tiny woman, barely visible in their midst, toward the doors of the black marble-and-glass Immigration Tower as she clutched a white paper application.

headline: U.N. Court, for First Time, Defines Rape as War Crime
abstract: A United Nations tribunal announced today the indictment of eight Bosnian Serb military and police officers in connection with rapes of Muslim women in the Bosnian war, marking the first time sexual assault has been treated separately as a crime of war.         The indictments were announced by the International Criminal Tribunal in the  Hague after almost two years of investigations.

headline: NEC and Packard Bell in Deal To Create the No. 4 PC Maker
abstract: Packard Bell Electronics, which dominates the American market for home computers but has not been consistently profitable, announced yesterday that it  would merge with the foreign PC operations of the NEC Corporation of Japan, which has had little success outside its home market.         The deal would create a new company called Packard Bell NEC that could be a powerhouse in the global PC business and give NEC a stronger foothold in markets that are also coveted by Japanese rivals.dr

headline: Wildcat Strike Shuts Down a G.M. Plant
abstract: A wildcat strike shut down a factory in Lordstown, Ohio, today that makes some of the General Motors Corporation's most popular cars, the latest sign of continued labor problems at the world's largest auto maker.         While there were several signs that the strike could prove brief, the work stoppage was another sign of the deep discontent on the floors of several large  G.M. factories. That discontent could make it more difficult for the national leaders of the United Automobile Workers union to work out a compromise this summer with G.M.'s top management before the U.A.W.'s national contract with the Big Three auto makers expires on Sept. 14.

headline: U.S. Warning 3 Foreign Companies Over Investments in Cuba
abstract: The Clinton Administration will send letters Wednesday advising private companies in Mexico, Canada and Italy that they may be subject to punitive action because of investments in Cuba, American officials said today.         The letters will be the first actions taken to carry out legislation intended to punish companies that use properties confiscated by Cuba from American citizens or corporations.

headline: Joint Chiefs Weaken Proposal For Land-Mine Moratorium
abstract: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have watered down a proposed American moratorium on land mines, recommending a broad exception that could allow the use of mines anywhere the United States and its allies need protection from an enemy across a demilitarized zone, Clinton Administration officials said today.         The proposal, which was presented to President Clinton in a White House meeting today, would allow the use of mines indefinitely in Korea and in other potential war zones where the United States and its allies patrol a demilitarized area recognized by the United Nations.

headline: No U.S. Arms Role in Bosnia, Holbrooke Says
abstract: Former Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke testified today that the Clinton Administration did nothing wrong -- in fact, did nothing at all -- with respect to Iranian arms shipments to Bosnia's Muslims in 1994 and 1995.         "We are now discussing something that didn't happen," Mr. Holbrooke, who was  the Administration's chief negotiator in the Balkan war, told the Senate Intelligence Committee. That was the gist of a three-hour session on the Administration's decision to take no action against the Iranian shipments, a policy that will be the focus of several Congressional hearings this year.

headline: Ford Chiefs Say the Taurus Can't Stay No. 1 at Any Cost
abstract: The Ford Motor Company will not risk missing its profit targets simply to insure that its Taurus is the nation's best-selling car again this year, a top Ford official said today.         Partly because of heavy advertising and generous rebates, the Taurus has held that position for the last four years. But the Honda Accord narrowly outsold the Taurus during the first four months of this year, 124,927 to 123,837, a pattern  that Ford's critics have attributed to the company's decision to redesign the Taurus and to raise the price when the new model was introduced last fall.

headline: Westinghouse Says It Weighs Separate Broadcasting Stock
abstract: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it was weighing the idea of separate stocks for its broadcasting and industrial operations.         The company, the nation's biggest broadcaster since acquiring CBS in November, confirmed that separate stocks were among the options it was considering. The Hollywood Reporter reported today that the company was considering a split.

headline: DIARY
abstract: TREASURY BONDS

headline: Albania Party Says It Won
abstract: Albania's governing party has announced that it won the country's general election by a landslide, the state-run television said today.         The two-round elections, held on May 26 and June 2, were marred by allegations of vote manipulation, and Western observers said the balloting failed to meet international legal standards. Most opposition parties boycotted  the voting and have said they will refuse to accept the few parliamentary seats  the Government said they won.

headline: Thi Cau Journal;Vietnam, a Convert, Pursues Capitalism Devoutly
abstract: Business has never been better at the "bank of the other world," where Tran Van Binh sells stacks of aluminum-foil gold bars, strings of plastic pearls and  wads of photocopied $100 bills from his front porch.         And at the nearby temple of the Goddess of the Treasury, where these votive offerings mingle with a cornucopia of real mangoes and roses and eggs and boiled duck and tiny bottles of rice wine, the crowds of worshipers have never been larger.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Prices Rise on Outlook For Seasonal Surge in Demand
abstract: Gasoline prices rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange on expectations that inventories at refineries would drop as a result of a seasonal increase in consumption.         On other markets, prices of crude oil also rose while wheat prices fell.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Placement Firm Will Steer Clients to Temporary Jobs The nation's largest job-placement company reached an agreement to channel laid-off white-collar workers -- like upper-level managers, engineers, accountants and lawyers -- into temporary work when it cannot place them in permanent, well-paying jobs.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE POLICY;A Role as Nation's Chief Salesman Abroad
abstract: Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown was in the Balkans in his self-assigned role as the nation's salesman in chief, seeking profitable opportunities for American businesses abroad and making the case that economic power should be a cornerstone of American foreign policy.         It was a generally successful strategy that allowed Mr. Brown to portray himself as a champion of American business interests the world over, and provided him a potent defense against Republicans in Congress who sought to eliminate his department on the grounds that it cost too much and gave government too active a role in the economy.

headline: An Emerging Prominence For Blacks in Publishing;Authors Press for Change in Minority Hiring
abstract: Career day comes to the fifth-grade class of M. G. Rhodes Elementary school bringing youthful questions about the nation's capital of book publishing that are too painful for candor.         "What's the racial makeup of your employees?" a young black student politely  presses Beverly Robinson, a visiting publicity director from Ballantine, a division of Random House. Seasoned in the art of public relations, she hesitates.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Steel Is Cited In Krupp Profit Drop
abstract: The German steel and engineering company Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp said  yesterday that its profit in the first half of 1996 had fallen to around 200 million marks ($131 million) from 223 million ($146 million) a year earlier. The company's chairman, Gerhard Cromme, in a speech prepared for the annual shareholder meeting, said the profit drop was mainly attributable to the company's steel division, which suffered price and volume declines.   (Reuters)

headline: Split of Electronic Data and G.M. Is Set
abstract: For E.D.S., life after its long-sought parting from General Motors might not  be so sweet after all.         The companies announced yesterday that Electronic Data Systems, the world's largest computer services provider, would pay the world's largest car maker $500 million for its freedom and face rival bidders for billions of dollars of G.M. contracts that now are captive. Beginning next year, E.D.S. will even have to offer easier payment terms to G.M.

headline: World News Briefs;New Zealand Faces Historic Land Claim
abstract: In a finding that is likely to result in the largest land claim in the country's history, an official report released today says virtually an entire province was illegally taken from Maori tribes during the last century.         The finding, which involves billions of dollars and tens of thousands of acres, provides a historic victory for the Taranaki Maori tribes on the west coast of the North Island. It could result in the return to the Maoris of Mount  Taranaki, a magnificent volcano that dominates the area.

headline: Few Big Ripples Are Seen For the Global Economy
abstract: When a huge international financial institution like the Sumitomo Corporation announces that one of its traders has cost the company $1.8 billion in trading losses, Americans naturally ask how might this affect them. The answer seems to  be that the impact will be negligible.         This is the third time in less than 18 months that a rogue trader has cost his employer $1 billion or more, and apart from the astonishment, the first two losses failed to leave much of a dent. A major British bank collapsed and various individuals were hurt, but national economies moved on basically unscathed.

headline: News Analysis;Telling Israeli Vote: More Fear Than Hope on Peace
abstract: Elections are always a time to draw conclusions about the state of a society, and the initial lessons of the Israeli vote did not look favorable either for the future of the Palestinian peace or the internal unity of Israel itself.         The first and most crucial statement was that a majority of Israeli Jews viewed the process of granting the Palestinians a homeland in exchange for peace with more fear than hope. The Likud's candidate, Benjamin Netanyahu, successfully capitalized on that fear, and Prime Minister Shimon Peres failed to allay it.

headline: Tough Talk for Israel From 3 Mideast Leaders
abstract: The leaders of Egypt, Jordan and the Palestinians called on Israel today to withdraw from all occupied Arab lands and to renounce what they called its "concepts of expansion, superiority and domination."         The three leaders -- President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat -- have already reached peace accords with Israel, and did not  mention Israel by name. But they referred to "the regrettable and bloody events  which the region has recently seen," and took an unusually firm line in setting  terms for "a real peace."

headline: Triumph of the Bottom Line;Numbers vs. Words at the Book-of-the-Month Club
abstract: In the seven decades that the Book-of-the-Month Club Inc. has flourished, its corporate rituals have become as obsolete as parchment paper and leather-bound books.         Gone are the days when prominent club judges savored the words of Hemingway and J. D. Salinger over fine sherry and elegant lunches, anointing the Book of the Month by dessert. The club's literary vetters were eliminated in 1994 as a quaint anachronism that the company said did not keep pace with a competitive, market-driven publishing industry.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL UNIT TO SELL STAKE IN BRAKE MAKER
abstract: The Allied Signal International Finance Corporation, a unit of Allied Signal  Inc., said yesterday that it would sell its 80 percent stake in the Turkish brake maker Transturk Fren Donanim Endustrisi A.S. to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Stuttgart, Germany, which makes automotive and electronics products, for $21 million. Also, Allied Signal completed the sale of its wholly owned hydraulic- and anti-lock-braking businesses to Robert Bosch for $1.5 billion. That sale was cleared by European regulators earlier this week. The businesses that were sold to Bosch accounted for about $2.1 billion of Allied Signal's 1995 sales of  $14.3 billion.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lufthansa Narrowed First-Quarter Loss
abstract: The chief executive of Deutsche Lufthansa A.G., Jurgen Weber, said yesterday  that the airline company's first-quarter loss narrowed by 10 percent. The pretax loss in the quarter was 49 million marks ($32 million), compared with 55 million marks in the first quarter of 1995. Lufthansa said that it usually posted a loss in the first quarter of a year.          For 1995, pretax profit was 756 million marks ($492 million), up 3 percent from 734 million marks in 1994. Net income in 1995 soared to 1.476 billion marks ($962 million) on one-time items, compared with 302 million marks in 1994. For 1995, the company had 879 million marks in extraordinary gains, including one-time tax benefits and aircraft sales.    (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: 59th Victim of Bombings
abstract: An Israeli man died today of wounds suffered in one of four recent attacks by Islamic suicide bombers directed against Israelis.         The man, Yitzhak Weinstein, had been unconscious since the attack on a bus in Jerusalem on Feb. 25. The Islamic militant group Hamas took responsibility for the bombing.

headline: I.B.M. Personnel Software
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce on Monday  computer programs to help big companies keep track of human resources information, posing a threat to niche companies like Peoplesoft Inc.         I.B.M. also will help companies set up computer systems to distribute human resources information.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Chasing Those New Issues
abstract: Entrepreneurs start innovative companies, take them public and became millionaires overnight. And everyone seems eager to get in on the action -- leading to great demand for shares in newly public companies.         Mutual funds are no exception, says Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund tracking firm. To spot funds that were heavily involved in initial public offerings, Morningstar in early April studied the most recent portfolios of more than 2,000 United States diversified equity funds.

headline: World News Briefs;Revival of Warsaw Pact No Joke in East Europe
abstract: A Russian news agency found out today that jokes about the old Soviet Union are not so funny to the people of Eastern Europe, even on April Fools' Day.         Itar-Tass, which traditionally runs a few gag items on April 1, reported today that Russia's Parliament was considering a revival of the Warsaw Pact, the old Soviet military alliance that once included Eastern European countries.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALLERGAN-UPJOHN MERGER TALKS ARE ENDED
abstract: Allergan Inc., a manufacturer of eye- and skin-care products, said yesterday  that discussions with Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. about a possible merger had been terminated because the proposed terms were "not feasible." Allergan made the announcement after The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Pharmacia & Upjohn was talking with Allergan about a takeover.          Allergan said the discussions involved a possible stock-swap merger with "pooling of interest" accounting that would in theory have allowed greater profits than a cash deal would have allowed. "The pooling was feasible for Allergan, but not for Pharmacia & Upjohn," Jeff D'Eliscu, an Allergan spokesman, said. Following the release of Allergan's statement, Pharmacia & Upjohn issued a statement saying that it was aware of what Allergan had said and had no further  comment. Allergan's shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $38.25. Pharmacia & Upjohn's stock rose 62.5 cents, to $39.625.

headline: World News Briefs;Israel and Militants Trade Fire in Lebanon
abstract: Israeli shelling in southern Lebanon that killed two Lebanese civilians on Saturday led to rocket attacks by Islamic militants on northern Israel overnight, but Israelis near the border emerged from bomb shelters today following diplomatic efforts to calm the situation.         The Israeli shelling on Saturday occurred in the area of southern Lebanon that Israel considers its security zone. Israel later said the shelling of civilians had been a mistake.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Sicola Martin Gets 2 Accounts
abstract: Sicola Martin in Austin, Tex., was awarded two high-tech accounts with combined billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million.          The Sun River Corporation, a computer company in Austin, has named Sicola Martin as the first agency to handle advertising. Sicola Martin was awarded the  account without a review. And the Motorola Computer Group in Tempe, Ariz., a unit of Motorola Inc., named Sicola Martin to handle its account, which had been handled by Hodskins Simone & Searls in Palo Alto, Calif. That decision came after an informal review.

headline: AT THE GATE;Communicating Not Just Over the Phone
abstract: WHEN Excel Communications Inc. makes its expected debut next month as a public company, many investors may be be swept off their feet, only to land right on their backsides.         The allure of the Dallas telecommunications company is indisputable. Revenues climbed from $30.8 million in 1993 to $506.7 million last year. For the first three months of 1996, sales were nearly quadruple those of the comparable period in 1995. This growth, the company says, now makes it the country's fourth-largest domestic residential long-distance company, behind AT&T, MCI Communications and Sprint.

headline: No Headline
COMPANY NEWS;NEW JERSEY GRANTS MERGER OF TWO TRUMP CASINOS
abstract: Donald J. Trump, the developer, received permission yesterday from New Jersey regulators for a $1.4 billion merger of his two biggest casino properties. Regulators also granted Trump a license for his fourth and newest casino, Trump  World's Fair Casino, which is to open next month. Trump plans to issue $1.1 billion in new bonds through his Trump Atlantic City Associates to pay off existing debt of Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort and Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. The two gambling halls will be merged under the Trump Atlantic City Associates umbrella. The deal will decrease their long-term debt by about $65 million, to $1.11 billion, Paul O'Gara, a lawyer for Mr. Trump, told the state Casino Control Commission.

headline: World News Briefs;Panama Leader Concedes Drug Money Aided Him
abstract: President Ernesto Perez Balladares admitted today that an accused drug cartel leader in Cali, Colombia, contributed $51,000 to his 1994 presidential campaign.

headline: College Bills and Rewards
abstract: To the Editor:         In "Scrimping on College Has Its Own Price" (From the Desk Of, March 3), Amy  Wu detailed the financial reasons for graduating from college in three years instead of four. Twenty-something years ago, when I graduated third in my class  in a small Catholic high school, I was armed with a strong desire for an education but lacked scholarship money or financial aid. I was one of six children, and the only opportunity I had to receive an education was through the City University of New York.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/ Imation may be a brand-new company but it has a long history. By Jon E. Hilsenrath.

headline: Penney's Wandering Eye Puts Wall St. on Watch
abstract: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, the country's fourth-largest retailer, was courted for a takeover by the J. C. Penney Company but swiftly refused the offer, both companies said yesterday.         The offer, which was made in February, has left Wall Street suspicious that Dayton Hudson, which has a mixed bag of both good and troubled retailers, is in  play. It also raised questions about whether J. C. Penney, the nation's fifth-largest retailer, had designs on other retailers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TOSCO SETS STOCK RATIO FOR ACQUISITION OF CIRCLE K
abstract: The Tosco Corporation said yesterday that it had set a stock-exchange ratio for its acquisition of the Circle K Corporation, which values the stock at $31.48 a share. Tosco, a refiner and marketer of petroleum products that is based in Stamford, Conn., agreed in February to buy Circle K, a Phoenix-based operator of gas stations and convenience stores, for about $900 million, including cash and assumption of debt. Circle K shareholders will receive 0.6162 share of Tosco common stock for each share of Circle K. Separately, Circle K said its chairman, president and chief executive, John Antioco, planned to resign after the merger. Robert Lavinia, Tosco's executive vice president, will then assume responsibility for Circle K.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Boots Is Planning To Buy Back Shares
abstract: The British retailer Boots Company P.L.C. said yesterday that it would carry  out a program to repurchase up to L300 million ($462 million) of its stock. The  company said that the buyback amount represented up to 51.36 million shares at a price of up to 580 pence ($8.93) a share. The stock closed yesterday at 578.5 pence, down 2.5.          Boots said, "The repurchase is designed to achieve a more efficient capital  structure for the long term, in line with Boots' stated policy of maximizing shareholder value." Boots is a retail and drugstore company with operations in Britain, France and Italy.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bankruptcy Begins At Bremer Vulkan
abstract: Bremer Vulkan-Verbund, once Germany's biggest shipbuilder, said yesterday that bankruptcy proceedings had formally begun, though work would continue at most operations.          The bankruptcy applies to the parent company and to several separately incorporated shipyards in western Germany. Bremer Vulkan filed for protection from creditors on Feb. 21 after 1995 losses of more than a billion marks, or $665 million.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Bankruptcy Pressed For Commodity Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers Inc., Merrill Lynch & Company and other broker-dealers are trying to force the AIOC Corporation, a New York-based commodities trading group, into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.         Mark J. Schapiro, a lawyer for the broker-dealer firms, said they had filed a Chapter 11 petition in the hope that AIOC might be able to get financing to avoid a liquidation of its assets.

headline: Caracas Journal;After a Beauty Crown, Now the Jewel of City Hall
abstract: Fifteen years after Irene Saez marched down the runway as Miss Universe, dazzling in her crown and roses, the former beauty queen reigns over a borough of Caracas that is fast becoming a theme park in good government.         Miss Saez, 34, is Mayor of Chacao, the richest part of Caracas, with 185,000  residents. In a capital that most frequently inspires dark awe -- that a country so rich can get so run down -- Miss Saez runs an area that is clean and orderly, where government, astonishingly, works.

headline: Whose E-Mail Is It?
abstract: To the Editor:         Regardless of one's interpretation of "employee rights," it is wrong to send  personal E-mail messages on the employer's time and equipment ("Who's Reading Your E-Mail? Maybe the Boss," Earning It, May 12).

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Somalia Battle Escalates As Toll Rises on 4th Day
abstract: Artillery shells and missiles pounded positions of rival Somali factions today as this capital struggled through the fourth straight day of heavy fighting that has left 11 people dead and 37 wounded.         The forces of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid and those of his former financier, Osman Hassan Ali, are battling for control of a strategic junction linking the divided capital with southern Somalia.

headline: Mazda Raises Some Prices
abstract: Mazda Motor of America has raised the suggested retail price of its 1996 models an average of $248. The increases are for cars shipped to dealers beginning this month, the company said. The increases affect virtually the entire line of sedans, convertibles, vans, trucks and sport utility vehicles, but not the base Millenia and Miata M Edition models.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LLOYD'S TO DELAY BEFORE SEIZING U.S. ASSETS
abstract: Lloyd's of London agreed yesterday to wait another month before attempting to seize assets from 2,700 United States investors, some of whom face financial ruin after huge losses at the British insurance market. Lloyd's also won greater protection from state regulators for its $20 billion bank accounts, used to pay  claims in the United States. Several states have attempted to seize some of those funds to repay investors. Nine states have sued Lloyd's, contending that it defrauded the investors by recruiting them to invest in Lloyd's without adequately informing them of the risks. Lloyd's, which denies the charges, has accused some state regulators of bringing lawsuits that would tie up crucial bank accounts and threaten the insurance market.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bangladesh Army Chief Ousted, Stirring Unrest
abstract: The President of Bangladesh dismissed the leader of his army today. Loyal soldiers moved to guard the President, but troops in some provincial barracks were reported to be showing signs of unrest.         Troops in tanks and armored vehicles circled the presidential palace as President Abdur Rahman Biswas accused the army chief, Lieut. Gen. Abu Saleh Mohammad Nasim, of trying to stage a revolt against his authority and dismissed  him.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Zeneca Is Selling A Unit to BASF
abstract: Zeneca Group P.L.C., a drug and chemicals company based in London, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its textile colors business to BASF A.G. of Germany for L138 million, or $208 million.          Zeneca Textile Color, will become part of BASF's textile and leather dyes and chemicals division. Zeneca Textile has operations in Britain, Brazil and Charlotte, N.C., and employs about 730 people, all of whom will transfer with the business.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Gaza Dissident Is Freed
abstract: A prominent human rights advocate in Gaza who has harshly criticized the Palestinian Authority has been released after 18 days of detention, rights groups said today.          The Gazan, Dr. Eyad Sarraj, a psychiatrist and head of the Independent Palestinian Commission for Citizens Rights, was released at 2 A.M. on Wednesday. He had been arrested at his home on June 9.

headline: PHYSICIANS HEALTH SHARES FALL AS EARNINGS DROP IS SEEN
abstract: The stock of Physicians Health Services Inc. fell about 10 percent yesterday  after the company, a managed health care concern based in Trumbull, Conn., said  declining premiums would result in an unexpected drop in earnings for the first  quarter. The shares of Physicians Health fell $3.1875, to $29.5625, in Nasdaq trading. Earlier, the shares had touched $26.50. Wall Street had been expecting  the company to earn 40 cents a share, based on the average estimate of six analysts surveyed by IBES International. It earned $3.14 million, or 33 cents a  share, in the first quarter of last year.

headline: World News Briefs;Western Sahara Vote Is Put in Doubt by U.N.
abstract: The United Nations has begun closing voter registration offices in the disputed Western Sahara, officials said today, making it unlikely that a long-delayed referendum on the region's future will take place.         United Nations officials had been trying to identify valid residents of the area for a vote giving them a choice between independence or integration with Morocco. The phosphate-rich territory, a former Spanish colony, is claimed by Morocco.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PAINE WEBBER IS FINED FOR RAIDING PRUDENTIAL
abstract: Paine Webber Group Inc. has been ordered to pay a rival, Prudential Securities Inc., a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, a record $2.5 million for raiding a Prudential brokerage branch office in Gainesville, Fla. A New York Stock Exchange arbitration panel imposed the fine last week because Paine Webber had hired almost all of Prudential's Gainesville brokers and sales assistants in 1993, The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday. The arbitrators told Paine Webber to pay Prudential $1 million in compensatory damages and $1.5 million in punitive damages. It was the largest punitive award  in a raiding case since at least 1991, the earliest date for which the exchange  keeps records.

headline: Possible Questioning of Philip Morris Staff
abstract: The Philip Morris Companies has told some Virginia employees that investigators from the Department of Justice may contact them about a Federal investigation of the tobacco company.         In a letter sent last week to current and former employees, Denise F. Keane,  senior vice president and general counsel of Philip Morris USA, said the cigarette maker was asked to provide the names of current and former employees who worked in certain departments and facilities, which were not identified in the letter.

headline: Soccer Hero Voices Liberia's Anguish
abstract: From the very outset of an interview conducted in the near-dark of his hotel  room here, where heavy curtains blocked out the dazzling late afternoon sun, George M. Weah wanted to make one thing clear.         "I am not a politician," said the 30-year-old Liberian, who was recently named the international player of the year by soccer's governing body. "I just have strong feelings for my country that I cannot hide."

headline: Pakistani Calls for Reform
abstract: Imran Khan, Pakistan's former cricket hero and a critic of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, announced today that he was forming a movement to fight corruption and injustice. He said at a news conference here that he would turn his Justice Movement into a political party if it won enough support.         Mr. Imran, 43, said he was starting the movement because he found Pakistan "on the brink of disaster."

headline: In Israel, a Ghost Town Stirs Back to Life
abstract: Minutes before a 4 A.M. cease-fire went into effect this morning, a last Katyusha rocket fired by Hezbollah guerrillas smashed into an apartment building in the heart of this border town, shaking an underground shelter where Aviva Ohion was sleeping with her family.         They were still in the shelter six hours later, even as neighbors were venturing outside to stroll the streets freely for the first time in more than two weeks.

headline: Mexico Tries to Restrict Some Foreign Investments
abstract: After several years of throwing open its economy, Mexico has recently tried to shut some doors to American and other foreign investors, contending that national interests come before trade agreements.         The latest attempt to restrict investment came this week as Mexican legislators, backed by the nation's strongest labor unions, demanded that foreign companies be prohibited from managing new pension funds that will be established next year as part of sweeping changes in the Mexican social security system.

headline: NBC Hopes to Woo Affiliates With Old-Fangled Technology
abstract: A few decades ago, before the age of cheap satellite communication, the television networks distributed programming to their affiliated stations around  the country over telephone lines. Now, with the help of the latest digital technology, NBC is hoping that it can lift its ratings and improve its affiliate relations by reviving that old model.         At the opening today of the National Association of Broadcasters convention in Las Vegas, Nev., NBC's president, Robert Wright, is expected to announce that the network, a unit of General Electric, is joining with MCI Communications Corporation and the computer makers Sun Microsystems and Silicon Graphics to create a high-speed data connection that could one day replace the satellite links that now bind the network and its affiliates.

headline: Falconbridge Raises Bid for Diamond Fields
abstract: Falconbridge Ltd. sweetened its offer for Diamond Fields Resources Inc. today in an attempt to avert a bidding war with Inco Ltd. for a huge metals deposit in Newfoundland.         Falconbridge weighed in with a new offer to share the deposit, in a region known as Voisey's Bay, with Inco. Diamond Fields' major asset is a majority stake in the deposit, which is described as the world's most important nickel strike in decades.

headline: Supporters Mob the Bulgarian King on His Return
abstract: King Simeon II of Bulgaria was mobbed by supporters today as he toured the lavish Orthodox churches of the capital, Sofia, on the second day of his return  from 50 years of exile.         Up to half a million people turned out on Saturday to welcome Simeon, a business consultant in Spain, and his wife, Margarita, a Spanish aristocrat.

headline: German War Crime Inquiry
abstract: A war crimes investigation has been reopened against a former West German Government minister nearly four decades after he was cleared of previous charges.         Wolfgang Weber, the prosecutor in Cologne, said today that he had been investigating the former minister, Theodor Oberlaender, since March.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Producer Prices Fell in May, Easing Threat of Inflation Prices at the producer level fell unexpectedly in May, the Government said, offering fresh evidence that inflation remains tame despite Wall Street's fears. Tumbling energy prices and stable food costs helped push the Producer Price Index down one-tenth of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department said. Excluding volatile food and energy costs, the core rate was unchanged after rising one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the three prior months.

headline: Chemical Bank Ex-Trader Returns to U.S.
abstract: A former currency trader for the Chemical Banking Corporation has been brought back to the United States from Britain to face charges that he concealed a $70 million trading loss while working in the bank's New York office.         Victor Gomez appeared yesterday before Federal Magistrate James Francis in New York and was released on a $250,000 personal recognizance bond.

headline: Bosnians See A California In Balkans
abstract: As the people in this valley emerge, battered by war and winter, two men are  waiting for them. They intend to grab everyone -- widows, refugees and demobilized soldiers alike -- by their collars, shake them soundly, then point them toward a vision.         "We're going to make this place into California," proclaimed Gen. Mehmed Alagic, without even a blush over a plan that might be mistaken for a fantasy. "Why not?"

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HEILEMAN FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY TO SPEED ITS SALE
abstract: As expected, the G. Heileman Brewing Company filed for bankruptcy protection  yesterday as part of its acquisition by the Stroh Brewery Company. Heileman has  said that a bankruptcy filing would make its acquisition by Stroh easier by wiping out the litigation risk from Heileman's debt holders. The plan is pre-negotiated, meaning the company believes it has most of the support it needs from creditors for the plan to be legally approved. Stroh announced on Feb. 29 that it planned to buy the company, in which the investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst owns a controlling stake, in a complex deal worth an estimated $275 million to $300 million.

headline: Politics, Passion and Graft at Issue in Rio Slayings
abstract: When Paulo Cesar Farias, who was the campaign treasurer for the former President, Fernando Collor de Mello, was found shot to death in bed with his girlfriend on Sunday, the police and his family labeled the deaths a crime of passion. But developments since then have raised the idea of a political motive  and brought in federal investigators.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REUNION RESOURCES AGREES TO TRIBO PETROLEUM OFFER
abstract: The Reunion Resources Company said late on Thursday that it had agreed to sell all of its oil and gas assets to the Tribo Petroleum Corporation for $11.4  million, as it moves to focus on its plastic businesses. Tribo, based in Houston, will pay $9.6 million in cash and $1.7 million in a promissory note due six months after the close of the transaction, expected on May 1. The agreement  comes three months after Reunion said the Bargo Energy Company dropped its plan to acquire the assets for $15.1 million in cash.

headline: Spanish Premier Reported Clear in Basque Deaths
abstract: A Supreme Court judge investigating charges that Spanish death squads carried out assassinations of Basque separatists in the 1980's has found nothing to link the squads to outgoing Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, Spanish newspapers reported today.         The newspapers, citing court officials, said that the judge, Eduardo Moner, was expected to produce a writ no later than Monday discarding testimony against Mr. Gonzalez. Such a writ would end the possibility that Mr. Gonzalez would lose his parliamentary immunity and be brought before the Supreme Court's penal section for interrogation.

headline: U.S. and Japan Say No to Any Food Aid For North Korea Now
abstract: The United States and Japan ruled out today sending immediate food aid to North Korea despite warnings that its food supply is "perilously close to collapse."         At the end of two days of talks by American, Japanese and South Korean officials on strategy toward the North, the three countries issued a joint statement saying they agreed to continue efforts to persuade the North to accept four-nation peace talks proposed last month by Washington and Seoul.

headline: For Magellan Shareholders, A Record Payout
abstract: The Fidelity Magellan fund declared its biggest distribution ever to shareholders on Friday because of large capital gains produced by the sale of technology stocks last fall and income received from its Government bond holdings.         For investors in retirement accounts, the distribution is mostly a nonevent,  but other investors will owe taxes on the distribution for the 1996 tax year.

headline: DIARY
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER DRILLING ENDS TALKS ON BUYING RENTAL COMPANY
abstract: The Parker Drilling Company, based in Tulsa, Okla., said yesterday that it had ended its negotiations to buy Oil and Gas Rental Services Inc. Last month, Parker said it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Oil and Gas Rental, a  privately held company in Morgan City, La., that rents drilling tools to oil companies. Terms were not disclosed, though a Merrill Lynch analyst, Kevin Simpson, estimated the price at about $100 million.

headline: About Real Estate;In Virginia, Good Sign For Offices
abstract: Two office projects are under construction in Fairfax County, Va., the leading suburban office market in the Washington area, providing the first evidence of a return to speculative office development in the county since the real estate recession of 1989.         At one project, along the Dulles Toll Road two miles east of Dulles International Airport, the steel is already in place for a four-story building of 103,000 square feet in which Airbus Industrie of North America has signed a lease for just under half the space. The rest is being built with no tenant commitments and is being marketed for occupancy this fall. The project is called Presidents Plaza II.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;After 5 Years of False Starts, Japan's Economy Is Stirring
abstract: This winter has lasted five years in Japan, but there is finally talk of an economic spring.         The stock market is up, corporate profits are rising, and there is plenty of  cash in the banks. Perhaps more important, the long economic chill has forced corporate Japan to re-examine itself and cut costs, and so now companies may be  better poised than before to compete with American and European conglomerates around the globe.

headline: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
abstract: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.      To the Editor:

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIVIDEND TO BE RAISED BY 9% ALONG WITH STOCK SPLIT
abstract: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that it would raise its dividend nearly 9 percent and planned to split its stock five-for-one. The company, an agricultural biotechnology and chemical concern, will now pay a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share, up from 69 cents. The new dividend will be paid June 12 to shareholders of record May 15. After the stock split, in which the company will issue five shares for every one share held, the quarterly dividend rate will drop to 15 cents a share. St. Louis-based Monsanto also said  it would provide stock-option grants to about 27,000 employees who do not currently receive options.

headline: Surge Expected in Sales of Cable Modems
abstract: The consumer search for faster connections to the Internet will fuel an almost doubling in demand this year for cable modems in North America, the research firm Dataquest said today.         Cable modems link computer users to the Internet by using a cable television  connection, which enables faster access than modems that use standard telephone  lines.

headline: India Swears In Its 2d Premier In 3-Week Span
abstract: After two weeks of political turmoil, India got another new Government today, but even before the new Prime Minister took office there were signs that he may  have trouble holding together a fractious 13-party coalition that almost broke apart in last-minute wrangling over Cabinet posts.         For many Indians, it was a sobering moment as the political establishment gathered for the swearing-in of the country's second Government in 17 days.

headline: U.S. Puzzling Over Motives Of North Korea in the DMZ
abstract: American officials, while playing down the threat posed by North Korea's sudden round of violations of the military armistice that keeps the peace between the two Koreas, said today that they were baffled by the message Pyongyang was trying to send.         They presume North Korean troop movements inside the two-and-a-half-mile-wide demilitarized zone are part of a continuing effort to undermine the 1953 Military Armistice Agreement and push the United States into bilateral peace negotiations with Pyongyang. Yet they think the timing is symbolic, possibly aimed at the parliamentary elections in South Korea this week and a brief visit  there planned for next week by President Clinton.

headline: Ex-Intel Engineer Sentenced to Prison Term
abstract: An engineer who stole information about the Pentium computer chip from the Intel Corporation was sentenced to 33 months in Federal prison today.         Guillermo Gaede, 42, a native of Argentina, had pleaded guilty to mail fraud  and interstate transportation of stolen property. He was sentenced here by District Judge Ronald M. Whyte.

headline: Zenith to Market a TV with a Modem and Ethernet Link
abstract: The Zenith Electronics Corporation announced today that through a partnership with Diba Inc. it planned to market by October a television equipped with both a high-speed modem and an Ethernet connection to make it possible to connect easily to the Internet without the expense of a personal computer.         Diba is a small Silicon Valley company that designs software and hardware to  make it possible for television viewers to browse the Internet.

headline: Helped by Regional Parties, Conservative Is Voted Spain's Premier
abstract: The leader of the conservative Popular Party, Jose Maria Aznar, cleared the last hurdle today to become Spain's Prime Minister, winning the investiture vote in Parliament and ending 13 years of Socialist governments.         Mr. Aznar, 43, a former tax inspector, promised a "centrist" and "reform-minded" administration that will cut government spending and reduce the  budget deficit so Spain can qualify to be part of the European Union's planned single currency.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Pakistan Premier Blames 'Foreigners' for Bombing
abstract: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto blamed foreigners for a bombing that killed 40  people on a crowded bus on Sunday and promised that those responsible would not  go unpunished.         Though no one has claimed responsibility for the bomb, which had been stuffed in the fuel tank, Ms. Bhutto told the state-run news agency that the attack was  "foreign-inspired subversion," a usual reference to neighboring India.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Europe Refuses to Lift Ban on British Beef
abstract: European Union veterinary experts today turned down Britain's request to relax an export ban on British beef imposed in response to a report that mad cow disease may be transmitted to humans.         Britain wants to resume exports of beef fat and gelatin made from boiled-down cattle carcasses. Those materials are widely used in products like soap, cosmetics, glue, candy and ice cream.

headline: Health Group Votes to Kill Last Viruses Of Smallpox
abstract: Two hundred years after a vaccine was first used to stem the spread of smallpox, the World Health Organization has decided to destroy the last remaining stocks of the smallpox virus, one of the biggest killers in history.         Destruction is scheduled for June 30, 1999, according to a plan that representatives of 190 counties approved at the final day of the weeklong annual meeting of the health organization. Final approval is required by member countries of W.H.O., the United Nations agency in Geneva, at their May 1999 meeting.

headline: Orange County To Issue Debt
abstract: Orange County has said that it plans to issue about $900 million of recovery  debt on June 6 and barring unforeseen complications will close the deal on June  11 and emerge from bankruptcy.         Christopher Varelas, the county's top financial adviser and a vice president  at Salomon Brothers Inc., said Friday that the county would issue recovery certificates of participation and pension obligation refunding bonds on June 6.

headline: Facing Bitter Fight, McAfee Withdraws Its Bid for Cheyenne
abstract: Facing a bitter war of wills between two chief executives, McAfee Associates  Inc. has decided to withdraw its $1 billion proposal to acquire Cheyenne Software Inc.         Yesterday's announcement sent shares of Cheyenne tumbling 17.7 percent. A merger of McAfee, the leading maker of software to detect computer viruses, and  Cheyenne, which makes software for managing personal computer networks, would have created the nation's fifth-largest software company.

headline: CHECHENS' LEADER SIGNS PEACE PACT WITH THE KREMLIN
abstract: After 18 months of a war that has left Chechnya in ruins and imperiled the presidency of Boris N. Yeltsin, leaders of both sides signed a treaty at the Kremlin today intended to end the fighting in the secessionist region in southern Russia on June 1.         President Yeltsin has said many times that he would never negotiate directly  with the separatists. But clearly believing that he cannot win the presidential  election next month without making a dramatic new gesture of peace, he decided last week to invite the Chechen leader, Zelim khan Yanderbiyev, to Moscow.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Nickelodeon Is Planning Saturday-Morning Assault
abstract: Inspired by a burst of ratings growth this year that has made Nickelodeon's cable children's programming competitive with those of ABC, CBS and Fox, Nickelodeon has decided to attack Saturday morning, traditionally a stronghold of the broadcast networks.         Herb Scannell, the new president of Nickelodeon, the children's cable channel that is owned by Viacom Inc., said yesterday that the network would develop original programs for Saturday mornings. That is a break from its pattern of introducing new shows at times when the other networks do not program for children, mainly Saturday and Sunday afternoons.

headline: Survey by Fed Says Economy Is Strong, With Little Inflation
abstract: Despite fresh strength in the economy, wages and prices remain largely in check, a survey by the Federal Reserve found today.         The lack of quickened inflation was taken by private analysts as a crucial factor weighing against action by the central bank to tighten monetary conditions at its policy meeting early next month. Stock prices promptly climbed after the survey was issued at noon, while bond prices rose in early trading but finished slightly lower.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PANAMSAT IN DEAL WITH CHINESE STATE TV
abstract: China Central Television, or CCTV, and the Panamsat Corporation announced yesterday that they had a satellite delivery agreement that would enable CCTV, a Chinese state broadcaster, to expand its reach to much of the world. The 10-year agreement widened coverage of CCTV broadcasts to include Europe, the Middle East and Africa, an official of CCTV said. Previously, broadcasts covered Asia and North America only. Fredrick Landman, the president and chief executive of Panamsat, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., said the agreement was worth tens  of millions of dollars. Panamsat's shares rose $1.125 to $32.125.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Executives Form Consulting Company
abstract: Four longtime industry executives are forming a consulting company named the  Advertising Partnership, with offices in New York and London, that will use interactive technology to help agencies and advertisers improve their relationships.          DeWitt Helm Jr., 62, a former president and chief executive of the Association of National Advertisers in New York, will be chairman and chief executive, and Richard Robbins, 48, who had been a consultant at Canter Achenbaum Heekin in New York, will be president. There will be two senior advisers: Kenneth S. Olshan, 62, former chairman and chief executive of the Wells Rich Greene BDDP unit of BDDP Worldwide in New York, and David Wethey, 51, founder and managing director of Agency Assessments/ Showcase Ltd., a consulting company in London.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PEOPLES HERITAGE TO ACQUIRE FAMILY BANCORP
abstract: Peoples Heritage Financial Group, a banking company, said yesterday that it would acquire Family Bancorp in a stock deal valued at about $113.2 million. Peoples will offer 1.26 of its common shares, worth about $25.60, for each Family share in a tax-free exchange. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Family gained $1.625, to $23.875, while shares of Peoples rose 12.5 cents, to $19.875. Family, with assets of $887 million, has 17 banking offices in the Merrimack Valley area near Haverhill and Lowell, Mass., and six banking offices  in southern New Hampshire. Peoples has $4.3 billion in assets and operates Peoples Heritage Bank, with 62 banking centers throughout Maine.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TRUSTCO DECIDES NOT TO PURSUE ACQUISITION OF ALBANK
abstract: The Trustco Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would not pursue a proposed $460 million acquisition of the Albank Financial Corporation. Last month, Trustco, a banking company based in Schenectady, N.Y., offered cash and stock totaling $40 for each of Albank's shares, or $33.33 a share after accounting for Albank's recent 6-for-5 stock split. Albank, the Albany-based parent of Albank F.S.B., rejected the offer, saying the bank was not for sale. Albank shares fell $2.25 yesterday, to $27.125, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: F.D.I.C. Says Risk Is Up at Small Banks
abstract: A nationwide survey shows that most small banks did not relax their lending standards last year but about 11 percent assumed more risk than usual, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.         The survey of loan underwriting practices is intended as an early warning about loan problems for the F.D.I.C.

headline: Records Tie C.I.A. Informer To Two Guatemala Killings
abstract: Government officials said today that classified documents strongly suggest that a Guatemalan Army colonel who was a C.I.A. informer may be guilty in connection with the 1992 killing of a guerrilla married to an American and the 1990 murder of an American innkeeper.         The State Department provided the classified documents to Congress on Friday, but, citing national security and the secrecy demanded by intelligence services, omitted those documents from thousands of papers on human-rights abuses in Guatemala that it declassified and released to the public today.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Moulinex Shares Up On Revamping Plans
abstract: The shares of Moulinex soared 21 percent yesterday, a day after the company,  a French maker of household appliances, disclosed plans to cut a fifth of its work force over three years. The stock closed at 98.2 francs, up 17.2 francs, in Paris.          The plan, which calls for the elimination of as many as 2,600 jobs, sparked  a debate in the French Government, with the Industry Minister, Franck Borotra, calling the job cuts unacceptable, but the Finance Minister, Jean Arthuis, conceding that Moulinex "needed restructuring."   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Market Place;Despite a suit, some analysts are recommending Sallie Mae.
abstract: THE long reach of the Orange County, Calif., crisis is having some odd repercussions. One of them is a $100 million lawsuit filed by the county against the Student Loan Marketing Association, better known as Sallie Mae. The suit contends that there was a scheme in which Sallie Mae and Merrill Lynch & Company engaged in a secret kickback deal to inflate profits to Merrill Lynch on Sallie  Mae notes sold to Orange County.         While Orange County is hoping that the proceeds of this, and other, lawsuits  will help cover some of its bankruptcy-related losses, several analysts say holders of Sallie Mae shares have nothing to fear. In fact, they say, Sallie Mae investors should consider buying more.

headline: Revamping Is Approved For Mesa
abstract: Shareholders of Mesa Inc. approved a refinancing today that turns over control from T. Boone Pickens, the company's founder, to Richard Rainwater, a Fort Worth financier. But they did not go along peacefully         In substantial numbers, shareholders voted against the refinancing, which greatly dilutes their own holdings. In addition, shareholders refused to approve a 1-for-4 reverse stock split that management had recommended. Rarely do shareholders at any company vote down management proposals.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;German Banker's Remark Lifts The Dollar to a 16-Month High
abstract: The dollar rose to a 16-month high against the mark yesterday after a German  central bank official suggested that a weaker mark could help the nation's sagging economy.         A higher dollar "would have benefits," said Olaf Sievert, a member of the Bundesbank's interest rate-setting council. He said he had "no fear" that German inflation would accelerate if the dollar rose "a couple of pfennigs." A pfennig is a hundredth of a mark.

headline: Soros Quiet on His Bets
abstract: In recent days, people who follow the financial markets have speculated that  large hedge funds like the Soros Fund Management, run by the international financier George Soros, may have bet that the price of copper would fall sharply, contributing to the market's instability.          Mr. Soros, contacted yesterday in London, said, "Most such reports are unfounded" but he declined to make any comments on his copper investment activities.

headline: Nasdaq Delisting Weitek
abstract: The Weitek Corporation, a maker of computer memory chips, said on Wednesday that it would be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market. Weitek said Nasdaq had informed it that the company did not meet its listing requirements. The San Jose company said it planned to appeal the ruling. Weitek said it would seek a new listing on the Nasdaq-run OTC Bulletin Board if the company could not maintain its Nasdaq listing. Weitek's stock closed today at 96.9 cents.

headline: Deal Gives Frito-Lay Head Start In Use of P.& G.'s Fat Substitute
abstract: Frito-Lay Inc. said today that it had signed an agreement with the Procter &  Gamble Company that would give Frito-Lay far larger quantities of P.& G.'s new fat substitute, olestra, than competitors would get, for about a year.         Frito-Lay, a unit of Pepsico Inc. and the nation's largest maker of snacks, agreed to pay at least $10 million for supplies of the no-calorie, no-fat oil over the span of the contract, said a Frito-Lay spokeswoman, Lynn Markley.

headline: Patents;Beyond 'lather, rinse, repeat': formal steps to take the guesswork out of the application of cosmetics.
abstract: PUTTING on makeup is a personal action based on vague, universal principles.  Now Justine Reynolds of Chester, N.J., has won a patent for a method of applying cosmetics.         Ms. Reynolds, a makeup artist and consultant, said she was inspired to patent a makeup process because there were plenty of secret ingredients and formulas for cosmetics but no rules about how to put them on. "Although use of cosmetics  is age-old, having begun sometime before the reign of Cleopatra, there still exists no unified, comprehensive approach to makeup application," Ms. Reynolds said in her patent application.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New York Festivals Names 5 Winners
abstract: The New York Festivals has named five grand Best of Show winners at the 38th  annual international print and radio competition. In print, there were four winners: the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago, for the best consumer campaign, for Altoids Mints, which are marketed by a unit of the Philip Morris Companies; Euro RSCG Ball Partnership in Singapore, a unit of Euro RSCG, for the best newspaper advertising, for the Samaritans, a society dedicated to the prevention of suicide; Lewis Moberly in London, for the best design for a package, for Boots Childrens' Batteries, marketed by the Boots Company P.L.C., and Wunderman Cato Johnson in Eschborn, Germany, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., for the best direct mail, for Andersen Consulting.

headline: Mexico Sees a Rate Rebellion;Businesses and Consumers Alike Chafe at Loan Costs
abstract: Emilio Espana hardly has the makings of a radical. The head of a clan of candy makers, he runs a 94-year-old company that produces mints and lollipops that eager children buy on street corners all across Mexico.         But Mr. Espana has rebelled against the Mexican financial establishment. In November, after the variable interest rate on a $500,000 bank loan to his company, Usher, rose to 109 percent a month, he stopped paying.

headline: UN Rights Report Flays France for Its 'Racist' Immigration Laws
abstract: PARIS—  A United Nations report sharply rebuked France on Thursday for "a wave of xenophobia and racism" that it said was sweeping the country.

headline: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Dip
abstract: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.3 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent last week, according to a national survey issued today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.93 percent, up from 5.91 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.81 percent this week, down from 7.9 percent a week earlier.

headline: U.S. Urges Lebanese To Disarm Islamic Group
abstract: The United States, working to broker a new cease-fire agreement in southern Lebanon, handed the Lebanese Government an initial proposal today that reportedly called on Lebanon and Syria to disarm Hezbollah guerrillas in exchange for a possible Israeli pullout from its buffer zone in nine months.         The plan met with initial skepticism from the Lebanese Prime Minister, but intensive contacts continued among Israeli, Lebanese, Syrian and American officials, along with related mediation attempts by the French and Jordanians.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Rollerblade Narrows Its List
abstract: Rollerblade Inc., the marketer of in-line skates, said yesterday that it has  narrowed its account review to 6 agencies, from 12. The account had been handled by Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis for six years until that agency declined to participate in the review. Though the billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $10 million.          Deborah Autrey, a spokeswoman for Rollerblade in Minnetonka, Minn., confirmed a report of the review this week in Adweek. She identified the six agencies as: Foote, Cone & Belding in Los Angeles, which is owned by True North  Communications; GSD& M in Austin, Tex., a unit of the GGT Group; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group; Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco; Ground Zero in Santa Monica, Calif., and Martin/Williams Advertising in Minneapolis, also owned by the GGT Group. Ms. Autrey, who declined to name the six dismissed agencies, said that a decision was expected by the end of next month.

headline: More Layoffs At Electric Boat
abstract: The Electric Boat unit of the General Dynamics Corporation said today that it would lay off 2,000 workers in Connecticut over the next four months, expanding  planned cutbacks as submarine work continues to shrink.         The maker of the Seawolf submarine said 600 workers would be dismissed next week and the rest would go by August. The company had previously said it would lay off 1,500 workers in Connecticut as part of a plan to cut 3,200 jobs this year.

headline: Radio Is Trying to Court Youngsters and Advertisers
abstract: Heather Hogan is a full-speed-ahead chatterbox of a 14-year-old who does not  yet know what she wants to do for a career. But she already has the kind of corporate title many might envy.         Ms. Hogan is "vice president of fun" at the Children's Broadcasting Corporation here, as well as a popular part-time D.J. at WWTC-AM, the flagship station of the corporation's fledgling children's radio network.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;New campaigns by Dunkin' Donuts and Wendy's use familiar faces to build loyalty.
abstract: TWO familiar advertising figures and a politician turned product peddler are  featured in new pitches for consumer brands that epitomize the appeal of continuing characters in marketers' campaigns.         Fred, the diligent Dunkin' Donuts baker who dutifully drives himself with the mantra "Time to make the doughnuts," is branching out as that company begins adding bagels to its menu of baked goods. In commercials by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, Fred visits New York for focus-group interviews, seeking opinions from picky local bagel noshers. In addition to the  requisite cab drivers and cops, Fred, portrayed by Michael Vale, encounters Edward I. Koch, the former Mayor who has developed a post-political career as an advertising star.

headline: Oneok Adds to Properties
abstract: The Oneok Resources Company said today that it had bought all of Scana Petroleum Resource Inc.'s oil and gas properties in Oklahoma for $46.7 million.  The purchase includes more than 500 producing oil and natural gas sites, according to Oneok Resources, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Oneok Inc.,  which is based in Tulsa. Scana Petroleum's parent company, the Scana Corporation, is based in Columbia, S.C. The purchase was financed by cash on hand and proceeds from a recent sale of oil and gas reserves in Alabama and Mississippi.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Santander Buys Stake In Chile's Banco Osorno
abstract: Banco Santander S.A., Spain's largest commercial bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 51 percent stake in Banco Osorno y La Union for $495 million in a merger that would create Chile's largest private bank. Santander plans to merge the bank, Chile's fourth largest, with Banco Santander-Chile, creating a financial institution with $7.9 billion in assets and a combined market value of $1.7 billion, the banks said in a joint statement. On Wednesday, the banks had said they were completing an agreement.          Santander agreed to pay $17 an American depository share, or $495 million, for the stake in Osorno. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, trading of American depository receipts fell 12.5 cents, to $15.375. Under the agreement, Santander will hold a 74.7 percent stake in the merged bank, which will be called Banco Santander-Chile.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;From Ancient Rome to Little Bo Peep
abstract: Forming an ambitious project that would use broadcasting, computers, the Internet and virtual-reality technology, Atlantic Productions, a television-documentary company, is joining with Sun Microsystems and Industrial  Light and Magic to develop multimedia re-creations of great civilizations of the past.         Anthony Geffen, chief executive of a newly formed company called Atlantic Networks, said yesterday that the partnership, which he said would soon include  a number of other members, would develop a series of eight-hour documentaries, relying on advancing computer technology from Sun to reproduce three-dimensional re-creations of Roman, Greek, Egyptian, and Chinese civilizations first on film, then on everything from CD-ROM's to museum exhibits to virtual-reality games.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Air France Posts Loss Of $580 Million for Year
abstract: Air France said yesterday that it lost 2.9 billion francs ($580 million) in the year that ended March 31 after recording a huge one-time charge. But it also reported its first operating profit, 413 million francs, since 1989.          The airline set aside just under 2 billion francs to pay for severance packages for flight crews and measures related to ground staff. Last fiscal year, the company had a loss of 467 million francs. (AP)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nasdaq Stocks Advance For 10th Straight Record The Nasdaq composite index roared to its 10th consecutive record high close, matching a string of highs set in 1992. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 6.14 points, to 5,575.22, while the Nasdaq jumped 9.14 points to end at 1,199.66.

headline: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
abstract: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.      To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Examines Competition in Snack Industry
abstract: The Justice Department said yesterday that it had begun a preliminary investigation of possible anti-competitive practices in the salty-snack industry, a $14 billion business.         Gina Talamona, a spokeswoman for the department, declined to say which company or companies might be the primary target of the investigation.

headline: RJR Nabisco Still Pressured For a Spinoff
abstract: Only hours after a Federal appeals panel dismissed a huge class action lawsuit last week that had been the principal legal nightmare facing the nation's cigarette makers, the financier Bennett S. LeBow was again calling for  the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to immediatly spin off its food company from its tobacco operations.         While Mr. LeBow and his ally, Carl C. Icahn, were defeated last month in an attempt to elect their slate of RJR Nabisco directors, the two dissident shareholders have not gone away, and neither has the push for a spinoff.

headline: Why This Matzoh Is Different From All Others: It's Moscow's
abstract: Keep calm!" shouted Alla Nazarova as she barred the surging crowed from the  door. Her plea meant nothing to the scores of people, all with rubles clenched in their fists, who were standing in line.         "I've worked here for five years," said the breathless Mrs. Nazarova, who runs the food supply store in Moscow's largest synagogue. "I've never seen it like this. Yesterday we sold three and a half tons of it."

headline: World News Briefs;Ukraine's Parliament Adopts Constitution
abstract: Ukraine's Parliament has adopted the country's first post-Soviet Constitution after months of resistance from Communist lawmakers. Approval of the measure came in a 315-36 vote that ended a dramatic 23-hour session on Friday.
