The Communists, who form the largest faction in Parliament, had opposed the proposed constitution, resisting provisions that allowed private ownership of land and factories. They also demanded that the Russian language have equal status with Ukrainian.         The Communists and their allies command about 170 votes in the 450-seat Parliament; passage of the constitution required a two-thirds majority, or 301 votes.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                 May 24    May 17    May 26                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.6       7.8       8.0 Distillate production, daily                  3.3       3.3       3.2 Gasoline stocks                             204.8     204.9     209.5 Distillate stocks                            94.8      90.4     115.1 Crude imports, daily                          7.0       7.8       7.0 Product imports, daily                        2.0       1.7       1.3 Crude stocks                                297.8     295.2     326.5 Crude production, daily                       6.4       6.4       6.6 Refinery utilization (%)                     94.6      92.2      95.2

headline: 3 Swiss Slain in Burundi
abstract: Three Swiss Red Cross workers were ambushed and shot to death today in Burundi, said a spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross.          The attack was on a vehicle in which the men were riding as they delivered water and medical supplies to hospitals in northern Burundi, said the spokesman, Tony Burgener.

headline: Czech Center-Right Coalition Loses Its Majority
abstract: The center-right coalition of Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus narrowly lost its parliamentary majority, according to unofficial election results released today.         In the balloting, the first since the Czech Republic split from Slovakia in 1993, voters did not follow the lead of some other former Soviet-bloc countries in returning former Communists to power, but the results nevertheless  indicate that many voters are questioning the direction and pace of free-market  reforms.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;France Succeeds In a Privatization
abstract: The French Government said today that the sale of the insurer A.G.F., the country's first large privatization of 1996, had been a success.         The Government expects to reap 9 billion francs, or $1.7 billion, from the sale of its 57 percent stake in the insurer, whose full name is Assurances Generales de France.

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 152.33 points, or almost seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,441.72. On Friday, the Nikkei index climbed 206.99 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: A Sweetheart Becomes Suspect;Looking Behind Those Kathie Lee Labels
abstract: Two months ago, a labor activist pulled a thread and Kathie Lee Gifford's storybook life began to unravel.         Overnight, the effervescent co-host of "Live With Regis and Kathie Lee," was  branded a pariah after Charles Kernaghan, executive director of the National Labor Committee Education Fund in Support of Worker and Human Rights in Central America, told Congress on April 29 that her clothing line was being made by 13- and 14-year-olds working 20-hour days in factories in Honduras.

headline: Nikkei Hits 4-Year High
abstract: Stocks continued their surge today, trading above the 22,000 barrier for the  first time since February 1992. After climbing as high as 22,077.87 in early trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 14.87 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,868.17. On Monday, the Nikkei closed at 21,883.04, the highest close since 22,107.12 on Feb. 7, 1992.

headline: G.E. Wins Taiwan Nuclear-Plant Contract
abstract: The General Electric Company has won a contract to supply two nuclear reactors and related equipment for Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant with a bid of $1.8 billion, the state-run Taiwan Power Company said today.         Liu Hung-chi, a deputy director of Taiwan Power, said the G.E. bid on Saturday was "lower than our base price."

headline: Companies Risk Losing Billions of Dollars, Economic Chief Says : From Beijing, a Forceful Warning
abstract: JAKARTA—  China's top economic policymaker warned Tuesday that if the United States carried out its threat to impose sanctions on Chinese goods, it risked starting a trade war that would cost American companies billions of dollars.

headline: Cali Cartel Chief Confesses
abstract: The leader of the world's most powerful drug cartel has confessed to charges  of drug trafficking in return for a reduced sentence.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;H & R Block Taps Young & Rubicam
abstract: H & R Block said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Inc. to its corporate advertising account, which was handled for 12 years by Bernstein-Rein in Kansas City, Mo. Billings were estimated at $15 million.          Jenny Lillis, media services manager at H & R Block in Kansas City, Mo., confirmed a report of the decision in the daily fax edition of Advertising Age.  She said the selection came after an two-month review that had been narrowed to  Y.& R. Chicago and four other finalists: the Leo Burnett USA unit of the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago; Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, which is owned  by its top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies; DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of the Omnicom Group, and the Publicis/Bloom Dallas unit of Publicis S.A. The Y.& R. office in Sydney handles the H & R Block account in Australia.

headline: CRASH IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;COMMERCE SECRETARY AMONG 33 LOST IN A CROATIA PLANE CRASH
abstract: A military plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and a delegation of American corporate executives slammed into a mountainside today as it approached the airport at Dubrovnik, on the Adriatic coast of Croatia. Chances that Mr. Brown had survived were "next to zero," a White House official said after more than 12 hours of rescue efforts.         Clambering over rocky, rugged terrain, working by flashlight in pelting rain, Croatian search parties found nine bodies and one survivor, described by a Dubrovnik doctor at the scene as "a woman who was bleeding profusely." She died  later, Croatian officials said.

headline: In an Amazon Cave, Light Is Shed on Early Americans
abstract: Digging in a cave near the Amazon River in Brazil, archeologists have found stone weapons, rock paintings and other traces of what may have been one of the  earliest human cultures in the Americas. The discovery could revise thinking --  and stir more controversy -- about the lives and migrations of the first Americans.         The excavations yielded evidence that the ancient Americans who regularly camped in the cave led lives distinct from the big-game hunters who roamed the plains and hills of western North America at the same time, about 11,000 years ago. These Amazonian people lived off the fruits and nuts and small game of the  tropical forest and took fish and turtles from the river.

headline: After a Battle, Israel Swears In A New Cabinet
abstract: Though still battling with key political associates over the final shape of his Cabinet, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his ministers were sworn in today as Israel's new Government.         Mr. Netanyahu, 46, tried in his inaugural speech to put the focus of the day  on the rise of a generation born after the establishment of the Jewish state. But the attention of the new Parliament and the nation was riveted on an 11th-hour power struggle with Ariel Sharon, a hard-liner and one of the Likud Party's most influential figures.

headline: Bosnia Hit-Squad Reports Chided as Effort to Halt Aid for Army
abstract: Opponents of a United States effort to equip and train the Bosnian Army are conspiring to block the program by spreading stories about assassination teams and Iranian troops, Bosnia's delegate to the United Nations said here today.         "There are some who don't like 'equip and train' within the region, within Europe and even within the United States," the delegate, Mohamed Sacirbey, said  today in a reference to the program. He implied that Russia and NATO allies of the United States in Europe were jealous of growing American influence in the Balkans.

headline: Farmers in a Poor Region of Russia Long for Stability and OpposeYeltsin
abstract: The idea of owning a private farm is just a passing fancy for Anatoly F. Gorda.         His socks are frayed. He smokes the cheapest brand of cigarettes from Rostov. And Mr. Gorda, a veterinarian who continues to work on the collective farm here  that in Soviet days was called Red Star, says he has no idea how he could afford the tractors and other equipment to till the soil.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;McGraw-Hill Settles Suit on Book Reselling
abstract: The McGraw-Hill Companies said today that it had reached an undisclosed settlement with seven used-book brokers and wholesalers accused of reselling used McGraw-Hill textbooks scheduled for destruction.         The settlement ends a lawsuit that McGraw filed in United States District Court in Newark last June against 20 used-book dealers and destruction companies. The company has already reached settlements with the other defendants. The defendants admitted no wrongdoing.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRONET TO BUY TELETOUCH COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Pronet Inc., a wireless communications company, said yesterday that it would  acquire Teletouch Communications Inc. for common stock worth about $75 million and the assumption of about $91 million in Teletouch debt. Pronet also would buy about $15 million of the company's preferred stock. Shareholders of Teletouch, based in Tyler, Tex., will receive about $5.50 in Pronet stock for each share of stock held. Pronet said the acquisition would create the fourth-largest public paging company in the United States, with about 1.4 million subscribers. Pronet, based in Plano, Tex., plans to manage the Teletouch operations through its Houston and Charlotte, N.C., centers. Pronet stock fell $1, to $27.625, and Teletouch rose 43.8 cents, to $5.125.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Growth Forecast Is Cut By German Institutes
abstract: Germany's six leading economic research institutes slashed their forecasts yesterday for economic growth in 1996 to three-quarters of 1 percent from the 2.5 percent they predicted six months ago. The institutes also criticized the Bonn Government, saying its drive to cut spending and qualify for the single European currency could limit any recovery.   (Reuters)

headline: NEW JERSEY DEAL TO TIE BIG INSURER WITH BLUE CROSS
abstract: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest health insurer in New Jersey, with 1.9 million enrollees, has agreed to join forces with a big Midwestern company that is one of the nation's largest health insurers, people with knowledge of the deal said last night.         The deal would link the New Jersey insurer, which is struggling to finance the costly expansion into managed care, with a company whose publicly traded subsidiary can raise money through the stock market. That company, the Anthem Group, is based in Indianapolis and already owns Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky.

headline: Real Estate;A development of mansions -- around a Nicklaus golf course -- rises in Westchester estate country.
abstract: WHEN Tokio Kasuga looked for a huge property close to New York City to develop, it was the height of the real estate boom. By the time the right place  -- for a championship golf course surrounded by mansions -- was found, a recession had set in.

headline: ISRAELI AIRCRAFT STRIKE GUERRILLAS IN BEIRUT SUBURBS
abstract: Charging that Party of God guerrillas in Lebanon had gone too far in their shelling of northern Israel, Israel today sent planes, helicopters and gunships  deep into Lebanon to strike at the group. The raids included the first attack on Beirut since the 1982 invasion of Lebanon.         In the most audacious attack, four Israeli Apache helicopters invaded Beirut  under overcast skies at 10:30 A.M. and fired on the Party of God headquarters in the ground floor of a high-rise building in the city's southern slums.

headline: Asian Aliens Now Smuggled From Mexico
abstract: In a case that American officials said highlights a new trend in trafficking  illegal immigrants through Mexico, authorities have broken up an organization that smuggled hundreds of undocumented Asians into the United States along a pipeline through Russia, Cuba and Central America.         The Chinese, Indian and Pakistani migrants paid up to $28,000 each to smugglers for a grueling clandestine journey that climaxed in this border city when teen-agers ferried them in inner tubes north across the Rio Grande to a muddy floodplain south of McAllen, Texas, United States officials said.

headline: Merger Plans Spur Stocks; Dow Rises 50.58
abstract: A couple of multibillion-dollar mergers helped drive stock prices upward yesterday, with all three major indicators advancing together for the first time in almost a week.         The Dow Jones industrial average gained 50.58 points, to 5,637.72, ending near its high of the day. Among the broader indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks added 8.23 points, to 653.73, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.17 points, to 1,106.57.

headline: Humana Sees Weak Profit This Quarter; Stock Drops
abstract: Shares of Humana Inc. fell 18 percent yesterday after the company cut its second-quarter earnings forecast, saying an unexpectedly large number of patients in its health plans had visited hospitals and medical specialists.         Humana, an operator of managed health care plans, also said it was considering revamping or even closing 10 recently acquired health plans that are losing money.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IVAX SEES DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS FOR SECOND QUARTER
abstract: The Ivax Corporation said yesterday that it expected earnings for the second  quarter to fall "significantly short" of recent periods because of price cuts and the sluggish pace of reorders for its generic drugs. Ivax stock plunged $8.625, to $15.25, on volume of more than 11.9 million shares. Ivax said that some customers had established significant inventories of its drugs and that it  had cut some prices. As a result, earnings for the Miami company before any special one-time costs would be between 6 cents and 8 cents a share in the quarter ending on Sunday, the company said. In the comparable period of 1995, Ivax earned 24 cents a share.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson Says Mindscape Will Have Loss in 1996
abstract: Pearson P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that its Mindscape unit would lose L46 million ($69 million) in 1996, most of it in the first half. The announcement follows a larger-than-expected L6.9 million loss in 1995 at Mindscape, a software business in Novato, Calif. "The losses at Mindscape will inevitably cast a shadow over the first-half-year's performance," Lord Blakenham, Pearson's chairman, warned in a statement before the annual shareholder meeting.          Shares in Pearson, which owns The Financial Times and Penguin, the book publisher, closed down 17 pence at 678.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: G.I.'s to Provide Security for War Crimes Investigators in Bosnia
abstract: As many as 200 American peacekeeping troops have been assigned to provide security to international war crimes investigators looking into the suspected massacre of thousands of Muslims in the eastern town of Srebrenica by Bosnian Serb military leaders, American military officials said today.         The investigation in Srebrenica, the first of its kind in the peacekeeping zone patrolled by American soldiers, is scheduled to begin on Tuesday, and could carry some risks for the American forces.

headline: Boston Chicken Is Purchasing Franchisee
abstract: Boston Chicken Inc. said today that it would acquire a 93 percent interest in Mid-Atlantic Restaurant Systems L.P., one of its franchisees, in a deal valued at about $79 million.         Mid-Atlantic Restaurant Systems, of Westchester, Pa., operates 78 Boston Market stores, the name under which Boston Chicken now operates its restaurants, in four states and expects to have 100 stores by the end of the year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;APPLE NAMES LANDI AS EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT
abstract: Apple Computer Inc. yesterday named Marco Landi, an Apple executive in Europe, to the post of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Mr. Landi, 52, is currently president of Apple Computer Europe, Middle East and Africa. He plans to assume his new position on June 1, overseeing four newly formed product divisions, worldwide sales, marketing and manufacturing operations. Analysts said Mr. Landi would be a welcome addition to the management team because of his solid reputation in Europe and his familiarity with the company and its woes.

headline: Croatia Arrests a Bosnian Croat Accused of War Crimes
abstract: The Croatian police announced today the arrest of a Bosnian Croat charged by  the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague with the murder and mistreatment of Muslim prisoners.         Zlatko Aleksovski, one of nine Bosnian Croats indicted by the tribunal, was arrested on Saturday near the coastal city of Split, according to a statement by the Croatian Ministry of Justice. It was the first arrest by the Croatian authorities of someone charged with war crimes.

headline: Israel Meets With U.S., but Sticks to Stance
abstract: Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met yesterday in Jerusalem to try to repair relations between the Clinton Administration and the new Israeli Government.         They spoke warmly about their shared desire for peace, while tiptoeing over their sharp disagreements on how to get there.

headline: Colombia's Leader, Cleared by Congress, Still Isn't in the Clear
abstract: Although Congress has cleared President Ernesto Samper of charges that Cali drug dealers financed his election, the Colombian leader faces an uncertain future. The threat of impeachment has been lifted, but calls for his resignation remain.         The 111-to-43 vote late Wednesday night supported the 45-year-old President by a greater margin than expected. But rather than strengthening his hand, it underscored the gap between opinions in Congress and among the public. Polls show that a majority of Colombians believe the President is guilty, though they  divide evenly on whether he should step down.

headline: Israel Says Lebanese Bomber Caused Blast in Jerusalem Hotel
abstract: A man seriously wounded while he was handling explosives in a hotel room in East Jerusalem last month was identified today as a would-be suicide bomber for  Hezbollah, the Party of God, the authorities said.         Internal Security Minister Moshe Shahal said the man, Hussein Mohammed Hussein Miqdad, from the Lebanese village of Faroun, "was motivated by Iranian money and Iranian officials who sent him to try and undermine the peace process  and to explode in Jerusalem."

headline: Remaking Sony, Bit by Bit
abstract: AS the sky darkened behind Cinderella's Castle, Nobuyuki Idei, president of the Sony Corporation, stood on a stage at Tokyo Disneyland, flanked by Mickey Mouse, Goofy and a host of other characters.         "Did you have fun?" Mr. Idei shouted to the crowd below, thrusting his arm forward as if leading a charge. But the 20,000 Sony employees and family members, who had been given the day off and free tickets to the amusement park to celebrate Sony's 50th birthday on May 7, remained silent. "Did you have fun?" Mr. Idei shouted again, and then again, until the crowd finally roared its approval.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Coca-Cola USA Picks 2 Agencies
abstract: The Coca-Cola USA division of the Coca-Cola Company has named Highway One Communications in San Francisco, an affiliate of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles,  and Block & Nardizzi in Stamford, Conn. to handle a variety of promotional marketing campaigns. Billings were not disclosed.          Ben Deutsch, a spokesman for Coca-Cola in Atlanta, confirmed a report of the appointments this week in Adweek. The decision came after a review that had been narrowed to Highway One, Block & Nardizzi and four other finalists: Einson Freeman in Paramus, N.J., a unit of the WPP Group; Frankel & Company in Chicago; the Flair Communications Agency in Chicago, and McCracken Brooks Communications  in Minneapolis, which is owned by BDDP Worldwide.

headline: Paris Journal;At Dinner Table, More Than Beef Falls From Grace
abstract: Mad cow disease may be changing menus and habits throughout Europe, but in France, beef is not the only thing that is disappearing from the table.         The French eat less daily bread and not even a quarter of them drink wine daily with meals any more, as their way of life becomes more hurried, more health-conscious, and, well, more like life everywhere else, including the United States.

headline: Top Editor Will Leave Magazine
abstract: Andrew Sullivan, the editor of The New Republic, announced yesterday that he  would step down from his post at the end of May.         Mr. Sullivan, who has edited the magazine since October 1991, said that he wanted to concentrate on writing, and that he had signed a contract with Alfred  A. Knopf to deliver a book on friendship. He will continue to write for the magazine as a senior editor.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO BUY ADDINGTON
abstract: Republic Industries, headed by H. Wayne Huizenga, agreed yesterday to acquire Addington Resources Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $322 million at Thursday's closing stock price. Republic, which provides waste management and electronic security services, will exchange 0.45 of a share for each of Addington's 15.2 million outstanding shares.  Shares of both Republic and Addington rose sharply yesterday in Nasdaq trading. Addington stock was up $3.50, or nearly 21 percent, at $20.50 a share, while Republic stock was up $4.8125 at $52. Addington is a waste-management company based in Ashland, Ky. It expects to post revenue of about $65 million to $70 million for its current fiscal year, while Republic has annual revenue of about $346 million.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LORAL TO SPIN OFF SPACE AND COMMUNICATIONS UNIT
abstract: The Loral Corporation said yesterday that it would spin off Loral Space and Communications Ltd. on the expiration date of the Lockheed Martin Corporation's  $9.1 billion offer to acquire most of Loral. Investors will get one share of Loral Space for every share of Loral they hold before April 22, the company said. The distribution of Loral Space shares is subject to the completed purchase by Lockheed Martin of two-thirds of Loral's 180 million outstanding shares for $38 a share. Lockheed Martin will also pay $344 million, or $7.50 a share, for a 20 percent stake in Loral Space, which will be traded on the New York Stock Exchange beginning April 20.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: USA Waste to Buy Sanifill for $1.2 Billion The consolidation in garbage hauling continued as USA Waste Services said it would merge with Sanifill in a deal worth $1.3 billion plus the assumption of debt. The new company, which will retain the USA Waste name, expects to have revenue of about $1.3 billion a year.

headline: Market Place;One epilogue to the budget crisis: free money for the Treasury.
abstract: THIS is a tale of how the Government managed to borrow $492 million from 23,000 American savers for nine days without paying a dime of interest to them,  while more sophisticated investors got interest on their money.         It wasn't something that anyone wanted to happen. But it came about as a result of the squabbling between Congress and the President about raising the debt ceiling at the end of March. The result was a nine-day delay in the regular monthly auctions for two-year and five-year Treasury notes.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                 Apr 12     Apr 5    Apr 14                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.5       7.3       7.6 Distillate production, daily                  3.1       3.1       3.2 Gasoline stocks                             201.6     201.8     212.1 Distillate stocks                            89.4      88.8     114.4 Crude imports, daily                          7.6       6.8       6.5 Product imports, daily                        2.2       1.5       1.0 Crude stocks                                300.8     301.0     336.0 Crude production, daily                       6.5       6.5       6.6 Refinery utilization (%)                     92.1      91.2      91.0

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Wage Talks Go to Arbitration
abstract: Wage talks collapsed yesterday between the German Government and the nation's largest public-sector union, sending the matter to arbitration. Union officials  rejected as too meager the Government's offer to raise wages one-half of 1 percent through April of next year and another 1 percent in the rest of 1997.          The impasse ended the fourth and final round of negotiations, sending the matter to a three-week arbitration period. Arbitration is expected to begin at the end of next week, although dates are not yet set. Under arbitration, both sides must meet to discuss the arbiter's proposals. Neither side is obligated to accept the proposals.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: World News Briefs;Nazi War Crimes Witness Hurt in Jump From Hotel
abstract: A former Nazi officer broke his pelvis today after jumping 15 feet from a second-story hotel terrace in an apparent effort to flee before he was to testify against another SS officer accused of war crimes in World War II.         The witness, Karl Hass, 84, a major in occupied Rome, arrived from Switzerland on Thursday to testify for the prosecution against Erich Priebke, accused of taking part in the killing of 335 civilians outside Rome in 1944.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PACE INDUSTRIES BEING BOUGHT BY LEGGETT & PLATT
abstract: Leggett & Platt Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the aluminum die-cast component maker Pace Industries for 5.2 million shares of common stock, valued at $118 million, and the assumption of about $200 million in debt. Leggett, a maker of components for home furnishings and other products based in Carthage, Mo., said that it expected to take a charge of $34 million, or 38 cents a share, in the second quarter in connection with the deal. Pace Industries, based in Fayetteville, Ark., makes aluminum gas-barbecue grill housings and exterior lighting and electric motor components.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cliff Freeman Wins Top Ad Club Award
abstract: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York has taken top honors, winning the Grandy Award as well as the most awards, at the 32d annual International Andy Awards presentation for creativity sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.         At a ceremony last night, Freeman, which is owned by Cordiant P.L.C., won the $50,000 Grandy Award, along with five Andys, for a campaign for the Prodigy Services Company, a joint venture of I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck & Company. Freeman won three more Andys for a campaign for the Little Caesars pizza chain and four Awards of Distinction.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: * U.S. Gold Inc., San Francisco, a subsidiary of Centre Gold P.L.C., to Ciociola & Co., New York, to introduce three video games: Olympic Summer Games, Olympic Soccer and Dream Team Basketball. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: Store Chief in Japan To Quit in Payoff Case
abstract: The president of Japan's largest department store operator said yesterday that he would resign after company executives were arrested on charges of paying gangster extortionists. The executive, Hiroshi Hidaka of the Takashimaya Company, said he ''feels responsibility'' over the scandal involving payments to ''sokaiya,'' racketeers who blackmail companies by threatening to disrupt their annual meetings.

headline: Reluctantly, Arab Parties Favor Peres
abstract: Israel's 850,000 Arab citizens can recite ample reasons for displeasure with  the Government of Shimon Peres, including the bombardment of Arab civilians in neighboring Lebanon, the cutoff of West Bank Arabs from their jobs in Israel, and the crackdown on Arab settlements suspected of harboring terrorists.         But today three of four Arab political parties in Israel encouraged their followers to swallow their misgivings and vote for Mr. Peres in next week's elections to prevent a victory by hawks who would dim the prospects of a peace settlement and a Palestinian state.

headline: Market Place;Without an economic cycle, those high-flying cyclical stocks may be in for a hard landing.
abstract: INVESTORS in cyclical stocks have already discovered significant relief from  the recent slide in the stock market. Although the broader market has fallen nearly 3 percent since its peak in mid-February, cyclical stocks have withstood  much of the turbulence. So far this year the Morgan Stanley Cyclical Index has climbed 13 percent, compared with a 5 percent gain for the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index.         Because the economic picture has improved, the fortunes of cyclical companies like Caterpillar, Ford Motor and Union Carbide, which typically move in tandem with the general economy, have brightened considerably. Wall Street strategists  have gone from predicting a possible recession to arguing about how fast the economy is growing.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Johnson Worldwide Reinforces Agency
abstract: Johnson Worldwide Associates, a marketer of sporting goods in Sturtevant, Wis., said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis by naming that agency to handle advertising for  its camping division and its Minn Kota line of trolling motors and marine accessories. Those accounts, in which the billings have not been determined, had been handled by Baxter Advertising in Minneapolis. Carmichael Lynch, which handles several Johnson fishing products brands, was awarded the new assignments without a review.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Discloses Plan To Keep Itself Afloat
abstract: Alitalia, Italy's national airline, said yesterday that it would split its operations in two and cut its work force in an effort to stay afloat. The revamping plan, the third by Alitalia in two years, was approved by the state holding company IRI, which controls the airline.         Alitalia said the five-year plan would involve the airline being divided into two, with one unit handling the group's long-haul flights and the other running  the remaining operations. Under the rescue plan, 2,833 jobs will be cut out of a total payroll of 18,000. The company ended 1995 with its eighth loss in a row  and debts totaling $2.85 billion.   (Reuters)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After Ford takes a greater hand, Mazda consolidates its ad account in Japan.
abstract: IN a departure from the usual practice in Japan, the Mazda Motor Corporation  has chosen to concentrate all its advertising with Hakuhodo Inc., Japan's No. 2  agency behind Dentsu Inc.         Generally, Japanese auto makers use different agencies for different models;  Mazda had had its account at Dentsu and two other shops. The decision to consolidate the account appears to be guided by the Ford Motor Company, which took effective control of the financially ailing Mazda this month and is trying  to turn it around, in part by adopting some American practices.

headline: Deal for Newspaper Sales
abstract: The American Publishing Company, a unit of Hollinger International Inc., has  agreed to buy The Tribune-Democrat in Johnstown, Pa., a 47,000 circulation daily, from Garden State Newspapers. At the same time, American Publishing will  sell several of its daily and weekly papers to Garden State. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The Hollinger dailies being sold to Garden State are The North Adams Transcript in North Adams, Mass.; The Bridgeton Evening News in Bridgeton, N.J.; The Sterling Journal Advocate, The Fort Morgan  Times and The Lamar Daily News, all in Colorado; and The Sidney Telegraph, in Sidney, Neb.

headline: Sumitomo Stockholders Create Big Fund to Help Cover Losses
abstract: Stockholders of the Sumitomo Corporation approved a company plan here today to cover losses in what Sumitomo has described as unauthorized transactions over more than a decade by its chief copper trader.         Acting at the company's annual meeting, the shareholders approved the establishment of a fund of 150 billion yen, or about $1.4 billion, to help cover the losses, which the company has estimated as $1.8 billion. They also voted to  cancel plans for a buyback of company stock.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Angotti, a small fish swallowed by a bigger fish, promises not to lose its allure.
abstract: ANOTHER independent agency has succumbed to the blandishments of a global giant as Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, a New York shop known for stylish, witty creative work for clients like Saab, agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies.         Angotti, which was founded in 1985, has 110 employees and billings of $150 million from accounts that also include Fuji Photo Film U.S.A. and PCS Primeco,  the wireless communications services company owned by Airtouch Communications, the Bell Atlantic Corporation, the Nynex Corporation and the U S West Media Group.

headline: Debate at Home Mirrors One on TV
abstract: There were two debates at the Ellenblum home tonight. One, on television, was between Prime Minister Shimon Peres and his Likud challenger, Benjamin Netanyahu. And one, in the living room, was between Ronnie Ellenblum and his mother-in-law.         "Netanyahu made a much better impression than Peres," said Doris Lankin, the  mother of Mr. Ellenblum's wife, Lenore. "He answered Peres without all this dreamy Middle East fantasy."

headline: Goldman-Rockefeller Merger Is Delayed
abstract: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. and a group of investors led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller agreed to extend by one month to May 31 the closing of their $1.2 billion merger.         The company, which owns the $1.3 billion mortgage on New York landmark Rockefeller Center, also said the Goldman-Rockefeller group would lend it $1.7 million to cover expenses until the merger closed.

headline: SPENDING IT;Schwab Flexes Muscles And Takes On Insurers
abstract: MUTUAL fund companies that stood by as Charles Schwab & Company swept into their business might have a word for the nation's big insurance companies -- beware.         With its trademark low commissions, Schwab recently began selling certain types of life insurance in California, and it plans to expand to all 50 states by the end of the year. Because of its national franchise and deep pockets, Schwab has the potential to become as big a force in the low-commission insurance market as it has in the no-load mutual fund world.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS TO CONSIDER SALE
abstract: The stock of Cellular Communications of Puerto Rico Inc. jumped almost 15 percent yesterday after the company said it would review various strategies, including a sale or merger of the company. The company, which owns and operates  cellular telephone systems in Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands,  said no decision had been made to pursue any particular alternative. Cellular Communications shares rose $4, to $31.25, in Nasdaq trading. The company's current market capitalization is $400 million.

headline: U.K. Probes Huge Losses By Japan Copper Trader
abstract: LONDON—  Britain's Serious Fraud Office announced Friday that it had opened an investigation into $1.8 billion in losses that the Sumitomo Corp. said it had suffered as a result of unauthorized trades by its chief copper trader in Tokyo.

headline: DEATH IN LEBANON: ISRAEL;Voicing Regret, Israeli Leader Offers a Cease-Fire
abstract: Prime Minister Shimon Peres expressed regret today over the deaths of at least 75 Lebanese civilians in an Israeli artillery strike and said Israel was prepared to accept an immediate cease-fire if its Islamic guerrilla opponents did too.         But Mr. Peres defiantly insisted that Hezbollah guerrillas had provoked the attack on a United Nations base where the civilians were seeking shelter. He said Israel responded to guerrilla fire from near the base, not knowing that it  was packed with civilian refugees.

headline: Uunet and MFS Plan to Merge As Internet Meets Fiber Optics
abstract: The MFS Communications Company, the largest provider of high-speed telephone  and data services to businesses, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Internet service provider Uunet Technologies in an exchange of stock valued  at $2 billion.         Analysts said the proposed acquisition, which was approved unanimously by the boards of both companies, underscored the rising importance of the Internet as a business communications medium. The deal would also create a new type of telecommunications company, one that will be able to link national and international companies with high-speed telephone, Internet and video transmissions.

headline: No Headline
A Purchase by I.B.M.
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Wilkerson Group, a pharmaceutical and medical products industry consulting firm. Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. Wilkerson Group, which is based in New York, has a client base that includes international pharmaceutical, biotechnology, supply, device and diagnostic companies.

headline: Stock Prices Fall in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks were down slightly here at midday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 50.34 points, two-tenths of 1 percent, to 22,616.46. On Wednesday, the Nikkei was up 69.63 points.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: * William C. Lyddan was named president of Brouillard Communications, New York,  a unit of the WPP Group, succeeding Stephen Cody, who resigned. Mr. Lyddan had been executive vice president and new business director at Campbell Mithun Esty, Minneapolis, owned by top management and the Interpublic Group of Cos. Also, James A. Gray 3d was named to the vacant position of president for public relations; he had been executive vice president and worldwide client services director at Manning, Selvage & Lee, Atlanta, a unit of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.

headline: Political Pact With Ex-Film Star May Bring Down India's Premier
abstract: Since Indira Gandhi was assassinated more than a decade ago, no woman has had a deeper impact on the political consciousness of India than a former movie actress, Jayalalitha Jayaram, who leapt in the early 1990's from a past playing  a courtesan in a score of low-budget films to heading the government of a state  with 60 million people.         Few Indian politicians have evoked the frenzy that accompanied her tours of the southern state of Tamil Nadu in the early period after she was elected Chief Minister in 1991. Men and women swooned in her presence and crawled across public platforms to touch her feet.

headline: In Central Europe, TV News Unfolds
abstract: No matter how much the post-Communist governments in Central Europe pledge to free their state-owned television stations from political interference, old habits die hard. From Bucharest to Budapest, government-run television dominates and the programming, particularly in news, remains predictable and safe.         But privately owned stations, many operated by Western investors, are slowly  loosening the government grip, with more adventurous news shows and recently released Hollywood movies as the lever.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Elisabeth Badinter, vice president of the supervisory board at Publicis S.A., Paris, was promoted to chairwoman, succeeding Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet, her father, the founder of the agency company who died on April 11. Maurice Levy was reaffirmed as chairman, chief executive and president of the Publicis management board. John F. Varty was named senior vice president and group management supervisor heading the retail automotive division at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, Warren, Mich., a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., succeeding Nicholas Popely, who  left. Mr. Varty had held a similar post at Foote, Cone & Belding, Santa Ana, Calif., a unit of True North Communications.

headline: As Clinton Visits Changing Asia, Military Concerns Gain Urgency
abstract: After his last trip to Japan three years ago, one dominated by vicious disputes over trade, President Clinton returns on Tuesday to a changed strategic landscape, with Japan seeming a reduced economic threat, and China seeming a larger military one.         With Beijing struggling to gain respect as a great power through displays of  military prowess off Taiwan, and North Korea declaring the 1953 armistice between the Koreas dead, Asia appears more fragile, raising new questions about  the American commitment to use its power to enforce the stability required for growth and trade.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Surge on Forecast Of Cold Weekend Temperatures
abstract: Wheat prices surged yesterday after forecasters said freezing temperatures would reach winter wheat fields this weekend, adding to damage already caused by one of the driest growing seasons on record.         On other markets, corn prices also rose, helping the Commodity Research Bureau index gain 1.03 points, to 253.41, its highest level since July 25, 1988. Heating oil and crude oil fell, pushing the energy-weighted Goldman Sachs  Commodity Index to 210.83, down 0.38 point from a record high on Tuesday.

headline: Digital to Close a Plant
abstract: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that it would close a plant in Colorado Springs by the end of September. The plant, which produces information  storage products for computers, has about 250 employees. Digital Equipment, the  computer maker will offer financial support and outplacement assistance to employees who lose their job as a result of the closing. The closing is part of a plan to integrate is systems business unit.

headline: Judge Agrees To Settlement in Drug Case
abstract: A Federal judge in Chicago gave final approval yesterday to a $351.3 million  settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused the major drug companies of conspiring to deny discounts to independent pharmacists.         Under terms of the settlement, approved by District Judge Charles Kocoras, under certain conditions retail pharmacies are eligible for the same discounts on brand-name drugs that drug makers routinely give hospitals, health maintenance organizations and mail-order houses -- provided the pharmacies can show that they have the same ability as managed-care companies to affect market  share by persuading doctors and patients to switch brands.

headline: Belgium Seeks to Arrest Head of Dassault
abstract: PARIS—  Serge Dassault, heir to an aircraft dynasty and chairman of a leading French military-industrial group, was drawn into a long-running Belgian political bribery scandal Thursday when Belgium's judicial authorities announced they had issued an international arrest warrant for him.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONWIDE ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL ACTIVITY IN MARKETING
abstract: Florida regulators accused Nationwide Insurance yesterday of pressuring its agents in the state to discriminate against consumers based on age, sex, marital status, employment and other personal information. In an order sent to the company, the state's insurance commissioner, Bill Nelson, said Nationwide created a marketing program to sell unnecessary policies, exclude consumers from coverage based on where they lived and deny policies because customers were unwilling to buy additional coverage. Mr. Nelson said the marketing program was  "an illegal system of operation." The state's move resulted from complaints from some Nationwide agents. Nationwide officials declined to comment on the order, saying they had not yet reviewed it. "Nationwide has a firm corporate policy to  comply with all laws and regulations," a company spokesman, Lou Fabro, said. "It is committed to pursue that policy of compliance." Nationwide has 688,000 automobile, homeowners and commercial policies in Florida.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Compagnie de Suez Expected to Post Loss
abstract: Compagnie de Suez S.A. is expected to post a 1995 loss today of between 4 billion and 7 billion French francs ($784 million to $1.37 billion), analysts said, as unprofitable real estate holdings continue to weigh on its books. The French banking and financial services company had a loss in the first half of 3.98 billion francs. The 1995 loss by Suez would be its second in two years. In  1994, the company posted a loss of 4.78 billion francs as it made huge provisions for losses on risky real estate.          The company's chairman, Gerard Mestrallet, predicted in mid-1995 that property charges could result in a full-year loss of 4 billion francs.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In a search for innocence, advertisers are reviving songs and styles of the not-so-pure 1970's.
abstract: BARRY WHITE growls about love again, and consumers are reminded how to spell  "Y.M.C.A." Yes, the mirrored disco balls are spinning anew along Madison Avenue  in a spate of advertising that recalls the music and fashions of the 1970's.         The hit songs of that decade, along with recycled images of its fads and foibles, are turning up in campaigns for marketers as diverse as the Anheuser-Busch and Stroh breweries, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the Nissan Motor  Corporation and the Prodigy Services unit of I.B.M. and Sears, Roebuck. The artifacts include Afro hairdos, hot pants, platform shoes and, of course, those  deft disco dance steps.

headline: A Widow's Pique
abstract: Milio Azcarraga Milmo usually travels with an entourage befitting the most powerful media mogul in Mexico. With his baronial bearing and distinctive appearance -- a stripe of white hair bisects his jet-black mane -- Mr. Azcarraga lives up to his nickname, "El Tigre."         On a bright, cold morning in January, however, Mr. Azcarraga turned up alone  at the home of Mary Anselmo in Greenwich, Conn. And on that day at least, the tiger acted more like a tabby.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Awards, Awards And More Awards
abstract: The advertising awards season continues with three separate sets of honors.         Anderson & Lembke Inc. in New York took top honors, winning the most awards including the best of show, at the 18th annual Ace Awards ceremony for business-to-business communications, sponsored by the Business Marketing Association in New York.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bidding for MGM Ends; Questions Remain
abstract: Though bids for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. were due yesterday at 11:30 A.M., it was not clear whether Polygram Holdings, considered a leading bidder, had actually put in an offer.         The management of Polygram, a unit of Philips Electronics N.V., was said to be waiting until a board meeting on Thursday to actually vote on whether to make a bid. Meanwhile other bidders who did submit offers to Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banking firm handling the offer, include Morgan Creek Productions, an independent production company as well as Regency Enterprises, which is headed by the producer Arnon Milchan. Both companies distribute their films through Warner Brothers, a unit of Time Warner Inc., which is said to be willing to support either offer.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MADGE NETWORKS SHARES SINK ON WEAK PROFIT OUTLOOK
abstract: The stock of Madge Networks Inc. plunged 27 percent yesterday, a day after the maker of computer networking products warned of weak second-quarter profits. Goldman, Sachs & Company cut its 1996 and 1997 earnings estimates for the company. The stock fell $6.375, to $17.125, as 6.6 million shares were traded on the Nasdaq. Madge said yesterday that it expected softness in its second-quarter revenues, and that as a result its net income "may fall significantly below pro forma first-quarter results."

headline: LeBow Says He Lost Fight On RJR Slate
abstract: In a surprising capitulation on the day before the annual meeting of the RJR  Nabisco Holdings Corporation, Bennett S. LeBow conceded defeat yesterday on his  slate of 10 company directors.         At a news conference in Manhattan, Mr. LeBow said he had been informed by his proxy solicitors that the directors nominated by RJR Nabisco management would be elected in a very low voting turnout of the company's 450,000 shareholders.

headline: Stocks Rise in Japan
abstract: Stocks were rising here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was  up 52.95 points, or a quarter-percent, at 22,490.25 points. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 69.94 points, or 0.31 percent.

headline: INVESTING IT;Volvo Is Getting Back to Basics, Basically
abstract: MOST people think the main thing Volvo makes is cars. They are wrong. As industry experts are fond of saying, Volvo is really a leading truck producer that also happens to make cars.         But that description isn't entirely on the mark, either. Besides cars and trucks -- which at least have something in common -- the Swedish company has a jumble of other goodies under its roof, from popular Nordic beers to mobile phones and medicines. Until recently, Volvo's eclectic product line also included Borkum Riff pipe tobacco and Cricket lighters. And earlier, Volvo also  owned a major Swedish investment bank, a share of a Nordic oil field, a stake in Hertz rental cars and Abbas Seafood and other companies.

headline: In Age of Instability, a King Anchors Thailand
abstract: More than a century ago, King Mongkut of Thailand put a new spin on the monarchy, accepting the fealty of his subjects, but also pledging his own loyalty to them.         Today his great grandson, King Bhumibol Adulyadej, 68, the world's longest-serving living monarch, celebrated his 50th anniversary on the throne in a day of pomp, ritual and a nationwide outpouring of homage.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Source Media Inc., Dallas, to Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young  & Rubicam Inc., to handle marketing communications for a new interactive cable television channel. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $20 million. Fetzer Vineyards, Hopland, Calif., a unit of the Brown-Forman Corp., to Gardner, Geary, Coll & Young, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the wine marketer, previously at Carmichael Lynch, Minneapolis, which continues to handle other Brown-Forman wine brands like Korbel champagne. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million.

headline: Italian Vote Cheers the Left, but the Future Is Murky
abstract: A center-left coalition claimed a historic victory tonight in Italy's parliamentary elections, based on partial returns indicating that it would control the Senate and that it was close to winning a majority in the Chamber of Deputies.         "Italy has said 'no' to the right," said Massimo D'Alema, whose Democratic Party of the Left, formerly the Communists, is the largest component of the center-left Olive Tree coalition. "The Olive Tree has won the election based on  a program and intends to govern the country."

headline: Changing Face Of Supermarket Magazine Sales
abstract: If this were an article in a supermarket checkout magazine, the headline might read: Mag Business Blowout! Distributors Dumped As Biggies Buy Control.         This is not of the same quality, of course, as a celebrity bedroom drama or an encounter with fried-chicken-eating aliens, but the once-stodgy business of distributing magazines to supermarkets and other retail chains is in the midst of a revolution that could affect everything from the way magazines are sold to  which magazines are sold.

headline: Piltdown Man Hoaxer: Missing Link Is Found
abstract: It was one of the great hoaxes of the 20th century, bigger than the famous photograph of the Loch Ness Monster, the Hitler diaries and the mysterious crop  circles that appeared in farmers' fields, evoking thoughts of energy fields, aliens and sprites. But when the Piltdown man, a pile of bones found in Sussex and hailed in 1912 as the "missing link" in the evolutionary chain, was declared in 1953 to be an elaborate ruse, another beguiling mystery remained. Whose ruse was it?         Over the years, a good number of candidates have been proposed: Charles Dawson, the lawyer and eager amateur scientist who discovered the Piltdown bones in the first place; the novelist Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, who lived nearby and was known to have visited the site; and even the distinguished Jesuit priest and scholar Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, the prime suspect of the scientist Stephen Jay Gould.

headline: Congressmen Going to Bat For U.S. Computer Maker
abstract: Congressmen in two districts where the supercomputer maker Cray Research is a major employer have asked the White House and the National Science Foundation to help persuade a Federal weather research laboratory not to purchase a multimillion-dollar Japanese supercomputer.         In letters last week, Representatives David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, and Martin O. Sabo, Democrat of Minnesota, urged the Government to select an American supercomputer maker to protect jobs and help maintain the United States' position in the computer industry, people who have read the letters, who insisted on anonymity, said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES TO BUY TWO BOTTLING COMPANIES
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the world's largest bottler of Coca-Cola soft drinks, said yesterday that it would buy the Coca-Cola Bottling Company West and the Grand Forks Coca-Cola Bottling Company, as well as the convertible debt and  warrants of Coke West held by the Coca-Cola Company, for about $158 million. Of  the $158 million, $78 million is cash and the rest is debt. Coke West and Grand  Forks, both closely held companies that are based in Billings, Mont., had pro forma 1995 net operating revenues of about $112 million and sold 23 million cases. Coca-Cola Enterprises distributes about 57 percent of Coca-Cola's domestic output.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: David A. Bell, chairman at Bozell Worldwide, New York, was named to the additional position of chief executive, succeeding Charles D. Peebler Jr., who continues as president and chief executive of the parent, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

headline: World News Briefs;China Drug Crackdown Orders Many Executions
abstract: Hundreds of drug traffickers were believed to have been executed today as courts marked World Anti-Drugs Day by convicting 1,725 people nationwide and meting out some of their harshest sentences.         Among those convicted on the United Nations-declared day against drug abuse and trafficking, 769 were sentenced to death or life imprisonment, and many were taken immediately from the courtroom to the execution ground to be shot, the official New China News Agency said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Partners & Simons, Boston, was awarded three accounts, with combined billings estimated at $5.5 million: Saville Systems, Burlington, Mass., as the first agency to handle its account; Process Software, Framingham, Mass., previously at Harpell Martins, Concord, Mass., and Cayenne Software Inc., being formed by a merger of Bachman Information Systems, Burlington, and Cadre Technologies, Providence, R.I., to handle advertising.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;360degrees COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY CELLULAR COMPANY
abstract: The 360degrees Communications Company, the former Sprint cellular division, said yesterday that it was buying the Independent Cellular Network in a deal worth more than $500 million. 360degrees Communications, based in Chicago, said  it would assume $362 million in debt from the privately owned Independent Cellular and give the owners, the Crown family of Chicago, 6.5 million shares of 360degrees Communications common stock. At its current value, the stock would be worth $156 million. Shares of 360degrees Communications rose 25 cents, to $24.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. That would make the deal worth a combined $518 million in stock and debt assumption. The takeover would give 360  Communications 3.2 million potential new customers in Pennsylvania, Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kelly Habib Merges With Duval Woglom
abstract: Kelly Habib John Advertising in North Andover, Mass., has acquired Duval Woglom Brueckner & Partnersin Boston and merged the two agencies to form KHJ Integrated Marketing Inc. Terms were not disclosed.          KHJ has 40 employees and billings estimated at $26 million from clients that include the Bank of America and General Datacomm. Judy Habib, 40, president at Kelly Habib, and Greg John, 38, chairman and creative director there, are heading KHJ in those positions. Betsyann Duval, 52, who had been chairman at Duval Woglom, becomes a director of and consultant to KHJ, which will be in the  former Duval Woglom office in Boston.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;WPP Says Revenues Rose 10% in 4 Months
abstract: The British advertising company WPP P.L.C. said yesterday that its revenues in the first four months of 1996 were up 10 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier, with profit margins rising by more than 1 percentage point. WPP, the world's biggest advertising company, said in a brief trading update that its debt had dropped by 21 percent in the corresponding period to L166 million from L211 million a year before.   (Dow Jones)

headline: More Cuts For Prices Of Cereal
abstract: General Mills Inc., which initiated price cuts in the cereal industry two years ago, said today that it would again cut its prices, by an average of 11 percent, on such cereals as Cocoa Puffs, Trix and Lucky Charms and increase the  package sizes of some other brands.         The price cuts by General Mills, the nation's second-largest cereal maker, follow recent similar moves by the Kellogg Company, the largest cereal maker, and Philip Morris's Post Cereal, the No. 3 company. They are expected to reduce  General Mills' fiscal year 1997 earnings by about $30 million to $35 million, or about 20 cents a share.

headline: F.T.C. Sues Ciba-Geigy Over Doan's Pills
abstract: The Federal Trade Commission is suing the Ciba-Geigy Corporation and one of its subsidiaries over advertising claims that Doan's backache medicine works better than other over-the-counter pain relievers.         While Doan's costs more than other pain relievers, there is no evidence to support "Ciba's longtime advertising message -- that Doan's pills are more effective than other analgesics such as Advil or Aleve for back pain," the Bureau of Consumer Protection said.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;IPC HOLDINGS SWEETENS ITS OFFER FOR TEMPEST
abstract: IPC Holdings Ltd. said yesterday that it would increase the cash component of its $943 million offer for the Tempest Reinsurance Company after the money manager George Soros backed its bid. IPC increased the cash portion to as much as $380 million, from $275 million, nine days after a rival bidder, Ace Ltd., sweetened its own offer for the property reinsurer to $923.8 million. The IPC move comes after two funds associated with Mr. Soros -- Quantum Industrial Partners and Tivadar Charitable Lead Trust -- promised to invest as much as $40.3 million if more than 39 percent of Tempest's shareholders chose to receive cash instead of IPC stock.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: DEERE & CO., Moline, Ill., said David H. Stowe Jr., its president and chief operating officer, will retire on May 31, after 28 years with the company but will remain on the board. Hans W. Becherer, chairman and chief executive, will assume the duties and title of chief operating officer.

headline: U.S. to Reopen Trade Talks With China on Piracy Issue
abstract: The Clinton Administration said today that it would send trade negotiators to Beijing next week after the Chinese Government offered to reopen talks on Chinese piracy of American movies, music and software.         The talks are scheduled for next Thursday and Friday, a week and a half before the June 17 deadline set by the Administration for deciding whether to impose sanctions on up to $3 billion worth of Chinese imports because of the piracy issue.

headline: Gasoline Rises 6 Cents a Gallon
abstract: Gasoline prices continued to soar in April as self-serve regular rose 6 cents a gallon, to an average of $1.24, a survey by the American Automobile Association showed yesterday.         This is the highest level since January 1991, when prices were affected by the start of the Persian Gulf war.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHSOUTH AGREES TO BUY PHYSICAL THERAPY PROVIDER
abstract: The Healthsouth Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Professional Sports Care Management Inc., a provider of outpatient physical therapy, for $67  million. Healthsouth, based in Birmingham, Ala., a provider of rehabilitation services for disabled patients, said the purchase would add 36 sites to its network of 900 outpatient centers in 45 states. Professional Sports Care is based in Harrison, N.Y. Under the agreement, the company's shareholders are to receive 0.233 share of Healthsouth's common stock for each share they own. The shares of Healthsouth fell 50 cents yesterday, to $35.50, on the New York Stock  Exchange. Professional Sports Care shares rose 12.5 cents, to $7.50, in Nasdaq trading. Healthsouth said that if its stock price were to rise above $38.625 during a specified period, the exchange ratio would be adjusted.

headline: Soccer in Sarajevo: More Than a Game
abstract: There was no time to practice -- the field had just been cleared of land mines -- but the thousands of soccer fans who packed into a stadium here did not care that the teams were a little rusty.         Some 15,000 fans, many wearing team caps and scarves, several in wheelchairs, turned out today to cheer as two rival Sarajevo teams played for the first time  in four years at the ruined Grbavaca stadium.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;We Need a Ron Brown Award for Business
abstract: COMMERCE Secretary Ronald H. Brown was an extraordinarily effective ambassador for our country's business community, and he will be missed.        But we can commemorate both his life and his belief that business can be a force for good by establishing an award that would be granted -- as a parallel to the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards -- to our nation's top exporters and most thoughtful, responsible overseas investors.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Forecast of Growth in Ad Spending Is Cut for a 2d Time
abstract: Madison Avenue's leading forecaster has for a second time reduced his estimate of how much marketers will spend this year to advertise in the United States. But the reduction is small and he still expects a spending record.         Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at the McCann-Erickson U.S.A. advertising agency, said yesterday that he expected advertising spending in 1996 to total $172.8 billion. That represents an increase of 7.4 percent from his final figure for 1995 spending of $160.9 billion.

headline: Lloyd's Tells Its Investors With Losses to Pay Up or Fight
abstract: Lloyd's of London took a vital step today in its bid to stay solvent, advising money-losing investors about the size of their final bills and threatening to fight anybody who will not pay.         Lloyd's has made an offer of L3.1 billion, or $4.7 billion, to help absorb the liabilities of investors hit hard by the insurance market's staggering losses.

headline: Merrill to Curb Indiana Activity Because of Political Donation
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Company will refrain from selling securities for some Indiana agencies for two years because an official of the firm donated $1,000 to the state's Lieutenant Governor, a company spokesman said yesterday.         Merrill Lynch's decision is an effort to comply with an industry rule meant to end a practice in which underwriters of municipal securities tried to win business by making political contributions to state and local officials.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;National Geographic To Martin Agency
abstract: The National Geographic Society in Washington has named the Martin Agency in  Richmond, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle an assignment  to create a national branding and membership development program, which will run in test markets. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Martin was selected after a brief review that also included two other finalists: Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, which is owned by Cordiant P.L.C., and the Ogilvy & Mather Chicago unit of the WPP Group. Two other agencies continue on the National Geographic roster: Arnold Communications in McLean, Va., and Goldberg Marchesano Kohlman in Washington.

headline: Durable Orders Rise 1.4%, Swollen by Military Goods
abstract: Orders for big-ticket manufactured goods posted a surprising rise in March as strong demand for new aircraft more than made up for weaker new-car orders, the  Commerce Department said today.         But analysts said that without aircraft and military orders, the report on durable goods reflected moderate economic growth.

headline: Media: PRESS;Less is more as demands increase upon the publishers of stock and mutual fund tables.
abstract: MAXIM of the newspaper business is: the smaller the type, the more loyal the  readers. Publishers or editors who are skeptical of that rule need only to listen to the experience of The Day, a daily in New London, Conn.         In March, The Day cut its daily financial tables from two pages to one, eliminating hundreds of stocks and, said Anthony Cronin, deputy managing editor, eliciting "a massive amount of protest."

headline: Business Travel;Three companies introduce electronic systems that could take the pain out of filing expenses.
abstract: THE tedium of filling out expense reports could soon be just an unhappy memory, thanks to American Express, Carlson Wagonlit and Rosenbluth International. These travel management companies are introducing electronic expense reporting systems designed to make this aggravating chore less onerous.          The basic concept behind the new systems, currently available only to corporations, is that whenever travelers use credit cards their expenses are registered electronically. When trips are over and it's time to prepare expense  reports, the systems allow travelers to record cash expenses and add any explanations desired. With the click of a mouse, travelers can electronically submit their reports for approval; once that is accomplished, the reports can then be routed to accounting for payments.

headline: INVESTING IT;Will Japan's Success Soon Shine on Its U.S. Investors?
abstract: IT'S bad enough when a seemingly smart investment idea goes wrong and costs you money. But it's an even greater frustration when being right doesn't pay off.         Take, for example, Japan.

headline: In a Recount, Cyber Census Still Confounds
abstract: Millions of Internet users have vanished without a trace since last summer. Millions more have reappeared since December. And a couple of million disappeared again just yesterday, when Nielsen Media Research revised its estimates of Internet use among adults in the United States.         More than half a year after the most ambitious attempt to count the number of people using the Internet, Nielsen and its academic advisers -- looking at the same set of data -- appear to be hopelessly split on how to interpret the numbers. Depending on whom and when one asks, there were 22 million adult Americans on the Internet last August. Or 19.4 million. Or 16.4 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A $76 Million Deal For Biondi at MCA Frank J. Biondi Jr., who was dismissed as chief executive of Viacom, has negotiated many big-money deals. Not the least of them is the pay package he is  getting from his new employer, MCA; a consultant says it is worth $76 million over five years. [Page D2.]

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE NUMBERS

headline: Lucent's Initial Offering Nets Record $3.025 Billion
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc., the AT&T Corporation spinoff, sold 112 million shares at $27 each yesterday, netting it $3.025 billion in the largest initial public offering in American history.         The stock sale creates one of the world's largest independent telecommunications equipment makers. It is a key step in the plan by AT&T to divide itself into three parts in the recently deregulated and increasingly competitive telecommunications industry.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Web Magazine at a Halt And Seeking Readers' Aid
abstract: The Web Review, one of the best- known of the magazines found only on the Internet, has stopped publishing and has issued an unusual appeal for financing  that draws on two models of voluntary contributions.         Bowing to users' hostility to subscription fees on the World Wide Web, the review said that it would consider an alternative system like that of public radio, where some supporters pay and the product is free to all, or like shareware, where users who benefit from a computer program are expected to send  payments voluntarily.

headline: How to Succeed in Russia
abstract: To the Editor:         Re "For the Brave, an Open-End Russia Fund" (Mutual Funds, April 28): Having  done business in Russia for 13 years, I agree wholeheartedly with warnings given investors who focus on so-called listed, tradeable stocks. Even if the market looks attractive, in a word, I say "don't."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Paul Woolmington was named to the new post of worldwide strategic media director at Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been executive media director at Bozell Worldwide, London, and a managing director at 20/20 Media, both units of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. Coby O'Brien, vice president and creative director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Interactive, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was named senior vice president and director, assuming responsibilities from Erica Gruen, who had been senior vice president and director at the Saatchi & Saatchi Interactive Resources division before she left to join Merkley Newman Harty, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, as media services director.

headline: Market Place;Generic drug makers cope with a shift in ingredient supply.
abstract: IN 1992, big brand-name drug makers won a victory in Europe over generic drug makers that is just beginning to be felt. A ban was imposed by the European Union on shipments of active ingredients used in drugs on which the patents were about to expire. In a double whammy for generic drug makers, the ban compounded  the pharmaceutical industry's earlier success in getting patents extended for years under the GATT trade agreement.         The independent generic drug companies, most of which are in the United States, used to rely on Western Europe for 80 percent of their active ingredients. No more. As the ban has phased in, the generic companies are increasingly turning to sources outside the European Union -- in Eastern Europe, India, China, Japan and South Korea. They are also discussing joint ventures to  produce the ingredients in Mexico.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. FILTER PLANS TO BUY DAVIS WATER IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: The United States Filter Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Davis Water and  Waste Industries in a stock swap valued about $102 million. U.S. Filter, based in Palm Desert, Calif., plans to exchange 0.933 common share for each of the 3.25 million Davis Water shares. The deal values Davis Water at $31.372 a share. Davis Water's stock rose 62.5 cents yesterday, to $29.875 a share. U.S. Filter stock was unchanged at $33.625. U.S. Filter provides industrial and commercial water treatment systems and services and has annual sales of about $472 million. Davis, of Thomasville, Ga., makes water treatment and pumping equipment and had  revenues of $215 million in its 1995 fiscal year.

headline: A Bridge in Germany Becomes a Post-Cold-War Battleground
abstract: For there to have been a cold war, there had to be a Glienecke Bridge. It spanned the chasm between two hostile worlds, becoming the backdrop for dramatic spy exchanges in real life and in countless espionage novels.         Now, having lost its role as a point of escape through the Iron Curtain, Glienecke Bridge is threatened with destruction. Once the setting for great events, it is now nothing more than a traffic hazard.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: ESAB Welding and Cutting Products, Florence, S.C., a unit of Charter P.L.C., to  Sawyer Riley Compton, Atlanta, to handle its account, which had been at Hodges & Associates, Fayetteville, N.C., and the Vandine Group, Pittsburgh, a subsidiary  of Hallmark-Tassone Inc. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million. Bayer Corp. pharmaceutical division, West Haven, Conn., a unit of Bayer A.G., to Carrafiello, Diehl & Associates, Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., to handle the first  direct-to-consumer advertising for Adalat CC Extended Release Tablets, a prescription medication for hypertension. Billings were not disclosed. The agency has advertised the product to health care professionals since 1993.

headline: Debt Insurance Deal For Orange County
abstract: Orange County said today that it had taken a major step toward emerging from  bankruptcy by securing insurance for its planned recovery financings.         The county said it had obtained the commitment of the MBIA Insurance Corporation, a unit of MBIA Inc., to insure the county's planned issue of about $800 million of new debt.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iran Building Tunnels For Missiles, U.S. Says
abstract: Iran is building tunnels along its Persian Gulf coast, apparently as protective storage sites for ballistic missiles, a United States official said today.         There was not yet any evidence of missiles present in the tunnels, but the tunnels appeared to be designed for protective warehousing of missiles rather than as launch sites, said Capt. Mark D. Neuhart of the Navy, a spokesman for the United States Central Command. His remarks confirmed a report on the tunnels that first appeared this week in Jane's Defense Weekly, a London-based military  magazine.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING ANNOUNCES ANOTHER INCREASE IN JET PRODUCTION
abstract: For the second time this year, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it would increase its commercial jet production to meet higher demand. Boeing said  it would increase production of its 737 jetliners to 17 airplanes a month by the beginning of 1998. The Seattle-based Boeing now builds seven of the jets a month at its plant in Renton, Wash. Boeing shares rose $1.625, to $84.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MAKER OF ARIZONA TEA TO ADD A BEER
abstract: Ferolito, Vultaggio & Sons, the maker of the fast-growing Arizona line of teas, announced yesterday that it would introduce a beer, Mississippi Mud Black  and Tan. The beer, to be brewed by the Stroh Brewery Company of Detroit, will be a blend of a continental pilsener and a porter, and will be sold in 32-ounce jugs. Don Vultaggio, the chairman of Ferolito, Vultaggio, which is based in Lake Success, L.I., also announced five new Arizona teas, a 20-ounce nonalcoholic Arizona Pina Colada, and a malt-based margarita called Palm Beach.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Economy Rose 1.2% in First Quarter
abstract: France's economy grew strongly in the first quarter, rebounding from a decline late last year caused by a paralyzing public sector strike, according to data issued yesterday. Growth in the first three months rose 1.2 percent after slipping four-tenths of 1 percent in the final 1995 quarter, the French statistics agency said.          Growth was driven by a 2.4 percent jump in consumer spending, which was hit  hard by a strike against the Government's austerity drive. A strong export performance also contributed.   (Reuters)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Talks Continuing on Viacom Cable Channel
abstract: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., and Edgar Bronfman Jr., the  chief executive of the Seagram Corporation, met again yesterday in an effort to  resolve their differences over the introduction of Viacom's new cable channel, TVLand, according to several executives close to the talks.         Both men described the meeting as extremely amicable. One reason perhaps was  Mr. Redstone's unexpected decision on Monday to allow Frank J. Biondi Jr., whom  he had ousted as president and chief executive of Viacom in January, to become chief executive of Seagram's MCA unit, despite a one-year noncompete clause in his Viacom contract and despite the companies' differences over TVLand. Mr. Biondi was formally named to the MCA post yesterday.

headline: Cellstar Shares Tumble
abstract: The stock of the Cellstar Corporation tumbled today, a day after the company, a wholesale distributor and retailer of cellular telephones, said it might post  a first-quarter loss. The stock fell $2.50, to $6.125, on the Nasdaq. The company, based here, said Thursday that its earnings would be signicantly below  analysts' consensus estimate of $6.122 million, or 32 cents a share, for the quarter ended Feb. 29.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ABRAXAS PETROLEUM AGREES TO BUY WYOMING PROPERTIES
abstract: The Abraxas Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire natural gas producing properties in Wyoming's Great Divide Basin for $47.5 million. The properties include total estimated reserves of about 87 billion cubic feet of oil equivalent -- a combination of natural gas and oil. That amount would double the company's current average daily output. The company, an energy concern based in San Antonio, did not disclose the seller.

headline: Patents;A cold cross-country drive is the inspiration for an automated motel-clerk system for tired travelers.
abstract: A CROSS-COUNTRY drive in subzero weather inspired Carmenina Parkhurst to invent an automatic motel clerk.         "Peter and I were on our way from the West to the East and we went by the northern route," Mrs. Parkhurst said, describing a 1983 trip with her husband.
