"We were really scared that if the car stalled, we'd freeze to death, and we wanted to get into a motel until the weather changed. We kept passing motels, and every one had a 'no vacancy' sign. I ran out and looked in every window, and not one of those motels had anybody in them. It was so cold they didn't want to  be bothered.

headline: World News Briefs;Commonwealth Defers Sanctions on Nigeria
abstract: Commonwealth countries said today that they would not carry out a set of sanctions they had considered against Nigeria until the two sides had talked more about ending a seven-month crisis in relations over Nigeria's human rights  conditions.         But Commonwealth ministers, speaking after two days of talks with a delegation from the Nigerian Government, made no mention of reversing Nigeria's  suspension from the 56-nation body, which was imposed in November.

headline: Voice-Mail Venture By 4 Regional Bells
abstract: Ameritech said today that it had formed a joint venture with Bell Atlantic, Nynex and Pacific Telesis to link the regional Bell telephone companies' voice-mail systems.         The venture, called Messaging Alliance L.P., will let customers record a message once and send it to mailboxes in other systems. The service can also link fax mailboxes. Each company owns 25 percent.

headline: Eyes of the World On Israel's Election
abstract: As Israelis prepare to go to the polls on Wednesday for one of the most important elections in their history, they are finding that a lot of the world is staring over their shoulder.         Though interest in the coming Russian presidential election is at least as high, what has distinguished Israel is the degree of foreign involvement in its  campaign.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: A Mature Housing Market;A Growing Business in Not-Quite-Nursing-Home Care
abstract: Her body is diminished by age and she needs a walker to get around, but Ida Apperman's voice is as tart as when she upbraided fifth graders acting up in the rear of her Newark classroom a half-century ago.         "We felt we had imposed on our family members long enough -- it was time to get out!" Ms. Apperman snapped as six other women in their 80's seated with her  at a white-linen-covered table nodded in agreement.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OMNICARE STOCK FALLS ON WORD OF INQUIRY AT UNIT
abstract: The shares of Omnicare Inc. of Cleveland declined $4.375, to $50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said on Tuesday that Government investigators had seized records from Omnicare's Home Pharmacy Services unit. In its statement on Tuesday, Omnicare said that the Government had not informed the company of the purpose of the inquiry but that it was cooperating with it. Omnicare acquired Home Pharmacy, which is based in Belleville, Ill., in 1992. Omnicare, which provides pharmacy services to health care institutions, said the unit accounted for less than 5 percent of sales.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fallon McElligott Gains Ad Age Honor
abstract: Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis has been named the United States Agency of the Year for 1995 by the trade publication Advertising Age in its 52d annual Agency Report issue.          Fallon McElligott, which was named Agency of the Year in 1983, was honored for work for clients like BMW of North America, a unit of BMW A.G. of Germany; the Coca-Cola Company, and the Prudential Insurance Company of America. The runner-up for 1995 Agency of the Year was Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Ogilvy & Mather Rightford in Johannesburg, which is part of the WPP Group, was named International Agency of  the Year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;OSICOM TECHNOLOGIES TO ADD BUILDERS WAREHOUSE
abstract: Osicom Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Builders Warehouse Association Inc. for about $60 million in stock. Osicom, based in Santa Monica,  Calif., makes digital video switches for the telecommunications industry. Builders Warehouse, also of Santa Monica, develops advanced networking products. The deal values Builders Warehouse at $15.04 a share, based on current stock prices. Osicom plans to issue 0.94 share for each Builders Warehouse share. In trading yesterday after the news, Builders Warehouse shares slipped 25 cents to  close at $14.75, while Osicom shares dropped $1.625 to close at $15.875.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Moulinex is Shifting Production to Mexico
abstract: The French household appliance maker Moulinex S.A. said yesterday that it would cut 2,600 of its 11,300 jobs and close four French plants to transfer production to Mexico. Moulinex also posted a loss of 702 million francs ($136 million) for the year ended March 31, more than triple its loss of 213 million francs a year earlier. The wider loss includes costs of 600 million francs for a three-year restructuring plan.          The company -- which makes appliances under the names Moulinex and Krups --  said it would close four of its 11 plants in Normandy.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italy's Slow Growth Raises Fears of Recession
abstract: The Italian economy, which last year registered the strongest growth in the industrialized world, is now close to recession, the Finance Minister, Vincenzo  Visco, said yesterday. Italy's gross domestic product grew 3 percent in 1995, and the treasury was expecting the same again this year, but a slowdown in other European economies has muffled Italy's recent export boom.          For a country to enter a recession it must experience two consecutive quarters of negative growth. Italy's G.D.P. fell in the fourth quarter of 1995 but grew at a modest two-tenths of 1 percent in this year's first quarter.   (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ASARCO SELLS REMAINING STAKE IN M.I.M.
abstract: Asarco Inc., a New York-based mining company, said yesterday that it had sold its remaining 15 percent stake in M. I. M. Holdings Ltd. of Australia to institutional investors for $331.2 million. As a result of the sale, Asarco will record an after-tax gain of $39 million, or 91 cents a share, in the quarter ending June 30. The company said that the sale would cut annual interest expenses by about $21 million. In its second quarter last year, Asarco earned $56.4 million, or $1.34 a share. Asarco took control of M. I. M. in 1930, when the mining company was struggling to develop its lead and copper deposits in Queensland. Asarco has steadily reduced its stake since then. Asarco shares rose $1.375 yesterday, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;O.K., Save the Whales, But Spare My Mailbox
abstract: OUR accountant liked to think he was as jaded as any of his colleagues; he prided himself on having "seen it all." It was thus with a bit of satisfaction that I showed him our charity list for last year and watched his eyes bulge. Where in past years he had seen only a lump sum, he could now behold in precise  detail our contributions to almost a hundred different organizations devoted to the betterment of man, the relief of misery and the preservation of the better parts of this planet as we know it.        Writing that list was as much an act of desperation as inspiration on our part. In addition to satisfying any prying I.R.S. eye that might intrude into our affairs, it was the only way my wife and I felt we could work our way out of a self-inflicted gift-giving quandary: we gave to many groups but in return we received only more requests for money.

headline: Telephone Rackets Disrupting Service to Caribbean Nations
abstract: The list of items that divide the many islands of the Caribbean is long: language, culture, race and religion, for starters. Any index of unifying features, on the other hand, is bound to be brief, embracing little more than a  common tropical climate and, for nearly 40 years, the 809 area code.         But now even that symbolic connection is in jeopardy. A proliferation of phone sex lines, television gambling services and trafficking in stolen cellular phone and calling card numbers, all centered here in this nation of seven million people, has led some American phone companies to block access to all 809 numbers, and some neighboring islands to flee to new area codes.

headline: INVESTING IT;Tax-Free Bonds? Don't Be So Sure
abstract: EARL McDONALD knew exactly what he wanted when he bought municipal bonds a few years ago. "I really didn't know or care how and who financed my bonds," said Mr. McDonald, 83, who lives in Fayette, Ala. "I was going for the high yield, and because I thought apartment buildings were secure investments. I figured people had to move in, and they had to move out."         But last month a Federal agency judge raised a question that Mr. McDonald had given little thought to: whether the bonds, which financed the building of seven low-income apartment projects in two Mississippi counties, deserved their tax-free status.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.      Monday None

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TCI Wins a Round in Running Satellite TV Feud
abstract: Three months ago, it looked as if Rupert Murdoch and MCI Communications Inc.  had outmaneuvered and outmuscled John C. Malone in snatching the last unclaimed  license for direct-broadcast satellite television service in the United States.          But now, Mr. Malone has fired back with Plan B, cutting a deal with Canada's  biggest satellite broadcaster. And MCI, which paid $682 million for its license  in January, is crying foul to Federal regulators.

headline: Red Cross Suspends Operations in Burundi
abstract: The International Committee of the Red Cross suspended its work in Burundi today after the killing of three Swiss staff members in an ambush on Tuesday.         Other aid agencies reduced activities outside the capital. The Government set up an inquiry into the killings, but the Interior Minister, Sylvestre Banzubaze, blamed Hutu rebels.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Co. Appoints a Senior Vice President
abstract: to the new position of senior vice president for corporate development, new ventures and electronic businesses. The appointment is effective immediately.         Mr. Forman, who is 50, has spent the last decade working in television, computer on-line services, print media and advertising at a number of organizations, including the Telemundo Group Inc., the Newspaper Association of  America and the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Prudential of Britain To Sell Stake in Unit
abstract: The Prudential Corporation, Britain's largest life insurer, said yesterday that it planned to sell a significant stake in its Mercantile and General Reinsurance subsidiary in a stock offering. Prudential, which is not related to  the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said it had decided to focus on retail financial services and fund management.          Prudential first considered the sale of Mercantile and General, one of the world's 10 biggest reinsurers, several years ago. The company might attract an offer of more than L1 billion ($1.5 billion), analysts said. Mike Davies, a spokesman for Prudential, said the company had not decided what percentage of Mercantile and General would be sold.

headline: Dr. Katsuma Dan, 91, of Japan; Was a Leading Marine Biologist
abstract: Dr. Katsuma Dan, a Japanese developmental biologist who made fundamental discoveries in studies of marine organisms, died on May 18 at the home of his eldest daughter in Osaka. A former resident of Tokyo, he was 91.         In the United States, his association with the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass., stretched back to the 1930's.

headline: On Line: A Bosnia Gallery
abstract: Bosnia: Uncertain Paths to Peace," an interactive photo essay and international discussion examining the aftermath of the war in Bosnia, begins today on the Internet as a special report by The New York Times on the Web.         The project, available at http://www.nytimes.com/bosnia, features a gallery of 150 pictures by the French photojournalist Gilles Peress that chronicle the last weeks of the siege of Sarajevo in February and March and the exodus of Serbs from the city's suburbs.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Continental Airlines Posted A Profit in the First Quarter
abstract: Continental Airlines reported a strong profit for the first quarter today, and said it was becoming a "normal company."         Net income reached $88 million, or $2.36 a share, reversing a loss in the first quarter of 1995 of $30 million. Revenue rose to $1.49 billion, from $1.41  billion a year earlier.

headline: Vietnam Ousts Official
abstract: The Communist Party has purged a high-ranking official who apparently fell from favor after opposing the quick pace of Vietnam's move toward a more open economy.         Confirmation of his expulsion was made in a statement on Friday.

headline: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS: THE PAYOFF;Once a Pharmacist, Now a Deal Maker
abstract: Leonard Abramson, a one-time cab driver, walked away yesterday with the biggest tip in his life -- some $492 million in cash.         The 63-year-old Mr. Abramson, the founder and chairman of U.S. Healthcare, stands to be the biggest winner under the terms of the $8.9 billion offer by Aetna Life and Casualty Company to acquire U.S. Healthcare. If the takeover is completed, Mr. Abramson will not only gain the most cash from the deal but will  also become the largest single holder of Aetna stock and a director of the company, which is based in Hartford.

headline: Poverty Meets Consumerism in Inland China
abstract: NINGXIA, China—  "Work hard and realize the goal of 0.1 billion yuan sales this year," declared a huge red banner strung across the atrium at Xinhua Shopping City. The staff at the newest department store in Yinchuan, capital of Ningxia province, looked well on course to meet the target — equal to about $12.3 million

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Ellis Communications Agrees To a $732 Million Acquisition
abstract: Ellis Communications Inc. said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $732 million in cash by a new company formed by a merger-and-acquisition lawyer  in Boston.         Ellis, a closely held company based in Atlanta, owns and operates 12 television stations, two radio stations and a sports management production company called Raycom. It will be acquired by Ellis Acquisitions Inc., a company set up by Stephen Burr, the Boston lawyer, and financed by Retirement Systems of Alabama, the state's main public-employee pension fund.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;When Discounts Don't Mean Good Deals
abstract: CLOSED-END funds have often been a double-edged sword for investors. While they offer a great way to bet on a single country or sector, they also have the  disappointing habit of trading at a deep discount.         Unlike open-ended mutual funds, closed-end funds are not obligated to buy back shares from investors at net asset value -- the value of the fund's holdings divided by the number of shares. Instead, investors trade the shares of closed-end funds in the open market on the various exchanges. If they lose confidence in a manager or if the fund's approach falls out of favor, those shares can trade at prices well below the underlying value of the fund's assets.

headline: For Indians, An Election Is Honest But Boring
abstract: Like India itself, Indian elections have always been raucous, free-for-all affairs, full of noise and mayhem and general outlandishness. At election time,  the successful politician has often been the one who has proven wilier than opponents at circumventing laws that are supposed to govern election practices,  especially spending.         By these standards, the general election that winds up with a third and final round of voting on Tuesday has been a pale shadow of the 10 previous elections,  so much so that Indian newspapers have had to find novel ways of describing it.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Suspects in Tourist Deaths Battle Egypt Police; 6 Die
abstract: Egyptian police fought a gun battle today with Islamic militants they said were responsible for killing 18 Greek tourists last week.         Two men believed by the police to have participated in the killing of the tourists were killed in the battle in southern Egypt. Four police officers died  and 14 others were wounded.

headline: World News Briefs;Central African Soldiers Continue Their Mutiny
abstract: A three-day-old mutiny by some 400 soldiers demanding their paychecks showed  no signs of abating today as the mutineers began looting and released hundreds of criminals after bursting into Bangui's main prison.         Witnesses said mutineers also entered the homes of business executives, demanding money and vehicles and beating those who refused.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LIBERTY MEDIA TO GET BIG STAKE IN VIDEO JUKEBOX
abstract: The Liberty Media Corporation has agreed to acquire a controlling stake worth up to $32 million in Video Jukebox Network Inc., operator of the Box interactive music-video network. Liberty plans to purchase 5.6 million shares of Video Jukebox for $2 each, or a total of $11.2 million, from a shareholder group. The  group will grant Liberty an option to buy another 5.7 million shares at $2 each. Subject to board approval, Video Jukebox will also issue Liberty options to buy an additional 4.7 million shares at $2 each. Liberty already holds between 5 percent and 10 percent of Video Jukebox. The shares rose 6.25 cents yesterday, to $1.75, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: World News Briefs;Shaky Government Stays in Turkey for Now
abstract: Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey said today that his weak conservative Government would remain in power for now despite losing the support of his coalition partner.         "We will continue to be the Government" until a new governing formula becomes clear, Anatolian news agency quoted Mr. Yilmaz as saying.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HIBERNIA AGREES TO BUY SECOND BANK COMPANY
abstract: The Hibernia Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the CM Bank Holding Company  for $201.7 million in cash, allowing it to expand into southwestern Louisiana. CM, based in Lake Charles, La., operates in a market that Hibernia, which is based in New Orleans, abandoned in 1992. Hibernia, with $7.20 billion in assets  at the end of 1995, is the second-biggest Louisiana-based bank, behind the First Commerce Corporation. Hibernia said it would have 187 branches after buying CM, with 17 percent of the state's deposits. On Monday, Hibernia said it would pay $46 million to buy the St. Bernard Bank and Trust Company in the eastern suburbs of New Orleans. The closely held CM has about $774 million in assets.

headline: U.S. Wins Liberians' Pledge to Back Truce
abstract: When an American delegation left Liberia today after a visit aimed at helping to restore peace to a city battered by two weeks of brutal fighting, the diplomats had made two significant steps .         After a tense meeting with the country's two dominant warlords, the delegation, led by William Twaddell, deputy assistant secretary of state, extracted a pledge from the two militia leaders to strengthen the cease-fire in  this capital by quickly withdrawing the thousands of boy soldiers who destroyed  much of the city and continue to terrorize its residents.

headline: Tran Van Tra of Vietnam, 77; Commander in Tet Offensive
abstract: Gen. Tran Van Tra, who commanded Vietnamese Communist raids on Saigon during  the Tet offensive of 1968 and directed the final assault on the city when it fell in 1975, died on Saturday, Vietnamese newspapers reported this week. He was 77.         The newspapers said he died in the city he captured, now known as Ho Chi Minh City. They did not give a cause of death but said he had been seriously ill for  some time.

headline: HINDU PARTY HEAD CHOSEN FOR POST OF INDIA'S PREMIER
abstract: After days of confusion arising from an inconclusive election, India's President chose a Hindu nationalist party today to lead the next Government. The party has pledged to make India a declared nuclear-weapons state, adopt tougher  policies on Pakistan and Indian-ruled Kashmir and abolish long-established legal protections for Muslims.         Confronted with no clear winner in the election and dithering by a group of center-left parties that had vowed to keep the Hindu nationalists from power but failed to come up with a credible governing plan, President Shankar Dayal Sharma appointed Atal Bihari Vajpayee as Prime Minister.

headline: Spendthrift Candidate Yeltsin: Miles to Go. Promises to Keep?
abstract: President Boris N. Yeltsin was in a beneficent, spendthrift mood on the campaign trail today. He promised a Tatar leader he met on the street $50,000 to open a new Muslim cultural center here. He visited a convent of the Russian Orthodox Church and gave $10,000 from his treasury to help cover the nuns' housekeeping costs.         And at a tense meeting with local officials and factory directors, Mr. Yeltsin made the most extravagant gesture of all.

headline: Tiger Management Buys USAir Stake
abstract: Tiger Management L.L.C. and affiliates have acquired an 11 percent stake in USAir Group Inc., the nation's sixth-largest airline company.         The Tiger group, which is led by Julian Robertson, a noted hedge fund manager, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased 6.9 million USAir common shares. Neither the prices of the shares nor the dates of purchase were specified in the filing, an S.E.C. form that is reserved for passive investors.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: GRUNTAL FINANCIAL CORP., New York, named Lee Fensterstock president and chief operating officer at its Gruntal & Co. securities brokerage subsidiary. Henry Gottmann was named executive vice president of retail and marketing. Stephen DiTursi was named executive vice president, capital markets, and Joanne Marren was named executive vice president and general counsel.    LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS INC., New York, named David Robbins to the new position of worldwide head of emerging-market Brady bond and Eurobond trading.

headline: Old Demons Are Roused On a Street In Berlin
abstract: For more than a century, Wilhelmstrasse was a seat of world power, as well known as Downing Street, the Quai d'Orsay and the Kremlin. Nearly all of its imposing government buildings are gone, but this week city officials began a new effort to remind Berliners of the street's extraordinary history.         Working with a group of historians, the officials have unveiled 23 plaques along Wilhelmstrasse and adjoining streets. They mark the places where German Chancellors, Presidents and government ministers, along with Nazi functionaries, made decisions that shook the world.

headline: Mutual Funds Still Receiving Big Cash Flow
abstract: While stock and bond markets continued to suffer a rough patch yesterday, evidence mounted that investors were not losing their appetites for stock and bond mutual funds. Far from it: A mutual fund trade group estimated that investors poured more cash into stock and bond funds in the first quarter of 1996 than in the first nine months of last year.         The Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group, estimated that stock and bond funds took in a net $23 billion in March. While that was down slightly from February's total, it also supported contentions by mutual fund companies that individual investors did not flee the markets after a sharp decline in stock prices early last month.

headline: World News Briefs;Worshipers Inaugurate New Cathedral in France
abstract: Easter celebrants filled the Resurrection Cathedral today for the inauguration of the first cathedral to be built in France this century.         The modern cathedral, designed by Swiss architect Mario Botta, stands as a red-brick cylinder with lime trees outlining its sloped roof.

headline: U.N. Says That Serbs Renewed Expulsions
abstract: The United Nations refugee agency accused Serbs today of resuming expulsions  of Muslims, while NATO's commander in Bosnia criticized all parties for violations of peace accords.         Serbs forced about 30 Muslims out of their homes over the weekend near the Serbian-held city of Banja Luka, said Kris Janowski, spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. Serbs beat some of the Muslims, he said.

headline: Harare Journal;Zimbabwe Opposition: A One-Woman Tempest
abstract: As a guerrilla, tiny, tough Margaret Dongo took the name Tichaona Munhamo, meaning "We'll sort this out on the battlefield."         Now that she's a member of Zimbabwe's Parliament, she is called "the ant in the elephant's trunk."

headline: Small Home Markets for Wind and Sun
abstract: Though it is in overseas markets that America's alternative energy companies  are thriving, there is at least a small constituency for their products at home.         The largest windmill yet erected in the United States began generating power  late last month just west of Traverse City, Mich., thanks to the willingness of  scores of local customers to pay a premium on their monthly electric bill.

headline: Invalid G.M. Shares Re-emerge in Europe
abstract: A batch of invalidated General Motors stock certificates, which were supposed to have been destroyed four years ago, have emerged again in Europe.         The Securities and Exchange Commission notified stock exchanges worldwide last week to be on the lookout for some 1.3 million canceled certificates of common and preferred stock with an estimated market value of about $7 billion.

headline: New Software For Business By Microsoft
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation is expected to announce on Tuesday that it has begun shipping its Exchange program, a tool for managing corporate mail that also allows groups of workers to share documents and projects. Electronic Data Systems will announce that it will use the program for its 68,000 employees worldwide.         The program, is a direct challenge to the popular Notes software of Lotus Development, now owned by I.B.M.

headline: Correction: Treasury Yield Curve
OPEC Is Expected to Delay Action on New Oil Output by Iraq
abstract: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting here, appeared paralyzed today, stuck between a certainty of lower oil prices if it failed to reduce its 11 members' output, but stymied by its members' refusal to cut their  current market shares.         As a result, OPEC was headed for an inconclusive resolution that would authorize Iraq to pump some 800,000 barrels of oil a day without any offsetting  cuts. A United Nations resolution in May allowed Iraqi exports, which had been halted following the Persian Gulf war, to resume soon.

headline: Ex-Nazi Faces Trial in Italy In Cave Killings
abstract: Paving the way for what could be Europe's last Nazi war crimes trial, an Italian military judge today ordered Erich Priebke, a former SS captain, to stand trial for his involvement in Italy's most dramatic wartime atrocity.         Mr. Priebke, 82, was a member of the German unit that in 1944 killed 335 men  and boys, including 77 Jews, in the Ardeatine Caves outside Rome. He is to stand trial on charges of "multiple homicide, aggravated by cruelty." The military judge in the case, Giuseppe Massi, rejected a defense request that Mr. Priebke be transferred from prison to house arrest because of his age and ill health.

headline: Kashmiris Reportedly Kill Four Hostages
abstract: The Indian police tried today to confirm a report that Kashmiri rebels had killed an American and three other hostages whom they had captured on July 4.         A police officer in Jammu said today that a middleman carrying messages between Muslim militants and the Indian Government had reported over the weekend that the Al-Faran rebels had killed and buried the hostages. The officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity, provided no other details.

headline: Serb Chief Is Named; Rival Refuses to Go
abstract: The Bosnian Serbs' wartime leader, Radovan Karadzic, named a new prime minister for Serb-controlled areas of Bosnia today, after dismissing the incumbent in a power struggle between ultranationalists and moderates in the self-styled Serb Republic.

headline: So Many Jokes, So Little Time
abstract: We know you're all working hard, with no time to surf the Internet, send E-mail to friends or goof off on company time. You certainly don't have the time to tell everyone all those great office jokes you've heard. So let us spread them for you. Send your best office jokes to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;National Power Rejects Talks With Southern
abstract: National Power P.L.C., Britain's largest utility, has rejected meeting with the Southern Company to discuss a merger, saying National Power was not for sale and questioning whether the United States company could offer a fair price. The  rebuff came in a letter from John Baker, the British company's chairman, to the  head of Southern's international unit, Tom Boren. Southern announced on Wednesday that it might bid for National Power.          While National Power would consider an offer, Mr. Baker said in his letter that "there is no point" in meeting unless Southern made a compelling offer "in  a credible way." Southern, based in Atlanta, had requested a meeting in advance  of a formal bid.   Bloomberg Business News

headline: First Michigan Bank
abstract: The First Michigan Bank Corporation acquired the Arcadia Financial Corporation of Kalamazoo, Mich., this week in a stock swap valued at about $20 million. Arcadia Financial owns Arcadia Bank and Trust, which has offices in Kalamazoo and Portage, Mich. Arcadia Bank and Trust, with $108 million in assets, will be known as FMB-Arcadia Bank.

headline: Tenneco To Acquire Pullman
abstract: Tenneco Inc., in another small move toward reorganization, said yesterday that it would acquire the Pullman Company, a privately held maker of automotive  suspensions and other parts, for about $300 million.         Tenneco said it would pay Pullman shareholders approximately $13.50 a share and assume the company's debts.

headline: An African Ex-Emperor Laments His Reputation
abstract: Before a recent army mutiny and intervention by France to evacuate its citizens and restore order, the last time most of the world had heard from this  sparsely populated country the news was as fantastic as it was sordid.         An African military leader, Col. Jean-Bedel Bokassa, who seized power on Jan. 1, 1966, from a repressive cousin to become "President for life," decided in 1977 that even that station was not exalted enough and crowned himself Emperor of a realm in the heart of Africa.

headline: Move to the Web Is in the Works For Compuserve
abstract: Deciding to flow with the relentless tide of the Internet rather than fight it, Compuserve Inc. is expected to announce today that it is rebuilding its entire on-line service on the standards of the World Wide Web, people briefed by the company said yesterday.         Compuserve's decision to embrace the open standards of the Web follows similar moves by the Prodigy Services Company, the Microsoft Network and AT&T's Interchange Online Network, all of which started as closed, proprietary services. But Compuserve, the world's second-largest consumer on-line service, with more than four million subscribers worldwide, is by far the largest network to acknowledge that it cannot compete against the rapidly growing Web.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chip Industry Indicator Plunges to 5-Year Low The semiconductor industry's leading indicator, its book-to-bill ratio, plunged  to a five-year low of 0.80 for the three-month period ended in March, reflecting a slowdown in personal computer sales and rapidly falling prices for memory chips.

headline: Victims' Kin Sue to Halt Apartheid-Era Inquiry
abstract: Less than a week before this country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission is to begin its work with a four-day hearing that will see more than a dozen survivors of apartheid-era atrocities tell their stories, the families of some of South Africa's most noted victims have gone to court hoping to halt the proceedings.         The commission, headed by Archbishop Desmond Tutu, was designed to offer a way for the country to put its violent past to rest. It is a compromise of sorts, as it avoids what could be thousands of criminal prosecutions, but nevertheless offers a public accounting of decades of torture and murder.

headline: Structure Set By Chief Lets A Chip Maker Bear His Loss
abstract: Jerry R. Junkins, the chairman, president and chief executive of Texas Instruments Inc., died unexpectedly of a heart attack while on a business trip in Germany yesterday. Despite the sadness and shock about Mr. Junkins's death, analysts said, his passing would have little impact on the company's future.         "He set up a structure so that if some person left, or there was a tragedy, as there was, they could close ranks and handle it," said Thomas P. Kurlak, a semiconductor analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York.

headline: Tapping the New Wealth of Women
abstract: LOS ANGELES—  When Alison A. Winter began her career in banking in 1971, the industry at large had yet to fully recognize one potential client base.

headline: Investigators Say Arson Was Likely in Venice Opera House Fire
abstract: Investigators have concluded that arson was the likely cause of a fire in January that left one of Italy's most beloved cultural monuments -- Venice's opera house, La Fenice -- a smoldering ruin.         Italian newspapers reported today that five experts headed by the chief of Venice's civilian defense, Leonardo Corbo, had determined that the fire was set  intentionally at various places in the 204-year-old opera house with the help of flammable materials, probably a mixture of oil and gasoline.

headline: Canada Backs a Bill Favoring Gay Rights
abstract: The Canadian House of Commons gave approval in principle today to a bill that would ban discrimination against homosexuals.         Members of Parliament voted 178 to 53 in favor of the Government-sponsored bill, which must now go through committee before a final vote in the House expected next week.

headline: New Pressures on Airline Crash-Liability Accord
abstract: The Warsaw Convention governing the liability of an airline when passengers die in a plane crash is crumbling as airlines try to raise the accord's $75,000  limit on damages.         But prospects for a new agreement are uncertain, because the United States Department of Transportation is demanding that the accord provide that damage suits involving Americans be heard in the United States. Some foreign airlines reject that demand.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBRECHT & QUIST PLANS TO GO PUBLIC
abstract: Hambrecht & Quist Group Inc., the investment bank that has helped many high-technology and health care companies sell shares, yesterday filed to raise  $80 million through its own initial public offering. The company, which is based in San Francisco, also gave the public an initial glimpse of its earnings. Hambrecht & Quist's income before income taxes totaled $71.9 million in the six  months that ended on March 31, up from $25.4 million a year earlier. The earnings for the 1996 period exceeded the $71.89 million that Hambrecht & Quist  earned before income taxes during the entire fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. Yesterday's filing was the first step in an initial public offering process that will probably take at least several months. Hambrecht & Quist plans to wait until later to release details of the stock offering, including the number of shares to be sold and their price.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Swissair Says U.S. Backs Link
abstract: Swissair, Delta Air Lines and partners have received antitrust immunity from  the United States Department of Transportation for their plan to coordinate services, Swissair said today         Swissair said the ruling allowed the group, which also includes Austrian Airlines and the Belgian carrier Sabena, to cooperate in scheduling service and  organizing their systems to work together as though they were a single airline.

headline: United Airlines Said to Weigh Boeing Order
abstract: United Airlines is in talks with the Boeing Company on ordering new planes, although neither company would confirm a report published today that United was  preparing a $3 billion order.         Separately in Taipei, China Airlines, Taiwan's largest airline, said today that it had signed an agreement to buy eight Boeing 747-400 jets for $1.4 billion.

headline: I.R.S. Ruling Clears the Way For Viacom's Cable Spinoff
abstract: Clearing the last hurdle in a regulatory steeplechase, Viacom Inc. said yesterday that the Internal Revenue Service had approved its plan to spin off its cable television systems on a tax-free basis to Tele-Communications Inc.         A spokesman for Viacom, Carl D. Folta, said the company planned to begin an exchange offer for the systems on June 24. Tele-Communications said last March that if Viacom had not received I.R.S. approval for the spinoff by that date, the deal could have unraveled.

headline: OFF THE RACK;Seeking Biotech Ventures With Wall St. Chemistry
abstract: SAY "biotechnology" and watch investors' eyes either smile in excitement or glare in exasperation.         But no matter which way your eyes usually go, two articles in Worth magazine's June issue may intrigue you. Both paint complimentary pictures of two industry players, one of which is not yet publicly traded.

headline: World News Briefs;Study Asks All Nations To Ban Leaded Gasoline
abstract: The World Bank issued a study yesterday about lead contamination in air and soil, calling on all nations to ban leaded gasoline and warning that even low levels of lead can affect the brain and nervous system of the young and cause hypertension, high blood pressure and heart disease in adults.          The study was prepared for the United Nations' international conference on cities, to be held June 3 to 14 in Istanbul, Turkey.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TELXON STOCK PLUNGES AFTER PREDICTION OF LOSS
abstract: The shares of the Telxon Corporation fell 31 percent yesterday after the company, which makes hand-held computers and wireless communication devices, said it would lose money in the first half of its fiscal year. Telxon said after the close of trading on Wednesday that it expected a loss of about 50 cents for  the period, which ends in September. Analysts had expected the company, which is based in Akron, Ohio, to earn 39 cents a share in the first half, according to analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Telxon's shares fell $4.625, to $9.875, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: INVESTING IT;A Downsizing Victim: Shareholder Services
abstract: THE I.B.M. shareholder-services department is a shadow of its former self.         When David Pitou worked as director of the operation nine years ago, it had 120 employees. Now Mr. Pitou's old shop has a payroll of two.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ZILA PLANS TO BUY BIODENTAL TECHNOLOGIES IN STOCK DEAL
abstract: Zila Inc., based in Phoenix, plans to acquire the Biodental Technologies Corporation for as much as $45 million in stock, which would make Biodental, which sells dental products to dentists, the exclusive United States distributor of Zila's oral cancer test once regulators approve it, the companies said yesterday. Biodental shareholders would receive between 0.75 and 0.825 share of  Zila common stock for each share of Biodental common stock. Based on Zila's closing price yesterday of $8.5625, up 31.25 cents, the purchase is valued at $41.1 million to $45.2 million. Shares of Biodental, based in Sacramento, Calif., rose $1.25 to $5.375 in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Violence Growing in Battle Over Brazilian Land
abstract: A confrontation in northern Brazil between families seeking land to farm and  the police ended in bloodshed this week, when the police opened fire and killed  19 people.         The clash between rural families and the police was one of the most violent since last August, when organizations seeking land reform announced they would increase wildcat occupations of the vast unproductive estates that dominate the  Brazilian countryside to step up pressure on the Brazilian Government.

headline: Chinese Pirate Factories Have Roots Abroad, U.S. Study Says
abstract: A detailed study by the Clinton Administration of Chinese factories that are  pirating billions of dollars worth of American software, music and videos shows  that almost all the operations are partly owned by foreign companies, some of them working from nations that are close allies and trading partners of the United States.         The list has been circulating in recent days among American companies with enormous stakes in the outcome of the latest confrontation between Beijing and Washington.

headline: SPENDING IT;For Reverse Mortgages, a Fannie Mae Imprimatur
abstract: REVERSE mortgages, portrayed as a way for elderly homeowners to remain in their houses while providing them with an income, have also been criticized as too expensive and confusing. The elderly are often wary of these loans, and because of this, reverse mortgages have accounted for only a small fraction of the total mortgage debt held by consumers.         That may change now that the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, the nation's largest supplier of home mortgage money, has begun to offer its own version of "home equity conversion" mortgages, providing the equivalent  of the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval for reverse mortgages.

headline: Women's Group Seeks Place at Irish Bargaining Table
abstract: Elective politics in Northern Ireland has always been strictly a man's game.  But now an energetic new women's movement is running in an election here, saying it would bring nonpartisan, nonsectarian voices to the negotiating table.         This British province voted today to select negotiators for peace talks that  are scheduled to start on June 10. In a three-week campaign, the Northern Ireland Women's Coalition argued that the male politicians, strutting and fretting and boycotting and walking out in a huff, had botched all previous negotiations.

headline: DIARY
abstract: SPENDING

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Anne Melanson, an executive vice president at Bates Worldwide, New York, a unit  of Cordiant P.L.C., was named to the agency's worldwide management board.

headline: G.O.P. Makes an Issue of Replacing U.N. Chief
abstract: Taking advantage of the Clinton Administration's indecision over whether to support Boutros Boutros-Ghali for a second term as Secretary General, Congressional Republicans want to force the debate into the open and thus into the Presidential political campaign, where Bob Dole has already made bashing the United Nations a popular sport.         These Republicans hope to put President Clinton, who is apparently ambivalent about the Secretary General, on the spot.

headline: Of Foundations and Goals
abstract: To the Editor:         As the founder of a so-called celebrity foundation, I take issue with "Celebrity Foundations in Glare of the Spotlight" (Spending It, March 31). It seems to imply that "celebrity foundations" (its term, not mine) serve as a means of self-aggrandizement rather than a legitimate method of contributing to  a community. "Celebrity foundations seem prone to criticism, mismanagement and sometimes far worse," it says.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Gasoline Price Increases Are Benefiting Producers As gasoline prices have risen, the greatest share of the profits have gone to crude oil producers, while gas stations and wholesale distributors are collecting 28 percent more than last year, Cambridge Energy Research Associates  said. Pushing up the prices are such industry changes as sharply lower inventories and a new wave of less-polluting, reformulated, oxygenated, seasonal and regional gasolines. [Page A1.]

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Rise to Record Highs
abstract: Record high prices for corn and wheat helped a 12 percent rise in the farm-price index in May from a year earlier, the Department of Agriculture said  today.         The index, the Government's gauge of prices paid to farmers for their crops and livestock, rose to a record high of 112 in May, up 3.7 percent from April.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Maneuvers Hurt Growth in Taiwan
abstract: Taiwan's economy in the first quarter grew at a pace slower than the Government had predicted because of the effects of Chinese military exercises in March, a Cabinet agency said yesterday. Gross domestic product rose 5.3 percent  in the first three months of 1996 from a year earlier, less than the gain of 5.8 percent predicted in February. The agency also lowered its forecast of G.D.P. growth from all of 1996 to 6.17 percent from a previous 6.36 percent.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 6/ Some new, and some old, ways for investors to play foreign countries. By Doreen  Hemlock.

headline: World News Briefs;London Orders a Review Of Guerrilla Convictions
abstract: The Government ordered a review of several years' worth of guerrilla convictions today after the discovery that equipment used to identify explosives in a string of bomb cases was contaminated.         Traces of a substance that is one of the main components of the plastic explosive Semtex were found in a centrifuge used to carry out tests since 1989,  said Home Secretary Michael Howard.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Long-Delayed Power Plant Gets Go-Ahead in Mexico
abstract: The Government announced today that it had resolved financing and other difficulties that for four years have delayed construction of a $647 million electric power generating plant near the northern industrial city of Ciudad Juarez.         Construction of the Samalayuca II plant is to begin within a month, the Government said.

headline: Events in Burma Threaten to Fracture ASEAN Regional Forum
abstract: SINGAPORE—  Less than two years after it was established as the only organization dealing with Asia-Pacific security problems, the ASEAN Regional Forum is in danger of being fractured and bypassed by events in Burma and other parts of Asia that it cannot handle, analysts say.

headline: Plans Have A Familiar Vroom
abstract: IF at first you don't succeed, try again. But maybe don't mention that a similar effort once fell short.         Last month, Penske Motorsports Inc. raised $72 million in an initial public offering of 25 percent of its stock. Penske Motorsports, one of the companies in the automotive and trucking empire of the entrepreneur Roger S. Penske, builds and operates auto race tracks, and one of its biggest moneymakers is expected to be a course now under construction in the ruins of an old Kaiser Steel plant here.

headline: BOMBING IN SAUDI ARABIA: THE WITNESSES;Survivors of Saudi Explosion Knew at Once It Was a Bomb
abstract: Staff Sgt. Alfredo Guerrero saw it coming, unfolding before him like the nightmare his training courses had etched.         The Saudi base, where American, British and French troops are housed in a complex called Khobar Towers, was already on a heightened state of alert after warnings of possible attacks on Americans.

headline: U.S. Healthcare Chief Will Get $1 Billion
abstract: U.S. Healthcare's merger with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company will mean big bonuses for top U.S. Healthcare executives, especially the chairman, Leonard Abramson, who will get about $1 billion.         Mr. Abramson, the chief executive and founder of the Pennsylvania H.M.O. company, will get more than $967 million in cash and stock, plus a $25 million corporate jet.

headline: G.M.'s Labor Costs for Parts Exceed Rivals', Study Says
abstract: The General Motors Corporation's labor costs for auto parts are $440 higher a vehicle than the Ford Motor Company's costs and $600 higher a vehicle than the Chrysler Corporation's because G.M. buys fewer parts from low-cost outside suppliers, according to a study issued here today.         The study, by an independent consulting firm in this northern suburb of Detroit, bolsters G.M.'s position in this summer's labor negotiations with the United Automobile Workers union. G.M. has been seeking extra concessions this year from the U.A.W. to offset the disadvantage the company has from manufacturing so many of its own parts using highly paid union workers.

headline: A Big Casino Wager That Hasn't Paid Off
abstract: IT looked like a sure bet: the world's largest casino, a Las Vegas under one  roof, in the heart of New Orleans, a city with 10 million tourists a year.         The prime owner of the new casino would be Harrah's Entertainment Inc., the nation's largest casino company, whose genius for cracking open new markets had made it Wall Street's darling.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;TALKS BETWEEN FUND AMERICAN AND MELLON END
abstract: Fund American Enterprises Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had ended talks with the Mellon Mortgage Company about a potential sale of Fund American's Source One subsidiary. The company said it broke off talks with Mellon after four months of negotiations. A tentative deal worth about $350 million was first disclosed in December. In March, the two sides were still negotiating a possible sale of Source One. Fund American said then that Mellon had revised the terms of the proposed purchase. Source One ended 1995 with a servicing portfolio of $32 billion and $2.8 billion in mortgage origination. Mellon Mortgage is a unit  of the Mellon Bank Corporation.

headline: Memory Chip Prices Revive, But the Increases Might Not Last
abstract: Prices for memory chips have rebounded slightly after Korean and Japanese semiconductor manufacturers said they would cut back production. But industry analysts say they do not expect the price gains to last, and they do not believe the production cuts are deep enough to create a sustained firming of prices.         The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation of Japan said on Tuesday that it would scale down a projected production increase in 16-megabit dynamic random access memory, or DRAM, chips. That followed Sunday's announcement by the Samsung Electronics Company of South Korea, the world's largest producer of memory chips, that it would shut its factories for two days a month for the year to cut production.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRECISION CASTPARTS TO ACQUIRE OLOFSSON
abstract: The Precision Castparts Corporation of Portland, Ore.. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Olofsson Corporation for about $52 million. Olofsson, based in Lansing, Mich., has annual revenue of about $40 million and makes precision turning and boring machines, mainly for the automotive industry. Precision Castparts said Olofsson would complement the machines business of its  specialty products division, which also performs high-precision boring as well as castings for the aerospace, automotive and medical industries.

headline: DEADLY FLIGHT -- A special report.;In Crash That Killed Brown, Signs of Safety Shortcomings
abstract: Capt. Ashley Davis of the Air Force and his co-pilot, Capt. Tim Schafer, had  good reasons to forget about trying to land in the pouring rain at Dubrovnik, Croatia, on the afternoon of April 3.          The captains had never seen the Dubrovnik airport, and the lowering rain clouds made it impossible for them to see it now.

headline: TV Agreement Gives Viacom Greater Access To Germany
abstract: As part of the continuing battle to win control of television viewers in Germany, Europe's largest market, Viacom Inc. and the Kirsch Group of Germany announced yesterday a wide-ranging 10-year agreement that several executives close to Viacom said was worth $1.7 billion.         The deal would give Kirsch the German television rights -- both free and pay  -- to Paramount Pictures' film and television library and future production. Paramount is a unit of Viacom. Kirsch also agreed to carry Viacom's cable services like Nickelodeon and MTV on its new digital pay-TV service in Germany.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;Delta Reports Record Operating Profit, but Has Net Loss After Charges
abstract: Delta Air Lines reported a fourfold increase in operating profits yesterday for the quarter ended in March, and announced new programs to share with employees both stock options and seats in boardroom meetings.         In addition, the credit rating of the Atlanta-based carrier was raised yesterday by Standard & Poor's to one notch below investment grade. It was the first time since 1993 that Standard & Poor's had lifted ratings for one of the parent companies of the biggest three airlines, Delta, American and United.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bundesbank Declines To Change Key Rates
abstract: Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, left its key interest rates unchanged yesterday. The discount and Lombard rates were each lowered a half-percentage point on April 18, to 2.5 percent and 4.5 percent, respectively. The Lombard rate is the rate at which banks borrow emergency overnight funds from the central bank. The discount rate is the cheapest form of central bank refinancing.   (AP)

headline: Market Place;Wired, going public, is a real company, but makes no profit.
abstract: A LITTLE over three years ago, the publisher of a new magazine pegged to the  hottest area in technology went public, offering 1.4 million shares at the modest price of $5. Today, Hypermedia Communications Inc., publisher of New Media magazine, trades in the $3 range. Rest assured no one on the roadshow for  the initial public offering of Wired Ventures Inc. will remind investors of the  Hypermedia story.         Wired Ventures, the San Francisco-based publisher of Wired magazine, recently filed for a public offering at up to $12 a share, which would give the company a market valuation of about $450 million. That valuation represents a multiple of  17.9 times last year's revenues for the company, which continues to post net losses, and the deal clearly intends to position Wired among the Internet companies it covers rather than the magazine companies it competes with.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ANHEUSER-BUSCH TO MAKE KIRIN BEER IN THE UNITED STATES
abstract: The Anheuser-Busch Companies plans to make and sell the Kirin Brewery Company's Japanese beers in the United States. Anheuser-Busch plans to start making Kirin's Lager, Ichiban Shibori and Kirin Light at its Los Angeles factory in March. The companies plan to form a joint venture to sell the beer, financed  with $9 million from Kirin and $1 million from Anheuser-Busch, based in St. Louis. Kirin's shares fell $5, to $121.50, and Anheuser-Busch shares were down 25 cents, at $73.75.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;LAYOFFS AND OTHER CUTS PLANNED BY GEORGIA-PACIFIC
abstract: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced a major cost-cutting program yesterday that was intended to increase profits by $400 million over three years. The company said it would offer voluntary retirement to 1,400 salaried workers and would make further reductions through layoffs. Georgia-Pacific, a forest products concern, said it would take an unspecified charge in the second  quarter to pay for the moves. The company's shares fell 25 cents yesterday, to $77, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Weirton Steel To Fix Furnace
abstract: The Weirton Steel Corporation said today that it had shut down its No. 3 blast furnace for 10 days for a major repair that could wipe out the steelmaker's earnings in the second quarter.         The company, based here, said it expected the shutdown would reduce second-quarter earnings by $5 million to $7 million. It earned $6.2 million, or  29 cents a share, in the second quarter of last year.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SFX BROADCASTING TO PURCHASE MULTI-MARKET RADIO
abstract: SFX Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Multi-Market Radio Inc. in a transaction valued at more than $100 million. Multi-Market currently owns, services or has agreed to acquire 14 radio stations. Under the agreement,  SFX will retain 12 stations that were supposed to go to Multi-Market in a swap with Liberty Broadcasting Inc., which is also being taken over by SFX. SFX will  exchange stock valued at $11.50 a share for Multi-Market's class A shares, plus other considerations. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Multi-Market fell 75 cents, to $10.50. Shares of SFX rose 62.5 cents, to $34.50. Multi-Market had revenue of $18.3 million last year, while SFX had revenue of $76.8 million.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CADMUS COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Richmond, said it had acquired Lancaster Information Group Inc., Lancaster, Pa., a printer of scientific, technical and medical journals, for $57 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Agency Expands Operations in Asia
abstract: Draft Direct Worldwide said yesterday that it had expanded its international  operations by opening two offices in Shanghai and Guangzhou, China, and acquiring two other offices in Malaysia and Singapore from Union Two Thousand in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.          The China offices will coordinate local activities for accounts like Japan Tobacco and the Sony Corporation. Ana Lee, executive vice president for Asian development at Draft Direct in Hong Kong, will also head the Shanghai and Guangzhou offices. Sennett Tzinberg, managing director at Union Two Thousand, will continue to oversee the two offices in that role.

headline: Keycorp in Talks
abstract: Keycorp is in talks to acquire Carleton, McCreary, Holmes & Company, a Cleveland investment banking firm, for an undisclosed price, the two companies said today. The Cleveland-based bank started Key Capital Markets Inc. in February to provide investment banking services to its corporate and government  clients.

headline: Guatemala and Rebels Reach Peace Accord
abstract: Guatemala's leftist guerrillas signed an important accord with that country's Government today in talks here that are aimed at ending 35 years of civil war.         The rebels also announced the suspension of their controversial "war tax" on  landowners as a goodwill gesture.

headline: High Technology, Not Huddled Masses;U.S. Brokers Help Cutting-Edge Foreign Companies Come to Wall Street
abstract: Jo A. Lernout and his partner, Pol Hauspie, found new ways to allow computers to recognize speech and turn written text into the spoken word a few years ago.  After starting a company in Belgium in 1987 to research and develop these products, they found customers ranging from AT&T to Samsung. By the middle of last year, they had decided to go public so that investors could discover them.          But the local stock exchange was not an appealing prospect. Even by the standards of Europe's small stock markets, the stodgy Brussels bourse is a minnow. Turnover rarely approaches five million shares a day, compared with hundreds of millions in the United States, and Belgians prefer to invest in established local companies like Petrofina, the big Belgian energy company.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Securities Close Higher
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities ended higher yesterday on late bargain hunting  and short-covering by investors in a quiet but choppy trading session.         The market had little reaction to a report showing a sharp rise in existing-home sales in March. And while rising commodity prices put pressure on  prices early in the session, a late retreat in crude oil helped ease some inflation concerns in the bond market.

headline: U.S.-CHINA TALKS OVER PIRACY FAIL
abstract: Two days of last-ditch talks ended today without resolving the wide differences that remain between China and the United States over Chinese pirating of software, music and movies, and the discord drew the two nations ever closer to a trade war.         The United States still accuses China of failing to carry out broad sections  of an agreement reached last year on the piracy issue, while China maintains that it is proud of its record of protecting intellectual property rights.

headline: Zeigler Coal Offers $1 Billion For Cajun Electric Power Plants
abstract: The Zeigler Coal Holding Company and a unit of the Northern States Power Company said yesterday that they had offered $1 billion in cash for the nonnuclear assets of the bankrupt Cajun Electric Power Cooperative Inc., beating out 11 other bidders.         The trustee in charge of Cajun's Chapter 11 reorganization said he would file a plan this month incorporating the offer by Zeigler and the Northern States unit, NRG Energy Inc.

headline: INVESTING IT;A Smart Gambler's Travels in the Land of Biotech
abstract: THE image of the venture capitalist as swashbuckler, ready to invest vast sums in raw start-ups and brilliant ideas, has always been more well-cultivated  myth than reality. But Kevin J. Kinsella, known as the P. T. Barnum of biotech,  has come very close to living the myth.         Mr. Kinsella is the founder of Avalon Ventures, based in La Jolla, Calif. Avalon is a "seed" fund, raising money to invest in enterprises at the riskiest  first stage of development, when they are no more than a gleam in the eye. And unlike a traditional venture-capital firm, Avalon usually creates companies from scratch, rather than financing would-be entrepreneurs.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHER OFFER IS MADE FOR NORWEGIAN DRILLER
abstract: The battle for Transocean A/S heated up yesterday when the Reading & Bates Corporation raised its offer for the Norwegian oil and gas driller, which agreed last week to merge with Sonat Offshore Drilling Inc. The $1.56 billion bid reflected a premium over the $1.46 billion deal with Sonat Offshore, which, like Reading & Bates, is a drilling company based in Houston. The previous Reading &  Bates offer was valued about $1.51 billion. Transocean said it would study the new offer. Shares of Reading & Bates fell 75 cents yesterday, to $21.125, on the New York Stock Exchange; Sonat Offshore shares fell $1.875, to $48.625.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Murdoch, With Softbank, To Buy Into TV Asahi
abstract: Rupert Murdoch is teaming with the Softbank Corporation, Japan's largest personal computer software distributor, to buy part of the major Japanese network TV Asahi. Softbank and the News Corporation, headed by Mr. Murdoch, will form a venture to buy Obunsha Media, a unit of the Obunsha Company, for about 41.75 billion yen ($386.6 million).         Obunsha Media's major asset is a stake in the private broadcaster, the Asahi  National Broadcasting Corporation, known as TV Asahi.(AP)

headline: Harland Says It Will Eliminate 2,500 Jobs
abstract: The John H. Harland Company said today that it would cut about 2,500 jobs, or 36 percent of its work force, in the next two years as part of a strategic reorganization.         The company, which prints checks and provides software and marketing services for banks, said it would streamline its check-printing business and its marketing efforts. The moves are aimed at offsetting the rise in paper costs, which has hurt the check-printing operations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Job-to-Job Health Bill Gains, Covering Mental Illness The Senate passed legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, on a 100-to-0 vote. The bill faces a difficult conference with the House, but appears to have irresistible political momentum.

headline: Walesa Back at Shipyard to Work, or Get a Pension
abstract: Chauffeured in a black Mercedes and wearing a suit, former President Lech Walesa turned up at the shipyard here today, ostensibly to reclaim his old job as an electrician.         But as his mode of arrival suggested, Mr. Walesa did not appear very serious  about work. Not even a brand new set of eight red-handled screwdrivers brought by his favorite Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Henryk Jankowski, persuaded Mr.  Walesa to don overalls and pick up tools.

headline: Steady Rate Policy Is Seen At Fed's Tuesday Meeting
abstract: With inflation under control despite low unemployment and a revival in economic growth, the Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave short-term interest rates at current levels when its policy-making body meets on Tuesday, economists say.         The lack of upward pressure on prices and wages could also persuade the Fed to leave rates unchanged at its subsequent policy meeting in July, the economists say, despite forecasts that growth in the second quarter is likely to accelerate from the unexpectedly robust 2.8 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year.

headline: Angry Britain Rejects Mass Slaughter of Cattle
abstract: LONDON—  Buoyed by signs of rising consumer confidence in the safety of British cattle, the government defiantly ruled out Tuesday any mass slaughter and said it would challenge the European Union's four-week-old ban on British beef exports in the European Court of Justice.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Sri Lanka Extends State of Emergency
abstract: President Chandrika Kumaratunga has extended a state of emergency to the entire country, giving herself sweeping powers in the war against Tamil rebels before June elections.         The decree, imposed on Thursday but announced only today, allows her to enforce laws without parliamentary approval, curb press freedom and ban political meetings. It also gives the military wide powers to arrest and jail suspects without trial.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korean Official Arrested in Scandal
abstract: Prosecutors investigating a bribery scandal arrested a top official of the South Korean Ministry of Finance and Economy yesterday, just two days after the  arrest of the chief stock market watchdog, a prosecution official said.          Han Taek Soo was arrested after a court issued a warrant on charges of bribery, the official said. His arrest was linked to the investigation into the  chief stock market regulator, Paik Won Ku, who was arrested on Sunday on suspicion of allowing favors to companies that were seeking listing on the Korea Stock Exchange.   (Reuters)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profits Increase 6% At British Telecom
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits rose 6 percent in the year that ended on March 31, showing that its efforts to stimulate demand for telephone services were working despite slack growth in the economy. Pretax profits for the period increased to L3.02 billion ($4.58 billion) from L2.66 billion for the previous year. The report was at the top end of many analysts' forecasts.          Despite growing operations abroad, the vast majority of British Telecom's operations are in domestic market, where it has begun a series of advertisements urging people to use their telephones more often.   (Reuters)

headline: Saba Habachy, 98 Former Egyptian Official
abstract: Saba Habachy, a former Egyptian official, oil industry consultant and international lawyer, died last Sunday in Evelyn Hospital in Cambridge, England. He was 98 and lived in Cairo and Manhattan.         Born in Egypt, Dr. Habachy received a doctorate at the University of Paris. He taught criminal law at the University of Cairo and served as a judge and as Egypt's Minister of Commerce and Industry. In 1952, he moved to New York.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Babcock International Sees Lower Earnings
abstract: The Babcock International Group, a British engineering and power-plant manufacturing company, said yesterday that profit for its fiscal year would be significantly below market forecasts. As a result, shares fell as much as 20.5 pence, to 108, a low for the stock, before recovering to 113 pence.          The company predicted profit before tax of L3 million ($4.5 million) for the year that ended on March 31. That breaks down as an operational loss of L18 million and a one-time gain of L21 million. Babcock's chairman, John Parker, said in an interview that the company had been hurt in part by tension between Britain and Saudi Arabia and that its German operations had been curbed by the "growing uncompetitiveness of German manufacturing and German industry."   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: COLGATE-PALMOLIVE CO., New York, said its controller, Stephen C. Patrick, would  become chief financial officer, succeeding Robert Agate, who will retire on July 1.

headline: Bosnia G.I. Who Shot Himself Is Evacuated
abstract: An American soldier who apparently wounded himself in the stomach was evacuated to Germany today.         Specialist Hector Rodriguez, 28, of Joliet, Ill., was flown to the Landstuhl  Regional Medical Center. American military officials here said he was in critical but stable condition.

headline: Merchants Score Off Dodger Pitcher
abstract: LOS ANGELES—  This summer, Los Angeles Dodgers fans will have something in common with merchants in that section of the city called Little Tokyo. Both will be rooting for the continued success of the Japanese pitcher Hideo Nomo.

headline: His Mission: First Revival For Prodigy, Then Buyout
abstract: Last spring, as I.B.M. was looking for a new chief executive for Prodigy Services, the stumbling, stodgy on-line service it owns jointly with Sears, Roebuck & Company, the candidates were summoned to I.B.M.'s headquarters in Armonk, N.Y.         One candidate was Edward Bennett, a cable television executive. When asked what he thought of Prodigy, he replied: "Slow, lame and ugly. The Brady Bunch of the on-line world."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REPLIGEN SAYS TALKS TO SELL UNIT TO GENZYME FAILED
abstract: The Repligen Corporation said yesterday that talks to sell the assets of its  Allegro Biologics unit to the Genzyme Corporation had failed, but did not give an explanation. On Feb. 12, Genzyme said it had agreed to buy the unit's assets  for undisclosed terms. Genzyme was to have assumed Repligen's recombinant Protein A business and develop and produce drugs for Repligen. Repligen, based in Cambridge, Mass., develops treatments for chronic and acute inflammation. Genzyme, also of Cambridge, makes drugs and develops treatments for cartilage damage, burns and chronic skin ulcers.

headline: World News Briefs;Nepalese Army Rescues 2 Climbers From Everest
abstract: Army helicopters lifted an American and an Australian from Mount Everest today, ending an ordeal for them that had claimed the lives of eight other climbers.         No more evacuations were planned, although climbers are still struggling down the mountain after a blizzard last week that killed eight climbers.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Powergen of Britain To Buy Back Stock
abstract: Powergen P.L.C. plans to buy back up to L400 million ($600 million) of its stock after failing to acquire another British utility. The electricity generator, which also raised its annual dividend more than expected, said it would buy back up to 10 percent of its stock with cash it had intended to use to buy Midlands Electricity P.L.C.          The company's pretax profit rose 26 percent, to L687 million ($1.04 billion), including a one-time gain of L121 million from a provision for litigation claims that it no longer needs. In the previous year, pretax profit was L545 million.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HITACHI SEEN CANCELING PLAN TO RAISE OUTPUT OF CHIPS
abstract: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan will abandon plans to increase production of computer chips with 16 megabits of dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, because of an  oversupply on the global market, The Nihon Keizai, Japan's premier financial newspaper, reported today. The company had planned to increase production to 15  million chips a year by the end of 1996 from 9 million. The price of a 16-megabit D-RAM chip, the most powerful memory chip widely in use, is expected to fall to 2,000 yen, or about $19, in June, about a third of the price at the start of the year, the newspaper said.

headline: Buenos Aires Journal;The Police May Need to Be Policed Themselves
abstract: Driving his family home after a late-night dinner last month, Domingo Mercatante accidentally bumped the back of another car waiting at a traffic light.         Mr. Mercatante and the other driver agreed that the damage -- a broken taillight -- was minor, and continued on their separate ways.

headline: Captain Held On Suspicion Of Hurling 3 Men in Sea
abstract: Canadian policemen stormed a Taiwanese ship today and arrested the captain, who has been accused along with his officers of throwing three Romanian stowaways overboard on the high seas, Government officials said.         The Royal Canadian Mounted Police boarded the ship, the Dubai, to arrest the  captain after he refused to leave the vessel and come down to the Halifax dock to meet with Canadian officials.

headline: Too Close for Comfort?;Inquiry Touches Money Laundering Expert's Backer
abstract: Charles A. Intriago is one of the nation's most trusted chroniclers of the war on money laundering. Through his Money Laundering Alert, the 54-year-old lawyer has befriended leaders of the crackdown on financial skulduggery by drug  lords and tax evaders, citing them in his newsletter, inviting them to speak at  his conferences and gossiping with them on the phone.         His editorial board of advisers is a roster of former top American Government officials and bank regulators, including Jo Ann S. Barefoot, a former Deputy Comptroller of the Currency, and Robert E. Powis, a former Treasury Deputy Assistant Secretary. He himself once served as special counsel on organized crime to then-Gov. Reubin O. Askew of Florida, and he prosecuted white-collar criminals as an assistant United States attorney in Miami. His expertise on money laundering has made him an oft-quoted source in newspapers.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization                                                June 21   June 14   June 23                                              1996      1996      1995 Gasoline production, daily                    7.9       7.6       8.0 Distillate production, daily                  3.3       3.4       3.1 Gasoline stocks                             206.8     205.3     208.6 Distillate stocks                            99.9      99.3     115.9 Crude imports, daily                          7.9       8.4       6.8 Product imports, daily                        2.0       1.9       1.8 Crude stocks                                308.1     306.7     318.9 Crude production, daily                       6.4       6.4       6.5 Refinery utilization (%)                     94.0      93.4      96.6

headline: Coca-Cola Changes Some Fruitopia Flavors
abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said it was dropping six flavors of its Fruitopia beverages and adding two in a drive to remake the brand.         The company said the flavors being dropped were not selling well.  Coke also  plans marketing changes including easier-to-read labels, a new slogan and promotions.

headline: S.& P. Drops Rating On Some Kmart Debt
abstract: The Standard & Poor's Corporation has lowered ratings on two issues of debt securities of the Kmart Corporation, and it indicated that the outlook remained  negative for the discount retailer.         The new S.& P. rating of double-B-minus on Kmart's industrial revenue bonds suggests that S.& P. considers the Kmart debt to be speculative with a vulnerability to default.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SAKS FIFTH AVENUE BEGIN TRADING TODAY
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue raised $400 million yesterday in an initial public offering of its shares, which are expected to soar when trading begins on the New York Stock Exchange this morning. Saks Holdings Inc., whose largest holder was Investcorp, sold 16 million shares at $25 each, a price analysts expect to increase as investors cash in on its cachet and a booming market for luxury goods. The sale of a 26 percent stake values the entire company at $1.52 billion. At $25, Saks is valued at 57 times its fiscal year 1996 earnings estimate of 44 cents a share, according to the lead underwriter, Goldman, Sachs  & Company.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN SKIING TO SELL RESORTS TO SETTLE U.S. SUIT
abstract: The Justice Department won agreement yesterday from the American Skiing Company to sell two New Hampshire ski resorts as a condition of gaining Government approval for its $137 million acquisition of S-K-I Ltd. The Justice Department said that without the divestiture, American Skiing would have controlled eight of the largest ski resorts in eastern New England. To resolve a Government civil lawsuit filed to block the deal, American Skiing agreed to sell S-K-I's Waterville Valley and its own Mount Cranmore ski resorts. The lawsuit and agreement were filed simultaneously in United States District Court. S-K-I owns Killington and Mount Snow-Haystack in Vermont and a majority stake in Sugarloaf in Maine.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;WANG WILL BUY BELLSOUTH'S DATASERV SUBSIDIARY
abstract: Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the BellSouth Corporation's Dataserv unit -- which provides computer services and develops imaging, document management and network storage software -- for about $30 million. The sale is part of an effort by BellSouth to shed businesses outside of telecommunications in the wake of new legislation that increases competition  in the industry.

headline: With Old Political Order Gone, Leaders in India Vie for Power
abstract: India's rival political groups clamored for power today after a general election that shattered the traditional base of the Congress Party and gave new  leverage to a tumultuous assemblage of groups representing the mosaic of castes, regions and languages in this nation of 930 million people.         With results nearly complete, India appeared to have crossed a watershed. The India of nearly 50 years since independence, dominated by the Congress Party except when scandals and other excesses prompted voters to punish it with two brief spells in opposition, seemed to have given way to a new, more fractious period in which the country would wear many political faces, reflecting India's  ancient diversities.

headline: Market Place;Rockwell wants to shed military businesses, but only at top prices.
abstract: THE cold war is over, Pentagon spending on new weapons is tumbling -- and the military contractors are rolling in money. How's that?         While some debate how good the Clinton Administration has been to business in general, there is little dispute that its policies have brought some important benefits to at least one major industry, weapons producers. By lowering some of  the regulatory hurdles to mergers, big military contractors have grown bigger -- in many instances, much bigger -- and they have generally found their weapons production ever more profitable because of heavy layoffs and less need to invest in new types of weapons.
