headline: 7 'Dead' Bosnians Alive, But Just Who Are They?
abstract: It has been two weeks since American peacekeeping troops on an artillery exercise on the outskirts of town heard bursts of automatic weapons fire, then saw seven men running up to surrender to them.         Since then, some of the men, who were turned over to the Serbs, have been tortured by Serbian interrogators into confessing to murder, United Nations officials say, and have become the center of the latest controversy over how wisely NATO is carrying out the peace accord.

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 18.79 points, or less than one-tenth of 1 percent, at 22,520.40. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 165.19 points.

headline: REPORT ON BOSNIA QUESTIONS ABILITY TO HOLD ELECTIONS
abstract: Internal reports from the monitoring group that must determine if Bosnia is ready to hold elections chronicle a series of human rights abuses that call into question the country's ability to carry out a free and fair vote by this fall.         The reports from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, if  they were made public, could make it difficult for its officials to certify that conditions are in place for elections. But those officials said they were under  "intense pressure" from Washington, as well as most European capitals, to grant  certification, regardless of the situation on the ground.

headline: Ross Perot Jr. To Control N.B.A. Team
abstract: Ross Perot Jr., saying he knows little about basketball but a lot about real  estate, agreed today to buy a majority stake in the Dallas Mavericks to make the team and a planned new arena the center of a vast construction project.         Mr. Perot, the 37-year-old son of the billionaire politician, joined with David McDavid, a local car dealer, to buy a 67 percent interest for $125 million from Donald Carter, who founded the National Basketball Association team in 1980. Mr. Carter and his associates will keep the remaining stake.

headline: Moody's Combining 2 Units In First Big Shift in Years
abstract: Moody's Investors Service, one of the two major bond rating agencies in the nation, announced yesterday what it said was the first major revamping of its operations in more than a quarter-century.         The principal change is a decision to merge the company's corporate and municipal bond rating operations into one group, which will be called Credit Ratings and Analysis.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL DATA AGREES TO BUY CIS TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: The National Data Corporation plans to buy CIS Technologies Inc., another health care management company, in a stock deal valued at about $97 million, the companies said yesterday. Under the agreement, Atlanta-based National Data will  offer 0.08682 share of its common stock for each CIS share, or a total of 2.8 million National Data shares, in a tax-free pooling of interests. Shares of CIS  rose 68.8 cents, to $2.688; National Data fell 37.5 cents, to $34.375. CIS, based in Tulsa, Okla., manages health care reimbursement and business offices.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
abstract: A Buffett Copycat Hasn't Kept Up

headline: As Peres Bids Farewell, Netanyahu Faces Delay in Naming Cabinet
abstract: The newly elected Israeli Parliament was sworn in today with a trumpet fanfare and a poignant speech from the departing Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, but still without a new government.         After failing to resolve 11th-hour disputes over the allocation of Cabinet portfolios, the Prime Minister-elect, Benjamin Netanyahu of the Likud Party, put off the introduction of his government until Tuesday.

headline: 2 Afghan Factions Agree to Share Power
abstract: Two Afghan factions that became allies when the Communist Government was ousted four years ago but later became enemies have signed a peace accord and are forming an interim administration.         Hezb-i-Islami, led by the former Prime Minister, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, signed  a peace accord with President Burhanuddin Rabbani's Government last Friday after four months of negotiations.

headline: Rivals of American and British Air Quickly Assail New Alliance as Anticompetitive
abstract: American Airlines and British Airways formally announced their plans yesterday for a broad marketing alliance, setting off sharp criticism from competitors and raising questions about the likelihood of their partnership winning approval from Government regulators in both countries.   In addition, their announcement left unanswered the question of what would become of British Airways' current marketing link with USAir, which would be eclipsed by the new alliance with American.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;THREE AIRLINES GIVE BOEING ORDERS FOR 34 PLANES
abstract: The Boeing Company received about $1.27 billion in orders yesterday from three airlines for 34 jetliners. Western Pacific Airlines, a discount carrier based in Colorado Springs, said it planned to spend $700 million on 20 Boeing 737's; CSA Czech Airlines, based in Prague, ordered 10 Boeing 737-500 twinjets valued at roughly $350 million, and Finland's national carrier, Finnair, said it planned to buy or lease four 757's, valued at about $220 million, its first Boeing planes. Finnair's 56-aircraft fleet now consists mainly of planes from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

headline: A MERGER OF HEALTH INSURERS;Insurance Deal Approved
abstract: Connecticut's Insurance Department today approved the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's $4 billion sale of its property-casualty business to Travelers Group Inc. The approval was the final regulatory hurdle for the deal, which creates the nation's fourth-largest insurer of buildings, automobiles and businesses. A few finishing touches have to be worked out by the companies, a spokesman for  Aetna said. Travelers will form a holding company, based in Hartford, to operate the companies' combined property-casualty operations. As many as 3,300 jobs at the new entity will be eliminated, with half the cuts to be made in Hartford, Travelers has said. The consolidation is expected to result in hundreds of millions of dollars in savings for the new company.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;An Interim Offer On Chip Trade
abstract: A Japanese industry group said today that a transitional agreement was needed to replace the semiconductor trade accord between the United States and Japan, which expires in July.         Norio Ohga, chairman of the Electronic Industries Association of Japan, which represents 600 Japanese electronics makers, said a transitional agreement could  last until 1999. He declined to say what form such a pact might take.

headline: Syria's Leader, at Cairo Meeting, Sees No Hope of New Israel Talks
abstract: In his first public comment since Israeli voters elected a new Prime Minister, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria said today that he had no hope that  peace talks between Israel and Syria would resume soon and that he believed that "things are not going ahead in a positive direction."         Mr. Assad and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt both spoke guardedly after meeting here for nearly four hours, saying they would wait and see what policies the new Israeli Government of Benjamin Netanyahu adopts before deciding how to respond to them.

headline: U.S. Sees Higher Gasoline Demand, and Prices
abstract: The demand for gasoline, already soaring, is expected to set records this summer, sending prices higher, a Government agency predicted yesterday.         Prices rose in the last month on strong demand and unusually tight supplies;  because of the long run of cold weather, refiners kept producing heating oil and kerosene rather than gasoline.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;Vanguard's Low-Key Foray into Low-Cost Planning
abstract: FEW companies approach a new business as does the Vanguard Group, the Valley  Forge, Pa., company known for its low-cost mutual funds. When Vanguard decided to start a discount brokerage unit more than a decade ago, its chairman, John C. Bogle, assured the board that, to keep expenses down, the company would not advertise the new venture.         So perhaps it is not surprising that as it prepares to introduce a personal financial services division, a full year after Mr. Bogle announced the enterprise, the company concedes that it might not be prepared to deal with the  customer demand that could result. The basic service for relatively small investors, offered for a flat fee, will not be rolled out until perhaps next year. Even the service for wealthy individuals could be overwhelmed if interest  is great from existing Vanguard customers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Agencies Expand With Overseas Plans
abstract: Two agencies are expanding operations overseas.         The Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies has acquired a minority share in Birkholz & Jedlicki G.m.b.H., a sports marketing agency in Frankfurt and Zurich. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Russian Bank Yields to Yeltsin
abstract: The Central Bank of Russia gave in today to President Boris N. Yeltsin's demand for money to help pay for his campaign promises, agreeing to turn over the equivalent of $1 billion to the Government.         The decision was made at a meeting of the bank's board of directors, the Interfax news agency said. Bank officials had earlier protested the demand and threatened to challenge it in court.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economy Springs Back At a 2.8% Growth Rate The economy revived in the first quarter, growing at an annual rate of 2.8 percent, the Commerce Department said. The report delighted the White House, where officials claimed credit for reviving an economic expansion that once seemed about to expire.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Promotional sweepstakes are winning the day, and the payouts are now bigger and  bigger.
abstract: MAKE way, Publishers Clearing House. The Shell Oil Company is now running its biggest promotion ever, with a million-dollar grand prize. And last week the Coca-Cola Company began its Red Hot Olympic Summer promotion, which it called the largest in the company's history, offering $81 million worth of prizes.         As for McDonald's, it offered not one but three million-dollar prizes recently in its Monopoly promotion, surpassing the Disney Video Masterpiece Trivia Challenge, which offered two cash prizes of $1 million apiece.

headline: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, with a 52-week bill to be auctioned on Thursday.

headline: London Journal;England's Toffs and Yobs: Sports Draws the Line
abstract: It has come down to this, the yobs against the toffs.         The toffs (derivation obscure; thought to come from the tassels or tufts worn by aristocratic students) dress in white trousers and blue blazers. They consume two tons of strawberries and 11,000 pints of fresh cream daily while watching a ball the size of an orange travel at speeds up to 120 miles an hour.  They applaud demurely and register surprise with a sudden intake of breath.

headline: INVESTING IT;Company's Systems Know the Way to San Jose
abstract: IN centuries past, navigators used the stars and magnetized needles dangling  from strings to find their way. It's not that way anymore.         Now, 24 satellites tended by the Defense Department circle the globe and use  radio signals and atomic clocks to pinpoint objects on earth within one centimeter. This network, the Global Positioning System, was created for military purposes, but increasingly serves civilian needs, too. Motorists whose  cars have devices that connect with the positioning system use the system to navigate streets. Surveyors use it for map-making. Pilots guide their flights with it. There are similar uses in areas from mining to agriculture to toll-taking.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXCEL ENTERS LONG-DISTANCE DEAL WITH WORLDCOM
abstract: Excel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to pay Worldcom Inc. $900 million over four years for long-distance telephone service, which it  will resell to business and residential customers.  Excel shares rose $1.50 yesterday, to $35.25, on the New York Stock Exchange; Worldcom shares rose $1.875, to $51.375, in Nasdaq trading. Excel, based in Dallas, said it would buy about 1 billion minutes on Worldcom's long-distance phone network every three months. Worldcom is based in Jackson, Miss.

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. to Send Warplanes To Qatar for Two Months
abstract: The United States will station 30 Air Force fighter jets in Qatar for two months starting in late June, in what the Defense Department called a show of support for United States allies in the Persian Gulf region.         The Air Force will send F-16 Fighting Falcons and F-15 Strike Eagle jets, plus four KC-135 refueling planes, to Qatar as an expeditionary force similar to one now in Jordan, said Bruce Riedel, a Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense. He said the move was "not cued to any specific threat" in the area.

headline: A Compromise Is Put Forth To Detail Risk Of Derivatives
abstract: Companies would have to shed more light on their use of derivatives, the often enigmatic and occasionally risky financial instruments, under a compromise proposal adopted yesterday by the Financial Accounting Standards Board.         The board, a private-sector group that sets rules on how companies keep their books, has been wrestling with how to account for derivatives for four years, putting forth various approaches that have all been roundly criticized.

headline: Market Place;The Stratosphere in Las Vegas comes down out of the clouds.
abstract: TRATOSPHERE, eh?         In the Las Vegas meat grinder, it is often said, a casino has to have a gimmick to avoid being turned into sausage. And that is exactly what the Stratosphere Tower, Casino and Hotel seemed to have.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Concern Selling Turkish Bank Interest
abstract: Turkiye Garanti Bankasi has agreed to pay $245 million for Osmanli Bankasi A.S., which once served as the central bank of the Ottoman Empire. The seller is Compagnie Financiere Ottomane, which is 49.9 percent-owned by the French banking and industrial concern Compagnie Financiere de Paribas S.A.          Clover Investments, a company held by Turkiye Garanti, will actually acquire the retail bank, which has 61 branches and 1,400 employees. Osmanli Bankasi, Turkey's oldest bank, was founded in 1863 by order of Sultan Abdul Aziz.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Talk of Bid For Thorn EMI
abstract: The shares of Thorn EMI P.L.C. soared yesterday on speculation that the Sony  Corporation was planning to bid as much as L23 ($35.20) a share for the company, a British music and consumer rentals concern.         But a person close to the Sony Corporation of America said he did not believe that Sony would bid for the company. And executives close to two other big entertainment companies, MCA Inc. and the Walt Disney Company, said that neither company would be a buyer at the rumored price.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BAB HOLDINGS AND CHESAPEAKE IN BAGEL DEAL
abstract: BAB Holdings Inc., which operates 131 Big Apple Bagel stores in 26 states, agreed yesterday to acquire the privately held Chesapeake Bagel Bakery, which operates 137 units. Terms of the proposed transaction were not disclosed. BAB Holdings, which is based in Chicago, said that Chesapeake Bagel, based in McLean, Va., is the fourth-largest bagel chain in the United States, with units  in 26 states and the District of Columbia. Chesapeake Bagel's 1995 revenues were $9.4 million. After the acquisition, BAB Holdings would become the nation's second-largest bagel chain, with 268 units in 31 states. The largest chain is the Bruegger's Corporation, a unit of Quality Dining Inc. Shares of BAB Holdings rose 62.5 cents, to $11.125, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CITYSCAPE FINANCIAL GETS HERITABLE FINANCE GROUP
abstract: The Cityscape Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had bought Heritable Finance Group, a British mortgage company, for about $66 million. The  transaction was mostly in cash, with less than 5 percent in stock. Cityscape, a  mortgage banking based in Elmsford, N.Y., said it would operate Heritable as part of its British subsidiary, the City Mortgage Corporation Ltd. Heritable was a subsidiary of Heritable Group P.L.C., which is 50.1 percent owned by the Philadelphia-based Corestates Financial Corporation. Cityscape's shares jumped $4.375, to $50, in Nasdaq trading. Heritable, based in Reading, England, had a loan portfolio of L130 million ($199 million) at the end of March.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS;Rate Fears Push Prices Down Again
abstract: The bond market continued to slide yesterday as prices remained under heavy pressure from investors who increasingly expect the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates next month.         The 30-year Treasury bond, a benchmark for the market, plunged 1 5/32, to 86  5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose 10 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.12 percent, its highest  level in more than a year. Between Friday and yesterday, bondholders have lost about $25 for each $1,000 invested.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Outdoor Advertising Awards Presented
abstract: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago and Hunt Adkins in Minneapolis shared top  honors, winning the Best of Show awards, at the 54th annual Obie Awards ceremony for creative excellence sponsored by the Outdoor Advertising Association of America.         At the ceremony last night in New York, Burnett won for an advertisement for  Altoids Mints ("The curiously strong mints"), which are marketed by a unit of the Philip Morris Companies. That ad also won an award in the consumer goods   category. And Hunt Adkins, formerly Hunt Murray, won for a campaign for the Minnesota Moose, an International Hockey League team in St. Paul. That campaign, which also won an award in the entertainment category, spoofed the National Hockey League lockout with ads like "Owners threaten lockout; Players have own key made."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DEAN FOODS TO CUT 840 JOBS AND CLOSE 13 PLANTS
abstract: The Dean Foods Company said yesterday that it would close 13 plants and cut 840 jobs, or nearly 8 percent of its work force, to focus more on its core milk  business and less on frozen vegetables. Dean said that it would take a $150 million charge before taxes in the fourth quarter for the reorganization, which  it expects will cut costs by more than $20 million in fiscal 1997. The company said it would report a loss for the quarter and year, which ended on Sunday. Two months ago, the company reported a 61 percent decline in third-quarter earnings because of slack prices in its frozen vegetable products and increased  costs in its pickle business. Dean, based in Franklin Park, Ill., is the nation's largest milk producer. Its shares fell 12.5 cents, to $24.50, before the announcement.

headline: Moscow Journal;Like Soybeans and Corn, Yeltsin's Worth a Gamble
abstract: Aleksandr Y. Basin took a break from the bustle at the commodities exchange the other day to boast how he had profited from President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election campaign.         "I made some money on Yeltsin," he said, a gold chain glistening beneath his  open collar. "I made a contract when Yeltsin was 26 percent and managed to sell  when he was 29."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Plank Road Brewery, Milwaukee, a division of the Miller Brewing Co. unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, to introduce Iguana Light beer in test markets including Dallas and Philadelphia. Although this is Burnett's first Plank Road assignment, the agency handles Miller brands like Miller Lite. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A Swiss Bank Is Reorganizing Management
abstract: The Union Bank of Switzerland said today that it would reorganize its management to to become more competitive internationally, marking the first change since Mathis Cabiallavetta took over as chief executive.         The move follows a similar one by the Swiss Bank Corporation, the parent of the investment bank SBC Warburg, which said last week that it would create four  new divisions to increase profitability. Swiss Bank announced those changes after its new chief executive, Marcel Ospel, took over.

headline: Fidelity Changes Some Fund Managers
abstract: The Fidelity Investment Company said today that it had changed the portfolio  managers on two of its select funds and created new positions to manage research in specific industries.         Nicholas Thakore was named manager of Fidelity Select Telecommunications. Mr. Thakore, an equity analyst covering appliances, gaming, furniture and carpets, textiles and apparel, replaces David Felman, who has managed the fund since 1994. Mr. Felman was named portfolio manager of Venture Equity Trust, a variable annuity product managed through the Fidelity Management Trust Company.

headline: Alpharma Gets Approvals
abstract: Alpharma Inc. said today that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market treatments for baldness, Minoxidil Topical Solution, and for vaginal yeast infections, Miconazole Nitrate Vaginal Cream. Minoxidil is the generic equivalent of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc.'s Rogaine, which has annual sales of about $100 million. Miconazole is the generic form of Monistat-7 Vaginal Cream, made by Johnson & Johnson's Ortho unit. It and similar products have annual sales in excess of $100 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;As on-line stock trading heats up, can bigger and better campaigns for cyberfirms be far behind?
abstract: PC FINANCIAL NETWORK, one of the pioneering on-line discount brokers, is counting on a humorous ad campaign to increase its share of the hotly competitive electronic investment market.         In the last six months, on-line investing has grown rapidly, with the introduction of e.Schwab, Charles Schwab & Company's computerized trading service, and Internet trading by E*trade Securities and Lombard Institutional Brokerage. The time seems ripe for this financial-services niche market to try to entice computer-savvy investors to experiment with on-line trading.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NESTLE AND BAXTER TO CONSIDER SELLING CLINTEC
abstract: Nestle S.A. and the Baxter Healthcare Corporation, a unit of Baxter International Inc., have agreed to consider dissolving their Clintec Nutrition Company joint venture, the companies said yesterday. Clintec, based in Deerfield, Ill., makes and distributes clinical nutrition products used by patients who are fed intravenously or who require nutritional supplements. The venture had 1995 sales of about $400 million. Baxter plans to consolidate the venture's intravenous nutrition business with its existing intravenous solutions business. Nestle, the giant Swiss food company, plans to oversee the nutrition supplement business. Clintec employs about 1,000 employees, roughly half in the  United States.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Phone Rate Cuts Set For British Businesses
abstract: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that it would cut the prices it charges business customers for domestic and international telephone calls by  as much as 36 percent, exceeding by L100 million ($151 million) the cuts mandated by regulators. British Telecom estimated that businesses could save as  much as L220 million ($332 million) each year from the move, which takes effect  on July 1.          In the last three years, British Telecom has cut prices by L1.3 billion to conform with price caps imposed by the Office of Telecommunications.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: CALTEX PETROLEUM CORP., Manila, an oil refinery joint venture of Chevron Corp.,  San Francisco, and Texaco Inc., White Plains, will shelve a $620 million refinery expansion in the Philippines.

headline: 2 Unions Sue Kmart Over Shareholder Vote
abstract: Two unions said today that they had filed suit against the Kmart Corporation, seeking to force the company to correct its tally of shareholder votes in a proxy contest at its annual meeting last month.         In a statement, the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said they were seeking to correct shareholder votes that were omitted or miscast because of clerical errors.

headline: PESO TRAIL -- A special report.;A Mexican Mover and Shaker Got the Red Carpet at Citibank
abstract: The instructions from Citibank's New York headquarters to clerks at the bank's Mexico City office were clear: Ask no questions.         Every few weeks throughout 1993, a mysterious courier made his way to the 16th floor of Citibank's glass-walled headquarters in Mexico City, carrying a cashier's check in pesos with a value of $3 million to $5 million. The clerks accepted the checks, which were made out to a Citibank subsidiary, and converted the proceeds to dollars. Then the money was wired to Citibank in New York, which sent it to accounts in Switzerland. No questions asked.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., said James Groff, who left this year, had rejoined the company as senior vice president and head of the new Internet appliance unit.

headline: After Imus Spoke, More and More Radio Affiliates Started Listening
abstract: Don Imus, the radio talk show host, is reaping the rewards of rudeness. Since his remarks about President and Mrs. Clinton, made to their faces at the Radio and Television Correspondents annual dinner last month, the "Imus in the Morning" show has been picked up by 10 additional stations.         With those 10, Mr. Imus is now heard on 80 stations around the country and has about 10 million listeners each week, said Bob Bartolomeo, director of affiliate sales for Westwood One, which syndicates the Imus show. The largest of the 10 new stations is WISN-AM, Milwaukee; the others are in Georgia, Louisiana, Indiana, Ohio, Oregon and Pennsylvania.

headline: Vietnam's 'Lost Commandos' Win Battle
abstract: Seeking to heal a wound from the Vietnam War, the Senate voted today to give  up to $20 million to the "lost commandos," hundreds of Vietnamese secret agents  written off as dead by the United States after being dropped behind enemy lines.         The bill, which passed without opposition, calls for $40,000 to be paid to each of the commandos or their survivors. There are at least 281 commandos known to be alive; some spent 20 years or more in prison camps in North Vietnam after  being declared dead by the United States military.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;No. 3 Korea Chip Maker Delays Expansion Plan
abstract: LG Semicon, South Korea's third-largest semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it had put a hold on plans to expand production of 16-megabit memory chips. The company, which had planned to expand monthly production to 10 million chips  by the end of the year, will maintain it at eight million chips instead, it said. The decision was announced a day after the Samsung Electronics Company said it would cut monthly output to 12 million chips from a planned 14 million.   (AP)

headline: PBS Names a Programmer
abstract: The Public Broadcasting Service named its chief of programming Saturday, filling the new position with a woman who formerly served as the senior vice president for programming. Kathy Quattrone, 45, a 20-year veteran of public television, was appointed executive vice president and chief programming executive by the president of PBS, Ervin Duggan, at the company's annual conference in San Francisco. Ms. Quattrone will be responsible for all programming distributed nationally by PBS, including children's, prime time and  syndicated programs. She said she hoped to put more emphasis on history and arts programming.

headline: Solve-Ex Confirms Two Stock Inquiries
abstract: The chairman of the Solv-Ex Corporation, John Rendall, acknowledged today that at least two Federal inquiries were being conducted into possible manipulation of the company's stock price.         Shares of the company, a mineral processing concern, plummeted 67 percent last Monday on news of a Federal grand jury investigation of possible stock manipulation. Solv-Ex shares fell $15.125 last Monday to close at $7.375. The stock rose $2.375 today, to $12.875.

headline: Stokely USA to Sell Unit
abstract: Stokely USA Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell the assets of its frozen-vegetable business to two buyers. The identity of the buyers and the purchase price were not disclosed. Stokely, which will continue to make canned vegetables, said the sale included processing plants in Grandview and Walla Walla, Wash. A third plant in Green Bay, Wis., accounting for less than 10 percent of Stokely's frozen processing capacity, remains for sale.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JP REALTY PURCHASES IDAHO MALL FOR $34.4 MILLION
abstract: JP Realty Inc. of Salt Lake City has acquired the Grand Teton Mall in Idaho Falls, Idaho, for $34.4 million. The real estate investment trust said it had financed the purchase with its $50 million secured revolving credit facility. With the acquisition, the company owns 44 properties, including regional malls,  community centers and commercial and business operations.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SUN TO BUY SOME CRAY RESEARCH ASSETS
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc. and Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday that they had  agreed to a deal in which Sun will buy Sun-related assets of the supercomputer maker Cray Research Inc., which was recently acquired by Silicon Graphics. The deal allows Silicon Graphics to dispose of the portion of Cray's business that was closely tied to Sun Microsystems, which remains a major competitor of Silicon Graphics in the computer work station market. Financial terms were not disclosed. Under the deal, Sun will acquire the Cray CS6400 enterprise server, a computer based on Sun Microsystem's Sparc-Solaris microprocessor chip and operating system, which runs with other large computer systems manufactured by Sun.

headline: Envoys Are Skeptical On 4 Saudis' Confessions
abstract: American officials do not doubt that four Saudis who were beheaded last month were guilty of the fatal car bombing of an American target here last November. The officials do, however, believe that the defendants' public confessions were  arranged by Saudi authorities, Western diplomats said today.         The men, Sunni Muslims in their 20's and 30's who grew up in the Saudi capital, made the confessions in almost identical language and delivered them with the aid of maps and pointers. The confessions were broadcast on state television on April 22 in a spectacle that one diplomat described as "almost surreal."

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DADE INTERNATIONAL COMPLETES $525 MILLION PURCHASE
abstract: Dade International Inc. of Deerfield, Ill., said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the in-vitro diagnostics business of Du Pont Medical Products, a unit of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, for about $525 million. The price was not disclosed when the agreement was announced in December. Dade, which is closely held, recently raised $350 million in a private junk-bond sale to help pay for the purchase. The company develops and makes medical diagnostic instruments and products. Dade's shareholders include Goldman Sachs Capital Partners and company managers. They bought Dade from Baxter International Inc. in 1994.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BELL & HOWELL TO USE THE INTERNET FOR ITS MEETING
abstract: Bell & Howell Company said yesterday that it would supplement its first annual shareholders meeting in Ann Arbor, Mich. with a first-of-its-kind session on the Internet. The Skokie, Ill., supplier of information-access products will  provide a live interactive audio feed of the meeting on May 16 to shareholders who connect electronically through its site on the World Wide Web (http://www.bellhowell.com).

headline: Man in the News: Necmettin Erbakan;In Turkey, a Zealous Pragmatist
abstract: The man at the center of Turkey's political earthquake is considerably less militant than he was 20 years ago, but he has not abandoned his Islamic and anti-Western beliefs.         Necmettin Erbakan, the Islamic party leader who on Friday put together a coalition that made him Prime Minister of this resolutely secular country, has a grandfatherly manner and a broad, reassuring smile.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Market Chain Has 15% Profit Gain
abstract: Tesco P.L.C., Britain's biggest supermarket operator, yesterday reported a 15 percent increase in pretax profit for the year ended Feb. 25. Tesco said its pretax profit before charges was L681 million, or $1.02 billion, compared with L595 million in the previous year.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent

headline: Zagreb Journal;In the Balkans, Three Languages Now Fight It Out
abstract: The guns have fallen silent and war crimes investigators have begun rooting around in muddy fields. But there remains, in the academies and the press, a fierce and unrelenting war about language.         The term Serbo-Croatian is now bound to offend anyone who is not a Serb. There are, many say, three languages in Bosnia -- Bosnian, Serbian and Croatian. And no matter how much passages may look alike, the United Nations prints public reports in all three.

headline: Lyons Talks May Prove Unpleasant For the U.S.
abstract: When the United States once again failed to send a check this spring to the World Bank fund that provides aid to the world's poorest nations, the other contributors -- chiefly Europe and Japan -- decided to teach a deadbeat a lesson.         They barred American companies from bidding on a range of projects financed by the fund, which brings agricultural science, food and health programs to villages in Africa and India. The United States Treasury estimates the sanctions will probably cost American companies $250 million to $300 million.

headline: FUNDS WATCH;Bank Funds Still Popular
abstract: The recent spate of bank mergers has reduced the number of bank-sponsored money market mutual funds. The funds, however, are increasingly popular with bank customers, according to a study by IBC's Money Fund Report in Ashland, Mass.         This year, 14 funds have closed. That leaves 468 bank money funds holding $175.1 billion in assets, more than a fifth of all money fund assets. Assets of  all money funds had grown 6.7 percent as of mid-May, but those of bank money funds had grown 8.3 percent.

headline: Insurance Queries And the Regulators
abstract: Consumers who turn to their state insurance regulators for help when shopping for health or automobile insurance may be getting bad information, a survey suggests.         A national study by the Center for Insurance Research indicates that state insurance regulators provided correct answers to basic questions about health insurance between 43 percent and 65 percent of the time.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ANN TAYLOR TO ACQUIRE REMAINING STAKE IN JOINT VENTURE
abstract: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement for the $38.6 million acquisition of 60 percent of a joint  venture that supplies much of the retailer's inventory. Ann Taylor plans to buy  out the stake of Cygne Designs Inc. in their joint venture called CAT. Cygne has had financial difficulty, and the acquisition should help assure Ann Taylor of continued supplies of women's apparel. Together, Cygne, based in New York, and CAT accounted for 54 percent of the New York-based retailer's merchandise in the past. The definitive agreement calls for Ann Taylor to pay with stock worth $36  million and as much as $2.6 million in cash.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP. (MCIC,NNM)
abstract: MCI Communications said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings jumped 21 percent, buoyed by increases in long-distance calling.         MCI, the nation's No. 2 long-distance company, said net income rose to $295 million, or 42 cents a share, from $244 million, or 36 cents, a year earlier. The results were one cent a share above the estimate of analysts surveyed by IBES International.

headline: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Climbs Against the Yen, And Strength Aids Rise vs. Mark
abstract: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, bolstered by concerns about the Japanese banking system and by expectations that Japanese investors would move more money abroad as their fiscal year began.         The dollar reached a 25-month high against the yen in Tokyo trading, before paring its gains in New York. Still, "there wasn't a lot of heart in the move up" against the yen, said Jerry Egan, managing director at the MTB Bank.

headline: Small Town's Worry: Boys Just Won't Be Boys
abstract: His brow furrowed, Kaname Ogura sat cross-legged on the floor and confided his deepest anxieties about the incorrigible behavior of his 16-year-old son. The boy is incomprehensibly good.         "I talked to his teacher about it," Mr. Ogura fretted, heaving a sigh. "I said, 'We're worried, because I know that kids are supposed to rebel at his age, and we haven't seen any rebellion.' "

headline: Spring Tonic in a Surge of Income Tax Refunds
abstract: An early surge in income tax refunds is giving Americans billions of extra dollars to spend this spring, which helps to explain the revival in the economy  now in progress.         The tax refunds, $52.1 billion through the end of March, are turning out to be a shot in the arm for the economy; indeed, the latest of several temporary shots in the arm that may well make the second quarter, just getting started, the strongest period of growth this year. "The refunds are definitely showing up as car down payments," Wynn Van Bussman, an economist at the Chrysler Corporation, said, "and that is stimulating sales."

headline: Christopher Sees Netanyahu In a Fence-Mending Visit
abstract: In a trip intended to repair relations between the Clinton Administration and the new Israeli Government, Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu spoke warmly today about their shared desire for peace, while tiptoeing over their sharp disagreements on how to get there.         There was no indication that Mr. Netanyahu, who took office only a week ago,  was ready to change his positions.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;KMART SECURES $3.7 BILLION CREDIT FACILITY
abstract: The Kmart Corporation said yesterday that the Chase Manhattan Corporation had completed the syndication of the retailer's new $3.7 billion credit facility, with the facility oversubscribed by about $1 billion. Kmart said the new facility was expected to become effective next month. Upon closing, the new $2.5 billion revolving credit facility and $1.2 billion term loan facility, each with a maturity of three years, will replace about $3 billion in existing credit facilities and other obligations and will provide Kmart with an additional $700  million in available liquidity.

headline: London Bomb Hurts Man
abstract: A man was slightly wounded today by an explosion in a London street next to a branch of Barclays Bank, the police said. A blackmailer targeting Barclays has mailed more than two dozen parcel bombs over 16 months.

headline: Paso de Cortes Journal;Life With a Fuming El Popo: Will It Blow Its Top?
abstract: The sky overhead was dimmed by a cloud of gray ash belched from the mouth of  a mighty volcano. But the dark plume was of no concern to Teresa Rosas Hernandez. As she has most days for the last 15 years, she climbed the volcano's flank to a wooden lean-to about 15,000 feet up where she makes fresh cheese tacos for the tourists who come to the Popocatepetl volcano.         "There's no danger," Mrs. Hernandez said cheerfully as she patted out a homemade tortilla and flipped it onto a wood-fired grill. "We hear the thunder from the volcano, but nothing else ever happens."

headline: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE IMPLICATIONA;Runoff Is Yeltsin's to Lose
abstract: When the Communist Party dominated Russian parliamentary elections last December, its leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, assumed that the vote was a down payment on future triumphs.         "This is the core of our support," he said at the time of the 24 million votes his party and its allies received while rolling to their impressive victory at the polls. "We can only grow from here."

headline: Call for Curbs If Top Serbs Are Not Held
abstract: The president of the international war crimes tribunal on the Balkans said today that the United Nations should reimpose sanctions on the Serbs if the two  top Bosnian Serb leaders are not arrested.         The president, an Italian judge, Antonio Cassese, has begun a public campaign for the arrest of Radovan Karadzic, the political leader of the Bosnian Serbs, and Ratko Mladic, their military commander.

headline: Defiantly, Bosnia Serbs Re-elect Party Chief
abstract: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, was re-elected as the leader of the ruling Bosnian Serb party today, defying calls by the international community for him to relinquish power or face renewed economic sanctions.         The congress of the Serb Democratic Party voted 354 to 1 to re-elect Dr. Karadzic to another four-year term as party chairman, Bosnian Serb officials said.

headline: Cost of Holding Bosnian Vote Is Estimated at $153 Million
abstract: An international team in charge of conducting elections in Bosnia by mid-September said today that the electoral process would cost $153 million beyond the $1.2 billion in foreign aid already pledged toward reconstruction and other civilian needs.         But even if the money can be found, so many problems remain that it is possible the voting will have to be postponed, Robert Frowick, the American diplomat who heads the operation, said at a news conference today. The Dayton accord, signed last December, specified that elections must take place within nine months, requiring a vote by Sept. 14.

headline: Market Place: Lowering the Bar For Corporate Earnings;Does Wall St. Forecast Performance or Set the Pace?
abstract: It all depends on what you expect. If a child comes home from school with nothing but C's on a report card, parental reaction may be outrage and anger. But if the preliminary indications had been for D's and F's, the reaction may be one of relief and even congratulations.         So it is now with Wall Street's view of corporate America's first-quarter earnings. "There has been a lot of talk about how great profits are and how they are so much better than expected," said Melissa Brown, the director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities. "But they are just better than recently reduced expectations."

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
abstract: * Jim McCann, founder and president of 1-800-FLOWERS, New York, was named the DMDNY Direct Marketer of the Year at the 31st annual DMDNY Marketing Conference, formerly known as Direct Marketing Day in New York. Also, Jonah Gitlitz, president and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association, was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award. * Advertising New York, the annual benefit event sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York, Advertising Women of New York and the American Advertising Federation, named three recipients of its first Good Egg Awards to honor corporate citizenship. They are: the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt; the Chase Manhattan Bank unit of the Chase Manhattan Corp., and The New York Times. Also, the John A. Riesenbach Foundation will receive a special award for its charitable work. The awards will be presented at the 1996  event, which is scheduled for June 19 in Rockefeller Center.

headline: Short Interest Rises Again on Big Board
abstract: With stocks continuing to surge, open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange have set their fifth consecutive monthly record in the most  recent period.

headline: Microsoft Hires 2 Apple Software Writers
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it had hired two key software designers from Apple Computer Inc. to work on its chief software products, adding to its roster of star computer scientists.         Steve Capps, one of the original software designers of the Macintosh personal computer, and Walter Smith, who designed the software for Apple's Newton hand-held computer, plan to work in Microsoft's Internet platform and tools division.

headline: Ukraine's President Ousts Prime Minister
abstract: The President of Ukraine, Leonid Kuchma, unexpectedly announced the removal today of his Prime Minister, an influential former security chief.         Mr. Kuchma told a Government meeting that he would sign an official decree relieving Prime Minister Yevhen Marchuk of his duties "soon," said the presidential spokesman, Dmytro Markov.

headline: More PC's Are Found in American Homes
abstract: The number of American homes with personal computers increased slightly last  year, but the percentage of households with PC's remained unchanged, a trade group said this week.         The Software Publishers Association's fifth annual survey said the number of  households with computers increased to 33.9 million from 32.6 million, while the percentage of homes with PC's remained at 34 percent.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iraqi Aide Casts Doubt On Accord on Oil Sales
abstract: A top Iraqi official says important differences remain with the United Nations over negotiating an oil-for-food plan, raising doubts about whether a deal can be struck when the talks resume next week.         United Nations and Iraqi officials are to begin a third round of negotiations on Monday on a Security Council offer to allow Iraq to sell $1 billion worth of  oil over 90 days to buy needed food and medicine.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago

headline: COMPANY NEWS;FAIRCHILD AIRCRAFT IN TALKS TO ADD DORNIER LUFTFAHRT
abstract: Fairchild Aircraft Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating to take over Dornier Luftfahrt G.m.b.H. from Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany. The Texas-based company provided no purchase price for Dornier, an unprofitable German maker of  turboprop airplanes. Fairchild Aircraft said the talks "are expected to lead to  Fairchild taking over control" of Dornier, whose main product is the Dornier 328, a 30-to-40-seat turboprop. A Daimler spokesman, Eckhard Zanger, confirmed that Dornier's parent company, Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G., was in talks with Fairchild, among other potential buyers.

headline: World News Briefs;11 Dead and 7 Missing In Floods in Central Italy
abstract: Heavy rain hit north and central Italy today as rescuers searched for seven people missing in western Tuscany, where at least 11 people have been killed in  floods this week.         Officials also announced a flood warning for the northeast Friuli-Venezia Giulia region, where road and rail links to Austria and Slovenia were blocked and the Tagliamento River was threatening to break its banks.

headline: STREET SMARTS;The Strange Allure of a Sinking Ship
abstract: MOTHS will fly too close to the flame, even if they see their colleagues catch fire. Lemmings will march toward the cliff, walking blithely to their destruction. But there's an explanation for their folly: They have teeny, tiny clumps of nerve cells for brains.         What excuse do investors in bankruptcy stocks have?

headline: Bahrain Holds 44 It Says Are Tied to Pro-Iran Plot
abstract: Bahrain announced the arrest of 44 people today in connection with a purported pro-Iranian plot to overthrow its Government.         The Interior Minister, Mohammad bin Khalifa al-Khalifa, said that 34 suspects had already confessed before an investigating judge and that the others were still being questioned, the official Gulf News Agency reported.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Schering Profits Up 16% in Quarter
abstract: The German drug company Schering A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 16  percent in the first quarter to 131 million marks, or $85.9 million, helped largely by higher sales of its multiple sclerosis drug Betaferon and a firmer dollar. The company, based in Berlin, makes 85 percent of its sales abroad.          The company said sales rose 5 percent, to 1.2 billion marks, or $787 million.   (Reuters)

headline: African Rebel With Room Service
abstract: Until he emerged from the bush to engage in peace talks here recently, the most frequently asked question about Foday Sankoh, the leader of West Africa's most mysterious guerrilla movement, was whether he really existed at all.         For five years under Mr. Sankoh's shadowy command, the so-called Revolutionary United Front indiscriminately burned Sierra Leone's villages, turned farmers into indentured servants and drove peasants like pack animals on  long foot campaigns.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citigate Leads Portfolio Awards
abstract: Citigate Albert Frank took top honors, winning the most awards, at the second annual Portfolio Awards ceremony honoring financial advertising, which is sponsored by the Financial Communications Society.         The New York and San Francisco offices of Citigate Albert, which is owned by  Citigate Group Ltd., won four awards, including best of show for print, for work for Hambrecht & Quist, the Union Bank of Switzerland and G.T. Global.

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:         Accustaff Inc., Jacksonville, Fla., 12 million shares. Robert W. Baird & Co.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Units Expanding At Interpublic
abstract: Two units of the Interpublic Group of Companies are expanding.         One unit, the Lowe Group, has acquired for undisclosed terms what it called a substantial minority stake in Roche Macaulay & Partners in Toronto and merged that agency with Lowe SMS in Toronto. The merged agency, operating under the Roche Macauley name, has 70 employees and billings estimated at more than $60 million from clients like Ikea, Mercedes-Benz and Ralston Purina.

headline: LATE FEES UPHELD FOR CREDIT CARDS
abstract: In a major victory for banks with interstate credit card operations, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that national banks could charge any late-payment fee permitted by their home state, regardless of whether the fee violates the law of the state where a card holder lives.         The Court upheld a 1995 ruling by the Supreme Court of California, which dismissed a suit against Citibank brought under state law by a group of California residents who had Citibank credit cards. Citibank, the biggest issuer of bank credit cards in the country, conducts its credit card operations from South Dakota, which has no cap on late fees or other credit card charges. The California plaintiffs argued that Citibank's charges of $15 or more for late payments were an illegal business practice under California law.

headline: Union Pacific Says It Will Push Merger
abstract: The Union Pacific Corporation said today that it hoped to continue working with the Department of Justice and to persuade the department to modify its criticism of Union Pacific's proposed merger with the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.         Union Pacific, based here, said it was disappointed by the Justice Department's critical filing but noted that the agency was "only one party among many" and that the Surface Transportation Board would have the final regulatory  say on the combination.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bartle Bogle Gets 2 Accounts
abstract: Bartle Bogle Hegarty in London was awarded two accounts, with combined billings estimated at $45 million.         The eyewear division of Bausch & Lomb in Rochester selected Bartle Bogle to handle advertising for its Ray-Ban sunglasses on a worldwide basis. The account, with billings estimated at $40 million, had been previously divided among three agencies: the Arnell Group in New York, for advertising in the United States; the London office of Young & Rubicam Inc., for Europe, and the Leo Burnett Company in Hong Kong, for Asia.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Banks Agree To Bailout Fund
abstract: Japanese banks yielded to political pressure yesterday to make an extra contribution to a Government plan to bail out failed mortgage companies, known as jusen, to reduce the burden on taxpayers. The banks accepted the proposal made on Tuesday by the Finance Minister, Wataru Kubo, to contribute extra money  to set up a new fund as a part of the plan.          Any profits the fund makes from investing the money would be used to cut the taxpayers' burden, but banks left open how much they would contribute and when. Officials said banks might bear an added burden of about 500 billion yen,  or $4.62 billion, to set up the fund, and agricultural companies and the Bank of Japan might pay a total of 200 billion yen, or $1.85 billion.   (Reuters)

headline: Tokyo Stocks Fall Slightly
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 3.72  points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,812.50. On Wednesday, the Nikkei fell  51.95 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 21,816.22.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner Purchase
abstract: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that its Southern Progress Corporation unit had bought Weight Watchers magazine from the H. J. Heinz Company. The price was  not disclosed. Southern Progress will not be involved with the Weight Watchers weight-loss centers or with other operations of Weight Watchers International. Nor will it be involved with the Weight Watchers Food Company, another Heinz unit. Weight Watchers magazine has a circulation of one million and readership of five million. It has editions for North America, Italy, Australia and Britain.

headline: Market Place;For Netcom, Its Fans Say Being Down Is Not Out
abstract: The fast-growing Internet business is often compared with the PC business a decade ago. And it is for just that reason that investors seem to be growing wary of the Internet and its wealth of too-good-to-be-true success stories.         Consider Netcom On-Line Communication Services of San Jose, Calif., the nation's largest independent provider of Internet access, but which has yet to turn a profit. The company went public in December 1994 at $13 a share and by November of last year, the stock reached a high of $91.50 a share. The company's subscriber base has more than quadrupled, to 400,000 last week, and its revenues climbed to $52.4 million in 1995, up from $12.4 million the previous year.

headline: Environmentalists Fault Mutual Funds
abstract: Flush with cash, mutual funds are seeing green, but Co-op America, a Washington group that promotes socially conscious investing, contends that they  are not investing green.         The group reported yesterday that 15 of the nation's largest mutual funds, including those offered by Fidelity Investments, the Vanguard Group, Capital Research and Management Company and the Janus organization, owned $30 billion, or an average of $2 billion each, of shares of companies the group regards as environmentally unfriendly.

headline: Global Talks Covering Phones Near Deadline
abstract: Negotiators from 51 countries are racing against the clock at the World Trade Organization in Geneva this month, hoping to meet their self-imposed deadline of April 30 for an agreement on liberalizing trade in telecommunications.         At stake is the future of the global telecommunications industry, and possibly of the World Trade Organization itself. The goal of the talks is to open domestic telecommunications markets to foreign companies, potentially saving consumers billions of dollars. But an agreement would also put many sluggish national telephone companies at risk of being trampled by more efficient foreign competitors.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EXCITE AND MCKINLEY TO COMBINE INTERNET DIRECTORIES
abstract: Excite Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the McKinley Group,  the creator of the Magellan Internet guide, in the first consolidation of leading Internet directories. The companies said the deal, valued at $18 million, would position Excite as the second-largest Internet search and directory service, behind Yahoo Inc., which pioneered the concept two years ago. Excite, based in Mountain View, Calif., said that the deal would combine its reviews of 60,000 sites on the World Wide Web with 40,000 on Magellan. Under the preliminary agreement, Excite will trade 1.2 million of its shares for the closely held McKinley, based on its stock price in the last 30 days, and assume  an unspecified amount of debt. Shares of Excite fell 25 cents, to $8.25, well below their initial public offering price of $17 a share in April.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;JOSTENS SHARES DROP AFTER LOWER INCOME ESTIMATE
abstract: The shares of Jostens Inc. fell yesterday after the company said its fourth-quarter earnings would be less than analysts estimated, in part because of higher costs for publishing school yearbooks. The company, a provider of class rings, yearbooks and achievement awards, said it expected earnings for the quarter ending on June 30 of 74 cents to 79 cents a share, compared with profit  from continuing operations of 67 cents a year ago. The company was expected to earn 80 cents a share, the average estimate of three analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;St. Martin's Cancels Book On Goebbels
abstract: Chastened executives of St. Martin's Press this week halted publication of a  controversial new book by David Irving after the company was besieged by angry telephone calls about the historical biography that even the company's chairman  concluded was "inescapably anti-Semitic."         The company notified Mr. Irving Wednesday night about the cancellation of his book, "Goebbels: Mastermind of the Third Reich," with a faxed letter. The British author vowed in turn to distribute the book around the world on the Internet.

headline: Big Bidders Win Auction For the Small
abstract: It was billed as one of the Federal Government's biggest small-business programs in history, a chance for corporate have-nots to become players in the booming business of wireless communications.         But today, two years and $10.22 billion later, as the Federal Communications  Commission concluded a special auction of wireless licenses reserved for "small  business," it looked more like an investment program for Japanese and South Korean industrial conglomerates.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SECURE COMPUTING TO BUY BORDER NETWORK TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: The Secure Computing Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Border Network Technologies in a stock transaction valued at about $190 million. The merger would create the second-largest computer-network security company. Under the agreement, a half share of Secure common stock would be exchanged for  each of the roughly 13.1 million outstanding shares of Border. Secure Computing  had total revenues of $20.7 million for the year that ended on Dec. 31, while Border's revenues were $3.3 million. Secure's stock rose $1.25 yesterday, to $30.25, before the deal was announced.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC., Roseland, N.J., acquired Merrin Financial Inc. of New York, its second purchase in two weeks aimed at bolstering its financial services. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Real Estate;Fidelity is developing an office complex in Rhode Island as the state rolls out  the red carpet.
abstract: THE FMR Corporation, the parent of Fidelity Investments, is developing a new  office complex here as the mutual fund giant continues to expand outside its home state of Massachusetts.         The move has coincided with efforts by Massachusetts to give tax breaks to certain businesses to keep them operating and growing in the state.

headline: Trade Group Will Decide Kodak Case
abstract: As expected, United States trade officials said today that they would file three complaints with the World Trade Organization contending that the Japanese  Government had colluded with the Fuji Photo Film Company to exclude film made by the Eastman Kodak Company and other foreign producers.         "Our comprehensive investigation of the Japanese film market has shown that the Government of Japan built, supported and tolerated a market structure that thwarts foreign competition, and in which exclusionary business practices are commonplace," a deputy United States trade representative, Ira S. Shapiro, said.

headline: Haft Defeats Son in Fight for Real Estate Empire
abstract: The patriarch of the feuding Washington Haft family, Herbert Haft, has won control of the family's real estate empire in a case against his son Ronald.         Judge Geoffrey M. Alprin of the District of Columbia Superior Court ruled on  Tuesday against Ronald Haft and a business ally, Donald Bourassa, saying that they had acted with "willful, wanton and reckless disregard" of Herbert Haft's rights when they seized control of Combined Properties Inc., the family's real estate management company.

headline: The Long Unabom Manhunt Becomes a Paperback Sprint
abstract: With the shipment of its first load of Unabom paperbacks yesterday, it appears Warner Books has triumphed in a frantic literary 100-yard dash made fierce by its tantalizing prize: a quickie book with the shelf life of a head of lettuce.         Warner Books managed to overtake the erstwhile front-runner, Pocket Books --  the original pioneer of quickie books -- whose fuming lawyers and top executives were left to ponder whether to defy an F.B.I. bureaucracy that has effectively stalled their finished book.

headline: Americans Fleeing Liberia Tell of New Horrors There
abstract: Scores of Americans and others fleeing intense fighting by rival militias in  Liberia were evacuated today by United States troops and brought to Sierra Leone's main airport here on the first leg of their escape.         The shaken evacuees arrived throughout the day aboard lumbering American MH-53 helicopters, 25 people at a time. Those who made it painted a picture of a country whose slide out of control in the space of an Easter weekend surpassed any of the other horrors they had seen in six years of a vicious civil war.

headline: Abbott Agrees to Settle Baby-Formula Suit
abstract: Abbott Laboratories said today that it had agreed to settle, for $32.5 million, lawsuits brought by 17 states that contended it had fixed the price of  baby formula.         Abbott continues to maintain its innocence but settled to avoid further legal costs, said Rick Moser, a company spokesman. It agreed to pay a total of $25 million, as well as to provide $7.5 million worth of formula, Mr. Moser said.

headline: SPENDING IT;A Star Moves Out; The Aura Lives On
abstract: TALK about frustration. You've been shopping for a home, and despite having serious money to spend, you have yet to see the house of your dreams. Is it too  much to ask for something special? Something with bragging rights, something that would make friends ooh and aah?         Well, then, consider these gems now on the market here:

headline: World News Briefs;American Is Accused Of Embezzlement at U.N.
abstract: An American citizen holding a high-ranking United Nations position in Geneva  has been accused of forgery and embezzling as much as $500,000 from the agency where he works, the Secretary General's spokeswoman said today.

headline: A Ghost of Maoist Fervor Lives On in Disgrace
abstract: For 10 years, Wang Li worked side by side with Mao and then became one of the most ardent firebrands of the early Cultural Revolution, helping to topple scores of Communist Party elders, some of whom survived to rule again.         Now at age 75, he lives impoverished in a tiny apartment in western Beijing,  where he is ailing from stomach cancer. Since emerging in 1982 from prison, where he was held for 15 years, he has sent 104 petitions to the Chinese leadership seeking rehabilitation, but it has never come.

headline: Trust Is a Casualty of Israeli Attacks
abstract: Lebanon's Prime Minister said tonight that Israel's 16-day assault on his country had done deep damage to prospects for normal relations between the countries once they reach a peace accord.         The Prime Minister, Rafik al-Hariri, also questioned whether Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel, who launched the offensive aimed at Hezbollah guerrillas, has been entirely candid in saying that Israel has no territorial interest in Lebanon, where it has maintained a "security zone" since 1982.

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 33.96 points, or -0.16 percent, at 21660.47. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 97.27 points.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Finnair Says Profits Increased 27% in Year
abstract: Finland's national airline, Finnair, reported yesterday that its profit jumped by more than 27 percent in the year ended March 31. Finnair earned 533 million markkaa, or $113 million, in the latest year, compared with 419 million  markaa a year earlier. Revenues were 7.18 billion markkaa, up from 6.65 billion.   (AP)

headline: Fitzroy Maclean, War Hero And Author, Is Dead at 85
abstract: Sir Fitzroy Maclean, an intrepid Scot known for his farflung military adventures in World War II and his writings about faraway lands, died on Saturday at the home of friends whom he and his wife were visiting in the English county of Hertford. He was 85 and lived in Strachur House, the family home in Strachur, a village in the Scottish county of Argyll.         Sir Fitzroy, who was made a baronet in 1957, died of a heart attack, said his son Charles Maclean, who is the heir to the baronetcy.

headline: Kmart Vote Disputed
abstract: The Kmart Corporation said today that a shareholder proposal to force board members to stand for election annually had failed, but the union group that backed the issue disagreed.         Kmart, the nation's second-largest retailer, said the nonbinding proposal to  end the current staggered system of electing directors received only about 39 percent of shareholder votes cast earlier this month. But the union group said the proposal received 57 percent of the votes.

headline: Communists In Russia Unveil Plan For Economy
abstract: The Communist leader, Gennadi A. Zyuganov, released the outline of his economic program today, a plan to revive the economy by having Russia spend its  way out of industrial and agricultural decline and seal itself off from foreign  competition.         In sharp contrast to the free-market reforms of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Mr. Zyuganov's proposal, which is centered on tight government control and regulation of the economy, is the most specific he has offered to date. It calls for heavy state spending on industry, particularly the military-industrial complex, as well as on education and medical care. The proposal advocates strict price controls on consumer goods and raw materials and lowering energy prices to stimulate domestic production.

headline: Tapping the Power of Satellite TV;3 Broadcasters Aim for Arabic Speakers Around the World
abstract: Karim Abdallah, who was working as an executive at the Cable News Network during the Persian Gulf war, remembers vividly the thirst of the Arab world for  the kind of minute-by-minute news coverage that CNN provided during that conflict. He remembers, too, how eagerly local broadcasters in Egypt and Bahrain agreed, when given the chance in the early days of the war, to pass the  network's satellite feed to their viewers.         The lesson -- if, indeed, they needed it at all -- was not lost on some influential and wealthy Saudi businessmen interested both in an investment opportunity and in gaining some measure of control over the distribution of information and entertainment to 300 million Arabic speakers across the Middle East and North Africa.

headline: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Adapt karaoke for CD-ROM and what do you have? A copyright problem, it seems.
abstract: AS they careen into the information age, the media are increasingly becoming  the butts of their own jokes.         The Internet is awash in spoof press releases (some may recall the classic, "Microsoft Buys Catholic Church"). The comedian Dana Carvey simultaneously blisters and bows to the gods of advertising on his new television series. The hilarious cable television show "Mystery Science Theater 3000," now a feature film, provides acidic yet affectionate commentary on movies and pop culture via  two robots and a guy who sit in the front row of a theater and wisecrack their way through stunningly bad films.

headline: No Headline
Despite Doubts, Official Gives Go-Ahead to Bosnian Vote
abstract: The European diplomat in charge of organizing national elections in Bosnia said today that although conditions had not been met for free and fair elections, the vote should nevertheless go ahead in September as scheduled.         Under the Balkan peace plan the official, Flavio Cotti, as chairman of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, was supposed to certify that conditions in Bosnia will allow fair elections before setting a date and supervising the vote. But Mr. Cotti, who is also the Swiss Foreign Minister, came under intense pressure from the United States and Europe to give the go-ahead to the elections despite the serious misgivings he and other diplomats  had expressed about the wisdom of proceeding.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SmithKline Eliminates Dual Share Structure
abstract: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it had eliminated a dual share  structure in effect since the 1989 merger of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation  of the United States and Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain. SmithKline announced the share structure change on Feb. 20. SmithKline's class A and class B shares are being merged into one class of common shares. Preference shares are being redeemed at a total cost of about $295 million.          SmithKline formerly had two classes of shares. Each equity unit contained a  combination of preference shares and common shares and traded in London and New  York.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Russians Place Bets On Vote's Future(s)
abstract: Mixing politics and financial speculation, Russia's fledgling futures market  is wheeling and dealing over next month's presidential election.         The bets are not on who will win, but on the percentage of the vote that the  candidates will receive. With a crowded field of contenders and ever-shifting electoral alliances, betting opportunities abound.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT UNIT SELLS PROPERTIES
abstract: The ITT Community Development Corporation said late on Thursday that it had sold several of its properties to Palm Coast Holdings Inc., an affiliate of the  Minnesota Power and Light Company, for $34 million. The sale includes properties, retail lots and retail land sales contracts totaling about 13,000 acres of land. Palm Coast is a planned community on Florida's northeast coast. ITT Community, a unit of ITT Industries Inc., also said a Minnesota Powerunit acquired an option to buy Palm Coast Utility Corporation's water and sewer assets. ITT Community said remaining assets expected to be sold include parts of Hammock Dunes, an oceanfront golf community; the River Club, a residential project; and other undeveloped properties.

headline: Reporter's Notebook;Yeltsin Serves Visitors A Big Plateful of Politics
abstract: If the leaders of the world's richest countries had the slightest doubts about what has been on President Boris N. Yeltsin's mind lately, they disappeared Friday night at a sumptuous private dinner at the Kremlin Grand Palace.         Squirming in their seats as they washed down their fish pasties, black caviar, stuffed pike and wild goose with fine wine and Russian vodka, seven heads of state listened to Mr. Yeltsin deliver a rambling 45-minute monologue on himself and his prospects for re-election this June.

headline: Ferris Wheel Will Look Down on Big Ben
abstract: Deciding to roll in the millennium in a big way, London is preparing to construct a 500-foot-tall Ferris wheel -- the largest in the world -- that would rotate continuously on the south bank of the Thames and provide nearly 1,400 presumably non-acrophobic riders with spectacular views of the city's landmarks.         Current plans call for the giant wheel to be up for only five years, from 1998 to 2002, although historians might point out that the Eiffel Tower, designed for the International Exposition of 1889, was theoretically also a temporary structure.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MANHATTAN BAGEL REPORTS ACCOUNTING IRREGULARITIES
abstract: The Manhattan Bagel Company said yesterday that it had found improper accounting at its I& J West Coast unit and would have to restate its financial results for the first quarter. Manhattan Bagel, a chain of bagel shops that is based in Eatontown, N.J., said it would also investigate other possible financial irregularities. The company will reduce its first-quarter earnings per share to 9 cents from the 12 cents previously reported. The announcement was made after the markets closed. Earlier, the company's shares fell $4.875, to $21.25, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: Clinton to Act On Banning Many Types Of War Mines
abstract: President Clinton has decided to impose a ban on American use of a large variety of land mines beginning in 1999, with an exception for their use in Korea, and will commit the United States to the eventual elimination of all mines, Administration officials said today.         The President's decision, which is to be announced at the White House on Thursday, would halt the use of so-called dumb mines, which remain armed indefinitely, except in Korea. They have been seeded there in hopes of discouraging a North Korean invasion of South Korea.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;ISS A/S Stock Falls On Accounting Problems
abstract: The shares of the Danish cleaning company International Service System A/S fell sharply yesterday after it announced it had found irregularities in its United States unit's accounting. The company said that the New York-based unit's finance chief had left the company and that accounting irregularities might cost the company $100 million.         Profits may have been overstated at the unit by at least $30 million, the company said.     ISS's stock price plummeted 53 kroner in Copenhagen, to 110 kroner, before finally closing at 131. The company's American depository receipts fell $2.50, to $11, on the New York Stock Exchange.   (AP)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY

headline: I.B.M. Plans to Buy Back $2.5 Billion in Stock
abstract: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it planned to buy back another $2.5 billion of its stock.         Since Jan. 31, 1995, the world's biggest computer company purchased about $6.5 billion of its own stock to increase its earnings per share. While stock buy backs can sometimes raise a company's share price, I.B.M.'s stock has not performed as well as that of competitors.

headline: U.S. Medical Station Attacked in Burundi
abstract: Seven people were killed and 32 wounded today in an attack on Hutu who had taken refuge with American missionaries in Burundi, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Burundi said by telephone.         There was no claim of responsibility, but suspicion focused on the army, which is dominated by the majority Tutsi.

headline: 100,000 RUSSIANS RALLY IN MOSCOW TO BACK YELTSIN
abstract: As security measures tightened all over the city in the wake of Tuesday's deadly subway bombing, more than 100,000 people today celebrated Russia's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union in 1990 by attending a boisterous rock concert for President Boris N. Yeltsin. It was his biggest rally in Moscow since his rise to power in 1990 and 1991.         The helicopters, armored personnel carriers and hundreds of police and security service officers who patrolled the political pop concert alongside Red  Square were a sign of heightened tension four days before the presidential election. But the huge turnout was an astonishing display of support for Mr. Yeltsin, whose tarnished record and hated war in Chechnya have cut deep into his popularity even among pro-democratic voters in Moscow.

headline: World News Briefs;U.S. Accuses 7 Nations Of Aiding Terrorists
abstract: The State Department issued its annual report about terrorism around the world today and listed the same seven countries as last year as sponsors of international terrorism.         Despite the recent agreement with Syria to try to curb violence in Lebanon, Syria remains on the list.

headline: INVESTING IT;Unsightly Veins? Zap. Wall St. Woes? Zap.
abstract: KATHLEEN LYONS-BOSWICK was perched on an examining table on a recent Saturday afternoon in the Pascack Valley Hospital in northern New Jersey, surrounded by dermatologists and vein specialists. She has had varicose and spider veins on her legs for years, but the treatment she had just received from a $135,000 laser-like machine has made some of the veins fainter -- and made her much happier.         "I can tell you right now," she said, pointing to one area after a demonstration of the technology, "this is better."

headline: BID FOR COALITION TO BAR COMMUNIST FADES IN MOSCOW
abstract: Hopes that Russian democrats had of forging a united front against the Communist Party in next month's presidential election suffered badly today when  President Boris N. Yeltsin's main liberal challenger harshly rejected all pleas  that he abandon his long-shot quest for the presidency.         For weeks Mr. Yeltsin has been courting Grigory A. Yavlinsky, the popular 44-year-old liberal leader, whose candidacy many people feel can only help the Communists by leeching votes from Mr. Yeltsin on election day, June 16. More than once the President has suggested that a deal was near. More than once Mr. Yavlinsky has responded by simply making new demands.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: MONDAY Bellsouth Corp Standard Prods Co

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:          ACC Consumer Finance Corp., San Diego, an initial public offering of 2 million shares. Montgomery Securities.

headline: Stocks Lower in Japan
abstract: Stocks traded lower here today, after a long holiday weekend. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 167.10 points, or nearly eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,495.28. On Monday, Japanese financial markets were closed in observance of Children's Day.
