headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan and U.S. Fail To Agree on Insurance
abstract: Two days of talks ended yesterday without agreement on ways to open up Japan's insurance industry to United States competition. No date has been set for the next meeting, but Japan is "willing to meet anytime, anywhere," an official of the Ministry of Finance said.          The major disagreement remains over the so-called third-sector insurance, a  niche that accounts for about 5 percent of Japan's overall market.  In Japan, American companies now concentrate on third-sector coverage -- specialized insurance that Japanese companies do not offer, like supplemental health coverage for catastrophic illness, nursing care and personal accident insurance.   (AP)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Singapore Video Accord
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications Ltd., the national telephone operator of Singapore, said today that it had signed an agreement with Time Warner Cable, a  subsidiary of Time Warner Inc., to form a partnership for video-on-demand projects.

headline: N.A.S.D. Fines a Member And Vows Stiff Regulation
abstract: The regulatory arm of the National Association of Securities Dealers has fined one of its largest brokerage firm members $75,000 for trading ahead of its customers and plans to announce today a big increase in the amount it spends to  enforce rules in the Nasdaq stock market.         The fine was levied against Mayer & Schweitzer, a subsidiary of Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm. The N.A.S.D., which operates Nasdaq, said Mayer had executed other orders ahead of customer orders to sell stocks that were falling in price. As a result, the N.A.S.D. said, the customers were treated unfairly.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;CASTLE HARLAN TO BUY FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS INSURANCE
abstract: Castle Harlan Inc. and the chief executive of Financial Institutions Insurance Group Ltd., John Dore, agreed yesterday to buy Financial Institutions  for $54 million. Castle Harlan, a New York-based merchant bank, and Mr. Dore signed a definitive agreement to pay $16 for each common share of Financial Institutions, an insurance holding company based in Wilmington, Del. Financial Institutions has offices in Chicago and Avon, Conn., and assets of more than $94 million. In Nasdaq trading yesterday, shares of Financial Institutions rose  75 cents, to $16. The agreement is the latest step in the effort by Castle Harlan to build its specialty insurance business.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Top Property Developer Is Arrested in Japan A leading Japanese real estate developer has been arrested in a growing investigation into the roots of Japan's debt crisis. The arrest of Kichinosuke Sasaki, president of Togensha, comes as big property debtors and the banks that  lent them billions of yen face increasingly sharp public criticism.

headline: World News Briefs;Yeltsin Assures Clinton On June Election
abstract: President Clinton received assurances today from President Boris N. Yeltsin that Russia would move ahead as scheduled with a presidential election in June.          The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said the two leaders spoke by telephone for 20 minutes and that Mr. Yeltsin repeated the statements he had made publicly in Russia on Monday, disassociating himself from a call by  his confidant, Maj. Gen. Aleksandr V. Korzhakov, for the election to be postponed.

headline: Nabisco to Eliminate 4,200 Jobs And Trim Product Line by 14%
abstract: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation, the maker of Oreos, Bubble Yum and other snack foods, said yesterday that it would discharge about 8 percent of its employees and eliminate nearly 14 percent of its products in an effort to trim operating costs by 2.5 percent.         The company, the food side of the RJR Nabisco tobacco and food company, said  half of the 4,200 job cuts would occur in the United States. Nabisco Holdings employs 54,000 people worldwide.

headline: COMPANY NEWS
abstract: HANCOCK HOLDING CO., a banking company in Gulfport, Miss., will acquire Community Bancshares, Independence, La., for about $22 million.

headline: Alco Standard to Split Into 2 Companies
abstract: In the final dismantling of a once-huge conglomerate, the Alco Standard Corporation announced yesterday that it would divide into two companies -- one a distributor of paper products and the other of office copiers and fax machines.          The jewel in this spinoff is Ikon Office Solutions, the office copier division, with $3 billion in annual revenues. Although smaller than the paper distributor, Unisource Worldwide Inc., which has $7 billion in revenues, analysts called Ikon a fast-growing operation likely to achieve, in New York Stock Exchange trading, a higher price-to-earnings ratio than Alco does now.

headline: More Suitors Weigh Making Bid for MGM
abstract: With a deadline of 11:30 A.M. today for bids for the MGM/UA Entertainment Company, some companies were still deciding yesterday whether to jump into the fray. A winner could be announced as early as this week but perhaps not for a month, people familiar with the talks said.         Lazard Freres & Company, the investment banking firm, is handling the sale of MGM. The winning bidder will be determined by Consortium de Realisation, an arm of the French Government. MGM is owned by Credit Lyonnais.

headline: Real Estate;Real estate agents in New York City are trying to clear up a local tax situation.
abstract: A DISPUTE between the New York City Finance Department and several groups of  real estate agents over the city's unincorporated business tax has eased after the department issued guidelines on which agents should pay the 4 percent income tax. Still, a series of appeals have been filed.         At issue is whether real estate agents are employees of their firms or independent contractors, who would have to pay the tax.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Job Market Booms, Raising Inflation Fears Employers added twice as many workers as expected to their payrolls in May. The  Labor Department reported that payrolls expanded by 348,000, a solid indication  that the economy is picking up momentum. The news sent interest rates soaring and raised fears that the Federal Reserve might move soon to slow growth to curb inflation.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;RITE AID TO END EXTENSION FOR REVCO ACQUISITION
abstract: The Rite Aid Corporation notified the Federal Trade Commission yesterday that it was ending the rolling 10-day extension of the regulatory waiting period for  its planned acquisition of Revco D.S. Inc. The move means that the F.T.C. has 10 days to come to an agreement with Rite-Aid. At that point, the company could proceed with the purchase unless the F.T.C. went to court to stop it. Rite Aid said it was negotiating with the F.T.C. in hopes of reaching an agreement before the waiting period, which is required by the Hart-Scott-Rodino antitrust  law, ends on April 19. On that day, Rite Aid's $1.8 billion tender offer for Revco is set to expire. The tender offer has already been extended several times. Revco is based in Twinsburg, Ohio, and Rite Aid is based in Camp Hill, Pa. Both are drugstore chains.

headline: Hard Landing at Denver;The S.E.C. Questions Disclosure on Airport Bonds
abstract: Way back in 1990, when the Denver International Airport was, literally, just  a hole in the ground, local officials were warned by their own consultants that  the baggage system that would later shred luggage and become a national joke was horribly flawed and might not work.         But this critical information was never conveyed to the investors who, in 1991 and 1992, ponied up some $3.5 billion for airport bonds. And now the Securities and Exchange Commission, in one of the most controversial cases in municipal finance, wants to hold some feet to the fire.

headline: Catalan Leader Holds Keys to Madrid
abstract: Jordi Pujol does not behave like a power-hungry radical. In his Barcelona office, a 14th-century palace, he keeps a photograph of King Juan Carlos. Liveried attendants bring him coffee and letters from a gothic courtyard filled with orange trees. On the telephone, the leader of Catalonia quietly and  easily switches from Spanish into French and English and back into Catalan.         Yet at 66, this Catalan nationalist has clearly enjoyed holding the keys to power in Spain. For the last 57 days, he sat back as conservative politicians from Madrid came to Barcelona to court him and to negotiate. They were the same  politicians who during the recent election campaign had scorned him as an uppity provincial lord, a man who would soon have to be put in his place.

headline: Negotiations Begin on Auto Industry Pact
abstract: Officials from the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were carrying baseball bats when they showed up here today for the ritual of opening negotiations on a three-year labor contract, but their meeting was cordial and largely ceremonial.         Stephen P. Yokich, the president of the U.A.W., and his aides brought two baseball bats given to them by activists who urged them to "go to bat" to stop auto makers from buying more parts from outside companies. Warned how Mr. Yokich had armed himself for the talks, Alexander J. Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive, picked up his own bat to show that he could play ball with the union.

headline: Russian Military Halts Assault on the Chechen Rebels
abstract: Responding to the command of President Boris N. Yeltsin, Russian forces today stopped their continuous aerial and ground assault on the mutinous republic of Chechnya.         After two weeks of some of the worst fighting and the most aggressive bombing of the 15-month war, silence spread across the major battlefields in southern Chechnya. There were still isolated battles, according to television news reports from the region, but there were no major mortar, helicopter or bomber attacks.

headline: INVESTING WITH: John L. Wallace;Robertson Stephens Growth and Income Fund
abstract: WHEN the broad stock market is treading water, a gifted stock picker rises to the occasion. So if you're part of the legion of market watchers who are convinced that prices are topping out for the year, you might want to direct your money to such a fund manager.         John L. Wallace, who runs the Robertson Stephens Growth and Income fund, was  quite the iconoclast at the Oppenheimer Main Street Income and Growth fund, which he left nearly a year ago. By concentrating on small growth stocks, Mr. Wallace amassed an impressive record there. From the Oppenheimer fund's beginning in 1988 until Mr. Wallace's departure last July (omitting a one-year hiatus for a reorganization), the fund's annualized return was 26.7 percent, far exceeding the 15.9 percent average for growth and income funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund tracking company in Chicago.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Commerce Secretary Lost In Croatian Plane Crash A military plane carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and a delegation of American corporate leaders slammed into a mountainside as it approached the airport at Dubrovnik, on the Adriatic coast of Croatia. Chances that Mr. Brown,  a 54-year-old political insider, had survived were "next to zero," a White House official said.

headline: Slight Rebound In Indicator of Chip Demand
abstract: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded slightly in May, although it still pointed to weak demand, providing a first sign that the five-month-old slump might be nearing an end, a trade group said today.   The report came after the close of the stock market, but analysts said it was likely to bolster semiconductor stocks, many of which are trading at historic lows. A protracted glut of memory chips has caused a free fall in prices, prompting several large manufacturers to cut back production plans.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;MCDONNELL DOUGLAS IS CONSIDERING 400-SEAT JET
abstract: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is considering building a 400-seat long-haul jet to compete with the Boeing 747, The Financial Times reported in today's issue. But the company said late last night that it had no immediate plans to build such a jet and called the newspaper's report "overstated and out  of context." The newspaper quoted Michael Sears, who was named president of the  Douglas Aircraft Company earlier this week, as saying the new jet could use the fuselage of McDonnell's 300-seat MD-11, while it would need to have new wings. "We know the MD-11 needs a big brother," Mr. Sears told the newspaper. "Over the next six months or so we will define what we would like to do with that big brother." The company said in a statement that "McDonnell is accelerating design and marketing studies of a variety of options to enhance our family of widebody aircraft."

headline: Okinawan Landlords Seek To Evict U.S. Military Bases
abstract: One of the most secretive American military installations in Asia is "the elephants' cage," a vast circle of steel towers used to eavesdrop on Chinese and North Korean military communications.         The elephants' cage cannot exactly be hidden, in that it covers an area the size of a football field and soars 90 feet in the air, but American and Japanese officials alike quickly insist that they have no clue what it does -- and then quickly change the subject.

headline: U.S. Diplomat Told Staff to Be Optimistic on Bosnia Vote
abstract: The American diplomat heading the team in Bosnia that is supposed to determine whether fair elections are feasible there instructed his staff last week to focus more on positive developments in their weekly reports, rather than detailing the litany of obstacles to free elections.         The decision by Robert H. Frowick, head of the Bosnian mission of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, to reorient the internal reporting of his staff has angered many within the mission.

headline: Union Pacific's Plan to Merge Hits Resistance At 3 Agencies
abstract: The Justice, Transportation and Agriculture Departments said yesterday that they were against a proposed $3.9 billion merger of the Union Pacific Corporation and the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation.         While the Justice Department's word can often make or break mergers, it has carried less weight in the railroad industry, which has seen steady consolidation since it was deregulated in 1980.

headline: Technology: ON THE NET;With a credit card and a modem, a search for commerce on the World Wide Web. Like a child's story, it could begin, 'Once upon a time . . .'
abstract: THERE was no way of knowing it back in May 1963. But a science book in the first-grade classroom at the Possum School would color my adult views of Utopian visions of technology in general, and of the World Wide Web in particular.         The school, near my home in semi-rural Possum Woods, Ohio, was a provincial place of modest resources. But it was a time when NASA's Mercury project was in  full throttle and "The Jetsons" were on ABC every Sunday night.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.25   8.25   9.00       DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.25       FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.25   5.28   5.97       3-MO. headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Royal Ahold Sells Shares To Raise $1.8 Million
abstract: The Dutch grocery giant Royal Ahold N.V. said yesterday that it planned to raise $1.8 billion through the sale of 36 million shares to pay for its planned  purchase of the Stop and Shop Companies, New England's largest grocery chain. Of the 36 million shares, 14 million are being offered in the United States. The new voting shares will be listed on the Amsterdam, Brussels and Zurich stock exchanges, with American depository receipts listed on the New York Stock Exchange.          Royal Ahold said it expected the shares to be sold after the close of business on July 16. The company had almost 125 million common shares outstanding at the end of the first quarter. Ahold's American depository receipts were up 87.5 cents yesterday, to $54.375 a share.   (Dow Jones)

headline: Japanese Stocks Lower
abstract: Stocks were trading lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,815.01, up 226.29 points, or 1.03 percent. On Tuesday, the index lost 193.73 points.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Indian Police Doubt Bombing in Collapse
abstract: Indian police said today that they could not explain the collapse of a guest  house in New Delhi on Saturday in which 17 people were killed, including eight foreigners, saying no trace of explosive material was found in the debris.         Two separatist groups in Kashmir, one of which had not been known previously, had claimed responsibility for the collapse.

headline: Many Tourists Delay Trips to Israel and Egypt, but Few Cancel
abstract: Egyptian and Israeli officials in the United States said yesterday that many  would-be tourists to their countries had delayed scheduled departures after the  killing of 18 Greek tourists in Cairo on Thursday and the Israeli Army's killing of at least 75 civilians in Lebanon on the same day. But so far, they said, there have been relatively few cancellations.         Tourism officials recognize the potential impact of violence in a region heavily dependent on tourist dollars. In 1994, the last year for which figures are available, Israel earned $2.2 billion from tourism and Egypt earned $1.4 billion, according to the World Tourism Organization in Madrid.

headline: Marines Kill 3 Liberians in an Attack Near U.S. Embassy
abstract: United States marines shot to death three intruders and wounded a fourth near the American Embassy compound in the Liberian capital today, a day after a 10-day-old truce was broken by renewed street battles.         In all, the marines counted four separate shooting incidents around the embassy and the Ambassador's residence in Monrovia, the capital.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;D.M.B.& B. Is Planning To Buy Italian Agency
abstract: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles said yesterday that it would acquire Barbella Gagliardi Saffirio in Turin and Milan, Italy, and merge it with its three offices in Italy to form B.G.S./D.M.B.& B. Though D.M.B.& B. would not disclose  terms of the acquisition, the agency company said it would create the largest international communications group in Italy, with billings estimated at $190 million.          Barbella Gagliardi Saffirio brings in billings estimated at $110 million from clients like Fiat S.p.A., to be added to D.M.B.& B.'s $80 million in billings from clients like Mars Inc. Pasquale Barbella, 54; Pietro Gagliardi, 52, and Silvio Saffirio, 53, the co-managing directors at Barbella Gagliardi Saffirio, were named co-chief executives at B.G.S./ D.M.B.& B. Gavino Sanna, 56, retains the title of president.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;SONY TO ACQUIRE SOFTWARE MAKER
abstract: The American unit of the Sony Corporation agreed yesterday to buy a maker of  digital mapping and navigation software from the News Corporation for an undisclosed price. The company being acquired, Etak Inc., will give the Sony Corporation of America the technology to expand its mobile navigation business.  Sony introduced its first car navigation system in Japan in June 1992 and began  selling it in the United States in 1994. The system, which costs about $3,000, uses small computer monitors that are installed in cars and track a vehicle's position on a computerized map via satellites. Etak introduced the first car navigation system for consumers in 1985, two years after the company was founded. Etak was acquired by the News Corporation in 1989.

headline: Chilean Link to Sumitomo Scandal Denied
abstract: Juan Pablo Davila, who has been at the center of copper trading scandal at Codelco, a state-owned copper producer, today dismissed speculation that he had  done business with a former Sumitomo trader accused of generating $1.8 billion in losses.         The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday that regulators were interested in locating a document that had been described by metals trader as possibly linking Sumitomo's trading losses to those suffered by the Chilean copper company and by the China International Trust and Investment Corporation, or Citic. The document, according to the trader, was a sales pitch prepared in 1993 by the Winchester Commodities Corporation of Britain and described the three companies as clients.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Mark Schwatka was named to the new position of senior vice president and senior  creative director at Grey Advertising, New York. He had been an executive vice president and executive creative director at Bates USA, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;More Job Cuts Set at Apple As Loss Exceeds Estimates
abstract: Burdened by its own internal turmoil and a broad slowdown in personal computer sales, Apple Computer Inc. reported a $740 million loss for the second  quarter, somewhat larger than it had predicted a month ago. The company also said that it would eliminate another 1,500 jobs in the next 12 months, in addition to the 1,300 job cuts previously announced.         Some analysts had been expecting far more drastic cuts, and it seemed unlikely that today's announcement about job cuts, made after the stock market closed, would restore confidence in the struggling computer maker.

headline: SPENDING IT;Need Tax Help? So Do the Experts in Washington
abstract: IT is estimated that about half the Americans who file Form 1040 income-tax returns do the work themselves, spending an average of 12 hours trying to understand the complex laws of the tax system. Many of these 59 million taxpayers will be stuck inside today, trying to complete their returns before tomorrow's filing deadline.         If that isn't frustrating enough, here is a much smaller number to ponder: Of the almost five dozen Senators and Representatives who write the nation's tax laws, only six said they did their own taxes. Most of the rest don't deal with the prose they helped to inspire, instructions like: "Subtract line 8 from line  7. If zero or less, skip lines 10 through 13, enter zero on line 14 below, and go to line 15." Instead, they hire professionals to figure out what it all means.

headline: Mutiny in Central Africa
abstract: Soldiers took control of the center of this capital city today and surrounded the presidential palace in the second mutiny in the Central African Republic in  as many months.         Civilians fled and traffic ground to a halt as about 200 soldiers spread out  across Bangui demanding wages for April and May and control of the national armory.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan's Jobless Rate Rose to 3.5% in May
abstract: Japan's unemployment rate reached a record high in May as the recovery failed to create enough jobs for people flooding into the labor market. The jobless rate rose to 3.5 percent in May from 3.4 percent in April, data showed yesterday.          Unemployment for men hit a record 3.6 percent, from 3.3 percent a month earlier. The rate for women fell from a record 3.7 percent in April to 3.4 percent in May.   (Reuters)

headline: America Keeps Peace, Clinton Tells Coast Guard
abstract: President Clinton mounted a broad defense of his foreign policy yesterday, arguing that in military deployments in Haiti and Bosnia and in his fight for free trade, he had chosen the unpopular course and left America better off for it.         In his second foreign policy address of the week, Mr. Clinton told the graduating class of the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., that he had trod a careful course in an era lacking the clear superpower  delineation of the cold war.

headline: Insurer Weighs Sale While Reinsurer Bids for a Rival
abstract: The insurance industry moved toward further consolidation yesterday as a major life insurance company said it was considering a sale and a large Bermuda-based reinsurance broker bid nearly $1 billion to buy one of its competitors.         The life insurance company, the First Colony Corporation, issued a statement  yesterday that said its board was considering a number of alternatives aimed at increasing its stock price.

headline: Bell Labs Operating System To Be Offered for Networks
abstract: Lucent Technologies, which was formed by the recent split-up of AT&T, said today that it would soon begin marketing an operating system developed by Bell Labs for use on interactive networks.         The operating system, named Inferno, is intended to operate either on a stand-alone basis in new computing and communications devices, or as an adjunct  to existing operating systems like Microsoft Windows 95 and Windows NT or Unix.

headline: Inherited Damage Is Found In Chernobyl Area Children
abstract: Ten years after the disastrous nuclear accident at the Chernobyl power plant  in the Ukraine, scientists report that they have found inherited genetic damage  in people exposed to the fallout.

headline: Market Place;What Fuels Nasdaq Rise? A Handful Of Big Issues
abstract: It looks like heaven for smaller stocks these days. But in fact it is bigger  stocks that are providing a lot of the action in the Nasdaq stock market.         Yesterday, for the ninth trading day in a row, the Nasdaq composite index set a record closing high. With yesterday's rise of 2.38 points, to 1,190.58, the index is up 6.2 percent in those nine sessions, a much better performance than either that of the Standard & Poor's 500 or the Dow Jones industrial average. [Page D8.]

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wunderman Cato Scales Back an Office
abstract: Wunderman Cato Johnson, the direct response and sales promotion unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., will reduce its presence in Los Angeles from a full-service office to a field office.         "We had lost some key accounts in that office" like Countrywide Financial, said Allan Winneker, president of the North American division of Wunderman Cato  in Chicago, adding that "we felt we could provide better service" for remaining  clients, which include Mattel Inc. and Nintendo of America, from full-service offices in Chicago and New York. Wunderman Cato also has a field office in Irvine, Calif.

headline: EARNING IT;A High-Tech Headhunter Who Knows His Prey
abstract: WHEN James Cannavino retired from I.B.M. last spring at age 51, he received hundreds of job offers. He had run many of the company's business units during his 32 years there and was a hot property in high-technology circles.         But he was determined to take at least a year off. He wanted to build a home  in West Palm Beach, Fla., and then to sort leisurely through the best opportunities. He considered himself unrecruitable in the short run.

headline: Quebec's Premier Softens His Stance on Independence
abstract: He has stopped his furious assaults on the federal Government and hardly mentions Quebec independence. Instead, Premier Lucien Bouchard now speaks of the "shared values" of French- and English-speakers and quotes the Quebec-born, English-language writer Joyce Marshall, who said it is "the rub and bite of difference that keeps us alert and alive."         On the night of Oct. 30, after the separatists narrowly lost the independence referendum, Mr. Bouchard suggested that another vote could come as early as 1996. Now, he tells Quebecers, he will call one only when he is sure of winning  and in any case not before the next provincial election, which must come before  September 1999.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Saudis Bar Some Africans As Health Risk to Mecca
abstract: Saudi Arabia has banned Muslims from four African countries from making this  year's pilgrimage to Mecca because of an outbreak of meningitis in Nigeria, Mali, Niger and Burkina Faso.         Saudi Arabia's official news agency, in a report late Sunday, quoted a Health Ministry official as saying the decision was made on the basis of information provided by the World Health Organization.

headline: Computer Issues In Retreat, With Dow Declining 36.57
abstract: Stocks fell yesterday as semiconductor and computer issues retreated for a second day on concerns that second-quarter earnings would prove disappointing.         "Every quarter at this time you get the bad news," said Ray Hirsch, who heads up technology company research at American Express Financial Advisors Inc., which has more than $150 billion in assets. "Investors start wondering, 'What if they're all going to do this?' "

headline: Lower Rates Raise Resales Of Single-Family Homes
abstract: Sales of previously owned homes jumped 6.9 percent in March to the highest level in more than two years as buyers responded to low mortgage rates.         The National Association of Realtors said sales of existing single-family homes were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.21 million, up from 3.94 million in February.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;PRONET SHARES LOSE OVER A THIRD OF THEIR VALUE
abstract: The stock of Pronet Inc. lost more than a third of its value yesterday after  the company said its earnings for the second quarter would be below Wall Street's expectations. The Dallas-based Pronet, a wireless-communications services provider, said the lower earnings projections were attributable to competitive pricing and said it expected operating earnings for the three months ending June 30 to be between $5.3 million and $5.7 million. Pronet said earnings for the rest of 1996 are expected to be even with second-quarter results or slightly lower. Pronet stock closed at $11.50, down $6.8125, or 33.7  percent, in Nasdaq trading.

headline: FIRST HAGUE TRIAL FOR BOSNIA CRIMES OPENS ON TUESDAY
abstract: The first international war crimes trials since those that judged German and  Japanese leaders after World War II begin on Tuesday in The Hague, part of an effort by outside powers to provide a measure of justice for the thousands of massacred and maimed innocents in the former Yugoslavia.         But the trials are a shadow of those conducted five decades ago at Nuremberg  and Tokyo. The commanders who ordered the killing of thousands, unlike those found responsible for genocide during World War II, remain at large. The NATO-led military force in Bosnia, although virtually an occupying power, has steadfastly refused to arrest those indicted on charges of war crimes. And evidence often remains in the hands of those suspected of commiting the crimes.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;BRENDLE'S SEEKS BANKRUPTCY COURT PROTECTION
abstract: Brendle's Inc. said yesterday that it had closed the doors of 18 stores and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Brendle's, known for its jewelry, housewares and gifts, said it would shed some merchandise lines and focus on five categories: party goods, crafts, personal health care, fitness and outdoor  products. The Foothill Capital Corporation, the company's secured lender, is providing a $25 million revolving credit line, Brendle's said. The company, based in Elkin, N.C., said its lease liabilities and the investment needed for a reorganization had forced the decision to file for bankruptcy. Brendle's plans to continue to sell jewelry. It sells party goods under the Party Universe name.

headline: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Homosexual Rights Bill Clears Canadian Senate
abstract: The Canadian Senate passed a bill today to ban discrimination against homosexuals in federal agencies and federally regulated companies, clearing the  way for the pioneering legislation to become law.         Parliament's lower chamber, the elected House of Commons, passed the bill on  May 9 after bitter debate and awaited approval from the Senate, the appointed upper chamber.

headline: Ally of Yeltsin And Reformer Out as Mayor
abstract: The Mayor of St. Petersburg, a liberal who was an early, close ally of Boris  N. Yeltsin and remains a symbol of Russia's reform movement, narrowly lost his bid for re-election on Sunday to his former deputy.

headline: NBC Will Buy Rockefeller Center Space
abstract: They will not even officially take title to the property till later this month, but Rockefeller Center's new owners have already sold a huge chunk of one of the center's 12 landmarked buildings.         Yesterday NBC announced that it would pay $440 million for the 1.6 million square feet it has long occupied at 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the flagship building  of the 63-year-old complex.

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: VESTRA TECHNOLOGIES INC., San Ramon, Calif., which provides radioactive-waste services and specialized engineering services, agreed to sell its nuclear engineering, government services and power services businesses to privately held Duke Engineering and Services Inc. for $27.5 million in cash.

headline: South Korea Asks Countries to Press The North on Border
abstract: The South Korea Government is asking Japan, China and Russia and other countries, to bring pressure to bear on North Korea to prevent further incursions by North Korean troops into its sensitive border area, a spokesman for South Korea's Foreign Ministry said today. He also said that Seoul is considering bringing the matter to the United Nations Security Council.         Nevertheless, there was relative calm tonight along the so-called joint security area at the border village of Panmunjon and South Koreans, feeling little threat, mainly went about their normal routines today.

headline: World News Briefs;Explosion in Brazil Mall Kills 44 and Injures 100
abstract: An explosion in a shopping mall on the outskirts of Sao Paulo at lunchtime today blew holes in concrete walls and killed 44 people. More than 100 others were injured. Rescue workers expected to find more bodies beneath the rubble, said Lieut. Col. Edson Alves Domingues of the Sao Paulo fire department.

headline: When On-Line Service Cannot Be Counted On
abstract: Blame sunspots or planetary alignment, computer gremlins or human error. More than a million computer network users suffered interrupted or erratic Internet and on-line service connections last week because of a variety of planned and unplanned service shutdowns.         Because of a single bad line in a computer program, Netcom On-Line Communications Inc. had to shut down its entire national system for 12 hours on Wednesday, affecting more than 400,000 Internet users, most of them businesses.

headline: Cockburn Town Journal;Rule, Britannia! Outpost of the Empire Is Restless
abstract: Normally, the only vessels that ply the tranquil turquoise waters of this easygoing British colony are yachts, diving skiffs and other pleasure craft. So  when a British frigate bristling with missiles and torpedoes dropped anchor here recently, local residents were not sure whether to be angry or amused.         Ostensibly, the frigate, the Brave, was merely making a courtesy call to this isolated corner of the West Indies, an archipelago of some 30 islands 600 miles  southeast of Miami. But because the elected government of the Turks and Caicos has been demanding since the start of the year that London dismiss its unpopular appointed Governor here, Martin Bourke, the warship's arrival was interpreted as a warning and a threat.

headline: EUROPE MAY EASE BRITISH-BEEF BAN
abstract: Leaders of the European Union's 15 member countries agreed today to a plan that would gradually allow the British to resume exporting beef. In response, Britain ended its monthlong disruption of the union's decision-making.         But exports would resume only after experts from all 15 countries certified to its Executive Commission in Brussels that the meat was free of contamination  from the so-called mad cow disease, a fatal brain disease that has undermined consumer confidence in all beef. Consumption of meat from infected animals has been tentatively linked to a fatal brain disease in humans.

headline: Fox and TCI In Discussions About Offering News Channel
abstract: Fox Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc., the largest cable operator in the country, are discussing a partnership that would lead to distribution of Fox's new 24-hour news channel into as many as 10 million homes served by TCI.         Executives familiar with the negotiations confirmed yesterday that talks were taking place but said that a deal had not been reached and might become part of  wider talks between the two companies. Word of the discussions was first reported yesterday in Variety, the entertainment-industry publication.

headline: New York Brokerage Is Accused of Fraud
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused a New York brokerage firm yesterday of defrauding New York University and other clients by making unauthorized stock trades and refusing to execute sales orders.         In pressing its case against A. R. Baron & Company and two of its principals  -- its chief executive, Andrew Bressman, and a trader, Roman Okin -- the S.E.C.  is seeking a temporary cease and desist order. That order would require the firm to appoint an independent compliance officer and give the S.E.C. a sworn accounting of all money paid to the company's principals since January 1995.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Canadian Press Empire to Face Scrutiny
abstract: Canadian regulatory officials said today that they would take a hard look at  Conrad Black's aggressive moves to expand his newspaper empire in Canada.         They said they would examine whether Mr. Black's proposal to acquire all of the newspaper publisher Southam Inc. would give his company, Hollinger Inc., too much control over the Canadian press. Hollinger already owns 38 of Canada's 106  dailies, although most of its papers are smaller.

headline: Enron Pipeline Deal
abstract: Enron Global Power and Pipelines L.L.C. has agreed to acquire a 50 percent interest in the Centragas natural gas pipeline in Colombia from Enron's parent company, the Enron Corporation, for about $40 million in stock. The 357-mile Centragas pipeline has a capacity of 100 million cubic feet of gas a day. In the deal announced this week, Enron Global will exchange 1.6 million newly issued shares for the pipeline stake. The Enron Corporation, based in Houston, owns 52  percent of Enron Global and the stake will be 55 percent once the transaction is completed.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
abstract: Premiere Technologies Inc., Atlanta, to the Fitzgerald & Co. division of the Fitzgerald Cos., Atlanta, to handle the account of the telecommunications provider, which had been handled in-house. Another Fitzgerald unit, Julie Davis  Associates, Atlanta, will handle public relations for the Premiere Worldlink Card. Total billings were estimated at more than $4 million. Quantel, Newbury, Berkshire, England, to Farago Advertising, New York, as first  American agency of record for the digital equipment manufacturer. Billings were  estimated at $2 million to $3 million. The European portion of the account is handled by the CSA Partnership Ltd., London.

headline: Of a Mr. Fix-It And a Legacy Of Spending
abstract: How a Would-Be Mr. Fix-It Left a Company in Ruins" (March 24), by Kurt Eichenwald, examined the rise and recent fall of Paul G. Kahn as chairman of the Ideon Group, formerly Safecard Services. The article, which discussed Mr. Kahn's spending on Ideon projects that were later abandoned, drew reader responses from within and outside the company.

headline: Market Place;Say 'Internet' And Watch Zenith Soar
abstract: Zenith Electronics has a grand brand name and a lot of red ink. Now it also has a hot stock.         Yesterday, Zenith shares leaped $7.125, to $22.875, after their opening on the New York Stock Exchange was delayed for 19 minutes by a surge of buy orders. That came after the stock soared last week.

headline: Thermo Electron Purchase
abstract: The Thermo Electron Corporation has an agreement to buy Medical Data Electronics, a private manufacturer of patient-monitoring systems, based in Pacoima, Calif. Financial terms were not disclosed. The purchase of Medical Data, which had 1995 sales of $34 million, is part of a plan by Thermo Electron  to expand its biomedical businesses.  Thermo Electron, based in Waltham, makes environmental and health monitoring systems. It has annual sales of about $2.2 billion.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;An antidrug campaign takes aim at heroin -- and its image
abstract: THE Partnership for a Drug-Free America will introduce today its first national campaign aimed at fighting the use of heroin, which is also its initial antidrug effort aimed at those ages 18 to 25.         The broadcast and print public-service advertising seeks to diminish the appeal of heroin -- unsell it, if you will -- by dispelling perceptions that the drug is glamorous or stylish. But the campaign, like other such pitches, faces a difficult task because it must convey a serious message without resorting to scare tactics or bathos, which could alienate the audience it hopes to reach.

headline: World News Briefs;2 More Fled North Korea, Authorities in South Say
abstract: A scientist and a writer from North Korea have defected and are seeking political asylum in South Korea, South Korean authorities said today.         News reports here said the two sought asylum separately through the South Korean Embassy in Beijing and were transferred to two different Southeast Asian  countries for their final journey to Seoul.

headline: Cold to Cold Calling
abstract: To the Editor:         Re "Life of a Cold Caller: Riding on a Smile and a Thick Skin" (March 24):

headline: COMPANY NEWS;EA INDUSTRIES ACQUIRES STAKE IN AYDIN
abstract: The electronic manufacturing concern EA Industries said yesterday that it had bought 11.7 percent of the Aydin Corporation from its chief executive for $10.75 million and had begun discussing a possible merger. EA Industries, based in West Long Branch, N.J., acquired 596,927 Aydin shares, for about $18 each. The chairman and chief executive of Aydin, Ayhan Hakimoglu, stepped down after the transaction and was replaced by I. Gary Bard, a director at Aydin. Aydin, based in Horsham, Pa., makes wireless and telecommunications equipment. It was unchanged at $15.50 a share.

headline: G.E. and United Technologies To Jointly Develop a 747 Engine
abstract: The General Electric Company and the United Technologies Corporation, rival engine makers, are cooperating to develop an engine for a new model of the Boeing 747.         Ownership of the as-yet-unnamed joint venture will be split 50-50 between G.E.'s Aircraft Engines division, which is based here, and United Technologies'  Pratt & Whitney division, based in East Hartford, Conn.

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ You'd think they were giving away free Chanel bags with every share of stock by  the way investors are snapping up shares in Loehmann's, the retailer. By Doreen  Hemlock.

headline: Wood Pulp Prices Off 40% Since Autumn
abstract: The prices of North American wood pulp have fallen 40 percent since last fall, one of the sharpest price reversals in the history of the industry, and consumers of many paper products, from tissues and paper towels to stationery and envelopes, are expected to find lower prices.         Surging inventories and slower growth in paper consumption worldwide are behind the price cuts, which have dropped the price of northern bleached softwood kraft pulp, a bellwether grade, from $985 a metric ton in November to $575 in mid-March, the lowest level since 1991. The decline, however, followed big increases over the last several years.

headline: Ford Contracts to ITT
abstract: ITT Industries' ITT Automotive subsidiary said today that the Ford Motor Company had awarded it two contracts totaling $650 million to produce brakes and other parts for a future vehicle. One contract calls for ITT to provide a completely assembled brake system package, including anti-lock brakes, front calipers, actuation, rear drum brakes and hoses. The second contract includes all brake, fuel and vapor lines as well as the fuel filler pipe for the new vehicle. The $650 million covers the life of the contracts, the company said in  a statement.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ALCOA OFFERS EARLY RETIREMENT INCENTIVES
abstract: The Aluminum Company of America has offered early retirement incentives to 3,600 employees, or 5 percent of its work force, in an attempt to cut costs. The incentives offered in letters this week included two weeks of pay for every year of service at the world's largest aluminum producer. Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh and has about 72,000 employees, is trying to cut $300 million from administrative and sales costs, which total $1.2 billion a year. Shares of Alcoa slipped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $57.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Gift Saves an Unusual Journal
abstract: Double Take magazine, a critically acclaimed new journal of literature, reporting and photojournalism, edited by Robert Coles, the Harvard child psychiatrist, and Alex Harris, a Duke University documentary photographer, has received a $10 million grant from the Lyndhurst Foundation of Chattanooga, Tenn.         The gift, one of the largest philanthropic contributions to an American publication, was made earlier this month and should insure the quarterly magazine's publication for at least another five years, said David S. Parker, its publisher. After its first year of publication, with four issues, the magazine lost $1.5 million and survived only with the help of a previous $2 million gift from the Lyndhurst Foundation, Mr. Parker said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
abstract: Brian Ribbey was named to the new position of senior vice president and integrated marketing group di rector at Cole & Webber in Seattle, a unit of the  WPP Group. He was pre viously general manager for the Mednick Group, Los Angeles.

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS;A Bear on Stocks Who's Outrunning the Bulls
abstract: ONE week, inflation fears grab the stock market by the throat. The next week, they all but dissipate.         Amid the jolts, stock investors keep scoring solid gains. But a select group  of investors, those most concerned about rising prices, have done extraordinarily well this year. They have flocked to precious metals, commodities and natural resources. Such assets, they say, represent the best opportunity because inflationary pressures are building in the economy.

headline: New Monetary Chief At European Group
abstract: European central bankers have picked the governor of the Dutch central bank to take over next year as the president of the European Monetary Institute, the  forerunner of an intended European central bank.         The Dutch central banker, Willem Duisenberg, 60, will succeed Alexandre Lamfalussy, who plans to retire in July 1997. The changes, announced on Tuesday, surprised the financial community.

headline: Wrigley Plant in Russia
abstract: The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company, the world's largest maker of chewing gum, said today that it expected to break ground next month on a $25 million factory in St. Petersburg, Russia. The plant, when completed, will make products to be sold in Russia and other countries in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

headline: Telekom Begins to Feel the Winds of Change
abstract: BERLIN—  It was hardly a ringing endorsement for Deutsche Telekom AG and its hopes for a static-free privatization later this year when the German parliament voted to drop its high-priced domestic telephone carrier in favor of a U.S. competitor known as Worldcom.

headline: SUMITOMO'S HUGE LOSS;In 1991, Agencies Were Told Of Letter on Sumitomo Trader
abstract: On Dec. 6, 1991, The Wall Street Journal reported in its commodities roundup  that regulatory officials had been informed of allegations regarding the trading practices of Yasuo Hamanaka, the Sumitomo Corporation's chief copper trader. Following is an excerpt from that report:         COPPER: Futures prices fell sharply on reports that a U.S. copper trader had  sent a letter to the London Metal Exchange and to the Commodity Exchange in New  York raising questions about Sumitomo Corp.'s powerful chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka. David L. Threlkeld, a U.S. metals trader based in Vermont, confirmed in an interview yesterday that he had sent the letter.

headline: The New Buzz: Growth Is Good;Latest Strategy for Business Is a Positive Spin on Layoffs
abstract: What a difference a few months make. When they agreed to merge this spring, Bell Atlantic and Nynex pointedly passed up an opportunity to announce the elimination of 3,000 "overlapped" jobs. New markets would open for the merged company, they insisted, saving the workers from layoffs. "We think we will create enough new jobs to redeploy most of those 3,000 people," said Ivan G. Seidenberg, Nynex's chairman.         The emphasis -- and even the buzzwords -- are shifting. The rhetorical trumpeting of layoffs, as if they were a badge of honor, is disappearing. The negative publicity that descended on AT&T after it announced in January that it  would eliminate 40,000 jobs was a turning point. Now, companies are choosing to  highlight the potential for new hires down the road. Announcements are increasingly in the style of Bell Atlantic and Nynex, with their focus on growth to save jobs, and only a footnote-like nod of acknowledgment that the 3,000 workers might be laid off if the growth fails to materialize.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Argyle Diamond Mine Leaving De Beers Cartel
abstract: The owners of the world's largest diamond-producing mine, the Argyle mine in  northwest Australia, have decided to pull out of the De Beers cartel. While a blow to De Beers, a unit of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, the  move is not likely to cripple the cartel. De Beers controls about 75 percent of  world diamond trade through the Central Selling Organization in London.          While Argyle, which is 56.8 percent owned by RTZ-CRA, and 38.2 percent by Ashton Mining Ltd., is the world's biggest diamond mine by volume, it produces a large quantity of small, low-value gems. These stones, which were fed to the Indian cutting market for jewelry production, made up 6 percent of total C.S.O.  sales in 1995.   (Bloomberg Business News)

headline: Treasury Prices Lose Early Gains
abstract: A report showing an unexpected decline in producer prices sent Treasury prices surging yesterday, but profit taking in the afternoon erased the gains.    Bond prices have been under pressure since Friday, when the May employment report showed surprising strength, suggesting that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates next month. In two sessions, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- which moves in the opposite direction from the bond's price -- rose to 7.12 percent -- its highest level in more than a year.

headline: Equity Offerings Planned for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible-debt offerings are expected this week:      Affymetrix Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., an initial public offering of five million shares. Robertson, Stephens & Co.

headline: I.B.M. and Apple Reported Near Licensing Agreement
abstract: I.B.M.'s chip-making division and Apple Computer Inc. are said to be close to concluding a licensing deal for Apple's Macintosh software operating system.         But while Apple's stock rose today on news of the talks, industry executives  said they did not expect -- as many investors apparently did -- that the agreement would lead to the manufacture of Macintosh clones by I.B.M. or any other major computer maker.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;DIANA SHARES RISE ON WORD OF INTERNET DEAL
abstract: The shares of the Diana Corporation rose by one-third yesterday after the company's Sattel Communications unit agreed to supply communications lines for Internet services to the Concentric Network Corporation for undisclosed terms. With the agreement, Diana became the latest stock investors have embraced amid the frenzy over the Internet. "Breathe the word 'Internet' around a stock and anything can happen," said Tom Pincince, senior analyst at Forrester Research. The shares rose $17.25, to $66, on the New York Stock Exchange before trading was halted. Sattel will supply high-speed communications lines and services to about 21 sites in the United States for Concentric Network, which is based in Cupertino, Calif.

headline: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Unlocking New Doors With Bonds
abstract: THE Treasury's adoption of "real," or inflation-indexed, bonds will provide an attractive alternative to conventional bonds for some investors, offering them precise inflation protection not currently available. The new bonds, the Treasury believes, will broaden the market for Government securities and eliminate the need to compensate investors for inflation risk.        In addition, the bonds now open the door for other governmental issuers.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS TO CUT JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: International Flavors and Fragrances Inc. said yesterday that it would close  three plants and dismiss 220 employees, resulting in a pretax charge of $50 million in the second quarter. The New York-based company also said earnings would be hurt by slower customer reorders for fragrances in Europe and the United States and price cuts forced by competition. The company said it would close factories in Union Beach, N.J.; Mexico City, and Rio de Janeiro. Most of the job cuts will occur at the New Jersey facility, which will cut 170 jobs. Shares of International Flavors fell $1.75, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Mario Is Looking Better With Age
abstract: At the Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles last month, Nintendo created an exhibit so extravagant that it could make Hollywood blush. In the lights-flashing, sound-blaring display the company presented its long-delayed video gaming box called Nintendo 64.          "Other titles shown at E3 paled in comparison to Super Mario 64," said Larry Marcus, a video game analyst for Alex. Brown & Sons, recalling the field of teen-agers jostling for a test run.

headline: Ecologists Criticize First Steps in Latin River Plan
abstract: Plans to begin blasting rock formations in the Paraguay-Parana rivers this June, a preliminary step in a proposed 2,000-mile water highway linking five South American countries, have prompted sharp criticism from environmentalists.  They say this violates pledges that the waterway's construction would depend on  the outcome of environmental studies.         The five-country consortium behind the Hydrovia project, a waterway that would run from Caceres, Brazil, to Punta del Este, Uruguay, says it is awaiting  results of a comprehensive environmental impact study, which is expected to be completed this year, before beginning work. The project calls for straightening  and dredging the rivers, controlling the flow of tributaries with dikes and removing rock formations to allow year-round shipping.

headline: How to Turn Around a Magazine for Walkers
abstract: Everyone loves a success story. Particularly the beleaguered magazine industry, where 7 out of 10 start-ups fail within a decade.         This story is about Jan Thaw Bruce, a woman with a tenacious belief in a foundering magazine devoted to walking. With the magazine in its death throes, Ms. Bruce, who was then its publisher, raised more than $1 million, acquired the publication from her boss and persuaded staff members to stay on without pay until the magazine could be repositioned and turned around.

headline: After Fighting Flares Again in Lebanon, Israel Shells Villages
abstract: Israel shelled civilian areas of southern Lebanon today for the first time since fighting between its forces and Hezbollah guerrillas ended three weeks ago.         Syria, the major power-broker in Lebanon, immediately accused Israel of violating the American-backed cease-fire agreement.

headline: Brandfort Journal;For Winnie's Apartheid Days, Why Not a Shrine?
abstract: Even in the middle of the afternoon on a weekday, Brandfort's dusty little main street is almost deserted.         Town Hall only opens for "occasions" -- mostly weddings. Even the liquor store owner says he does not make enough money to remodel his store, so the separate entrances for whites and blacks remain.

headline: Seeking Feng Shui Harmony
abstract: LOS ANGELES—  Before the Wells Fargo HSBC Trade Bank opened its El Monte branch last fall, the manager, Julius Ting, had the office inspected by an expert.

headline: No Change In U.S. Policy After Review Of Air Crash
abstract: The Air Force said today that it is reviewing "every procedure" that might have played a role in the crash of the military plane in Dubrovnik, Croatia, last week that was carrying Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown.

headline: Securities Regulation Bill Advances
abstract: A bill to overhaul regulation of Wall Street had an easy time on the House floor today, gaining broad bipartisan support.         After concluding a 40-minute debate, House leaders postponed a final vote on  the measure until Wednesday. The bill was considered on a calendar of uncontroversial items and its passage and advance to the Senate was widely expected.

headline: Syrian's Game: Both Ends Against the Middle
abstract: For five hours on April 22, Secretary of State Warren Christopher held intense discussions with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria at his presidential palace in Damascus to end the fighting between Israel and Muslim guerrillas in southern Lebanon.         While Mr. Christopher paid court, a few miles away at Damascus International  Airport an Iran Air 747 unloaded Katyusha rockets and other military equipment for delivery via Syrian military trucks for those guerrillas, American intelligence officials believe.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;NUTRITION FOR LIFE SHARES FALL ON S.E.C. INQUIRY
abstract: Nutrition For Life International said yesterday that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating the way the company distributes its wide range of health products. The company's stock fell $4, or 17 percent, to $19, in Nasdaq trading. The inquiry seems to be focused on the company's "executive-level distributor program," it said. The company develops health products like nutritional supplements and weight-management systems distributed through independent contractors. A distributor may become what the company calls an executive by generating sales volume of $1,000 to $1,500 through his organization. Executive status entitles a distributor to earn commissions on sales generated by other distributors in his organization.

headline: Times Co. to Pay $226 Million in TV Deal
abstract: two television station, saying that it would pay $226 million to buy KFOR-TV of  Oklahoma City and WHO-TV of Des Moines. The purchase of the stations, both NBC affiliates, was announced on Tuesday.         Because of the deal, the Times Company said it expected that earnings would drop by 1 to 2 cents a share this year.

headline: Norway Oil Strike Ending
abstract: Leaders of the Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers said today that they had decided to call off their offshore strike because of faltering support from strikers. The federation began the strike by 750 workers at nine installations last Saturday after about 400 service workers went on strike last month.

headline: Former Chief Executive Offers Apple Encouragement and Says OldStrategy Can Still Work
abstract: The financially troubled Apple Computer Inc. has received a vote of confidence from its former chairman, John Sculley, who argues in an article in the current issue of a Silicon Valley magazine that the "hot-product" marketing  strategy that made Apple the nation's leading personal computer maker in the late 1980's and early 1990's can still work.         Mr. Sculley's comments come at a time when Apple's new chairman and chief executive, Gilbert F. Amelio, is preparing to offer a new strategy for saving the company. Mr. Amelio will outline the strategy Monday at an annual Apple developers meeting to be held at the San Jose Convention Center.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;REPORT BY BAUSCH & LOMB COMMITTEE CLEARS EXECUTIVES
abstract: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that a special committee had found no evidence that any company executive participated in or knew about irregularities that required the company to restate its 1993 and 1994 financial results. The committee of independent directors was convened in October to review management  practices after Business Week published an article that said the Bausch & Lomb had shipped unsold products and faked invoices to inflate sales figures. The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether the Rochester-based  company inflated 1993 sales of contact lenses. The company's board said "appropriate steps" had been taken to strengthen control practices.

headline: Shares of Horizon/CMS Sliding After Multiple Blows
abstract: Just last winter, the Horizon/CMS Healthcare Corporation still had the glamorous look of a fast-growing nursing home company with an array of promising units.         The company had acquired three similar companies in two years and had announced a fourth merger deal. But disappointing earnings led to a chain of unpleasant disclosures, and Horizon/CMS shares lost more than half their value, falling 37.5 cents yesterday to close at $13 on the Big Board, down from  a 52-week high of $28.125 on Jan. 25.

headline: COMPANY REPORTS;AT&T Profit Is Up 14% For Quarter
abstract: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that profit from long-distance telephone  and wireless services climbed nearly 14 percent in the first quarter, to $1.4 billion, but that sales growth in its long-distance business was appreciably slower than that of its competitors, the Sprint Corporation and MCI Communications.         The results were roughly in line with analysts' expectations, who said they were respectable in view of AT&T's huge-scale spinoff of its communications-equipment and computer companies.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS SHARES RISE AFTER AGREEMENT WITH AT&T
abstract: The shares of the U.S. Robotics Corporation reached an all-time high yesterday, rising 6.3 percent after the AT&T Corporation selected U.S. Robotics  to make equipment that gives customers high-speed access to AT&T's data and Internet networks. No financial details were released. U.S. Robotics shares rose $10.50, to $177.25, on Nasdaq. AT&T stock rose 87.5 cents, to $60, on the New York Stock Exchange. Rakesh Sood, an analyst at Hambrecht & Quist, estimated the size of the contract at $500 million over the next two to three years.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;HA-LO INDUSTRIES TO GET TELEMARKETER IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Ha-Lo Industries said yesterday that it would acquire Market U.S.A., the telemarketer, for about $67 million in stock. Ha-Lo, which distributes advertising products such as hats and T-shirts to Fortune 500 companies, professional sports teams and other organizations, agreed to exchange about 2.5  million shares of its stock for the closely held company. Ha-Lo's shares rose 50 cents each, to $27.25, in Nasdaq trading. Market U.S.A., based in Des Plaines, Ill., reported revenue of $37 million in 1995 and projects 1996 revenue of $50 million. The company has 16 calling centers in the United States and Canada.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;ONE CALIFORNIA BANKING COMPANY TO BUY ANOTHER
abstract: Vallicorp Holdings Inc., a banking company based in Fresno, Calif., said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Sunrise Bancorp of Roseville, Calif., for cash and stock worth $20.6 million. Sunrise has assets of about $120 million and two branches. Vallicorp has 54 branches and $1.3 billion in assets. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Sunrise Bancorp  stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $3.75 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Vallicorp stock fell 12.5 cents, to $15.875.

headline: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Prices Drop as Traders See An Eventual U.N.-Iraq Accord
abstract: Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as traders bet that Iraq would eventually agree to a United Nations proposal allowing a limited sale of oil.         On other markets, wheat prices rose on continued expectations that an Agriculture Department report would show a greatly reduced winter crop.

headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever Profit Rises 3.4% in Quarter
abstract: Unilever N.V. said yesterday that its first-quarter profit rose 3.4 percent with help from soaring profits in North America, but the results were hurt by mad cow disease costs.  Unilever said a write-off in its British frozen beef business related to concerns over mad cow disease wiped out profit in Europe.          Unilever's net income for the quarter was 808 million guilders ($472.5 million), up from 783.0 million guilders a year ago. Sales totaled 19.44 billion guilders, up from 18.18 billion. In North America, operating profit rose more than 90 percent, to 258 million guilders ($150.9 million). North American food sales were helped by steps taken last year to reduce inventories.   (AP)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After slipping badly, Bates USA works to regain its footing.
abstract: AFTER a year of living difficultly that included the departures of longtime clients and top managers, Bates USA is striving to regain its footing with an ambitious series of steps from bolstering offices outside its New York headquarters to bettering creative output.         But the agency faces a struggle to overcome its setbacks as other large competitors forge ahead with strategic initiatives and acquisitions. For instance, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, which like Bates USA has suffered defections of accounts and executives, is expected to announce today the purchase of N. W. Ayer & Partners from Adcom Investors Inc.

headline: Domestic Sales Rose 4.3% For Auto Makers in March
abstract: Domestic sales of cars and light trucks rose a combined 4.3 percent last month, the final figures from the auto makers showed today, giving a strong start to the important spring selling season.         The industry's overall performance was bolstered by sharp gains by Toyota and Honda and came despite the dampening effects of a 17-day strike that squelched production at General Motors.

headline: World News Briefs;U.N. Report Said to Back U.S. on Cuban Downings
abstract: A United Nations investigation has concluded that Cuba's downing of two light civilian aircraft flown by Cuban-Americans occurred over international waters, a United States official said today.          Undersecretary of State Peter Tarnoff, in a briefing at the White House on a United Nations report that is yet to be issued, told reporters that the investigators had also found that the Cuban fighter pilots failed to issue proper warnings before shooting down the two unarmed planes in February.

headline: Doctor, a Torturer, Is Shot in Argentina
abstract: One of the most notorious military doctors of Argentina's brutal military dictatorship was shot 20 times on Friday in an attack outside his home in the Quilmes suburb.         The doctor, Jorge Berges, who was convicted of torture and trafficking in babies during the military's "dirty war" of repression against leftists in the 1970's, was shot by two young men. They escaped in a white van that was later found burned and abandoned, the Buenos Aires police said.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                                               Previous      Year                               Yesterday       Day       Ago
